    "pages": }\n'''Andrew Christopher Pruski''' (born November 11, 1978) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for  in . He was previously a member of the Anne Arundel County Council from 2014 to 2022, serving as its chair from 2018 to 2019 and its vice-chair from 2021 to 2022.\n\n\nPruski was born in , on November 11, 1978. He graduated from , earning his Bachelor of Arts in history in 2000 and his Master of Science in secondary education in 2001.\n\nShortly after graduating, Pruski became a social studies teacher at . In October 2003, he participated in a school employees protest at the  headquarters over stalled contract negotiations and persistent payroll errors. Although the school board reached a contract with the teachers' union in December, Pruski expressed discontent with the deal, saying \"There are a lot of issues on the table we need to discuss. It's not just the contract.\" Pruski later worked as an assessment supervisor for  from 2005 to 2014, and for Prince George's County Public Schools since 2014.\n\nPruski entered politics in 2006, running unsuccessfully for the  and losing to Jamie Benoit in the Democratic primary. In the same year, he was appointed to the Anne Arundel County Board of Appeals, where he served until 2009, when he was appointed to the Anne Arundel County Board of Education by Governor .\n\nIn August 2013, Pruski announced that he would again run for the Anne Arundel County Council in District 4. Pruski narrowly won the Democratic primary on June 24, 2014, edging out his opponent by 151 votes. Afterwards, Pruski resigned from the Anne Arundel County Board of Education, complying with a state law that prohibits candidates from appearing on a general election ballot for more than one paid position. Pruski won the general election on November 4, defeating Republican challenger Chike Anyanwu with 57.5 percent of the vote.\n\n\nPruski was sworn into the Anne Arundel County Council on December 1, 2014. He was re-elected in 2018, making him the only incumbent council member who was not term limited and was not defeated in the primary election. In December 2018, Pruski was unanimously elected to serve as the county council's chairman.\n\nIn September 2021, Pruski said he was considering a run for the , but said his decision depended on the legislative maps drawn by the General Assembly. He filed to run for delegate in , later being redrawn into District 33A, in December. He won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, receiving 52.2 percent of the vote. He won the general election on November 8, defeating Republican challenger Kim Mills.\n\n\n\nPruski was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Economic Matters Committee. Pruski was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\nPruski is married to his wife, Roxanne, who as of 2013 is an assistant at . Together, they have three children and live in .\n\n\n\nPruski supports the , a sweeping education reform bill passed by the legislature during the 2020 legislative session that would provide schools with $3.8 billion a year for 10 years, but thinks that teachers should be paid more apart from the raises outlined in the Blueprint.\n\nIn January 2010, Pruski voted against the expansion of charter middle schools through ninth grade.\n\nIn May 2019, Pruski said he supported county executive Steuart Pittman's first budget, which included $46 million in additional funding for education paid for through increased income and property taxes.\n\n\nIn March 2015, Pruski said he opposed a full repeal of , but supported finding ways to reduce the fees imposed by the tax. In April, he voted against bills that would repeal the stormwater fee in Anne Arundel County.\n\nIn October 2016, Pruski wrote to the  to ask legislators to support a bill that would ban  during the 2017 legislative session.\n\n\nIn January 2022, Pruski introduced a bill that requires gun store owners to install video surveillance, exterior bollards, and concrete barriers to prevent smash-and-grab style burglaries at gun stores. The bill passed and was signed into law by county executive Steuart Pittman on January 4, 2022.\n\n\nIn June 2019, Pruski introduced a bill that would give workforce housing a 50 percent discount on capital connection charges and expands the types of zones allowing that housing.\n\nIn June 2020, Pruski voted against a bill that would limit where assisted living facilities could be built in residential areas.\n\nIn July 2020, Pruski introduced a bill that would pause rent increases of 3 percent or more during the , until 120 days after the state's emergency declaration is lifted. The bill passed in a 4-3 vote.\n\n\nIn September 2015, Pruski introduced a bill that would limit where medical marijuana dispensaries could be built.\n\n\nIn July 2019, Pruski endorsed  in the .\n\nIn February 2021, Pruski voted for a resolution that condemned the  and called for the disqualification of President  from holding office again.\n\n\nIn September 2018, Pruski voted against a resolution introduced by councilmember  that would have recognized \"preborn\" children as human and deserving of humane treatment and protection. In July 2022, following the 's decisions in '''', Pruski voted for a resolution in the Anne Arundel County Council supporting a women's access to reproductive health care.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brenda Jeanette Thiam''' (born September 9, 1969) is an American politician who was a member of the  from  from 2020 to 2023. A member of the , she was the first African-American Republican woman to serve in the . In 2024, she unsuccessfully ran for the  in , losing to former state delegate  in the Republican primary election.\n\n\nBrenda Jeanette Thiam was born and raised in  on September 9, 1969. She was one of four children and was raised in a single-mother family after her father, a radio personality, filed for divorce and moved to .\n\nThiam graduated from  in 1987, and later attended  in 1994, earning a  degree in physical education. She later attended the , earning a  degree in 2002; , where she earned a  degree in special-education leadership in 2015; and , where she earned a  in applied behavior management in 2017.\n\n\n\nAfter graduating from North Carolina Central University, Thiam worked as a special-education teacher for  and for various nonprofits until 2019, While working for the , she secured a $100,000 grant to support the ongoing education of teachers for students with intellectual disabilities. Thiam lost her job just before the start of the , after which she started her own nonprofit, Oasis Community Support Services Inc., to support the needs of adults with autism.\n\nThiam first got involved in politics as a member of student government in school. She was a registered  until 2012, when she switched to the . From 2016 to 2018, she served as the vice president of the Washington County Republican Club. In 2016, she applied to fill a vacancy on the Washington County Board of Commissioners, which was filled by Wayne Keefer, a small-business owner. In 2020, Thiam successfully ran for the  City Council, placing sixth in the nonpartisan primary. Thiam later withdrew from the race after being appointed to the Maryland House of Delegates, but she remained on the ballot for the general election.\n\n\nIn September 2020, following the appointment of  to the , Thiam applied to fill the vacancy left by his resignation in the Maryland House of Delegates. The Washington County Republican Central Committee nominated Thiam to fill the vacancy later that month, and she was appointed to the seat by Governor  on September 23, 2020.\n\nThiam was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on October 6, 2020, where she served on the House Judiciary Committee and was a member of the . She was the first black Republican woman to serve in the  and the first black Republican to serve in the legislature in the nearly three decades since  died in office in 1991. In 2022, Thiam was appointed deputy minority whip.\n\nThiam ran for election in , seeking a full term in the Maryland House of Delegates. She won the Republican primary election on July 19, 2022, but was defeated by Democratic challenger  in the general election on November 8. Following her defeat, Thiam called on the Republican Party to \"embrace\" mail-in voting if it hoped to win future elections.\n\n\n\n\nOn June 20, 2023, Thiam filed to run for Congress in  in  to succeed . She announced her candidacy on July 25, 2023. During the Republican primary, she ran on a platform including tackling the  and requiring recipients of  to undergo additional assessments to determine whether they're still eligible to continue receiving benefits. Thiam was defeated in the Republican primary election by former state delegate  on May 14, 2024, placing second-to-last with 3.3 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nDuring her run for Hagerstown city council, Thiam said she supported addressing the  and improving the city's , and opposed raising taxes. Upon being appointed to the Maryland House of Delegates, she said that her legislative priorities included the opioid epidemic and the , which she opposed. She also described herself as \"\", expressing interest in working with legislators to promote family planning options other than abortions, and said she opposed the \"\" movement. Thiam supported the reelection campaign of President  in the .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Thiam introduced a bill that would require students to pass a civics test before they could graduate from high school, as well as the \"Learning at Home Relief Act\", which would provide a $250 per child  toward costs associated with online school, such as child care and internet services. Both bills failed to move out of committee. She also voted for the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, which repealed the , and against the Plastic Bag Reduction Act, a bill to ban the sale of plastic bags and to require stores to charge a minimum of 10 cents for paper bags. In February 2021, during debate on a bill to extend the  to immigrants, Thiam introduced an amendment that required that benefits only go to \"taxpayers of lawful status in the United States\". The amendment was rejected by a 48-91 vote.\n\nIn October 2021, Thiam was one of five Maryland state legislators from Garrett, Allegany and Washington counties who sent a pair of letters to West Virginia officials asking about annexation of  to West Virginia. The letters were later withdrawn by their authors, House Minority Leader  and state senator , following criticism from local officials and some constituents.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Thiam introduced a bill to allow municipalities to establish Police Accountability Boards and another to prohibit dirt bike drivers from committing motor vehicle offenses; both bills died in committee. She also expressed concerns with proposals to legalize , questioning whether black Marylanders would be able to make money from the recreational market. In March 2022, during debate on a bill creating a statewide ballot referendum on codifying the right to abortion access, Thiam introduced an amendment requiring the  to collect data regarding abortions performed in the state, including gestational age and number of abortions performed. The amendment was rejected by the Maryland House of Delegates by a 39-83 vote.\n\nIn January 2022, Thiam filed a lawsuit against the legislative district maps drawn by the  during the , seeking to replace the newly passed map with one that uses only s. The  ruled 4-3 against the plaintiffs in April 2022, upholding the legislature's map.\n\nIn April 2022, following a spike in gas prices as the result of the , Thiam supported Maryland's brief , which she later made efforts to extend by an additional 45 days. She also introduced legislation to decouple the state's gas tax from inflation, which failed to pass out of committee.\n\nIn July 2022, Thiam said that she supported s, , and increased purging of .\n\nIn 2023, Thiam testified in support of a bill to allow municipalities to enforce laws against driving dirt bikes on public roads.\n\nDuring her 2024 congressional campaign, Thiam said that she supported restarting construction on the  and opposed  and  imposed during the . She also said that she disagreed with Judge 's ruling against requiring the  system to provide parents with the ability to opt their students out of classroom instruction on LGBTQ topics, and opposed removing  from the  ballot under the , saying that she did not believe that the  was an insurrection. Thiam also expressed support for abolishing the .\n\nIn October 2023, amid the  and subsequent , Thiam expressed support for  and its right to defend itself, as well as the expansion of the  and humanitarian efforts in ; however, she later said that she opposed giving foreign aid to any country without first addressing domestic issues and implementing limits on how much aid could be given and for how long. Thiam also opposed calls for a ceasefire in the war, saying that it would allow Hamas to retreat and restrategize for another, deadlier attack on Israel.\n\n\nThiam is married to her husband, Mam Malick Thiam, who migrated to the United States from  in 2000 and unsuccessfully ran for Washington County Treasurer in 2022. Thiam moved to  in 1995. Together, they moved to Hagerstown in October 2006, and have a daughter.\n\nIn July 2022, Thiam and her daughter were involved in a car crash in Hagerstown. Both were transported to Meritus Medical Center with minor injuries, and were released later that day.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Deni Taveras''' (born December 13, 1972) is a  politician who is a member of the  for  in . She was previously a member of the , representing District 2 from 2014 to 2022.\n\n\nTaveras was born in  in December 13, 1972. When Taveras was only four years old, her mother, Filomena Garcia, committed suicide. She moved between family members in New York and the Dominican Republic before settling with her father, Bienvenido Taveras. Taveras' father was killed while he was driving his taxi cab when she was eight years old. After this, she was placed under the care of her maternal grandmother in the neighborhood of .\n\nTaveras attended , where she earned a B.A. in chemistry in 1995, the , where she earned a M.S. in chemistry in 1998, and the  at , where she earned a M.P.A. degree in public affairs and urban regional planning in 2003.\n\nTaveras moved to Maryland after receiving a job offer from the Dominican American National Roundtable in  Taveras became unemployed when the  hit. At the same time, the condominium complex she lived in was going bankrupt, and Taveras assumed leadership of the condo association.\n\n\nAfter earning her master's degree, Taveras worked for the . Her concern for environmental issues prompted her to lead efforts to ban both fracking and styrofoam in her county. She became involved with Dominicans 2000, a group of Dominicans seeking to make community change through political action.\n\nFrom 2011 to 2013, Taveras worked as the chief of staff for state senator .\n\nTaveras made her first run for public office in 2014 for the Prince George's County Council in District 2, seeking to succeed councilmember , who ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 47B. During her primary campaign, Taveras sought to win over Hispanic voters and received endorsements from Campos, County Executive , and state delegate . She won the Democratic primary in June 2014, edging out state delegate  by six votes. After the ballots were counted, Neimann requested a recount but it did not change the vote difference. Taveras was unopposed in the general election.\n\n\n\nTaveras was sworn into the Prince George's County Council on December 1, 2014, making her the first Latina elected to the council. She was re-elected in 2018 after narrowly winning the Democratic primary against Hyattsville mayor Candace Hollingsworth. In December 2020, the council voted to elect Taveras to serve as its vice chair.\n\nIn September 2021, Taveras, termed out of running for a third term on the Prince George's County Council, announced that she would for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 47B in 2022. She won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, receiving 52.6 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary election.\n\n\nTaveras was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. She is a member of the House Health and Government Operations Committee.\n\n\n\nIn October 2018, Taveras voted against overriding County Executive Rushern Baker's veto on a bill that would waive a school facilities surcharge for certain residential developers.\n\n\nIn 2016, Taveras introduced legislation that would hold landlords and property managers accountable for sex trafficking at their rental properties. The bill passed the county council unanimously and was signed into law by County Executive Baker.\n\nIn September 2020, Taveras introduced the \"Fair Housing Act\", a bill to strengthen the county's code enforcement to improve the quality of housing.\n\n\nIn 2019, Taveras voted in favor of legislation that would block all county agencies from engaging in immigration enforcement.\n\n\nIn 2019, Taveras introduced legislation that would require all police officers to wear body cameras. Following the killing of William Green, a handicuffed man, by police officer Michael Owen Jr. in January 2020, Taveras reintroduced the bill.\n\n\nIn 2015, Taveras was one of two county councilmembers to vote in favor of a proposal to provide  to workers in Prince George's County.\n\nIn 2018, Taveras voted in favor of legislation that would establish a public financing program for local candidates by 2026.\n\n\nTaveras endorsed  for president on November 17, 2015.\n\nIn 2021, Taveras endorsed state delegate  for . She initially endorsed former Prince George's County Executive Rushern Baker for , but later endorsed author and former nonprofit CEO  after Baker suspended his campaign.\n\n\nTaveras expressed concern over the construction of the  in her district, saying \"I don't want to lose the vibrancy and the diversity that we currently have in our community. That is what makes us who we are in Langley Park and gives us the rich vibrancy that we have.\" Despite her concerns, she acknowledged that this displacement was inevitable in the long run, even with all the potential benefits of the Purple Line. She also expressed skepticism over a plan to add toll lanes to the  and  using public-private partnerships.\n\n\nTaveras lives in .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n| date      = July 12, 2022\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John Robinson Leopold''' (born February 4, 1943) is an American politician who served in the state legislatures of Hawaii and Maryland and later as a county executive as a . He was convicted of a common law misdemeanor-misconduct in office and served a 30-day sentence in county jail and received a fine. He resigned on February 1, 2013, and was succeeded by Laura Neuman, after a vote by the Anne Arundel County Council.\n\n\n\nJohn Robinson Leopold was born on February 4, 1943, in , . In 1964 he graduated from  with a Bachelor's degree in English. Before moving to , Leopold was the first Republican elected to the Board of Education in Hawaii, where he served two years. He was also the State Director for  while in Hawaii.\n\nOn June 29, 1967, he was elected as Republican chairman of the 16th Representative District. In 1970 he was elected to the  and was reelected in 1972.\n\nOn January 10, 1977, Leopold was appointed by President Gerald Ford to the National Title I Advisory Committee for the Education of Disadvantaged Children. On February 25, 1991, Leopold was appointed by President George Bush to the National Council on Disability and confirmed by the United States Senate.\n\nLeopold was elected  Executive on December 4, 2006, after serving 20 years in the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\n\nOn March 2, 2012, Leopold was indicted on multiple counts of misconduct in office for using his county-provided police security to investigate political opponents, to remove campaign signs, and to transport him to public places to engage in sexual liaisons with women.\n\nOn March 7, 2012, David Holway, President of the International Brotherhood of Police Officers held a press conference in  to demand the immediate resignation of Leopold and the Chief of Police, James Teare.\n\nOn January 29, 2013, Leopold was suspended from office after being found guilty on two counts of misconduct in office. He was subsequently sentenced to a $100,000 fine and two years in jail, with all jail time suspended except 30 days in jail and 30 days under house arrest. He voluntarily resigned from the office of the County Executive.\n\nIn April 2019, Anne Arundel County Circuit Court denied Leopold's request to vacate his criminal conviction. Leopold based the request on the grounds that his defense attorneys represented him ineffectively, which the judge disputed in her ruling.\n\n\nIn 2018 Leopold ran for a seat in the House of Delegates in District 31B, a two-delegate district which includes the area he previously served as a delegate. In the June 2018 Republican primary, Leopold placed third with 10% of the vote, behind Brian Chisholm (39%) and incumbent Del.  (43%), both of whom went on to the November 2018 general election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Terry Lee Baker''' (born November 24, 1955) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for  in  and  counties. He was previously the vice president of the Washington County Board of Commissioners from 2006 to 2010 and from 2018 to 2022, and the board's president from 2010 to 2018.\n\n\nBaker was born on November 24, 1955. He grew up in , and graduated from . He attended , where he earned an A.A. degree in 1975, and , where he earned a B.S. degree in education in 1978.\n\nAfter graduating, he worked as a carpentry coordinator at . Baker also coached  and  at a local high school until he was elected county commissioner in 2006. He retired from  in July 2015. Baker continues to operate his own home improvements contracting business.\n\nBaker entered politics in 2002, when he became a member of the  town council. In 2004, he became the town's assistant mayor. Since 2006, he has worked in various county government offices, including in the Board of Health, Economic Development Commission, and Social Services Board.\n\nOn December 6, 2010, Baker was sworn in as the vice president of the Washington County Board of Commissioners, later serving as the board's president from 2010 to 2018 and becoming the vice president after the end of his presidency.\n\nOn July 14, 2021, Baker filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 1C, seeking to succeed Delegate , who had previously announced that he would run for the  in 2022. He won the Republican primary on July 19, 2022, and later defeated  challenger Carrie R. Hinton and  challenger Charlotte McBraerty in the general election on November 8.\n\n\n\nOn July 12, 2015, Baker announced that he would run for the  in , challenging incumbent . Baker finished second to Amie Hoeber, a former  deputy under President , in the Republican primary election, receiving 23.1 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nBaker was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\n\nBaker is married and has two children and three grandchildren. He owns two homes, including one in Clear Spring, Maryland, and another in .\n\nBaker is an accomplished distance runner, placing seventh at the 1982 .\n\nOn July 25, 2018, Baker's wife, Katrina, filed for a temporary protective order against him, accusing him of \"slapping, shoving, stalking and verbally abusing her over two separate incidents at the couple's homes\" in July. She was granted a temporary protective order, but she withdrew her petition on July 26 after she and her husband negotiated a separation agreement.\n\n\n\nBaker opposed the , saying that they \"should be a decision made by parents and teachers, if they want it in their schools or not.\"\n\n\nIn March 2018, Baker expressed concerns over a pipeline project proposed by  that would stretch from southern Pennsylvania through Maryland to another planned pipeline in West Virginia.\n\n\nIn September 2015, Baker said he opposed the .\n\n\nBaker self-identifies as . During the 2023 legislative session, he opposed a bill creating a  to codify '''' into the .\n\n\nIn June 2019, Baker voted against increasing Washington County's income tax rate from 2.8 percent to 3.2 percent so the county could receive a larger disparity grant, expressing concerns that the grants were not guaranteed in the long run. In April 2021, Baker voted in favor of lowering the tax rate back to 2.8 percent.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Margaret L. \"Maggie\" McIntosh''' (born December 22, 1947) is an  from the state of . She was a member of the  from 1993 to 2023. She is a former Baltimore City Public School teacher who now chairs one of the six standing committees of the Maryland House of Delegates. A , she represented the state's  in . Following her retirement from the Maryland House of Delegates in 2023, McIntosh has worked as a senior consultant at the Cornerstone Government Affairs lobbying group.\n\n\nMcIntosh received her Bachelor's Degree in arts education from  in 1970 and her Master of Science degree from the  in 1987. An educator, she taught art in the Baltimore City Public Schools from 1972–78, before becoming an adjunct instructor of continuing education at Catonsville Community College (now known as the  campus of the ).\n\nShe would later spend nine years working for the City of Baltimore at the Commission on Aging and Retirement Education, serving from 1985 to 1988 as the Director of Pre-Retirement Education. During that time, she was heavily involved in Democratic campaigns, including those of  and .  She was elected as a delegate to both the  and , the latter as a delegate pledged to .\n\n\nMaggie McIntosh was appointed to fill a vacancy in the House of Delegates in November 1992, when Delegate Anne Perkins accepted a teaching position in China. Two years later she was elected to a full term representing the 42nd District of Baltimore City and parts of Baltimore County. She has been re-elected in 1998, 2002, 2006 and 2010, but had to run in a substantially different district after the post-2000 round of ;  the , which she now represents, contains only 10% of the voters from her previous district, the 42nd. Nevertheless, in 2002, she placed first in a Democratic primary election in her new district which included five serving or former delegates vying for three seats. Since then, she has been re-elected each term, most recently in the 2018 election to serve another four years.\n\n\nIn the House of Delegates, McIntosh first served on the Appropriations Committee. She chaired the Subcommittee on Personnel and was a member of the Education and Economic Development and Capitol Subcommittees. In 1998, McIntosh assumed the position of Vice Chairman of the Commerce and Government Matters Committee. In 2001, she was named House Majority Leader after a previous stint as Deputy Majority Whip (1995–98), and became the first woman in Maryland history to serve as majority leader. In January 2003, McIntosh was named chairman of the House Environmental Matters Committee, which handles legislation regarding not just the environment, natural resources, and agriculture, but also transportation, housing, and local government. In January 2015, McIntosh was appointed to chair the House Appropriations Committee, the first woman in the history of Maryland to do so, overseeing the state operating and capital budgets, supplementary appropriations bills, state and county bond authorizations, higher education institutions, state and local agency procedures and programs, collective bargaining, social services, and state personnel and pension matters.\n presenting McIntosh with a governor's citation, 2022]]\nIn November 2021, McIntosh announced that she would retire from the House of Delegates at the end of her term in 2022. On April 1, 2022, Governor  issued a Governor's Citation to McIntosh, and signed a bill into law creating the Maggie McIntosh School Arts Fund, which invests $250,000 a year into arts projects in Baltimore City public schools.\n\n\n\n* Voted 2nd (after Speaker ) in ''The Maryland Gazette of Politics and Business's'' list of most influential Maryland state delegates for 2010\n* Inducted into 's Circle of Excellence after being named to Top 100 Women in Maryland list in 1998, 2000, and 2010\n* Elected Vice-Chair of The Chesapeake Bay Commission (2012–present)\n* Sponsor of 2012 Bottle Deposit bill\n* Co-Sponsor of Death Penalty Repeal legislation\n* Co-sponsor of Marriage Equality legislation\n* Lead Sponsor, Chesapeake Conservation Corp Program\n* Lead Sponsor, Ground Rent Registration and Reform\n*Co-sponsored HB 860 (Baltimore City Public Schools Construction and Revitalization Act of 2013). Signed by the Governor on May 16, 2013, the new law approved 1.1 billion dollars to construct new schools in Baltimore City.\n\n\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 43rd District''' Retrieved on November 20, 2014\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 43rd District''' Retrieved on Jan. 11, 2012\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 43rd District'''; retrieved March 3, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 43rd District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42'''; retrieved November 6, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\nDelegate McIntosh is the first woman to chair the powerful Appropriations Committee in Maryland's House of Delegates, after being the first woman to be appointed majority leader in the House of Delegates and the first openly gay elected member of the Maryland General Assembly in March 2003.  McIntosh is also the first woman to serve as the chairman of the Environmental Matters Committee where she has steered several major legislative initiatives to passage. The  Restoration Act, which funded upgrades at wastewater treatment plants around the state, is among McIntosh's accomplishments, as well as an annexation measure passed in 2006 in which she brought counties and municipalities together.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John G. Trueschler''' (born September 13, 1957), was a member of the , District 42.\n\n\nIn the 2002 election, Trueschler won his first election.  He won a seat in District 42, which covers portions of .  He served in this district along with fellow Republicans  and .  In the general election, they defeated Democratic challengers , who was an incumbent, Matthew Joseph, and .  The prior Delegates from District 42 were in different districts after the lines were redrawn.  Incumbent Democrat  moved to District 41 and  moved to District 43.\n\nIn 2006, Trueschler decided to retire rather than run for reelection.  Democrat  was elected to replace him, one of several seats that the Republicans lost in the 2006 election in the House of Delegates.\n\n\nTrueschler was born and raised in the northern Baltimore area.  He attended Hampton Elementary School, Towsontown Junior High School, and .  After high school he went to  where he graduated in 1979 with his B.S. in landscape architecture, . Trueschler returned to college to get his J.D. from the , where he graduated with honors in 1991.\n\n\nAfter graduating from West Virginia, Trueschler was a licensed landscape architect.  After law school, he was admitted to Maryland Bar in 1991.  He is a founding member of the North Central Republican Club and served as vice-president from 1990 until 1991.  He is an active member of the  and is a committee member of the Dulaney District.  Finally, he is on the Soccer Board for the Lutherville-Timonium Recreation Council.\n\nWhile in the , Trueschler was a member of the Economic Matters Committee, and several subcommittees including the business regulation subcommittee, the unemployment insurance subcommittee, the alcoholic beverages work group, and the corporations work group.\n\nHe was a member of the Medical Malpractice Insurance Work Group, the Maryland Veterans Caucus, and the National Conference of State Legislatures.\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42''' Retrieved on Oct. 1, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|birth_place        = , , U.S.\n|death_date         = \n|death_place        = \n|party              = \n|spouse             = Margaret Presley\n|children           = 3\n|education          =  () () ()\n|website            = \n}}\n'''Dana Max Stein''' (born September 19, 1958) is an American politician who has served as a member of the , representing  in , since 2007. A member of the , he has served as the  of the Maryland House of Delegates since 2024.\n\n\nStein was born in  and attended , later graduating from . He later attended , where he earned a B.A. degree in government, the Woodrow Wilson School of Public Affairs at , where he earned a  degree, and , where he earned a  degree in 1985.\n\nAfter graduating, Stein worked as an attorney for the -based law firm  until 1992, when he founded Grassroots Recycling, a local recycling group. Later that year, he and eventual   founded Civic Works, a nonprofit organization that supported Baltimore-based urban service projects, including the restoration of the .\n\nStein first became involved in politics in 1994, when he unsuccessfully ran for the Baltimore County Council in District 2, challenging incumbent councilmember . In 1996, he became the president of the Baltimore County Central Committee. Stein was later the committee's treasurer from 1996 to 2002 and its chair from 2001 to 2002.\n\n\n\nIn May 2002, following Governor 's appointment of state delegate Michael Finifter to the Baltimore County Circuit Court, he applied to serve the remainder of Finifter's term in the Maryland House of Delegates. The Baltimore County Central Committee voted to nominate Stein in June, and he was appointed by Glendening and sworn in on June 25, 2002. Stein ran for a full term in the 2002 Maryland House of Delegates election, in which he was defeated in the Democratic primary by .\n\nIn 2006, Stein ran for the Maryland House of Delegates, seeking to succeed state delegate , who ran for the . He won the general election on November 8, and was sworn in on January 10, 2007. In 2022, Stein was redrawn into District 11B, in which he ran for re-election.\n\nStein was the deputy majority whip from 2011 to 2015. In May 2023, the house speaker, , nominated Stein to be speaker ''pro tempore'' of the Maryland House of Delegates, succeeding .\n\n\n\n* Vice-Chair, Environment and Transportation Committee, 2015–present (local government & bi-county agencies subcommittee, 2015–2018; motor vehicle & transportation subcommittee, 2015–2019; chair, natural resources, agriculture & open space subcommittee, 2015–2019, member, 2020–present; chair, environment subcommittee, 2020–present)\n* Joint Subcommittee on Program Open Space and Agricultural Land Preservation, 2011–present\n* Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2015–present\n* House Chair, Joint Committee on the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area, 2015–present\n* Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, 2022–present\n* Ways and Means Committee, 2002–2003 (finance resources subcommittee, 2002–2003)\n* Environmental Matters Committee, 2007–2015 (ground rent work group, 2007; local government & bi-county subcommittee, 2007–2009; land use & ethics subcommittee, 2007–2010; motor vehicles & transportation subcommittee, 2007–2015; environment subcommittee, 2008–2012; housing & real property subcommittee, 2013–15)\n\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Stein introduced legislation to ban the use of , a harmful pesticide used on food crops. The bill was watered down to a bill to study banning the pesticide amid concerns over a possible  invasion. He reintroduced the chlorpyrifos ban in 2020, during which it passed, but was vetoed by Governor Hogan.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Stein introduced legislation to prohibit  in residential areas. The bills were voted down in committee.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Stein introduced legislation that would enforce the  on all commercial buildings taller than three stories. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, after Governor  revoked a  rule to regulate  emissions in the state, Stein introduced a bill to codify the regulations into law.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Stein introduced a bill to require the  and  to develop a plan to address the impact of  on state and local projects by July 2019. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan. In 2019, he introduced legislation to push back the deadline to October 2020, and required all jurisdictions that regularly flood during high tide to come up with sea level rise plans, which passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan. During the 2022 legislative session, Stein introduced legislation that would assign \" scores\" to permits issued by the .\n\nAlso in 2018, Stein introduced legislation that would prohibit Maryland from withdrawing from the  without the legislature's approval.\n\nIn 2021, Stein introduced the , a sweeping environment reform bill that would increase the state's goal of cutting carbon emissions from a 40 percent reduction from its 2006 levels to a 60 percent cut by 2030. The bill failed to pass after negotiations between the House and  broke down in the final weeks of the legislative session. Stein reintroduced the bill during the 2022 legislative session, during which it passed and became law without Governor Hogan's signature.\n\nIn September 2022, Stein co-signed a letter to U.S. Energy Secretary  in support of a proposal rule that would increase the efficiency level of gas furnaces to 95% Annual Fuel Utilization Efficiency.\n\nIn January 2023, Stein testified in support of the Bring Your Own Bag Act in Baltimore County, which would ban grocery stores from using plastic bags.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Stein introduced \"Jaelynn's Law\", which would require guns to be safely stored and inaccessible for children below the age of 18. The bill was named for 16-year-old Jaelynn Willey, who was fatally shot in 2018 by a boy who had his father's .\n\n\nDuring his 2006 House of Delegates campaign, Stein said he supported .\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Stein introduced the Maryland Driver Privacy Act, which would prohibit federal agencies from accessing state databases unless it had a  and blocked the state from providing agencies with photos of individuals for immigration investigations. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor Larry Hogan. The Maryland General Assembly overrode Hogan's veto during the special legislative session later that year.\n\n\nAs executive director of Civic Works, Stein supported the passage of  of 1993, which created and provided funding for .\n\nDuring his 2006 House of Delegates campaign, Stein said he supported legislation to encourage competition in the energy industry.\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Stein introduced legislation that would require the  to compile a list of people convicted of animal abuse or neglect.\n\nIn 2013, Stein introduced legislation that would require girls lacrosse players to wear protective headgear.\n\nIn July 2020, Stein cosigned a letter calling on Governor Larry Hogan to extend the state's  eviction moratorium, which was set to expire at the end of the month, until January 2021.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Stein introduced legislation that would ban \"\" by requiring that the state's Electoral College members cast their votes for the candidate who won the majority of the vote.\n\n\nIn 2011, Stein introduced legislation to eliminate the state's tax break for  sales.\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Stein introduced the Taxpayer Protection Act, which gave the 's investigators the ability to enforce income tax fraud cases involving tobacco and motor fuel. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan in May 2017.\n\n\nStein is married to his wife, Margaret Presley-Stein. Together, they have three children and live in .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''April Fleming Miller''' (born October 5, 1970) is an American politician who is a member of the  for  in . She was previously an at-large member of the Frederick County Board of Education from 2010 to 2018.\n\n\nMiller graduated from  in 1988. She later attended the , where she earned a  degree in biology/psychology in 1992, and the , where she earned her  of Optometry in 1996. Miller is an optometrist at Evich and Nathan Optometry and Optical Center in .\n\nMiller served on the Frederick County Board of Education from 2010 to 2018, and was elected its vice president in 2017. She was defeated in the 2018 general election after serving two terms on the board. In January 2020, Governor  appointed Miller to a five-year term on the  Board of Trustees, succeeding former board chair Debra Borden.\n\nIn 2022, Miller was one of four Republicans to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 4. She won the Republican primary, coming in second place behind incumbent state Delegate  with 25.8 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nMiller was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. She is a member of the House Ways and Means Committee.\n\n\nMiller identifies as a \"common-sense conservative\".\n\n\nIn October 2021, Miller said she opposed COVID-19  for students.\n\n\nMiller does not support the , a sweeping education reform bill passed in 2021, saying that she would like the  to pause its implementation as schools recovered from the .\n\nIn 2011, Miller expressed sympathy with a parent complaint that the textbook ''Social Studies Alive! Our Community and Beyond'' was politically tilted, saying \"I think it disrespects our country, because it doesn't say a lot positive about it, and I think that's detrimental to unity.\" In 2012, Miller objected to allowing 's '''' to be available in high schools, saying that while she did not want to ban books, she thought the school board should be more involved in evaluating books used in schools.\n\nIn February 2015, Miller testified in support of a bill requiring parents to provide consent before schools could survey students about their drug use or sexual activity.\n\nIn April 2016, Miller introduced a policy that required refusals by students or parents to take federally and state-mandated tests to be \"honored without question\".\n\nIn June 2017, Miller voted against a contract with the Frederick County Teachers Association, opposing the contract's four-year salary scale transition plan by saying that it did not benefit students and their families.\n\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Miller introduced a bill that would require abortion care providers to notify law enforcement if they suspect a patient is a victim of , and would make not doing so a misdemeanor offense.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Roy C. McGrath''' (August 9, 1969 – April 3, 2023) was an American  who served as the director of the Maryland Environmental Service (MES) from 2016 to 2020, and as the chief of staff to Governor  from June to August 2020.\n\nMcGrath resigned as chief of staff after '''' reported that he had received a $233,647 severance payment after leaving the MES, which led federal and state prosecutors to open an investigation into McGrath's severance payments. In October 2021, he was indicted on charges including , theft in programs receiving federal funds, and . A three week long manhunt ensued after he did not appear for court, which led to a police chase in  in which McGrath was shot and killed by both himself and law enforcement at the same time.\n\n\nMcGrath was born on August 9, 1969, in Greece, to father Howard McGrath, an attorney, and his wife Polyxene. There is some ambiguity about McGrath's legal name.  He is identified as \"Roy Carlos McGrath\" in his marriage license. In the federal and state indictments against him, he is simply referred to as \"Roy C. McGrath\".  According to the FBI's wanted poster for McGrath, he may have used seven different names:  Roy Carlos McGrath, Roy Charles McGrath, Roy Baisliadou, RC Baisliadou, Roy Mak-Grath, and RC McGrath.\n\nMcGrath grew up in Maryland, attending the Leonard Hall Junior Naval Academy and graduating from  in 1987. He later attended the , where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in government and politics, and economics in 1993. After graduating, McGrath spent 18 years at the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, a trade group based in northern , where he worked in various capacities including vice president of business development.\n\nMcGrath first got involved with politics at 18, becoming a member of the  and later forming a  club in Southern Maryland. In 1991, he served as a congressional intern and assistant to U.S. Representative . In 1992, as the chair of the  Republican Central Committee, he chaired campaign activities for  in the county and later served as an alternate delegate to the , pledged to Bush, and worked on 's unsuccessful congressional campaign in . McGrath later worked on Hogan's  in 2014, serving as the director of the group \"Lawyers for Hogan\" and overseeing early voting and Election Day operations.\n\n\nMcGrath served as a member of Governor-elect 's transition team. He later joined the Hogan administration as a senior advisor and liaison to the  on January 21, 2015. He left this position on July 1, 2015, to become one of Hogan's deputy chiefs of staff.\n\n, 2017]]\nIn December 2016, Governor Hogan appointed McGrath as the Executive Director of the Maryland Environmental Service, (MES) where he described himself as the CEO. While director of the MES, McGrath used state funds on personal expenses, including a $50,935 , $63,000 on remodeling and furniture, and $50,000 on trips to , Miami, Israel, and . He also received employee incentive payments of $117,932 between September 2017 and September 2019. According to legislative investigators, McGrath also personally hired \"loyal colleagues\" to key positions in the agency who were persuaded to donate to Hogan's campaign, even though they did not live in Maryland.\n\nDuring the , McGrath was named by Hogan to the state's Coronavirus Response Team. In this capacity, he spearheaded efforts with , a confidential project that saw the state purchase 500,000  from  for $10 million. According to prosecutors, McGrath began secretly recording meetings with other government officials on his iPhone around this time, which violated Maryland's  laws. It was McGrath's efforts related to the COVID-19 tests that led Governor Hogan to appoint McGrath as his new chief of staff following the resignation of Matthew A. Clark on May 26, 2020.\n\n\nIn August 2020, the '''' reported that McGrath received a $233,647  that included a year's salary after voluntarily leaving the Maryland Environmental Service, which was approved by the agency's board of directors in a private online meeting on May 28. According to federal prosecutors and investigators, McGrath attempted to delete any mention of the compensation from public minutes following the vote. McGrath defended his severance package, writing in an op-ed for ''The Sun'' that he was entitled to a corporate-style  because MES operates \"not much different from a private-sector entity.\" He resigned as chief of staff on August 17, 2020, four days after the story's publication. According to an affidavit obtained by the media, Hogan was first made aware of the payout on August 2, 2020, after MES board member Joseph F. Snee Jr. told Hogan's chief counsel, Michael Pedone, about the payout. After Hogan learned about the payout, McGrath was called to Hogan's office to discuss the matter the following day. Still, it is unclear as to whether Hogan took any further action before the ''Baltimore Sun'' article was released 10 days later. Following McGrath's resignation, Hogan ordered an audit of the Maryland Environmental Service.\n\n leaders of the  quickly questioned the payout, with House Speaker  and Senate President  releasing a joint statement calling its disclosure \"truly shocking\" and asked the Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight to hold immediate hearings to look into why the payment was made; the co-chairs of the committee, state senator  and delegate , promised to investigate the payment. Before the committee's first meeting on August 25, McGrath sought Hogan's help, asking him via text message to intervene on his behalf. Hogan did not respond to his texts, instead immediately releasing the texts to the committee. During this first meeting, MES board members testified that they were misled by McGrath into believing that Hogan wanted them to approve the payment. In September 2020, former MES deputy Beth Wojton testified that McGrath routinely prevented her and other employees from seeing expenses related to the Environmental Business Leadership Conference, a series of MES events held each year. Later that month, the committee took the unusual step of authorizing a subpoena for McGrath, who testified before legislators in December 2020. During his testimony, McGrath repeatedly declined to answer questions, invoking the  at least 130 times.\n\nIn September 2020, Democratic leaders of the Maryland General Assembly announced plans to reform the Maryland Environmental Service following McGrath's tenure. In December 2020, legislators introduced the Maryland Environmental Service Reform Act of 2021, which changed the management structure and oversight of the agency. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 13, 2021.\n\nIn May 2021, the Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight released a report on its investigation into McGrath, which suggested that McGrath flouted state personnel rules, received questionable reimbursements, and mischaracterized the details of his severance payment. The committee's final 82-page report was released in May 2022, which highlighted a pattern of questionable expenses and self-dealing under McGrath's tenure and called on the Maryland Environmental Service to take civil legal action against him.\n\n\n\n of McGrath, June 2021]]\nIn October 2020, '''' reported that both state and federal prosecutors were investigating the severance payments made to McGrath at the end of his tenure as MES director. On October 5, 2021, McGrath was indicted by a  on charges for wire fraud, misconduct in office, and improper use of state funds. He lashed out against state prosecutors in a Facebook post later that week, saying that \"politically-motivated bullies\" were after him and that he was confident \"the exculpatory facts will come to light and speak for themselves\". Later that month,  Magistrate Thomas M. DiGirolamo approved  for McGrath, requiring him to surrender his passport and firearms. In November 2021, McGrath pleaded not guilty to criminal charges in federal court. If convicted, he could have faced up to 140 years in prison.\n\nIn November 2021, McGrath claimed that Governor Hogan had expressed support of his severance package, releasing screenshots of text message conversations between him and Hogan in August 2020, including one where Hogan wrote: \"I know you did nothing wrong. I know it is unfair. I will stand with you\". According to Michael Ricci, Hogan's Director of Communications, the governor sent the message before he learned more details about how McGrath obtained the severance package. Ricci also disputed other emails released by McGrath, calling them a \"complete fabrication\".\n\nIn June 2022, a superseding indictment was issued against McGrath, alleging that McGrath had forged a memorandum from Hogan approving the severance payment.\n\nIn August 2023, the  sought to seize $119,000 in assets from an TD Ameritrade account belonging to McGrath, alleging that the account was entirely funded by his MES severance payment. In October 2024, U.S. District Court Judge  ordered the money to be forfeited to the U.S. government.\n\n\nOn October 5, 2021, the same day McGrath was indicted on federal charges, he was indicted on state charges in  Circuit Court for multiple counts of wiretapping and misconduct for allegedly recording conversations with the governor, cabinet secretaries and other officials without their consent. He was due to stand trial for the state charges in July 2023.\n\n\n for Roy McGrath]]\nMcGrath's federal trial was originally scheduled for October 24, 2022, but was delayed until March 13, 2023. However, he failed to appear in court for the beginning of his trial, prompting U.S. District Court Judge  to issue a warrant for McGrath's arrest. The  launched a manhunt for McGrath, whom they now considered a fugitive. According to a search warrant  and  footage obtained by the media, McGrath did not make reservations to travel to Maryland ahead of his scheduled trial, despite having told his attorney and wife otherwise. During the manhunt, McGrath purchased a used white , had a gun, and used multiple cellphones, which the  used to track him as he went into hiding. \n\nDuring the manhunt, McGrath self-published two books, ''Betrayed: The True Story of Roy McGrath'' and ''Betrayed: The True Story of Maryland Environmental Service'', under the  \"Ryan C. Cooper\". \"Cooper\" declined to give out further biographical details about himself, including his birthday or middle name, only describing himself as a semi-retired man who moved from  to Florida who sympathized with McGrath. In the books, McGrath defended his tenure at the Maryland Environmental Service and provided a tell-all against Governor Larry Hogan, who he claimed had acted out of \"delusional, ego-driven aspirations for the \". A third book was planned to release once more was known about McGrath's location, but never published. Federal officials were able to connect Cooper to McGrath through his own credit card and cellphone signals associated with Cooper's email address that showed McGrath traveling to a \"variety of hotels in different states\" on the East Coast during the manhunt.\n\nOn April 3, 2023, FBI agents sought to arrest McGrath at a  store near the 10700 block of Kingston Pike in . He ignored police trying to arrest him, resulting in a police chase that ended when McGrath was boxed in near a local fast-food restaurant and auto parts store. McGrath ignored demands to put his hands out the driver's side window and told agents that he had a loaded gun, which he fired at his right temple. At the same time, FBI agents fired at McGrath, striking his left cheek. He was taken to the , where he died 30 minutes later. ''The Washington Post'' reported that in a document, law enforcement said they believed McGrath shot himself during the traffic stop, but that it was unclear whether the self-inflicted wound or shots from law enforcement killed him. The FBI concluded its investigation into McGrath's death on July 20, 2023, but were unable to determine whether McGrath or the FBI agent fired the fatal shot. Prosecutors declined to bring criminal charges against the FBI agent who opened fire, saying that he had acted in self defense.\n\n\nMcGrath married his first wife, Yuliya ( to Julia, née Kryvenko), in 1997, and was divorced in 2010. In September 2021, less than two weeks before McGrath was federally indicted, he married Laura Bruner, who was his girlfriend at the time he served as MES director. They lived together in , before selling their home and moving to , in December 2020.\n\nMcGrath and Bruner purchased a home in Naples for $610,000.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Benjamin Todd Jealous''' (born January 18, 1973) is an American civil rights leader, environmentalist and executive director of the . He served as the president and chief executive officer of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People () from 2008 to 2013. When he was selected to head the NAACP at age 35, he became the organization's youngest-ever national leader.\n\nJealous ran for  in the . He ran as a , and won the party's nomination in the June 2018 primary, defeating  Executive  and seven other candidates. However, he lost in the general election to the incumbent governor, Republican .\n\nJealous is a partner at , board chairman of the Southern Elections Fund and one of the John L. Weinberg/Goldman Sachs Visiting Professors at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School. In 2013, Jealous was named a Young Global Leader by the .\n\nJealous was selected as president of , and its associated foundation, on June 2, 2020, and assumed the position on June 15. On November 14, 2022, Jealous was named the executive director of the , the first person of color to hold the position, effective January 23, 2023. Jealous' 2023 book, ''Never Forget Our People Were Always Free: A Parable of American Healing'' was released on January 10, 2023.\n\n\nJealous was born in 1973 in , and grew up on the . His mother, Ann Jealous (née Todd), is biracial. She worked as a psychotherapist and had grown up in . She had participated there in the desegregation of . She is the author, with Caroline Haskell, of ''Combined Destinies: Whites Sharing Grief about Racism'' (2013). His father, Fred Jealous, who is white, is descended from settlers of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, related to businessman , and directly in line to inherit the fortune from the Sargent and Co business. He founded the Breakthrough Men's Community and participated in Baltimore sit-ins to desegregate lunch counters. Jealous's parents met in Baltimore in 1966. At the time, they did not openly date each other in public; when they went to the movies, they took separate paths to adjacent seats to hide their relationship. As an interracial couple, they were prohibited by state law from marrying in Maryland before 1967. They married in , and returned to live in Baltimore for a time before moving to California in the early-1970s. As a child, Jealous was sent to Baltimore to spend his summers with his maternal grandparents, who lived in the  neighborhood. Jealous graduated from  in  in 1990.\n\nJealous's father was best friends with comedian 's father, ; as a result, Jealous has been friends with Dave Chappelle since childhood, and the two are god-brothers.\n\nJealous earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science from . A , he later earned a Master of Science in comparative social research from .\n\n\n\n\nAt , Jealous began working as an organizer with the . As a student, he protested the university's plan to turn the  (the site of 's assassination) into a research facility and was suspended. During his suspension, Jealous traveled through the South. During this time 's three black colleges were slated to be closed because of financial difficulties. Jealous organized with the local  chapter to keep them fully funded and maintain their operations.\n\nWhile in Mississippi, Jealous began working as a reporter for '','' Mississippi's oldest historically black newspaper, under the tutelage of publisher Charles Tisdale. He eventually became its managing editor. His reporting was credited with exposing corruption among high-ranking officials at the state prison in . In addition, he helped acquit a small farmer who had been wrongfully accused of arson. Jealous returned to Columbia in 1997, where he applied for and was awarded a .\n\nAfter completing his degree at Oxford and returning to the US, Jealous worked as executive director of the  (NNPA), a federation of more than 200 black community newspapers. During his term, he relocated the organization's editorial office to  in Washington, D.C. He set up an online syndicated news service that shared content with all of the organization's member papers.\n\nAfter the NNPA, he served as director of the US Human Rights Program at . He focused on issues such as promoting federal legislation against prison rape, racial profiling, and the sentencing of persons to  (LWOP) who are convicted for acts committed as children. (In 2012, the US Supreme Court ruled that such sentencing was unconstitutional, and ordered its ruling to be applied to people already in prison.) Jealous is the lead author of the 2004 report \"Threat and Humiliation: Racial Profiling, Domestic Security, and Human Rights in the United States.\"\n\nJealous was President of the Rosenberg Foundation, a private foundation located in San Francisco, California from 2005 to 2008.\n\n\n\nJealous was elected in 2008 as president and CEO of the ; at age 35, he was the youngest person to serve in that position. He served until late 2013. During his term, Jealous initiated national programs on criminal justice, health,  and , expanded existing programs and opened the NAACP Financial Freedom Center to provide financial education and banking resources.\n\nDuring his tenure, the NAACP helped register 374,553 voters and mobilize 1.2 million new voters to turn out at the polls for the . It supported abolition of the  and , endorsed , and fought laws it believed were intended for voter suppression in states across the country.\n\nDuring Jealous's tenure, the number of NAACP's online activists increased from 175,000 to more than 675,000; its donors increased from 16,000 individuals to more than 132,000; and the number of total NAACP activists was 1.7 million.\n\nJealous led the NAACP to work closely with other civil rights, labor and environmental groups. In 2010 the NAACP was one of the conveners of the , which Jealous referred to as \"an antidote\" to the . In June 2012, the NAACP led several thousand protesters from different groups to march down 's Fifth Avenue in protest of the NYPD's policy of  policing. In 2012 Jealous formed the  along with other progressive leaders, to build a national campaign around three goals: getting big money out of politics, supporting voting rights, and reforming broken Senate rules. Finally, in 2013 Jealous gave the keynote address at the A10 Rally for Citizenship, a major rally for immigration reform at the .\n as he signs the Educational Excellence for African Americans executive order, 2012]]\nJealous broadened the NAACP's alliances in 2011 at the  when a conservative coalition of criminal justice reform advocates endorsed an NAACP report authored by Jealous. In the report, Jealous highlights the adverse effects of  on society and the case for increasing public funding for education. In Texas later that year, the NAACP worked with leaders of the Tea Party to pass a dozen criminal justice reform measures, leading to the first scheduled prison closure in state history. Similarly, in 2013, the NAACP worked closely with Virginia Governor  to pass bipartisan voting rights reform that gave former offenders the chance to vote after they served the terms of their sentence.\n\nUpon announcing his resignation in 2013, Jealous was praised by activists for his coalition-building efforts.\n\nJealous was noted for reviving and building the resources of the NAACP. According to '','' he was:\n\n }}\n\n\n\n\nOn May 31, 2017, Jealous announced his candidacy for governor of Maryland in the , then held by  (R). His running mate was .\n\nMany labor and progressive groups issued early endorsements of Jealous, including the  (APWU-Maryland),  (CWA), , the Maryland State Education Association, the  (SEIU), , , , the Maryland Working Families Party,  and Progressive Maryland.\n\nJealous received endorsements from Senators , , and , as well as longtime friend, comedian .\n\nThe Democratic primary was held on June 26, 2018. Despite trailing in polling in the months prior to the primary, Jealous and Turnbull won the primary with 40% of the vote in a nine-candidate field, 10% ahead of the second place duo.\n\nJealous ran on a platform that included , , , and a $15  for Marylanders. His views were described by an analyst for  as . However, Jealous disputed this characterization. On August 8, 2018, when questioned by a reporter about whether he considered himself a socialist, Jealous referred to himself as a \".\" When the reporter asked a second time whether he was a socialist, he responded, \"Are you fucking kidding me?\"\n\nIn October 2018, Jealous confirmed to '''' that he would \"vow to defend\" the Executive Order by Hogan related to banning companies from working with the state who boycott the Israeli Occupation and/or settlements. This order is very similar to one the ACLU successfully challenged into suspension in Arizona as unconstitutional. Jealous's campaign added that if the ACLU was successful in suspending the Maryland order, he would \"bring leaders in the Jewish community and the Maryland-Israel Development Center together ...to figure out if there's a constitutional way to discourage the  movement in Maryland.\"\n\nThe general election was held on November 6, 2018, and Jealous lost the election to the incumbent governor, Hogan by a wide margin of 11.9%.\n\n\nIn 2014 Jealous became a senior partner at Kapor Capital. He also joined the  as a senior fellow.\n\n\nJealous is a  Democrat. He endorsed  in his , then supported  after she was nominated as a candidate by the Democratic Party.\n\n\n\nJealous was married to , an NAACP lawyer and law professor at  in July 2002. Epperson is the sister of CNBC correspondent . Jealous and Epperson have two children. The couple divorced in 2015. Jealous has been a  since 1978. He is a resident of .\n\n\nJealous has earned the following awards and honors for his activism:\n* In March 2009, Jealous received the  for distinguished professional achievement from  and in 2010 spoke as the Class Day speaker at .\n* In 2010, Jealous was named to '''' magazine's \"40 Under 40\" rising stars of American politics.\n* In 2010 and 2011, Jealous was named to the ''Nonprofit Times'' \"Power & Influence Top 50\" list.\n* In 2012 Jealous was named to  magazine's \"40 Under 40\" list.\n* Jealous was ranked No. 3 on the 2012 '''' Top 100 list.\n* In December 2012, Jealous was awarded the 2012  for Creative Citizenship, which is given annually to an individual who has challenged the status quo through distinctive, courageous, imaginative, and socially responsible work of significance.\n* In March 2013, Jealous was named a  by the Davos .\n* Jealous was ranked No. 1 on The 2013 ''Root'' Top 100 list.\n* In December 2013 Jealous was named Marylander of The Year by the ''Baltimore Sun''.\n\n\n*'''', a book of personal essays edited by Jealous and Trabian Shorters\n\n\n\n\n\n*  (archive)\n*  () interview with NAACP President Ben Jealous\n*  () by Benjamin Jealous and Julian Bond for ''The New Republic''.\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n}}\n\n'''Robert A. Costa''' (born October 9, 1958) is an American politician who was a member of the , and until his retirement represented , which is located in . He defeated Democrat Mike Shay in the 2006 election. In 2002 he defeated Democrat Dotty Chaney to initially capture the seat of this newly created district. He announced his retirement in 2014. He was succeeded by .\n\n\nCosta was born on October 9, 1958, in . Costa attended  in . After high school he attended , focusing on general studies.\n\n\n\nPrior to becoming an elected official, Costa served in the  from 1981 until 1985. After his service in the military, Costa became a professional firefighter with the Anne Arundel County Fire Department. He has also spent some time as a real estate agent.\n\nCosta has been an active member in several organizations. He is on the executive board of Local 1563, the Anne Arundel County Professional Firefighters Association. He was a member Anne Arundel County Republican Central Committee from 1998–2002, serving as its chair from 1999 until 2000. Costa is the founder of the South County Republican Dinner Club. He is also a member of the Italian Businessmen's Association in Annapolis, the South County , the Deale , Deale Elementary School P.T.A., the Alliance of the Chesapeake, the  (NRA), and the Maryland Rifle and Pistol Association. He is also a member of the Arbor Day Foundation, , and the Anne Arundel Affordable Housing Coalition. Finally, he served as the chair of the Board of Directors of the Avalon Shores Civic Association from 1999 until 2001.\n\nCosta has received numerous awards for his service including the Outstanding Patriotism Award, Annapolis Chapter, Military Order of World Wars in 1983 and the Outstanding Legislative Leadership Award, ARC of Maryland and Maryland Association of Community Services in 2005.\n\nWhile working for the House of Delegates, Costa has been selected as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee and the Investigation Committee. He served as Deputy Minority Whip from 2003 to 2005.\n\n\n*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n*voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006(SB154)\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted against in-state tuition for undocumented immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* On February 17, 2012, Costa was one of two s (the other being Delegate  of ) to vote in favor of the Civil Marriage Protection Act, a bill allowing . The bill passed 72-67. The bill needed 71 votes to pass.     "pages": }\n'''Dalya Attar''' (born October 17, 1990) is an American politician who currently serves in the , representing  in northwest, northern and southwest Baltimore City.\n\n\nAttar was born fourth of six children to an  father and a  mother. She was raised as a   in , where she attended the  School for Girls. Attar later graduated from the , where she earned a  degree in criminal justice in 2011, and the , where she earned her  degree in 2014.\n\nWhile attending the University of Baltimore, Attar worked as a paralegal for Greenspan, Hitzel & Schrader until 2015, when she became a trial attorney for the firm. In the same year, she also began working as an assistant state's attorney in the Baltimore State's Attorney office, prosecuting narcotics and firearms cases.\n\nAttar developed an interest in criminal justice while in middle school, and became interested in politics in high school. She has cited , , and Karen Chaya Friedman as her role models.\n\n\nOn June 9, 2017, Attar announced that she would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 41. During the Democratic primary, she ran on a platform of spurring development, improving schools, and reforming the juvenile justice system. Attar won the Democratic primary in June 2018, defeating incumbents  and .\n\nAttar was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She is the first Orthodox Jew elected to the  and the highest-ranking Orthodox Jewish woman in American history. Attar served on the Environment and Transportation Committee from 2019 to 2020, afterwards serving as a member of the Ways and Means Committee.\n\n\n\nIn March 2019, Attar voted against a bill that would allow s to carry guns in Baltimore schools. She also supported a bill that would allow  to have its own private police force.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Attar introduced a bill that would require incarceration for violent offenders with open warrants. She also supported a bill that would ban s over unpaid parking tickets.\n\n\nAttar supports improving public schools and providing publicly-funded scholarships for s.\n\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, after , the director of the state  (CAIR) chapter, was temporarily suspended from the state Commission on Hate Crime Response and Prevention for making Facebook posts comparing Israel to  and calling attendees of the  \"genocide sympathizers\", Attar introduced legislation to remove Chaudry from the commission and replace her with \"two members of the Muslim community\". The bill was amended to remove representatives from organizations including CAIR from the hate crimes commission by requiring members to be advocates for protected classes under Maryland's hate crime laws.\n\n\nAttar supports using an  to draw Maryland's legislative districts.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Attar introduced a bill that would prevent husbands from having a civil divorce unless they granted their wife a .\n\nIn 2022, Attar voted against a bill that would expand the types of medical professionals who can perform abortions in the state, and voted to sustain Governor 's veto on the bill.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Attar introduced legislation to move Maryland's 2024 primary date from April 23the first day of , which prevents Orthodox Jewish voters from participating in electionsto May 14. The bill's contents were added to another bill, which passed and was signed by Governor .\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Attar supported a bill that would require the  to seek federal approval for the .\n\n\nAttar is married to Asaf Mehrzadi, a longtime family friend. Together, they have two children.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Malcolm L. Augustine''' (born March 10, 1969) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  from the  since 2019. A member of the , Augustine has served as the president pro tempore of the Maryland Senate since 2023.\n\n\nAugustine was born in ,  on March 10, 1969. He graduated from  in ,  and later attended  in , , where he earned an  degree in government in 1991. He is a member of the  fraternity.\n\nAugustine entered politics in 2012 by becoming the co-chair of Progressive Cheverly. At the same time, he became the chair of the Cable Television Commission in . In 2014, Augustine unsuccessfully ran for  in District 47A, coming in fourth place and losing to  and .\n\nIn 2015, Prince George's County   appointed Augustine to represent Prince George's County on the  (WMATA) Board of Directors.\n\nIn August 2017, Augustine declared his candidacy for Maryland Senate, seeking to replace state senator , who sought to become the next Prince George's County State's Attorney. He won the Democratic primary with 84.1 percent of the vote and the general election with 93.0 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nAugustine was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. Since 2023, he has served as the president pro tempore of the Maryland Senate.\n\n\n* Finance Committee, 2019–present (energy & public utilities subcommittee, 2019–present)\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on the Management of Public Funds, 2019–present\n* Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2019–present\n* Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee, 2019–present\n* Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 2019–present\n* Joint Electric Universal Service Program Work Group, 2020–present\n* Joint Committee on Behavioral Health and Opioid Use Disorders, 2019, 2020–present\n* Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 2021–present\n\n\n* , 2019–present\n* Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019–present\n* Co-chair, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n\n\n\nAugustine introduced legislation in the 2020 session that would ban  from all stores and require stores to charge a minimum of 10 cents for paper bags. The bill's counterpart in the  passed by a vote of 95-37 and received a favorable report from the Senate Finance Committee, but never received a vote in the Senate. The bill was reintroduced in the 2021 session and passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 97–37.\n\nIn 2021, the Maryland  gave Augustine a score of 89 percent in their annual environmental scorecard.\n\n\nAugustine introduced legislation in the 2020 session that would allow minors over 12 years of age to seek mental health treatment without their parent's consent. The bill passed the State Senate by a vote of 30–15. The bill was reintroduced in the 2021 session and passed and became law without the governor's signature.\n\nAugustine introduced legislation in the 2021 session would require employers to provide workers with safe and hygienic workspaces, , emergency pandemic action plans that include sanitation protocol and changes in shift hours, paid health and bereavement leave, free , an additional $3 an hour in  and the ability to refuse dangerous work without fear of retaliation. A narrowed version, which removed the initial $3 an hour in hazard pay and made paid sick leave contingent upon funding from the state or federal government, passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 93–39.\n\nIn the 2022 session, Augustine introduced legislation that would include dental care in patients'  coverage.\n\n\nWhile on the WMATA Board of Directors, Augustine argued against fare hikes and service cuts, expressing worry that they would hasten ridership decline. He was the only board member to vote against a 2017 fare hike that increased the price by 10 cents for rush hour and 25 cents for off-peak travel times.\n\nIn the Senate, Augustine expressed major concerns against a proposal to build a  train that would connect  to , instead calling on the legislature to invest in the  project cancelled by Governor .\n\n\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 47A District (Democratic Primary)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2018 Race for Maryland Senate&nbsp;– 47th District (Democratic Primary)'''\n:\n*'''2018 Race for Maryland Senate&nbsp;– 47th District (General Election)'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
