    "pages": }\n'''Carl L. Anderton Jr.''' (born May 20, 1973) is an American politician who was a  member of the , representing  in , from 2015 to 2024.\n\n\nCarl Anderton Jr. was born in  on May 20, 1973, grew up in , and graduated from  in . He is married with two children.\n\nAnderton was a member of the Town Commission of  from 2006 to 2011, and served as the mayor of Delmar from 2011 to 2015. He served as the President of the  from 2013 to 2014.\n\nIn December 2013, Anderton declared his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates, seeking to challenge  incumbent . During the general election, the  distributed fliers opposing Conway, portraying him in a black  typically seen on bank robbers. Anderton distanced himself from the fliers, saying that he was unaware of the fliers until someone told him about it over the weekend and that he had no involvement with their distribution. He defeated Conway in the general election with 52.2 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nAnderton was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. He was a member of the Environment and Transportation Committee from 2015 to 2018 and from 2019 to 2023, and the Appropriations Committee in 2019 and from 2023 to 2024. Anderton was also a chair of the Wicomico County Delegation during his entire tenure and the vice-chair of the  in 2024. \n\nFollowing the death of  executive Robert L. \"Bob\" Culver, Jr. in 2020, Anderton applied to replace Culver, but was defeated by cardiologist Rene Desmarais. Desmarais declined the county council's appointment, which prompted the council to reopen the application process, for which Anderton applied a second time. The council ultimately voted to keep County Administrator John D. Psota in place as acting county executive until the . Anderton was rumored to be a candidate for Wicomico County executive in 2022, but announced in February 2022 that he would seek a third term to the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nOn July 9, 2024, Anderton announced that he would be resigning from the Maryland House of Delegates on July 23, 2024, to become the director of rural strategy within the Maryland Department of Commerce.\n\n\nFollowing his election win, Anderton expressed that he would reach across party lines. He supports , saying that overregulation in Maryland is \"detrimental to  farmers and business owners.\"\n\n\nAnderton opposed legislation introduced in the 2016 legislative session that would big chicken companies to handle and dispose of excess poultry manure.\n\n\nAnderton introduced legislation during the 2015 legislative session, nicknamed \"The Evo Bill\" after the Evolution Craft Brewery in , that would allow Wicomico County to increase their beer production from 22,500 barrels to 45,000 barrels each year. The bill passed and was signed by Governor  on April 29, 2015.\n\nAnderton introduced legislation during the 2020 legislative session that would allow the city of Salisbury to make its own alcohol licensing commission following controversy surrounding permits for the . After a compromise was found between the city of Salisbury and Wicomico County, the legislation passed the  unanimously and became law on May 8, 2020.\n\n\nAnderton is a long-time supporter of a project to construct a 32 turbine  off the coast of , saying that it would bring jobs to the area. While he supports renewable energy alternatives like solar power and offshore wind, he does not think those energy sources are fully sustainable on their own and supports the construction of a  on Maryland's Eastern Shore.\n\nIn September 2018, Anderton received a score of 83 percent from the Maryland .\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Anderton cosponsored a bill that would hold  financially responsible for cleanup costs associated with pollution spilling over the . He opposed legislation that banned oyster harvesting in sanctuaries.\n\n\nAnderton opposed legislation introduced in the 2016 legislative session that changed how transportation projects are prioritized in Maryland, arguing that it would put projects on the Eastern Shore on the backburner.\n\nAnderton introduced legislation during the 2017 legislative session that would have incrementally increased highway user revenue appropriations to Maryland towns. The bill did not receive a vote during the legislative session, but was reintroduced in 2018. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 24, 2018.\n\n\nIn 2015, Anderton voted alongside six other Republicans for a bill that would decriminalize the possession of . During the 2018 legislative session, Anderton supported a bill that would legalize the production and sale of  in Maryland, saying that \"passing the bill would be a win for lawmakers and farmers.\" Anderton supports using a  to let voters decide on legalizing  in Maryland.\n\n\nAnderton opposed a bill that would raise the minimum wage to , instead promoting a compromise bill proposed by Governor Hogan that would raise the state's minimum wage to $12.10 by 2022.\n\n\nAnderton campaigned on repealing the  and broadening Wicomico County's enterprise zones. Anderton supports legalizing  in Maryland, saying that the state \"needs additional sources of revenue in order to get more funding for things like education resources.\"\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Seth Adam Howard''' (born March 17, 1974) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  from  since 2015.\n\n\nHoward was born in  on March 17, 1974. He graduated , and afterwards served in the  from 1994 to 1998, and in the  from 1999 to 2003. Since 2004, Howard has owned the Broadleaf Tobacco and Smoke Shop in .\n\nHoward ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in , seeking to succeed delegate , who announced his intent to retire after redistricting moved him to . During the primary, the  endorsed his campaign with an 'AQ' rating. He defeated  lieutenant Jim Fredericks in the primary election, receiving 52 percent of the vote, and later defeated Democratic challenger Mitchelle Stephenson in the general election with 63.3 percent of the vote.\n\n\n, 2015]]\nHoward was sworn into the House of Delegates on January 14, 2015, and has served as a member of the Economic Matters Committee during his entire tenure. In January 2020, the  gave Howard a score of 63 percent, making him the lowest-scoring Republican in the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nHoward has served as the Deputy Minority Whip for the Maryland House Republican Caucus since 2021, filling a vacancy left by the election of Delegate  to serve as the House Minority Whip. In February 2021, Howard was appointed as the chairman of the Maryland House Republican Caucus' Business and Economic Committee.\n\nIn 2020, Howard was an alternate delegate for the .\n\n\nHoward is married and has a child.\n\n\n\nIn February 2017, Howard voted against a bill providing workers with up to seven days of  a year, criticizing it as a burden for small businesses. During the 2018 legislative session, he introduced a bill that would require  to notify customers when their personal information is stolen in .\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Howard introduced legislation to reduce the county's archery safety zone to 50 yards.\n\nIn March 2018, during debate on a bill to ban s following the , Howard introduced an amendment that would grandfather in already purchased bump stocks.\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Howard voted against a bill banning wage discrimination on the basis of gender identity, pointing to existing federal protections against sex-based wage discrimination, including the  and the .\n\n\nIn April 2018, after  delivered a speech on the House floor to support a bill banning  for LGBT teens, Howard was one of four Anne Arundel County delegates to abstain from voting on the bill.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Howard voted against a bill that would allow the Anne Arundel County Council to pass a .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ralph M. Hughes''' (born April 17, 1948) is an American politician who represented district 40 in the  from 1991 to 2007 and a member of the  from the same district from 1983 to 1991.\n\n\nHughes was born in , April 17, 1948. He attended  and graduated from  in 1966. Hughes went on to  earning a  degree in 1970. Three years later he completed the  earning a  The , M.A.S., 1985. Professor (criminal justice), , from 2007. Member, Monumental City Bar Association. He is a member of the Mount Hope Baptist Church in Baltimore and is married.\n\n\nHughes won his first election in 1982, running for one of three seats in Baltimore's 40th legislative district to the . There he served on the Judiciary Committee, 1983-90.\nIn 1990 he won a seat in the Maryland Senate and served on its Judicial Proceedings Committee from 1991 to 2007. He was chair, Special Committee on Substance Abuse, 2001–2007, member, Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, 1995, Senate Chair, Joint Committee on Investigation, 1995, member, Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 1995–1999; Article 27 (crimes & punishments) Revision Committee, 1999–2003, Senate Special Commission on Medical Malpractice Liability Insurance, 2004, Abatement of Drug-Related Nuisances Work Group, 2004. Hughes served as Vice-Chair, , a member, , 1991-2007 (chair, crime & safety committee, 2000; member, law & justice committee, 2000–2007, redistricting committee, 2000–2007; drug treatment committee, 2001–2007).\n\n\n*2006 Hughes sponsored Senate Bill 592 which would have repealed Maryland's mandatory minimum sentences for repeat felony drug offenders\n*2003 Hughes introduced a bill that would have imposed a moratorium on Maryland's death penalty. The bill, however, died on the Senate floor with 23 senators voting for it and 24 against.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Charles J. Otto''' (born February 15, 1964) is an American politician and farmer serving as a  member of the  representing  since 2011.\n\n\nOtto was born on February 15, 1964, in . He graduated from  and attended the  and graduated from , earning a  degree in animal science in 1986.\n\nOtto is a corn and soybean farmer. He previously worked as a sales representative and crop consultant for various organizations, including the William B. Tilghman Co. and the Maryland Farm Bureau, from 1987 to 1995.\n\n\nOtto was elected to the House of Delegates in , succeeding , who was appointed to the seat following the death of her husband . He was sworn in on January 12, 2011. Otto has served in the Environment and Transportation Committee during his entire tenure. He has also worked as the Deputy Minority Whip for the Maryland House Republican Caucus since 2013.\n\n\n\nIn 2012, Otto said he opposed a bill that would ban  in chicken feed, claiming that arsenic was not \"an environmental threat or a human health threat\". The  states that all forms of arsenic are a serious risk to human health.\n\nIn 2014, Otto supported legislation to allow the use of  to catch clams south of the .\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Otto introduced legislation to allow hunting on Sundays in Worcester County. The bill passed and became law.\n\n\nIn March 2013, Otto voted against a bill to repeal the death penalty.\n\nFollowing a string of false s made against schools and other public facilities across  in early 2016, Otto introduced legislation that would increase penalties for people who make fake bomb threats. The bill passed and was signed into law.\n\n\nOtto supports Maryland's Broadening Options and Opportunities for Students Today (BOOST) program, which provides state-funded scholarships to low-income students attending s. He also supports the expansion of s.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Otto introduced legislation that would allow residents of Somerset County to qualify for free tuition at .\n\n\nOtto opposes proposals to build a  off the coast of , supporting legislation in 2018 that would've required turbines to be built 26 miles offshore. The bill received an unfavorable report in the Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\nIn 2014, Otto introduced bills to repeal .\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Otto signed onto a letter calling on the federal government to ban . In January 2017, the  said it would deny a proposal to allow seismic airgun blasting off the coast of Ocean City.\n\nIn 2019, Otto supported legislation to hold  fiscally responsible for costs associated with  cleanup projects and implementing the dam's watershed implementation plan.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Otto voted against legislation to increase fees on license plates and official documents to pay for road repair projects. In March 2013, he voted against legislation to index the state's es to inflation.\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Otto voted against a bill to raise the state's minimum wage to $10.10 an hour.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Otto voted against the Firearm Safety Act, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s. In May 2023, he signed onto a letter calling on Governor  to veto the Gun Safety Act, an omnibus gun control bill that increased requirements and fees to obtain a handgun permit, strengthened safe storage requirements, and prohibited carrying guns near certain locations.\n\n\nOtto supported the  in Maryland, but expressed concerns with the .\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Otto voted against the , which legalized same-sex marriage in Maryland.\n\nIn 2019, Otto introduced legislation requiring Somerset County commissioners to live in the districts they represent. The bill passed unanimously and became law.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Eric Douglas Ebersole''' (born May 20, 1958) is an American politician who serves as a Delegate to the  representing . From 2015 to 2023, he represented .\n\n\nEbersole was born in  on May 20, 1958, and grew up in . He attended the , earning a  degree in mathematics education in 1980 and an  degree in the same field in 1986.\n\nAfter graduating, Ebersole worked for more than three decades as a high school math teacher in Howard County, at , , and  High Schools. He also served as an adjunct instructor in mathematics education at the . Among the awards Ebersole won during his time as a teacher was his selection as Outstanding Secondary Mathematics Teachers of the Year in 1987 by the Maryland Council of Teachers of Mathematics and his selection as Wilde Lake High School's Teacher of the Year in 2002.\n\nIn addition to his work as a classroom teacher, Ebersole was actively involved in a number of professional and community organizations. He was a member of the Maryland Council of Teachers of Mathematics and served in a number of leadership roles in that organization. In addition he volunteered with the Catonsville Chamber of Commerce, is a life member of the Catonsville Historical Society, and served in a number of leadership roles in the Catonsville Presbyterian Church.\n\nFollowing redistricting in 2010, the three incumbent legislators representing District 12, which had formerly been divided into two sub-districts, chose not to run for re-election. Ebersole ran for the seat in a crowded primary field, and was elected alongside  and  as an all-freshman delegation to the General Assembly.\n\n\nEbersole was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. Since 2022, he has served as Deputy Majority Whip. He has filed to run for re-election in 2022.\n\nIn October 2015,   appointed Ebersole to a commission to study the use of  in the state's public schools. The commission submitted its final recommendations, which included reducing the length and testing units for the  test and giving assessments during regular class time, on July 7, 2016.\n\n\n* Member, Ways and Means Committee, 2015- (education subcommittee, 2015-; election law subcommittee, 2015–17; revenues subcommittee, 2017–18; chair, finance resources subcommittee, 2019, member, 2015–19; chair, early childhood subcommittee, 2020-)\n* Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 2015-\n\n\n* House Chair, , 2017–18\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019-\n\n\n\nEbersole introduced legislation in the 2015 legislative session that would create a commission to survey and assess how much time is spent on testing in each grade level and each school system. The bill passed and became law on May 12, 2015.\n\nEbersole introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would require the appointment of a full-time teacher and parent of a public school student to the . The bill passed and became law without Governor Larry Hogan's signature on May 28, 2019.\n\nEbersole introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would require the  to keep track of the number of students restrained or placed in seclusion. The  bill unanimously passed the House of Delegates. He later introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would ban the use of seclusion in public Maryland schools. The bill passed and became law on April 9, 2022.\n\n\nEbersole endorsed former Secretary of State  for president on November 17, 2015. Ebersole endorsed  for Governor of Maryland on August 8, 2018.\n\n\nIn July 2019, Ebersole attended and spoke at a rally outside the office of   to urge Cummings to protest against the .\n\n\nEbersole introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would require school systems to allow students to participate in s. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 97-39.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Mary Angela Lehman''' (born April 8, 1964) is an American politician from the  and is a current member of the  representing .\n\n\nLehman was born in , on April 8, 1964. She grew up in , and attended the , where in 1987 she received her  in English Literature and  in Journalism.\n\nFrom 1993 to 1994, Lehman worked as a spokesperson for Citizens Against the Stadium II, a group that protested the construction of the  football stadium in . After a vote on condemning the ' proposed football stadium was tabled by the Prince George's County Council, she accused the football team of engaging in \"the politics of intimidation\" by threatening not to work with the city if the resolution passed. Team officials eventually announced that the stadium would be built in  after meeting with local residents.\n\nIn 2003, Lehman began working as an educational liaison to Prince George's County council member Tom Dernoga. In 2007, she began working for delegate , who encouraged her to run for public office.\n\nFrom 2010 to 2018, Lehman served on the  Council, succeeding Tom Dernoga, who was term-limited. As a councilwoman, she oversaw the opening of the  and lobbied for the library to have solar panels, pervious parking surfaces, electric car chargers, low flow toilets and sinks, and emergency lighting. She also had a role in saving the  from closure.\n\nIn February 2018, Lehman, who was term limited from running for another term on the Prince George's County Council, announced her candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 21. She came in third place in the 2018 Democratic primary, defeating primary opponent Matt Dernoga by only 222 votes.\n\n\n\nLehman was sworn in as a member of the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019, and is a member of the Environment and Transportation Committee, the housing and real property subcommittee, and agriculture and open space subcommittee.\n\nLehman is a member of the Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus and the Women Legislators of Maryland, and is an associate member of the Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus.\n\nIn January 2020, Lehman filed to run as a convention delegate for  at the .\n\n\n\nIn 2014, Lehman voted to approve an amendment to the county's charter that would give members of the county council another four-year term opposed to only two consecutive terms.\n\nLehman opposed legislation introduced by delegate  during the 2019 legislative session that would set up a public financing system for county campaigns in the 2026 election cycle, saying that the 2026 timeline was too far away. She also voted against legislation that would lift the ban on developer contributions in county political races.\n\n\nIn 2012, Lehman promoted legislation introduced by delegate  that would allow the Prince George's County council to require shoppers to pay for disposable bags. The bill was unexpectedly killed in the House Environmental Matters Committee, where it received a 12–11 vote to kill the bill.\n\nLehman introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would have set strict standards for recycling crumb rubber-modified turf. She withdrew the bill later in the session, but planned to reintroduce it in the next legislative session.\n\nLehman received a score of 100 percent on the Maryland League of Conversation Voters' 2021 legislative scorecard.\n\n\nLehman introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would require landlords to prove they are in compliance with local laws and state statutes when they file a failure to pay rent case.\n\n\nLehman introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would require corporate combined tax reporting. The bill passed the House of Delegates but did not receive a vote in the . She also cosponsored legislation that would create a multi-state compact to end corporate tax breaks aimed at getting businesses to move across state lines.\n\n\nAs a councilwoman, Lehman was vocally opposed to a proposed high-speed maglev train that would run from , to , citing concerns over the train's environmental impact, cost, and economic potential. In the 2018 legislative session, she filed legislation that would have provided state income and property tax credits to companies affected by the maglev's construction.\n\nLehman introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would give local governments veto power over state-backed toll road projects. She said that she would oppose a repeal of existing laws that give Eastern Shore counties the right to block state-backed toll facilities.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sarah Kelly Elfreth''' (born September 9, 1988) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing the  since 2019.\n\nBorn and raised in New Jersey, Elfreth moved to Maryland to study political science at  and later earn a  from . She became involved with Maryland politics while attending Towson, during which she was appointed by Governor  to be a student member of the  Board of Regents. After graduating, Elfreth moved to Annapolis, where she successfully ran for the  in , defeating Republican challenger and former state delegate  in the general election. She was reelected in . Her district encompasses the lower half of , including the state capital of . \n\nElfreth won the 22-way Democratic primary in the  in  and then defeated the Republican nominee in the general election. She will be sworn in on January 3, 2025.\n\n\nElfreth was born and raised in , where her stepfather worked as a locomotive engineer and her mother worked as a probation officer. She graduated from  in 2006, and attended , where she received her  degree in political science in 2010 and submitted a thesis on how having students participate in governing boards can make them more effective. In 2012, Elfreth earned her  degree in public policy from , where she worked as a research assistant in the Office of Government and Community Affairs from 2010 to 2012. Elfreth serves as an adjunct professor for Towson University's Honors College.\n\n\nElfreth became active in politics while attending Towson University, when she became involved with student government and began traveling to  to lobby the . In 2009,   appointed Elfreth to be the student member of the University System Board of Regents. She didn't become involved with electoral politics until her senior year at Towson, after hearing a speech by former  . She briefly served in the office of   before working as the Government Affairs Director at the .\n\nAfter moving to , Elfreth became involved with local politics, becoming a member of the Ward 1 Residents Association and serving on the District 30 Democratic Club, and volunteering for the campaigns of multiple local Democratic officials. In June 2017, Elfreth filed to run for Maryland Senate, seeking to succeed state Senator , who did not seek re-election to run for . During the Democratic primary, she ran on a slate with House Speaker , whom she would later cite as her political mentor. Elfreth was elected to the Maryland Senate with 53.8 percent of the vote against former state delegate .\n\n\n\nElfreth was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. She is currently the youngest woman ever to serve in the Maryland Senate. Elfreth is a member of the Budget and Taxation Committeeincluding as the chair of its Pensions and Public Safety, Transportation, and Environment subcommittee and as a member of its Capital Budget subcommitteeand is the chair of the Joint Committee on the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bay Critical Areas and Joint Subcommittee on Program Open Space and Agricultural Land Preservation. She is regarded as one of the most productive members of the legislature, having passed 84 bills during her tenure, more than any other legislator during that time.\n\nElfreth served as an at-large delegate to the  and s. As of May 2024, she had plans to campaign for  in  during the .\n\nIn 2022, Elfreth served as the chair of the .\n\n\n\nOn November 4, 2023, Elfreth announced that she would run for the  in  to succeed , who had announced his retirement a week before. During the Democratic primary, which developed into a three-way race between Elfreth, , and , Elfreth campaigned on environmental issues, abortion rights, and healthcare, and received support from U.S. senators  and , and from several Anne Arundel County-based legislators.\n\nElfreth was the only candidate in the race who expressed openness to accepting campaign contributions from corporate s, saying that she would accept donations from corporations within the district, and received more than $4 million in support from 's United Democracy Project super PAC. Elfreth defended her campaign receiving support from AIPAC by saying she did not solicit the support and that she would support campaign finance reform if elected to Congress, referencing Sarbanes's . AIPAC's contributions, as well as the $1 million in contributions she received from supporters, allowed her campaign to overcome the fundraising gap between her and Dunn, who had raised $4 million during his campaign.\n\nElfreth won the Democratic primary election on May 14, 2024, and defeated Republican nominee Rob Steinberger in the general election on November 5, 2024. She is the youngest woman ever elected to the U.S. House of Representatives from Maryland. She and  will be the first women to represent Maryland in the U.S. House of Representatives since 2016, when  retired to unsuccessfully . When Elfreth resigns to take office in the U.S. House of Representatives, the Anne Arundel County Democratic Central Committee will be tasked with appointing someone to serve the remainder of Elfreth's term in the Maryland Senate. State delegates  and  have reportedly expressed interest in running to succeed Elfreth.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Elfreth voted for the Maryland Police Accountability Act and supported an unsuccessful Republican amendment to the bill that would require law enforcement agencies to keep a record of positive community feedback.\n\nDuring debate on a bill to give the  prosecutorial power in police-involved deaths in 2023, Elfreth voted for amendments that would allow states attorneys' to decide first whether to prosecute a case, and another to appoint a director of the investigations division. Both amendments were rejected in largely party-line votes.\n\nIn June 2023, following a  that left three dead and another three injured, Elfreth attended a vigil to honor the victims of the attack and endorsed calls for accountability from state legislators.\n\n\nDuring her tenure as the student member of the University System of Maryland Board of Regents, Elfreth voted against a three percent tuition increase and spoke in support of Governor Martin O'Malley's four-year tuition freeze. She also voted for a resolution recommending against a policy on pornographic films following the screening of '''' at the .\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Elfreth introduced legislation to expand the Board of Regents' membership and implement additional oversight reforms. The bill passed both chambers unanimously and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 30, 2019.\n\nDuring her 2024 congressional campaign, Elfreth campaigned for school board candidates running against candidates endorsed by , saying that she viewed the \"threat Moms for Liberty poses to our boards of education as one of the greatest threats to democracy.\" In October 2024, after '''' reported that Anne Arundel County school board candidate Chuck Yocum had a history of child sexual abuse charges stemming from his teaching job at , Elfreth called for Yocum to drop out of the school board race.\n\n\nWhile a student at Towson University, Elfreth testified in support of a bill to increase polling places at college campuses and make it easier for college students to register to vote.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Elfreth introduced legislation to create an \"Office of Digital Inclusion\" in the . The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 13, 2021. She also introduced legislation that would require the state's Commission on Environmental Justice and sustainable Communities to \"reflect the racial, gender, ethnic, and geographic diversity of the state\". The bill passed and became law on May 30, 2021.\n\nAlso in 2021, Elfreth introduced the \"Student and Military Voter Empowerment Act\", which would require s to create websites to provide students with voting information and allow military members to register to vote using their  . The bill passed and became law without Governor 's signature on May 30, 2021.\n\nDuring debate on a bill that would allow the Maryland State Board of Elections to tabulate mail-in ballots before election day in 2022, Elfreth was one of two Democratic state senators to vote for a Republican amendment that would have limited people to picking up and delivering only 10 ballots for other voters.\n\n\n, 2022]]\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Elfreth proposed legislation to allow jurisdictions to create Resilience Authorities to provide funding to large infrastructure projects related to , , and . She also co-sponsored legislation to expand the public's role in rehabilitation projects in the  resurfacing project.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Elfreth introduced various environmental bills, including:\n* Senate Bill 62, which would create the position of Chief Resilience Officer within the \n* Senate Bill 319, which would expand the state's clean energy loan program to include  projects,  projects, and  projects\n* Senate Bill 119, which would establish a fund to reduce pollution in Maryland waterways\n* Senate Bill 195, which would require Maryland to switch to safer alternatives in  and ban  chemicals in \n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Elfreth introduced legislation that would require the Maryland State Retirement and Pensions System to consider climate change as a financial factor when making investment decisions. The bill passed and became law on April 9, 2022.\n\nIn 2023, Elfreth introduced a bill to establish a State Disaster Recovery Fund to help jurisdictions recover from natural disasters. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Elfreth was one of three senators to vote against a bill to ease restrictions around backup generators for s in Maryland.\n\n\nIn June 2023, Elfreth spoke in support of the Gun Safety Act, which increased the requirements and fees to obtain handgun permits and limited where gun owners could carry their weapons. During the 2024 legislative session, Elfreth introduced a bill to levy an eleven percent excise tax on firearm sales to fund the state's trauma system.\n\n\nElfreth supports a  to the  and strengthening . She opposes conditioning U.S. aid to , saying that she believed that \"all nations have a responsibility in supporting humanitarian aid to the region as the only way to begin the very long road towards a peaceful two-state solution\". During her 2024 congressional campaign, she supported a permanent ceasefire in the  conditioned on the return of  and the provision of additional humanitarian aid, but criticized \"unbalanced and nuanced\" state and local resolutions calling for a ceasefire. She also expressed concerns with some of Israel Prime Minister 's public statements during the war, but said that conversations on Israel's leadership and governance should be handled in private between it and the United States.\n\nElfreth traveled to Israel for the first time in July 2023, visiting locations including an  battery, the , religious sites, and a  tunnel on the Lebanese border. She met with a  official during her visit, after which she expressed concerns with \"some verbiage\" used by the official and an evasive answer about the authority's failure to hold elections in the region.\n\nElfreth supported an amendment introduced by U.S. senator  that would condition U.S. foreign aid on a country's compliance with international law, though a spokesperson clarified her belief \"that Israel is acting in accordance with these laws\" and later reiterated that she would only support requiring countries to comply with existing conditions as opposed to establishing new conditions.\n\n\nIn June 2024, Elfreth signed onto a Maryland Healthcare for All pledge to support legislation to extend -provided healthcare benefits beyond 2025.\n\n\nElfreth condemned the , saying that those who participated in the attack should be referred to as terrorists.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Elfreth introduced legislation to provide Maryland workers with up to 12 weeks of , funded by a  shared equally by the worker and employer.\n\n\nElfreth supports , describing access to abortion services as a matter of economics. During the 2024 legislative session, she introduced a bill to provide abortion clinics in Maryland with $500,000 in grants toward physical security infrastructure.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Elfreth introduced a resolution to designate June 28 as \"Freedom of the Press Day\" in honor of the five killed at the . The bill passed unanimously and became law on April 18, 2019. In June 2019, Governor Hogan signed a proclamation declaring June 28 to be \"Freedom of the Press Day\" in Maryland.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Elfreth introduced legislation to provide students access to  in school bathrooms. The bill passed and became law on May 30, 2021.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Elfreth introduced the \"Great Maryland Outdoors Act\", which would increase staffing, expand recreational amenities, and improve equity of access for . The bill passed and became law on April 24, 2022. She also introduced the \"David Perez Military Heroes Act\", which provides state funding for psychedelic research to help military veterans with , which passed and became law.\n\nIn October 2022, after '''' published a report accusing  manager Michael Browning of presiding over a toxic work environment that senior park service officials had failed to address despite receiving multiple employee complaints since 2015, Elfreth and House majority leader  wrote to Maryland Secretary of Natural Resources  calling for an independent review into the ' handling of employee reports. Haddaway-Riccio did not address legislators' call for an independent investigation in her response letter, instead saying that the department's human resources division was investigating the misconduct allegations \"in consultation with the Maryland Department of Budget and Management and the Office of the Attorney General\" and that she had taken \"appropriate actions to address the situation\" by firing assistant Gunpowder park manager Dean Hughes and state park superintendent Nita Settina.\n\n\nIn March 2023, Elfreth was one of five Democrats to vote for an amendment to decouple the state's  from inflation. The amendment was rejected by the Maryland Senate in a 20-27 vote.\n\nDuring her 2024 congressional campaign, Elfreth said she supported .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Stephen M. Waugh''' (born June 16, 1964) is an American politician who was a member of the  representing  in  and  counties from 2015 to 2019.\n\n\nWaugh was born in , on June 16, 1964. He graduated from the  before attending the , where he earned a  degree in aerospace engineering in 1986. After graduating, Waugh served in the , serving as an  pilot, aviation safety officer, and forward air controller, and attaining the rank of chief of combat in the  before leaving the Marine Corps in 2006 to attend the , where he earned a  degree in technology management.\n\n\nAfter graduating from the University of Phoenix, Waugh worked as the director of Bowhead Support Services' Patuxent River Business Unit from 2006 to 2007, afterwards working as a systems engineer at the  in southern Maryland. He served as an alternate member of the Calvert County Board of Appeals from 2011 to 2014.\n\nWaugh first became involved with politics in 2008 after what he described as the country taking a \"pretty serious left turn\". He unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland Senate in District 27 in , losing to incumbent state senator  with 48.5 percent of the vote.\n\n\nWaugh was elected to the Maryland Senate in  after defeating Dyson. He was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 14, 2015. He served as a member of the Health and Environmental Affairs Committee during his entire tenure, including on its comptroller issues, education, and health subcommittees. Waugh was considered one of the most effective Republican legislators in the  during his tenure.\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Waugh introduced a bill to ban wind energy projects east of the , which he said would interfere with the air station's specialized radar system used to test the stealth capabilities of aircraft.\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Waugh opposed bills that would require the  to prioritize road construction projects using a scoring system, give the  the ability to pursue cases against  policies, and ban fracking in Maryland. He also criticized President 's proposal to cut all funding for the Chesapeake Bay Program in his .\n\nIn August 2017, following the  in , Waugh supported the removal of the  from the , saying that he didn't want it to \"become a rallying cry for white nationalists\".\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Waugh criticized a bill to remove the  from hearing funding appeals from local officials, calling it the \"great mistake of this session\". He also introduced a bill to repeal sections of the Firearms Safety Act of 2013, including a ban on the sale of s. Following the , Waugh led four bills aimed at addressing school safety, including one that would put armed s in every public school. Waugh also voted to override Governor 's veto on a bill prohibiting colleges from asking about criminal history on student applications, the only Republican member of the Maryland General Assembly to do so.\n\nWaugh ran for a second term in . Governor Hogandispleased with Waugh's legislative record, including on votes for legislation backed by Senate President  and veto overrides during the 2018 legislative sessionsupported his opponent, former Maryland Natural Resources police officer , who defeated Waugh in the Republican primary election on June 26, 2018, by a margin of 752 votes. Waugh was the only Republican state senator to lose their primary election that year.\n\nIn a November 2018 interview with '''', Waugh blamed Hogan for his loss, saying that his endorsement led to a tidal shift in party loyalty that overwhelmed his campaign. Following his defeat, he applied to a doctorate program in engineering.\n\n\nWaugh is married to his wife, Myra. Together, they have two children.\n\nIn November 2011, Waugh and his son were involved in a plane crash at the Chesapeake Ranch Estates airport in , that left him with multiple broken bones. The  conducted an investigation into the plane crash, concluding that the crash occurred because of runway lights shining through the tall tree surrounding the runway, providing a \"false sense of safe approach\", and Waugh dragging the plane in \"a little bit low\" for a shallow landing. Waugh also blamed the environmental conditions at the airport, saying that a high overcast blocked all moonlight and starlight, creating a so-called black hole effect. In February 2012, Waugh's son received a \"hero proclamation\" from the Calvert County Board of County Commissioners for saving his father's life by pulling him from the aircraft following its crash.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Angela Celestine Gibson''' (born March 21, 1949) is an American politician who was a Democratic member of the  from  from 2017 to 2019. Gibson was appointed to the House on February 24, 2017, to replace , who resigned upon appointment to State Senate.\n\n\nGibson was born in , where she graduated from . She later attended , where she earned a  degree. She is the president of the Epsilon Omega chapter of the  sorority.\n\nGibson first got involved in politics in 1987, working as a spokeswoman for the  until 2017. In 2006, she became a member of the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee.\n\n\nIn February 2017, following the appointment of state delegate Nathaniel Oaks to the , Gibson applied to fill the vacancy left by his resignation from the Maryland House of Delegates. Fellow members of the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate Gibson to succeed Oaks. On February 24, 2017, Governor  appointed Gibson to the Maryland House of Delegates. She was sworn in later that day, and served as a member of the Judiciary Committee. Gibson remained the chairwoman of the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee during her tenure in the House of Delegates.\n\nGibson sought re-election in , during which she ran on a ticket with state delegate . She was defeated in the Democratic primary on June 26, 2018, placing fourth with 11.7 percent of the vote.\n\nFollowing her defeat in the Democratic primary, Gibson continued to serve as a member on the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee. In May 2023, following the appointment of state delegate  as the Assistant Secretary for the , Gibson applied to fill the vacancy left by his resignation in the Maryland House of Delegates. In June 2023, the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee voted to send Governor  the names of both Gibson and civil rights attorney  for consideration to fill the vacancy. On June 18, 2023, Moore appointed Ruff to fill the vacancy.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Theodore J. Sophocleus''' (May 28, 1939 – June 8, 2018) was an  from  and a member of the . Before seeking political office, he was a pharmacist and a drug store chain executive.\n\n\nSophocleus was born in , on May 29, 1939, the son of Greek-American immigrants John and Despina Sophocleus. As a youth, he lived in the city's  neighborhood and attended  in Baltimore.  After high school, he graduated from the , where he earned his Bachelor of Science degree in Pharmacy in 1962.\n\n\nAfter graduation, Sophocleus worked for the  chain from 1960 to 1977, rising to an executive position. He subsequently was an executive with a Texas drug store chain before moving to , where he opened his own pharmacy.\n\n\nSophocleus first served two terms on the elected County Council of , beginning in 1982. He took an active role on his constituents' behalf regarding  issues at  in Linthicum. He ran unsuccessfully for Anne Arundel County Executive in 1990 and 1994.\n\n\nSophocleus began serving in the  in 1993, when he was appointed by Governor  to replace Tyras S. Athey (who had resigned). Sophocleus was elected in his own right in 1998 and was serving in his fourth full term in the House of Delegates at the time of his death, representing Maryland's District 32 in .\n\nHe served on many committees, including the Appropriations Committee, and was also Deputy Majority Whip.\n\n\nWhile in the House, Delegate Sophocleus:\n::*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n::*voted against Tax Reform Act of 2007 to increase sales tax by 20% (HB2)\n::* opposed \n::* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20&nbsp;years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000\n::* voted in 2007 for a Maryland version of \"\" (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25&nbsp;years in state prison\n::* voted in 2008 for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000&nbsp;unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192&nbsp;arrests\n::* voted in 2009 for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years\n::* also voted in 2009 for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet\n::* between 2015-2018, he annually voted to support classroom teachers, public schools, police and hospitals in Anne Arundel County. Since 2002, funding to schools across the State has increased 82%, resulting in Maryland being ranked top in the nation for K-12 education.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 14, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 13, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 13, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\nSophocleus died on June 8, 2018, while hospitalized in Baltimore. He was survived by his wife, Alice. Upon his death, both fellow Democrats and Republicans in the House of Delegates lauded his bipartisan helpfulness. Said one Republican Delegate: \"Ted Sophocleus was one of the finest people I've met in public office. He was honest, true to himself and his constituents, and loved his family dearly.\"\n\n\nSophocleus was inducted by his alma mater into the Patterson Park High School \"Alumni Hall of Fame\". He was honored by the Maryland State's Attorneys' Association as \"Legislator of the Year\" in 2004. The Maryland Network Against Domestic Violence also named him \"Legislator of the Year\", in 2005.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She was nominated to the Bureau in September 2005 by  . On January 4, 2006, Bush placed her in office by way of a , bypassing the need for  confirmation.  Her confirmation was unlikely, given strong objections by some senators. Sauerbrey's recess appointment caused some controversy; however, her experience as minority leader in the  and managing a complex  project helped rally others to her cause.\n\n\nSauerbrey was born in Baltimore, Maryland, the only child of Ethel, a secretary/stenographer, and Edgar Richmond, a steelworker for  at . She is a 1955 graduate of  and a 1959 graduate of , and was a teacher before entering politics. In 1959, she married Wilmer J.E. Sauerbrey, who is credited with having introduced her to conservative politics.\n\nFrom 1978 to 1994, she was a  member of the , and served as  from 1986 to 1994. Her committee assignments included the Appropriations Committee; Subcommittee on Education and Transportation; Ways and Means and Economic Matters.\n\nIn 1990, she was elected as the national chairman of the , serving in 1991 when President  spoke to the organization.\n\nSauerbrey ran unsuccessfully for  twice, in  and . She was defeated by Democrat  both times, the first time by a very narrow margin.  The 1994 election was in doubt as charges of voter fraud led to a lawsuit by the Sauerbrey campaign to overturn the election, which was ultimately unsuccessful.\n\n (center), President of the International  Human Rights and Democracy Foundation, and  (right), General Secretary of the , 2006.]]\n\nIn 2002,  nominated Sauerbrey to be Representative to the , of the  of the , with the rank of Ambassador. In that post, Sauerbrey focused mostly on three issues: the need for more education for women, the importance of empowering women economically and politically, and protection of the .\n\nIn January 2006, while the Senate was recessed, President Bush appointed Sauerbrey as . It was reported then that this and other such appointments would end at the conclusion of the congressional session in January 2007.\n\nIn a January 15, 2007, hearing before the , Democratic lawmakers and advocates for refugees called for increased help for fleeing Iraqis. Sauerbrey said a UN-predicted wave of refugees did not occur right after the U.S.-led invasion of Iraq and was instead occurring at that present time.\n\nSauerbrey was inducted into the  in 2013 and has written opinion articles published by '''' as recently as 2017.\n\nIn November 2020, amid , Sauerbrey expressed no regrets about challenging her 1994 election outcome, saying, \"I think when you have a pretty good indication that the election is rigged, you should fight\". Sauerbrey also questioned the transparency, accuracy, and timeliness involved with counting mail-in ballots.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*, ''The New York Times'', October 11, 2005\n* ''The Washington Post'', October 26, 2005\n* ''The Washington Times'', October 25, 2005\n* ''National Review Online'', November 14, 2005\n\n\n* &nbsp;– Sauerbrey's blog\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''William J. Frank''' (born February 4, 1960) is an American politician who served as the deputy secretary of the Maryland Department of Disabilities from 2015 to 2018. A member of the , he previously served as a member of the  representing the  from 2003 to 2015.\n\n\nWilliam Frank is a member of the , representing District 42, which covers a part of .  Prior to 2002, District 42 was represented by Democrats , , and .  However, after the district lines were redrawn, McIntosh moved to District 43 and Rosenberg moved to District 41, where they both won reelection.  On the other hand, Campbell remained in District 42, but was defeated by a host of new Republicans, including Frank, , and .\n\nIn 2006, Frank won reelection, along with . Incumbent Trueschler did not run for reelection.  In his stead, Democrat Stephen W. Lafferty won his seat.\n\n\nFrank attended  in .  After high school, he went to  in , graduating cum laude in 1982 with his B.A. in political science.  Frank returned to college to get his master's degree.  He graduated from the , receiving his M.A.S. (administrative science) in 1992.\n\n\nSoon after college, Frank began working as vice-president of marketing for the Maryland Credit Union League , working there until 1989.  When he left MCUL, he joined Allfirst Bank (which was acquired in a spin-off from  by ), first as an assistant vice-president of the Public Affairs Division from 1989 until 1996, and then as an assistant vice-president and relationship manager from 1996 until 1999.  In 1999, Frank was hired as a development and marketing consultant for the  and continues to work there.\n\nFrank has been an active member in his community.  He served as a volunteer cook for the Christopher Place Employment Academy  from 1988 until 1994. Additionally, he served on the Board of Directors for Action for the Homeless (now Center for Poverty Solutions ) from 1992 until 1996.\n\nFrank is a member of the Fr. O'Neill Council for the  since 1994. Locally, he served on the board of governors for the Rodgers Forge Community Association , from 1995 until 1997.  He was a board member for the Home School Association for the Immaculate Conception School  from 1998 until 2000.  Frank has served on the President's Council of  since 1998, and the Marketing Advisory Council since 2000. He is on the board of directors of the Independent College Fund of Maryland , and is a member of the Dulaney Valley Improvement Association  in , and the North Central Republican Club.\n\nAs a Republican member of the , Frank has served as chief deputy minority whip since 2005.  He is a member of the Judiciary Committee and the Appropriations Committee, in addition to various subcommittees.  Since being elected to the House of Delegates, he has been the deputy minority whip (2003) and the assistant minority whip (2003–05).\n\n\n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42''' Retrieved on Oct. 1, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42''' Retrieved on Oct. 1, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa14007.html\n* https://web.archive.org/web/20070906044522/http://www.billfrankfordelegate.com/\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michelle Laskin Hettleman''' (born August 26, 1964) is an American politician who has served in the  representing  since 2020. A member of the , she previously represented the district in the  from 2015 to 2020.\n\n\nHettleman was born in , on August 26, 1964. She is Jewish. Her grandparents came to the United States as refugees to escape .\n\nHettleman spent her childhood moving between three different places before settling in the Baltimore area shortly before she turned seven years old. She graduated from  and later attended , where she earned a  degree in political science in 1986. After graduating, Hettleman briefly moved to  before moving back to , and eventually to .\n\nHettleman first became involved in politics while at Northwestern, where she campaigned for 's . She worked as a scheduler for U.S. Representative 's . Afterwards, Hettleman worked as a legislative aide to U.S. Representative  until 1990, when she became the director of government relations for various Jewish organizations, including the Baltimore Jewish Council, the , and the . She eventually worked as a campaign manager for Cardin's U.S. Senate campaigns in  and  .\n\n\n\nHettleman was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. She was a member of the Appropriations Committee during her entire tenure. In 2017, Hettleman said she considered challenging state senator  in the , but instead ran for a second term.\n\nDuring the , Hettleman endorsed  and later served as a delegate to the , pledged to Clinton. She later served as a delegate to the , pledged to , and the , pledged to .\n\nIn December 2019, following the resignation of state senator Robert Zirkin, Hettleman said that she would apply to serve the remainder of Zirkin's term in the Maryland Senate. Her candidacy was backed by the Baltimore County Democratic Party. In January 2020, the Baltimore County Democratic Central Committee unanimously voted to nominate her to fill the vacancy, defeating state delegate  and community activist Alan Zukerberg. Governor  appointed her to the seat a few days later, and she was sworn in on February 3.\n\nHettleman was a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee until 2023, and has since served on the Budget and Taxation Committee. In October 2023, following the resignation of , Senate President  appointed her to serve as the chair of the Rules Committee.\n\nIn January 2024, Hettleman, along with state delegate  and 20 other Jewish lawmakers, created the Maryland Jewish Legislative Caucus.\n\n\n\nHettleman is married to her husband, Jeffrey. Together, they have two adult children and belong to the . Kalman \"Buzzy\" Hettleman, who was the state Secretary of Human Resources under Governor , is her .\n\n\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Hettleman introduced legislation that would allow pharmacists to provide patients with s without a prescription, which passed and became law. In 2023, amid the 's decision in '''', she introduced legislation that would require patients to provide consent before their records about reproductive health care could cross state lines. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn January 2019, Hettleman was one of nine Maryland lawmakers to add their names to a manifesto signed by 326 state legislators to reaffirm their commitment to protecting abortion rights.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Hettleman introduced legislation to prohibit  near residential communities. She later said that she supported hemp expansion, but said that health concerns separated it from .\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Hettleman introduced legislation to establish the Maryland Corps, which would enable high school graduates to do a gap year in exchange for job training, a $15 minimum wage, and a $6,000 educational grant. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn March 2019, Hettleman joined House Republicans in voting for an amendment to restore budget cuts to the Broadening Options and Opportunities for Students Today (BOOST) program, which provides state-funded scholarships to low-income students to attend private schools. In October, she penned a letter to the  calling for an expansion of its curriculum on .\n\nDuring her candidacy for the Maryland Senate in December 2019, Hettleman said she would support increasing school construction and implementing the .\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Hettleman introduced a bill that would allow people to opt into a \"do not sell\" registry that would prohibit gun dealerships from selling them firearms.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Hettleman voted for the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults.\n\nIn 2020, Hettleman introduced legislation to allow the state to open s.\n\nIn February 2022, Hettleman spoke in support of the Time to Care Act, which would create a state paid family leave program.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Hettleman introduced legislation that would provide low-income tenants with a  in eviction cases. In 2022, she introduced bills that would require judges to delay eviction proceedings if a tenant applies for rent assistance, which passed and was vetoed by Governor .\n\n\nIn 2018, Hettleman supported a bill to raise the state's minimum wage to . During debate on legislation to do so in 2019, she considered introducing an amendment to index the state's minimum wage to inflation, but ultimately decided against doing so, saying it \"wasn't the right opportunity\" to introduce floor amendments.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Hettleman introduced legislation that would provide Baltimore County librarians with . The bill passed and became law without Governor 's signature. In January 2020, Baltimore County library employees voted to unionize under the .\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Hettleman supported legislation that would ban the state from contracting with companies that support the  movement.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Hettleman introduced legislation that would require state police to keep s for 20 years, which passed and became law. She also introduced a bill requiring kits to be tested within 150 days, which died in committee. In 2019, she introduced legislation requiring police to test previously untested rape kits, which passed and became law. The bill's implementation was delayed after Governor  declined to distribute the $3 million in funding to assist with kit testing, which Hettleman condemned. In 2023, she introduced a bill that would require hospitals to extend the time police need to keep rape kits to 75 years and would allow patients and their representatives to track the progress of kit testing. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Hettleman introduced a bill to allow  people to change their names without advertising it in newspapers. The bill passed and became law without Governor 's signature.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

McFadden''' (born August 3, 1946) is an  who represented district 45 in the  from January 11, 1995 to January 9, 2019, and who was the Senate's  from January 10, 2007 to January 9, 2019.\n\n\nBorn in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, August 3, 1946, McFadden attended high school at the , graduating in 1964.     "pages": }\n\n'''Andrew A. Serafini''' (born March 9, 1962) is an American politician from  and a member of the . He was a member of the  from District 2, which covers parts of , from February 2015 to August 2020. He was also a member of the  from District 2A from March 2008 to February 2015.\n\n\nSerafini graduated from  in .  After high school, he went to  in south central  where he received a degree in Business Administration in 1983.  He also briefly played football there.\n\n\nAfter college, Serafini was a pricing analyst for  from 1984 until 1985.  He later attended the College of Financial Planning in  where he received his certified financial planning designation in 1988. He was a financial advisor for  from 1985 until 1990. Since that time he has been the President of Serafini Financial Services, Inc. in Hagerstown.\n\nIn addition to his work, Serafini was also active in many organizations.  He was the chair of the Board of Trustees for Grace Academy (where he coached the boys' varsity soccer team to a national title), in Hagerstown from 2005 until 2007 and has been the vice-chair since 2008. He was a former member of the Board of Trustees for the Maryland/Southern Delaware Chapter of the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation. He was the District Chair of the Christian Business Men's Committee, and was the Finance Campaign Chair for John F. Barr, the President of the Board of County Commissioners of Washington County in 2006.\n\n\nSerafini took the oath of office to become a member of House of Delegates on the afternoon of March 7, 2008. He was assigned to the Ways and Means Committee and the Environmental Matters Committee.  He was also a member of the Washington County and s as well as a member of the Maryland Rural Caucus.\n\nOn February 2, 2015, Serafini was sworn into the Maryland State Senate to replace Christopher Shank who resigned to become director of the Governor's Office of Crime Control and Prevention.\n\nOn July 30, 2020, Maryland's Senate Republican Caucus announced Serafini was resigning effective August 1. Serafini cited long hours and stress, the demands of his financial adviser job, and wanting to spend more time with his family.\n\n\n*'''2018 Race for Maryland Senate – District 2'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House Of Delegates – District 2A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House Of Delegates – District 2A'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Bryan Warner Simonaire''' (born September 6, 1963) is an American politician who serves as a  representing District 31, which encompasses much of northern 's  suburbs. A member of the , he served as the minority leader of the Maryland Senate from 2020 to 2023.\n\n\nSimonaire was born in . He graduated from  in 1985, receiving a Bachelor of Science degree in computer science, and from , where he earned a Master of Science degree in engineering in 2005. He is a member of .\n\nAfter graduating from Bob Jones, Simonaire has worked as a  for  (now  since its acquisition in 1995). In 2002, he founded Heroes-at-Home, a web-based program that helps the needy.\n\nSimonaire became involved in politics in 2005, when he joined the North Count Republican Club's board of directors. He entered the race for state Senate in District 31 later that year, seeking to succeed retiring  state senator  and running on a \"common sense, conservative\" platform that included opposition to . The district was targeted by the , which saw the election as an opportunity to make legislative gains. Simonaire won the Republican primary in September 2006, and later won the general election on November 7, 2006, defeating Democratic state delegate Walter J. Shandrowsky by 659 votes, or a margin of 1.72 percent. It was the closest election in the s.\n\n\n\nSimonaire was sworn into the  on January 10, 2007. He was initially a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee from 2007 to 2010, afterwards serving on the Health and Environmental Affairs Committee until 2022. Since 2023, he has served on the Education, Energy, and the Environment Committee.\n\nSimonaire endorsed  in the  and later served a Romney delegate to the .\n\nIn 2014, Simonaire proposed a constitutional amendment to remove legislative leaders' ability to remove voting powers from any member of the . The amendment was introduced after state Delegate  was stripped of his voting powers and committee assignments after being sentenced to 30 weekends in jail for driving under the influence. In 2016, Simonaire introduced the \"Dwyer amendment\", which would have prevented Senate president  from removing a member's voting powers. The proposed rule change was rejected in a 11-31 vote.\n\nIn October 2020, Simonaire was elected as the minority leader of the Maryland Senate, which was seen by the media as the Senate Republican caucus becoming more conservative as to push back on the perceived leftward shift of the  following the election of  as Senate president. In this capacity, Simonaire sought to allow his party to make their own committee assignments and oversaw the party's state Senate campaign in , in which the party lost two seats in the Maryland Senate. Following the 2022 elections, Senate Republicans opted to elect  as minority leader.\n\nSimonaire endorsed Maryland Secretary of Commerce  in the . After she was defeated by far-right state delegate  in the Republican primary, he declined to endorse or campaign with Cox, instead focusing on competitive Senate elections.\n\n\nSimonaire is married and has seven children. He lives in , and attends  churches.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Simonaire spoke against a bill to ban  on minors, arguing that it would dissuade teens from seeking counseling. His daughter, , a member of the , spoke in support of the bill and accused her father of seeking conversion therapy for her after she  as  in 2015. Simonaire disputed his daughter's story in interviews with the media, saying that he had recommended her  after she approached him for advice with her depression and anxiety, but added that he disagreed with her \"lifestyle\".\n\n\n\nIn 2009, Simonaire said he would vote to repeal the  if legislators passed a constitutional amendment to ban . He later voted for an amendment to the death penalty repeal bill to limit the death penalty's use rather than fully repeal it, which passed 25-21. During the 2013 legislative session, Simonaire voted against repealing the death penalty.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Simonaire implored legislators to pass a  bill introduced by Governor . He also expressed willingness to work with Democrats to pass a bipartisan judicial transparency bill.\n\n\nSimonaire opposes the , calling for its repeal during the 2021 legislative session and comparing them to the Bridge of Excellence education reforms in 2002. He supports legislation requiring the  to prepare a problem gambling curriculum in schools.\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Simonaire said he opposed , a bill that extended  for .\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Simonaire introduced a bill that would force the county Board of Education to vote on certain curriculum items if a petition got the signatures of at least three percent of parents.\n\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Simonaire testified against a bill to restore voting rights for ex-felons.\n\nIn May 2020, Simonaire asked Governor  to call a special session to pass election integrity bills, expressing concern that the use of  in the  would lead to voter fraud.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Simonaire introduced a package of election reform bills, including  and signature verification on mail-in ballots, citing what he called \"major deficiencies\" in the . The package failed to move out of committee, and many bills from the package were reintroduced in 2022. He also supported a bill to shift control of local election boards to whichever party had a majority of registered voters in each jurisdiction, and sought to amend a bill to expand early voting centers to require local boards of elections to consider \"geographical distance\" in deciding where to locate early voting centers.\n\nSimonaire opposed the congressional maps drawn by the Legislative Redistricting Advisory Committee (LRAC), of which he was a member, instead supporting maps drawn by Governor 's Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission. During the LRAC's map drawing process, he pressed for a bipartisan map drawing process and hoped legislators would produce a single map, but predicted that Democrats on the commission would pass their own map. He criticized the commission's final congressional and legislative maps as \"seriously ed\". After Judge  struck down the state's congressional maps in March 2022, Simonaire criticized Democrats for not including Republicans in the process of drafting a new map.\n\n\nSimonaire is an  and has expressed willingness to work with legislators to pass a bipartisan climate bill. He voted in favor of bills to ban  and  in Maryland.\n\nSimonaire was critical of  and introduced legislation in 2013 to offset the fee in Anne Arundel County. In 2015, he voted in favor of a bill to make the rain tax optional for Maryland's largest jurisdictions.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Simonaire expressed concern with the Climate Solutions Now Act, which he said would force jurisdictions to choose between planting more trees and protecting local sewage projects. After it was reintroduced in 2022, he objected to provisions that would require large buildings to become carbon neutral by 2040 and expressed that legislators should instead focus on climate solutions \"starting at the regional level\".\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Simonaire voted against the Firearms Safety Act, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nSimonaire is a , opposing  and same-sex marriage, citing religious beliefs.\n\nSimonaire opposed the , reading '''' on the Senate floor to protest the bill and warning that \"young, impressionable students\" would be taught the \"homosexual worldview\" if the bill passed. He also unsuccessfully sought to amend the bill to allow religious adoption agencies to refuse services to same-sex couples. In 2015, he voted against a bill that would allow same-sex couples to use donor sperm for .\n\nIn 2014, Simonaire said he opposed a bill to prohibit discrimination against  people. In 2021, he was the lone vote against a bill to allow transgender people to change their names without advertising it in newspapers.\n\nIn 2015, Simonaire introduced a  that would allow terminally ill patients to try experimental drugs not approved by the . In 2019, he spoke against the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Simonaire introduced legislation to revise a translation of the  to \"Strong deeds, gentle words\", saying that he believed that the current meaning of the motto (\"Manly deeds, womanly words\") was sexist.\n\nIn 2022, Simonaire downplayed the impact of the 's decision in '''', which overturned '''', calling it a \"Democratic ploy\" to energize voters. In 2023, during debate on a bill creating a  to codify abortion access rights into the , Simonaire compared abortion to the death penalty and sought to amend the bill to prohibit abortions after , which failed by a vote of 13-33.\n\n\nIn 2013, Simonaire said he opposed a bill to provide $450,000 in tax breaks to .\n\nIn 2021, Simonaire spoke against legislation to extend the state's  to . He also opposed legislation to allow counties to implement es and to impose a tax on , and unsuccessfully attempted to amend the tax bill to prevent large companies from increasing prices for consumers or small businesses to pay for the tax.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Simonaire supported a bill to cut taxes on s and implored legislators to pass additional tax cuts.\n\n\nIn March 2024, following the , Simonaire and state senator  introduced a bill that would allow the governor to declare a year-long state of emergency after damage to critical infrastructure, though it would eliminate the authority to seize private property for government use, as now allowed under a state of emergency. The bill was withdrawn following discussions with the Moore administration.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
