    "pages": }\n'''Vaughn Morton Stewart III''' (born November 15, 1988) is an American attorney and politician. He is a member of the , representing  in  since 2019.\n\n\nStewart was born on November 15, 1988, in  to father Vaughn Stewart Jr., who served as the mayor of Anniston from 2012 to 2016, and mother Eva Sproull Andrews. He graduated from  and later attended the , where he earned a  in political science in 2011, and , where he earned a  degree in 2014.\n\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Stewart moved to , where he worked as a law clerk for U.S. District Court Judge  and as a legal intern for the . He later worked as a summer associate with  and on  matters, such as legal assistance to refugees. In the summer of 2011, Stewart worked as a staff writer for ''''.\n\nStewart first became involved in politics in 2015 as a policy director for Maryland state senator 's  in . He later served as the treasurer and precinct chairperson of the District 19 Democratic Club, and on the boards of the Action Committee for Transit and the Montgomery County Renters Alliance.\n\nIn August 2017, Stewart declared his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 19. He came in third place in the Democratic primary, receiving 16.9 percent of the vote. He won the general election with 24 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nStewart was sworn into the  on January 9, 2019. He has served as member of the Environment and Transportation Committee since 2019, including on its environment subcommittee from 2019 to 2022 and its transportation subcommittee since 2023. In 2022,   appointed Stewart to lead the newly created \"Progressive Policy Forum\" within the House Democratic Caucus. In 2023, Jones appointed Stewart as one of two Chief Majority Whips for the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\n\nStewart married Alexandra Tucker Stewart, an attorney at WilmerHale, on May 29, 2016. Their wedding was officiated by U.S. Court of Appeals judge . Together, they live in  and have one child.\n\nStewart is a two-time cancer survivor. He was diagnosed with  in 2007 and  in 2017. Both cancers have since gone into remission.\n\n\n\nIn between  treatments, Stewart studied health care policy. He supports proposals to regulate  manufacturers like  and to create a statewide  system.\n\n\nStewart introduced legislation during the 2019 legislative session that would increase  and s. The bill would ease  for , introduce new real-estate transaction fees to fund  projects, and allow tenants to terminate leases in cases of unsafe housing or harassment by landlords. The bill was reintroduced during the 2020 and 2022 legislative sessions.\n\nIn March 2019, Stewart voted in favor of legislation that would require landlords to . The bill was rejected by the House Environment and Transportation Committee in a 2-17 vote.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Stewart introduced a bill that would require landlords that own properties that use  to test for a series of contaminants every three years.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Stewart introduced legislation that would delay an eviction when a tenant can prove they have applied for rental assistance. The bill passed both chambers. He also introduced the \"Tenant Protection Act of 2022\", which establishes rules and procedures for landlords who give tenants ratio utility bills. The bill passed both chambers and became law without the governor's signature.\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Stewart introduced a bill to make it easier for tenants to put their rent payments in escrow if their landlord neglects life-threatening defects in their residence.\n\n\nStewart introduced the \"Dignity Not Detention Act\" during the 2021 legislative session, which prohibits jurisdictions from contracting with  to detain  in local jails. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor . The Legislature voted to override Hogan's veto on December 7, 2021.\n\n\nIn 2018, Vaughn supported the .\n\n\nStewart co-sponsored legislation introduced during the 2019 legislative session that would raise the state's minimum wage to .\n\n\nStewart introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session to create a multi-state compact to end  aimed at getting businesses aimed to move across state lines.\n\nIn February 2020, Stewart co-sponsored legislation that would investigate the possibility of distributing .\n\nStewart introduced legislation during the 2022 legislative session that would prohibit the  from using apps that automatically destroy text messages. He also introduced legislation that would amend the  to set up an  elected position in Maryland, which would \"receive, respond to, and investigate ethics complains\" against state officials. The bill did not receive a committee vote.\n\nIn May 2022, Stewart attended a protest in  against the alleged mistreatment of hundreds of animals at Inotiv's Indiana drug toxicity lab.\n\n\nDuring the , Stewart ran to be a national delegate at the  pledged to .\n\nDuring the 2022 primaries in Maryland, Stewart endorsed  for ,  for , and  for .\n\n\nStewart supports increasing funding for  projects, including a proposal that would build a 27-mile monorail line between  and .\n\nStewart introduced legislation during the 2019 legislative session that would increase the minimum fine against drivers who fail to yield to a pedestrian to $150, with fines larger than the minimum amount going toward improving pedestrian safety. The bill passed and became law. He also introduced legislation that would require state-funded highway projects or projects built through  to go through environmental studies.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Alfred W. Redmer Jr.''' (born January 15, 1956) was a Maryland Insurance Commissioner and was the Republican nominee for  of  in 2018. He formerly served as a legislator in the , representing District 8 in Baltimore County, prior to being appointed Maryland Insurance Commissioner in 2003.\n\n\nA lifelong resident of Baltimore County, Redmer graduated from , which is in , a northeast area  suburb.  After high school he attended  in .  The American College is a college for life insurance s.\n\n\nAfter completing his education, Redmer founded Redmer Insurance & Investment Services. He was also the Marketing and public relations specialist for the Mather Companies. He was a trustee for the Council on Economic Education in Maryland.\n\n\nRedmer was a member of the Republican State Central Committee for 9th District in Baltimore County from 1978 to 1982. He was the co-chair of 's Presidential Campaign, 8th District, in 1980. He served on the campaign staff for U.S. Representative  in 1980 and again in 1982. He was elected as a delegate for the 2nd Congressional District for the .\n\n\nRedmer was first elected to the  in January 1990 to represent District 8 in Baltimore County, which covers the greater  area. During his tenure in the House of Delegates, Redmer served as Minority Leader from 2001 to 2003. Additionally, he was a member of several committees, including: the Environmental Matters Committee from 1991 until 2003, the Special Joint Committee on Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program from 1995 to 1998, the Joint Legislative Task Force on Organ and Tissue Donations during 1997 and 1998, and the Joint Committee on Health Care Delivery and Financing from 1999 until 2003.\n\nHe served on the Legislative Policy Committee from 2001 to 2003, the Spending Affordability Committee from 2001 until 2003, the Rules and Executive Nominations Committee from 2002 to 2003, the Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer in 2002, and again in 2003, and finally the Health and Government Operations Committee.\n\n\nIn 2003, Redmer was appointed Maryland Insurance Commissioner by Governor , resigning his seat in the House of Delegates. Redmer served in this position for two years before resigning to accept a position with , a health insurance company located in .\n\nRedmer was appointed to a second term as Maryland Insurance Commissioner by  (R) in January 2015.\n\nKathleen A. Birrane was appointed Maryland Insurance Administration Commissioner May 2020\nhttps://insurance.maryland.gov/AboutUs/Pages/Bio.aspx?Name=Birrane\n\n\nRedmer was a candidate for County Executive of Baltimore County in the . If elected, he would've been the first Republican County Executive in the heavily-Democratic county in 24&nbsp;years. He was endorsed by Gov. Hogan in the Republican primary. Redmer stressed his close relationship to Maryland's Republican governor, saying \"If you like Larry Hogan, I'm your guy\". His campaign advertising called for new schools and improved discipline in schools, while opposing low-income . He opposed Baltimore County being a  for illegal immigrants. Redmer pledged not to raise taxes and proposed consideration of a build-leaseback approach with private sector participation to finance the construction of replacements for three County high schools: , , and .\n\nRedmer was defeated by Democrat Johnny Olszewski in the general election.\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08''' Retrieved on Sept. 07, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08'''; retrieved September 7, 2007.\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08''' Retrieved on Nov. 10, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08''' Retrieved on Nov. 10, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1986 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08''' Retrieved on Nov. 11, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/former/html/msa12299.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Heather R. Mizeur''' ( ; born December 6, 1972) is an American politician who served as a member of the  from January 10, 2007 to January 14, 2015, representing the 20th district in . She was a candidate for  in the  but lost the Democratic primary to  . In 2022, she unsuccessfully ran for the  in , challenging incumbent U.S. Representative . She lost the general election to Harris by 11 points.\n\n\nMizeur was born on December 6, 1972, in . Her father, Dale Mizeur, was a welder at the  factory and a member of the . She attended Blue Mound High School, where she graduated as  of her graduating class. Mizeur attended the  as a  from 1991 to 1994, but dropped out after receiving a full-time job offer in the office of U.S. Representative , who she had interned for during her junior year.\n\nMizeur first got involved with politics when she was 15 years old, volunteering for the campaign of  . By age 23, she served as the legislative director for U.S. Representative . In 1998, Mizeur briefly left Capitol Hill to work for the National Association of Community Health Centers before returning to work for U.S. Senator  in 2003, later working on his  and writing his health care platform.\n\nIn November 2003, Mizeur was elected to the  City Council, succeeding outgoing councilwoman Carol Stewart. Around this time, she also became a  specializing in health care policy. In 2005, after state delegate  announced that he would run in the , Mizeur entered the race to succeed him. She won the Democratic primary, placing first with 21.9 percent of the vote, and later won the general election with 30.8 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nMizeur was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 10, 2007, and was re-elected for a second term in 2010. She was the first openly gay member of the Maryland General Assembly to have a spouse.\n\n\n* Member, Health and Government Operations Committee, 2007–2009 \n** Health Facilities & Occupations subcommittee, 2007–2009\n** Public Health & Long-Term Care subcommittee, 2007–2009\n* Member, House Emergency Medical Services Work Group, 2009–2012\n* Member, Appropriations Committee, 2009–2015 \n** Health & Human Resources subcommittee, 2009–2010\n** Oversight Committee on pensions, 2009–2015\n** Capital Budget subcommittee, 2011\n** Vice-chair, Education & economic development subcommittee, 2011–2015\n* Joint Committee on Transparency and Open Government, 2011–2014\n* Task Force to Study Court Decision regarding Pit Bulls, 2012\n\n\n\n* Vice-Chair, Land Use and Transportation Committee, , 2011–2015 (member, transportation committee, 2007–2015)\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2007–2015\n\n\n\n\n\nIn November 2012, Mizeur told '''' that she was \"taking a very serious look\" at running for governor in . She began fundraising for a potential bid in January 2013, before launching her campaign on July 16, 2013. Her running mate was  , a  pastor who backed the state's . If elected, she would have become Maryland's first female governor and the first openly gay person elected governor of any U.S. state.\n\nMizeur participated in the state's public financing system, making her the first gubernatorial candidate to limit their campaign spending since Republican  in .\n\nDuring the primary, Mizeur received endorsements from former U.S. Representative , , the , , and . She also refused to criticize any of the other candidates in the primary, instead pointing out the differences in their political positions.\n\nMizeur was defeated by   in the Democratic primary election on June 25, 2014, placing third with 21.7 percent of the vote. In her concession statement, she said that she needed some time to rest and \"collect my thoughts, my energy, and my strategic sense of where we take this next\". Mizeur later endorsed Brown in an op-ed to '''' in October 2014, in which she asked her supporters not to vote for her as a write-in candidate in the general election.\n\n\nFollowing her gubernatorial campaign, Mizeur did not run for re-election as a member of the . She also sold her home in Takoma Park to move to her farm in , where she and her wife grow organic s.\n\nMizeur was seen as a potential candidate in the , in which incumbent U.S. Senator  said she would not run for re-election. She later said on April 8, 2015, that she would not run for Senate in 2016, and later endorsed U.S. Representative  for the seat.\n\nIn October 2017, Mizeur launched a nonprofit organization named Soul Force Politics, which sought to increase involvement with politics and social justice in Maryland. A podcast by the same name was also launched alongside the nonprofit, which included episodes featuring , former U.S. Senator Barbara Mikulski, , '''' reporter Jenna Johnson, and Governor .\n\n\n\nIn January 2021, Mizeur announced that she would run for the United States House of Representatives in Maryland's 1st congressional district, challenging incumbent U.S. Representative , citing the  and Harris' involvement in refusing to certify the results of the .\n\nDuring the primary, Mizeur received endorsements from the entire Maryland House delegation (excluding Harris), most , U.S. Senator , and  mayor . She also received backing from the , , , Sierra Club, and EMILY's List.\n\nIn December 2021, the Maryland General Assembly redrew Maryland's congressional districts to make Maryland's 1st congressional district more competitive for Democrats, an effort that Mizeur cheered on and invited supporters to testify in support of. Mizeur's opponents accused her of seeking to influence the redistricting process and opposed the newly drawn maps.\n\nMizeur won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, defeating Democratic challenger R. David Harden with 68.8 percent of the vote. In the general election, Mizeur criticized Harris of refusing to debate her, noting that he had turned down multiple debate opportunities. Harris and Mizeur agreed to a televised debate moderated by Cecil TV, a community broadcasting outlet in , and to attend a forum hosted by the  chapter of the . The debate was held on October 27.\n\nMizeur was defeated by Harris in the general election, in which she received 43.1 percent of the vote to Harris' 54.4 percent. She conceded the election to Harris on the night of the election.\n\n\nMizeur is openly , having come out to her parents during her sophomore year of college. She married her wife Deborah in 2005, at a time when same-sex marriages were not recognized by the state of Maryland. The couple made their vows official in  after it briefly made same-sex marriage legal in 2008. The couple lived in Takoma Park while Mizeur served in the Maryland House of Delegates, but later moved to Chestertown, where she owns a 34-acre herb farm, named \"The Apotheosis of Washington\" after  that adorns the dome of the . Mizeur is .\n\n\nDuring her 2014 gubernatorial run, Mizeur was regarded as a , as well as the most liberal candidate in the Democratic primary.\n\n\nIn October 2013, Mizeur unveiled a plan to expand access to  by providing full-day pre-K programs to 4-year-olds and half-day programs to 3-year-olds in lower-income families. If enacted, the plan would have cost nearly $280 million annually.\n\nIn October 2017, Mizeur said she supported a plan to provide free  tuition to Maryland students.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Mizeur introduced a bill that would temporarily ban  in Maryland until the Maryland Department of the Environment completed a study to determine whether the practice endangers drinking water and public health. The bill was reintroduced in 2013 and 2014.\n\nIn June 2011, Governor  appointed Mizeur to a commission to investigate whether fracking endangered drinking water and public health. During the 2012 legislative session, she introduced a bill that would require natural gas companies to pay $15 per leased acre to fund the state's fracking study. In November 2014, after the study concluded and Governor O'Malley allowed energy companies to begin drilling in the state, Mizeur cautioned governor-elect  against acting in a rash manner when mapping out his administration's fracking proposals.\n\nIn September 2011, Mizeur introduced a Democratic National Committee resolution that called on President Obama to kill the . In November, Mizeur attended and spoke at the \"Surround the White House\" rally to protest the construction of the pipeline.\n\nIn February 2012, Mizeur said she supported imposing a  on natural gas of at least 10 percent, and was \"open-minded\" about a rate as high as 15 percent. She also said that the state should not allow drilling without first passing a \"competitive\" severance tax to ensure the state is able to oversee the industry.\n\nIn May 2014, Mizeur unveiled a plan to increase government oversight on utility companies by expanding the  membership, reforming the franchising process, and requiring power companies to renegotiate their licenses every 10 to 15 years.\n\nIn November 2022, Mizeur said she supported building s off the coast of Maryland, saying that she refused to believe it was an \"either-or choice\" in supporting wind energy or supporting commercial fishermen.\n\n\nIn November 2022, Mizeur said she supported providing immigrants with s to support Maryland's commercial fishing and aquaculture industry.\n\n\nDuring her gubernatorial campaign, Mizeur said she supported legalizing and taxing the sale of  in Maryland, and said she would use the revenue generated from its sale to fund expanded pre-kindergarten education. In April 2014, Mizeur voted for a bill to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana, instead making it a civil offense.\n\n\nIn November 2013, Mizeur said she would support raising the state's minimum wage to $16.70 by 2022. At the time, the state's minimum wage was $7.25 an hour. In May 2014, she introduced the Paycheck Fairness Act, a proposed bill that would require employers to justify differences in pay between men and women for similar jobs and treat  the same way under the law as . She also proposed a  program that would pay workers two-thirds their salary and up to $1,000 a week for up to six weeks.\n\nIn March 2014, Mizeur voted to increase the state's minimum wage from $7.25 an hour to $10.10 an hour by 2017.\n\n\nIn 2005, Mizeur ran for one of Maryland's four seats on the . She later served as a  at the , initially staying neutral before eventually pledging her vote to U.S. Senator .\n\nIn April 2016, Mizeur endorsed U.S. Senator  in the , and supported  after she was nominated as candidate by the Democratic Party.\n\n\nIn July 2004, Mizeur introduced a resolution to the Takoma Park City Council supporting a lawsuit filed by nine gay couples against the state for the right to wed. The measure passed the city council unanimously, making Takoma Park the first jurisdiction in the state to formally support same-sex marriage.\n\n\nIn 2011, Mizeur supported and spoke in support of the , a bill that would have legalized same-sex marriage in Maryland. After the bill was reintroduced and signed into law in 2012, Mizeur and her wife traveled across the state to fight opponents of , a ballot referendum seeking to overturn the Civil Marriage Protection Act.\n\nAlso in 2011, Mizeur supported and spoke in support of a bill that would provide transgender individuals with protections against . She again supported the bill when it was reintroduced in 2014.\n\nIn April 2014, Mizeur said she supported legalizing  for terminally ill patients.\n\n\nIn November 2013, Mizeur unveiled a tax plan that included tax hikes for the state's wealthy, cuts of up to $150 a year to the state's , and  breaks for small businesses. She also said she supported creating a Cabinet-level position for advocating for regulatory reforms on the behalf of the business community.\n\nIn May 2022, Mizeur said she supported closing tax loopholes for large corporations and restoring tax rates for individuals making more than $400,000 a year to the rates they were paying to their pre- levels. She also said she supported providing tax credits to renters to preserve .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n|votes      = 249,398\n|percentage = 51.4\n}}\n\n|votes      = 117,383\n|percentage = 24.2\n}}\n\n|votes      = 104,721\n|percentage = 21.6\n}}\n\n|votes      = 6,863\n|percentage = 1.4\n}}\n\n|votes      = 3,507\n|percentage = 0.7\n}}\n\n|votes      = 3,221\n|percentage = 0.7\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* campaign website\n*\n* (archived)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Katherine A. Klausmeier''' (née '''Nossel'''; born February 22, 1950) is an American politician who has served as a member of both chambers of the  at the state capital of , currently in the upper chamber of the  representing  in northeast , since 2003. A member of the , she previously served as  of the Maryland Senate from 2019 to 2020 and represented the same district earlier in the lower chamber of the  from 1995 to 2003. Klausmeier is the longest serving current member of the Maryland Senate, serving in the  for 21 years, and as a delegate for eight years before that.\n\n\nKatherine Nossel was born in  on February 22, 1950, to father Jerome Bernard Nossel, a local tavern owner and mother Elizabeth (née Stager). She was raised in  of northeastern suburban . She attended and graduated from the  student body at  (founded 1939), on Edison Highway in East Baltimore city, and attended the nearby  (CCBC), where she received an  in 1971. Klausmeier also attended, but did not graduate from  in .\n\n\nAfter graduating from CCBC, Klausmeier worked as a child life coordinator at the  for thirty years. She also served as the president of the Gunpowder Elementary School  from 1987 to 1989, and again from 1991 to 1994. Klausmeier first became involved with politics as an election judge in 1990 and 1992. From 1991 to 1992, she served as the education chair of the Baltimore County . Klausmeier served as the vice president of the Baltimore County Commission for Women from 1991 to 1993, and chaired the task force charged with studying whether to create an elected or appointed school board in Baltimore County in 1993.\n\n\n\nKlausmeier was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in , and was sworn in on January 11, 1995. She served as a member of the Environmental Matters Committee during her entire tenure.\n\nKlausmeier was elected to the Maryland Senate in , and was sworn in on January 8, 2003. She has served as a member of the Finance Committee during her entire tenure, and became the committee's vice chair in 2023. From 2019 to 2020, Klausmeier served as the president pro tempore of the Maryland Senate, making her the second woman in Maryland history, after , to hold the position.\n\nIn the , Klausmeier was challenged by state delegate , who received the backing of Governor  and the  in their \"Drive for Five\" campaign. The election was seen as one of the most competitive in the Maryland Senate, as Miele was expected to benefit from having the endorsement of Governor , who won the district by 37 points in , but Klausmeier was seen as being the slight favorite due to her high name recognition and strong community roots. During the election, Klausmeier shifted toward the  in an attempt to appeal to Republican voters, including photos of her with Hogan in campaign mailers. She defeated Miele in the general election on November 6, 2018, edging out Miele by a margin of 1,061 votes, or 2.3 percent.\n\nIn August 2024, after  won the Democratic nomination in the  in , Klausmeier expressed interest in serving the remainder of Olszewski's term as . If nominated by the Baltimore County Council, she has also suggested that she would run for reelection to her Senate seat in 2026.\n\n\nKlausmeier is married to her husband John, who owns and operates Klausmeier & Sons Auto Repair in . Together, they have two daughters. She is .\n\n\n'''' has described Klausmeier as a .\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Klausmeier was the only Senate Democrat to vote against a bill that would require courts to impose sentences below the minimum when sentencing a juvenile criminal offender as an adult and the Maryland Police Accountability Act, a police transparency and accountability reform package that repealed the .\n\nIn 2022, Klausmeier was the only Senate Democrat to vote against a bill repealing a law that allowed children to be arrested for disturbing school activities.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Klausmeier supported a bill to make handgun theft a felony.\n\n\nIn 2019, Klausmeier voted against a bill that would block the  ineligible to receive subsidies meant for renewable energy, saying that the bill would harm the incinerator and counties that use it to burn trash.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Klausmeier introduced legislation to establish an Office on Climate Change within the governor's office to centralize combat change efforts. She also advocated for requiring all newly-built schools in Maryland to be .\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session and following the , Klausmeier introduced legislation requiring lockable doors in every Maryland classroom and annual active threat drills in schools. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn 2020, Klausmeier was the only Senate Democrat to vote against overriding Governor 's veto on a bill to repeal Maryland's Handgun Permit Review Board, which handled conceal carry applications.\n\nIn 2021, during debate on a bill that would prohibit people from carrying guns at polling places, Klausmeier was the only Senate Democrat to support an amendment to the bill that would exempt police and off-duty or retired officers from the bill.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Klausmeier introduced a bill that would allow pharmacists to tell consumers that they can pay less for their prescription drugs. In 2019, she introduced legislation to establish the Prescription Drug Affordability Board to negotiate the prices of prescription drugs.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Klausmeier voted for a bill to decriminalize the possession of , but voted against voting to override Governor 's veto on the bill, resulting in its death.\n\n\nIn 2017, during debate on a bill to provide workers with up to seven days of , Klausmeier introduced an amendment to lower the amount of days to five. After the amendment was rejected, she voted against the bill.\n\nIn 2022, Klausmeier was the only Senate Democrat to vote against the Time to Care Act, which provided workers with up to 24 weeks of .\n\n\nIn February 2011, Klausmeier said that she was \"conflicted\" on how she would vote on the , which would legalize . She later said that she would vote for the bill, and voted for it again when it was reintroduced in 2012.\n\nIn 2016, Klausmeier was one of four Democrats to vote against overriding Governor 's veto on a bill to restore voting rights to felons on parole.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Klausmeier introduced a bill that would prohibit companies from charging higher insurance premiums to families who own s or s. In 2020, she was the only Senate Democrat to vote against the Housing Opportunities Made Equal (HOME) Act, which would make it illegal for landlords to discriminate against renters on the basis of source of income.\n\nIn 2020, Klausmeier introduced legislation to ban s from school campuses. The bill was introduced after Santino Sudano, a 21-year-old student at , was charged with second degree rape after pleading guilty to a fourth degree sex offense in April 2018.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Klausmeier was the only Senate Democrat to vote against a bill to extend the state's  to s. In 2023, she again voted to exempt undocumented immigrants from the state's earned income tax credit.\n\n\nIn 2007, Klausmeier introduced a bill that would provide tax breaks to businesses that ban smoking, seeking to prevent a bill that would ban smoking in bars and restaurants statewide.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Klausmeier introduced legislation to reduce toll late fees from $50 to $5.\n\nIn March 2023, Klausmeier was one of five Democrats to vote for an amendment to decouple the state's  from inflation. The amendment was rejected by the Maryland Senate in a 20-27 vote.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jefferson L. Ghrist''' (born March 14, 1975) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2015. A member of the , he previously served as a member of the  Board of Commissioners from 2006 to 2014.\n\n\nGhrist was born on March 14, 1975. He graduated from  and later attended  and , where he earned a  degree in economics in 1997. After graduating, Ghrist worked as an assistant store manager at  and as a real estate agent.\n\nGhrist was first elected to the Caroline County Board of Commissioners in 2006. He served as the board's president of the Caroline County Board of Commissioners from 2010 to 2012, and again in 2014. Ghrist briefly  in  in 2010, challenging incumbent Democratic U.S. Representative , but dropped out in December 2009 and endorsed state senator .\n\n\n\nOn October 29, 2013, Ghrist filed paperwork to run for election to one of the three District 36 seats in the House of Delegates. In the primary, he edged out incumbent delegate  with 17 percent of the vote and by a margin of 144 votes, and went on to win the general election with 24.1 percent of the vote. Ghrist was sworn in on January 14, 2015, and is the first state delegate from Caroline County since Robert Thornton in 1994. He has served as a member of the Appropriations Committee during his entire tenure, and as deputy minority whip from 2019 to 2021, and as the minority parliamentarian since 2022.\n\n\nGhrist is married to his wife, Michele, whom he met in high school and married soon after graduating college. Together, they have two children and live in .\n\n\nGhrist is a  who supports  and increasing state funding to local jurisdictions while reducing taxes. During his tenure as county commissioner, he voted to cut Caroline County's budget by thirteen percent by reducing payrolls and employee pensions.\n\n\nGhrist opposes the , saying that its costs will be a \"disaster\" for school systems and students and predicting that counties would have to raise taxes to pay for it. During the 2023 legislative session, he introduced the Right to Learn Act, which would allow students attending failing schools to change schools and expand the state's  voucher program.\n\n\nGhrist supports \"pragmatic, scientifically-supported\" environmental laws, but opposes environmental legislation passed by the . In 2019, he opposed a bill to establish the Oyster Advisory Commission to develop policy recommendations on protecting oyster habitats, predicting that it would kill Maryland's  industry. During the 2022 legislative session, Ghrist opposed a bill that would move pesticide regulation from the  to the .\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ghrist opposed a bill that would require s on all gun sales, which he said would \"destroy the rural way of life\".\n\n\nIn 2018, Ghrist said that he opposed the , calling marijuana a \"\". In 2023, Ghrist said he voted for  to legalize recreational marijuana.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Ghrist introduced legislation that would prohibit foreign governments from buying agricultural land in Maryland.\n\n\nGhrist supports reducing state funding for rural . He supports building a second  and supports setting aside money for the project ahead of its construction, saying that he hoped project planners would avoid \"the same mistake\" Baltimore legislators made by not setting aside money for the Red Line before Governor  cancelled it.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Rona E. Kramer''' (born August 16, 1954) is an American politician who served as the  under Governor  from 2015 to 2023. She was previously a member of the  from 2003 to 2011.\n\n\nKramer was born in Washington, D.C., on August 16, 1954, one of three children of eventual Montgomery County Executive  and his wife Betty Mae. She grew up in , where she graduated from . Kramer later attended the , where she earned a B.A. degree in law enforcement in 1976, and the , where she earned her J.D. degree in 1979. She was admitted to the  in 1980.\n\n\nAfter graduating from the University of Baltimore, Kramer worked as an entrepreneur in shopping mall management. She also served as the president of the Montgomery County Chamber of Commerce from 1992 to 1993.\n\nIn 2002, Kramer ran for  in District 14, which had no incumbent senator following redistricting. In the Democratic primary, she defeated state delegate  and former delegate , and defeated Republican businessman Jorge Ribas in the general election.\n\n\nKramer was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 8, 2003, where she was described by '''' as being a \", business-oriented lawmaker\". She also described herself as a .\n\nKramer supported a bill giving the legislature veto power over the failed  and  merger, capping electricity rate increases, and the limited repeal of the  in 2009. Kramer opposed proposals to repeal the state's computer services tax, legalize , and prevent .\n\nKramer unsuccessfully ran for re-election in 2010, losing to state delegate . Following her loss, she worked as the senior vice president and general counsel at Kramer Enterprises, a commercial real estate company owned by her father.\n\n\n\nOn January 8, 2015, Governor-elect  named Kramer as his Secretary of Aging. She was one of several Democrats to serve in his cabinet. Kramer's nomination was unanimously approved by the Maryland Senate on March 6, 2015.\n\nIn this position, Kramer oversaw the launch of the \"My Groceries to Go!\" supplemental food program and the state's durable medical equipment reuse program. During the , she oversaw the rollout of s to Maryland's senior populations.\n\n\nDuring the , Kramer was a co-chair of Democrats for Hogan.\n\n\nKramer is a single mom and has two daughters. Together, they live in . Kramer is Jewish.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sue Hecht''' (born December 7, 1947) is an American politician from  and a member of the . She retired in 2011 after serving three terms in the , representing Maryland's District 3A in . She is known for her campaign slogan \"Hecht Yes!\".\n\n\nHecht was born in  on December 7, 1947. She attended Frederick Community College, , and , where she earned her  before becoming an adjunct professor at , a freelance writer, and executive director of a non-profit organization. Hecht has received numerous awards for her work, including being included in a list of Maryland's top 100 women.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 3A''' Retrieved on Nov. 21, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland State Senate – District 3''' Retrieved on Oct. 8, 2007\n:\n*'''1998 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 3'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n*'''1994 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 3'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000\n* voted for Jessica's Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007\n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008\n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009\n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet, 2009\n\nFor the past four years, Delegate Hecht has annually voted to support classroom teachers, public schools, police and hospitals in Frederick County. Since 2002, funding to schools across the State has increased 82%, resulting in Maryland being ranked top in the nation for K-12 education.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Patrick Nicholas Hogan''' (born February 15, 1979) is an American politician and academic administrator who served as a member of the  for District 3A from 2003 to 2007 and again from 2011 to 2015. He is son of former congressman  and the younger half-brother of the 62nd Governor of Maryland, .\n\n\nHogan was born in . He attended  in  After high school, he graduated from the  in 2002 with his Bachelor of Arts degree in government and politics.\n\n\nDelegate Hogan was first elected to the  in 2002. He was defeated for re-election in 2006 but re-elected to his old seat in 2010. He did not run for reelection in the 2014 Maryland General Election. During his tenure, Hogan served as a member of the Environmental Matters Committee and several subcommittees.\n\nIn addition to his legislative work, Hogan was a member of the steering committee for the Frederick County Drug Treatment Court in 2003. He was on the board of directors of the  in 2003, and a member of the Task Force on Business-Owner Compensation in Condemnation Proceedings from 2004 until 2005.\n\nBetween his separated terms as a delegate, Hogan was director of development for the YMCA of Frederick County. After his second term, he was vice president of business development for the Hogan Companies and a deputy legislative officer for Maryland's Office of the Governor. Hogan was appointed as the 's vice chancellor for government relations in November 2015, a position he left in October 2023 to join a lobbying firm in Annapolis.\n\n\nHogan's father is , who represented  from 1969 to 1975 and later served as the county executive of . His older half-brother is , the former .\n\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– District 3A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– District 3A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– District 3A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*  Previous Candidate for House of Delegates District 3A, Maryland |url=https://vote-md.org/Intro.aspx?State=MD&Id=MDHoganPatrickN |website=Vote-MD |publisher=Vote USA Inc. |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180625172219/https://vote-md.org/Intro.aspx?State=MD&Id=MDHoganPatrickN |archive-date=June 25, 2018 |access-date=January 29, 2023}}\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Tony McConkey''' (born November 21, 1963) is a former elected official in the . He was first elected in 2002, taking the seat of former Delegate , who ran for a State Senate seat. He served in District 33, which is located in . He lost a bid for re-election in 2018 to Democratic challenger .\n\n\nBorn in , he graduated in 1986 from the  with a joint B.A. (government & politics) and B.S. (business management) degree. He attended the , graduating with a J.D. in 1990.\n\n\n\nAs a member of the Republican Party in the Maryland House of Delegates, he served as Ranking Member on the House Appropriations Committee. McConkey fought in March 2007 to allow for an elected school board in Anne Arundel County. However, a bill was passed that allowed the Governor to select the members from a list. McConkey and  were the only dissenting votes.\n\nAnother issue that McConkey advocated for was limiting privileges for . He co-sponsored a bill in the House, similar to the one submitted by State Senator  to require driver's license applicants to prove they are citizens of the United States. Currently, Maryland is one of several states that does not demand proof of citizenship to obtain a driver's license.\n\nMcConkey was a real estate broker. In 2010, he pleaded guilty to violating laws that protect homeowners during foreclosure and lost his real estate licence and was ordered by a judge to pay $75,000. He has sought to have his license restored.\n\nMcConkey's disbarment as an attorney in the state of Maryland is on record with the Maryland Court System.\n\nIn 2013, he was reprimanded by the House for introducing legislation that would have personally benefited him.\n\nOn November 8, 2018, McConkey was defeated by , a Democrat, for Delegate in District 33A by less than 1 percentage point (185 vote margin).\n\n\n*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted against slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 33rd District, Division A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 33rd District, Division A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 30th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 22A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Pielke''' (March 4, 1942 – June 6, 2008) was appointed in 2002 to represent District 9B, which covers a portion of .\n\n\nPielke was appointed on January 14, 2002, during what was a tumultuous time for this district and its representation in the . After serving in the military, Pielke returned to college, this time to get his J.D. from the , graduating in 1971.\n\n\nPielke served in the  from 1964 to 1968. After receiving his law degree, Pielke was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1972 and began his practice of real estate, tax and small business law.     "pages": }\n\n'''David C. Harrington''' (July 31, 1954 – September 20, 2022) was an American politician from , a member of the  and a former member of the . From 2008 to 2022, he served as president and CEO of the Prince George's Chamber of Commerce in addition to serving as a Senior Policy Advisor for Common Health Action. Harrington was a board member of the Eugene and Agnes E. Meyer Foundation, Consumer Health Foundation, Bowie State Board of Visitors and co-lead of the Robert Wood Johnson Place Matters special committee.\n\n\nHarrington was born on July 31, 1954, in , New York. He has a  in political science from . He also received a  from the  in . From 1995 to 2002, Harrington was the Mayor of . From 2001 to 2002, he served as president of the Maryland Municipal League. In 2002, he was elected to represent District 5 on Prince George's County Council.\n\nHe worked as a senior fellow and faculty member at the James MacGregor Burns Academy of Leadership at the .\n\nIn 2006, Harrington ran for reelection to Prince George's County Council. In December 2007, Harrington was elected Council Chair.\n\n\nHarrington was appointed to the State Senate in 2008 to fill the vacancy created by the death of . While serving in the senate, Harrington was a member of the Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee and a member of the Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland.\n\nHarrington ran for reelection to the state senate in 2010 but was defeated.\n\n\nHarrington's wife Cheryl is the owner of Shortcake Bakery. His oldest son, Stephen, is an alumnus of  and the . David's younger son Christopher is an alumnus of  and has an MBA from the  at the University of Maryland.\n\nHarrington died September 20, 2022.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''James Brochin''' (born February 22, 1964) is an American politician who was a member of the  representing the  in  from 2003 to 2019. He unsuccessfully ran for  in , placing second behind former state delegate  in the Democratic primary by a margin of 17 votes.\n\n\nBrochin was born in  on February 22, 1964, to father Arnold Brochin and mother Carol Ginsburg. After graduating from , he attended the , where he earned a  degree in political science in 1986. Brochin earned his  degree in political science from the  in 1990.\n\n\nBrochin worked as a legislative analyst for Maryland Senate President  in 1989, afterwards working as a lobbyist for Baltimore County from 1990 to 1991 and a senior political writer for '''' from 1994 to 2001. He was also a political science instructor at the 's Catonsville campus from 1990 to 1998 and at  since 1994. During the , Brochin was the campaign manager for state senator 's gubernatorial campaign. Since 2000, he has worked as an insurance broker.\n\n\n\n\nBrochin ran for the Maryland Senate in the  in 2002, seeking to unseat Republican state senator . He was redrawn into the 42nd district after the  issued a ruling redrawing the state's legislative maps. Brochin engaged in a door-knocking campaign for nearly three years leading up to the election, in which he defeated Republican state delegate  in the general election with 50.99 percent of the vote.\n\nBrochin ran for re-election to a second term in 2006, in which he defeated Republican challenger Douglas B. Riley. He was reelected to a third term in 2010 after defeating Republican challenger Kevin Carney.\n\nDuring his 2014 re-election campaign, Brochin was challenged by former state delegate Connie DeJuliis, who ran as a . That year, he claimed that Governor  and Democratic leaders of the  had redrawn his district with the hopes that he would lose his re-election bid to a Republican, citing his vote for a bill introduced by former Republican Governor  to give the state control of . In May 2014, DeJuliis's husband, state labor commissioner Ron DeJuliis, was charged with stealing Brochin's campaign signs. After defeating DeJuliis in the Democratic primary election with 69.4 percent of the vote, Brochin won reelection with 51.6 percent of the vote against Republican challenger Tim Robinson.\n\n\n\nBrochin was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 8, 2003. He has described himself as a  with socially liberal views, while ''The Baltimore Sun'' has described him as an  and  and as one of the most conservative Democratic members of the Maryland Senate. Brochin was a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee from 2003 to 2004, afterwards serving on the Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Committee until 2007, after which he returned to the Judicial Proceedings Committee for the remainder of his tenure. From 2016 to 2019, Brochin served as the chair of the .\n\n\n\nIn November 2016, Brochin told '''' that he was considering a run for  in . He announced his candidacy on October 19, 2017, seeking to succeed , who was term limited. During the Democratic primary, he campaigned for increased funding for college and career readiness programs in schools, more treatment options for s, and against what he called \"development interests\" in Baltimore County, prioritizing land preservation, , and ethics reforms. He also received endorsements from Attorney General  and Comptroller , and outraised his Democratic opponents.\n\nFollowing Kamenetz's death in May 2018, Brochin said that he would reject any offers to serve out the remainder of Kamenetz's term and encouraged other candidates running for county executive to do the same.\n\nBrochin was defeated in the Democratic primary by  by nine votes, prompting him to request a recount that expanded Olszewski's lead to 17 votes. Following his defeat, Brochin endorsed Republican Governor  for re-election.\n\n\nBrochin has a daughter. He moved to , in 2007, but now lives in . He is .\n\n\n\nBrochin has described himself as a \"law and order legislator\". In April 2012, Brochin said that he would support reforms providing violent youth offenders with intensive counseling and therapy to deter juvenile crimes in Maryland, citing their success in Texas and Missouri. During the 2015 legislative session, he introduced legislation to prevent people that commit crimes with firearms from receiving good behavior credits during their sentence. In March 2016, Brochin voted for legislation that would redirect low-level drug offenders into treatment instead of prison, expand record expurgations for certain convictions, and reduce sentences for parole violators.\n\nIn December 2016, Brochin criticized the state's evidence retention system, which allowed for certain jurisdictions to destroy s after one year while others had to keep kits indefinitely. During the 2018 legislative session, Brochin introduced a bill that make it easier to convict repeat sexual offenders by allowing prosecutors to introduce evidence showing that they had a pattern of behavior. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring an interview on  radio in 2021, Brochin suggested that Baltimore County residents should boycott Baltimore until it removed  from major intersections. In response, Baltimore Mayor  remarked, \"Thank God the citizens of Baltimore County were smart enough to not elect a gaslighting racist like Jim Brochin\", which Brochin responded to in a ''Baltimore Sun'' op-ed denying that his comments were racist.\n\n\nBrochin supports the  and opposed Governor 's bill to repeal it, worrying that prosecutors would lose a valuable \"bargaining chip\" when negotiating s. He also supported unsuccessful efforts to place a ballot initiative on the death penalty repeal on the 2014 general election ballot.\n\nIn August 2011, Brochin suggested implementing a surcharge on eviction notices to help the Baltimore Housing Authority pay nearly $12 million in court-ordered judgments owed to former tenants.\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Brochin introduced a bill that would prohibit county candidates from accepting campaign contributions with developers who apply for certain development or zoning approvals. During his 2018 county executive campaign, he rallied against proposed developments in , including the Towson Row project and apartments near , and said that he opposed the HOME Act, which prohibits landlords from discriminating against potential tenants based on their source of income, saying instead that he would support legislation requiring developers to set aside a certain percentage of housing units for low or moderate income families.\n\nIn 2021, Brochin helped pay for attorneys representing opponents of a proposed affordable housing project in east Towson.\n\n\nIn May 2011, Brochin said he would sign Republican state delegate 's petition to place a  repealing the , which extended in-state tuition to , on the 2012 ballot.\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Brochin introduced legislation that would prohibit  from turning magnet schools into neighborhood schools without the permission of the Baltimore County Delegation. In 2016, he introduced a bill to make seat-belts mandatory on school buses. In March 2018, Brochin was the only Democrat in the Maryland Senate to vote against a bill to strip the  of its oversight and management of the state's annual \"beg-a-thon\", in which school system leaders appear before the board to request additional school construction funding.\n\nBrochin also voted for a bill to provide low-income students with free tuition to Maryland community colleges.\n\n\nIn January 2015, Brochin said he opposed a  proposal in  and introduced a bill to ban fracking in Maryland.\n\n\nFrom 2002 to 2012, Brochin accepted nearly $13,000 in campaign contributions from gun lobby organizations, including more than $2,000 from the  (NRA). The NRA gave Brochin a \"B\" rating in 2002, followed by \"A\" ratings and endorsements for his reelection campaigns in 2006 and 2010, but an \"F\" rating in 2014. During the 2009 legislative session, Brochin supported a bill that gave judges the authority to seize guns from people with protective orders. In 2013, following the , he voted for the Firearms Safety Act, which banned  in Maryland. Following the , Brochin voted for a bill to ban  in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring his 2018 county executive campaign, Brochin said he supported Governor 's executive order prohibiting companies that support the  movement from contracting with the state government.\n\n\nIn March 2018, Brochin opposed the , but voted for a bill to decriminalize possessing less than an ounce of marijuana.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Brochin sought to weaken a paid sick leave bill through amendments reducing the number of sick days employees can receive and allowing the  to provide hardship waivers to businesses that prove that the law would cause them harm.\n\n\n's press conference on a bill requiring Maryland to use an  if other states agreed to do the same.]]\nIn May 2017, Brochin voted against a bill that would require Maryland use an  to draw its legislative and congressional maps if , Pennsylvania, Virginia, and North Carolina all agreed to do the same, and spoke at the press conference where Governor  vetoed this bill. In July 2021, he co-founded Fair Maps Maryland, an anti- lobbying group, alongside former Republican Howard County Executive . Brochin criticized legislative leaders for forming their own redistricting commission to draw Maryland's congressional and legislative maps during the , instead endorsing the redistricting commission appointed by Governor .\n\n\nDuring the 2007 legislative session, Brochin introduced legislation that would abolish the statute of limitations on child sexual abuse lawsuits.\n\nBrochin was a long-time opponent to , insisting on s instead, and initially said that he would vote against the  in 2011, but ended up voting for it after hearing same-sex marriage opponents describe members of the gay community as \"pedophiles\". After the Civil Marriage Protection Act was reintroduced in 2012, he introduced an amendment that would grant same-sex couples the ability to get a civil union instead of a marriage, which was rejected by the Maryland Senate. During the 2014 legislative session, Brochin voted against a bill to ban , citing a hypothetical example of a  waiting in the women's restroom to attack.\n\nIn February 2016, Brochin voted against overriding Governor 's veto on a bill that would restore the voting rights of recently released felons.\n\nIn March 2018, Brochin voted against a bill that would require presidential candidates to release their s to appear on the ballot in Maryland.\n\n\nBrochin opposed tax increases proposed by Governor . During the 2015 legislative session, he introduced legislation to repeal  and another bill to re-add a checkbox on state income tax return forms that would allow taxpayers to contribute to the Fair Campaign Financing Fund.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Brochin introduced a bill that would prohibit the  from audio-taping passenger conversations, which was killed by the Maryland Senate in a 23–22 vote. In January 2014, following the publication of a secret audit that found that Baltimore speed cameras had likely charged motorists for thousands more erroneous tickets than previously disclosed, he introduced a bill that would require ombudsmen to hear complaints about erroneous tickets. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor . In March 2016, Brochin voted against a bill requiring the  to use a scoring system to determine which transportation projects it would prioritize.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Charles E. Sydnor III''' (born March 18, 1974) is an  who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2020. A member of the , he previously represented District 44B in the  from 2015 to 2020.\n\n\nSydnor was born in  on March 18, 1974, and was raised in its . He graduated from the  and attended , where he earned a  degree in history in 1996; the , where he earned a  degree in policy science in 2000; and the , where he earned a  degree in 2002. Sydnor is a member of the  fraternity.\n\n\n\nSydnor was a college intern to Baltimore City Circuit Court Judge , and was admitted to the  and  after graduating. He has worked as an attorney for  since 2001, and worked as a consumer council for the  from 2010 to 2012.\n\nFrom 2007 to 2013, Sydnor served on the Citizen's Advisory Committees of the  and the Baltimore Corridor Transit Study for the .\n\n\nOn July 12, 2013, Sydnor said that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in , seeking to succeed state Delegate , who ran for the Maryland Senate and with whom he ran on a slate. He won the Democratic primary with 23.4 percent of the vote on June 24, 2014, and later won the general election alongside  in November 2014.\n\n swears Sydnor into the Maryland House of Delegates, 2015]]\nSydnor was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 13, 2015. During his tenure, he served as a member of the Judiciary Committee and chaired its civil law & procedure and criminal justice subcommittees.\n\nIn December 2019, following the resignation of state Senator , Sydnor applied to serve the remainder of her term in the Maryland Senate. The Baltimore County Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate Sydnor to the seat, while the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate state Delegate  to the seat. Governor  appointed Sydnor to the seat on December 30, 2019, and he was sworn in on January 8, 2020. He has served as a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee during his entire tenure. Sydnor was elected to a full four-year term in .\n\nIn October 2024, Sydnor expressed interest in running for  in 2026.\n\n\nSydnor is married and has three daughters. He lives in .\n\n\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Sydnor introduced legislation to create a separate mental health unit within the .\n\nIn 2016, Sydnor introduced a bill that would require police to obtain a warrant to use a , which can locate a cellphone's user within six feet. The bill died in committee.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, after a suspect was arrested in the  murders by police who used consumer genealogical databases to identify him, Sydnor introduced a bill to prohibit police access to such databases to identify criminal suspects through  samples submitted by relatives. The bill was reintroduced in 2021, during which it passed and became law. Sydnor also introduced legislation to conceal the identities of juveniles charged as adults.\n\nIn 2021, Sydnor said he supported legislation to return control of the Baltimore Police Department back to the city of Baltimore and the Police Reform and Accountability Act, an omnibus police reform bill to repeal the  and regulate the  that police could use during arrests, and introduced a bill that would require on-duty officers to wear body cameras by 2025, which passed and became law. He also voted against a bill to create criminal penalties for police officers who intentionally use , saying that he felt unsatisfied with the bill's definition of excessive force, and criticized other police reform bills passed by the legislature for \"not going far enough\".\n\n\nIn May 2019, Sydnor condemned social media comments made by state Delegate  toward members of the  that contained racially-charged language.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Sydnor introduced legislation that would force the state to settle its 13-year-old lawsuit against its  (HBCUs) by annually distributing $57.7 million to the state's HCBUs over a decade. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor Hogan. The bill was reintroduced in 2021, during which it passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn 2021, Sydnor introduced legislation to add an appointed member of the Baltimore County Board of Education.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Sydnor supported legislation to look into creating a new governance structure to oversee water and wastewater systems in the Baltimore and Baltimore County. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Sydnor voted against the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults.\n\n\nIn August 2015, Sydnor called for the resignation of Maryland Housing Secretary  after Holt claimed without evidence that parents were deliberately exposing their children to lead paint to get free housing.\n\nIn October 2021, Sydnor attended a protest against the Baltimore County Council's proposed redistricting plan, saying that the newly drawn districts would not adequately represent the county's population and  Black voters into a single district. He later led a lawsuit against the county's redistricting plan, which resulted in a new map with a second minority opportunity district. During the 2022 legislative session, Sydnor introduced legislation that would allow the Maryland attorney general to intervene when local governments violate federal voting laws.\n\n\nSydnor supports the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Nancy J. King''' (born October 7, 1949) is an American politician who is a member of the  from the  since 2007. A member of the , she has served as the majority leader of the Maryland Senate since 2020. King previously represented the district in the Maryland House of Delegates from 2003 to 2007.\n\n\nKing was born in , where she graduated from  and attended  from 1967 to 1969. She later moved to , where she became the vice president of her family's consulting and forensic engineering company, Trecor Inc., in 1987.\n\n\nKing was appointed to the Montgomery Village Foundation Board of Directors, where she served from 1991 to 1996. In 1993, she became the president of the Montgomery County Council of Parent-Teacher Associations.\n\nKing was elected to represent the first district of the  in 1994, serving until her election to the Maryland House of Delegates in 2002. During her tenure, King served as the board's president from 1997 to 1998 and from 2000 to 2001, and was critical of Montgomery County Executive 's fiscal conservatism, especially toward cuts to the county's education funding. She also supported expanding the school system's  program following the , supported studying later start times for classes, and reduced .\n\n\nKing was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in , and was sworn in on January 8, 2003. She served on the Ways and Means Committee and as deputy majority whip from 2006 to 2007.\n\n\nIn July 2007, following the resignation of , King applied to serve the remainder of his term in the Maryland Senate. She was appointed to the seat by Governor  and was sworn in on September 5, 2007. King was elected to a full term in  after defeating state delegate  in a competitive primary election in which she ran with the backing of the Maryland Democratic Party establishment and used campaign material to try to embarrass Ali.\n\nKing has served as a member of the Budget and Taxation Committee since 2007, and was its chair in 2019, and has been a member of the Executive Nominations Committee, the Rules Committee, and the Legislative Policy Committee since 2019. In January 2018, she delivered the Democratic response to Governor 's State of the State Address.\n\nIn July 2019, King endorsed former vice president  in the . She would later serve as a delegate to the  pledged to Biden.\n\nIn December 2019, after  said he would not seek re-election as , King explored running to succeed him but ultimately decided against it. In January 2020, following the election of  as Senate president, Ferguson appointed King to serve as majority leader of the Maryland Senate.\n\n\nKing is married and has three children.\n\n\n\nIn 2001, King supported efforts to repeal the county's ban on cell phones in the classroom, calling it a \"security blanket\" for students and parents amid the .\n\nIn 2002, King said she opposed condom demonstrations in sex education classes, arguing that it was the responsibility of parents to teach their children how to use contraceptives.\n\nDuring the 2007 legislative session, King introduced legislation to prohibit student school board members from voting on personnel matters.\n\nIn 2011, King voted for , a bill that extended  for .\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, King introduced a bill to stop the state from administering the Maryland School Assessment.\n\nIn 2015, King introduced a bill to provide $20 million annually to allow Montgomery County to issue $700 million in bonds for school construction.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, King introduced a bill to allow school districts to extend their school calendar up to five days past the state's June 15 deadline for closing schools without needing permission from the . The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor . In 2019, she supported a bill that would repeal Hogan's executive order requiring schools to start after  and dismissed proposals from Hogan to hold a referendum on school start dates, calling it \"silly\" and \"unnecessary\".\n\nDuring debate on the  bill in 2020, King introduced an amendment that would reduce funding for the Blueprint implementation if the  reduced the state's revenues. The amendment was added to the bill.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, King introduced a bill to repeal Maryland's ban on placing wagers on games of poker played at home. In 2020, she introduced legislation creating a ballot referendum to repeal the state's ban on , which passed and was approved by voters in November 2020. In 2023, she proposed a ballot referendum on legalizing .\n\n\nDuring the 2006 legislative session, King supported a bill that would allow for the confiscation of weapons before a judge orders a final protective order.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, King voted for the Firearms Safety Act, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nIn November 2023, King and eight other state senators signed a joint letter that threatened to defund immigrants rights group  because it had called for an immediate ceasefire in the  and condemned the \"utilization of US tax dollars to promote the ongoing violence.\"\n\n\nIn 1996, King abstained from voting on a bill to ban  in public education, saying that she thought the county no longer needed to spell out what groups needed special protections. In 1997, she voted against allowing a high school television production class to air a debate about  on the school's public cable channel. In 2006, King voted to uphold a committee decision blocking a bill to amend the state constitution to ban same-sex marriage. During her 2010 Senate campaign, she called legalizing same-sex marriage a \"very, very difficult issue in our district\" but said she would vote for it if a bill to do so was introduced. She voted for the  in 2011 and 2012.\n\nIn June 2001, King said she would support renaming an elementary school in  after Lillian B. Brown, a retired Black teacher who taught at a nearby school during .\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, King voted to repeal the .\n\nIn 2019, King supported the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults, likening it to getting an abortion.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, King introduced legislation to give  $450,000 in tax breaks. In 2018, she supported a bill providing $5.6 billion in tax incentives to  to build their  in Montgomery County.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, King introduced a bill that would provide tax credits toward child and dependent care costs. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nKing supports proposals to add s to  and the . In April 2021, she criticized a bill that would require more scrutiny over state s as an \"attempt to add time and costs\" to the highway projects. King blocked the bill from receiving a vote after  Pete Rahn said it would result in a three-year delay to the highway projects.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Luke H. Clippinger''' (born September 24, 1972) is an American politician and lawyer who has served as a member of the , representing the state's  in , since 2011.\n\n\nClippinger was born in Baltimore on September 24, 1972. He graduated from the  and attended , where he served as the manager of the  radio station and earned a  degree in politics in 1994, and the , where he earned a  degree in 2005. He was admitted to the  in 2007.\n\n\nClippinger says he has been involved in politics since he was seven years old as a worker in 's city council campaign.\n\nWhile attending Earlham, Clippinger conducted polls for various elections in , served as the communications director for the Wayne County Democratic Party from 1992 to 1994, and ran unsuccessfully for  assessor in 1994. After graduating, he interned for Indiana state senators  and Joe O'Day during the 1995 legislative session, afterwards working as an office manager for  candidate Mary Pat Clarke. In 1996, Clippinger worked as an intern and was later named to manage the re-election campaign of U.S. Representative . He worked as a community development specialist for the Indiana Department of Commerce until 1998, when he was named to manage the campaign of congressional candidate  and, following his election to Congress, became Hill's district director until 2005.\n\nIn 2006, Clippinger was named as the campaign manager for 's short-lived campaign for . Afterwards, he worked as a spokesperson for 's mayoral campaign and as an assistant state's attorney in  since 2007. Clippinger served as a member of the platform committee at the .\n\n\n, 2023]]\nIn 2010, Clippinger ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 46, seeking to succeed retiring state delegate . He won the Democratic primary election in September, placing third with 18.7 percent of the vote.\n\nClippinger was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 12, 2011. He was a member of the Judiciary Committee from 2011 to 2015, afterwards serving in the Economic Matters Committee before returning to the Judiciary Committee as its chair in 2019. Clippinger served as the chair of the Democratic Party Caucus from 2015 to 2018.\n\n\nClippinger is openly gay. He attends the  in Baltimore.\n\nIn April 2016, Clippinger said that he experienced \"significant fatigue\" at the end of the 2016 legislative session, and in June he was diagnosed with a rare form of . In January 2017, he said that the cancer was in remission.\n\n\n'''' has described Clippinger as a \"leader of the progressive wing\" in the House.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Clippinger supported the Reform on Tap Act, a bill backed by Comptroller  to deregulate the state's craft beer industry.\n\nIn 2022, Clippinger supported legislation that would require companies on  to close at 10 p.m. nightly.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Clippinger introduced \"Jake's Law\", a bill that would increase penalties for drivers who cause fatal accidents while . The bill was named for Jake Owen, a five-year-old boy who was killed in a 2011 crash caused by a driver who was talking on his phone. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn July 2017, Clippinger and other lawmakers from District 46 released an \"anti-violence plan\" that called for increased funding for social programs and strengthened gun laws.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Clippinger introduced a bill that would require police trial boards to release audio from their hearings under the state Open Meetings Act. The bill passed the House of Delegates, but died in the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.\n\nIn May 2020, Clippinger expressed disappointment with Governor 's veto of a bill to increase funding for the  for 10 high-crime \"microzones\" in the city.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Clippinger introduced a bill to remove the  from the state's parole board. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Hogan.\n\nIn 2023, Clippinger supported legislation that would give the  sole prosecutorial power over cases involving police-involved deaths.\n\n\nIn August 2019, Clippinger signed onto a letter calling for the  to add lessons on  and  movements into social studies curriculum. The Department of Education agreed to update its curriculum to include this material two weeks after it was sent.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Clippinger supported a bill to ban s. He also defended a bill that would require firearms dealers to install security devices, including 24-hour burglary alarm systems and security bars.\n\nIn 2023, Clippinger introduced legislation to increase the requirements and fees to obtain a handgun permit. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Clippinger supported legislation creating a  on . He also introduced a bill establishing the framework for the state's cannabis industry, which passed and became law without Governor 's signature.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Clippinger introduced the Maryland Healthy Working Families Act, a bill that would allow workers to accrue up to seven days of paid sick leave a year. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor ; lawmakers voted to override Hogan's veto during the 2018 legislative session.\n\n\n victory party, 2012]]\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Clippinger supported the , a bill to legalize . He supported it again when it was reintroduced in 2012, during which it passed and was signed into law. Clippinger opposed , a 2012 referendum to repeal the Civil Marriage Protection Act.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Clippinger attended a rally at the  to support a bill that would ban discrimination against  people. He reintroduced the bill in 2014, during which it passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Clippinger introduced legislation to ban  on minors. In 2020, he supported legislation to repeal . Clippinger supported the bill when it was reintroduced during the 2023 legislative session, during which it passed and became law without Governor 's signature.\n\nIn April 2015, after the  passed the , Clippinger penned an open letter inviting Indiana businesses to relocate to Maryland.\n\nIn April 2019, Clippinger called for the resignation of Baltimore mayor  amid the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Cheryl Summers Landis''' (born October 11, 1954) is a  politician from . She was a member of the , representing , based in .\n\n\nLandis worked for nearly three decades as a member of the  from 1989 to 2016, serving as an executive administrative officer and strategic business partnerships specialist. She also served as a woman for Maryland and on the 's executive, credentials and rules committees.\n\n\nLandis has been a member of the Maryland House of Delegates since October 8, 2021.
