    "pages": }\n'''Angela Angel''' (born December 26, 1979) is an American politician who represented  in the  from 2015 to 2019. A member of the , she  in  in 2022.\n\n\nAngel was born in . She received her undergraduate degree at 's . Angel then graduated from the  at , where she received her  in 2004. She graduated with Honors and a specialization in Alternative Dispute Resolution. She served as a judicial fellow to Judge  of the  from 2004 to 2005. She was admitted to  in 2005.\n\nAngel first got involved with politics in 2000, when she worked as a legislative aide to  . In 2010, Angel served as the principal coordinator for policy and politics in  for Governor , and later served as legislator director for the  until 2011. From there, she worked as a Education and Social Services Specialist for the Prince George's County Council until 2014, when she began working as the Legislative Affairs Counsel for the Prince George's Department of Environmental Protection.\n\n\nFrom 2015 to 2019, Angel served on the Health and Government Operations committee in the Maryland House of Delegates. She was also a member of the .\n\nIn March 2018, Angel said that she was sexually harassed while working in the , saying that she \"felt defenseless when she was accosted in front of other people and no one came to her defense\".\n\nAngel announced that she would run for the  on November 8, 2017, seeking to succeed retiring state Senator . She lost the Democratic primary to former state Delegate , receiving 36.8 percent of the vote to Griffith's 55.0 percent.\n\n\nIn April 2023, Angel applied to fill a vacancy in District 25 of the Maryland House of Delegates left by the resignation of . In May 2023, the Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee unanimously voted to nominate its chair, , to succeed Barnes. In December 2023, Angel again applied to fill a vacancy in District 25 of the House of Delegates left by the appointment of  to the Maryland Senate. The Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate Denise Roberts to the seat over Angel.\n\nIn July 2024, after Prince George's County councilmember Mel Frankin resigned from his at-large seat on the county council, Angel filed to run in the  to succeed Franklin. She was defeated by  in the Democratic primary on August 6, 2024.\n\n\n\nOn December 20, 2021, Angel announced her bid for the Democratic nomination in Maryland's 4th congressional district. She was defeated in the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, placing third behind former Prince George's County State's Attorney  and former Congresswoman .\n\n\nIn June 2012, Angel briefly lived in a  after escaping an abusive marriage. She is a  of five children. She is .\n\n\n\nDuring her House campaign, Angel said that she would support efforts to bring the  to Prince George's County.\n\n\nDuring her House campaign, Angel said that she supported .\n\n\nIn 2018, Angel was a sponsor of the Healthy Maryland Act, a bill that would establish a universal  system in Maryland.\n\n\nIn November 2015, Angel signed a letter condemning Governor 's decision to block Syrian refugees from resettling to Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Angel introduced legislation to change the definition of abuse to include harassment and malicious destruction of property. The bill died in the House Judicial Proceedings Committee, prompting Angel to attach her legislation as an amendment, which passed the House with a vote of 65-60, to a domestic-violence-related bill introduced by state Senator . Veteran lawmakers accused Angel of violating constitutional rules by making this move, with House parliamentarian  arguing that reviving a dead bill by grafting it onto a live bill \"upends the integrity of the committee system that first put the brakes on Angel's legislation\". The House passed Ramirez's bill as amended, but the legislation died in the Senate.\n\nAngel supported a 2018  lawsuit against the , saying that \"institutions with predominantly Black student bodies should be given equitable funding by the state with those with White students in the majority\".\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''D. Bruce Poole''' (born June 17, 1959) is the former chairman of the . He was formerly a member of the  representing , which covers .\n\nPoole was first elected to office in 1986 when he defeated Republican Ronald J. Stansbury for the seat in District 3A. In 1990, he captured 95% of the vote to maintain his seat. In 1994, Poole narrowly won reelection by defeating Republican Richard D. Wiles by 66 votes. He was defeated in 1998 by Republican .\n\n\nPoole was born and raised in Washington County. He attended . In 1981, he received his  from  in . He briefly attended the  before getting his  from Washington and Lee in 1985.\n\n\nPoole was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1985 and served as a trial lawyer for several years. He was the secretary of the Washington County Bar Association in 1986 and served as the first president of the United Democratic Club of Washington County.\n\nIn 1981, Poole was the recipient of the Rotary International Graduate Fellowship. He was the co-author of the Best Brief in Nation,  in 1984.\n\nPoole is a partner in the Hagerstown, Maryland personal injury, family law and business law firm \n\nFollowing the  in Maryland where the Democrats lost the governor's mansion, Poole was elected Chair of the , succeeding Yvette Lewis.\n\nOn March 1, 2017, after serving two years as Chair of the , Poole was succeeded by former news anchor and congressional candidate .\n\n\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 2B''' Retrieved on Sept, 01 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 2B''' Retrieved on Sept, 01 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jill Priscilla Carter''' (born June 18, 1964) is an American politician and attorney who has served as a member of the  since 2018, representing the  in . She previously represented the district in the  from 2003 until her resignation in 2017.\n\n\nCarter is the daughter of the late , a civil rights activist and leader in the desegregation movement in  in the 1960s and early 1970s. Her mother, Zerita Joy Carter, was a public school teacher specializing in Early Childhood Education. Carter graduated  in Baltimore. Carter received her B.A. in English from  in 1988 and a Juris Doctor from the  in 1992.\n\n\nAfter graduating from the University of Baltimore, Carter served as a clerk to Baltimore City Circuit Court Judge Kenneth L. Johnson until 1993, afterwards working at various law firms before practicing law as a sole practitioner in 1998. In the same year, she also founded the Walter P. Carter Foundation.\n\n\nCarter has been involved in politics since she was young, when she campaigned for .\n\n\n breakfast, 2015]]\nIn 2002, Carter ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 41. She won the Democratic primary in September 2002, placing first with 18.2 percent and ousting incumbent state delegate Wendell F. Phillips. She won the general election and was sworn in on January 8, 2003. During her tenure in the House of Delegates, she was a member of the Judiciary Committee.\n\nCarter has often been referred to as a lone voice in the wilderness for her challenges to established politicians on matters of adequate housing for the poor,  of children, to adequately fund public education, both in the legislature, and in the Circuit Court for Baltimore City, and, in 2007, calling for a special session of the legislature to deal with the  utility rate increase.\n\nIn 2016, Carter served as a delegate to the , pledged to U.S. Senator . Following the convention, she endorsed Democratic nominee , saying that the prospect of a  presidency left her with no other option.\n\nOn December 30, 2016, Carter resigned from the Maryland House of Delegates to become the director of the Baltimore Office of Civil Rights and Wage Enforcement under Baltimore mayor . In this capacity, she handled citizens' law enforcement-related complaints and oversaw the implementation of the Civilian Review Board.\n\n\n\nOn January 16, 2007, Carter announced her candidacy in the , seeking to succeed  following his . Her platform included promises to replace the entire police command staff within the , increase the city's education funding to 20 percent of its budget, and creating an advisory panel of former police commissioners. Carter was defeated by incumbent mayor  in the Democratic primary on September 11, 2007, placing fourth with 2.8 percent of the vote.\n\n\nIn February 2018, Carter filed to run for the  in District 41, challenging incumbent state senator , who had been indicted on federal corruption charges. In the primary election, she sought to position herself as an outsider and an \"independent voice\" in the legislature, citing her participation in the \"Take a Hike, Mike\" rally outside the  opposing Senate president  Her campaign was backed by , , and various local pastors and labor unions.\n\nAfter Oaks resigned from the state senate in March 2018, Carter applied and was nominated alongside central committee member Joyce J. Smith by the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee to fill the remainder of his term. She was appointed by Governor  on April 30, 2018, and sworn in on May 4 after resigning as director of the Office of Civil Rights and Wage Enforcement. She won the Democratic primary in June 2018, defeating J. D. Merrill, the son-in-law of former Governor  with 54.9 percent of the vote.\n\nCarter is a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee.\n\n\n\nOn November 18, 2019, Carter announced her candidacy in the  to succeed U.S. Representative  after his death in October 2019. During the Democratic primary, she sought to position herself a , running on a platform that included , the , and ending U.S. involvement in foreign wars. She was defeated in the Democratic primary by former U.S. Representative , placing third with 16 percent of the vote. Following her defeat, she said she would run in the regular election for the district, in which she again placed third with 8.7 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nPrior to her re-election in 2006, she became a vocal critic of then mayor (and later Governor) 's \"failed policing policies\". She posited that the so-labeled, zero tolerance, arrest strategy failed to cause significant reduction in a soaring crime rate in Baltimore City, but, rather, pressured police officers to make tens of thousands of arrests that did not produce criminal charges. She also called for a federal investigation into  practices.\n\nIn 2014, Carter introduced \"Christopher's Law\", a bill named for Baltimore County teen Christopher Brown, who died after being tackled by a police officer in 2012, that would require police officers to be trained in CPR. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor O'Malley.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Carter introduced legislation to limit when employers could ask about a job applicant's criminal record. The bill passed and became law after the legislature overrode Governor 's veto. She also introduced \"Anton's Law\", a bill that reformed the , to require transparency in investigations of complaints against law enforcement officers.\n\nCarter was a vocal critic against a 2019 bill that would allow  to establish its own private police force, and was one of two state senators to vote against the bill in the Maryland Senate. In 2021, amid the , she called for hearings on the repeal of the JHU police authorization bill. In July 2021, after JHU announced that it would move forward with its plans to create a private police force, Carter called the university's decision a \"terrible miscalculation\" that was \"tone deaf\" to the concerns raised by students, faculty, and community members.\n\nIn 2020, Carter voted against the Violent Firearms Offenders Act, a bill introduced by Governor Hogan to strengthen penalties on gun offenders, criticizing it as \"more of the same old  mentality that has failed to reduce crime over the long term\". She also introduced a bill to increase state funding for violence intervention programs to at least $3 million annually, which passed but was vetoed by Hogan; the legislature overrode his veto during the 2021 legislative session.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Carter introduced legislation to repeal the . She voted against the bill in committee after a provision allowing police departments to hand disciplinary decisions over to an independent civilian oversight board was removed. The bill passed and became law after the legislature overrode Governor Hogan's veto of the bill. She also reintroduced Anton's Law, which passed and became law; and introduced another bill to implement a statewide  policy; and supported a bill to limit .\n\nIn 2022, Carter introduced a bill that would reform the state's juvenile sentencing rules, including a ban on confinement for first-time misdemeanor offenses unless a crime involved a gun, and prohibited police from interrogating children without first allowing them to speak to an attorney. The bill passed and became law without Governor Hogan's signature. She also introduced a bill to require police officers convicted of a crime committed while on duty to forfeit all or part of their pensions.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Carter introduced a bill that would require private security guards to be licensed by the state, and establish minimum training standards for security agencies. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor . She also introduced a bill that would repeal a law that automatically charges minors as adults with serious crimes, which failed to move out of committee.\n\n\nDuring the 2004 legislative session, Carter introduced a bill to expand the Baltimore school board from nine members to thirteen, including five appointed members and seven elected members.\n\n\nIn March 2013, Carter said she supported Governor Martin O'Malley's bill to ban assault-type rifles and require a license to purchase a handgun.\n\nIn April 2016, after the Baltimore police shot a 14-year-old boy carrying a BB gun that resembled a pistol, Carter introduced legislation to ban the manufacture and sale of imitation guns.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Carter opposed an -backed bill to increase penalties for illegal gun possession. During debate on the bill, she introduced an amendment to allow people convicted on illegal gun possession charges to apply for , which initially passed before being removed from the bill following a .\n\n\nDuring the 2009 legislative session, Carter introduced legislation to prohibit the closure of the  psychiatric hospital.\n\nCarter supports . In 2020, she and state delegate  introduced a bill to establish a universal  system in Maryland.\n\n\nIn 2019, Carter voted against a bill to loosen ownership limits on marijuana dispensaries, expressing concern that the bill did not consider the state's equity goals.\n\nIn 2021, Carter introduced a bill that would decriminalize the possession of , and later said she was \"heartbroken\" after the bill did not come up for a veto override vote following Governor Larry Hogan's veto. During the 2022 legislative session, Carter introduced legislation to legalize recreational marijuana. She voted against a bill establishing a  to legalize recreational marijuana in Maryland, saying that she believed it was more important to \"hammer out details of licensing and community reparation funds\". In 2023, after voters approved of Question 4, Carter expressed concern with equity within the marijuana industry. She also introduced a bill to ban vehicle searches based on cannabis odor, which passed and became law without Governor 's signature.\n\n\nIn October 2002, Carter appeared in an ad to support , a referendum to reduce the size of the .\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Carter co-sponsored the , which would legalize . However, she staged a walkout during a committee vote on the bill, which she said was to draw attention to \"more important, or at least equally important\" issues of education funding cuts in Baltimore and child custody in divorces. She did not co-sponsor the bill when it was reintroduced in 2012, but voted for it when it came up for a vote in the House. During the 2023 legislative session, she introduced a bill to prohibit discrimination against  and  individuals in state prisons.\n\nIn June 2015, Carter signed onto a letter calling for the renaming of . In 2016, Carter introduced a bill to destroy the  at the . She later amended the bill to send the statue to the .\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Carter introduced a bill to prohibit  board members from holding no-bid contracts with the system. The bill helped prompt the '''''s investigation, which found that nine UMMS board members, including Baltimore mayor , had business deals worth hundreds of thousands of dollars with the hospital network, the bill unanimously passed the  and was signed into law by Governor Larry Hogan. After Pugh resigned amid the UMMS contracts controversy, Carter said that she had made a \"mistake\" in endorsing Pugh in .\n\nIn April 2019, Carter joined Republicans in voting against a bill to eliminate the  on child sexual assault lawsuits, causing it to deadlock in committee. She later voted against the bill on the Senate floor, which she called a difficult vote but added that she felt that \"our law in its current form is enough\".\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Haven N. Shoemaker, Jr.''' (born January 26, 1965) is an American politician who is currently the State's Attorney for . He previously served as a  member of the  from 2015 to 2022, and as the House  in 2022. He also previously served as a Carroll County Commissioner, as Mayor of Hampstead, Maryland, and as a member of the Hampstead Town Council.\n\n\nShoemaker was born in . After graduating from  in , he attended the , where he earned a  degree in political science in 1987, and , where he earned a  degree  in 1992. In between universities, he served in the  for two years.\n\nShoemaker was admitted to the  in 1992 and has operated his own law office since 1994, when he moved in Hampstead.\n\nIn 1995, Shoemaker unsuccessfully ran for the Hampstead Town Council. In 1996, he ran to fill a vacancy in the town council left by the resignation of Dwight W. Homer, but lost to Seth Shipley. He ran again in 1997, winning the election with 227 votes. He served on the town council until he was elected the town's mayor in 2003. He ran on a ticket alongside outgoing mayor Christoper Nevin. In November 2005, Shoemaker announced his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in . He received 14.7 percent of the vote in the Republican primary election. He ran unopposed in 2007.\n\n\nIn 2010, Shoemaker was elected to the Carroll County Board of County Commissioners, representing District 2. He was sworn in on December 6, 2010.\n\nWhile on the Carroll County board of commissioners, Shoemaker introduced an \"English only\" ordinance which was passed unanimously in 2013. He opposed an unsuccessful 2020 proposal to repeal the ordinance which he has called his idea.\n\nIn June 2013, Shoemaker voted to block Carroll County residents and businesses from paying , calling the tax \"idiotic\".\n\nShoemaker announced his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates on June 24, 2013. He won the primary election with 17.3 percent of the vote and defeated Democratic candidates Dorothy G. Scanian and Zachary Hands in the general election with 27.2 percent of the vote.\n\n\nShoemaker was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. He served as the House Minority Whip in 2022.\n\nIn 2016, Shoemaker ran for alternative RNC delegate from  in the , pledged to . He voted for  in the general election, albeit \"not happily\".\n\nShoemaker was re-elected in 2018, during which he ran on a \"Team \" platform alongside state Senator  and Delegates  and .\n\nIn July 2021, Shoemaker announced his candidacy for Carroll County State's Attorney, opting out of a third term in the legislature. He won the Republican primary on July 19, 2022, receiving 57.3 percent of the vote.\n\n\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2021–2022\n* Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2019–2022\n* Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2022\n* Legislative Policy Committee, 2022\n* Member, Ways and Means Committee, 2015–2021 (finance resources subcommittee, 2015–2017; education subcommittee, 2015–2020; election law subcommittee, 2017–2021; early childhood subcommittee, 2021)\n\n\n* Minority Parliamentarian, 2017–2021\n* Chief Deputy Minority Whip, 2021\n* House Chair, Carroll County Delegation, 2017–2022\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2015–2022\n* Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2015–2022\n\n\n\nIn May 2019, Shoemaker accused   of \"playing partisan politics\" in asking officials to review whether the state's  had investments in  after the state passed laws restricting access to abortions.\n\nIn March 2022, Shoemaker voted against legislation that would create a ballot referendum to enshrine access to reproductive care into the .\n\nIn April 2022, Shoemaker voted against legislation that would expand abortion access by expanding who can perform abortions and providing financial support to train health care professionals to offer reproductive services, calling it the \"most radical expansion of abortion in Maryland's history in a state that already has some of the most liberal abortion laws in the country.\"\n\n\nIn December 2020, the Maryland Free Enterprise Association gave Shoemaker a score of 100 percent in its annual legislative scorecard.\n\n\nIn June 2020, Shoemaker attended the Carroll County Freedom Rally to protest the state's coronavirus restrictions. Later in the month, Shoemaker authored a '''' op-ed \"Gov. Hogan deserves an 'F' for his handling the pandemic, roepening\", that argued Governor Hogan wasn't doing enough to reopen businesses in Maryland amid the . In November 2020, he authored another op-ed, \"With Republicans like Gov. Hogan, who needs Democrats?\", that accused Governor Larry Hogan of setting up a \"snitch hotline\" that allows Marylanders to call in crowd-size violations to law enforcement authorities.\n\nIn September 2021, Shoemaker voted against regulations that would implement an universal  in public schools. In February 2022, he called on Governor Hogan to repeal the state's school masking policy.\n\n\nShoemaker introduced legislation in the 2016 legislative session that would limit  for kindergarten students and prevent any future testing of prekindergarten students. The bill passed and became law on April 26, 2016.\n\nIn February 2020, Shoemaker voted against legislation that would reverse a  start date for all public schools in Maryland. In March 2020, Shoemaker voted against the  reform bill.\n\n\nShoemaker introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would require election officials to verify signatures on all , and another bill that would prohibit sending mail-in ballots to voters unless the voters requested them. Both bills did not receive a vote on the House floor.\n\n\nShoemaker opposed the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2021.\n\n\nShoemaker opposed legislation introduced in the 2022 legislative session that would require firearm dealers to install video surveillance and alarm systems at their gun shops, saying that he considered the security requirements \"onerous\".\n\n\nIn July 2017, Shoemaker joined 35 of his House and Senate colleagues penned a letter questioning the legal merits of a lawsuit launched by   over .\n\n\nIn July 2020, Shoemaker hosted a rally outside of the  to support law enforcement officials following the .\n\nIn March 2021, Shoemaker voted against the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, arguing that it would cause a mass exodus of police officers from forces across the state. He also voted against legislation that would end  sentences for s.\n\n\nIn November 2020, Shoemaker called an anti-Donald Trump banner displayed at the house of a  administrator \"hate speech\".\n\nIn April 2021, Shoemaker voted against legislation that would require schools to allow students to engage in s.\n\nShoemaker introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would prohibit registered sex offenders from operating babysitting services.\n\nIn February 2022, Shoemaker voted against legislation that would create a ballot referendum to legalize , saying it would be wrong to legalize marijuana before the state can conduct its study of its public health effects.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Regina T. Boyce''' (born August 7, 1976) is an  who currently serves in the . Delegate Boyce is a  who represents the  of the state of Maryland.\n\n\nBoyce was born on August 7, 1976, in . She graduated from the  in  and later attended  and , where she earned a  degree in  and  in 1998, and the , where she earned a M.P.A. degree in 2014. After graduating, she became the director of the Adult Learning Center for Strong City Baltimore.\n\nBoyce ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in 2018, her first run for elective office. During the primary election, she formed a slate with state Senator  and state Delegate .\n\n\nBoyce was sworn in as a member of the  on January 9, 2019.\n\nIn April 2019, Boyce resigned from the  ahead of the vote to protest comments made by Delegate , the caucus chair, that she found \"unacceptable and infuriating\". Barnes had cast doubt about whether African-American members of the House of Delegates would want to vote for \"a white lesbian\" – referring to Maggie McIntosh, who is openly gay – in the election to nominate a new .\n\nIn August 2021, Boyce was appointed to a commission to study  and make recommendations on new parks in \"recreational deserts\" and upgrades to existing parks.\n\nIn 2023,  announced Boyce as one of two Chief Deputy Whips.\n\n\n* Member, Environment and Transportation Committee, 2019–present (environment subcommittee, 2019–present; natural resources, agriculture & open space subcommittee, 2019–present; motor vehicle & transportation subcommittee, 2020–present)\n* Member, State Park Investment Commission, 2021–present\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2019–present\n* Past member, , 2019\n\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Boyce introduced legislation that would ban people from holding an elected public office and a political party office simultaneously.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Boyce introduced legislation to ban the intentional release of balloons.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Boyce introduced legislation that would require government agencies to evaluate the environmental impacts of their actions.\n\n\nIn 2019, Boyce voted against a bill that would allow  to form its own  force. The bill passed through the Baltimore City Delegation by a vote of 9-4. She later voted against it in the House of Delegates, where it passed 94-42.     "pages": }\n'''David Mercado Valderrama''' (born February 1, 1933) is a Filipino-American politician from Maryland. He served as a  member of the  from 1991 to 2003 and was the first Filipino-American elected to a state legislature on the , as well as the first  and first  elected to the .\n\n\nValderrama was born in  on February 1, 1933. At 16 years old, he went into business for himself, selling everything from cars to cigarettes. He aspired to be a , organizing an orchestra while in high school. He also helped edit the school paper and won national essay contests. He attended , where he earned a  degree in 1956, and , where he earned a  degree in 1988.\n\n\nValderrama became involved with politics while attending college. He spoke out against the regime of   after his declaration of  in the Philippines in 1972, later criticizing him during his meeting with   in 1982. In December 1984, Valderrama was arrested during an  outside of the , and in the following year he formed the Asian Americans Against Apartheid group to encourage community protests against the regime in  and for the release of .\n\nIn 1982, Valderrama ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in . Although his bid was unsuccessful, political observers were surprised with the force in which Philippine American voters turned out to support Valderrama. In 1986,   appointed Valderrama to serve on the .\n\nIn September 2016, Valderrama attended an anti-Marcos protest in  to protest against Philippine President 's decision to allow Marcos' burial at the  cemetery.\n\n\nValderrama was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 1991. From 1995 to 2001, he served the , and as the Deputy Majority Leader of the House of Delegates from 2001 to 2003. During his service, he unsuccessfully pushed for the legalization of .\n\n\n* Member, Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee, 1991–92\n* Member, Environmental Matters Committee, 1992–94\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 1995–2003 (gambling subcommittee, 1995–97; chair, gaming law & enforcement subcommittee, 1999–2003)\n* Member, Joint Committee on Protocol, 1995–2003\n\n\n* Member, Law Enforcement and State-Appointed Boards Committee,  (chair, 1995–98)\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William H. Cole IV''' (born November 21, 1972) is an  who represented the 11th District on the . He was first elected to a four-year term beginning in December 2007 and served until his appointment by the mayor in August 2014 as CEO and president of the .\n\n\nWilliam H. Cole IV was born on November 21, 1972, in . He attended Loyola Blakefield High School in Towson, Maryland, and graduated with a  in government and politics from the  in 1994. He graduated with a  in legal and ethical studies from the  in 1996. Cole was a member of the Alpha Epsilon Lambda Honor Society.\n\n\nCole began his career in government as an intern in the  in 1994, then served two sessions as a legislative aide to former state senator , chairman of the judicial proceedings committee. In 1996, he was hired by Congressman  (MD-07) as staff assistant and later special assistant managing one of three district offices. He remained on the congressman's full-time staff until January 2003.\n\nCole was elected to the Maryland Democratic State Central Committee in 1998 and in January 1999 was appointed by  to fill the district  seat in the  seat vacated by . He served on the House Judiciary Committee, its Family & Juvenile Law Subcommittee, and the House Special Committee on Drug & Alcohol Abuse. The 2002 legislative redistricting process eliminated Baltimore's 47th Legislative District in Baltimore City and Cole lost to three incumbents in the newly formed 46th Legislative District in September 2002.\n\nFirst elected to the 11th District of the Baltimore City Council in September 2007 after defeating 8 other primary opponents, Cole was re-elected in 2011 winning 75% of the vote. During his two terms on the City Council, Cole chaired a number of standing and special committees including Taxation, Finance & Economic Development, Executive Nominations, Housing & Community Development, Recreation & Parks and the Special Committees on Property Tax Reduction, New Homeowners Tax Credit, and the Maritime Industrial Overlay District Review. He also served as a member the Land Use & Transportation, Budget & Appropriates, Health, Education, and Public Safety Committees.\n\nHe was elected as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte from the 3rd Congressional District in 2012.\n\nIn August 2014, Cole resigned from the Baltimore City Council after he was appointed President & CEO of the  (BDC) by Mayor . During his time at BDC, he led Baltimore's business recovery efforts  after the 2015  and spearheaded the efforts to keep the  in Baltimore.\n\nIn April 2019, he announced that he was leaving BDC to join former Howard County Executive  as a partner in Ulman's consulting firm, Margrave Strategies.\n\n\nCole has served on more than a dozen boards & commissions including the Downtown Partnership of Baltimore, Waterfront Partnership of Baltimore, Visit Baltimore, the Baltimore Hotel Corporation, Midtown Community Benefits District. Since 2013, he has chaired Cecil Bank and its holding company, Cecil Bancorp, Inc., leading the state-chartered financial institution through two recapitalizations and a release from a 2010 regulatory \"written agreement\" the bank operated under until 2022.\n\nCole is a 2018 fellow in equitable economic development at the , a partnership with the Urban Land Institute and the National League of Cities. He is a 2012 alumnus of the  Young Leaders Conference and a member of the 2012 class of New Deal Leaders.\n\nIn October 2022, he was appointed by Senate President  to the  Board of Directors.  He helped create the Maryland Thoroughbred Racing Operating Authority in 2023.\n\n\nCole and his wife, Michelle, have three adult children and live in the Otterbein neighborhood of downtown Baltimore.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jennifer R. Terrasa''' (born June 6, 1969) is an American politician who has served as a  member of the  since 2019. She was previously a member of the  from 2006 to 2018.\n\n\nTerrasa was born on June 6, 1969, in . Her family moved to  when she was a toddler, where she graduated from . She attended the  in , where she earned a  degree in sociology in 1992, and the , where she earned a  degree in law review in 1997. She was admitted to the  in the same year. \n\nAfter graduating, she served as a law clerk to  judge Howard S. Chasanow until 1998 and Howard County Circuit Court judge Lenore R. Gelfman until 1999. From 2000 to 2006, Terrasa served as a family law hotline attorney for the Women's Law Center of Maryland.\n\n\nIn 1994, Terrasa moved to the  neighborhood of Columbia. She was appointed to the neighborhood's Village Board in December 2001, succeeding Victoria Dieringer, who resigned for personal reasons. She resigned from the Village Board in December 2005 to run for the Howard County Council, seeking to succeed councilmember , who announced plans to run for the Maryland House of Delegates. She won the general election with 62.0 percent of the vote.\n\nTerrasa was a national delegate for  at the . Before the , Terrasa canvassed alongside county council member  in  for Obama.\n\nTerrasa faced a tough re-election campaign in 2010, facing off against  moderate Dennis R. Schrader in the general election. She defeated Schrader in the general election, receiving 67.1 percent of the vote.\n\nIn January 2018, Terrasa declared her candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates, seeking to succeed delegate . who announced plans to retire at the end of his term. Turner endorsed Terrasa's campaign in January 2018. She won the Democratic primary with 27.7 percent of the vote, coming in third out of a field of four Democrats. She won the general election with 27.1 percent of the vote, defeating Republican Chris Yates.\n\n\nTerrasa was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019.\n\nIn February 2022, House Speaker  assigned Terrasa and  to lead the newly created Progressive Policy Forum within the House Democratic Caucus.\n\n\n* Member, Environment and Transportation Committee, 2019–present (housing & real property subcommittee, 2020–present; land use & ethics subcommittee, 2020–present; local government & bi-county agencies subcommittee, 2020–present)\n* Member, Appropriations Committee, 2019 (health & social services subcommittee, 2019; oversight committee on personnel, 2019)\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019–present\n* Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Women Legislators of Maryland, 2019–present\n\n\n\nTerrasa, alongside Howard County Council chairman Jon Weinstein, introduced legislation in February 2016 that would create a public financing system for candidates who swear off large donations. The legislation was reintroduced in 2017.\n\n\nIn March 2021, Terrasa, alongside Delegates , , and Vaughn Stewart, joined the Leaders for Climate Accountability, a national work of public officials who support holding corporate polluters accountable for their contributions to the . She introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would allow the  to sue companies that have contributed to the climate crisis through fraud or deception. The bill was reintroduced in the 2022 legislative session.\n\n\nTerrasa supports  and . She co-sponsored the Healthy Maryland Act of 2019, which would institute Medicare-for-all, single-payer healthcare legislation in Maryland.\n\n\nIn October 2015, Terrasa introduced legislation that would require 15 percent of all new housing units developed in downtown Columbia to be affordable to families earning between 40 and 80 percent of the county's median income.\n\nIn October 2018, Terrasa introduced a bill that would require new  and apartments to have infrastructure to support charging stations for s.\n\n\nFollowing the election of President-elect , Terrasa introduced legislation that would designate Howard County a .\n\n\nTerrasa supports the legalization and regulation of .\n\n\nTerrasa supports using an  to draw Maryland's legislative and congressional district maps.\n\n\nIn July 2018, Terrasa introduced legislation that would repeal Howard County's tax on mobile home rental sites. The County Council voted to kill the bill in September 2018.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Melony Ghee Griffith''' (born June 5, 1963) is an American politician who was a member of the  representing  in  from 2019 until her resignation on October 31, 2023.  She previously served as  of the Maryland Senate from 2020 to 2023, and as a member of the  from 1999 to 2015.\n\n\nMelony Ghee was born on June 5, 1963, in , to father Frank F. Ghee Jr., and mother Mary E. Ghee. She grew up as a  in  and graduated from . She later attended , where she earned her Bachelor of Science degree in psychology, criminology and rehabilitation in 1985. In 1987, she graduated from  with a  degree.\n\n\nAfter graduating from Howard, Griffith worked as a . From 1992 to 1993, she worked as a project coordinator for the 's Health Education Project at the . She later served as a senior program officer for the  from 1998 to 2004, afterwards working in various positions for the Prince George's County Health Department until 2009.\n\nGriffith first got involved in politics in 1996, running as a  for the  in District 7.\n\n\nGriffith was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 13, 1999. She was a member of the Judiciary Committee until 2002, afterwards serving on the Appropriations Committee until she left the legislature in 2015. During her tenure, Griffith gained a reputation as a policy wonk, especially in health care policy.\n\nIn 2000, Griffith served as a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\n\n;2014\nOn October 15, 2013, Griffith announced that she would run for the Maryland Senate in District 25, challenging incumbent state senator . Currie was seen as a vulnerable candidate following his federal corruption trial, in which he was acquitted after arguing that his conducts violated Senate ethics rules rather than federal laws, and subsequent .\n\nThe Democratic primary was seen as the most competitive election in the district since Currie's election in , with the Prince George's County establishment backing Currie and area newspapers backing Griffith. Griffith ran on a platform focusing on economic development, jobs, education, and public safety, and ran a \"nice\" campaign against Currie, whom she considered a friend, by not mentioning his corruption charges to voters. Currie enjoyed a significant fundraising advantage over Griffith, having almost three times the cash on hand as her.\n\nGriffith was defeated by Currie in the Democratic primary in June 2014, receiving 37.7 percent of the vote to Currie's 58.7 percent.\n\n;2018\nIn November 2016, after state senator Ulysses Currie announced he would resign from the Maryland Senate, Griffith applied to serve the remainder of his term in the Maryland Senate. However, Currie rescinded his resignation later in the month a few days before it was sent to go into effect, citing the \"political fighting\" over the selection of his replacement.\n\nIn June 2017, after Currie announced that he would not seek re-election in , Griffith announced that she would again run for the Maryland Senate in District 25. She received support from the Prince George's County establishment in her run against state delegate , whom she defeated in the Democratic primary with 55 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nGriffith was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. She was a member of the Budget and Taxation Committee from 2019 to 2022, afterwards serving as the chair of the Finance Committee.\n\nIn January 2020, Griffith was elected by the Maryland Senate to serve as president pro tempore, making her the first African American woman to have the role. She stepped down as president pro tempore in 2023.\n\nDuring the , Griffith supported  and served as a co-chair of the Maryland Women for Biden group, alongside , , and .\n\n and House Speaker  enacting law in 2022]]\nIn April 2022, Griffith signed 103 Maryland measures into law together with Republican Governor  and House Speaker . It was the first time that two Black women had taken part in such a ceremony as Maryland's presiding officers. Jones represented the house while Griffith as the President pro tem represented the Maryland Senate.\n\nOn October 6, 2023, Griffith announced that she would resign from the  at the end of the month to become the head of the Maryland Hospital Association. She is the organization's fifth president, as well as the first African American woman to hold the position.\n\n\nGriffith has two children and has lived in  since 2002.\n\nIn May 1999, Jeb Bello, a  at the  in , filed a lawsuit against Griffith, asking for $3.1 million in damages and alleging that she defamed him by portraying him as \"a bigot and a racist\" for seating a white couple before her and a Black companion, which culminated into a campaign that prevented him from finding another job in Annapolis. The case was settled out of court in January 2001.\n\n\n\nGriffith chaired a work group to develop House Speaker ' \"Black agenda\", which included proposals to extend  coverage for pregnant women until 12 months postpartum.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Griffith said she supported a bill to allow non-citizens to enroll in health insurance programs, calling it a \"first good step\".\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, during a committee hearing on the Fair Wage Act, a bill that would have raised the minimum wage to $15 an hour by October 2023 and indexed future increases to , Griffith supported an amendment to the bill delaying the increase to 2024 and removing provisions indexing it to inflation.\n\n\nIn October 2011, ahead of the special legislative session to redraw , Griffith expressed disappointment with the failed  pressure campaign toward Governor  to draw a map that considered \"specific issued raised by the caucus\".\n\n\nIn 2001, Griffith voted for a bill to ban discrimination on the basis of . During the 2006 legislative session, she voted against overturning a committee decision to kill a proposed constitutional amendment to ban . In December 2011, Griffith said she opposed the , a bill to legalize same-sex marriage in Maryland.\n\nDuring the 2007 legislative session, Griffith voted for a bill creating a referendum to legalize  gambling in Maryland. In February 2012, she said she opposed a plan to build a casino in , noting that Prince George's County voted against slots in the 2008 referendum and saying that she preferred \"other forms\" of economic development for the county.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

In 2007, she became the Deputy Minority Whip in the .  Shewell represents District 5A, which covers .\n\n\nTanya Shewell attended  in  and graduated as valedictorian.     "pages": }\n'''Charles Anthony Muse''' (born April 17, 1958) is an American politician and minister who has served in the  representing  since 2023, and previously from 2007 to 2019. A member of the , he represented the district in the  from 1995 to 1999. Muse unsuccessfully challenged incumbent U.S. Senator  in , and ran for  in 2002 and .\n\n\nMuse was born in  on April 17, 1958. He was one of six children born to Gloria Watson, who had her first child when she was a teenager and married a man prone to violent outbursts, frequently beating him, his siblings, and his mother. They grew up in the  neighbourhood of Baltimore. At age 12,  his mother announced that they were moving to  to escape their stepfather. Muse fled from his family and lived with his older brother, afterwards he passed through 11 foster families before settling with  pastor George Stansbury.\n\nMuse was expelled from three different school systems, including from , where he jumped up on a lunchroom table and starting a fight with other students. As a teenager, he became mixed up with the wrong crowd and eventually needed to be rescued by Stansbury after running into a drug dealer whom he feared was going to harm him. Muse began preaching at his father's church by age 13.\n\nMuse attended , where he earned a  degree in history in 1981; , where he earned a  degree in 1984; and , where he earned a  degree in church and community development in 1991.\n\n\nMuse began working in the ministry at age 20, first preaching at the Mount Zion United Methodist Church in , where he became known for his dramatic preaching and for adding guitars and drums to the service. He was reassigned to work as a pastor at the  in  from 1984 to 1999, during which he expanded the church from 120 members to over 4,000 worshippers. Shortly after he left the church, Methodist leaders said that the church was $6 million in debt and had bond payments that were \"seriously in arrears\". Bishop Felton May offered the church $1.2 million in aid to help the church repay its debts, which Muse said was \"not generous enough\" and led him to resign from the Methodist denomination to become a nondenominational pastor. In interviews with '''', Muse offered a series of reasons for leaving the church, including \"theological differences\" in United Methodist's decision to appoint a  pastor, accusations that the church hierarchy did not support his congregation because they \"are racist\", and did not like his style of worship, which involved  and . After leaving the denomination, he started his own church, the Ark of Safety Christian Church, in .\n\nIn May 2000, United Methodist Church officials filed a lawsuit against Muse to sort out assets and debts, which was settled with Muse paying the church $13,000 in exchange for the return of a television set and desk in 2002. After the church closed later that year, he acquired the property for $3.2 million and moved the church he founded, the Ark of Safety Christian Church, to the location. The Ark of declared bankruptcy in 2012 following the . A court modified the church's mortgage terms, and the church continued to make regular payments until it  in 2017, after which it began leasing the property. In January 2020, TMI Realty Advisors, who owned the site of Ark of Safety, motion to evict the congregation, alleging in court documents that Muse had not paid its $15,000 monthly rent since June.\n\n\nFrom 1987 to 1992, Muse worked as a member of the Maryland State Ethics Commission. He became involved in politics after businessman Sydney Moore, who compared him to , introduced him to influential Black politicians in county politics. In 1990, Muse unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in , challenging incumbent delegates Gary R. Alexander, , and , all three of whom were running on a slate backed by Senate President  During the campaign, he filed a complaint with the  after discovering campaign signs that had defaced with racist phrases. Muse was defeated in the Democratic primary election, placing last with 18 percent of the vote. After his defeat, he moved to , where he was invited to run for the House of Delegates in District 26 by state senator .\n\n\nMuse was sworn into the  on January 11, 1995, where he was a member of the Ways and Means Committee. He did not seek re-election to a second term in 1998, instead mounting an unsuccessful  in District 26, challenging incumbent state senator Gloria Lawlah, whom he criticized for voting against school construction bills. He narrowly lost the Democratic primary to Lawlah by a margin of 267 votes, or two percent.\n\nIn June 2005, Muse told the ''Washington Post'' that he was exploring another run for state senator in District 26, again challenging Lawlah. He entered the race after Lawlah announced that she would not seek re-election in , and defeated state delegate  in the Democratic primary election. In November 2006, Muse campaigned with Republican governor .\n\n\nMuse was first sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 10, 2007. He served as a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee from 2007 to 2010, and again from 2013 to 2019, and on the Finance Committee from 2010 to 2013. Muse was transferred from the Finance Committee to the Judicial Proceedings Committee for repeatedly opposing a bill proposed by Governor  to strengthen the state's wind energy industry, a move he expressed frustration with.\n\nIn 2022, Muse filed to run for the Maryland Senate in District 26, seeking to succeed retiring state senator Obie Patterson. He narrowly won the Democratic primary election on July 19, defeating challenger Tamara Davis Brown by a margin of 345 votes, or 1.2 percent. He won the general election and was sworn in on January 11, 2023. Muse is a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee.\n\n\n\n\nOn May 19, 2002, Muse announced his campaign for Prince George's County Executive, seeking to succeed term-limited county executive . During the Democratic primary, he ran on a platform of abolishing  and requiring uniforms in schools, and received endorsements from county religious leaders. Muse raised the second most funding out of candidates in the race with $347,000 cash on hand in August 2002, behind M. H. Jim Estepp.\n\nMuse was defeated in the Democratic primary by eventual winner , placing third with 18.7 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nOn June 26, 2017, Muse announced that he would again run for Prince George's County Executive in , seeking to succeed term-limited county executive . Muse was seen as one of the three frontrunners in the race, alongside state's attorney  and former congresswoman . He sought to position himself as an outsider rallying against the \"political machine\", and received endorsements from local labor unions.\n\nMuse was defeated in the Democratic primary by Alsobrooks, placing third with 10 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn September 2011, Muse said that he was exploring a  in 2012, challenging incumbent Senator . He announced his candidacy on January 5, 2012, and ran on a platform of addressing foreclosures, education disparities, and high unemployment.\n\nDuring the Democratic primary, Muse received endorsements from state religious leaders, but was heavily out-raised and out-funded by Cardin, who had the backing of the Maryland Democratic establishment and President , which led Muse to complain that the state party should \"do a better job staying neutral\" in the contest. Muse was defeated in the Democratic primary in April 2012, placing second and receiving 15.7 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nMuse is married to Pat Lawson Muse, an anchor for . Together, they have a daughter, whom they adopted after Muse officiated the funeral of her mother.\n\n\nMuse has been described as a .\n\n\nIn April 2004, Muse opened a 24-hour shelter at his Ark of Safety church to house victims of . In July 2005, he partnered with other churches and the Prince George's County Police Department to provide services to domestic violence victims and to create job training programs with local businesses in an effort to reduce violent crime in the county.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Muse voted for a bill to abolish the death penalty.\n\nIn 2015, he introduced legislation to remove the  from the state's parole board.\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Muse introduced a bill that would repeal a rule adopted by the  that prevented courts from setting a high bail on low-income defendants.\n\n\nIn 1996, Muse voted for a bill to provide state funding for the construction of .\n\nIn June 2011, Muse launched an effort aimed at blocking the construction of a high-end  near , which he claimed would create unmanageable traffic on .\n\n\nIn 1996, Muse introduced a bill to create a task force on deciding whether to enforce mandatory uniforms at public schools. The bill passed and became law, and the task force recommended against uniforms later that year. In 1997, he introduced a bill that would require uniforms in public schools, despite the task force's recommendations, which passed the  in a 11-9 vote.\n\nIn 1997, Muse introduced legislation that would make the  fully appointed. During his 2002 and 2018 county executive campaigns, he said he would support making the school board fully elected. He also expressed support for increasing teacher pay and to refurbish aging schools.\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Muse voted against , a bill that extended  for .\n\nIn 2013, Muse was the only member of the  to vote against a bill to give the Prince George's County Executive control over the county school system's budget.\n\n\nMuse was opposed to legislation proposed by Governor  to strengthen Maryland's  industry.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, during debate on a bill establishing a statewide referendum on expanding gambling in Maryland, Muse supported an amendment that would allow  to be played at casinos, saying that card games \"don't come with many of the same social ills as slots.\"\n\nIn February 2012, Muse said he opposed plans to build a billion-dollar casino near  and vowed to \"do everything in my power\" to stop the deal from passing. The bill passed the Maryland Senate in a 35-11 vote, with Muse being one of two Prince George's County-based senators to vote against it.\n\nIn February 2017, Muse voted against the nomination of Gordon Medenica to serve as the chair of the .\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Muse voted for the Firearm Safety Act, which placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nMuse opposes same-sex marriage on religious grounds. In 2007, he voted against a bill to ban discrimination against transgender people. In February 2011, Muse voted against a bill to legalize , predicting that the bill would open the doors to making  and marriage between people of very different ages \"acceptable.\"\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Muse attended rallies opposing and later voted against the . During debate on the bill, he introduced an amendment to rename it to the \"Marriage Redefinition Act\", saying that the bill would redefine marriage from being \"between one man and one woman\". After the bill became law and , Muse donated to groups opposing the referendum.\n\nIn 2014, Muse voted for a bill to ban discrimination against transgender people.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 special legislative session, Muse was the only Democratic state senator to vote against the congressional redistricting plan proposed by Governor , accusing the legislature of putting party politics before voters and manipulating minority communities.\n\n\nIn 1998, Muse said he opposed abortion. During the 2023 legislative session, Muse voted in favor of putting a  before voters in 2024.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Muse voted against a bill to legalize  for terminally ill patients. In March 2023, he expressed openness to voting for a bill to legalize palliative care.\n\nIn August 2017, after Senate President  defended , the former Supreme Court Chief Justice who authored the infamous , Muse called for his . No action was taken.\n\n\nDuring his 2002 county executive campaign, Muse said he would support lifting Prince George's County's cap on property taxes. In 2012, he voted for a bill that would allow full funding of any school spending plan approved by the County Council. During the 2015 legislative session, Muse introduced legislation that sought to block a proposed 15 percent property tax increase in Prince George's County.\n\nIn 2012, Muse voted against a bill to raise es on Maryland's wealthiest residents.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jolene Ivey''' ( Stephenson; born July 30, 1961) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  since 2018, first representing the 5th district from 2018 to 2024 and then the county's at-large district since 2024. She has also served as the council's president since 2023. A member of the , Ivey was a member of the  from the  from 2007 to 2015.\n\nIvey unsuccessfully ran for  on the ticket of Maryland Attorney General  in , placing second behind Lieutenant Governor  and his running mate .\n\n\nIvey was born in  on July 30, 1961, to father Joseph L. Stephenson, an African-American  captain during , and mother Shirlita Hutchins, a white woman. Her parents divorced when she was three years old, and her father remarried to Genevieve Abel Stephenson, an African-American woman, in 1968, when Jolene was seven. Ivey graduated from  and later attended , where she earned a  degree in mass communication in 1982, and the , earning a  degree in journalism in 1992.\n\n\nAfter graduating from Towson, Ivey worked as a co-host of ''Say Baltimore'' on  and  from 1983 to 1984, afterwards working as a writer and producer for WMAR-TV until 1988. She has worked as a freelance writer since 1989, and as the director of media relations for the Community Teachers Institute since 2004.\n\nIvey first got involved in politics after being elected class representative as a senior at High Point High School in 1978. She later volunteered for 's . From 1988 to 1989, Ivey worked as the press secretary for U.S. Representative  from 1988 to 1989. In 1997, she started Mocha Moms, a support group for at-home mothers of color that also pushed for policy changes to support breastfeeding mothers.\n\n\n share info on House floor]]\nIvey ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in , challenging the district's three incumbents. She defeated delegate Rosetta Parker in the September 2006 Democratic primary and ran unopposed alongside delegates Doyle Niemann and Victor R. Ramirez in the general election. Ivey was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 10, 2007. She was a member of the Ways and Means Committee during her entire tenure and served as the chair of the  from 2012 to 2014. She also focused on issues related to children and families, and was supportive of  and efforts to authorize a casino in Prince George's County.\n\nIvey was a delegate to the , pledged to U.S. Senator .\n\nIn December 2012, Ivey defended former state delegate  following her suspension from office after being found guilty of stealing state funds to pay an employee at her law firm, saying that Alston should still have her seat \"if the truth is that she made a sloppy bookkeeping mistake\".\n\n\n\nIn September 2013, '''' reported that Maryland Attorney General  had narrowed his running mate choices to a handful of politicians from Prince George's County and Baltimore, including Ivey. Gansler announced Ivey as his running mate on October 14, 2013. On the campaign trail, Ivey criticized Lieutenant Governor  as a \"failed leader\" and focused her attacks on his voting record, mismanagement of the state's , and his decision to send his children to a . She also defended Gansler after the '''' published a photo showing him at a house party attended by his son where underage drinking was taking place.\n\nGansler and Ivey were defeated in the Democratic primary election by Brown on June 24, 2014, placing second with 24.2 percent of the vote. Had the Gansler-Ivey ticket won the Democratic primary and defeated  in the general election, Ivey would have been the first Democratic African American woman to serve as lieutenant governor in the United States and the second nationwide, behind only Florida Lieutenant Governor . Following her defeat, Ivey worked as a community relations representative for  in its bid to bring the 's new headquarters to Prince George's County.\n\n\n\nIn October 2015, Ivey said that she was planning to run for Prince George's County Executive in 2018, seeking to succeed term-limited county executive ; she instead filed to run for the Prince George's County Council in District 5 in May 2017, seeking to succeed term-limited councilmember . Her campaign focused on improving constituent services in the county. Ivey defeated former  mayor Walter James Jr. in the Democratic primary on June 26, 2018, and ran unopposed in the general election.\n\nIvey was sworn in to the Prince George's County Council on December 3, 2018. '''' has described Ivey as a member of the county council's liberal bloc. She ran unopposed for a second term in 2022.  In December 2022, outgoing county council chair Calvin Hawkins nominated Ivey to succeed him as council chair. However, she declined the nomination, instead nominating Tom Dernoga, who was unanimously elected to serve as chair. In December 2023, the Prince George's County Council unanimously voted to elect Ivey as its chair.\n\nIn June 2024, after county councilmember Mel Frankin resigned from his at-large seat on the county council, Ivey told  that she would run in the  to succeed Franklin. She won the Democratic primary on August 6, 2024, and will face Republican nominee Michael Riker in the general election.\n\nIn October 2024, Ivey said that she would run for Prince George's County Executive if  defeats  in the .\n\n\nIvey met her future husband, , through a mutual friend who attended Jolene's high school and Glenn's law school. They have been married since 1988, have five childrenincluding Maryland delegate and live in . All five were home births. Ivey is a member of the Cheverly United Methodist Church.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Ivey supported Prince George's County Executive 's plan to take control of the , calling it the \"final and most important piece in our county's renaissance.\" In 2014, she criticized a proposal by Governor  to provide $4 million to expand access to  classes, saying that it was too little of an amount to do much to support kids who needed it.\n\nIn October 2020, Ivey voted against a plan to build six schools in Prince George's County using a , expressing concerns with the partnership's lack of transparency and questioning its timing amid the .\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session and after Prince George's County councilmember  plead guilty to federal corruption charges, Ivey introduced a bill to amend the  to add an amendment requiring officeholders who plead guilty or are convicted of a felony to immediately resign from office.\n\n\nIn February 2012, Ivey voted for a bill to impose a five-cent tax on plastic bags in Prince George's County.\n\n\nIvey supports relocating the 's headquarters to Prince George's County.\n\nIn October 2013, Ivey said that she opposed plans to redevelop part of the  into an academic village of housing, office, and retail development.\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Ivey introduced legislation to ban s from being built on  properties.\n\nIn 2019, Ivey introduced a bill to eliminate and cut the county's  application fees, which were among the most expensive in the . The bill passed and became law.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Ivey testified for legislation that would allow local governments to pass  laws.\n\nIn April 2024, Ivey expressed concerns with a proposal to cap rent increases in Prince George's County at three percent per year, saying that it was \"not a permanent solution\" and would scare away landlords in a county where nearly four in every ten residents is a renter.\n\n\nDuring her 2014 lieutenant gubernatorial campaign, Ivey said she supported decriminalizing marijuana use, pointing to the penalties' disproportionate impact on African Americans and Latinos. She declined to back legalization, worrying that it would make Maryland a magnet for people in surrounding states where it remained illegal.\n\n\nIn October 2015, Ivey supported a bill that required Prince George's County businesses to provide employees up to seven days of  annually.\n\n\nIn October 2021, Ivey voted against the county council redistricting plan proposed by councilmember Derrick Leon Davis and criticized the county council for voting to approve it over the map that was being drawn by the county's redistricting commission. Davis' redistricting plan was overturned and replaced by the commission-drawn map by the  in March 2022.\n\n\nDuring her tenure in the House of Delegates, Ivey advocated for the removal of the  at the . She attended the memorial's removal in August 2017. Ivey also supported repealing \"\" as the official state song. In 2013, she introduced legislation to designate November 1, the day on which , as \"Maryland Emancipation Day\".\n\nIvey supported the  amidst efforts to repeal it in 2013, but eventually voted for a bill to repeal it after her husband  testified for it.\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Ivey supported the , which legalized . In October 2012, she appeared in an ad to support .\n\nIn June 2021, Ivey expressed frustration with the county's spending of at least $17.6 million toward defending the county in police discrimination lawsuits, saying that the county should do more to stand up for African-Americans as a majority-Black county.\n\nIn October 2022, Ivey voted against the appointment of outgoing councilmember Todd Turner as the chair of the county ethics office, expressing concerns with his integrity in the office.\n\n\nDuring her tenure in the House of Delegates, Ivey voted for increases to the state's , , , and . She opposed a proposal to raise property taxes in Prince George's County amidst the .\n\n\nIvey opposed proposals by Governor  to expand the . She also opposed proposals to build a  train connecting  and , saying that it would \"disproportionately benefit the wealthy\" and hurt the county by peeling customers away from .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n|votes      = 249,398\n|percentage = 51.4\n}}\n\n|votes      = 117,383\n|percentage = 24.2\n}}\n\n|votes      = 104,721\n|percentage = 21.6\n}}\n\n|votes      = 6,863\n|percentage = 1.4\n}}\n\n|votes      = 3,507\n|percentage = 0.7\n}}\n\n|votes      = 3,221\n|percentage = 0.7\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Stephen W. Lafferty''' (born February 28, 1949) is an  who was a member of  from January 2007 to September 2019, representing District 42 from 2007 to 2015, and District 42A from 2015 to 2019. Lafferty was the first  to be elected in district 42 since it was moved to  after the 21st century census and redistricting. In September 2019, he resigned from the House of Delegates to serve as chief sustainability officer for  .\n\n\nLafferty was born in , on February 28, 1949. He attended the  where he earned his B.A. in American studies in 1971. Just a year later at , he earned a M.A. also in American studies; and then a teacher's certificate at Towson State University in 1977. He was a teacher (mathematics & social studies) for Baltimore City Public Schools from 1974–1978. Lafferty served as executive director & assistant director for the  during 1978–1980. He received a J.D. from the  in 1983. He was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1983.\n\nHe is married to Betsy Lafferty. Lafferty resides in Stoneleigh.\n\n\nLafferty was a member of House of Delegates from January 10, 2007, to September 6, 2019. He served on the House Environmental Matters Committee and its housing & real property, its land use & ethics and its local government & bi-county subcommittees. He also contributed to the ground rent legislation of 2007 through the ground rent work group.\n\n\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted in favor of prohibiting ground rents in 2007(SB106)\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000\n* voted for Jessica's Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007\n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008\n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009\n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet, 2009\n* co-sponsored and voted for HB0294 (cross filed with SB281) that restricted gun possession, 2012\n\n\nIn 2019, Lafferty became Baltimore county's first chief sustainability officer.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42: \n*2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42A: \n*2018 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42A: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Barrie Ciliberti''' (born July 27, 1936) is an American professor and politician. He is a professor at the  and current  legislator in the , representing . He previously represented  in the House of Delegates from 1995 to 1999.\n\n\nCiliberti was born in , where he graduated from . He later attended , where he earned a  degree in history in 1957; , where he earned a  degree in history in 1960; and , where he earned a  degree in administration in 1975.\n\nCiliberti is married to his wife, Pam, and has five adult children. Outside of politics, he enjoys  and spending time with his children. His family moved from  to  in the early 2000s.\n\n\nSince 1965, Ciliberti has worked as an associate professor of education at .\n\nIn 1985, Ciliberti was appointed by President  to a member of the National Graduate Fellows Program Fellowship Board for a six-year term. President Reagan also appointed Dr Ciliberti to serve as a member of the National Advisory Council on Adult Education. He has served as a guest lecturer for the  and a special assistant for ethnic affairs with the .\n\nIn 1994, Ciliberti was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in District 39, riding the  to victory. He lost re-election to a second term in 1998, losing to Democrats , , and .\n\nCiliberti unsuccessfully ran for Congress in , losing to incumbent   in the Republican primary election.\n\nDr. Ciliberti has served two civilian tours in  working with the United States Department of State.  On his first term, he worked with the United States Embassy in  on election security in advance of the . Dr. Ciliberti's second tour was 255 miles north of Baghdad in the city of Mosul, Iraq where he served as the Senior Governance Advisor for Ninewah Province where he helped build the governance capacity of Provincial and city leaders throughout .\n\nIn 2014, Ciliberti unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 4, receiving 14.0 percent of the vote in the Republican primary.\n\nIn January 2015, the Frederick County Republican Central Committee recommended Ciliberti to replace  in the Maryland House of Delegates after she was appointed to serve in Governor-elect 's cabinet as the . The Carroll County Republican Central Committee also voted to recommend Ciliberti, in addition to Jason Miller and Ken Timmerman, to fill the vacancy. Hogan appointed Ciliberti to the House of Delegates on February 3, 2015.\n\n\nCiliberti was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates to represent District 39 on January 11, 1995. During his legislative career in the Maryland General Assembly, he became known for his opposition to mandatory  and his stance against aggressive driving.\n\nCiliberti was again sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates to represent District 4 on February 4, 2015 after paying campaign finance infractions for missing campaign finance reports.\n\nCiliberti was an early and enthusiastic supporter of , even when many in the  were keeping their distance. In 2016, Ciliberti ran for National Delegate to the , pledged to Trump. He won the Republican primary with 15.4 percent of the vote. He ran again as an Alternate Delegate pledged to Trump in , receiving 32.8 percent of the vote in the Republican primary.\n\n\n* Member, Environment and Transportation Committee, 2019–present (housing & real property subcommittee, 2019–present; land use & ethics subcommittee, 2019–present)\n* Special Joint Committee on Pensions, 2017–2018\n* Appropriations Committee, 2015–2018 (education & economic development subcommittee, 2015–2018; oversight committee on pensions, 2015–2018)\n* Member, Environmental Matters Committee, 1995–1999 (environmental & natural resources subcommittee)\n* Member, Joint Committee to Study Mandates on Local Government, 1995–1997\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2016–present\n* Member, Maryland Military Installation Legislative Caucus, 2017–present\n\n\n\nCiliberti supports the overturning of '''', saying that the issue of abortion should be left to the states.\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Ciliberti introduced legislation that would prohibit abortions past 20 weeks, excluding specific medical emergencies. The bill was re-introduced during the 2016 legislative session.\n\nIn September 2015, Ciliberti and state Senator  wrote a letter to , the Maryland Secretary of Budget and Management, to push the state to eliminate funding for  from the state's budget.\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Ciliberti introduced a bill that would require a 24-hour waiting period after a pregnant person receives a  before a provider could perform an abortion.\n\n\nIn July 2015, the Maryland Business for Responsible Government gave Ciliberti a score of 86 percent in its annual legislative scorecard.\n\n\nCiliberti introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would charge people who attack doctors or nurses with a sentence of up to 10 years in prison, a $5,000 fine, or both.\n\nIn April 2020, Ciliberti questioned the legality of the  implemented by an executive order issued by Governor Hogan, calling the mandates \"draconian\".\n\n\nIn April 2019, Ciliberti voted against the . He was the only member of the Frederick County delegation to do so.\n\n\nIn July 2015, the Maryland Business for Responsible Government gave Ciliberti a score of 50 percent in its annual legislative scorecard.\n\nIn April 2021, Ciliberti joined Democrats in the House Environment and Transportation Committee in voting in favor of the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2021.\n\n\nIn March 2018, Ciliberti voted against a bill that would ban s, which passed the Maryland House of Delegates by a vote of 128-7. He was the only member of the Frederick County delegation to vote against the bill.\n\n\nIn December 2019, Ciliberti called the  an \"attempted \".\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Meagan C. Simonaire''' (born August 8, 1990) is a former American politician from  and was the youngest member of the . She represented House District 31B (which includes  and portions of ,  and ) in the  from 2014 to 2018. She is the daughter of  .\n\n\n\nSimonaire is the third of seven brothers and sisters, and spent most of her childhood in the Middle East where her  worked as an engineer for .\n \nAfter she moved to the U.S., she attended  in  to study cosmetology.\n\n\n\n\n\nSimonaire was elected to the House of Delegates in 2014 to one of the two seats in House District 31B. After a competitive primary, Simonaire beat out several other candidates to win a seat alongside then House Minority Leader , replacing incumbent  who was defeated after a string of legal issues.\n\n\nSimonaire publicly  as  in April 2018 while supporting a bill banning  for LGBT teens. In a speech on the House floor, she claimed her parents suggested conversion therapy after she came out to them in January 2015. Her father, Senator Bryan Simonaire, disputed her story and continued to oppose the bill. The bill was ultimately passed by both the House of Delegates and Senate.\n\nElected as a Republican, Simonaire joined the  on October 15, 2018.\n\n\n\nSimonaire chose not to run for reelection in 2018 and retired from elected office due to her changing views. She is working as a cosmetic tattoo artist, specializing in eyebrow tattooing. She provides free services to burn patients, cancer patients, domestic violence survivors, and human trafficking survivors.\n\n\n\n*'''2014 Republican Primary Election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 31B'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 31B District'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
