    "pages": }\n'''Mark Edelson''' (born September 12, 1985) is a South Africa-born American politician and attorney who is a member of the  for  in .\n\n\nIn 1999, Edelson's family moved from South Africa to , where he attended , where he earned degrees in philosophy and criminal justice. He moved to Baltimore in 2007 to attend the , earning his  degree in 2010. After graduating, Edelson worked for the Goldman & Goldman, P.A. law firm and became a board member of The Associated: Jewish Community Federation of Baltimore and the Baltimore Jewish Council.\n\nIn June 2015, Edelson announced that he would run for the  in District 1, seeking to succeed outgoing city councilmember Jim Kraft. He ran on a platform that included creating \"transit hubs\" within the city and streamlining the city permitting process. Edelson came in third place in the Democratic primary with 17.3 percent of the vote.\n\nIn June 2017, Edelson was the attorney for  when the bike advocacy group filed a lawsuit against the city of  to block the demolition of protected bike lanes on Potomac Street. Circuit Court Judge Althea M. Handy halted the demolition on June 10, 2017. The lawsuit was dropped on June 28, 2017, after   pledged not to demolish the bike lanes.\n\nIn 2018, Edelson became the president of the Canton Community Association. While president, the group evaluated how to make the neighborhood more welcoming, including the removal of the , opposed a proposal to expand Boston Street in southeast Baltimore, and advocated for the revival of the .\n\nIn 2020, Edelson worked on the transition team for Baltimore Mayor-elect , serving on its transportation and infrastructure subcommittee.\n\nIn 2022, Edelson ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 46, seeking to succeed outgoing state delegate . During the primary, he received endorsements from councilmember Zeke Cohen, former state delegate , and former councilmembers Jim Kraft, Ed Reisinger, and Rikki Spector. Edelson won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, coming in third place behind incumbents  and  with 19.0 percent of the vote.\n\n\nEdelson was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Appropriations Committee.\n\n\nEdelson lives in the  neighborhood of Baltimore. He is Jewish.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n for the signing of the .]]\n'''Wayne Thomas Gilchrest''' (born April 15, 1946) is an American politician who served as a  member of the  representing . In 2008, Gilchrest was defeated in the Republican  by State Senator . Following his departure from politics he has worked on environmental education. He is also a member of the ReFormers Caucus of . In 2019, Gilchrest became a registered Democrat.\n\n\nBorn in , Gilchrest was the fourth child of Elizabeth and Arthur Gilchrest's six boys. After graduating high school in 1964, he joined the . His tour of duty saw action during the  of the , and later the . He earned the rank of  in Vietnam where, as a platoon leader, he was wounded in the chest. Gilchrest was decorated with the , , and . He is a member of the , , and .\n\nIn 1969, he received an  from  in . He then spent a semester in  studying rural poverty in . He went on to receive a  in history from  in 1973. Since then, he has done some work towards a  at  in Baltimore.\n\n\nWhile teaching at  on the , Gilchrest ran against four-term 1st District  incumbent  in 1988. Dyson was plagued by allegations of improper contributions from defense contractors, questions about his sexual orientation, and the suicide of his top staffer. Despite being badly outspent, Gilchrest lost narrowly to Dyson. He sought a rematch in 1990; this time soundly beating Dyson by 14%. In 1992, he survived a close contest against , who had represented the 4th District before being drawn into the 1st District. Gilchrest won by only 3%, largely by swamping McMillen on the Eastern Shore. He wouldn't face serious opposition again for over a decade.\n\nGilchrest broke ranks with his party more often than any other House member in 2007. While Democrats and Republicans were nearly tied in registration in 2006 (183,332 Democrats to 180,856 Republicans), the district had a strong tinge of  that usually favored Republicans. The 1st had a  rating of R+13, indicating that it was a strongly Republican district, and supported President Bush's re-election with over 60% of the vote.\n\nGilchrest was a member of many moderate Republican groups such as the , , and the . He was also the co-chairman of the  together with Democrat  (). Gilchrest was a Republican co-sponsor of Rep. 's \"Military Readiness Enhancement Act\" which would have repealed the \"\" policy. Gilchrest also spoke in favor of same-sex marriage while the Maryland Legislature was considering legalizing it, calling same-sex marriage a matter of \"social justice, civil rights and a more viable democracy.\"\n\nIn 1993, Gilchrest was the lone Republican vote in support of a bill that would have created . Aside from his socially liberal stance, Gilchrest has drawn attention for his stance on the . Though he initially supported the war, Gilchrest's support waned as the occupation became increasingly violent, expressing his support for the  and called on setting a timetable for withdrawal from Iraq. Gilchrest also joined 16 Republicans and 229 Democrats voting in favor of House  (H.CON.RES) 63, a  expressing disapproval for the .\n\n\n\nGilchrest's moderate voting record resulted in vigorous primary challenges from Republicans who considered him a . However, none were successful until 2008. That year, State Senator , State Senator , Joe Arminio, and Robert Banks challenged Gilchrest in the 2008 Republican primary. Harris was strongly supported by the .\n\nHarris defeated Gilchrest in the Republican primary, with Pipkin finishing third. After Gilchrest's loss in the primary, he broke with his party and endorsed   , the  nominee, in the general election, being quoted as saying, \"Let's see, the Republican Party, or my eternal soul?\" and \"Party loyalty, or integrity?\" when questioned. Kratovil won the election.\n\nOn September 18, 2008, Gilchrest made radio comments praising the Democratic Presidential ticket of  and , causing some media outlets to claim his endorsement of the Democratic ticket. However, Gilchrest quickly clarified these comments, saying that they did not amount to an endorsement. Despite the fact that he did not officially endorse Obama, in an October 2 '''' article, Gilchrest sharply criticized his own party and their presidential nominee, fellow Vietnam veteran . Gilchrest said that the Republican party \"has become more narrow, more self-serving, more centered around 'I want, I want, I want.'\" and said that McCain \"recites memorized pieces of information in a narrow way, whereas Barack Obama is constantly evaluating information, using his judgment. One guy just recites what's in front of him, and the other has initiative and reason and prudence and wisdom.\" Gilchrest later told  that he voted for Obama in the November election.\n\nGilchrest was ranked as the House's most liberal Republican in 2008 (his final term) by the '''', placing him to the left of 8 House Democrats.\n\n\n* Committee on Natural Resources\n** Subcommittee on Fisheries, Wildlife and Oceans (Chairman 2001–2007)\n* Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure\n** Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation\n** Subcommittee on Railroads, Pipelines, and Hazardous Materials\n** Subcommittee on Water Resources and Environment\n* Founder and Co-chair of the Chesapeake Bay Watershed Task Force\n* Co-founder and Co-chair of the Congressional Climate Change Caucus\n* Co-chair of the House Oceans Caucus\n* Chairman of the House Corps Reform Caucus\n* Co-founder and Co-chair of the House Organic Caucus\n* Co-founder and Co-chair of the House Dialogue Caucus\n*Board member of the  (NIAC).\n\n\n\n! style=\"background:#ccc;\"|Year\n! style=\"background:#ccc;\"|Office\n! style=\"background:#ccc;\"|Election\n!\n!     "pages": }\n\n'''Nicole Annette Williams''' (born September 23, 1977) is an American attorney and politician serving as a  member of the  representing , which represents a portion of .\n\n\nWilliams was born on September 23, 1977, in  She attended the , where she earned a  degree in history and communications in 1999, and the , where she earned a  degree in 2002. She was admitted into the  in 2002, the  in 2005, and the  in 2015. After graduating, Williams worked as an attorney for several law firms, including Ober, Kaler, Grimes & Shriver, Hileman & Williams, and Rees Broome.\n\nWilliams got involved with politics in 2010 when she filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in . In 2012, she successfully ran for Delegate to the , representing . In 2014, Williams graduated from a training course hosted by Emerge Maryland, an organization created to prepare potential female Democratic candidates for public office, and successfully ran for the Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee, representing District 22 At Large. In September 2017, she again announced her candidacy for the House of Delegates in District 22. She came in fourth place in a field of five candidates, receiving 13.8 percent of the vote. In December 2018, Williams was elected to be the 3rd Vice Chair of the .\n\nIn October 2019, Delegate  resigned from the Maryland House of Delegates after being indicted on  charges. Following speculation, Williams applied to fill the vacancy left by the former Delegate. Her candidacy was endorsed by state Senator  and Delegates  and , and the central committee recommend Williams to Governor  to fill the vacant seat.\n\nSince 2019, Williams has served on the Board of Directors for Emerge Maryland.\n\n\nAfter the resignation of Delegate , the Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee recommended Williams to the Governor to fill the vacant seat. Governor Hogan appointed Williams on November 15, 2019. Williams was sworn in as a Delegate on December 6, 2019, and assigned to the House Judiciary committee.\n\nIn 2020, Williams ran as a delegate to the , representing . She was an at-large delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\n\nIn January 2022, Williams attended a  rally at Lawyers Mall in . During the 2022 legislative session, Williams introduced legislation that would establish that civil or criminal charges can't be pursued against people who experience s, s, or from undergoing .\n\n\nWilliams introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would allow voters to cast ballots at curbside voting locations.\n\n\nIn February 2022, Williams attended a rally to urge lawmakers to pass the Time to Care Act, legislation that would offer  to all Marylanders.\n\n\nIn May 2021, Williams attended a rally alongside a number of elected officials to protest a proposed  train between  and Washington, D.C. Williams introduced legislation during the 2021 legislative session that would block the use of state funds to construct the maglev.\n\n\nIn July 2021, Williams attended a public hearing hosted by the Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission to ask commission members to keep the state's current multi-member legislative district system in their proposed map.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Frank D. Boston, Jr.''' (December 5, 1938 – May 10, 2011) was an  who served in the  and a chairman of the powerful . Boston was one of three delegates serving the 41st  district, which lies in the central, northwest section of .\n\n\nFrank Boston was born in , December 5, 1938. He attended  and later received a bachelor's degree from the  in 1973. Boston also received a master's degree in education from the  in 1979. Boston was a vocational evaluator and teacher with the .\n\n\nBoston was appointed to the House of Delegates after He represented District 41 (D) in Baltimore City from 1987 to 1999. Boston's first committee assigned was the House Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee in 1987. In 1991 he joined the House  and served there for two years. He then served for one year on the Commerce and Government Matters Committee  (1994), and finished his career on the Economic Matters Committee (1995–1999). Boston was a leader on the House floor as well, serving as Deputy Majority Whip from 1992 to 1994. He was Chairman of the Baltimore City Delegation and a member of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David R. Craig''' (born June 12, 1949) is an American  politician from the State of  who unsuccessfully sought the Republican nomination for  in . He was appointed, and sworn in as  on July 7, 2005. Craig was elected in 2006 and re-elected in 2010. Craig previously served in the  in 1995–99 representing Harford County and in 1990-94 in the . He was also elected  of  from 1985 to 1989 and 2001 to 2005. David was a  and  in the  for thirty-four years.\n\n\n\nCraig was born in 1949 in  to Joseph E. Craig (1917–2011). He graduated  in 1967, and obtained a  in History from  in 1971 and a Master's degree from .\n\n\nCraig married his high school sweetheart; Melinda Lee Blevins, in 1971. They have three children and nine grandchildren.\n\n\nCraig spent thirty-four years in the  as a  and . He began teaching in 1971 at Edgewood Junior High School. He then taught at Havre de Grace Community School for seven years, and later at Magnolia Middle School, , and .\n\n\n\n\nCraig began his political career serving on the   beginning in 1979 he was elected to 3 consecutive 2 year terms. He was elected Mayor of  from 1985 to 1989 and 2001 to 2005. He resigned upon swearing in as the  Executive.\n\n\nCraig was elected to the  in 1990, representing District 34 (Harford County). He was a member of the following committees: Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee, 1991–92; Ways and Means Committee, 1992-93 (education subcommittee); Commerce and Government Matters Committee, 1994. Vice-Chair, Harford County Delegation, 1993.\n\n\nCraig was then elected to the  in 1994 and served until 1999, representing District 34 (Harford County). He was a member of the following committees: Joint Committee to Study Mandates on Local Government, 1995–97; Economic and Environmental Affairs Committee, 1995–99 (education subcommittee; health subcommittee); Executive Nominations Committee, 1995–99; Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, 1995–99; Joint Committee on Protocol. Chair, Harford County Delegation, 1998-99.\n\n\nCraig ran for Harford County Executive in 1998 against then-Delegate James Harkins. Harkins defeated Craig in the Republican Primary and was subsequently re-elected in 2002. Harkins resigned as County Executive to become Director of Maryland Environmental Service in 2005, and Craig was appointed by the County Council to fulfill the term. Craig was then elected as County Executive in 2006 and 2010. As Mayor of Havre de Grace, Craig was elected President of the (MML) in 2005, and in 2010 as County Executive, he was elected by his peers as President of the  (MACo). He is the first elected official to have served as President of both organizations.\n\n\n\nDavid Craig announced his candidacy for Governor of Maryland on July 3, 2013. His position platform included phasing out the income tax in Maryland. He was defeated by  in the Republican gubernatorial primary on June 24, 2014.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Harford County Executive - Harford County''' Retrieved on Nov. 3, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Harford County Executive - Harford County - Republican Primary'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland State Senate – District 34 - Harford County''' Retrieved on Nov. 3, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 34 - Harford County''' Retrieved on Nov. 3, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\nThe David Craig Park on Saint John Street in Havre de Grace was named after him.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Susan K. McComas''' (born April 3, 1951) is a member of the  since 2002, first representing  from 2003 to 2015 and then  since 2015. A member of the , she previously served on the  Town Commission from 1987 to 2002, and thrice served as the town's mayor.\n\n\nMcComas was born in  on April 3, 1951, and raised in . Two of her great-grandfathers, John H. Martin and John L. Murray, served the , from 1869 to 1870 and from 1901 to 1903 respectively, and her uncle James O'Neill served as the mayor of Bel Air, Maryland, from 1970 to 1974. McComas graduated from  and later attended , where she earned a  degree in social and behavioral sciences in 1974, studied at the , and earned her  degree at the  in 1980, after which she was admitted to the  and the .\n\n\nMcComas has worked as an attorney in private practice since her graduation from the University of Wyoming, only briefly working in the Law Offices of Bruce J. Gilbert from 1984 to 1985. She was also a member of the board of directors of the Sexual Assault/Spouse Abuse Resource Center from 1982 to 1989.\n\nMcComas first became involved with politics as a file clerk for the , after which she worked as a legal intern for the  and for , and as a researcher for the . From 1983 to 1985, she worked as a commissioner for the Harford County District Court, afterwards unsuccessfully running for the  Town Commission. Following her defeat, McComas applied to serve on the Bel Air Town Historic District Commission. She ran again and won election to the Town Commission again in 1987, where she served until her election to the Maryland House of Delegates in 2002. McComas thrice served as the town's mayor from 1991 to 1992, from 1997 to 1998, and from 1999 to 2000. She was succeeded by Joan Morrissey Ward.\n\nIn January 1990, following the resignation of John W. Hardwicke from the , McComas applied to serve the remainder of his term. The Harford County Republican Central Committee voted to nominate her, , and Jeffrey Wilson to the seat. The Harford County Council voted to appoint Wilson to the seat later that month.\n\nFrom 1998 to 2002, McComas was a member of the Harford County Republican Central Committee.\n\n\n\nIn April 2002, McComas filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 35B, which had no incumbent following redistricting. She ran on a platform involving transportation, crime, and development issues, and faced challengers Robert Shaffner and Francis Eurice in the Republican primary election, which she won with 50.1 percent of the vote. In the general election, McComas faced Bel Air town commissioner David E. Carey, whom she defeated with 61.4 percent of the vote. She was sworn in on January 8, 2003. She was a member of the Judiciary Committee from 2003 to 2023, afterwards serving on the Appropriations Committee. McComas has also served as deputy minority whip from 2015 to 2018, and since 2023.\n\nMcComas is a member of the Harford County Delegation. She became the delegation's chair in 2008, during which she controversially hired her aide to be the delegation receptionist for the 2009 legislative session. McComas was ousted as chair in February 2009, after its members voted to replace her and vice chair  with  as chair and  as vice chair. She challenged the vote to remove her, and later filed an ethics complaint and rules violation claim against the delegation's new leaders, claiming that the vote to remove her as chair violated the Open Meetings Act and the Roberts Rules of Order. McComas was elected as the delegation's vice chair in 2021.\n\n\nMcComas married to her husband, Charles Henry McComas III, whom she met while attending Johns Hopkins, in 1979. They moved to  from Wyoming after college in 1980.\n\nIn January 2010, McComas suffered a heart attack while visiting her mother, who died a few hours after the incident, in Wyoming. She recovered from the heart attack after having two s put in.\n\n\n\nDuring her 1985 Bel Air Town Commissioner campaign, McComas said that she supported proposals to control the town's suburban growth, including annexation, warning of its \"\". In 1987, she said she supported preserving the town's historical and architectural past, but conceded that preservation needed to be done with citizen cooperation. In 1995, McComas said that she opposed \"any growth or development\" that would increase tax burdens and demand for government services.\n\nIn January 2015, McComas supported efforts to block the construction of a  in Bel Air.\n\n\nIn February 2021, during debate on a bill to stagger of elected Harford County school board members' terms, McComas supported an amendment to create a fully-elected school board in the county. The amendment failed in a 4–4 tie.\n\nIn February 2022, McComas opposed a bill to repeal a law that allowed police to arrest children for disturbing school activities. During debate on the bill in the House, she remarked that \"I've been accused of  because I said, you know, that Black fathers aren't as prevalent as they were in the 40s and 50s. The bottom line is that we need to understand that the teachers are dealing now with a society that has changed significantly.\" Her comments drew anger from other House lawmakers and prompted the bill's sponsor, , to issue a statement calling on McComas to immediately apologize for her remarks. She apologized on the House floor a few days later, saying that her words were \"inarticulate\" and that she intended to emphasize the importance of fathers.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, McComas supported the SERVE Act, a bill introduced by Governor  to establish a  for high school graduates.\n\n\nIn November 2000, McComas said she opposed Question A, a Harford County referendum to establish in-district elections of county councilmembers, saying that it would \"pit one side of the county against another\".\n\nIn June 2002, McComas celebrated the ' ruling against Maryland's legislative redistricting plan, calling it a \"victory or the people of Maryland and the Republican party\". During the 2017 legislative session, she introduced legislation to create a \"\" to draw Maryland's legislative and congressional districts.\n\n\nIn the legislature, McComas has voted against bills to raise the state minimum wage, which she says hurt small businesses. She opposes any increases to taxes or fees.\n\nIn March 1988, McComas said she opposed a state bill to lower the county's  from ten percent to five percent, saying that the county would have to raise es by two cents to make up for the lost revenue. Later that year, she proposed imposing a five percent tax on videotape rentals to make up for the lost revenue. In January 1992, McComas opposed a proposal by Harford County Executive  to impose a $35 fee per ton of non-recyclable garbage dumped at county waste facilities, saying that the fee would force Bel Air to raise taxes. After the fee was passed, she said that the town would refuse to pay it. In May 1993, McComas said she opposed cutting the town's early filer tax discount. Later that month, she voted to half the tax discount to one percent, saying that it was \"hard to swallow\" but preferred it to raising taxes.\n\nDuring the 2004 legislative session, McComas voted against a bill to raise $670 million in sales and income tax increases.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, McComas voted against the Firearm Safety Act, which banned s and required people buying any gun other than a hunting rifle or shotgun to obtain a license. In 2016, she attended a Second Amendment protection rally at the . In 2017, McComas introduced legislation to allow for bulk gun permit renewals and to prohibit law enforcement from collecting \"certain captured data\" from vehicles leaving gun shows without a warrant. In 2019, she supported the Parishioner Protection Act, a bill that would allow churchgoers to carry firearms. In 2022, McComas questioned the effectiveness of a bill to ban s in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring her 1985 Bel Air Town Commissioner campaign, McComas said that she supported increasing police salaries and hiring a full-time psychologist to help with police retention. In 1987, she said that she opposed a county law to reimburse towns for police training, suggesting that cadets in the Bel Air Police Academy should \"pay for their education\" like workers in other professions.\n\nIn 2005, McComas introduced legislation that would allow town police officers to cross jurisdictional borders to pursue drunk or reckless drivers.\n\nIn October 2020, following the , McComas said that she did not support banning police chokeholds, saying that the idea gave her \"heartburn\" and preferring instead to discourage their use.\n\n\nDuring the 2005 legislative session, McComas introduced legislation to ban egg donation for  or . In 2023, she introduced legislation to prohibit women from getting an abortion without first having a .\n\nIn April 2010, McComas voted against an  resolution against Maryland Attorney General  for issuing an opinion supporting . During the 2012 legislative session, she voted against the , which legalized .\n\nIn 2013, McComas opposed a bill to repeal the death penalty in Maryland, saying that it would make people feel less safe.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, McComas opposed a bill to abolish the  for child sexual abuse cases, saying that she was \"skeptical it would do any good\". She was criticized by sexual abuse survivors for her response to an email from University of Maryland biotech researcher John Plaschke, who had emailed McComas asking her to support the bill, in which she wrote: \"I hope that you have sought treatment and have moved beyond the abuse. It is very much about your personal resilience to live and thrive.\"\n\nIn 2017, McComas supported legislation to establish statewide police standards on the handling of s.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, McComas voted against a bill to decriminalize attempted suicide, arguing that it would discourage police from preventing people from committing suicide.\n\n\nDuring her 1985 Bel Air Town Commissioner campaign, McComas said that she supported making Bel Air more pedestrian friendly and using  to reduce traffic. In 2002, she said that she supported moving state transportation funding away from mass transit projects and toward building roads.\n\nIn 1998, McComas proposed constructing overhead walkways across  and  to connect pedestrians to the nearby . In May 2002, she voted against a proposal to expand  through Howard Park, saying that it would be unfair to the residents of the area.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Talmadge Branch''' (born January 30, 1956) is an  who represented the  in the  from 1995 to 2023. Branch is a former chairman of the  and founder of the Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland's foundation.\n\nBranch was an unsuccessful candidate in the  to fill out the term of the late . Branch then withdrew from the overlapping  for the same congressional seat.\n\n\nBranch was born in  on January 30, 1956. He attended  in Baltimore and then  where he got his  in 1978. By 1980 Branch had earned his  in liberal studies from .\n\n\nBranch has been a member of House of Delegates since January 11, 1995.  He served on the House Appropriations Committee and was its vice-chairman from 2003 to 2007.  He also serves on the Ways and Means committee. He is a member of the  Legislative Policy Committee, the Special Joint Committee on Pensions, the Task Force to Study the State's Retiree Health Insurance Liabilities, the Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, the Spending Affordability Committee, the Joint Commission on the Maryland Port Administration and he is the House Chair of the Joint Committee on Welfare Reform.\n\nOn April 16, 2022, Branch announced that he would not seek re-election in the s. He said that he did not plan to endorse a third delegate candidate to succeed him and that he would stay in the Baltimore area to build on a consulting business.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 45th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n*Co-sponsored HB 860 (Baltimore City Public Schools Construction and Revitalization Act of 2013).     "pages": }\n\n'''Gerald Clark''' (born November 29, 1952) is a  politician. Clark represented  of the  from when he was appointed to the position on October 13, 2016, to January 11, 2023.\n\n\nClark was born in  on November 29, 1952, and attended  in . He is a small business owner, having operated the Port of Call Wine and Spirits in , since 1979.\n\nFrom 2002 to 2014, Clark served on the . Since 2016, he has been a member of the Tri-County Council for Southern Maryland.\n\nIn 2014, Port of Call Liquors was cited for violations of the law prohibiting the sale of alcohol to minors. The Calvert County Liquor Board imposed Clark's business with a five day suspension, 30 days of abeyance, and a $1,000 fine.\n\nIn September 2016,   appointed Clark to the Maryland House of Delegates, filling a seat left by former Delegate , who had been appointed by Hogan to serve on the .\n\n\nClark was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on October 13, 2016.\n\nClark filed to run in the . He was unopposed in the Republican primary, but faced Democratic candidate Julia Nichols in the general election. During the election, Clark endorsed  in his race for  District 29. He won with 57% of the vote.\n\nIn January 2022, Clark announced that he would not seek re-election in the .\n\n\n*  Environment and Transportation Committee, 2017–2023 (local government & bi-county issues subcommittee, 2017–2018; natural resources, agriculture & open space subcommittee, 2017–2023; land use & ethics subcommittee, 2019–2023)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Pamela Graboski Beidle''' (born July 21, 1951) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  from  since 2019. A member of the , she previously represented the district in the  from 2007 to 2019, and was a member of the Anne Arundel County Council from 1998 to 2006.\n\n\nBeidle was born in . She graduated from  and later attended , earning her  in business in 1977, and , where she earned her  degree  in business administration in 1994.\n\n\nAfter graduating from AACC, Beidle started her own insurance company, Beidle Insurance Agency, which she ran with her husband until 2017. She was also a member of the Northern Anne Arundel Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Life Underwriters, and served on the boards of Leadership Anne Arundel and Hospice of the Chesapeake.\n\nIn 1998, Beidle won election to the Anne Arundel County Council in District 1, succeeding term-limited councilmember George F. Bachman Jr. She was sworn in December 1998, and served until December 4, 2006.\n\n\n\nBeidle was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 10, 2007. She was a member of the Environmental Matters Committee (later renamed to the Environment and Transportation Committee) during her entire tenure.\n\nIn August 2017, Beidle filed to run for the  in District 32 in 2018, seeking to succeed retiring state senator , who had encouraged her to run. The district was targeted by the  in its \"Fight for Five\" campaign in 2018. After running unopposed in the primary election, Beidle faced Republican county councilmember John Grasso in the general election, whom she defeated with 66.4 percent of the vote. '''' compared the general election to the , noting that Beidle was deep-rooted in local politics while Grasso had comparatively less political experience, held politically partisan views, and was known for making controversial Facebook posts.\n\nBeidle was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. She has been a member of the Executive Nominations Committee and the Finance Committee since 2019. In December 2022, Senate President  appointed Beidle as the chair of the Executive Nominations Committee, a position she gave up to become the chair of the Finance Committee following the resignation of  in October 2023.\n\n\nBeidle is married to her husband Len. Together, they have three children.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Beidle introduced legislation to create an elected school board in Anne Arundel County. The bill passed and became law.\n\nDuring debate on the  in 2019, Beidle expressed concern with the education reform bill's Concentration of Poverty Grants, which provided extra funds to schools with high populations of students that receive free or reduced-price lunches, saying that she wanted the percentage floor required to receive the grants to be lowered.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Beidle introduced a bill that would require the state to switch to safer alternatives in  and ban  chemicals in food packaging.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Beidle was one of 18 Democratic state delegates to vote against the Firearm Safety Act of 2013, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Beidle introduced legislation to repeal of the state's Handgun Permit Review Board, which handled  applications. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor ; the legislature overrode Hogan's veto during the 2020 legislative session. She also voted against Hogan's appointments to the board, claiming that there was \"too much secrecy\" surrounding the board's decisions.\n\n\nIn 2019, Beidle voted against the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Beidle introduced legislation to prohibit health care companies from raising prices on \"essential goods or services\" by more than 10 percent during a state of emergency. She also introduced a bill requiring Maryland to stay in the Interstate Medical Licensure Compact for an additional eight years, which passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn April 2022, Beidle spoke in support of legislation to provide paid sick leave, recalling when her business continued to pay a worker who took off after she and her mother were diagnosed with cancer.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Beidle voted against legislation to raise the state's minimum wage  to $10.10 an hour by 2017.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Beidle expressed concerns with the Maryland Police Accountability Act, also known as , especially with provisions to repeal the state's , and introduced an amendment to the bill to remove \"unfounded and unsubstantiated complaints\" from records that could be obtained under the . The amendment was rejected by the Maryland Senate in a 21-26 vote.\n\n\nIn 2012, Beidle voted for the , which legalized .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Beidle supported legislation to decriminalize the possession of .\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Beidle voted against a bill to index the state's  to inflation to pay for transportation projects. In March 2023, she was one of five Democrats to vote for an amendment that would have repealed this bill.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Beidle supported legislation to extend the state's tax on health insurance companies.\n\n\nIn June 2002, Beidle said she opposed a proposal to build a  line between  and  In April 2022, she introduced legislation that would make it more expensive for the Baltimore-Washington Rapid Rail company to build the maglev line by requiring it to pay 25 percent of costs associated with acquiring land through condemnation to the jurisdiction where the land is located.\n\nIn 2016, Beidle introduced legislation that would require the  to use a scoring system to determine which state transportation projects to fund. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor ; legislators overrode his veto later that year.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Beidle supported legislation to add citizen members to the state's Chesapeake Bay Bridge Reconstruction Advisory Group.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ana Sol Gutierrez''' (born January 11, 1942) is a   from the  of  who was the first Latina to ever be elected to the . She served four terms in the , representing  in Maryland's District 18. Gutierrez sat on the Appropriations Committee and was chair of the Delinquency Prevention and Diversion Services Task Force beginning in 2006. In 2003, Gutierrez was the first Latina elected to state office.\n\nIn 2016, Gutierrez ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination in Maryland's 8th Congressional District, ultimately being defeated by .\n\n\nGutierrez was born in  and attended  before moving on to , garnering a B.S. in chemistry and earned an M.S. in technology of management, scientific & technical information systems from . She did her postgraduate studies in  at . Gutierrez has served in all three levels of government.  As a deputy administrator in the Transportation Department during the Clinton Administration, on the Montgomery County School Board, and as a Delegate for the 18th District.\n\n\n\n* Member, Board of Education, Montgomery County, 1990–98 (president, 1995–96; vice-president, 1994–95). \n* Member, Governor's Commission on Hispanic Affairs, 1989–91, 1992–94. \n* Deputy Administrator, Research and Special Programs Administration, U.S. Department of Transportation, 1994–96. \n* Member, Task Force to Study Driver Licensing Documentation, 2003–04.\n\n\nAna Sol Gutierrez is strongly allied with  in support of a system whereby the default Maryland Driving Permit will not conform to the standards mandated by the  Act, and may be issued to . She favors the issuance of a special ID which will conform to federal standards which would allow the bearer to enter federal buildings, board planes, and engage in other transactions which require identity cards conforming to the standards set out in the Real ID Act of 2005. She opposes a two-tier licensing system which would issue driving permits to undocumented immigrants, but which would not conform to the Real ID standards which would be the default for Maryland driving permits issued to qualified Marylanders, because \"[i]n this climate, that's a scarlet letter\". Governor  later directed the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration to phase in compliance to the Real ID standards by 2010.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jeffrie Eugene Long Jr.''' (born November 12, 1996) is an American politician who is a member of the  for  in  and  counties in Maryland.\n\n\nLong graduated from  and later attended , where he earned a  degree in clinical psychology. He is currently the pastor at Communion Church in . Long previously served as a legislative aide to then-  and state senators  and .\n\nIn 2020, Long was elected as a  delegate, pledged to , with 19.5 percent of the vote.\n\nIn February 2021, Long applied to fill a vacancy in the Maryland House of Delegates left by the appointment of state delegate  to the . The Prince George's County Democratic Committee nominated Jacqueline Steele-McCall to fill the vacancy, but the Calvert County Democratic Central Committee picked  to fill the vacancy. Jones was ultimately appointed to the seat by Governor  on February 17, 2021. Long challenged Jones' incumbency in the , defeating her in the Democratic primary with 54.3 percent of the vote. He faced no opposition in the general election.\n\n\nLong was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He and  are the first  members of the . He is a member of the House Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\nIn 2024, Long applied to run as a delegate to the  pledged to , but was denied by the . He was later selected to be an at-large delegate to the DNC, where he supported  following Biden's withdrawal from the race.\n\n\nLong has described himself as a \"\". During his House of Delegates candidacy, Long campaigned on topics such as women's rights, making schools safer, fixing the state's transportation system, and making Maryland more retiree-friendly.\n\n\nLong lives in .\n\nIn April 2023, Long was charged with home invasion and first-degree felony assault after allegedly breaking into his aunt's Huntingtown home and threatening her with a pipe. His attorneys denied the charges, arguing that Long was not in the area when it occurred and that the charges were the result of an undisclosed family matter. If convicted, Long faced a maximum of 25 years in prison for each charge. In May 2023, both charges were downgraded before trial to misdemeanors, second-degree assault and fourth-degree burglary. In August 2023, the St. Mary's County State's Attorney's Office dropped all charges against Long.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jane Lawton''' (May 24, 1944 &ndash; November 29, 2007) was an  from  and a member of the . The Jane E. Lawton community center, located in Leland Park in , was renamed in her memory on June 14, 2009.\n\n\nLawton was born in , , on May 24, 1944, to Clarence and Ruth Alice England.\n\nLawton attended the  where she graduated .\n\n\n while working as a special assistant to him]]\n\nAfter college she worked briefly for IBM. She also worked as Special Assistant to the   until the birth of her first child in 1974. She became a member of the  Town Council in 1981, later becoming treasurer, then Chairperson (this position is now referred to as the Mayor of the Town). Later, she was Special Assistant to  when he was  of Montgomery County. After  succeeded Potter, she became the County Cable Administrator. In the State Legislature, she was originally appointed to fill the seat of former delegate John Hurson, but was elected in her own right in the fall of 2006. She passed two bills during her brief time in office. The following session, two more bills were passed in her name, one of which was a Farms-to-Schools program she had been working on the previous session and planned to introduce during the 2008 legislative session. She also served on the Environmental Matters Committee while in the House.\n\n\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax by one percentage point to 6% - Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n\n\nLawton died of unknown causes on the morning of November 29, 2007, after giving a speech in downtown Washington. She was declared dead at George Washington Hospital Center. Her death appeared to be caused by a .\n\nJane was a longtime member and past President of the National Association of Telecommunications Officers and Advisors (NATOA). In 2008, NATOA created and awarded the first Jane E. Lawton Commemorative Award, presented yearly to an elected official who exemplifies what it means to promote community interests in communications.\n\nThe Jane Lawton internship was created to honor her memory through the President's Leadership Class.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Peter A. Hammen''' (born July 1, 1966) is an  who represented the 46th legislative district in the . Delegate Hammen was also the Chairman of the House Health and Government Operations Committee.\n\n\n\nBorn in , Maryland on July 1, 1966, Hammen attended the  and earned his B.S. in criminal justice in 1989 and his  in public administration in 1993.\n\n\nDelegate Hammen was a member of House of Delegates from January 11, 1995 to December 2016. He initially served on the House Environmental Matters Committee and then moved to the House Health and Government Operations Committee in 2003. He served as that committee's chairman from 2005 to 2016. He was the House Co-Chair of the Joint Legislative Task Force on Small-Group Market Health Insurance. Hammen resigned his seat in December 2016 to take a job in the administration of Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh.\n\n\n*Co-sponsored HB 860 (Baltimore City Public Schools Construction and Revitalization Act of 2013).     "pages": }\n\n'''Joan Carter Conway''' (born April 5, 1951) is an American politician who represented  in the . She is the first  woman to be appointed chairman of any of the standing committees in the Maryland Senate.\n\n\nSenator Conway was born to Floyd O. and Pauline N. Carter in , on April 5, 1951. She attended the Community College of Baltimore, earning her A.A. in human services in 1987 and then the , with a B.A. in sociology in 1988. She is co-owner of CIG Professional Tax Services, Inc. Conway was appointed to the Senate, from the , when John A. Pica Jr. decided to retire in 1997. Since then she has won three elections without major opposition. In 2007, Conway headed a team of 3 incumbent delegates (,  and ) and 7 state central committee members (men  and , and Democrats Sherrod Barnes, Jeremy Rosendale, Beatrice Brown, and Sylvia Williams) to victory with every person on her ticket winning in the September primary. No other 11-person ticket achieved such distinction in the state primary election.\n\n\nA member of Senate from January 8, 1997, to January 2019, Senator Conway was Chair of the Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee and a member of the . Senator Conway was defeated in the 2018 democratic primary election by .\n\n\n\n\nIn 1999 Conway was arrested and charged with hindering a law enforcement officer after a six-year-old girl was struck by a vehicle in front of her office and she allegedly refused to provide space for the paramedics to work on the child. The charges were later dropped by State's Attorney .\n\n\nIn a 2005 complaint filed with the Baltimore Circuit Court, Chief liquor inspector Samuel Daniels Jr. accused Conway of acting in collusion with other members of Baltimore's Liquor Board to replace him with her husband, Vernon Conway. At the time the complaint was filed Daniels had been suspended for reasons he claimed stemmed from his attempts to investigate bars on The Block which had quid pro quo relationships with other liquor inspectors and with Senator Conway. Daniels was later found by the city's labor commissioner to have been unfairly suspended and after being reinstated he eventually dropped the charges.\n\nIn 2010, while serving as the chair of the committee that hears alcohol bills, Conway went on the record saying that a bill that would allow wine to be shipped to residents of the state \"is not going anywhere\" despite the fact that 6 of the 9 members of her own committee and both chambers supporting the legislation. Conway cited the fact that it would be difficult for the state to ensure taxes were collected on wine shipped into the state and that it would give minors the ability to tap the internet to obtain alcohol. 37 of the 50 states currently allow wine to be shipped directly to residents.\n\nBut some proponents of the direct-shipping bill question whether she is too personally tied to the system to be fair. Her husband, Vernon \"Tim\" Conway, is a city liquor inspector since 1995 who made $67,000 in his position last year, according to city records.\n\nAccording to a 2008 analysis by The Baltimore Sun, more than 80 percent of state legislators have received campaign contributions from the liquor lobby.\n\n\nIn the 2014 Maryland legislative session, Senator Conway introduced legislation to prevent the use of public college and university funds to support scholarly involvement in academic organizations that have voted to boycott Israel. Editorial boards for both the '''' and the '''' came out against the bill. The legislation failed to get out of committee but on the House side was incorporated as an amendment to the State's budget bill.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Kathleen M. Dumais''' (born July 5, 1958) is an American politician who represented the 15th District of the , encompassing the western and northern portions of . Born in , Dumais grew up in Maryland and eventually pursued a degree at the . As an attorney, she specialized in family and juvenile law and had a career-long interest in education, at one point working as a teacher in .\n\nIn 2002, Dumais was elected to the House of Delegates from District 15, which includes , , and a large swath of rural northern Montgomery County. She sat on the Judiciary Committee and has served on the Special Committee on Drug and Alcohol Abuse, the Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, and as the  for the House of Delegates.\n\nDumais was the Majority Leader for the House of Delegates in 2019.\n\nIn November 2021, Dumais resigned from the House of Delegates after being appointed to serve on the Montgomery County Circuit Court bench by  .\n\n\n\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006(SB154)\n* voted against slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted in favor of slots (HB4) in the 2007 Special session \n\n\n\n*2005 Legislative Award from the Maryland Network Against Domestic Violence (MNADV)\n*2007 Public Policy Award from the Maryland Coalition Against Sexual Assault (MCASA) \n*2008 Legislator of the Year Award from the Maryland Legislative Agenda for Women (MLAW)\n*2009 Public Policy Award from the Maryland Chapter of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15''' Retrieved on Nov. 20, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Susan Clair Lee''' (; born May 14, 1954) is an American politician. She has served as the 72nd  since 2023. She was a member of the  from 2015 to 2023, and of the  from 2002 to 2015. She represented , covering parts of , and was the first Asian American elected to the Maryland State Senate, as well as the first Asian American woman and first Chinese American elected to the Maryland legislature.\n\n\nLee was born in , . She grew up in Montgomery County and attended . She earned a  degree from the  before graduating from the . She is a member of the  and the . Before becoming a state legislator, Lee was an attorney in private practice, having previously worked as an attorney for the  and the . She was also co-chairwoman of the Montgomery County  Multicultural Community Partnership.\n\n\nOn February 19, 2002, Governor  appointed Lee to the Maryland House of Delegates following the election of  as . This appointment came after a recommendation by the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee, on which she sat. She was sworn in on February 21 and was subsequently elected to her first full term in 2002. She was re-elected in 2006 and 2010.\n\n\nIn August 2013, Lee announced that she would run for the Maryland Senate, seeking to succeed state senator , who ran for  in . She won the Democratic primary with 85.1 percent of the vote, and later won the general election with 70 percent of the vote. Lee was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 14, 2015. Since November 2018, she has served as the Senate majority whip.\n\n\n;Maryland House of Delegates\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2002–2015 (member, gaming law & enforcement subcommittee, 2002–2003; civil law & procedure subcommittee, 2003–2006; chair, juvenile law subcommittee, 2007–2011; chair, family law subcommittee, 2011–2015)\n* Deputy Majority Whip, 2003–2015\n* Member, Joint Committee on Access to Mental Health Services, 2011–2014\n\n;Maryland Senate\n* Majority Whip, 2019–2023\n* Deputy Majority Whip, 2017–2018\n* Member, Judicial Proceedings Committee, 2015–2023\n* Joint Committee on Cybersecurity, Information Technology, and Biotechnology, 2015–2023\n* Executive Nominations Committee, 2019–2023\n* Legislative Policy Committee, 2020–2023\n\n\n\nOn January 10, 2023, Governor-elect  named Lee to serve as the . She took office in an acting position on January 18, and is the first Asian American person to serve as the Maryland Secretary of State. On February 14, the Maryland Senate unanimously approved Lee's nomination.\n\nIn September 2023, Lee said that her office would consider removing former President  from the primary election ballot under the . She ultimately decided against excluding Trump. Lee was an at-large delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\n\nBetween late May and June 2020, Lee virtually met four times with representatives from the , the , and the Maryland Judiciary. These meetings resulted in the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee releasing a report with 19 recommendations to help the state's correctional systems navigate the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nIn March 2021, Lee rebuked disparaging statements made by former president  regarding the COVID-19 pandemic, in which phrases like \"Kung Flu\" and the \"China virus\" stoked . Later that month, after  aired a clip showing senior  health advisor and then- director  saying he believed the  \"escaped\" from a lab in  in September or October 2019, Lee took to the floor of the Maryland Senate to condemn Redfield's comments and suggested that Asian-Americans could be targeted because of his remarks.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Lee introduced a bill that would require prosecutors to disclose whether  or  were used during the criminal investigation of a case. The bill was withdrawn after its first hearing. She also introduced a bill that would make it a crime to possess  with the intent to use it, with sentences up to 10 years in prison and or a $10,000 fine, following a ransomware attack that froze government computers in .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Lee introduced a bill that would repeal the prohibition on prosecuting  against a victim who is the spouse of the assailant. The bill unanimously passed out of the Maryland Senate and passed the Maryland House of Delegates by a vote of 115-18.\n\n\nIn January 2020, Lee criticized the proposed  and  expansions, telling '''', \"So far the state's top-down kind of planning [on the toll lanes] has disregarded any dialogue about some of the financial risks, the risk to our environment, the risk to our communities, and to our businesses and to our quality of life\". She also introduced a bill that would give counties the ability to block state toll projects.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Lee introduced a bill that would ban s in Maryland. The bill was reintroduced during the 2022 legislative session, during which it passed the House of Delegates and the state Senate, and became law without Governor Hogan's signature. Following the bill's passage, she was invited to the  by U.S. President , where he announced a new  rule regulating privately made firearms.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Lee introduced a bill that would require s for private sales of s. The bill passed the Maryland Senate by a vote of 31-14 and the Maryland House of Delegates by a vote of 87-47, but was vetoed by Governor Hogan on May 7, 2020. The Maryland General Assembly voted to override the governor's veto on February 9, 2021.\n\n\nIn June 2018, following national outcry about the , Lee called on Maryland counties to \"stop taking blood money from \" to detain immigrants. At the time, only three counties (, , and  counties) had facilities for detaining immigrants that were used by ICE.\n\n\n campaign event, 2016]]\nIn April 2015, Lee endorsed U.S. Representative  in the . In November, she endorsed former Secretary of State  for .\n\n\nIn February 2004, Lee criticized a bill that would have defined marriages in Maryland as the union of a man and woman, saying before a House Judiciary Committee hearing, \"These bills are inflammatory, they are divisive and they promote intolerance to a large portion of our population\". In February 2006, Lee voted against a bill that would amend the  to ban . The bill failed to pass by a vote of 61-78. In 2012, she voted for the , which passed out of the Maryland House of Delegates by a vote of 72-67.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Lee introduced a bill that would codify the right to abortion access. The bill was withdrawn in the final week of the legislative session, which was shortened by the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Lee introduced a bill that would have granted adoptees above the age of 18 access to their original s. The bill failed to pass out of the state Senate by a vote of 16-31. She also introduced a bill that would have required  judges to undergo a minimum of 60 hours of training on child abuse investigations,  in custody decisions, , and qualifications for child abuse evaluators and treatment providers.\n\n\nIn November 2007, Lee voted in favor of House Bill 2, which raised individual and corporate income tax provisions, and House Bill 5, which increased the state sales tax, car titling tax, and hotel tax.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  campaign website\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph Vogel''' (born January 4, 1997) is an Uruguay-born American politician who has served as a member of the  from  since 2023. A member of the , his district includes the  cities of  and ; he represents the district alongside fellow Democratic delegates  and .\n\nIn May 2023, Vogel announced that he would run for the  in . He was defeated in the Democratic primary on May 14, 2024, placing second behind .\n\n\nVogel was born in , Uruguay on January 4, 1997, to mother Gabriela and father David Vogel, an advisor to the Uruguayan government. His ancestors sought refuge there before . He immigrated to the United States with his family when he was three years old due to his father's job as a diplomat for the . His family settled in , upon immigrating to the United States. He became a U.S. citizen in November 2016.\n\nVogel attended . He was also active in  during this time, a Jewish youth group, which he has said is what motivated him to pursue a career in politics. He later attended , where he earned a bachelor's degree in political science in 2018. Following this, he went on to  where he earned a master's in public policy at the  in 2022.\n\nWhile a student at George Washington University, Vogel served as an at-large member of the Student Association Senate, but was impeached for violating its attendance policy by missing four meetings in January 2018 due to his involvement with 's  in .\n\n\n\n\nVogel developed an interest in politics while in school, where he had been active in student government. He volunteered on 's  and later worked on 's . Vogel was a college intern for then-House Minority Leader  and then-Senate Minority Leader .\n\nVogel took a year off of college at George Washington University to work on the national advance team of 's . He later got involved in the  movement and in protests against the , and worked as an advance lead for 's  and as advance director for 's . After Booker suspended his campaign, he worked the presidential campaigns of  and .\n\nVogel served on the Maryland Youth Advisory Council from 2015 to 2016. He also worked as a policy fellow at Interfaith Works in  and founded Learn It Together, a  to help students of essential workers as they transitioned to  during the .\n\n\n, 2023]]\nIn September 2021, Vogel announced he would run for the , challenging incumbent Democratic state delegate , who later announced his retirement; Kagan, who had political differences with Gilchrest, recruited Vogel to run for the seat. During the primary, Vogel strategized with Connecticut state senator  and hosted campaign events featuring Cory Booker. He won the Democratic primary with 27.9% of the vote and defeated Republican challengers Helene Meister and Donald Patti in the general election with 27.5% of the vote.\n\nVogel was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He represents , which includes the cities of  and . He is the  of the  and, alongside , is the first  member of the Maryland General Assembly. He is a member of the House Ways and Means Committee.\n\n\n\nIn May 2023, Vogel announced he would run for the  in  to succeed , who was running for the  in  to succeed retiring Democratic senator . If elected, he would have been the first Latino, first Gen Z, and first openly LGBTQ member of Congress from Maryland.\n\nVogel was seen as a frontrunner, alongside former  deputy administrator , in the Democratic primary, during which he received endorsements from various national groups and local officials, and ran on a platform including support for  (DACA) recipients and , expanding health care access, addressing , and fighting . Vogel's campaign also focused on his legislative record and political activism toward abortion rights and gun control, as well as .\n\nVogel was defeated by McClain-Delaney in the Democratic primary election on May 14, 2024, placing second with 26.3 percent of the vote. He conceded defeat that night and endorsed McClain-Delaney in the general election.\n\n\nDuring his House of Delegates campaign, Vogel ran on a platform that included climate, mental health, and economic issues. He has described himself as a \"pragmatic progressive\" and cited , , and  as his political role models.\n\n\nVogel supports making public colleges tuition-free, codifying President 's cancellation of up to $20,000 in student loan debt into law, and increasing state education funding. During the 2023 legislative session, he introduced a bill to forgive up to $30,000 in  for mental health professionals employed at Maryland public schools. During the 2024 legislative session, Vogel supported a bill to create a statewide health education framework.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Vogel introduced legislation to provide funding for climate startups.\n\n\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Vogel cited strategic competition with China as the United States' top foreign policy challenge and called for strengthening supply chains, investing in , and promoting  to counter it. He also supported working with China to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions.\n\n\nVogel describes himself as an \"outspoken supporter of \". In 2016, he stated that his \"commitment to the U.S.-Israel relationship is a direct result of  and \". He supports a  to the  and does not support conditioning U.S. foreign aid on Israeli actions. He supports the working definition of  promoted by the , stating in an interview with ''Jewish Insider'' that he accepts \"fair criticism of the Israeli government\", but views the \"delegitimization and demonization\" of Israel as antisemitic.\n\nWhile a member of the GWU Student Association Senate, Vogel opposed a student government resolution encouraging the university to divest from companies accused of violating . The Senate voted to reject the resolution by a vote of 14–15, with one abstention, in May 2017. After Vogel was impeached from the GWU Student Association Senate for missing four consecutive meetings in violation of its attendance policy in 2018, he accused three of its members of being \"closely aligned with the  movement\" and of launching an effort to kick him out of the Senate following his efforts against the pro-Palestinian divestment resolution. In March 2018, after one of the three senators, Brady Forrest, was accused of antisemitism after old Facebook posts resurfaced showing Forrest calling for a boycott of a campus event sponsored by Jewish student groups that he claimed supported the , Vogel drafted a letter signed by nearly 70 student leaders calling for Forrest's resignation. He spoke out against members of the Student Association Senate for failing to censure Forrest in April 2018.\n\nIn May 2023, Vogel said he supported the .\n\nIn October 2023, amid the  and subsequent , Vogel said he would support increasing the U.S. military presence in the region to deter future conflicts and called on Congress to provide Israel and Palestine with monetary support to help Israel defend itself and to assist with humanitarian efforts in Palestine. He also criticized activist groups  and  as \"fringe organizations\" after they released statements accusing Israel of provoking the war, and cosigned a letter with other congressional candidates supporting President 's actions toward the war. Vogel criticized calls for an unconditional ceasefire in the conflict, saying that any bilateral ceasefire must come with the release of all  and increased flow of humanitarian aid into the , but added that he supported U.S. calls for restraint and civilian protections in Israeli attacks. He called for the removal of Israeli Prime Minister  in March 2024, saying that peace could not be achieved in Israel with him in office. He also expressed concerns with President Biden's decision to withhold military aid to Israel amid its , but ultimately conceded that he trusted the president's judgement.\n\nIn November 2023, Vogel called for the resignation of , the director of the state  chapter, from the state Commission on Hate Crime Response and Prevention after making Facebook posts comparing Israel to  and calling attendees of the March for Israel \"genocide sympathizers\". Chaudry was suspended from the commission by Attorney General  the following day. During the 2024 legislative session, after Chaudry was reinstated to the board in December 2023, Vogel introduced legislation to remove Chaudry from the board and replace her with \"two members of the Muslim community\" and another bill allowing for the removal of commission and task force members for \"misconduct, incompetence, neglect of duties, or other good cause\".\n\n\nFollowing the , Vogel advocated for gun control. During his House of Delegates campaign, he said he supports legislation to hold gunmakers liable for ; he also said he supports banning s, increasing funding for violence prevention programs, and requiring gun owners to have .\n\n\nVogel supports  but opposes making people give up their private insurance plans and prohibiting health care companies from covering procedures covered by .\n\nVogel supports increasing funding for drug intervention and treatment programs. During the 2023 legislative session, he introduced the Josh Siems Act, which would require emergency rooms to include  testing in toxicology screens. The bill was named for  native Josh Siems, who died from a fentanyl overdose on his 31st birthday in 2022. The bill unanimously passed the  and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Vogel introduced a bill to give state employees four hours of leave for cancer screenings and another that would allow students to possess and administer .\n\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Vogel expressed support for efforts to support  and DACA recipients. He supports the , which would codify provisions of the DACA program into law.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Vogel introduced a bill to establish a commission on  response and prevention following an uptick in hateful acts in Montgomery County, which was signed into law by Governor Moore. He also introduced the Event-Goer Rights and Accountable Sales (ERAS) Act following the , which requires ticket issuers to enforce a ticket refund policy and ban restrictions on ticket resales and transfers.\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Vogel supported the , the , and the .\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Vogel introduced a bill that would require police to notify property owners to remove hateful graffiti from their properties. He also spoke against proposed bills to ban transgender students from competing on girls' sports teams in schools and another that would ban sexually explicit materials from school libraries, saying that the introduction of both would be \"detrimental\" to the trans community, and supported a bill to prohibit school boards from . In March 2024, Vogel voted against a bill that would legalize  in Maryland, believing that it would not bring in additional revenue for the state and that it would hurt casino workers.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Vogel introduced a bill to provide tax credits to Maryland-based news media outlets with fewer than 50 employees for advertising costs.\n\n\nVogel lives in . He is  and openly .\n\nVogel is trilingual; he speaks English, Spanish, and Hebrew.\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Anne Healey''' (born January 2, 1951) is an . She is a member of the , representing  in  since 1991. She previously served on the City Council in  from 1987 to 1990.\n\n\nHealey was born in  on January 2, 1951. She graduated from , and later attended , where she earned a  degree in 1972, and the , where she earned a  degree in 1974.\n\n\nAfter graduating, Healey became a newspaper writer and editor for various Maryland-based newspapers, including '''', '''', and ''''.\n\nHealey first got involved with politics in grade school after attending a campaign parade for then-presidential candidate . After a 15-year long career in journalism, Healey decided to pursue a career in politics. From 1987 to 1990, Healey served on the Hyattsville City Council. Afterwards, she ran for state delegate in District 22, winning the Democratic primary with 18 percent of the vote and the general election with 24 percent of the vote.\n\n\nHealey was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 1991. She is the House Chair of the House Rules & Executive Nominations Committee and a member of the Environmental Matters Committee and its housing & real property and motor vehicle & transportation subcommittees.\n\n\n* Chair, Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2013–present (member, 1998–2006)\n* Member, Environment and Transportation Committee, 2015–present (housing & real property subcommittee, 2015–present; motor vehicle & transportation subcommittee, 2017–present; chair, local government & bi-county agencies subcommittee, 2015–present)\n* Member, Joint Subcommittee on Program Open Space and Agricultural Land Preservation, 2019–present\n* Member, Joint Expenditure Study Group on Law Enforcement and Transportation, 1991\n* Member, Joint Study Group on Transportation and Lottery Revenues, 1991\n* Member, Ways and Means Committee, 1991–2006 (vice-chair, 1997–2006; chair, vice-chair's subcommittee, 1997–2006)\n* Member, House Chair, Task Force on Telecommunications Taxes, 1994\n* Member, Special Joint Committee on Competitive Taxation and Economic Development, 1996–1997\n* House Chair, Task Force to Study County Property-Tax Setoffs and Related Fiscal Issues, 1997\n* Member, Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 1999–2003\n* Member, Special Committee on Higher Education Affordability and Accessibility, 2003–2004\n* Member, Spending Affordability Committee, 2003–2007\n* Member, House Chair, Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2007–2012\n* Member, Environmental Matters Committee, 2007–2015 (ground rent work group, 2007; housing & real property subcommittee, 2007–2015; motor vehicle & transportation subcommittee, 2007–2010; chair, local government & bi-county subcommittee, 2007–2015)\n\n\n* Member, County Affairs Committee, , 2015–present (bi-county committee, 1991–2002, 2008–2014; law enforcement & state-appointed boards committee, 2003–2007; maryland-national capital park & planning commission committee, 2008–2012)\n* President, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2021–present (member, 1991–present; legislative committee, 2006; secretary, 2016–2018; 2nd vice-president, 2018–2019; 1st vice-president, 2018–2019; vice-president, 2020–2021)\n* Member, Maryland Bicycle and Pedestrian Caucus, 2004–present\n* Member, Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2005–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2015, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member,  (budgets & revenue committee, 2005–present)\n\n\nWhile reporting for ''The Catholic Review'', Healey met her future husband, Neal Conway. Together, they have lived in Hyattsville since 1979 and have raised two children. Healey is a devout  and is of  descent. In September 2015, she was invited to attend 's visit to the .\n\nIn June 2020, Healey was diagnosed with . Her  treatments ended in December and she continued to receive radiation treatment during the 2021 legislative session.\n\n\n\nHealey introduced legislation during the 2013 legislative session that would make the Maryland school year start after . The bill passed to form a task force investigating a post-Labor Day start, of which Healey was a member. In 2019, Healey voted for, and later voted to override the governor's veto on, a bill that would allow school districts to start before Labor Day.\n\n\nIn 2015, Healey introduced legislation to protect bees from . The bill passed and became law on May 28, 2016.\n\nIn 2017, Healey sponsored legislation that would require developers to replant an acre of trees for every acre of forest they clear. Healey introduced legislation during the 2018 legislative session that would create a state definition for priority forests to improve state s. In 2019, Healey introduced legislation to create a task force to monitor and address future deforestation and make recommendations to prevent forest loss without disrupting growth and development.\n\n\nIn 2004, Healey voted in favor of legislation that would levy a two-percent tax on s to keep medical malpractice insurance costs for doctors in check.\n\nIn 2006, Healey voted in favor of legislation that would require  to pay more for employee health care benefits. The bill was vetoed by Governor , and the legislature failed to override his veto on an 88-50 vote in the House and a 30-17 vote in the .\n\nIn 2019, Healey voted in favor of legislation that would create a five-person panel to investigate and negotiate the prices of high-priced drugs.\n\n\nIn 2021, Healey voted in favor of legislation that would prohibit state and local government agencies from providing records or data to  for the purpose of civil immigration enforcement.\n\n\nDuring the , Healey endorsed . In , she endorsed .\n\n\nIn 2001, Healey voted in favor of legislation that would ban . In 2006, she opposed legislation that would ban . The bill failed to pass out of the House of Delegates on a 61-78 vote.\n\nHealey opposes the . In 2013, she voted in favor of legislation to repeal the death penalty, which was signed into law by Governor Martin O'Malley.\n\nIn 2003, Healey supported a proposal that would strip funding for  from the state budget. In 2005, she voted against a bill to provide state funding toward . In 2022, Healey voted against the Abortion Care Access Act, a bill to expand the array of medical providers who could perform abortions. She also voted against overriding the gubernatorial veto on the bill. Healey was targeted for a primary challenge by Pro-Choice Maryland in 2022 for her anti-abortion stances. She won the primary.\n\n\nIn 2013, Healey voted in favor of legislation to raise the state's  to replenish the state's transportation fund. In 2015, Healey voted against legislation that would repeal .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
