    "pages": }\n\n'''John Daniel Bailey''' (born August 27, 1965) is an American politician who has served as a  member of the  from the , based in  and , since 2019.\n\n\nBailey was born in  on August 27, 1965. He attended  in  and attended the  and , where he earned a  degree in management in 2013 and a  degree in management in 2014. From 1991 to 2017, he worked as a  for the .\n\nIn March 2018, Bailey declared his candidacy for Maryland Senate, seeking a primary challenge to senator , who was a target of   for voting with Senate President  one too many times. During the primary, Hogan endorsed and financed Bailey's campaign. He defeated Waugh in the primary by nearly 800 votes. He defeated Democratic challenger Thomas Brewer in the general election with 60.2 percent of the vote.\n\nBailey is a life member of the , who gave him an AQ rating and endorsed his candidacy in 2018.\n\n\n\nBailey was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019.\n\n\n* Member, Judicial Proceedings Committee, 2021–present\n* Member, Joint Committee on Ending Homelessness, 2019–present\n* Member, Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee, 2019–2020 (education subcommittee, 2019–present; alcohol subcommittee, 2020–present)\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2019–present\n\n\n\nBailey introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would charge  dealers with  if fentanyl was a contributing cause of someone's death. The bill was rejected by the Senate Judiciary Committee by a vote of 4-7.\n\nBailey introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would ban the possession of  by minors on school property. The bill failed due to concerns about a fine it would impose as a civil penalty. He reintroduced the bill during the 2022 legislative session without a fine.\n\n\nDuring his 2018 state senate campaign, Bailey called the Safe to Learn Act  legislation that includes $40 million in school safety funding  a \"step in the right location. But that was a small step,\" adding that local and state government and law enforcement \"do 75 percent of what that bill says already.\"\n\nDuring a debate on an education reform bill introduced in the 2019 legislative session, Bailey introduced an amendment that would update the bill to include the state's most recent calculation of schools with more than 80 percent of students receiving . The amendment was rejected by a vote of 18-27, but Senate President Bill Ferguson publicly committed to working with Bailey to ask Governor Hogan to process a budget amendment for the additional funding without cutting elsewhere.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Bailey voted against a multi-billion-dollar education reform bill, calling it \"ill-planned\". He also introduced legislation that would exempt s from receiving .\n\nBailey opposed legislation introduced in the 2022 legislative session that would break up the  and use the college's  campus to create a new Charles County Community College.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Bailey voted against legislation that would ban  food containers in restaurants.\n\nIn October 2019, the Maryland  gave Bailey a score of 20 percent, the lowest score in the Maryland Senate and tying him with senator .\n\nDuring a debate on the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2021, Bailey introduced an amendment to the bill that would exempt  from needing to be . It was adopted as a friendly amendment.\n\n\nDuring his 2018 state senate campaign, Bailey said that he was opposed to the creation of a publicly available gun registry, saying that people who want to get guns could potentially abuse the information. He also said that he would have voted against Maryland's  and  ban.\n\nDuring a debate on legislation that would prevent people from carrying a gun in or near a polling place, Bailey introduced an amendment that would exempt law enforcement officers, off-duty officers, or retired officers from the bill's provisions. The amendment failed on a 17-29 vote.\n\n\nDuring his 2018 state senate campaign, Bailey said that he is opposed to allowing Maryland to be a .\n\n\nBailey co-sponsored legislation during the 2020 legislative session that would strengthen punishment for crimes against minors.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Bailey protested legislation that would repeal the  in Maryland. He also voted against legislation that would create criminal penalties for police officers who intentionally use , fail to intervene to stop colleagues, or refuse to aid someone wounded by police. He introduced legislation that would incorporate law enforcement officers and first responders into Maryland .\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Bailey voted against legislation that would require s to wear s.\n\n\nBailey introduced legislation during the 2019 legislative session that would allow people in St. Mary's County to hunt any game bird or game mammal on Sundays during . The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 30, 2019.\n\nBailey co-sponsored legislation introduced during the 2020 legislative session that would make helmets optional for motorcyclists and their passengers if the motorcycle operator is 21 or older. The bill was rejected by the Senate Judiciary Committee by a vote of 5-6.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Bailey voted to sustain a gubernatorial veto on a bill that would levy a tax on  on large tech companies, pointing out that residents could easily go to states neighboring Maryland to avoid paying the state's taxes.\n\n\n* Certificate of Appreciation, , 1989, 2001\n* Conservation Officer of the Year, , 1999, 2004\n* Wildlife Law Enforcement Officer of the Year, Wild Turkey Federation, 2001, 2002\n* Officer of the Year, Northeast Conservation Law Enforcement Chiefs Association, 2003\n* Commendation for Significant Contributions in Wildlife Conservation, Natural Resources Police Force, , 2006, 2010\n* Annual Award for Excellence, , 2009\n* Certificate of Commendation, , 2009, 2015\n* Humane Law Enforcement Award, , 2015\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Cornell N. Dypski''' (September 23, 1931 – January 20, 2009) was a member of the  representing the  and a member of the  representing the .\n\n\nCornell N. Dypski was born and raised in a two-story rowhouse on Dillon Street in  on September 23, 1931. His father was an n immigrant and his mother worked in a cannery in . His father died from an automobile accident when he was a child. He graduated from the  in 1950 and attended the .\n\n\nDypski worked as an insurance salesman. He also worked as a court constable. He then worked as an administrative officer at the  from 1972 to 1994.\n\nHe represented  of the  from 1975 to 1983. It was redistricted into the 46th District in 1983. In 1995, he was a member of the Governor's Commission on Baltimore City Automobile-Insurance Rate Reduction. He also represented  of the  from January 14, 1987, to January 8, 2003.\n\nHe was a four year recipient of the Community Service Award for work as a chair of the United Charity Campaign.\n\n\nDypski married Joyce Houtz. Together, they had one son: Michael C. Dypski.\n\nDypski was friends with fellow state senator . His older brother, , was also a member of the Maryland House of Delegates in the 46th District in 1966.\n\n\nDypski died on January 20, 2009, at Gilchrist Hospice Care in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Gloria Gary Lawlah''' (born March 12, 1939) is an  who served as the Secretary of the  under Governor  from 2007 to 2015. She previously served in the  from 1991 to 2007 and in the  from 1987 to 1991.\n\n\n\n\nLawlah was born in  on March 12, 1939. She grew up with Newberry alongside her sister, Gene. She attended  in , where she earned a  in social studies. While at Hampton, she met her future husband, Jack, who eventually settled in , a neighborhood in . In 1972, she moved to .\n\n\nLawlah first got involved with politics after realizing that her home in Hillcrest Heights was represented by a  in the . Afterwards, she began working with elected officials and the local  to integrate schools in . She then got involved with the Prince George's County Women's Democratic Club, where she was able to meet U.S. Representative ,  , and then-state Senator .\n\n\nLawlah was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 1987.\n\n\n* Member, Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee, 1987–1991\n* Member, Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 1987–1991\n\n\nIn 1990, Lawlah defeated incumbent state Senator  in the Democratic primary election, backed by abortion-rights advocates who sought to create a -proof majority in the . Despite her, and other, victories in the general elections that year, the sought-after supermajority was never achieved. She was sworn in on January 9, 1991.\n\nLawlah considered running in the  in . In October 1991, she endorsed Prince George's County   for the seat.\n\nLawlah did not seek re-election in 2006, seeking to retire at the end of the year.\n\n\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on the Management of Public Funds, 2001–2007\n* Member, Budget and Taxation Committee, 1995–2007 (capital budget subcommittee, 1999–2007; chair, health & human services subcommittee, 2003–2007, member, 2001–2007; chair, health, education & human resources subcommittee, 1997–1999; chair, public safety, transportation & environment subcommittee, 2000)\n* Member, Economic and Environmental Affairs Committee, 1991–1994\n* Member, Joint Committee on Investigation, 1991–2007\n* Member, Joint Legislative Work Group on Community College Financing, 1994–1995\n* Member, Special Joint Task Force on Transportation, 1995\n* Member, Executive Nominations Committee, 1995–2000\n* Member, Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer, 1996, 2003\n* Member, Spending Affordability Committee, 1997–2000\n* Member, Joint Audit Committee, 1998–2007\n* Member, Joint Committee on Health Care Delivery and Financing, 1998–2007\n* Member, Senate Committee on Redistricting, 2001–2002\n* Member, Legislative Policy Committee, 2001–2003\n* Member, Special Commission on Legislative Prayer, 2003\n* Member, Joint Committee on the State's Emergency Medical Response System, 2003–2005\n* Senate Co-chair, Joint Committee on Protocol, 2003–2007\n\n\n* Chair, , 2004–2007 (vice-chair, 2001–2003)\n* Member, , 1999–2007 (chair, international affairs committee, 2001–2007; member, state budget committee, 2000, judicial nominating committee, 2000–2007, redistricting committee, 2000–2007, historically black colleges & universities committee, 2001–2007)\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 1991–2007 (member at large, executive board, 2001–2002; 2nd vice-president, 2002–2003; president, 2003–2004)\n* Member,  (economic development, trade & cultural affairs committee)\n\n\nOn February 7, 2007, Governor  appointed Lawlah to serve as the Secretary of the . Her nomination was unanimously approved by the Maryland Senate on February 23, 2007.\n\n\nLawlah remained active in politics after 2015, organizing the 1,000 Maryland Women .\n\n\nLawlah endorsed former Secretary of State  for president on November 17, 2015. In April 2016, Lawlah endorsed U.S. Representative  in the . In July 2019, she endorsed former Vice President  for president. In the , Lawlah voted as an elector in Maryland's 4th congressional district. In March 2021, she endorsed   for Governor of Maryland.\n\n\nLawlah is married to her husband, Jack, and has three children and six grandchildren. Together, they live in Hillcrest Heights, Maryland.\n\n\n\nLawlah identifies as \"\". In 1990, she challenged and defeated anti-abortion state Senator Frank Komenda in the Democratic primary elections after he voted for legislation that would have eliminated about 90 percent of abortions in Maryland. In 1991, Lawlah voted in favor of legislation that would provide access to abortion in Maryland while requiring physicians to inform minors' parents when their children seek an abortion. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor  on February 18, 1991.\n\n\nDespite objections she made during hearings, Lawlah supported legislation backed by Governor  in 2004 to allow Prince George's County  to have s. In July 2011, Lawlah resigned from the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission after attending a single meeting, saying that she was \"thrilled\" to be named but had not anticipated the \"tough\" schedule.\n\n\nIn October 1992, Lawlah criticized the Prince George's County Judicial Nominating Commission for rejecting attorney Elvira M. White, a Black woman, for judgeship based on charges of White being a \"closet racist\". In August 1994, she came to White's support after a  judge ruled that she failed to adequately represent a woman charged with conspiring to murder her parents.\n\n\nIn 2000, Lawlah refused to endorse a referendum to abolish term limits for the county executive and county council of Prince George's County. In November of that year, voters rejected a referendum by a 2-to-1 margin.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Benjamin Scott Barnes''' (born March 30, 1975) is an  who represents District 21 in the . A , he was first elected in 2006 and reelected in 2010, 2014, and 2018.\n\n\nRaised by a single mother, Barnes grew up in  in Maryland. He graduated from  in 1993 before enrolling at the , where he earned a  degree in economics and political science in 1998.\n\nBarnes says he first got involved with politics as a child, attending pro-choice marches in Washington, D.C., with his family. Barnes began working in politics shortly after graduating, first at  as an organizer from 1999 to 2000. Afterwards, Barnes worked as a political and legislative advisor to  , later earning a promotion to Deputy Legislative Director. During his time with Miller, Barnes attended night classes at the , graduating with a  in 2003. Barnes was admitted to the  in 2004, and clerked for Judge James J. Lombardi in the Prince George's County , 7th Judicial Circuit until 2005. before assuming his current position as a senior attorney at the John Hall Law Group in .\n\n\n\nBarnes was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 10, 2007. He has served as the Chief Deputy Majority Whip since 2013 and as the chair of the House Appropriations Committee since 2022. Barnes is currently a member of the Rules and Executive Nominations Committee and the Spending Affordability Committee, and was previously a member of the House Judiciary Committee and the Economic Matters Committee.\n\nDuring the , Barnes was elected and served as a pledged delegate for  to the  in Denver, Colorado.\n\n\n* Chief Deputy Majority Whip, 2013–present (deputy majority whip, 2011–2012)\n* Chair, Appropriations Committee, 2022–present (member, 2015–present; chair, oversight committee on pensions, 2015–2019; chair, education & economic development subcommittee, 2019–present, vice-chair, 2015–2019; chair, capital budget subcommittee, 2021–present, member, 2015–present, vice-chair, 2020)\n* House Special Committee on Drug and Alcohol Abuse, 2007–present\n* House Chair, Special Joint Committee on Pensions, 2015–2021 (member, 2021–present)\n* Member, Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2019–present\n* Member, Spending Affordability Committee, 2020–present (chair, 2019)\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2007–2011 (civil law & procedure subcommittee, 2007–2011)\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, 2011–2015 (banking, economic development, science & technology subcommittee, 2011; public utilities subcommittee, 2011–2015; workers' compensation subcommittee, 2012–2015)\n* Member, Commission on Maryland Retirement Security and Savings, 2015–2016\n* House Chair, Spending Affordability Committee, 2016–2019\n\n\n* 1st vice-chair, , 2012–2014 (law enforcement & state-appointed boards committee, 2007–2008, 2011; Washington suburban sanitary commission committee, 2008–2010; vice-chair, Maryland-national capital park & planning commission committee, 2012; chair, county affairs committee, 2017–present, member, 2013–present)\n* Member, , 2007–present (capital budget committee, 2018)\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019–present\n\n\nBarnes is married to Caitlin McDonough, a partner with the lobbyist law firm Harris Jones & Malone. and daughter to Former Secretary of State . The couple has three sons.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Barnes introduced legislation that would expand the  to include the Maryland Secretary of Commerce, two members appointed by the  and the , and a second student member. The bill passed both chambers unanimously and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 30, 2019.\n\nIn January 2020, Barnes proposed an amendment to change how much funding the state would provide toward education funding in  and Prince George's County, resulting in an annual increase of $146.9 million and a $202.9 million respectively by 2030.\n\nBarnes supported legislation introduced during the 2021 legislative session that would allow college athletes to profit off their name, image, and likeness.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Barnes voted to pass legislation that would require  of gun buyers, place new limits on firearm purchases by the , and ban s and  that hold more than 10 bullets.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Barnes introduced legislation to ban firearm possession on the campuses of public colleges and universities, with exceptions for police officers and security personnel. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a 89–49 vote on April 4, 2018.\n\n\nBarnes was the original House sponsor of the , arguing in 2011 that Maryland was discriminating against gay couples by not allowing them to marry. He voted in favor of the legislation when it was reintroduced in the 2012 legislative session as an Administration bill under Governor Martin O'Malley.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Barnes voted to pass legislation that would repeal the  in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Barnes voted to pass legislation that would raise gas taxes to replenish the state's transportation fund.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Herman L. Taylor Jr.''' is an  who served as a member of the  from 2003-2011 in Maryland's 14th Legislative District. District 14 includes parts of , , , , , , , , , ,  in . He is the founder of the Minority Business Economic Council.\n\n\nDelegate Taylor was first elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in 2002 and re-elected in 2006. He serves on the House Economic Matters Committee and is Chairman of the Subcommittee on Unemployment Insurance. He is the current Co-Chair of the Joint Committee on Unemployment Insurance Oversight. He has served on the Banking, Economic Development, Science & Technology Subcommittee, and is currently a member of the Business Regulation Subcommittee and the Public Utilities Subcommittee.\n\nDelegate Taylor served as the Historian of the Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland in 2003. From 2006–2008 he was the Second Vice Chair of that Caucus and is currently Chairman of the Economic Development Committee and Co-Chair of the Legislative Review Committee. He is also a member of the Maryland Veterans Caucus and the Maryland Democratic Business Caucus.\n\nDelegate Taylor has received several prominent awards while serving in public office. In 2003, the Maryland State Department of Education presented him with the 2003 Award of Excellence in Education. In 2004, he was named Legislator of the Month by the Center for Policy Alternatives for his work on the Living Wage bill. In 2006, he was given the Clean Energy Partnership Award. Recently, he was awarded the Bethune-DuBois Institute Award and  Community Builder Award. He also received the 2008 Public Service Award by the  fraternity for his work on securing funding for the Washington, DC Martin Luther King Jr. National Memorial. He was named the 2008 Legislator of the Year by the Washington DC Building and Construction Trades Council.\n\nTaylor retired from the House of Delegates to run for Congress in 2010.\n\n\n*voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359) \n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted against slots in 2005 (HB1361) \n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6) \n*voted in favor of increasing the sales tax by 20% - Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2) \n\n\nIn addition to his public service, Delegate Taylor was the President & CEO of his Deskmate Office Products company for 20 years. His company is one of the largest minority owned office products distributors in the Washington metropolitan area.   \nDelegate Taylor received The Washington Metropolitan Top Forty under 40 Award for his business and, in 1995, he was named one of the 50 Leaders of Tomorrow in the golden anniversary issue of Ebony magazine. He has served on advisory boards for Capital Bank and  Bank, and has been a member of the Task Force on Lending Equity within Financial Institutions Providing State Depository Services since 2005. Taylor's community service has included involvement with the Rainbow/Push Coalition's Wall Street Project, the National Coalition of Minority Businesses, the Smithsonian Anacostia Museum, the African-American History and Culture, the Washington Adventist Hospital Foundation, the Olney Theatre, the Boys and Girls Club of Greater Washington, and the ARC (formerly Association for Retarded Citizens). He is currently the Managing Director of the Minority Business Economic Council and serves the minority owned businesses around the Maryland area.\n\nTaylor also made appearances on Bravo's The Real Housewives of Potomac as Gizelle Bryant's boyfriend\n\n\n\nIn 2010, Herman Taylor announced he was retiring from the House of Delegates to run for Congress in . He was defeated in the Democratic primary by .\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert B. Long''' (born January 11, 1957) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  from the  since 2015.\n\n\nLong was born in  on January 11, 1957. He was raised by a single mother. Long attended  and the  before becoming a  realtor for Covenant Realty. He is also a former union truck driver.\n\nLong is a member of the Maryland Association of Realtors, the Greater Baltimore Board of Realtors, the  Legacy Group, and the . He first ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in 2010, but was defeated by incumbents , , and  in the general election.\n\nLong is married and has four children.\n\n\n\nLong was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates alongside Republicans  and  in the , during which the three ran on a platform involving economic issues. He was sworn in on January 14, 2015, and has served as a member of the Ways and Means Committee during his entire tenure. Long keeps a brick from the former Sparrows Point steel mill on his desk as a reminder \"of where we've been and where we have to go\".\n\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Long introduced a bill that would fine parents $1,000 if their child gets into trouble at school four times. In 2023, he introduced the Parent and Guardian Accountability Act, which would require parents to participate in counseling with their student after repeating a notice of repeated disruptive behavior during school hours.\n\n\nIn August 2022, Long signed onto a letter asking Governor  to keep the Back River Wastewater Treatment Plant under the Maryland Environmental Service's control, expressing concerns that the plant would \"resort back to mismanagement\" if given back to the city of .\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Long supported legislation to provide $8.5 billion in tax incentives to  to build their  in Montgomery County, hoping that Amazon locating in Maryland would bring jobs to his district.\n\nIn 2020, Long expressed concerns with a bill to impose a six percent tax on \"luxury services\" and lobbied to have \"marina services\" removed from the luxury services defined in the bill.\n\n\nIn November 2016, Long condemned a tape recording of a vulgar discussion  had on ''Access Hollywood'' in 2005 about , calling it \"disgusting and inappropriate\". He supported Trump in the , expressing optimism that he would bring manufacturing jobs back to his district as president.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Long introduced legislation that would extend state hate crime protections to first responders.\n\nIn 2023, during debate on a bill to establish the state's , Long introduced an amendment that would prevent occupants of a motor vehicle from smoking cannabis near a minor. The amendment was rejected in a 40-97 vote.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sara N. Love''' (born April 6, 1967) is an American politician who currently serves as a member of the  representing the 16th district since 2024. A member of the , she previously represented the district in the  from 2019 to 2024.\n\n\nLove was born in  on April 6, 1967, where she graduated from . She attended , where she earned a  degree in history in 1989, and the , where she earned a  in law in 1993. After graduating, she worked as a law clerk for Judge  from 1993 to 1994. From 1998 to 2014, she worked for various women's health groups, including the , the , and . From 2005 to 2016, Love worked for the  of Maryland, serving as the president of the board of directors from 2008 to 2012 and as the group's public policy director from 2012 to 2016.\n\nIn August 2017, Love declared her candidacy for state delegate in Maryland's 16th legislative district, seeking to succeed state delegate , who ran for Congress in . In the primary election, Love finished third in a field of eight candidates, edging out  teacher Samir Paul by 9 votes. Paul filed for a recount of the results on July 10, 2018. Love maintained her lead over Paul after the recount, increasing her vote total in the district to 12 votes. He conceded from the election on July 27, 2018. She came in third place in the general election, receiving 29.4 percent of the vote.\n\n\nLove was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She has served as a member of the Environment and Transportation Committee during her entire tenure, including as the chair of its motor vehicle and transportation subcommittee from 2023 to 2024.\n\nDuring the , Love canvassed for  in the Pennsylvania cities of  and .\n\nIn May 2022, ahead of the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in '''', Love launched StandUp MD, a program to train college students and recent graduates about political organizing and to support  candidates in Maryland. The program was funded by Love's campaign, as she did not face any opposition in her re-election bid that year.\n\nIn March 2024, after state senator  announced that she would resign in May to become the executive director of the Maryland Commission for Women, Love said that she would apply to serve the remainder of Kelly's term in the Maryland Senate. The Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee nominated Love to fill the seat on June 3, 2024. Love was appointed to the seat by Governor  and sworn in on June 13, 2024.\n\n\nLove is a self-described progressive Democrat.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Love introduced a bill to strengthen and codify the Keep Antibiotics Effective Act, which restricts the use of antibiotics in food-producing animals. The bill passed and became law without Governor 's signature.\n\nIn February 2022, Love introduced the \"George Taylor Act\", which would ban products containing . The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Love introduced the \"Clean Trucks Act\", which would require vehicle manufacturers and dealers to sell an increasing percentage of zero-emission vehicles beginning in model year 2027. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nIn November 2023, following the  and subsequent , Love and other District 16 legislators released a statement condemning the attack and condemned antisemitic and Islamophobic hate crimes.\n\n\nLove supports increasing the Maryland minimum wage to .\n\n\nDuring her time at the ACLU, Love lobbied for several policing bills, including one prevent police from searching a person's emails before obtaining a warrant, another that prevents police from tracking cellphones without warrants, and a bill to limit  abuse by requiring conviction before police could confiscate property.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Love introduced a bill that would allow Maryland drivers to designate their gender as \"X\" on their license. The bill passed and became law without Governor Larry Hogan's signature.\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Love introduced the \"Maryland Online Privacy Act\", which restricts the kinds of data companies can collect to only what is necessary and relevant to the product, would give consumers the right to know which data is being collected and the ability to have it deleted, and bans targeted advertising.\n\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Love introduced the \"Sarah Debbink Langenkamp Memorial Act\", which would make hitting a cyclist in a bike lane an offense punishable by up to two months in jail alongside a fine of up to $2,000. The bill was named after Sarah Debbnik Langenkamp, a Bethesda cyclist who was hit and killed by a flatbed truck in August 2022.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''James Carew Rosapepe''' (born May 20, 1951) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  in since 2007. A member of the , he previously represented the district in the  from 1987 to 1997, and served as the  from 1998 to 2001.\n\n\nRosapepe was born in  on May 20, 1951, where his parents were working as American journalists. His grandparents migrated to the United States from  in the early 20th century. Rosapepe grew up in  before moving to  in the late 1960s, and attended  as an undergraduate, but did not graduate, and .\n\n\nRosapepe has been involved in politics since he was 17 years old. While living in Arlington, he served as the president of the Arlington Youth Council. Rosapepe took a year off from attending Yale to work as an intern to the President's Council on Youth Opportunity within the . During his internship, he was the subject of multiple  memos that questioned whether he should have a voice in the Youth Conference, citing his activism and anti-Nixon views. Despite these memos, White House aide Steve Hess, who hired Rosapepe, said that he would not consider discharging him as the council also included members of the right-wing  organization, and that having \"some radical liberals\" in the Youth Conference gave it credibility. Afterwards, Rosapepe worked as a policy assistant to various congressmembers, for whom he worked on macroeconomic and competition issues. From 1979 to 1981, he served as a member of the . Rosapepe worked for the Maryland Committee on Federal Income Tax Conformity in 1982, and afterwards chaired the Economic Development Committee for the city of , until 1986. He also served as a member of the Maryland Democratic State Central Committee from 1985 to 1992, and later as the treasurer of the  from 1985 to 1989 and as its deputy chair 1989 to 1992.\n\nRosapepe served as the president of the Maryland Main Street Development Association from 1984 to 1985. Afterwards, he served on the boards of directors for the  and National Small Business United until 1992. Since 2001, Rosapepe has served as the chief executive officer of Patuxent Capital Group. He has also worked as a federal lobbyist for the .\n\n\nRosapepe was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 3, 1987. During his tenure, he was a member of the Spending Affordability Committee from 1987 to 1993, afterwards serving as its vice chair from 1995 until his resignation on December 31, 1997. '''' described Rosapepe as a suburban liberalsupporting organized labor, environmental advocacy, and increased education spendingand as an ally of Governor . He also became involved with foreign policy issues during his tenure, attending an exchange trip to  in 1982 and extensively traveled to parts of the former . In 1995, Rosapepe was appointed to the .\n\nRosapepe worked as a national treasurer for U.S. Senator 's . He worked on the  and  presidential campaigns of , in which he helped organize  behind Clinton and got to know Clinton, , and many of their close advisors, including  and .\n\n\n\nOn September 25, 1997, President  nominated Rosapepe to serve as the U.S. Ambassador to Romania. He was confirmed by the  on November 6, 1997, and was officially sworn in on January 20, 1998. In this capacity, Rosapepe helped integrate Romania into  and helped secure the country's support in the , and supported the country's transition to a democratic  system by promoting U.S.-Romanian trade. He also criticized  mayor  for campaigning against a law granting rights to . Rosapepe was the subject of an internal State Department report in which officials claimed that morale within the embassy plunged during his tenure and that the embassy often provided \"inadequate\" information on Romanian affairs, with communications often \"tilted towards the Romanian perspective\".\n\n\nFollowing his ambassadorship, Rosapepe was appointed by Governor  to serve on the  from 2001 to 2006. In this capacity, he voted against tuition increases and criticized Governor  for vetoing the Higher Education Affordability and Access Act, a bill to cap tuition increases for three years and restore budget cuts to higher education. He also founded the Marylanders for Access to Quality Higher Education to lobby for the legislature to override the governor's veto on the bill.\n\n\nIn 2006, after Governor  did not reappoint Rosapepe to the University System Board of Regents, Rosapepe launched a  against state Senator , who was perceived by other Democratic lawmakers as being too conservative after siding with Republicans and Governor  on key votes, including a bill to ban s in Maryland. During the Democratic primary, Giannetti gained national attention after performing the  on Rosapepe, who was choking on a piece of lobster at an Italian restaurant they were both eating at. Rosapepe defeated Giannetti in the Democratic primary with 58 percent of the vote, after which Giannetti switched his party affiliation to  to run against Rosapepe in the general election. Rosapepe again defeated Giannetti in the general election.\n\n\nRosapepe was sworn in on January 10, 2007. He was a member of the Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee from 2007 to 2016, afterwards serving on the Finance Committee. Rosapepe has served as a member of the Budget and Taxation Committee since 2019, and as the committee's vice chair since 2020.\n\nIn January 2012, Rosapepe expressed interest in running for  in  if  ran for  instead of seeking re-election. Franchot declined to run for governor in , and Rosapepe subsequently ran for reelection to the Maryland Senate.\n\nIn April 2019, Rosapepe and state Delegate  launched \" for Maryland\", becoming the first two Maryland lawmakers to endorse his bid for president. He also organized groups of ethnic leaders from Central and Eastern Europe, including , to support and campaign for Biden in s.\n\n\nRosapepe is married to Sheilah A. Kast, a former White House and economics correspondent for .  He is . In November 2009, Rosapepe and his wife published ''Dracula is Dead'', a travel literature book that explores the political and social history of Romania during the 20th century.\n\nIn late December 2007, Rosapepe was struck by a car in a hit-and-run incident during a business trip in . He returned to Maryland in early January 2008 with two s in his right leg.\n\n\n\nIn April 1994, Rosapepe said he opposed a bill to provide state funding to build a new stadium for the  in , saying that the stadium funds should instead go toward improving state schools. During the 1997 legislative session, he led an unsuccessful revolt against House leadership, in which he rallied for increased funding for education in underserved communities and .\n\nDuring the 2008 legislative session, Rosapepe introduced legislation that would allow disabled students to participate in school sports.\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Rosapepe voted for , a bill that extended  for . In 2020, he supported a bill to lower the requirements for undocumented immigrants to apply for in-state tuition at public colleges.\n\nIn September 2013, Rosapepe expressed concerns with an  agreement that allowed school properties to be considered as possible  locations, which he said could affect the health of students.\n\nIn October 2018, Rosapepe defended  president  following the death of football player , saying that it was \"insane\" that people wanted to make Loh \"a scapegoat\" for McNair's death. He urged Loh to stay as president after he offered his retirement later that month, and celebrated Loh's decision to delay his retirement until June 2020.\n\n\nRosapepe opposes . During the 2008 legislative session, he introduced a bill that would require utility companies that build power plants in Maryland to first sell their electricity in-state, which passed and became law. In July 2012, after a  left more than a million residents without power for several days, Rosapepe called for fines of $100 million against  and  as well as requiring utility companies to place power lines underground to prevent future outages. Rosapepe expressed disappointment with the 's decision not to place stiff fines against the utility companies in its assessment following the derecho.\n\n\nDuring the 1987 legislative session, Rosapepe voted to overturn a  ruling that allowed victims of crimes committed with  handguns to sue the weapon's manufacturers. During the 2013 legislative session, he voted for the Firearm Safety Act, which banned assault weapons and placed restrictions on firearm purchases. In 2016, Rosapepe introduced legislation to ban terrorists from banning firearms and supported bills banning firearms on campuses and requiring domestic abusers to surrender their guns.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Rosapepe supported legislation to establish the Prescription Drug Affordability Board to negotiate the prices of prescription drugs and other bills to make it easier for uninsured people to apply for health coverage.\n\nIn April 2020, amid the , Rosapepe urged Governor  to form a regional pact with bordering states. He criticized the 's rollout of the , accusing the agency of creating \"artificial shortages\" and not providing adequate constituent services. Rosapepe also supported a  in schools.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Rosapepe voted for legislation to raise the minimum wage to .\n\n\n, 2012]]\nDuring his tenure as the president of the Arlington Youth Council, Rosapepe opposed anti- laws that were aimed at teenagers and campaigned for more county funding for educational research.\n\nIn March 1995, Rosapepe voted to keep restrictions on how state tax dollars could be used to pay for abortions through .\n\nDuring the 2009 legislative session, Rosapepe voted for legislation to abolish the .\n\nIn February 2011, after the Religious Freedom and Civil Marriage Protection Act, a bill to legalize , was amended to include more protections for religious groups, Rosapepe said that he would support the bill. He was seen as a key vote on the bill, and his support gave it the support it needed to pass the Maryland Senate. In 2012, Rosapepe voted for the .\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Rosapepe supported a bill to restore voting rights for felons on parole. In 2016, he voted to override Governor 's veto of the bill.\n\nIn 2020, Rosapepe introduced legislation to make  permanent.\n\n\nDuring the 1988 legislative session, Rosapepe introduced legislation that would require pizza shops to charge the sales tax on deliveries. In 1992, he voted for a bill to raise $1.2 billion in income and sales taxes.\n\nIn 1997, Rosapepe voted for a bill to provide tax credits to businesses who hire disabled people. He also opposed a proposal by Governor  to cut personal income taxes by 10 percent, preferring tax cuts aimed at middle- and lower-income families.\n\nDuring debate on a bill that would provide $5.6 billion in tax incentives to  to build their  in Montgomery County in 2018, Rosapepe introduced an amendment that would terminate the tax incentivizes if unclaimed by 2022. The amendment was adopted by the Maryland Senate.\n\n\nRosapepe supports the  and . In June 2015, he attended a rally at the  to protest against its possible closure by the .\n\nDuring the 1991 legislative session, Rosapepe introduced a resolution urging Congress to fund the design and development of a  train route connecting  to . In December 2017, he said that he opposed the proposed D.C.-Baltimore maglev train route.\n\nIn 1997, Rosapepe supported a bill to ban s on state highways, saying that the lanes made driving more difficult and less safe.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''Dracula is dead: how Romanians survived communism, ended it, and emerged since 1989 as the new Italy'', , 2009. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Nicholas Patrick Charles II''' (born December 16, 1982) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2023. He previously represented the district in the  from 2019 to 2023.\n\n\nCharles was born in  and grew up in , and graduated from . He served in the  and the  of the  from 2001 to 2006, afterwards attending , where he earned an  in aviation management, and the , where he earned a  degree in business administration, both in 2009.\n\n\nAfter serving in the military, Charles worked as a defense contractor for the . In 2015, he started his own consulting company.\n\nIn 2014, Charles unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 25, placing fifth in the Democratic primary. He ran again in 2018, during which he ran on a slate with incumbents  and . Charles placed third in the Democratic primary and general elections.\n\n\nCharles was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. He served as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee until 2021, afterwards serving in the Ways and Means Committee. Following the appointment of  to serve as , Charles was unanimously elected as the chair of the .\n\nIn October 2023, after state senator  announced that she would resign at the end of the month, Charles announced that he would apply to serve the remainder of Griffith's term in the . He was the only candidate to apply for the seat and in November, he was unanimously nominated by the Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee to the seat. Charles was appointed to the seat by Governor  and sworn in on December 5.\n\n\n, 2023]]\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Charles introduced a bill that would prohibit employers from firing workers who refused to get the .\n\n\nIn February 2015, Charles called s \"part of the problem\" when referring to a foreclosure and housing crisis in Prince George's County. During his 2018 House of Delegates campaign, he said he supported legislation to reform the real estate appraisal process. In 2023, Charles introduced a bill to provide low-income homeowners with a  in foreclosures.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Charles introduced a bill that would allow people targeted by  to sue callers for damages.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Charles introduced a bill that would ban discrimination against students and guardians in education.\n\n\nAfter serving in the military, Charles bought a home in .\n\nCharles' personal military awards include two s.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carolyn Josephine Krysiak''' ( Fabiszak; August 9, 1939 – May 8, 2024) was an American politician who represented the  in the . Krysiak was also the chair of the House Facilities Committee, being appointed by Speaker  to that position in 2005.\n\n\n\nKrysiak was born in Baltimore, Maryland on August 9, 1939. She graduated from  (all girls) and then attended the University of Maryland and the Community College of Baltimore. Prior to taking office she was a supervisor in the Baltimore City Department of Finance. She was of Polish descent.\n\n\nKrysiak met her future husband, Charles J. Krysiak, at a Catholic Youth Organization dance. They married in 1962, and together they had five children and lived in the  neighborhood of Baltimore. Charles served in the Maryland House of Delegates from 1966 until his resignation in 1979, when Governor  appointed him chair of the Maryland Workers' Compensation Commission.\n\nKrysiak died from cancer at her daughter's home in , on May 8, 2024. She was 84.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 46th District''' Retrieved on Mar. 3, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Doyle L. Niemann''' (March 19, 1947 – May 1, 2024) was an American prosecutor, public administrator, and politician who represented District 47 in the  from 2003 to 2015. He was the Chief of Operations for the  State's Attorney's Office in the administration of State's Attorney .\n\n\n\nNiemann was born in , on March 19, 1947. He was a Regents Scholar at the  where he attended from 1965 to 1967. He then graduated from the  with a B.A. in government in 1969 and was a member of the  honor society. Teaching fellowship, Graduate School of Government, University of Texas, 1970. , J.D., 1997 (Order of Coif; Editor, Maryland Law Review). He was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1997. An Assistant State's Attorney for Prince George's County since 1998, Delegate Niemann specialized in prosecuting economic and s. He previously served on the Mount Rainier City Council (1983–1987), the Maryland Democratic Committee (1986–1990), and the Prince George's County Board of Education (1996–2002).\n\n\n\nMember of House of Delegates since January 8, 2003. Member, Environmental Matters Committee, 2007- (environment subcommittee, 2007-; housing & real property subcommittee, 2007-; natural resources subcommittee, 2007-; chair, ground rent work group, 2007-).\n\nNiemann was instrumental in legislation addressing consumer economic issues including the 2005 enactment of the Protection of Homeowners in Foreclosure Act (PHIFA) and the 2008 efforts to modernize Maryland's draconian foreclosure procedures. PHIFA was one of the very early attempts by a state to end what is commonly known as a  (or fraud). PHIFA has been the model for other states fighting these frauds. In 2008, Delegate Niemann was once again a leader in the House in the successful fight to strengthen the standards for mortgage brokers, to make substantial changes to the Maryland procedures for foreclosures that protected consumers, and to improve PHIFA. Notably, these financial measures were taken months before most Americans were aware of the financial crisis that hit the nation in the fall of 2008.\n\n\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted against slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted for the Tax Reform Act of 2007 (HB2)\n* voted in favor of prohibiting ground rents in 2007(SB106)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n\n\nNiemann died at the  in , on May 1, 2024, at the age of 77. Governor  ordered flags to fly at half-staff in honor of Niemann on May 31.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 47th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 47th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''B. Daniel Riley''' (February 16, 1946 – August 31, 2016) was an American politician who represented  in the .\n\n\nBorn in , he was a  social studies teacher from 1978 until 2006.\n\n\nRiley attended  high school and graduated in 1964.  He graduated from  with his B.S. (education) in 1978 and with his M.A. (education) in 1984.\n\n\nRiley has had two separate terms as a member of House of Delegates. Initially he served from January 13, 1999, to January 8, 2003, representing District 34 (), and more recently he served from January 10, 2007, to January 9, 2011, representing  (). Riley lost his bid to return to the legislature for the 2011 term when he lost in the 2010 democratic primary by 57 votes.\nRiley was a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee. In his first term he was a member of the Commerce and Government Matters Committee and its transportation subcommittee.\n\n\nMaryland League of Conservation Voters, which consists of all the major Maryland environmental organizations, gave Delegate Riley a 100% voting record, on environmental issues for the 2008 session.  Delegate Riley's lifetime score is 86%.\n\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000 \n* voted for Jessica's Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007 \n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008 \n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009 \n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet, 2009 \n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 34A - Cecil & Harford County''' Retrieved on November 3, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 34A - Cecil & Harford County''' Retrieved on November 3, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36 - Harford County'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Kullen was originally appointed to the seat in 2004, and elected in 2006. She served on the Health and Government Operations Committee from 2004 to 2011 and as President of the Women Legislators of Maryland, a nonpartisan committee of state legislators, from 2009 to 2011. In 2014, Kullen ran unsuccessfully for a seat in the  in District 27C, losing to incumbent .\n\n\n*Member of House of Delegates August 4, 2004 - January 12, 2011\n*Chief Deputy Majority Whip,     "pages": }\n}}\n\n'''Allan H. Kittleman''' (born October 20, 1958) is an American  politician who was the ninth  for  from 2014 to 2018. Kittleman previously served as a  from 2004 to 2014, representing the 9th district covering Howard and , and was Senate  from 2008 to 2011. He also previously served on the Howard  from 1998 to 2004.\n\n\nBorn on October 20, 1958, in , Kittleman attended  in Howard County, Maryland. He earned a bachelor's degree from the  (UMBC), in 1981 and graduated with honors from the  with a  in 1988.\n\n\nKittleman was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1988 and was an associate with Smith, Somerville & Case, 1988–1991 (legal assistant, 1984–1988) and a partner with Herwig & Humphreys, LLP from 1996 to 2003 (associate, 1991–1996). Kittleman has worked for the law firm Godwin, Erlandson, MacLaughlin, Vernon & Daney since 2008.\n\n\nHe is the son of the late  and was appointed by Governor  (R) to fill his seat in the Maryland Senate. In 2006, Kittleman won re-election against Democrat Richard Corkran. He has a reputation as a social libertarian. In 2010, Senator Kittleman defeated Jim Adams by a wide margin in the general election after facing no primary opposition. On September 16, 2008, Kittleman was elected Minority Leader of the Maryland Senate. On January 30, 2010, the Senate Republican Caucus again chose him to serve as Minority Leader with Senator  as Minority Whip, who defeated Senator .\n\nSenator Kittleman resigned as Minority Leader on January 18, 2011. During the 2011 General Assembly session, he was the only Republican in the Maryland State senate to speak in favor of or vote for a .\n\n\nKittleman was elected County Executive of Howard County, defeating Councilwoman Courtney Watson in the 2014 election. Kittleman's declared priorities as executive included improving the delivery of human services, closing the education gap and rebuilding infrastructure throughout Howard County.\n\nKittleman spent $1.1 million on school site security, including $800,000 for hiring three s and a supervisor for them.\n\nHe created and later expanded the \"Achieve 24/7 initiative\" which provided small grants to support mental health support and racial equity resources in schools.\n\nKittleman helped develop a draft proposal which suggested making zoning changes and architectural updates to the Long Reach Village Center.\n\nKittleman increased the county operating budget by 15.5% from about $1.4 billion to $1.6 billion over the course of his term, and his budgets passed unanimously each year in the 4–1 majority Democratic County Council.\nKittleman brought many projects to completion that had been discussed for decades but never addressed, including a new Howard County Circuit Courthouse, expansion of MD Rt 32, establishment of a Community Resources Campus, improvements to a pedestrian bridge over Route 29, and purchase of a $23.1 million plot of land intended for a new high school.\n\nControversial measures undertaken by his administration include reassessing the sustainable growth tier structure of the county in order to change which farmland was required to be in an agricultural preservation program. The structure was put in place in 2012 by County Executive  in 2013. On February 9, 2017, Kittleman vetoed a bill passed three days earlier by the County Council on a 3–2 vote to declare Howard County a sanctuary jurisdiction for illegal immigrants. He said that the bill was unnecessary because he knew of no complaints of unfair treatment due to immigration status.\n\nDemocratic County Councilman  defeated Kittleman in the November 2018 election for County Executive. Kittleman said he was disappointed though he accepted the voters' decision and would seek to help Ball's transition.\n\n\nFollowing his election defeat in 2018, Kittleman was appointed to the Maryland Worker's Compensation Commission by Governor .\n\nIn September 2021, Kittleman announced he would run for County Executive of Howard County in the 2022 election. He cited community division and taxes as key issues for his campaign.\n\nKittleman sought and received campaign contributions from the Citizen's Election Fund, a tax-funded government program that provides money to candidates and bars them from accepting donations from businesses, PACs, or special interest groups. 2022 is the first year a local public campaign finance program was available. Kittleman had previously opposed the creation of the Citizen's Election Fund.\n\nKittleman lost to incumbent county executive  in the general election on November 8, 2022, and conceded to Ball the following day.\n\n\n\n*'''2022 race for Howard County Executive'''\n:\n\n*'''2018 race for Howard County Executive'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 race for Howard County Executive'''\n:\n\n*'''2010 race for Maryland State Senate&nbsp;– District 9'''\n:\n\n*'''2006 race for Maryland State Senate&nbsp;– District 9'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*   (official website)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Steven C. Johnson''' (born December 30, 1960) is an American politician who is a  member of the  representing .\n\n\nJohnson was born on December 30, 1960, in . He attended  and . Johnson served in the  from 1977 to 1987, and as an auxiliary police officer in Aberdeen from 2006 to 2016. He also worked as a construction supervisor at  and owns the Johnson Family Pharmacy in Aberdeen.\n\nFrom 2005 to 2017, Johnson worked as the director of Economic Development for the city of . He ran for the Aberdeen City Council in 2007, but he was disqualified shortly before the general election for not living within the city limits. Johnson initially challenged his disqualification, but dropped his legal challenge, saying that he didn't \"want to alter the natural outcome of the election\". In 2014, he unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 34A.\n\n\nJohnson won election to the Maryland House of Delegates in , edging out incumbent state delegate  by a margin of 165 votes. He was sworn in on January 9, 2019, and has served as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee during his entire tenure. Since 2023, Johnson has served as deputy majority whip.\n\n\nJohnson is married with three children.\n\n\n\nIn February 2021, during debate on a bill to stagger the terms of elected Harford County school board members, Johnson supported an amendment to create a fully-elected school board in the county. The amendment failed in a 4-4 tie.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Johnson voted against legislation requiring background checks for sales of shotguns and rifles.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Johnson introduced the \"Connor's Courage\" Act, named for  student Connor Sheffield, which would allow students to take  at school. The bill passed and became law.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Johnson voted for legislation to raise the state minimum wage to $15 an hour.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Johnson introduced legislation that would protect s from being shut down by local permit laws.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Johnson opposed an amendment to legislation to enact a 30-day  amid the  that would've extended the holiday to 90 days. He also introduced legislation that would exempt oral hygiene products from the state sales tax, which passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Arthur Carr Ellis''' (born July 26, 1961) is an American politician and accountant who has served as a member of the  from the  since 2019.\n\n\nEllis was born in , Jamaica, on July 26, 1961. He graduated from the  with a  degree in chemistry and agriculture in 1983, and the  (CUNY) with a  in accountancy in 1990. He served in the  from 1983 to 1989, and in the  until 2001, attaining the rank of . He returned to the United States and moved to Maryland after being discharged from military after being injured while serving.\n\nAfter graduating from CUNY, Ellis became an associate at , afterwards working as an instructor for the , the , and the  until 1993. From 2008 to 2017, he worked as a volunteer leader at the .\n\nEllis became involved in politics as a member of the Charles County  chapter, becoming its communications director in 2016. In March 2017, he criticized the state's $900,000 purchase and preservation of land where  was enslaved before escaping to freedom, arguing that the money would be better spent on youth programs. He ran for the Maryland Senate in 2018, challenging six-term incumbent . Ellis defeated Middleton in an upset in the Democratic primary on June 26, 2018, receiving 52.0 percent of the vote and edging out Middleton by 651 votes. Following Middleton's defeat, the  targeted the district, backing businessman and Charles County Republican Party chairman Bill Dotson, who Ellis defeated in the general election on November 6, 2018, with 66.2 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nEllis was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. Since 2020, he has served as the assistant deputy majority leader.\n\n\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on the Management of Public Funds, 2023–present\n* Finance Committee, 2023–present\n* Joint Committee on Ending Homelessness, 2019–present\n* Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee, 2019–2022 (education subcommittee, 2019–2022; health subcommittee, 2019–2022)\n* Joint Subcommittee on Program Open Space and Agricultural Land Preservation, 2019–2022\n* Senate President's Advisory Work Group on Equity and Inclusion, 2020–2021\n\n\nDuring his 2018 campaign, Ellis described himself as a .\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Ellis voted against an amendment to the  that would provide $150 million in grants toward programs to improve students' behavioral health, arguing that it could \"stigmatize poor kids and create a long-lasting trail of unemployability for these children\". In January 2021, he said he supported overriding Governor 's veto of the Blueprint.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Ellis introduced a bill that would split up the  and use the college's  campus to create a new Charles County Community College.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ellis introduced a bill to require the makeup of local election boards to be based on the party affiliation of voters in each county, rather than the governor's political party. He also supported a bill that would eliminate at-large county commissioner districts, requiring commissioners to be elected to individual districts.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ellis introduced an amendment to the  that would prioritize tree planting projects in underserved areas, and another amendment requiring the state's climate transition workgroup to include a veteran, a formerly incarcerated person, two women and two NAACP members; both amendments were adopted.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ellis introduced a bill that would prohibit s from entering schools unless instructed or in the event of an emergency. The bill failed to move out of committee.\n\nIn 2022, Ellis said he supported overriding Governor Larry Hogan's veto of a bill to repeal the Law Enforcement Officer's Bill of Rights.\n\n\nDuring his 2018 campaign, Ellis said he supported upgrades to  and  and , as well as expanding  to Charles County. During the 2020 legislative session, he introduced a bill to provide $27 million toward building a light rail line in southern Maryland along Route 5, and another to provide inmates with -administered identification cards and license renewal before their release.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ellis introduced a bill to rename  to the President  Highway.\n\n\nEllis is married to his wife, Rosalind. Together, they have two children.\n\nEllis was inducted into the Charles County NAACP Hall of Fame in 2018.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Gloria Jean Wolberg Roesser''' (May 8, 1930 – October 2, 2017) was an American journalist and politician.\n\nRoesser was born in  She received her bachelor's degree in economics from  and took graduate courses in economics at the . Roesser worked as a reporter for the '''Suburban Record''' newspaper in . She lived in . Roesser was involved with the . She served in the  from 1987 to 1995. She then served in the  from 1995 to 2003. From 2004 to 2007, Roesser served as secretary for the . Roesser died from leukemia in a hospital in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert Alan Zirkin''' (born April 24, 1971) is an American politician who was a member of the  from the  from 2007 to 2020. A member of the , he previously represented the district in the  from 1999 to 2007.\n\n\nZirkin was born in , on April 24, 1971, to Barry and Barbara Zirkin. He grew up in  and graduated from . He later attended the  through  in 1992 and graduated from  with a  degree in political science with honors in 1993, and , where he earned his  degree in 1998. He was admitted to the  in 2000.\n\n\nZirkin says he has been involved in politics since he was in elementary school, when his parents would take him  while volunteering for local campaigns, including for the Smith-Greenspring Association. After graduating from Johns Hopkins, he served as the president of Young Democrats of Maryland from 1994 to 1995 and spoke at the .\n\nZirkin operated his own solo practice from 2008 to 2015, afterwards opening the Zirkin and Schmerling Law firm, which focuses on criminal law, family law, medical malpractice, and workers' compensation.\n\n\nZirkin was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in  and sworn in on January 13, 1999. He was a member of the Judiciary Committee during his entire tenure, including as the chair of its juvenile law subcommittee from 2003 to 2007, and was a member of the .\n\nOn July 18, 2005, Zirkin announced that he would run for the Maryland Senate in District 11, seeking to succeed , who retired to  in . He won the September 2006 Democratic primary with 71.3 percent of the vote, and defeated Republican Jeffrey Yablon in the general election.\n\nZirkin was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 10, 2007. He was a member of the Budget and Taxation Committee during his first term from 2007 to 2010, afterwards serving in the Judicial Proceedings Committee for the remainder of his tenure. Media outlets described Zirkin as a  and  who frequently clashed with progressive groups, legislators, and activists. After state senator  was elected  in , Senate President  appointed Zirkin as the chair of the Judicial Proceedings Committee.\n\n\nZirkin has a history of ingratiating himself with Republicans in the General Assembly and Governor . During his tenure in the legislature, Zirkin attended Hogan's 2017 press conference where he announced his support for Zirkin's bill to ban  in Maryland; endorsed Republicans in competitive county executive elections; and appeared at several fundraisers held by Republican members of the Judicial Proceedings committee. During an August 2018 interview with the '''', Zirkin accused , the Democratic nominee for governor in the , of attempting to politicize judicial appointments in Maryland, which he considered out of character for the state, and criticized his criminal justice platform as being unrealistic. Despite this, Zirkin did not endorse either candidate in the general election.\n\nZirkin became less focused on his legislative career after his mother died from cancer in June 2019, prompting rumors that he would resign. Zirkin resigned from the Senate effective January 1, 2020, saying that politics had become too divisive and driven by special interests and social media. He was succeeded by state delegate .\n\n\nIn December 2020, a year after his resignation, Zirkin started his own lobbying firm, Zirkin & Schmerling Government Relations. He lobbied on behalf of the Catholic Church in opposition to the , which would extend the statute of limitations for child sex abuse cases. After the bill passed during the 2023 legislative session, Zirkin was reported to be advertising services to abuse survivors.\n\nIn May 2024, former Republican Governor  announced that Zirkin would co-chair the \"Democrats for Hogan\" organization supporting his . In interviews with '''' and '''', Zirkin said that he was supporting Hogan in part because of his positions on , noting that Alsobrooks had been endorsed by U.S. senator , who has been critical of U.S. support for Israel's military amid the .\n\n\nZirkin is married to his wife Tina. Together, they have two daughters and live in . He is  and a member of the Chizuk Amuno Congregation in .\n\n\nIn April 2017, Zirkin threw the first pitch at  on .\n\n\n\nDuring the 2009 legislative session, Zirkin amended a bill partially repealing the  to require a murderer's conviction to be based on  to be eligible for the death sentence. He was considered to be the swing vote for a bill to repeal the  in Maryland in 2013, which he ultimately supported, but later said that he had no moral qualms with seeing \"horrible monsters\" being put to death.\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Zirkin opposed a bill to reform the state's bail-setting practices to use computers instead of District Court commissioners to determine who should go free pending trial, instead supporting a bill that would add an amendment to the  to overturn the ' unanimously 2017 decision that prohibits judges from setting bails that defendants are unable to pay.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Zirkin introduced an omnibus crime bill that would increase the maximum penalties for using a gun while committing a  from 20 to 40 years in prison, provide $21 million to violence prevention programs over four years, and repeal a law that allows defendants charged with or serving a sentence for a violent crime to be transferred from jail for drug treatment. Many of the bill's provisions were taken from proposals by Republican Governor , who introduced them as part of a package of bills to combat street violence and reimplement mandatory minimum sentencing. The bill was opposed by Progressive Maryland, who called it \"racially bigoted injustice\" written by white supremacists that is designed for mass incarceration of Black people and \"genocide\". In response, Zirkin spoke on the Senate floor against Progressive Maryland, calling the group's members \"lint\" and \"crazies\" and condemning the group's use of the term genocide as it evoked memories of . Zirkin's bill passed the Senate, but was rejected by the House of Delegates.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Zirkin introduced Grace's Law 2.0, which increased the state's penalties for cyber harassment from a maximum penalty of a year in jail and a $500 fine to three years in prison and a $10,000 fine. The bill was named for Grace McComas, a 15-year-old who took their own life in 2012 following online taunts and hate speech. The bill unanimously passed the General Assembly and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nZirkin repeatedly introduced bills to ban  in Maryland, including in 2017, which passed and was signed into law by Governor . During the 2015 legislative session, he introduced a bill to hold energy companies financially liable for injury, death, or loss of property caused by fracking.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Zirkin amended the Firearm Safety Act to add a provision banning patients admitted to a hospital for emergency mental health evaluations on the recommendation of a doctor from purchasing a firearm. In 2016, he supported a bill to ban guns from college campuses. In 2019, Zirkin voted for a bill to repeal Maryland's Handgun Permit Review Board.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Zirkin opposed the Trust Act, which would prohibit local authorities from cooperating with  (ICE). After the bill failed to pass that year, state delegate  criticized Zirkin as a \"\" and called on his constituents to vote against him in the Democratic primaries that year. During a Jews United for Justice meeting in July 2017, he said that he supported \"nine out of ten provisions in the bill\", but opposed the provision that would prohibit detainee fingerprints from going to ICE, which he worried would protect people on the .\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Zirkin introduced a bill that would prohibit the state from contracting with companies that support the  movement. After the bill failed to pass, Governor  signed an executive order codifying it into law.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Zirkin introduced a bill to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana and reduce fines for possession to a maximum of $100. He reintroduced the bill in 2014, during which it passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nZirkin voted against a bill that would require employers to pay sick leave during the 2017 legislative session, but voted in January 2018 to override Governor 's veto on the bill.\n\n\nIn 2006, Zirkin opposed attempts to force a vote on an amendment to the  to ban gay marriage in 2006. He was a co-sponsor of the , which legalized  in 2012, and of a 2014 bill to prohibit discrimination against  in housing, employment, and public accommodations.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Zirkin introduced a bill that would ban smoking in cars when there is a passenger younger than eight years old. The bill passed the Senate, but died in the House of Delegates.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Zirkin pushed for an amendment to weaken Alex and Calvin's Lawa bill to increase penalties for people who provide alcohol to someone younger than 21 years oldby only allowing jail time and higher fines only if the adult in question \"knew or should have known\" that an underage drinker would drive, and if the driver caused \"serious injury or death to the individual or another.\" He also sought to introduce an amendment to Noah's Lawa bill expanding the use of ignition locks on drunk drivers' vehiclesthat would allow  in civil lawsuits involving drunk drivers.\n\nIn March 2016, Zirkin supported a bill to limit when the  could use devices to record the conversations of passengers, calling it \"indiscriminate mass surveillance\" and an encroachment of people's privacy rights.\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Zirkin expressed concerns with a bill hat would allow a woman who becomes pregnant during a rape to terminate the attacker's parental rights, saying that he was troubled with the idea of a man losing his parental rights without being convicted of sexual assault. After the Senate Judicial Proceedings committee made changes to the bill following its passage in the House of Delegates, Zirkin appointed himself, bill sponsor , and  to a conference committee to negotiate the final wording of the bill. The committee appeared to reach an agreement, but could not get the bill's new text printed before the legislature adjourned sine die at midnight.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Zirkin voted for the End-of-Life Option Act, which would provide terminally ill patients with , after adding amendments to the bill to raise the age limit, require mental health assessments, and remove immunity clauses for doctors who offer the prescriptions.\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Zirkin opposed a bill to raise taxes on Marylanders that earn at least half a million dollars a year, accusing legislators of singling out a certain class.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gwendolyn T. Britt''' (November 29, 1941 – January 12, 2008) was a member of the , first elected in 2003, to represent District 47 in , USA, winning with 99.4% of the vote. Britt died suddenly in January 2008 of natural causes.\n\nHer district included the areas and towns of , Buck Lodge, , , Avondale, Ridgecrest, Carole Highlands, , North Brentwood, Colmar Manor, Cottage City, , , , , West Lanham Hills, and .\n\n\nBritt graduated from  She received her B.S. in political science from .\n\n\nBritt was a business office manager for  from 1968 to 1984. She later held jobs as a real estate agent with  Realtors from 1984 to 1988. Later, she was a human resources and personnel manager with  from 1988 to 2002. She made headlines in the 1960s when she was arrested at the  for refusing to leave. She was one of five  students who were plaintiffs in civil rights suits that were heard before the  arguing for desegregation of the .\n\nShe was also a  in the 1960s and spent 40 days in jail in . She was also a voter registration volunteer in , helping African Americans who had been denied the right to register to vote reportedly for inability to interpret the Constitution before white registrars.\n\nIn 2007, Britt co-sponsored a controversial bill, with State Delegate Justin Ross, to allow convicted released felons the right to vote, and became lead sponsor of a bill to legalize . The former bill successfully passed both the houses of the Maryland state legislature, however, she suddenly died of heart failure or stroke before the latter bill could be introduced. She was a member of the , and chairman of the Prince George's County Senate Delegation.\n\n\nBritt died on January 12, 2008, in Lanham.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*'', , January 13, 2008.''\n*'' , , January 18, 2008.''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
