    "pages": }\n'''Brooke Elizabeth Lierman''' (born February 14, 1979) is an American civil rights attorney and politician who is the 34th . She was first elected in , becoming the first female Comptroller of the state and the first woman elected to an independent state government office in Maryland. A member of the , Lierman was previously a member of the , representing  in .\n\n\n\nLierman was born in Washington, D.C., on February 14, 1979, to father Terry Lierman, who served as the chair of the  from 2004 to 2007. She graduated from  in , in 1997. Lierman attended , where she earned an  degree in history in 2001. She later attended the , where she earned a  degree and graduated cum laude in 2008. Between college and law schools, Lierman was an  member at The DREAM Program in , working with children living in public housing developments.\n\nLierman is a counsel for the Baltimore civil rights firm Brown, Goldstein, & Levy LLP, where she handles a variety of civil rights and disability rights cases. She is also a trustee of the  and on the board of Advocates for Children and Youth and the Downtown Partnership of Baltimore.\n\n\n\nLierman first got involved in politics by working on the 2002 campaign of U.S. Senator , and on the presidential campaign of  and . Prior to going to law school, Lierman worked at the  in Washington, D.C. While at law school, Lierman was President of the American Constitution Society and worked as a policy advisor to  . Lierman clerked for Judge  and Judge , both Chief Judges of the federal , from 2009 to 2010.\n\nIn July 2013, Lierman announced her candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 46. She won the Democratic primary, receiving 28.1 percent of the vote and filling the seat left by retiring Delegate .\n\n\n\nLierman was sworn in as a member of the House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. She was a member of the Appropriations Committee from 2015 to 2019, afterwards serving on the Environment and Transportation Committee until 2023. She was also a member of the Women Legislators of Maryland and a co-chair of the Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus.\n\nIn 2016, Lierman filed to run as a Delegate to the , representing . She received 14.5 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary election, coming in third in a field of nine candidates. Shortly after the election of President  in November 2016, Lierman organized Baltimore Women United, a coalition of female volunteers and activists. During the , she co-founded and co-chaired the Maryland Women for  organization.\n\nIn August 2018, Lierman organized a protest against the opening of a campaign office for  in Baltimore City, highlighting his opposition of the  and handling of the  redevelopment project.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn August 2020,  reported that Lierman had been aggressively contacting party activists and influencers about a potential run for Comptroller. On December 17, 2020, Lierman announced her candidacy for  in the 2022 election, which was being vacated by , who unsuccessfully . She received endorsements from various elected officials across the state, including U.S. Representatives  and , President of the  , Speaker of the Maryland House of Delegates , Prince George's County Executive , and former U.S. Senator .\n\nLierman defeated  mayor Tim Adams in the Democratic primary election on July 19, 2022, receiving 66.2 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary, winning with the highest margin of victory of the highly contested statewide Democratic primaries. She defeated  executive  in the general election on November 8, 2022, becoming the first woman to serve as Maryland comptroller and the first woman elected by voters to an independent state government office in Maryland.\n\n\n.]]\nLierman was sworn in on January 16, 2023.\n\nIn February 2023, Lierman released a list of legislative priorities for the 2023 legislative session, including creating a chief information officer position to promote modernizing technology in the comptroller's office, increasing transparency and access to the agency, and increasing state contracts offered to diverse businesses. During the 2023 legislative session, legislators passed bills supporting these priorities, including a bill to create a new Taxpayer Advocate Division for the comptroller.\n\nLierman was an at-large delegate to the , pledged to . During the , she canvassed for Harris in .\n\nIn October 2024, Lierman and Lieutenant Governor  presided over the , marking the first time in Maryland history in which only women presided over the meeting.\n\n\n\nIn January 2019, Lierman was one of nine Maryland lawmakers to add their names to a manifesto signed by 326 state legislators to reaffirm their commitment to protecting abortion rights.\n\nIn March 2022, Lierman spoke in support of legislation that would enshrine the right to abortion in the , recounting being raped while in college and worrying over the thought of what she might do if she became pregnant as a result.\n\n\nLierman supports increasing funding for  and .\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2017 legislative session that would ban pre-K suspensions and expulsions. The bill passed and became law on May 27, 2017.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Lierman voted in favor of a bill that would give school districts the right to decide when classes begin and end each year. The bill passed but was vetoed by Governor Hogan. Lierman voted in favor of overriding the gubernatorial veto.\n\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would allow  in city elections, as well as . She later withdrew the bill after talking with her colleagues in the Baltimore House Delegation.\n\n\nIn September 2017, Lierman was one of 10 lawmakers to receive a score of 100 percent on the Maryland ' annual legislative scorecard. She received the same score in the organization's 2019 scorecard.\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would ban all  in Maryland. The bill passed and became law without Governor Hogan's signature on May 28, 2019. The bill was slated to go into effect in July 2020, but its deadline was extended to October amid the .\n\nLierman introduced \"The Plastics and Packaging Reduction Act\", a bill that would ban the sale of s and require stores to charge a minimum of 10 cents for s, during the 2020 legislative session. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 95-37, but was placed on hold amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The bill was reintroduced in the 2021 legislative session.\n\nLierman introduced legislation during the 2022 legislative session that would require the Maryland State Retirement and Pensions System to consider  as a financial factor when making investment decisions.\n\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would allow student athletes at  to engage in .\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would give college athletes the right to profit off their names and likenesses.\n\nIn February 2022, Lierman attended a rally encouraging Maryland legislators to pass a bill that would offer  to all Marylanders. She voted in favor of the Time to Care Act, which provides up to 24 weeks of paid leave per year.\n\n\nLierman supports the legalization of  and says that regulation of the industry should fall under the Alcohol and Tobacco Commission.\n\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2018 legislative session that would make it illegal for police officers to have sex with people in custody. The bill passed and became law.\n\nLierman cosponsored legislation introduced during the 2020 legislative session that would research providing .\n\nLierman introduced legislation during the 2022 legislative session that would require strip clubs and bars on  in downtown Baltimore to close by 10 P.M. The legislation was protested by businesses owners, who said that the bill would cripple their livelihoods. The bill was modified to require business owners to record and share videos of activity on The Block, deploy off-duty police officers at peak hours, and incorporate security plans on February 18, 2022, after the group of legislators behind the bill reached a compromise with the owners of clubs on The Block.\n\nAmid the , Lierman introduced legislation that would divest Maryland's retirement and pensions systems from Russia.\n\n\nLierman supports the Baltimore Red Line and organized a protest against the opening of Larry Hogan's campaign office in Baltimore in 2018 over his position on the Red Line and State Center redevelopment project.\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would give counties the ability to prohibit the construction of s, highways, or  without the consent of a majority of the affected counties. She reintroduced this legislation in 2020. Lierman also introduced a bill that would boost funding for statewide bicycle infrastructure. The bill passed but was vetoed by Governor Hogan on May 24, 2019.\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would increase funding for bus and subway maintenance. The bill passed the Maryland House of Delegates by a vote of 95–36.\n\nLierman introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would increase funding for the state's bus and rail budget by $757 million. The bill passed but was vetoed by Governor Hogan on May 28, 2021. The  voted to override the gubernatorial veto during its special legislative session in December 2021.\n\n\nLierman is married to Eben Hansel, a real estate attorney who she had met while they were both students at Dartmouth College. The couple married on September 19, 2009. Together, they have two children and live in . She is .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Nicholas James Mosby''' (born 1978) is an American politician from , .  He is the current president of the . First elected to serve on the city council from 2011 to 2016, Mosby was subsequently appointed in 2017 to the , representing Baltimore City's 40th District. He was elected as Baltimore City Council president in November 2020, assuming the role in December of that year. Mosby ran for a second term in 2024, but was defeated in the Democratic primary by city councilmember .\n\n\nMosby was born in the  neighborhood of Baltimore. He attended  where he participated in debate team and served as the student council president. According to classmates, Mosby aspired to be mayor while still in high school.\n\nMosby then attended , where he received his  in  in 2001. Mosby was inducted as a member of  fraternity within the Pi Omega chapter in Baltimore. Mosby then worked as a network engineer and project manager with . Prior to his political career, Mosby served as a Senior Project Manager with .\n\n\n\n and City Councilor ]]\n\nMosby's first attempt for office was as one of seven competitors in the 2007 Democratic primary for the open seat in Baltimore's District 11 City Council seat, vacated by  In this race, competitor  received the endorsement of '''', Maryland Governor  and Congressman , and Mosby went on to place 4th in the election with 10.45% of the vote.\n\nIn 2011, Mosby ran again for city council, this time for the city's 7th district seat (his home neighborhood of  having since been transferred to that district).  The district's incumbent, , was facing scrutiny for allegations including that her primary residence was outside the city, in violation of city law. Mosby cited this negative media coverage, and Conaway's $21 million libel suit against a blogger as an impetus for him to run against her.\n\nIn the intervening years, Mosby had served as a member of the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee from 2008-2010. Indeed, despite being the challenger, the '''' described the \"politically-connected\" Mosby as the establishment-backed candidate in the race, citing endorsements of him by Governor (and former Baltimore mayor) O'Malley, prominent union groups, the editors of ''The Baltimore Sun'', and the sitting Mayor .\n\nMosby ultimately defeated Conaway and the other challengers in the Democratic primary with a 51% share of the vote. His defeat of the incumbent Conaway was characterized as an \"upset\" in city media.\n\nDespite losing the primary nomination, Conaway launched a write-in campaign for the general election later that year. In a formal complaint to Maryland  , Conaway alleged illegal conduct on the part of Mosby's campaign in the primary relating to the use of the  logo on a mailer and allegations that she had lied on her tax returns, but Mosby's campaign denied any wrongdoing. In November, Conaway further alleged \"major fraud\" in absentee ballots sent for the wrong council district, writing a formal appeal to  , although local officials stated they had received no complaints about the process.\n\nIn spite of the write-in challenge, Mosby still won \"decisively\" in the general election, winning 76.13% of the vote.\n\n\nIn his first year as councilmember, Mosby initially emerged as one of several council allies of Mayor Rawlings-Blake, helping that summer to approve her budget cut proposal, against the amendments of Council President . Mosby voted against a proposal to amend the city charter to require biannual audits of city agencies, a stance which also aligned with the Rawlings-Blake administration. Instead, later that year Mosby put forward a separate bill, proposing a city wide commission \"to provide input on city audits and how they are conducted,\" whose members would all be appointed by the mayor. The city's auditor opposed the move, saying the mayoral appointments would \"jeopardize [their] independence.\"\n\n\nIn the summer of 2012, Mosby questioned Mayor Rawlings-Blake's appointment of , a city outsider, to head the , although he ultimately deferred to her judgment in approving his appointment.\n\nIn July 2013, when 20 city s were shut down as part of Mayor Rawlings-Blake's budget, Mosby spoke in favor of their continued operation under  administration, including one in  re-opened by his fraternity, Omega Psi Phi.\n\nIn 2014, Mosby started the \"Get Fit with Councilman Mosby\" Challenge, partnering with close to 30 s, fitness organizations and chefs, the American Heart Association and  to provide free access to fitness and cooking classes. Mosby called for hearings on the effects of s on children, and proposed legislation that to require warning labels on all advertisements for sugary drinks.\n\nWith the aim to support the , Mosby supported unsuccessful 2014 legislation that sought to reduce littering by imposing a fee on disposable plastic bags used in stores.\n\nIn September 2014, following the contentious appointment of a replacement for another seat on the council (that of  to the 11th district), Mosby supported a special election to replace any further empty seats.\n\nMosby opposed proposed 2015 state budget cuts to the , arguing the cuts would be \"devastating.\"\n\nIn 2016, Mosby was the sole \"No\" vote to limit the influence of the mayor on the city's powerful .\n\nIn August 2016, Mosby voted to raise the city's  to $15, though the bill failed to pass the full city council.\n\n\nIn 2013, Mosby, along with fellow councilmember Carl Stokes, initially opposed the $107 million  deal proposed by the Rawlings-Blake administration meant as incentive for the construction of 's regional headquarters in the Harbor Point section of the city. However, in September, Mosby ultimately voted for the measure.\n\nIn February 2014, Mosby supported Mayor Rawlings-Blakes' proposal for expansion of tax breaks for developers of apartment projects within the city.\n\nWhile praising support for new housing construction across his district and the city, Mosby recognized that investment in jobs and schools would be necessary in addition to development. He criticized Baltimore's affordable housing law as too weak, and sought to place more responsibility on developers to set aside units for low-income renters.\n\n]]\nAs Baltimore overhauled its zoning regulations for the first time in decades, Mosby proposed \"more stringent\" requirements on liquor stores within residential neighborhoods, including a Public Nuisance Prevention Board that would have allowed community members to provide input on when to limit certain kinds of alcohol sales. Mosby criticized his fellow council members, who stripped his proposed amendment by an 11 to 3 vote, as \"cocky\" and \"arrogant.\"\n\n\nIn 2013, Mosby sponsored  legislation, which passed the city council the next year over the opposition of business groups like the Maryland Chamber of Commerce and the . The bill, which Mosby characterized the act as the \"most progressive\" iteration in the country, expanded the city's existing prohibition on asking about criminal history on public job applications to private employers as well.\n\nBaltimore's business community proposed replacing the prohibition with voluntary commitments like \"a pledge to hire a certain number of ex-offenders each year\" During the spring of 2014, Mosby attempted to reach an agreement with the GBC and business interests, but reported that they were unable to come to a consensus, and so the legislation continued. In an attempt to assuage business critics, Mosby drafted an amendment to exclude job postings where a criminal record would be automatically disqualifying. In multiple editorials, the editors of ''The Baltimore Sun'' urged Mosby to accept the GBC's further proposed changes to the law, claiming it would improve Baltimore's perception as \"business-friendly.\"\n\nDespite the opposition, the city council passed the bill 10 to 4 at its April 29 meeting. The final passed legislation applied to private employers with 10 or more employees, where a criminal history would not otherwise bar the candidate (such as in child care). In passing the legislation, Baltimore joined 10 states and about 60 local governments nationwide with similar legislation. Mayor Rawlings-Blake signed the bill into law at the end of May.\n\n\nIn 2012, Mosby proposed a city law, subsequently passed, banning the sale of items to minors by stores where more than 20% of sales were for alcohol. Mosby proposed further restrictions on liquor stores in 2016, requiring that they not \"adversely affect, jeopardize or endanger public health,\" but was unable to gain majority support on the council, who voted to remove his amendment from the final zoning package. Mosby also lobbied to shut down operators of illegal after-hours clubs in his district, which he cited as a source of violence.\n\nIn the hopes of diverting young men from work in the drug trade, Mosby encouraged  projects within his district as an alternative way of making a living. He wrote in support of neighborhood farm activists in their fight to keep plots from being sold by the city for redevelopment. Mosby also worked with local activists in opposition to anti-LGBT violence.\n\nIn August 2013, Mosby worked with fellow councilmember  to close a  in the  neighborhood, following complaints from local merchants about associated crime. The two councilmembers supported increasing police foot patrols in the neighborhood.\n\nFollowing the 2013 , Mosby proposed a non-binding resolution calling on the city of Baltimore to boycott Florida-based businesses in protest.\n\nIn 2013, Mosby's wife, Marilyn, launched her campaign for Baltimore's State Attorney. The two made the city's increasing homicide rate a central part of their program. Beginning in April, the couple organized weekly \"Enough is Enough\" marches, working with police and community groups to reduce crime and violence in West Baltimore. Mosby noted the impact of increased police on suppressing crime in his district in June of that year. ''The Baltimore Sun'' reported Mosby as supporting a \"criminal justice system that is tough on violent offenders and keeps them off the street.\" Following the  in July of that year, Mosby criticized the State's Attorney's level of transparency and communication regarding the investigation.\n\nIn January 2014, Mosby worked with fellow councilman  and community activists to call for greater citizen intervention against rising homicides in the city, in particular a proposal for a \"mobilized street force\" of city residents to patrol the  and  neighborhoods. Mosby and Scott also collaborated in proposing a comprehensive security review of city buildings following a January 2015 security breach at a police station.\n\nIn February 2015, Mosby was a supporter of requiring  for police officers \"as quickly as possible\".\n\n\nDuring the  following the , Mosby's council district included Gray's residence in the  project. Mosby received national coverage for his visible presence during the unrest, and for his calling attention to the roots of the violence. Mosby argued that fundamentally \"folks in West Baltimore [...] don't feel they are part of the process.\" He drew both praise and criticism for his willingness, along with others on the city council, to work with community members including members of gangs in order to bring an end to the unrest.\n\nMosby agreed that the unrest was \"unproductive\" but also the result of decades old of lack of investment and socio-economic decline. Mosby also criticized the 's early handling of the unrest as \"incendiary,\" \"not factual\" and \"problematic at best.\"\n\nFollowing the violence, Mosby advocated for the city to expand its \"Safe Streets\" anti-violence program to the Sandtown-Winchester neighborhood. He also praised Mayor Rawlings-Blake's decision to fire police commissioner , saying he hoped it would allow for a \"reset\" of community-police relations.\n\n\nSeveral months after the Freddie Gray unrest, Mosby was reported among those considering a run for . City residents began receiving phone calls polling their potential support for a run in August. Mosby published an op-ed in the ''Sun'' calling for \"political will\" to use data analysis, like the CitiStat program, to modernize the administration of the city. Finally, on October 26, Mosby formally announced his candidacy.\n\nWhen he announced his bid for the mayoral election, Mosby decided to forego a bid for re-election to his seat on the city council.\n\nMosby proposed reforming Baltimore City's Civilian Review Board to include elected seats. Similarly, he (along with several other candidates) proposed the city transition to a partially-elected school board. Recognizing the limits on the city's ability to reform city schools legislatively (as the system is controlled in part by the state of Maryland directly), Mosby promised to provide extra-legislative support for the system, such as increasing use of  members to find recent college graduates to teach in city schools.\n\nAs a candidate, Mosby called for the creation of a city task force \"to help provide free expungements of criminal records, pay fees for Baltimore residents to seek GEDs, cover the cost of vocational training at Baltimore City Community College in certain high-demand job sectors, subsidize apprenticeship programs and refund the income taxes for unemployed ex-offenders to the business that hire them.\" During his candidacy, Mosby opposed granting tax breaks to the operators of the , citing the potential loss of millions in tax revenue without prior study. He also called for the city to sue lead paint manufacturers, and to use the proceeds to remove lead from houses in the city. He also claimed he would eliminate the city's  on  lawsuit settlements. Mosby proposed cutting the city's property taxes and introducing a separate fee for trash pickup.\n\nAlong with most of the candidates, Mosby supported the city's tax increment-financed support of the  redevelopment proposed by  CEO .\n\nIn the televised Democratic Primary debates, opponents implied Mosby would have a potential conflict of interest if elected mayor, as his wife remained the city's state's attorney. Respondents to a non-scientific poll in ''The Baltimore Sun'' said 57% to 41% that they did think it would pose a conflict of interest. In its editorial, the ''Sun'' rejected the idea, arguing Mosby \"deserve[d] the chance to make his case.\" In November 2015, 58% of poll respondents said his marriage would not impact their vote one way or the other (38% said it made them less likely to support him).\n\nIn a November poll, Mosby registered 10% support among likely primary voters. In January, he was reported to have 7% support among primary voters. By mid-March, Mosby was reported to have 6% support. Polling in April showed his support at 4%.\n\nMosby dropped out of the race the week before the primary, though his name remained on the ballot. In dropping out, Mosby endorsed one of the two frontrunners, Catherine E. Pugh, which fueled speculation that he may have been seeking a position with a future Pugh administration, speculation which Mosby denied. Upon Pugh's victory in the primary later in April, speculation then focused on whether Mosby would seek to replace Pugh in the 's 40th district. Mosby ultimately applied for the seat, but the district's central committee selected Delegate  instead.\n\n\nIn January 2017, Mosby applied to the Democratic Central Committee of Maryland's 40th district to replace the outgoing Robinson in her seat in . Mosby was selected after the committee's original choice, Pugh aide Gary Brown Jr., was indicted for campaign finance violations. On taking office, Mosby cited lead abatement, property values and school performance as legislative focuses for him.\n\nThree months after his appointment, Mosby made an unsuccessful attempt to become the head of Baltimore's delegation to the House of Delegates.\n\n\nIn March 2017, Mosby sponsored legislation to assist people affected by .\n\nIn January 2018, Mosby supported plans to demolish and redevelop the Gilmor Homes project in his former city council district.\n\nIn March 2018, Mosby put forward legislation to use state funds to research the effect of Maryland's gun laws.\n\nMosby was a 2019 co-sponsor of legislation to allow lawsuits to be filed in Baltimore courts against manufacturers of lead paint The legislation failed to pass during the 2019 session.\n\nIn January 2019, Mosby joined State Senator Mary Washington to introduce bills prohibiting Baltimore city from placing liens on homes and churches due to unpaid water bills.\n\nWhile serving on the House's  task force in 2019, Mosby suggested eliminating caps on the number of licensed producers in the state in order to avoid excluding racial minority owners from participating in the growing market.\n\nMosby was lead sponsor of a statewide \"Ban the Box\" bill, which was passed but vetoed by Maryland Governor \n\nIn March 2020, Mosby was the lead sponsor of several among a package of ethics, anti-corruption and campaign finance bills that passed the House of Delegates.\n\nMosby supported reforms to Maryland's  system in March 2020, which required courts to consider parent's extenuating circumstances and actual income before assigning the amount of support to be paid, calling them \"definitely incremental steps in the right direction,\" and called for a commission to look into the situation further.\n\nA graduate and supporter of , Mosby sponsored an unsuccessful 2018 House bill to increase Maryland HBCUs funding to compensate for historical losses due to unfair treatment by the state. In May 2019, another Mosby-sponsored bill was successfully signed into law, this one providing up to $240,000 in annual tax credits to historically-black Maryland colleges and universities.\n\nMosby was a critic of proposals in 2019 to move the  from Northwest Baltimore's  to  in neighboring .\n\n\nAs a delegate, Mosby was involved in several bills involving criminal justice and policing. Mosby criticized Governor Larry Hogan's removal of judicial discretion in applying mandatory minimum sentencing laws, arguing they have \"never been an effective way of reducing violence.\" In 2020, he sponsored a bill allowing parole without governor approval for inmates who had served more than 30 years.\n\nIn 2019, Mosby voted against allowing school police to be armed. He was also skeptical of the  proposal for a private police force and voted against the legislation authorizing it. Mosby supported moving Baltimore's police academy at .\n\n\nLate in the summer of 2019, Mosby was reported to be considering a second run for mayor of Baltimore. By October 2019, it was instead reported that Mosby was considering a run for the Presidency of the Baltimore City Council. Mosby announced his candidacy in December.\n\nMosby entered into what ''The Baltimore Sun'' called \"the first competitive race for the position in nearly a decade.\" Mosby was considered an early frontrunner in the race, with a February poll showing him receiving 26% of support, with his closest competitor, former council member Carl Stokes, receiving 10% support.\n\nHe received the endorsement of Mayor Jack Young in March. In May, Mosby received the endorsement of ''The Baltimore Sun'' in the Democratic primary election. In the primary, held June 2, Mosby was the victor, winning with 40.2% of the vote.\n\nPrior to the general election, Mosby received the endorsement of the  on November 2. He easily won election in November, defeating his Republican opponent with 79.5% of the vote.\n\nIn March 2021, ''The Baltimore Sun'' reported that federal prosecutors had opened a criminal investigation into Mosby and his wife, State’s Attorney Marilyn Mosby, subpoenaing her campaign and the couple’s business records.\n\nMosby ran for a second term in 2024, but was defeated in the Democratic primary by city councilmember .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2005, Mosby married  (née James), who subsequently became the  of . The two are often referred to as a \"power couple\" in Maryland politics. Shortly after his wife's election, Mosby stated he would recuse himself from any prosecutor-related matters in the city council, following speculation that the two might influence each other's actions in office.\n\nOn July 21, 2023, the Mosbys filed for divorce.\n\n\nIn October 2020, a $45,000 tax lien was filed against the property of Nick Mosby and his wife, Baltimore State's Attorney Marilyn Mosby, for three years of unpaid federal taxes (2014, 2015, and 2016). Nick Mosby stated that he has been \"in ongoing conversations with the IRS\" about resolving this issue. That same month, it was reported that Mosby's consulting company, Monumental Squared LLC, was listed as sharing its address with a developer who was also a major campaign donor to Mosby. Later in October, Mosby received scrutiny over his joint ownership of a rental property that was reported to be unregistered with the city, and not listed as lead-certified. Mosby's co-signator on the mortgage argued that Mosby had no direct involvement in the renting of the home, nor in evictions from it.\n\nMosby stated the debt was a result of an early withdrawal from his retirement savings that he used to cover \"family tragedies.\" Mosby subsequently reported the tax lien was paid off in full.\n\nDuring Marilyn Mosby's federal trial for mortgage fraud, Mosby testified that he lied to the public about the status of his taxes. Mosby later stated he regretted lying to voters.\n\n\nMosby is a lifelong .\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Mary Lynn Washington''' (born May 20, 1962) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  from  since 2019. She previously represented the district in the  from 2011 to 2019.\n\n\nWashington was born as the oldest of six children and raised in , where she graduated from the . She later attended , where she earned a  degree in human services in 1989. Washington moved to  in 1992 to attend , where she earned  and  degrees in sociology and submitted a  on the ' influence on national identity.\n\n\nWashington worked as an assistant professor at  from 1995 to 2002, afterwards working as a research fellow for the . From 2002 to 2005, she became the director of the Baltimore Housing Authority's HousingStat office.\n\nWashington first got involved in politics in 2006, when she unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 43. She ran again in 2010, in which she won the Democratic primary, placing third with 25.1 percent of the vote, and ran unopposed in the general election.\n\n\n\nWashington was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 12, 2011. Upon her swearing in, she became the first openly lesbian African-American elected official in the state.\n\nOn September 7, 2017, Washington announced her candidacy for the Maryland Senate in District 43 in , challenging incumbent state senator . She defeated Conway in the Democratic primary in an upset on June 26, 2018, by a margin of 492 votes, and ran unopposed in the general election.\n\n\n\n* Appropriations Committee, 2011–2015 (transportation & the environment subcommittee, 2011–2012; oversight committee on personnel, 2011–2015; education & economic development subcommittee, 2013–2015)\n* Ways and Means Committee, 2015–2019 (education subcommittee, 2015–2019; finance resources subcommittee, 2015–2017; revenues subcommittee, 2015–2019; election law subcommittee, 2017–2019)\n* Regional Revitalization Work Group, 2013–2019\n* Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 2015–2019\n* Tax Credit Evaluation Committee, 2015–2019\n* House Co-chair, Joint Committee on Ending Homelessness, 2015–2019\n* Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2017–2019\n\n\n\nWashington was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. Upon her swearing in, she became the first openly gay African-American person and the first openly gay woman to serve in the state. She ran for re-election unopposed in .\n\n\n\n* Education, Energy and the Environment Committee, 2023–present\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2023–present\n* Joint Committee on the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area, 2020–present\n* Senate Vaccine Oversight Work Group, 2021–present\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 2019–2022\n* Senate Co-chair, Joint Committee on Ending Homelessness, 2019–2022\n* Judicial Proceedings Committee, 2019\n* Co-chair, Work Group to Study Shelter and Supportive Services for Unaccompanied Homeless Minors, 2019–2020\n* Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee, 2020–2022 (education subcommittee, 2020–2022; alcohol subcommittee, 2021–2022)\n\n\n\nOn November 19, 2019, Washington announced her candidacy for  in , challenging incumbent mayor . She entered the race at a financial disadvantage, but quickly rose money during the election campaign, reporting $155,000 cash on hand by January 2020, the fourth most of any candidate. During the primary, Washington received endorsements from the  Local 500, , Baltimore Women United, and  Baltimore.\n\nOn March 16, 2020, Washington suspended her campaign for mayor, citing the . She initially declined to endorse another candidate in the race, but later endorsed Democratic nominee  shortly before the general election. Had she won the Democratic primary and general election, she would have become the city's first openly LGBTQ person to serve as mayor of Baltimore.\n\nIn September 2020, Baltimore Comptroller-elect Bill Henry announced that Washington would co-chair his transition team.\n\n\nWashington has been described as a , including by herself.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Washington introduced legislation to make it illegal to  incarcerated women while they are in labor or recovering from giving birth. The unanimously passed the Maryland General Assembly and was signed into law by Governor . In March 2019, she was the lone senator to vote against a bill to allow for \"enhanced penalties\" when a person kills a pregnant woman.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Washington said she \"strongly and unconditionally opposed\" legislation that would allow Johns Hopkins University to have its own private police force. She was one of two state senators to vote against the bill.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Washington introduced bills to require Maryland to operate a standalone prerelease center for women that would provide \"trauma informed prerelease services\". During her mayoral campaign, she said she supported establishing local control of the .\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Washington supported legislation that would eliminate  in prekindergarten and kindergarten. She added that while she did not oppose standardized testing, she did not consider assessments to be the best way to improve instruction for students at these age groups.\n\nIn March 2018, Washington said she opposed a bill placing a referendum on the 2018 ballot to legalize  at casinos and racetracks to fund education, calling the expansion of gambling a \"tax on the poor\".\n\nIn July 2019, Washington co-signed a letter to the  calling for topics on the  and s to be added to social studies curricula.\n\nDuring her 2020 mayoral campaign, Washington said she supported the  and criticized the city's police spending, adding that she would fully fund the city's \"community schools approach\". In March 2020, she voted against amendments to the Blueprint bill that would create a \"checkpoint\" to test the success of the reforms by 2026, and proposed an amendment that would require school systems to increase salaries for non-teacher school employees by $3 an hour.\n\nIn December 2022, administrators of Maryland's  discovered a calculation error affecting all 31,000 prepaid accounts, which led to the Maryland Prepaid College Trust suspending interest payments and preventing families from accessing their prepaid plans. Following this, Washington sent a letter to Maryland Attorney General  asking him to investigate the 529 agency.\n\n\nIn February 2018, Washington said she supported banning  in Maryland.\n\nIn March 2023, after it was announced that the Back River Wastewater Treatment Plant would treat 675,000 gallons of wastewater from the , Washington introduced legislation to block the plant from processing any wastewater.\n\n\nIn March 2015, Washington voted against legislation to allow s in Baltimore to carry guns inside of schools. In October 2016, she said she supported bills to restrict high-caliber guns, citing their use in violent crimes in Baltimore.\n\n\nIn May 2020, Washington said she supported a  in eviction cases.\n\nIn February 2023, Washington denounced Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott's approval of the  conduit deal, calling it a \"disdain for Baltimore City voters\" and an \"abuse of power\".\n\nIn June 2023, Washington said she opposed plans to install a  at a funeral home in the  of Baltimore, citing its environmental impacts to its surrounding community.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Washington introduced legislation that would legalize and tax .\n\n\nWashington served as a convention delegate to the  in 2012, pledged to President , and 2020, pledged to former Vice President . She supported Biden's selection of U.S. Senator  as his vice president. In November 2020, following the , Washington signed 's Count Every Vote petition objecting against Republican efforts to invalidate 2.5 million  in  be counted.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Washington supported the , which legalized . She opposed , a 2012 referendum that sought to repeal the Civil Marriage Protection Act. During the 2019 legislative session, Washington introduced legislation that would allow the  to issue gender-neutral driver's licenses. In 2023, she introduced the Trans Health Equity Act, a bill that would require the state's  program to cover , which passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Washington introduced legislation to establish a task force to develop recommendations on how to address  in Maryland, which passed and became law. She introduced legislation in 2014 to adopt the task force's recommendations and create the Maryland Homeless Youth Count Demonstration Project, which also passed and became law. During the 2021 legislative session, she introduced a bill that would make homeless youth eligible for tuition waivers, which passed and was signed into law by Governor  in May 2021.\n\nIn March 2018, Washington was one of three female members of the Maryland General Assembly to refuse to sign onto a letter pushing back against a report on sexual harassment in the legislature, calling it an attempt by legislative leaders to \"control the narrative\" on the topic of harassment in the State House. In June 2018, after '''' published a story revealing that state delegate  was under investigation for allegations of , she sent a letter to leaders of the Maryland General Assembly questioning the pace of the investigation and calling for the release of an interim report. After Anderson was removed from leadership positions in August 2018, Washington said that his punishment was \"too little and too late\" and pushed for a resolution to allow Anderson to withdraw from the general election.\n\nDuring her 2020 mayoral campaign, Washington said she would not support appointing a city manager, saying it should be the role of the mayor to run the city.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Washington introduced a bill that would remove all  products from the market.\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Washington introduced legislation to provide $2,500-a-year tax credits for s who buy homes in Baltimore.\n\nIn June 2017, Washington supported calls to place a moratorium on tax sales of homes with unpaid water bills, adding that the city should investigate all tax sales over the past three years into whether any properties were sold over questionable bills. During the 2019 legislative session, she introduced legislation that would ban Baltimore from placing liens against properties over unpaid water bills. The bill unanimously passed the Maryland General Assembly.\n\nDuring her 2020 mayoral campaign, Washington said she supported investing into small and minority-owned businesses and cutting the city's property tax.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Washington introduced legislation that would exempt diabetic care products from the state sales tax. The bill passed unanimously and was signed into law by Governor  on April 1, 2022.\n\n\n\nWashington is openly lesbian, having come out to her family while she was in high school. She is married to her wife, Jodi Kelber-Kaye, whom she met during her unsuccessful campaign for state delegate in 2006 and began dating in February 2008. Together, they live in the  of Baltimore.\n\nWashington was raised as a , but is now a  and a member of the First and Franklin Presbyterian Church.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Shaneka Tarae Johnson''' (née '''Henson'''; born July 29, 1983) is an American politician and attorney who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2019. A member of the , she previously served as an alderwoman on the  from 2017 to 2019.\n\n\nShaneka Tarae Henson was born in , on July 29, 1983. Her mother, Terry, and her father were both pastors at the New Life Presbyterian Church in Annapolis for fifteen years. Henson graduated from  with a Bachelor of Science degree, and the  with a Juris Doctor degree. Henson was admitted to the  in 2010, after which she worked as a practicing attorney for the Anne Arundel County State's Attorney's office and the . In 2020, she started her own law firm, Johnson Legal Group LLC.\n\nIn 2016, Henson graduated from a training course hosted by Emerge Maryland, an organization created to prepare potential female Democratic candidates for public office.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2016, Henson filed to run for the Annapolis City Council in ward 6, challenging incumbent Alderman Kenny Kirby, who later announced his retirement. In the Democratic primary, she faced challenger DaJuan Gay, whom she defeated with 67.8 percent of the vote. Henson ran unopposed in the general election, and was sworn in on December 4, 2017.\n\nIn October 2018, Annapolis mayor  named Henson to serve as acting mayor for two weeks.\n\nHenson resigned from the city council on April 29, 2019, after the Anne Arundel County Democratic Central Committee nominated her to the Maryland House of Delegates. She was succeeded by DaJuan Gay following a  to fill her seat.\n\n\nIn April 2019, following the death of House Speaker , Henson applied to serve the remainder of his term in the Maryland House of Delegates. The Anne Arundel County Democratic Central Committee voted 11-1 to nominate her to fill the vacancy. Governor  appointed her to the seat on May 6, and she was sworn in on May 16. She is the first African-American woman to represent Annapolis in the . Henson was elected to a full four-year term in .\n\nHenson served on the Appropriations Committee from 2019 to 2023, after which she was switched to the Ways and Means Committee after questions were raised about a potential conflict of interest involving Henson's legal work for a nonprofit which received state funding. In April 2024, the Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics released a five-page letter condemning Henson's \"ongoing practice\" to hide her conflicts of interest, recommending to legislative leaders that she not be reassigned to the House Appropriations Committee and calling on her to apologize to the public. Henson released a statement on her website in response to the report that scolded members of the panel for failing to strike a more \"collaborative and constructive tone\" and contradicted some of the ethics panel's findings.\n\n\nHenson is married to her husband, Marcus Johnson. Together, they have a son. She is a .\n\nIn May 2016, Henson settled a $1,889 state tax lien that had been placed against her.\n\n\n\nHenson supports a \"holistic approach\" toward addressing crime, which includes addressing socioeconomic issues and tackling issues \"from the law enforcement perspective\".\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Henson introduced legislation to freeze child support orders of parents serving a prison sentence of six months or longer. The bill passed and became law. She introduced another bill to ease restrictions on when prosecutors could use  in witness intimidation cases.\n\n\nHenson supports the .\n\n\nIn July 2020, Henson criticized Governor  requiring voters to apply for a  if they did not want to vote in-person for the , saying that he had \"stepped on people's voting rights\". During the 2021 legislative session, she introduced legislation to ban guns at polling places and supported a bill requiring the automatic mailing of ballots to all registered voters.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Henson introduced bills to establish statewide  standards, which did not receive a vote, and another to close a loophole that allowed Annapolis to avoid responsibility for inspecting its public housing units, which was signed into law by Governor . In 2021, she introduced legislation to shield a tenant's eviction records from public view if they won an eviction case.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Henson supported the CROWN Act, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of hair style and texture.\n\nHenson participated in  in Annapolis, , and . In July 2020, she spoke in support of federal legislation to recognize  as a public health trauma and to make , rental assistance, and  available to African Americans regardless of age or disability. Later that month, Henson signed onto a letter calling on regional news organizations to increase employee diversity.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Henson supported a bill to make  a state holiday.\n\nIn October 2021, Henson participated in and spoke at a protest in Annapolis to endorse legislation expansion to expand abortion rights in Maryland.\n\n\nIn February 2021, Henson was the only member of the  to vote against a bill providing tax credits to businesses impacted by the .\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Henson introduced a bill to add critical medical devices, including thermometers, s, and s, to the state's sales tax exemptions, which passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Gail Bates''' (born December 24, 1945) was a member of the Maryland Senate from 2015 to 2019 and a member of the  from 2002 to 2015. She was selected to replace  in the Maryland House of Delegates in February 2002 when Kittleman was selected to replace Chris McCabe in the . In a close election in 2018, Bates was defeated by non-profit executive  by 1.7 percentage points. Bates was nominated to serve on the state Board of Education by Gov.  in February 2019.\n\n\nBates graduated from the  in 1968 with a B.S. in Education.  She later took courses at .\n\n\nBates was a mathematics and home economics teacher in Anne Arundel County from 1968 to 1973. She then served as an office manager for  from 1976 to 1980. In 1980, she held a position as a tax supervisor for Mark Buckley, C.P.A.  From 1983 to 1984 she was a manager for the Records and Tax Department of the Maryland Farm Bureau. Since 1984, she has been a sole proprietor as a .  She served as an assistant to the Howard County Executive from 1991 to 1998 and was Chief of Staff for Delegate Donald E. Murphy in District 12A from 1999 until 2002.\n\nBates has been an active member of different organizations such as the Howard County Republican Club, the Maryland Federation of Republican Women, the Howard County Republican Central Committee (serving as Treasurer from 1980 until 1984), the Howard County Chamber of Commerce, the Maryland Association of Certified Public Accountants, and Howard County Republican Women, serving as president since 2001.\n\nAs a member of the , Bates served on the Appropriations Committee, the Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, and the Special Joint Committee on Pensions.\n\nShe was a board member of the Howard County Chapter of the  from 1996 until 1999.  She has served with the Christian Jail Ministry since 1997 and the Howard County Farm Bureau since 1998. She has been the Treasurer of the Howard County Tourism Council since 2004.  She is a member of the Therapeutic Horsemanship Association and received the Life Achievement Award from the Howard County Republican Central Committee in 1990.\n\nIn 2007, Bates sponsored a bill that would have defined marriage as between one man and one woman in the state of Maryland, barring  in the state. The bill was voted down in the Judiciary Committee.\n\n\n*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n*voted against the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n\n\nIn the 2002 election, Bates defeated Democrats Walter E.     "pages": }\n'''Todd B. Morgan''' (born January 1, 1956) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for  in . He was previously a member of the St. Mary's County Board of Commissioners from 2010 to 2022 and served as its vice president in 2014.\n\n\nMorgan graduated from  in  with a . He later attended  in , where he earned his  degree. Morgan moved to St. Mary's County in 1979 following graduation.\n\nMorgan began his career by working at federal  contractor  in finance and acquisitions. He also previously taught classes for 20 years at various local colleges, including , , and the , and as an  at . From 2004 to 2010, he was the president of the Southern Maryland Navy Alliance.\n\nIn 2010, Morgan was elected to the St. Mary's County Board of Commissioners, and was re-elected in 2014 and 2018. He served as the board's vice president in 2014.\n\nIn August 2016, Morgan applied to fill a vacancy in the Maryland House of Delegates left by the appointment of state delegate  to the . The St. Mary's County Republican Central Committee included Morgan on its list of three potential nominees, but Governor  appointed former  commissioner  to the seat in September.\n\nIn February 2022, Morgan filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 29C, seeking to succeed retiring state delegate Jerry Clark. He defeated Maryland Adjutant General Timothy Gowen in the Republican primary on July 19, receiving 64.8 percent of the vote.\n\nMorgan endorsed former Maryland Secretary of Commerce  for governor in .\n\n\nMorgan was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\n\nMorgan has three children. His wife, Maria, died in November 2012 following a long battle with injuries sustained in a traffic accident in July 2011.\n\n\nMorgan self-identifies as a .\n\n\nMorgan opposed a bill introduced by state delegate  that would require elections for county commissioners to only be decided by voters within the districts in which the candidate is running rather than at-large, voting in 2021 to ask the  for a referendum on the bill and for another another referendum on eliminating districts altogether.\n\n\nIn May 2020, Morgan voted to designate St. Mary's County as a  sanctuary area.\n\n\nIn March 2022, Morgan introduced a resolution that called on the St. Mary's County planning commission to amend the  to allow review of future  facilities in the county. The resolution was unanimously approved by the Board of Commissioners. In August, he voted for an ordinance that would restrict medical marijuana growing and processing operations to certain zoning areas.\n\n\nIn June 2019, Morgan described a  event held at the St. Mary's County Library as \"going after and targeting the kids for sexuality\".\n\n\nIn November 2022, Morgan said he supported reductions in or eliminating the . Elmore was also the chairman of the .\n\n\nBorn in 1939 in , Elmore attended the . He was on the House Ways and Means Committee and its revenue subcommittee. He was also the 2005 chair of the Maryland Rural Caucus.\n\n\nAfter initially filing to run for reelection, Elmore withdrew from the race in late June 2010 while spending several days in the hospital receiving treatment for a cracked vertebra he suffered the previous winter.\n\nElmore died on June 26, 2010, following a brief bout of cancer.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 38A'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 38A'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Johnny Ray Salling''' (born October 31, 1961) is an American politician from  from the . He is currently serving as a Maryland State Senator representing District 6, which covers southeast , including ,  and .\n\n\nSalling was born in Baltimore, Maryland on October 31, 1961, where he graduated from . In 1979, he joined the , serving as a combat engineer until 1981. Upon his return to the , he worked as a steel worker for  at the  in  for more than 30 years, where he gained experience as a  for the  union.\n\nIn September 2013, Salling filed to run for , seeking to succeed Democratic state senator , who had announced his retirement from the . He says that the closing of the Sparrows Point mill in 2012 moved him to run for public office. Stone endorsed his challenger, state delegate , during the general election. Salling defeated Olszewski in the general election, garnering 47.9 percent of the vote compared to Olszewski's 44.7 percent.\n\n\n\nSalling was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 14, 2015. He was a member of the Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Committee from 2015 to 2019, afterwards serving as a member of the Budget and Taxation Committee. In April 2017, Salling joined the Reform on Tap task force, which was led by   and sought to reform the state's regulations on the production and distribution of beer in the state.\n\nIn July 2019, Salling responded to a  about a request for an ethics investigation into   with \"Get rid of this illegal know!!!!!\" The  called on Salling to apologize for the tweet or to resign. He deleted the tweet after speaking to '''', denying having made the tweet and suggesting that he may have been hacked.\n\n\n\n\nIn August 2019, Salling announced his candidacy for  in the , seeking to take on incumbent Democrat . He did not have to give up his state senate seat to run for Congress, as he was not up for reelection until 2022. Salling narrowly won the Republican nomination, earning 19.1 percent of the vote in the primary election. He was defeated by Ruppersberger in the general election, receiving 33 percent of the vote.\n\n\n'''' has described Salling as a , but notes that he occasionally votes with Democrats on bills involving workers' rights and opportunities.\n\n\nIn 2018, the Maryland  gave Salling a score of 17 percent on its annual legislative scorecard – the lowest score in the Maryland Senate.\n\nDuring a debate on a sweeping climate action bill in March 2021, Salling introduced an amendment that would lower the bill's pollution reduction goal from 60 percent to 50 percent, contending that it was too ambitious. The amendment was rejected by a vote of 15-31.\n\n\nSalling denounced an executive order issued by  executive  in April 2017 that formalized police policy on undocumented immigrants in the county, calling it \"dangerous\".\n\n\nSalling says that he does not agree with the legalization of , but he does accept that cannabis does have some medicinal benefits.\n\n\nSalling supports providing police departments with additional funding and training and disagrees with calls to  and invest in community social services.\n\n\n during a press conference on the , 2024]]\nIn March 2024, following the , Salling and state senator  introduced a bill that would allow the governor to declare a year-long state of emergency after damage to critical infrastructure, though it would eliminate the authority to seize private property for government use, as now allowed under a state of emergency. The bill was withdrawn by Simonaire following discussions with the Moore administration.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''David George Boschert''' (July 30, 1947 – June 30, 2011) was an American politician.  Boschert was most recently a  member of the , representing  in the . During his political career he played roles in both the  and .\n\n\nBoschert was a  in the  and served in .\n\nBoschert held a number of sales and customer oriented jobs early in his life.  He worked for local banks in various capacities, including as a branch manager and President for Public Relations, from 1979 to 1990.  In 1987 he started his own company, Community Image Consultants, Inc., but it proved unsuccessful.\n\nFrom 1980 to 1982, Boschert was the head of the , which primarily deals with zoning issues.\n\nFrom 1984 to 1994, Boschert served as a  member of the  for District 4 of .  He served as Chairman of the Council from 1992 to 1994.  While in office, the County passed legislation limiting the Council to two terms.  After two terms, Boschert ran for a District 33 Delegate seat in 1994, but lost.  He switched political parties prior to the 1998 election. In 1998, Boschert ran again for the 33rd district seat and won.\n\nBoschert was appointed by Governor  in 2000 as Executive Director of the Annapolis Regional Transportation Management Association.\n\nIn 2003, Boschert began a run for Congress in Maryland's , but later withdrew to avoid a challenge by Bob Duckworth, who went on to be the Republican nominee.  Boschert subsequently chose to retire from the state House of Delegates and run for the Republican nomination for County Executive in 2006 to replace , who was term limited.  He lost the nomination to  , who went on to defeat  in the general election. Leopold was later ousted from office due to several scandals.\n\nLater in his life, Boschert taught political science classes part-time at , located in Arnold, Maryland.\n\n\n\nBoschert served in the  from 1999 to 2007. While serving in the state legislature, Boschert was a member of the powerful Ways & Means Committee. Boschert upset his party and Republican Governor  early in the 2003 legislative term when he opposed the governor's slot machine legislation. Boschert ignored a heavy lobbying effort and voted to kill the Governor's proposal in Committee.\n\nLater, Boschert returned to the good graces of the Republican Party in part by voting for the former Governor's proposals, including supporting the effort to install slots at racetracks. Throughout his career, Boschert cultivated a moderate image, though he co-sponsored a .\n\n\n\nBoschert earned an Associate of Arts degree in political science from  in 1978 and a Bachelor of Science in Business Management from the  in 1981.\n\nBoschert lived in . He was married and had a grown son and daughter. He died from cancer in 2011.\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 33A''' Retrieved on Oct. 13, 2007\nVoters choose two:\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 33A''' Retrieved on Oct. 13, 2007\nVoters choose three:\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 33A''' Retrieved on Oct. 13, 2007\nVoters choose three:\n:\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* http://www.hometownannapolis.com/cgi-bin/read/2006/09_03-76/OPN\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* David Boschert \n* David G. He served alongside Democrat   In 1993, he defeated Democratic incumbent .\n\n\nMurphy graduated from the former , in .   He later graduated from the  with his bachelor's degree in real estate and science in 1983.\n\n\nMurphy was and continues to be a real estate consultant.  He was a delegate to the .  He was the chair of the [www.baltimorecountyrepublicans.org Baltimore County Republican Central Committee] from 2002 until 2003. He is a co-founder of the  and a past president of the Holmehurst Community Association.\n\nWhile a member of the Maryland House of Delegates, he was a member of the Judiciary Committee and the civil law and procedure subcommittee. He served as Deputy Minority Whip from 2002 until 2003.  Murphy did not seek reelection in 2002.\n\nMurphy is now a GOP strategist, serving in 2010 as advisor to Senate candidate Dr. Eric Wargotz of Maryland, according to Fox News.\n\nCurrently, Murphy works as a federal-policies analyst for the  (MPP), a national group looking to liberalize laws on marijuana.  As state delegate he had sponsored the first medical marijuana protection bill.\n\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 12A''' Retrieved on Jan, 27th, 2008\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 12A''' Retrieved on Jan, 27th, 2008\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/former/html/msa12279.html Maryland Manual\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Mark Nicholas Fisher''' (born August 3, 1962) is an American  who represents  in the , which covers parts of . He previously represented  from 2011 to 2015. He also hosts a podcast called ''Mark and the Millennials'', which explores the divide between conservative  and the .\n\n\nFisher was born in . He attended , where he earned a B.A. in international affairs and economics. After graduating, he became a managing member for telecommunications infrastructure company Telecom Capital Group LLC. In 2003, Fisher founded Gray's Field Foundation, a nonprofit group to fund preservation of a baseball field in .\n\nFisher is a . He is married and has three children, and lives in .\n\n\n\nFisher ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 27B in 2010, challenging incumbent Democratic legislator . In an upset, he defeated Kullen in the general election with 52.6 percent of the vote. He was sworn in on January 12, 2011. He was a member of the House Ways and Means Committee from 2011 to 2015, and has been a member of the House Economic Matters committee since 2015. A founding member of the Maryland Freedom Caucus, '''' has described Fisher as one of the most vocal conservatives in the House of Delegates.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Fisher spoke against the state's new legislative redistricting map, claiming that Democrats had ed multiple districts in  to benefit the party. After the  passed the new maps, Fisher joined the lawsuit against the new maps and argued that his own district was gerrymandered, citing that it was drawn into Prince George's County. The  ruled that the new maps did not violate the state constitution in April 2022.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Fisher voted against a bill to index the state's es to inflation.\n\nIn February 2014, Fisher criticized Media Rights Capital, the production company behind '''', for threatening to leave the state unless it was given millions of dollars in tax credits, calling it \"ransom\".\n\nIn March 2014, Fisher voted against a bill that would raise the  to $10.10/hour. He also introduced an amendment to this bill that would exempt all businesses with 50 or fewer employees from the minimum wage increase, which would fail by a 45–88 vote. In 2019, he voted against a bill that would raise the state minimum wage to $15/hour, calling it \"\".\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Fisher voted against a bill requiring employers to provide workers with seven days of  per year, arguing it would cause restaurants to automate low-paying jobs.\n\nIn March 2020, Fisher introduced an amendment to House Bill 932, which would implement a sales tax on digital services, that would have exempted educational products from the tax on the basis that the generated revenue would be going to the . The amendment failed along party lines.\n\nIn 2022, following a spike in gas prices as the result of the , Fisher said he supported holding a special legislative session to suspend gas and electric taxes, eliminate retirement income and business property taxes, and lower the income tax rate.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Fisher introduced a bill to ban people or businesses associated with the  from buying farmland in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Fisher voted against , which provided in-state tuition to s.\n\nIn March 2019, Fisher introduced an amendment to the  that would restrict $1 million of the  budget until completion of a report to facilitate the exercise of  rights on campus. The amendment failed by a vote of 42–96.\n\nIn March 2020, Fisher introduced an amendment to the  (HB1300) that would allow students attending \"failing schools\" to transfer to an \"alternative school\" within the same county. His amendment was rejected by a vote of 41–93. He opposes the Blueprint, saying that he would support \"suspending and rewriting\" the bill because of its cost.\n\nIn April 2023, Fisher sent a letter to State Superintendent Mohammed Choudhury accusing the  of hiding scores from failing scores by altering data files available on the department's website. An investigation conducted by the state inspector general found no evidence of these claims.\n\n\nIn March 2020, Fisher voted against a bill that would prohibit stores from providing customers with plastic bags, calling it \"\". He voted against the bill again when it was reintroduced in 2021.\n\nIn 2021, Fisher introduced a bill that would have prevented elected officials at the state and local level from using the government's s without paying for it. Democrats on the House Environment and Transportation Committee rewrote his bill to allow state employees and local elected officials free access to the charging stations for their personal vehicles. The committee then voted 17–5 to approve the changes and brought the bill to the House floor for debate, where Fisher proposed an amendment that would revert the bill back to its original state. His amendment was rejected by a vote of 47–80.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Fisher said he opposed the Climate Solutions Now Act, calling it a \"takeover of the economy\".\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Fisher voted against the Firearm Safety Act of 2013, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nFisher opposed legislation to establish the Prescription Drug Affordability Board, suggesting it was a \"price control\" bill. During the 2024 legislative session, he opposed a bill that would allow undocumented immigrants to buy their own health insurance.\n\n\nFisher has criticized the , predicting that the United States would \"devolve into a \". In May 2024, he signed onto a letter condemning the jury's guilty verdict in the , calling the ruling a \"political prosecution from a kangaroo court and left-leaning prosecutor\" that is turning the U.S. justice system into a \"third world parody of law and order\".\n\n\nFisher's district includes the , Maryland's only .\n\nIn February 2021, Fisher suggested that investing in the  could be a solution to the , arguing that there is not enough solar or wind infrastructure to address the climate emergency. He advocated for nuclear power investments in the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2021.\n\nIn March 2019, Fisher introduced legislation to include nuclear as a Tier 1 Fuel that could be used as part of the state's renewable portfolio. He later amended his bill to instead mandate a study on the future of the nuclear industry in Maryland, causing it to pass the House Economic Matters Committee by a vote of 20–1. His bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 102–34, but would not receive a vote in the Senate.\n\n\nFisher opposed a bill to add an amendment codifying abortion access rights to the .\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Fisher opposed the Trans Health Equity Act, a bill that would require the state's  program to cover , comparing  healthcare to \"child mutilation\" and the book ''Brave New World'', and calling it a violation of human rights. He introduced an amendment to the bill to allow cancer victims to have their , which was rejected by the legislature.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Linda K. Foley''' (born March 10, 1955) is an American politician and labor organizer who previously served as president of the  and vice-president of the  from 1995 through 2008. In December 2021,   appointed her to fill a vacancy in  of the  ().\n\n\nFoley was born in  on March 10, 1955, where she attended .\n\nShe was a  for the  in ,  before turning to full-time work at the ''Guild'' in 1984.  She was elected its secretary-treasurer in 1993 and its president in 1995. She received a  degree in journalism from the  at  in , , in 1977.\n\nIn 1995, Foley was elected the first woman President of the Newspaper Guild, which would eventually merge with the Communications Workers of America in 1997. In May 2008, Foley was defeated for re-election by Newspaper Guild Secretary-Treasurer Bernie Lunzer.\n\nFoley later became the president of the Berger-Marks Foundation, an organization promoting women in the labor movement, which closed in 2017. She was elected to the Montgomery County, Maryland, Democratic Central Committee in 2018 and subsequently became the chair of the , Democratic Party.\n\n\n\nIn December 2021, the Montgomery County Democratic Party voted 20-2 to nominate Foley to fill a vacancy left by the resignation of former Delegate , who was appointed as a Circuit Court judge by  . Her opponents, attorney Michael Shrier and former delegate , each garnered one vote. Hogan appointed Foley to the House of Delegates on December 14, 2021.\n\n\n* Women Legislators of Maryland (2021–present)\n\n\nMs. Foley drew criticism after May 13, 2005, for stating that the  is responsible for journalists being targeted – \"''not just being targeted verbally or, politically. They are also being targeted for real, in places like . What outrages me as a representative of journalists is that there's not more outrage about the number, and the brutality and the cavalier nature of the US military toward the killing of journalists in Iraq. I think it's just a scandal. They target and kill journalists from other countries, particularly Arab countries like , for example. They actually target them and blow up their studios with impunity.''\" \n\nIn August 2005, the '''' stated in an editorial: \"Target and kill? Foley has been under attack since she said those words. And should be. Even the infamous killing of journalists by tank fire at the Palestine Hotel in Baghdad was found not to have been deliberate, in an extensive investigation by Reporters Without Borders. Some facts: according to The Committee to Protect Journalists, at least 36 journalists have been killed in action in Iraq since March 2003, along with 18 media support workers; insurgent actions account for 34 of those 54 deaths; U.S. military fire accounts for at least 11. The committee says the record shows that \"the military seems indifferent and unwilling . . . to take steps to mitigate risk.\" But target and kill? The committee finds \"no evidence to conclude that the U.S. military has deliberately targeted the press in Iraq. So on that subject here's what Foley should have said: nothing.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
