    "pages": }\n\n'''Kenneth P. Kerr''' (born January 28, 1957) is an American politician. He is a  member of the . He represents , which covers parts of . He was previously a member of the  Board of Education from 2016 to 2018.\n\n\nKerr was born in  on January 28, 1957. He attended , where he earned an  degree in general studies in 1976. While at Frederick Community College, he met his wife in a philosophy class, who he married in 1984. He also attended , where he earned a  degree in music in 1981. After graduating from Hood College, he worked as a fourth grade teacher for  from 1983 to 1986. During this time, Kerr led a group of fourth-graders through the  and thought to himself, \"Wow, this is really cool. It'd be great if I could do this someday.\" After teaching, Kerr worked in the  field for 10 years, working various jobs including computer repair and writing s. Writing manuals made him return to , where he earned a  degree in professional writing in 1995. After graduating from Towson, Kerr worked as an English professor at , , , , and . Since 1999, he has worked as an English professor at Frederick Community College, serving as the chair of the English department from 2011 to 2017. He later attended , where he earned a  in 2003.\n\nIn 2014, Kerr unsuccessfully ran for the Frederick County Board of Education, seeking to replace board member Brad Young. He lost to incumbent April Miller in the general election by a margin of 43 votes. He declined to request a recount, saying that he trusted the proficiency of the elections officials in tallying absentee and provisional ballots.\n\nIn April 2016, Kerr again ran for the Frederick County Board of Education. During the general election, Kerr teamed up with candidates Michael Bunitsky and incumbent school board member Joy Schaefer to campaign and fundraise together and to pool funds. Kerr was victorious in the general election, receiving 25.7 percent of the vote. He was sworn in on December 7, 2016.\n\nIn January 2018, Kerr announced his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates, seeking to challenge Delegate . He ran unopposed in the Democratic primary. Kerr defeated Folden in the , earning 52.4 percent of the vote. After his general election win, Kerr resigned from the Frederick County Board of Education. The  voted to appoint Lois Jarman to fill his seat.\n\n\nKerr was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. Since 2019, he has sat on the Health and Government Operations Committee. Kerr is also an associate member of the Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, as well as the Veterans Caucus.\n\nIn 2024, Kerr applied to run as a delegate to the  pledged to , but was denied by the .\n\n\n\nKerr introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would allow farmers who grew malting barley and rye as s to  their crops while still earning a stipend. The bill received an unfavorable report from the Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\n\nKerr introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would allow some restaurants, bars, and taverns to continue selling alcoholic beverages that could be consumed off-site. The bill passed and became law with Governor Larry Hogan's signature on May 18, 2021.\n\n\nKerr introduced legislation in the 2020 legislation session that would categorize  as among the most dangerous controlled substances in Maryland.\n\n\nKerr supported legislation introduced by Delegate  during the 2017 legislative session that would require schools be open for at least 1,080 hours a year, or roughly 155 full school days.\n\nDuring the 2018 election, Kerr ran as \"a champion for public education.\"\n\nIn January 2019, Kerr testified in support of a bill that would classify teachers at the  as state employees, rather than \"at will\" employees.\n\nKerr introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would prove funding for a teacher apprenticeship program for the  system. He also introduced a bill that would allow students to attend a nonprofit institution of higher learning at the same cost as an average four-year rate for tuition and fees for public colleges and universities through .\n\nKerr introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would require seizure training for teachers and other school employees. It received a favorable subcommittee report.\n\n\nIn March 2019, Kerr voted in favor of legislation that would ban s.\n\n\nIn February 2020, Kerr was one of seven Democrats who voted against a bill that would mandate s on private sales and transfers of shotguns and rifles.\n\n\nKerr introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that aims to reduce the amount that young people pay for insurance through the . The bill passed and went into effect without Governor Larry Hogan's signature on May 30, 2021.\n\nIn March 2019, Kerr voted in favor of a bill that would allow physicians to prescribe  to terminally ill people, at the patient's request, to aid in their death.\n\n\nKerr supports the legalization of . During the 2018 election, Kerr received an A-plus rating from the Maryland Cannabis Policy Coalition for his support of legalizing marijuana.\n\n\nIn July 2019, Kerr endorsed  in the . He ran as an uncommitted delegate for the .\n\n\nIn October 2017, Kerr voted in favor of legislation that would allow students to use bathrooms and locker rooms according to their gender identity and provides alternatives for students uncomfortable for any reason.\n\n\nDuring his 2018 campaign, Kerr said that people should look at the impact that technology such as  could have before building more lanes on .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''George Clayton Edwards''' (born April 9, 1948) is an American politician who previously served as a member of the  from District 1.\n\n\nEdwards was elected as the State Senator for Maryland District 1 in 2006, which covers  and parts of  and  counties.  He defeated Thomas Conlon, both of whom ran for the seat vacated by  who retired after 16 years in the State Senate.\n\n\nEdwards attended  in .  He received his  in business administration from , cum laude in 1970.  He later attended  to get his teacher's certificate.\n\n\nAfter college, Edwards was drafted by the . He served in the  for six years.  He has been active in Garrett County Economic Development Corporation and the Maryland Association of Counties.\n\nEdwards was first elected to the  in 1982 and served for 24 years before running and winning the State Senate seat. As a member of the House of Delegates, Edwards was the Minority Leader from 2003 to 2007.\n\nServing in the  since 2007, Edwards announced in July 2021 that he would not seek reelection in 2022.\n\nHe is a member of the , the , the , and the .\n\n\n\nIn 2016, legislation was introduced in the Maryland Senate (SB 361) that would require the disclosure of fracking chemicals during a liability suit involving harm or injury to persons from gas drilling and  operations. The bill also required higher insurance coverage for gas companies. Edwards introduced amendments that would reduce the liability insurance requirements and limit chemical disclosure. After several days of public outcry from his district, including letters and emails from more than 350 citizens and businesses, Edwards withdrew the amendments. The final bill passed out of the Senate.\n\nIn October 2021, he was one of five Maryland state legislators from Garrett, Allegany and Washington counties who sent a pair of letters to West Virginia officials asking about annexation of  to West Virginia. These letters caused a local uproar, with Allegany County officials calling the request a political stunt, an embarrassment and unneeded distraction. Following criticism from local officials and some constituents, Edwards and Delegate  issued a letter withdrawing support for the secession proposal.\n\n\n* ''' Race for Maryland State Senate – District 1'''\n:\n\n* '''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – '''\n:\n\n* '''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – '''\n:\n\n* '''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – '''\n:\n\n* '''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – '''\n:\n\n* '''1986 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – '''\n:\n\n\n* Voted against the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* Voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* Voted for  in 1999 (HB703)\n* Voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)[\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Patrick J. \"PJ\" Hogan''' (born September 22, 1962) is an American lobbyist and politician from  and a member of the . He was the Vice Chair of the Maryland State Board of Elections from 2014 to 2021. Hogan was a member of the  from District 39, which covers parts of , from January 11, 1995, to August 10, 2007. He was initially elected as a  but switched to the  in 2000. Hogan resigned from the Senate to become the Vice-Chancellor for Government Relations for the  from August 2007 to September 30, 2015. The position has been described as the chief lobbyist for the university system. He left the university system to work as a lobbyist in Annapolis.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''William Opeyemi Jawando''' (born January 2, 1983) is an American politician and author who has served as an at-large member of the  since 2018.\n\n\nJawando was born in , on January 2, 1983. He is biracial, with a white mother from Kansas, Kathleen Gross, and a Nigerian father, Olayinka Jawando, who divorced when Jawando was six years old. He attended the , where he earned a B.A. degree in sociology in 2004 and a J.D. degree in 2007.\n\nIn May 2022,  published Jawando's autobiography, ''My Seven Black Fathers''. The book follows his early life and career, with each of the book's chapters describing each of his \"fathers\".\n\n\nJawando first got involved in politics as a student at Catholic University, where he made efforts to establish a campus  chapter, which was resisted by the school over the organization's stance on abortion. After national pressure, including from then-President and CEO of the NAACP , the university ultimately backtracked and allowed the chapter's formation. He later worked as an intern for then-House Minority Leader , then-U.S. Senator , and U.S. Senator  until 2009. Afterwards, he worked in the  and the  until 2012.\n\n\n\nIn 2014, Jawando ran for the  in , seeking to succeed , who . During the Democratic primary, he received endorsements from several local labor unions, , and . Jawando lost the Democratic primary on June 25, 2014, placing fourth with 15.1 percent of the vote, a margin of 400 votes out of 37,264 votes cast. Following his defeat, he joined Governor 's political action committee, O' Say Can You See PAC, as a senior adviser.\n\n\n\n\nIn April 2015, Jawando announced his candidacy for the  in , seeking to succeed , who ran for . During the primary, he received endorsements from members of the  and , including U.S. Representatives  and , former U.S. education secretary , and former  administrator . He also ran on a platform of increasing the minimum wage, protecting abortion rights, paid sick and family leave, campaign finance reform, and police accountability.\n\nIn December 2015, '''' reported that Jawando's campaign accepted donations from , who Jawando said he was introduced to by a friend in New York's financial sector. He promised to give away Shkreli's contributions to charity, however, campaign finance records show that Jawando's campaign had kept $22,900 in contributions from six other  employees.\n\nJawando was defeated in the Democratic primary by state senator  on April 27, 2016, placing fifth with 4.6 percent of the vote.\n\n\nIn September 2017, Jawando announced his candidacy for the Montgomery County Council at-large. During his campaign, he utilized the county's public financing program. Jawando won the 34-way Democratic primary and later the general election, and was sworn in on December 3, 2018, becoming the second Black lawmaker elected countywide in Montgomery County. He was subsequently re-elected in 2022.\n\nIn November 2022, Jawando joined the transition team of Governor-elect . He was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\nIn December 2023, Jawando started his own , Will of the People PAC, to support progressive candidates.\n\n\n\nOn May 2, 2023, Jawando announced that he would run for  in 2024, seeking to succeed incumbent U.S. Senator , who had announced the day before that he would not run for re-election in 2024. During the Democratic primary, he sought to position himself as a , citing his record on the Montgomery County Council, and ran on a platform including , a federal  program, and . He was viewed by the media as a long-shot candidate behind frontrunners  and .\n\nJawando dropped out of the race on October 20, 2023, and endorsed Alsobrooks a few days later.\n\n\nJawando has been described by media outlets as a progressive, including by himself.\n\n\nIn April 2020, Jawando introduced the COVID-19 Renter Relief Act, a bill that prohibits landlords from increasing rent during and within 30 days after a public health emergency. He later partnered with local businessman David Blair to establish the Montgomery County Food Security fund to support those struggling financially during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\n, 2021]]\nIn March 2021, Jawando co-signed a letter written by the Montgomery County Council to Governor  criticizing his administration's vaccine rollout, which they charged as disproportionally impacting people of color and low-wage residents of the state. In September 2021, he said he supported a proposal by Elrich to instate a  for county workers.\n\nIn October 2021, Jawando joined  advocates at a protest at the , where he called on Hogan to reinstate eviction protections and on legislative leaders to form a special session to pass tenant protections bills. In August 2022, he supported a proposal by County Executive  to extend the COVID-19 Renter Relief Act by an additional six months and to limit rent increases at 4.4%.\n\n\nDuring the , Jawando expressed support for the  movement, but ultimately clarified and said he does not support defunding the police. He supported several bills as county councilmember to increase police oversight and reduce police brutality.\n\nIn January 2019, Jawando introduced the Law Enforcement Trust and Transparency Act, a bill that would require the State Prosecutor's Office or the United States Department of Justice to investigate officer-involved deaths. The bill passed and went into effect in 2020. In December 2021, he criticized a proposal by County Executive  to establish a police accountability board, saying it \"falls short as introduced and the kind of public buy-in that's needed\".\n\nIn May 2019, after released police body-camera footage showed a white officer using the , Jawando called on Montgomery County Assistant Police Chief Marcus Jones to open an investigation into the incident. In June 2019, he introduced a bill to establish a Policing Advisory Commission to involve citizens in the county police department policy formulation.\n\nIn July 2020, Jawando introduced a bill to limit a police officer's use-of-force, which included restrictions on s and a ban on neck restraints. The bill was unanimously passed by the Montgomery County Council.\n\nIn July 2020, Jawando voted to reassign 12 of the 23 active s (SROs) in . In November 2020, Jawando introduced a bill to remove SROs from Montgomery County Public Schools, instead redirecting the money toward mental health programs and restorative justice programs in the county. During the 2021 legislative session, he supported a state bill to replace SROs with counselors. In April 2021, Jawando and the Montgomery County Public Schools system launched the Student Wellbeing Action Group (SWAG), a workgroup to determine what supports students needed without SROs present.\n\nIn May 2021, Jawando introduced a bill that would require police officers to complete a 30-hour training course on racial equity and conflict resolution. The bill passed and was signed into law by Elrich in November 2022.\n\n\nIn October 2021, Jawando led efforts to launch a Guaranteed Income Pilot Program in Montgomery County, which would give $800 per month to 300 targeted families for two years.\n\nIn September 2023, Jawando introduced a bill to incrementally phase out the county's , which he called a \"legacy of slavery\", by 2028. He withdrew the bill in January 2024, saying that he would instead push for a similar statewide bill.\n\n\n\nIn October 2020, Jawando voted against a bill to give tax breaks to  developers near  stations. He later voted to sustain County Executive 's veto of the bill in December 2020. In February 2021, Jawando introduced bills to allow multi-family housing to be built near Metro stations, and another to limit rent increases to once a year.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Jawando testified in support of a bill that would require landlords to have a \"just cause\" for choosing not to renew a tenant's lease.\n\nIn July 2022, Jawando introduced a bill that would establish an all-electric building standard in construction by 2024.\n\nIn July 2023, Jawando introduced a bill to cap annual rent increases in Montgomery County at six percent. The bill passed and was signed into law by County Executive .\n\n\nIn December 2019, Jawando participated in and spoke at a rally in  to support of the .\n\n\nIn October 2019, Jawando introduced the CROWN Act, a bill that would ban discrimination based on natural hairstyles. The bill passed and became law, making Montgomery County the first county in the United States to ban hairstyle discrimination.\n\nIn May 2022, following the leak of a draft opinion of the 's ruling in '''', Jawando predicted that Maryland would become \"an important part of the nationwide care collection\".\n\nIn September 2023, Jawando voted for a bill to ban the sale and use of gas-powered leaf blowers.\n\n\nIn May 2019, Jawando said he supported expanding the county's property tax credit for owner-occupied residences.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Jawando testified in support of a bill that would allow counties to implement a . He also proposed a bill to suspend the county's carryout bag tax during the COVID-19 pandemic; the bill was withdrawn in April 2020, after he spoke with representatives from local labor unions and environmental groups.\n\nIn June 2020, Jawando introduced a resolution to declare racism a public health crisis. The Montgomery County Council unanimously voted for the resolution.\n\nIn April 2023, Jawando introduced a bill to increase the county recordation tax by over a dollar for each $500 of the sales price.\n\n\nJawando opposed Governor 's plan to widen  and the , saying in December 2019 that the plans would \"do nothing to reduce miles travelled or tailpipe emissions\" and that its express toll lanes would \"only be available to the wealthiest residents\".\n\n\n holds up Jawando's four-month old child, 2011]]\nJawando met his future wife, , in 2004 at the Chi-Cha Lounge in  They were engaged nine months later. As of January 2023, Michele is senior vice president for programs of the . Together, they have four children and live in .\n\nOutside of politics, Jawando is a choir singer at the  in Silver Spring.\n\nIn November 2021, Jawando missed a court hearing he had requested to contest two traffic citations. Jawando's chief of staff stated that he paid the fines before his license was to be suspended in response to the absence.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Joseph R. Bartlett''' (born December 30, 1969) is an American politician and real estate investor who served as a member of the  for District 4A from 1999 to 2011.\n\n\nBartlett was born on December 30, 1969, in , the son of then-future Congressman . Bartlett earned an Associate of Arts degree from  in 1992, followed by a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Administration from  in 1994.\n\n\nIn 1994 and 1996, Bartlett served as a campaign manager for his father's re-election campaigns.\n\nBartlett was elected to the  in November 1998, succeeding . He served from January 1999 until January 2011, and opting not to run for re-election in 2010. After leaving office in 2011, he established Bartlett Real Estate Solutions, a real estate firm.\n\n\nIn 2010, Bartlett drew criticism for using taxpayer money to pay his girlfriend's rent during the 2008, 2009, and 2010 legislative sessions. In total, the state had paid $31,923 for rent. Bartlett said that he was not dating Katharine Hopkins when he began renting from her in 2008, and that he cleared the housing arrangement with a legislative ethics attorney when the two started dating. The controversy eventually led Bartlett to announce he would not run for re-election to a fourth term on July 6, 2010. In August 2010,   called for tighter rules on lodging expenses following the controversy.\n\n\nBartlett is a practicing  and lived in , as of the last update to his  biography.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kathleen Hartington Kennedy Townsend''' (born July 4, 1951) is an American attorney who was the sixth (and first female)  from 1995 to 2003. She ran unsuccessfully for governor of Maryland in .\n\nIn 2010, Townsend became the chair of the non-profit American Bridge, an organization whose focus is to raise funds for Democratic candidates and causes. Since 2021, she has served in the  as an advisor on retirement. She is a member of the prominent political , and is the oldest grandchild of  and .\n\n\nShe was born in , the eldest of  and 's eleven children. She is named after her paternal aunt . She is the eldest grandchild of  and . Kennedy spent her childhood between the family's homes in  and . While she was growing up, it was not assumed that the girls in the politically oriented Kennedy family would run for office. However, after her uncle President  was assassinated, her father wrote her saying, \"As the oldest of the next generation you have a particular responsibility. ... Be kind to others and work for your country.\" Her family gave her the nicknames \"Clean Kathleen\", \"the Nun\", and \"the Un-Kennedy\".\n\nOver the summer of 1964, Kennedy won four blue ribbons for her \"excellence in horsemanship\". On August 29, 1965, the fourteen-year-old Kennedy was somersaulted by her horse while competing at Sea Flash Farms in . She was left unconscious and bleeding internally and was rushed to , located fifteen miles away. Her family was en route to  at the time of the incident and was not located for another three hours.\n\nShe was sixteen when her . The night he was shot at the , Kennedy and her two eldest brothers, Joseph II and Robert Jr., were being flown to Los Angeles aboard one of the planes in the Secret Service's presidential fleet named \"the ''Jet Star''\".\n\nShe was educated at Our Lady of Victory Elementary School in Washington, D.C., and later graduated from  in . She attended  of , receiving her  in history and literature in 1974. She then studied at the , receiving her  degree in 1978.\n\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Kathleen worked as an attorney at a private , Clendenen & Lesser, in , while her husband, David Townsend, attended . In 1982, she was admitted to the , and worked as a  for U.S. District Court Judge . She also worked on her uncle , stumped for local Democrats, and was hired as a  for   in the early 1980s while she and her husband resided in .\n\nIn 1984, the family settled in the , in her husband's home state. In 1985, she was admitted to the . In 1986, Townsend became the first  member to lose a  when she ran for the  in Maryland's strongly Republican , using the name Townsend only. Incumbent Republican  defeated her 59% to 41%.\n\nAfter her failed congressional bid, Townsend went to work for the state government of Maryland, holding numerous posts including assistant . In 1993, Townsend took a job at the  overseeing grants to local police departments and community groups.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1994,  was running for  in a highly contested primary against then-Lt. Governor  when he selected her as his running mate. Experts did not believe she would be an asset, but her name recognition (she now used the name Kennedy Townsend) and her fund-raising skills helped him to win.\n\n\nIn the general election, Glendening and Townsend beat Republican candidate  in one of Maryland's closest and most controversial gubernatorial elections. After unofficial results indicated that Sauerbrey had lost the election by a narrow margin, she began making what ''The Washington Post'' called \"sensational charges\" that the election had been stolen. Sauerbrey's allegations included ballot box stuffing, 100% voting in one precinct, voting by numerous dead people, and what she called the Kennedy \"precedent\"that unproven rumors that John Kennedy had stolen the 1960 Presidential election proved that his niece Townsend had stolen this election.\n\nThe official vote tally declared Glendening the winner by 5,993 votes out of 1.4 million. Sauerbrey hired an election specialist known for aggressive tactics then filed a lawsuit alleging that 50,000 votes had been cast illegally. By the time the hearing began in January 1995, however, Sauerbrey had backed away from the fraud charges and her claim centered on sloppy election procedures and 3,600 challenged ballots. The number of challenged ballots would not have been enough to change the result even if all of them were thrown out. The judge ruled that about 1,800 votes had been cast in  by people whose names should have been purged from the rolls, but said that there was no clear and convincing evidence that fraud or procedural errors had affected the outcome. Sauerbrey dropped the suit three days before Glendening was to be inaugurated, but still maintained her belief that she had won the election.\n\nSauerbrey ran against Glendening again in , but this time Glendening and Townsend won by a much wider margin (55% to 44%).\n\n\nDuring her tenure as lieutenant governor, Townsend focused on  and promoting . Under her leadership, Maryland became the first state to require  as a prerequisite to high school graduation. Townsend's \"HotSpot Communities Initiative\" collaborated with law enforcement and government agencies to design and implement a comprehensive enforcement and prevention strategy at targeted high-crime areas. Her \"Break the Cycle\" program required offenders on parole or probation to take frequent s.\n\nDuring the , Townsend travelled to  to campaign for . \n\n\nIn the , Townsend faced   and   in the general election.\n\nDuring the campaign, Townsend was criticized for her choice of running mate,  , a novice politician who had switched parties only a few weeks before. Some also criticized the choice of a white male as unlikely to help minority turnout. Ehrlich's running mate was , an  lawyer who had been chairman of the Republican Party of Maryland.\n\nThough Maryland traditionally votes Democratic and had not elected a Republican governor in almost 40 years, Townsend lost the race, gaining 48% of the vote to Ehrlich's 51% and Lancaster's 1%. Ehrlich became only the seventh Republican governor in state history. In the end, most observers agreed she ran a weak campaign. They specifically cited a lack of planning, claiming that she hastily booked campaign stops in rural areas hostile to her. '''' said the defeat derailed her political career, at least in the short run.\n\n\nTownsend, along with siblings  and , endorsed  for president in the 2008 Democratic primaries.\n\nTownsend wrote the book ''Failing America's Faithful: How Today's Churches Are Mixing God with Politics and Losing Their Way'', published in 2007. She also contributes to ''The Recovering Politician'', a website started by Jonathan Miller.\n\nShe is an adjunct professor at the , a visiting fellow at  at , and senior Nitze fellow at .\n\nIn December 2010, she was appointed chair of American Bridge, a new non-profit that would raise funds for Democratic candidates and causes, and that was intended to be a Democratic counterpart to right-leaning organizations such as  and . She noted that the Democrats did not have such an organization during the 2010 election cycle, and that Republicans outspent the Democrats by $70 million. \"I want to compete dollar to a dollar with the Republicans and I want to beat them\", she said.\n\nTownsend endorsed incumbent Democrat 's  in the  over  by her brother Robert. Four months later, Townsend and four of her siblings endorsed Democratic Vice President 's  in the , and denounced their brother Robert Jr.'s decision to endorse former President , calling the move a \"betrayal\".\n\n\nIn 1973, she married David Lee Townsend (born 1947), whom she had met when he was a graduate student and her tutor at Radcliffe. As of April 2020, David is a member of the faculty at  in Annapolis. The couple have four daughters:\n\n* Meaghan Anne Kennedy Townsend (born November 7, 1977)\n*  (November 1, 1979 – April 2, 2020)\n* Rose Katherine \"Kat\" Kennedy Townsend (born December 17, 1983)\n* Kerry Sophia Kennedy Townsend (born November 30, 1991)\n\nOn June 27, 2011, her daughter Maeve gave birth to a son named Gideon Joseph Kennedy McKean. Gideon was the first great-grandchild for Bobby and Ethel, as well as the first of the fifth generation of Kennedys.\n\nMaeve and son Gideon went missing, and were presumed dead, in a canoeing accident that occurred on April 2, 2020. After 26 hours, the recovery mission was suspended. Maeve's body was found in the  on April 6 and Gideon's body was recovered April 8. His body was 2,000 feet from where his mother's was found.\n\n\nShe has served on the boards of many organizations, and as a consultant to several corporations. She is the chair of the Institute for Human Virology at the . She is on the boards of directors of the  Foundation, the , the  and . She was formerly on the independent Advisory Council of the  (ACORN), a panel that was appointed to review the functioning of ACORN following the scandal touched off by hidden camera videos in September 2009, and the board of the ''''. Townsend is also a member of the  and the . She is also on the Board of Selectors of . She is on the board of directors at the Lightbridge nuclear fuel technology company.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  of Kathleen Kennedy Townsend on her book ''Failing America's Faithful'', from the University of Chicago's \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Richard W. Metzgar''' (born November 28, 1953) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  from the  since 2015.\n\n\nMetzgar was born and raised in , on November 28, 1953. His father worked for the  and his mother owned a dry cleaning business and worked for the . Metzgar graduated from  and attended Northwest Bible College and later earned a  certificate and from the .\n\nMetzgar is a small business owner, working as the general manager of G & W Motors from 1989 to 2015 and as the president of My Son's Parking, Inc. from 1994 to 1998. He was also the owner of the original Essex Diner. Metzgar also started the Gateway Pastors and Churches Association and served as a ministry leader for several area churches and as an associate pastor at Essex Church of God from 2004 to 2014.\n\nIn 2006 and 2010, Metzgar was an unsuccessful candidate for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 6. During his 2010 candidacy, he ran on a platform involving environmental and economic issues, including , pollution, and public safety.\n\n\n\nMetzgar was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates alongside Republicans  and  in the , during which the three ran on a platform involving economic issues. He was sworn in on January 14, 2015. Metzgar was a member of the Ways and Means Committee from 2015 to 2017, afterwards serving in the Health and Government Operations Committee until 2019. He has since served as a member of the Appropriations Committee.\n\nIn July 2015, after Governor  announced that he had been diagnosed with , Metzgar held a \"Hogan Strong\" vigil in Bel Air.\n\nMetzgar served as an alternative delegate for the . During the , he endorsed state delegate , calling his opponent  a \"third term\" of Governor , whom he criticized for disapproving of Cox and former President .\n\n\nMetzgar is married and has two adult children.\n\n\n\nDuring his 2006 House of Delegates campaign, Metzgar said he would support strengthening .\n\nIn May 2015, following the beating of a Richard Fletcher, a 61-year-old Dundalk resident who intervened in a fight outside his home, Metzgar called for the closure of the Baltimore Community High School, where the perpetrators of the attack attended. The  voted to close the school in January 2016.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Metzgar supported legislation that would require police to obtain a warrant to use a , which can locate a cellphone's user within six feet.\n\nDuring debate on the , which abolished  sentences for juveniles, in 2021, Metzgar supported an amendment that would make the bill not apply to people convicted of -related crimes. The amendment was rejected in a 51–83 vote.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Metzgar voted against the Clean Energy Job Act, a bill that expanded the state's clean energy mandates. In 2023, he supported the POWER Act, which expanded the state's  goals.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Metzgar said he opposed the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults, citing his faith. He supported a bill to establish the Prescription Drug Affordability Board, a body tasked with making recommendations to the Maryland General Assembly on how to make prescription drugs more affordable.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Metzgar supported legislation to allow sales of liquor in Baltimore County on Sundays.\n\nIn October 2023, Metzgar participated in a protest against the  and its policies toward  students participating in school sports and using bathrooms that correspond to their .\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Metzgar introduced a bill to .\n\n\nDuring his 2010 House of Delegates campaign, Metzgar said he supported repealing tax increases passed under the  administration.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Christopher R. West''' (born April 7, 1950) is an American politician from  from the  party. He is a member of the  from the , representing Central and Northern . He was previously a member of the  from District 42B.\n\n\nWest was born on April 7, 1950, in , . He attended , where he earned a  degree in 1972, and the , where he earned a  degree in 1975. He was admitted to the  in 1975.\n\nWest became involved in politics by working as an attorney for the  from 1982 to 1996, and again from 1998 to 2003 after serving as the executive director of the Republican State Central Committee for two years. In 1988, he filed to run for Delegate to the , representing . He came in tenth place in a field of 13 candidates, receiving one percent of the vote. During the , West represented the  in a lawsuit challenging the results of the election.\n\nIn 1997,  named West as a resident counsel in its Baltimore offices. He operated the commercial lending practice of the firm's banking, corporate, and securities practice group.\n\nIn 1998, West was seen as a possible candidate to succeed Joyce Lyons Terhes, who had announced that she would not seek re-election as the state's GOP chairman after a series of key losses across the state. He was once again considered a possible candidate for the seat after chairman  announced his resignation at the end of the year. He sought election as Chairman of the Maryland Republican Party that year, but was defeated by , the party's first vice chairman.\n\nIn February 2003, Governor  appointed West to the Maryland State Arts Council. He served as the council's vice-chair from 2006 to 2007.\n\nIn April 2013, West filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 42B. During the primary, there were attempts to recruit West to switch to the Senate race and challenge , but he refused, saying that he had \"no plans to switch over and run for State Senate.\" He won the Republican primary with 35.2 percent of the vote, coming second to . He defeated Democrats Robert Leonard and Craig J. Little in the general election, receiving 33.3 percent of the vote.\n\n\nWest was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015.\n\nAfter Senator Jim Brochin announced that he would run to replace  , West announced he would run to succeed Brochin in the Senate. He ran on a slate with Republican , who was running for House of Delegates. He defeated Robbie Leonard in the general election with 51.0 percent of the vote. West raised the third most funds out of every other Senator for his 2018 campaign, raking in a total $443,282.80 during the 2018 election cycle.\n\nWest was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. Since 2020, he has served as the caucus parliamentarian of the Maryland Senate GOP caucus.\n\nIn August 2023, West announced that he would not run for re-election in .\n\n\n;Maryland Senate\n* Member, Judicial Proceedings Committee, 2019–present (member, work group on COVID-19 & housing, 2020)\n* Work Group to Study the Transformation of Manufacturing in Maryland's Emerging Digital Economy, 2021–present\n* Member, Marijuana Legalization Work Group, 2019\n* Senate President's Advisory Work Group on Equity and Inclusion, 2020–2021\n* Vice-Chair, Baltimore County Delegation, 2019–2021\n\n;Maryland House of Delegates\n* Member, Health and Government Operations Committee, 2015–2019 (estates & trusts subcommittee, 2015–2017; insurance subcommittee, 2015–2019; health facilities & occupations subcommittee, 2017; health facilities & pharmaceuticals subcommittee, 2017–2019; health occupations & long-term care subcommittee, 2017–2019)\n* Marijuana Legalization Work Group, 2019–\n* Member, Death with Dignity Work Group, 2015\n* Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 2015–2019\n* Regional Revitalization Work Group, 2015–2019\n* Punitive Damages Work Group, 2016–2017\n*  (ACA) Work Group, 2018\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2015–2019\n\n\nWest has a reputation for being \"far and away the most  in the .\" Although he represents a conservative district, he often works as a man of compromise. In January 2020, the  gave West a score of 40 percent on its annual legislative scorecard, the lowest score among Republicans.\n\n\nWest supports banning s after a fetus reaches  unless the mother's life is at risk.\n\n\nIn 2019, following the legislature's vote on a bill that would raise the state's minimum wage to  by 2025, West agreed to participate in a work group proposed by Democratic Senator  that looked to study ways to help small businesses in the years leading up to the bill's full effective date.\n\nIn December 2020, the Maryland Free Enterprise Association gave West a score higher than 70 percent, making him the only senator to earn such a high score.\n\n\nIn August 2021, West signed onto a letter calling on the  to issue a universal  for students and teachers across the state in response to the . He was the only Republican to sign onto the letter.\n\n\nWest introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would end the practice of suspending  for unpaid court fines and fees. The bill passed unanimously and became law on May 8, 2020.\n\nWest introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would abolish life without parole for those who committed crimes as juveniles and allow those who have served 20 years or more to petition to a judge for release. The bill passed with bipartisan support, but was vetoed by Governor  in April. The legislature voted to override Hogan's veto on the bill on April 10, 2021.\n\n\nWest introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would require agencies to provide a voter application form and general voting information to people preparing to transition back to society from prison. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 93-36.\n\n\nIn April 2019, West voted against legislation that would mandate a 50 percent renewable energy target for 2030 over his disapproval of a provision that would provide  with renewable energy subsidies.\n\nIn December 2019, the Maryland Public Interest Research Group gave West a score of 83 percent on its annual legislative scorecard.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, West introduced legislation that would create timelines for Maryland's remaining power plants to transition away from coal and establish a transition fund to mitigate economic impacts for employees. He later withdrew the bill over worries that it would not pass in the House, but announced in March 2021 that he had worked out a deal with  that would cause the  to stop burning coal in 2030.\n\nWest introduced an amendment to the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2021 that would require newly constructed school buildings that use funding from the Build to Learn Act to install rooftop solar panels. The amendment failed by a vote of 15-31. He was also one of two Senate Republicans to vote in favor of passing the climate action plan, which passed the Senate by a vote of 34-11.\n\nIn November 2021, the Maryland  gave West a score of 100 percent on its annual legislative scorecard.\n\nIn March 2022, West introduced an amendment to the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2022 that would require local school systems to consider installing solar panels on roofs of new school buildings, requiring school systems that decide against doing so to explain why to the Interagency Commission on School Construction. The amendment was passed in a 30-14 vote.\n\n\nWest introduced legislation in the 2016 legislative session that would ban off-track betting at the . He later amended the bill to allow off-track betting, but required that the Fairgrounds enter a contract agreement with the Greater Timonium Community Council, and banned  and .\n\nWest introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would legalize  in  and .\n\n\nIn June 2021, West signed onto a letter that urged Governor Larry Hogan to use federal rent relief funding support legislation that would provide low-income tenants with access to legal representation in eviction cases.\n\n\nWest does not support the , saying that he would oppose it until a method to test people for being under the influence of marijuana is developed. West introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would limit companies to operating up to six  through ownership or management agreements. The bill passed and was signed into law at a limit of four dispensaries.\n\nWest introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would allow actively licensed physicians to become a certifying provider of . The bill passed unanimously and became law on May 8, 2020.\n\n\nWest introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would prohibit law enforcement agencies from purchasing certain military equipment through the . The bill passed unanimously in the Senate, but did not receive a vote in the House of Delegates.\n\nIn February 2021, West voted in favor of legislation that would repeal the .\n\nIn April 2021, West co-sponsored legislation that would order police departments to provide  for on-duty police officers by 2025. However, he withdrew his support for the bill after it was amended to include provisions that would create an employee assistance mental health program and implement a statewide use of force policy.\n\nWest introduced two amendments to the Police Reform and Accountability Act of 2021: the first to insert portions of the Senate's Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights repeal into ' bill and the other to establish that law enforcement agencies have the  under a preponderance of the evidence during trial board proceedings and that officers can only be disciplined . Both amendments made it into the final bill.\n\nWest opposed provisions in \"Anton's Law\" that would allow police misconduct complaints to become public, introducing an amendment that would keep unsubstantiated complaints private. The amendment was rejected on a party line vote.\n\n\nIn 2019, West voted in favor of legislation that would make it legal for doctors to prescribe a  to terminally ill patients who want to end their lives. The bill failed to pass out of the Senate, receiving a 23-23 vote. West was the only Republican to vote in favor of the bill.\n\nIn February 2020, West co-sponsored legislation that would make single-occupant bathrooms .\n\nIn August 2020, West signed onto a letter calling on the  system to ban  in the form of  and s.\n\nWest introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would create penalties for vandalizing or destroying historically significant statues in Maryland.\n\nIn February 2021, West cosponsored legislation that would provide students with access to s in school bathrooms. The bill passed and became law on May 30, 2021.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brian Michael Crosby''' (born December 5, 1982) is an American politician from the  and is a member of the  representing .\n\n\nCrosby was born in , . He graduated from  in  in 2001. He attended , where he received a  in business administration. Crosby later attended  where he received his . and was admitted to the  and  in 2008. Starting in 2011, Crosby served in the  after completing . While in the Army, he completed the Infantry Officer Leadership Course, , and  and deployed to  three times. He currently serves as a Captain in the .\n\nIn September 2017, Crosby announced his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 29B, seeking to challenge incumbent  Delegate . He defeated Rey in the  with 53 percent of the vote, or by a margin of about 700 votes.\n\n\nCrosby was sworn in as a member of the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. In 2021,   appointed Crosby to serve as vice chair of the Economic Matters Committee, succeeding Delegate .\n\n\n* Vice-Chair, Economic Matters Committee, 2021–present (member, 2019–present; banking, consumer protection, & commercial law subcommittee, 2019–2020; property & casualty insurance subcommittee, 2019–2020; public utilities subcommittee, 2022–present; vice-chair, workers' compensation subcommittee, 2021–present)\n* Member, Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2021–present\n* Member, Joint Committee on Cybersecurity, Information Technology, and Biotechnology, 2019–2020\n\n\n* Vice-Chair, , 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n\n\n\nCrosby supports the , a sweeping education reform bill passed by the legislature during the 2020 legislative session that would provide schools with $3.8 billion a year for 10 years. He criticized a bill introduced that year that would allow teachers to carry guns in schools, later calling it the \"dumbest policy in American history. Teachers sign up to teach. They don't sign up to go through combat trauma.\"\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Crosby voted for a bill that would prevent school boards from discriminating against people on the basis of race, ethnicity, color, religion, sex, age, national origin, marital status, sexual orientation, gender identity, or disability; the bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 94-36 and the Senate by a 34-13 vote, and became law without the governor's signature. During a debate on the bill, Crosby voted against an amendment that would have blocked public schools from discussing gender and sexuality in the classroom. The amendment failed by a 37-95 vote. He also voted against an amendment that would prohibit transgender students from competing on girls' sports team in schools, which was defeated in a 42-91 vote.\n\n\nIn September 2020, Crosby criticized the Maryland State Board of Elections for only having one early voting center in his county for the .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Crosby introduced legislation that would require elections for county commissioners to only be decided by voters within the districts in which the candidate is running. The bill later passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 95-39. He also proposed legislation that would require buses on fixed routes to stop at early voting centers during elections, which passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 104-32.\n\n\nCrosby supports expanding the .\n\n\nIn 2020, Crosby voted in favor of legislation that would require additional s on secondary firearm transfers.\n\n\nIn 2019, Crosby said that he would support a ballot referendum on legalizing marijuana.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Crosby introduced legislation that would require the Maryland Department of State Police to give  to all on-duty officers by 2022.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Crosby introduced legislation that would abolish  in Maryland. The bill was reintroduced in the 2021 and 2022 legislative sessions.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Crosby voted for a bill that would expand abortion access by providing $3.5 million to train nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and midwives to perform abortions in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Crosby introduced legislation to exempt s from the state , and another bill to exempt s and s from the state's sales tax. Both bills passed unanimously and were signed into law on April 1, 2022.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Wayne McKay''' (born March 5, 1969) is an American politician who has served as a  member of the  representing the , which covers parts of , , and  counties. He was previously the state delegate for  from 2015 to 2023.\n\n\nMcKay was born on March 5, 1969, in Rockville, Maryland. He manages a dry cleaning business, which has four locations in  and .\n\nFrom 2010 to 2014 served as president of the Allegany County Board of County Commissioners and the Cumberland Area Metropolitan Planning Organization. He also served as a member of the Allegany County Board of Education and various other county-level boards.\n\nIn June 2013, McKay announced his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates, seeking to succeed Delegate , who previously announced plans to retire. Following his candidacy announcement, Myers endorsed his bid for the delegate seat. He won the primary election with 56.2 percent of the vote, defeating Republican challenger Ray Givens. McKay's general election opponent, Nick Scarpelli, was financially backed by former state delegate . He defeated Scarpelli in the general election, receiving 57 percent of the vote.\n\n\nMcKay was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015.\n\nIn July 2017, McKay announced that he would not seek re-election in the , instead choosing to seek election as Allegany County Register of Wills. However, McKay was not selected to fill the position after Rebecca Drew, then-Register of Wills, resigned facing misuse of funds allegations, and later filed to run for re-election to the House of Delegates in October 2017.\n\nIn July 2021, McKay announced his candidacy for the  in , seeking to succeed Senator , who previously announced plans to retire.\n\n\n;Maryland Senate\n* Member, Judicial Proceedings Committee, 2023–present\n* Member, Executive Nominations Committee, 2023–present\n* Member, Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2023–present\n* Member, Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 2023–present\n* Member, Joint Subcommittee on Program Open Space and Agricultural Land Preservation, 2023–present\n\n;Maryland House of Delegates\n* Member, Appropriations Committee, 2015–2023 (public safety & administration subcommittee, 2015–2023; oversight committee on pensions, 2015–2017; oversight committee on personnel, 2018–2023; capital budget subcommittee, 2019–2020)\n* Member, Joint Committee on Ending Homelessness, 2015–2023\n* Co-Chair, Study Group on Economic Stability, 2019–2023\n\n\nIn October 2021, he was one of five Maryland state legislators from Garrett, Allegany and Washington counties who sent a pair of letters to West Virginia officials asking about annexation of  to West Virginia. These letters caused a local uproar, with Allegany County officials calling the request a political stunt, an embarrassment and unneeded distraction. Following criticism from local officials and some constituents, Delegate  and State Senator  issued a letter withdrawing support for the secession proposal.\n\n\n\nMcKay supports limiting BOOST funding to schools that don't discriminate in admissions, but opposes the elimination of BOOST, saying that it would be \"discrimination in itself\" and that lawmakers need to have more tolerance for funding s.\n\nMcKay introduced legislation during the 2016 legislative session that would bring an  curriculum to Maryland's public school systems.\n\n\nMcKay opposed legislation introduced in the 2015 legislative session that would impose a three-year moratorium on .\n\n\nMcKay introduced legislation during the 2017 legislative session that would expand  to establish an adult dental option. During the 2018 legislative session, he introduced a bill that would establish a pilot program for adult Medicaid dental coverage. The bill passed and became law. During the 2019 legislative session, McKay introduced legislation that would establish the Adult Dental Pilot Program to provide basic dental insurance to certain individuals between the ages of 21 and 64 that are eligible for both  and Medicaid. The bill passed and became law.\n\n\nMcKay supports the requirement of prevailing wages in public construction contracts. He opposed legislation introduced in the 2019 legislative session that would raise the minimum wage to  by 2025, saying that he was concerned about higher wages resulting in families making too much money to qualify for benefits like  and .\n\n\nIn September 2021, McKay attended a meeting for the Legislative Redistricting Advisory Commission to encourage the commission to keep  whole in its redistricting map. He also encouraged the commission to decrease the size of the .\n\n\nMcKay introduced legislation in the 2017 legislative session that would allow people to kill or wound  if one of the animals threatened a . The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 124-17.\n\nMcKay introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would place  on members of .\n\n\nMcKay introduced legislation in the 2015 legislative session that would lower the corporate tax rate in Washington and Allegany counties from 8.25 percent to 4 percent.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
