    "pages": }\n'''Boyd Kevin Rutherford''' (born April 1, 1957) is an American politician, businessman and attorney who served as the ninth  from 2015 to 2023. \n\nA member of the , Rutherford was nominated by President  to serve as Associate Administrator in the U.S. , serving from 2001 to 2003. He then joined the administration of Governor , serving as the  from 2003 to 2006. Rutherford served as Assistant Secretary for Administration to the  from 2006 to 2009.\n\n\nRutherford was born in  to a  family. His parents worked as a postal worker and as an office worker at the , and his grandmother, Thelma, was a well-known party activist and ally of Washington, D.C. mayor . Rutherford grew up in the  neighborhood of D.C., where he attended public schools until the 8th grade, afterwards graduating from . He earned a bachelor's degree in economics and political science from  in 1979. In 1990, Rutherford earned both a  degree and a master's degree in communications management from the .\n\n\n\nAfter graduating from Howard University, Rutherford worked as an analyst for the  from 1979 to 1981. He then worked as a marketing representative for  until 1986, afterwards working as a senior account executive at  for one year. Rutherford worked as the director of business development at the Kelly Law Registry from 2000 to 2001.\n\nRutherford is a member of the State Bars of  and , as well as the . After earning his Juris Doctor degree, he moved back to Washington, D.C. from , and worked as a litigation associate for various firmsincluding , , and from 1990 to 2000. Rutherford worked as a managing member of Eastwide Strategies LLC from 2010 to 2015, and as a counsel for Benton Potter & Murdock from 2012 to 2015.\n\nRutherford considered himself a  as a young adult. He was a registered Democratic voter while living in Washington, D.C., but left the party and became a Republican when he was in his late thirties, saying that he was fed up with the  and belieivng that the Democratic Party saw African-Americans as \"political and social victims\". He was a member of the  Republican Central Committee from 1996 to 2002, during which he served as the co-director of 's  and campaigned for Howard County councilmember Dennis Schrader's reelection campaign, and served as a delegate to the . Rutherford was a member of the Baltimore City Brownfields Redevelopment Council from 1998 to 2000, and the Corridor Transportation Corporation from 1999 to 2000. In April 2009,  chair  named Rutherford as the RNC's chief administrative officer. He served in this position until 2011.\n\n\n\nIn September 2001, a week after the , President  appointed Rutherford to serve as the associate administrator of the 's Office of Small Business Utilization. He became the associate administrator of the Office of Performance Improvement in 2002. Following the resignation of Michael J. Harrison in January 2006, Bush nominated Rutherford to serve as Assistant Secretary for Administration for the  (USDA), during which he gained a reputation as a tough-minded boss.\n\n\nOn January 7, 2003, Governor-elect  appointed Rutherford as the secretary of the . Ehrlich's transition team chose Rutherford for this position because of his business-oriented mindset, believing that it would help bring better ideas on how to streamline government.\n\nIn May 2004, Rutherford sought to bypass the 's appeals process for a lucrative state contract to build a  crime lab after rejecting a bid from Roy Kirby & Sons, who offered to build the crime lab for $3 million less than the other bidder. Rutherford's basis for rejecting Kirby's bid was based on an investigative report by Warren Wright, a procurement advisor to the board, which detailed Kirby's attempts to obtain insider information about the state's bidding process. Kirby challenged the board's decision to reject his offer to build the crime lab, but later dropped his lawsuit after Rutherford agreed to absolve Kirby of any wrongdoing in connection with the bidding process.\n\nIn October 2004, state legislators criticized Rutherford after '''' reported that the state spent $2.5 million in land preservation funds to purchase an 836-acre tract of forest in  amid negotiations to sell it to an unnamed individualonly referred to as \"the benefactor\" by officialswithout securing a commitment that he would forfeit the right to develop it. ''The Baltimore Sun'' later reported that the unnamed individual was  president and CEO , a prominent political donor who gave $10,000 to the  in 2003 and would have received $7 million in tax breaks for the purchase. Rutherford testified to legislators that Governor Ehrlich personally endorsed the land deal after Rutherford informed him of the details (though Ehrlich later denied any knowledge of the deal), and that the  (DNR) showed Hackerman \"a number of different properties\" and allowed him to select the one he would be interested in purchasing. Rutherford also said that the state would not have purchased the land if Hackerman did not propose the transaction and that he promised to donate development rights in the future and return some of the preserved land to the county for school construction. At the same time, Hackerman told DNR officials that he planned to build houses with waterfront views on the preserved property and sought to block a federal grant that would have allowed the state to permanently preserve the area. In November 2004, Hackerman withdrew from the transaction in a letter to Rutherford and offered to donate $1 million to St. Mary's County so it could purchase part of the protected tract for school construction. After a legislative hearing on the land deal in December 2004, Rutherford told reporters that three of Ehrlich's top aides urged him to pursue the transaction and apologized for concealing Hackerman's identity in discussions about the land deal, saying that it was his idea.\n\n\n\n\nOn January 30, 2014, businessman  named Rutherford as his running mate in the . The two had met while working in the administration of Governor Ehrlich, in which Hogan was the Maryland Secretary of Appointments. During the campaign, he described himself as a  to the governor's chief executive role, pitching a plan that would have Cabinet secretaries report to the lieutenant governor instead of Hogan directly. After winning the Republican primary with 43 percent of the vote in June 2014, the Hogan-Rutherford ticket defeated Lieutenant Governor Anthony Brown and his running mate, Howard County Executive , with 51 percent of the vote in what many considered to be an . Rutherford co-chaired the Hogan transition team with former Maryland business and economic development secretary James T. Brady.\n\nHogan and Rutherford ran for a second term in , during which the two defeated Democratic nominees  and  with 55.4 percent of the vote.\n\n, November 2022]]\nRutherford was seen as the likely Republican frontrunner in the , but he announced in April 2021 that he would not seek to succeed Governor Larry Hogan. During the Republican primary, he endorsed former Maryland Secretary of Commerce . After Schulz was defeated by state delegate  in the primary, Rutherford declined to endorse Cox and correctly predicted that Democratic nominee  would defeat him in the general election. In November 2022, Governor Hogan tasked Rutherford with handling the transition from the current administration to the newly-elected Moore-Miller administration.\n\n\n\nRutherford was sworn in as lieutenant governor on January 21, 2015. He was the third consecutive African American elected as lieutenant governor in Maryland. While Governor Hogan was going through treatment for , Rutherford often acted as governor and chaired meetings on the . During his tenure, Rutherford oversaw the state's efforts to combat the , which focused on expanding prevention and treatment efforts as well as increased monitoring of prescription drugs, and called for increased penalties for heroin dealers. He also coordinated with city officials on the state's response to the , promoted efforts to expand home ownership and combat  in , and supported bills to reform to Maryland's procurement process and to strengthen penalties for violent crime.\n\nIn June 2015, Rutherford attended the  to promote Maryland's aerospace and defense industries. In October 2017, he led a diplomatic mission to France, Belgium, and Estonia to discuss cybersecurity and opioid abuse with European officials. In January 2020, Rutherford traveled to  and  to attend conferences to promote economic development in Maryland.\n\nIn December 2016, Rutherford came under criticism after giving a speech to the  in which he condemned a recent increase in , but added that he didn't know what was causing it. State senator  condemned his remarks in a tweet, to which Rutherford replied, \"You act as though hate is new. It was always there. I'd rather people show their real colors than hide\", prompting further criticism. Rutherford clarified his tweet about a day after posting it, saying that he believed that the United States could benefit from a candid discussion about racially motivated hate and pointing out that he grew up during the .\n\nDuring the , Rutherford oversaw non-COVID-19 portions of the government so that Governor Hogan could focus entirely on the pandemic. He defended the Hogan administration's COVID-19 vaccine rollout and the Board of Public Works's use of emergency procurement powers during the pandemic, and criticized the legislature for overriding Governor Hogan's vetoes on the  and a  tax to pay for the education reform package, citing the .\n\n\nIn January 2023, Rutherford joined , law firm Davis, Agnor, Rapaport & Skalny LLC as a government relations and lobbying personnel. In March 2023, he published ''Rutherford's Travels'', a book that documents his visits to all 76  during his second term as lieutenant governor. In April 2023, Rutherford joined the Dr. Nancy Grasmick Leadership Institute at  as its inaugural senior fellow.\n\n\nRutherford and his wife Monica live in , and they have three adult children; one son and two daughters.\n\n\nIn December 2022, an 187-acre area in  was named the \"Rutherford Area\", in honor of Rutherford.\n\n\nRutherford has described himself as a  and social moderate, distancing himself from the  on issues including  and , and believing in business development as a way to empowerment. As lieutenant governor, Rutherford gained a reputation as a \"policy wonk\".\n\nIn 2012, Rutherford criticized Vice President  for suggesting that Republicans sought to enslave African Americans. In 2013, he condemned  chairman 's contention that Republicans who affiliated with the  were racist, saying that Bond was the reason he was no longer a member of the NAACP. He also rebuked the  for investigating conservative organizations.\n\nDuring his 2014 lieutenant gubernatorial campaign, Rutherford criticized Governor 's rollout of  and economic policies, and expressed support for s and the state's minority-owned businesses. He opposed the , suggesting that its projected $2.45 billion construction cost would be better spent on highway expansion. After Governor Hogan cancelled the  in June 2015, Rutherford suggested a  as an alternative to the transit line.\n\nIn July 2015, Rutherford attended and spoke at an anti- rally in , during which he criticized , especially the , as a terrible situation. He supported bills introduced by Governor  that would require the state to use an  to draw its congressional districts.\n\nRutherford declined to support Republican presidential nominee  in the . In July 2019, he criticized President Trump's  toward the city of Baltimore. In January 2021, following the , Rutherford called Trump's incitement of violence at the  an \"impeachable offense\" and called for Trump's resignation. In an interview following the attack, he told ''The Baltimore Sun'' that he believed that Trump's supporters did not represent the core of the , saying that he and Hogan represented the party's establishment. He also said that Trump \"took advantage of the Republican Party\" and suggested that he did not care about the party.\n\nIn October 2019, Rutherford voted to remove the  from a  plaque that honored both  and  who fought in the , calling the flag a \"divisive symbol that has no place in this or any statehouse\". In June 2020, Rutherford voted to remove the plaque without a replacement; later that month, he voted for a proposal to install a new marker in its place, which failed to pass after the State House Trust deadlocked 2–2.\n\nIn June 2020, Rutherford described the  as a \"turning point in our nation\" and a signal for the county to examine the racism \"that exists just under the surface of many institutions\". He also said he stood with those participating in .\n\nIn December 2020, Rutherford voted to approve a wetlands license for the proposed .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n|votes      = 92,376\n|percentage = 43.0\n}}\n\n|votes      = 62,639\n|percentage = 29.1\n}}\n\n|votes      = 33,292\n|percentage = 15.5\n}}\n\n|votes      = 26,628\n|percentage = 12.4\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n|votes      = 884,400\n|percentage = 51.0\n}}\n\n|votes      = 818,890\n|percentage = 47.2\n}}\n\n|votes      = 25,382\n|percentage = 1.5\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n| votes      =  1,275,644\n| percentage =  55.4\n}}\n\n| votes      = 1,002,639\n| percentage = 43.5\n}}\n\n| votes      = 13,241\n| percentage = 0.6\n}}\n\n| votes      = 11,175\n| percentage = 0.5\n}}\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Richard Stuart Madaleno Jr.''', commonly known as '''Rich Madaleno''' (born June 16, 1965), is an  from . A , he was a member of the , representing the state's 18th district in , which includes  and , as well as parts of ,  and . Madaleno served as chair of the Montgomery County Senate Delegation from 2008 to 2011. He previously served four years in the .\n\nOn July 17, 2017, Madaleno ran for the Democratic nomination for the .\n\n\nGrowing up in , Madaleno was educated at  and . He then went to  where he earned a  in 1987 and a  in 1989.\n\nOn leaving university, Madaleno began his career in Maryland government, working first for the Maryland General Assembly's Department of Fiscal Services, which provides staff support to Senators and Delegates. During this time, he was appointed Senior Analyst for the House Appropriations Committee. In 1995, he was hired by then-Montgomery County Executive  to work for 's Office of Intergovernmental Relations. He served in that capacity until his election to the House of Delegates in 2002. He is considered an expert in the state budget process and serves on the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee.\n\n\nIn 2002, he won one of three seats representing Maryland's 18th district in the House of Delegates. He placed second, out of seven candidates, in the Democratic primary election in September 2002 and, along with his two fellow Democratic nominees, faced no  opponents in the general election.\n\nIn April 2006, incumbent district 18 senator Sharon Grosfeld announced that she would not be running for re-election. Madaleno decided to seek the  seat and quickly established himself as the leading candidate. Indeed, he attracted no primary opponents whatsoever and faced only nominal Republican opposition in November. His was the only open Senate seat in the whole of Maryland that did not see a primary contest. In the , he defeated his Republican opponent by more than three-to-one.\n\n\nIn the Maryland Senate, Madaleno led efforts to advance legislation important to LGBT Marylanders. In 2009, he was the lead sponsor of the Religious Freedom and Civil Marriage Protection Act, which would have legalized same-sex marriage. Although that version of the bill was never voted on,  three years later. Also in 2009, he successfully sponsored legislation with his colleague, Senator , to eliminate the inheritance tax paid by domestic partners on jointly-owned primary residences. The legislation became law in July 2009. In 2014 he successfully sponsored a bill to make  illegal in housing, employment, and public accommodations. In 2018, he introduced legislation to protect young people from the dangers of .\n\nIn 2007, Madaleno sponsored legislation to increase the value of the Maryland Refundable Earned Income Tax Credit, an anti-poverty tool. During a special session later that year, the measure was incorporated into a larger tax bill and became law. In addition, he helped close a tax loophole that was costing Maryland roughly $10 million a year by passing legislation that stops a common business practice of artificially lowering taxable profits by paying rent, a deductible business expense, to shell companies controlled by the same parent company.\n\nMadaleno co-sponsored the law requiring equal pay for equal work. In 2017, when federal funding for  was under threat, he sponsored the law ensuring that funding for  clinics in Maryland would continue. Madaleno co-sponsored a bill to allow counties to enact public financing for county elections. Madaleno co-sponsored a bill to increase the number of s, and he fought attempts by Republicans to close early voting centers in populous areas of Montgomery County.\n\nMadaleno has led efforts to improve public education and worked for equitable distribution of funding to public schools throughout Maryland. Madaleno authored the Hunger-Free Schools Act of 2017; as a result, qualified students across Maryland now receive free breakfast and lunch. Madaleno co-sponsored legislation expanding eligibility for tax credits for college savings and for those saddled with student loan debt, as well as a \"tuition freeze\" for Maryland college students from 2007 to 2010. ''The Washington Post'' credits Madaleno with helping to keep college affordable in Maryland.\n\nMadaleno co-sponsored the law implementing the  in Maryland; a 2017 law against price gouging by generic drug manufacturers; the Firearms Safety Act of 2013, which bans s and s; a number of environmental regulations, including a ban on ; and legislation to improve . In 2017, Madaleno worked with  to restore federal funding for programs that protect the .\n\n\n\nIn May 2017, Madaleno declared his candidacy to be . In February 2018, Madaleno announced that his running mate was business executive and former  appointee . Madaleno would have been the first  and the first openly gay governor of Maryland.\n\nIn the June 2018 primary, Madaleno finished in fifth place for the , which was won by .\n\n\nIn November 2018, it was announced that Madaleno would be nominated to serve as budget director for  Executive .\n\n\n* 2007, 2008, and 2009: Certificate of Appreciation, Maryland Municipal League\n* 2009: Legislative Award, The Arc of Maryland\n* 2014: Consumer Hero, Maryland Consumer Rights Coalition\n* 2016: MLK Courageous Leadership Award, Maryland Citizens' Health Initiative\n\n\nMadaleno was the first person to be elected to the General Assembly as an  candidate. He is also the first openly gay Maryland state senator. Along with Delegates , , , , , ,  and  he formed part of the nine-strong  grouping in the . His election campaigns have won the support of the .\n\nMadaleno is a member of , where he has chaired the  and taught .\n\nHe and his husband, Mark, have two children. They are  homeowners.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Peter Murphy ''' (born July 15, 1949) is an American politician and member of the  who previously represented district 28 in the . In 2014, he was elected President of the .\n\n\n\nMurphy was born in , on July 15, 1949. He has both a  and an  from the , and an Ed.S. Degree in Counseling from . \nHe began his non-political career as a microbiologist for the . There he developed a strong interest in teaching and education and went on to teach science and math at General Smallwood Middle School in . He later directed a large educational testing program at .\n\n\nMember of House of Delegates since January 10, 2007. Member, Ways and Means Committee, 2007- (education subcommittee, 2007-; transportation subcommittee, 2007-).\n\n\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax by 20% - Tax Reform Act of 2007 (HB2)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* sponsored House Bill 30 in 2007, allowing the state to confiscate unused portions of gift certificates after 4 years.\n\n\nMurphy is  . He was one of eight openly  members of the , alongside Sen.  (D–Kensington) and Dels.  (D–Burtonsville),  (D–Takoma Park),  (D–Baltimore),  (D–Baltimore),  (D–Silver Spring) and  (D–Baltimore).\n\nHe is a divorced father of two daughters.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* Official web site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Westley Watende Omari Moore''' (born October 15, 1978) is an American politician, businessman, author, and veteran, serving as the 63rd  since 2023.\n\nMoore was born in Maryland and raised primarily in New York. He graduated from  and received a master's degree from , as a . After several years in the  and , he became an investment banker in New York. Between 2010 and 2015, Moore published five books, including a young-adult novel. He served as CEO of the  from 2017 to 2021. Moore authored '''' and ''The Work.'' He also hosted ''Beyond Belief'' on the , and was executive producer and a writer for ''Coming Back with Wes Moore'' on .\n\nMoore is a member of the . He won the  against  nominee  by a 32% margin, to become Maryland's first African-American governor and the third African-American person elected as governor of any U.S. state.}}\n\n\nMoore was born in  in 1978, to William Westley Moore Jr., a broadcast news journalist, and Joy Thomas Moore, a daughter of immigrants from  and , and a media professional.\n\nOn April 16, 1982, when Moore was three years old, his father died of acute . In the summer of 1984, Moore's mother took him and his two sisters to live in , New York, with her parents. He was occasionally  by ' stepmother, Carol Kirlew. His grandfather, James Thomas, a Jamaican immigrant, was the first Black minister in the history of the . His grandmother, Winell Thomas, a Cuban who moved to Jamaica before immigrating to the U.S., was a retired schoolteacher. Moore attended . When his grades declined and he became involved in , his mother enrolled him in .\n\nIn 1998, Moore graduated  from Valley Forge with an , completed the requirements for the 's early commissioning program, and was appointed a  of  in the . He then attended , from which he graduated  with a B.A. in  and economics in 2001. At Johns Hopkins, he also played wide receiver for the  team for two seasons and was initiated into the , and Sigma Sigma Chapter of the  fraternities. In 1998 and 1999, Moore interned for  . He later became involved with the  before serving in the Army. He also interned at the  under Secretary . \n\nAfter graduating, he attended  as a , where he earned a master's degree in international relations in 2004 and submitted a thesis titled ''Rise and Ramifications of Radical Islam in the Western Hemisphere''. He was activated in the Army following the , and was deployed to  from 2005 to 2006, attaining the rank of  while serving in the . He left the Army in 2014.\n\n\n in January 2020]]\nIn February 2006, Moore was named a  to Secretary of State . He later worked as an investment banker at  in  and at  from 2007 to 2012 while living in . In 2009, Moore was included on 's \"40 Under 40\" list.\n\nIn 2010, Moore founded a television production company, Omari Productions, to create content for networks such as the Oprah Winfrey Network, PBS, , and . In May 2014, he produced a three-part PBS series, ''Coming Back with Wes Moore'', which followed the lives and experiences of returning veterans.\n\nIn 2014, Moore founded BridgeEdU, a company that provided services to support students in their transition to college. Students participating in BridgeEdU paid $500 into the program with varying fees. BridgeEdU was not able to achieve financial stability and was acquired by student financial services company Edquity in 2019, mostly for its database of clients. A '''' interview with former BridgeEdU students found that the short-lived company had mixed results.\n\nIn September 2016, Moore produced ''All the Difference'', a PBS documentary that followed the lives of two young African-American men from the  from high school through college and beyond. Later that month, he launched ''Future City'', an interview-based talk show with Baltimore's  station.\n\nFrom June 2017 until May 2021, Moore was CEO of the , a charitable organization that attempts to alleviate problems caused by poverty in New York City. It works mainly through funding schools,  and shelters. It also administers a disaster relief fund. During his tenure as CEO, the organization also raised more than $650 million, including $230 million in 2020 to provide increased need for assistance during the . Moore also sought to expand his advocacy to include America's poor and transform the organization into a national force in the poverty fight. Moore served on 's board of directors from September 2020 to November 2022, resigning from the board shortly after becoming governor-elect.\n\n\nOn April 27, 2010,  published his first book, ''''. The 200-page book explores the lives of two young Baltimore boys who shared the same name and race, but largely different familial histories that leads them both down very different paths. In December 2012, Moore announced that ''The Other Wes Moore'' would be developed into a feature film, with  attached as an executive producer. In September 2013,  published his second book, ''Discovering Wes Moore''. The book maintains the message and story set out in ''The Other Wes Moore'', but is more accessible to young adults. In April 2021,  announced it would adapt ''The Other Wes Moore'' into a feature film. As of June 2022, a film has yet to be produced.\n\nIn January 2015, Moore wrote his third book, ''The Work''. In November 2016, he wrote ''This Way Home'', a young adult novel about Elijah, a high school basketball player, who emerges from a standoff with a local gang after they attempt to recruit him to their basketball team, and he refuses. In March 2020, Moore and former '''' education reporter Erica L. Green wrote ''Five Days: The Fiery Reckoning of an American City'', which explores the  from the perspectives of eight Baltimoreans who experienced it on the front lines.\n\n\nMoore first expressed interest in politics in June 1996, telling a '''' reporter that he planned to attend law school and enter politics after two years at Valley Forge. He told '''' in October 2022 that he felt the idea of holding elected office \"only started to feel like a real possibility in 2020, when he was about to leave his job running Robin Hood\".\n picnic, 2014]]\nMoore gave a speech at the , supporting  for president. In 2013, he said that he had \"no interest\" in running for public office, instead focusing on his business and volunteer work. Later that year,   said that he considered Moore as his running mate in the , in which he ran with  .\n\nIn April 2015, following the , Moore said that the demonstrations in Baltimore were a \"long time coming\" and that Baltimore \"must seize this moment to redress systemic problems and grow.\" Moore attended the funeral for  but left early to catch a plane to Boston for a speech he was giving on urban poverty. He later said he \"felt guilty being away, but it wasn't just that. An audience in Boston would listen to me talk about poverty, but at a historic moment in my own city's history, I was .\" On the eighth anniversary of Gray's death in April 2023, Moore made a tweet calling his death a \"turning point not just those who knew Gray personally, but the entire city\".\n\nIn February 2017, Governor  nominated Moore to serve on the  Board of Regents.\n\nIn October 2020, Moore was named to serve on the transition team of  . In January 2021, Speaker of the Maryland House of Delegates  consulted with Moore to craft her \"Black agenda\" to tackle  in housing, health, banking, government, and private corporations.\n\n\nIn June 2013, a '''' investigation alleged that Moore was improperly receiving homestead property tax credits and owed back taxes to the city of Baltimore. Moore told ''The Sun'' that he was unaware of any issues with the home's taxes and wanted to pay what they owed immediately. In October 2022,  reported that Moore had not paid any water and sewage charges since March 2021, owing $21,200 to the city of Baltimore. Moore settled his outstanding bills shortly after the article was published.\n\nIn April 2022, the family of Baltimore County Police Sergeant Bruce Prothero, whose murder in 2000 is highlighted in ''The Other Wes Moore'', accused Moore of making contradictory statements about where the proceeds of the book went, saying that the family \"directed no donations\" to anywhere, including the nonprofits Moore named. The family also complained that Moore exaggerated his role in their son's life.\n\nMoore was the subject of a  article in which he was accused of embellishing his childhood and where he actually grew up. Shortly after the article was published, Moore created a website that attempted to rebut the allegations. He was later criticized for failing to correct television interviewers who incorrectly said he received the  during interviews. In August 2024, '''' reported that Moore had falsely claimed that he was awarded the Bronze Star for his military service in his 2006 application for a White House felllowship, which he said was an \"honest mistake\" and that his commanding officer, , suggested he should do it, believing that Moore had earned it and was going through the paperwork to process it, and expressed remorse for the error and for failing to correct interviewers. Fenzel also told the ''New York Times'' that Moore initially objected to mentioning the Bronze Star in his application, but included it after he told Moore that he and others approved the medal and that the paperwork would be processed by the time his fellowship began. Fenzel said that he would resubmit the paperwork so that Moore could be awarded a Bronze Star the week that the ''New York Times'' published their article about Moore's application.\n\nA  article highlighted Moore's connections to various industries, including pharmaceutical, technology, beauty and retail giants, and the  cannabis company. Moore left Green Thumb Industries in March 2022, and said in October that he would use a  to hold his assets and resign from every board position if elected governor. In May 2023, Moore finalized his trust, making him the first governor to have one since .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn February 2021, Moore announced he was considering a run for  in the . He launched his campaign on June 7, 2021, emphasizing \"work, wages, and wealth\" and running on the slogan \"leave no one behind\". His running mate was , a former  who represented  from 2010 to 2019.\n\nDuring the primary, Moore was endorsed by House Majority Leader ,  executive , television host , and former Governor . He also received backing from the  and .\n\nOn April 6, 2022, Moore filed a complaint with the Maryland State Board of Elections against the gubernatorial campaign of , accusing \"an unidentified party\" of anonymously disseminating \"false and disparaging information regarding Wes Moore via electronic mail and social media in an orchestrated attempt to disparage Mr. Moore and damage his candidacy.\" The complaint also suggested that King \"may be responsible for this smear campaign\", which the King campaign denied. In April 2024, King's campaign was fined $2,000 after prosecutors connected the email address to an IP address used by Joseph O'Hearn, King's campaign manager.\n\nMoore won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, defeating former  chairman  and Comptroller  with 32.4% of the vote. During the general election, Moore twice campaigned with U.S. President . He also campaigned on reclaiming \"patriotism\" from Republicans, highlighting his service in the U.S. Army while also bringing attention to  nominee and state delegate 's participation in the . Moore defeated Cox in the general election, and became Maryland's first Black governor and the first veteran to be elected governor since .\n\nIn December 2022, Moore was elected to serve as finance chair of the .\n\n\n\nMoore was sworn in on January 18, 2023. He took the  on a  owned by abolitionist , as well as his grandfather's Bible. The morning before his inauguration, Moore participated in a wreath-laying ceremony at the - Memorial at the  to \"acknowledge the journey\" that led to him becoming the third elected Black governor in U.S. history. Later that night, he held a celebratory event at the .\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Moore testified for several of his administration's bills, making him the first governor to do so since .\n\n\nMoore began announcing nominations for his 26-member cabinet on November 14, 2022. He finished announcing his cabinet nominees on April 12, 2023, with the nomination of Sanjay Rai as Secretary for the Maryland Higher Education Commission. According to '''', Moore assembled his cabinet at a slower pace than previous Maryland governors. \n\nTwelve of Moore's cabinet nominees are women and 14 are people of color. His nominees have mixed experience in government, social entrepreneurship, and philanthropy. Three of them, Secretary of Emergency Management Russell Strickland,  superintendent Roland Butler, and  Carolyn Scruggs, are holdovers from the Hogan administration.\n\nAs his , Moore chose Fagan Harris, who co-founded the Baltimore Corps organization with Moore a decade ago. Moore also named three members of the Maryland General Assembly to his administration: state senator  as Director of the Maryland Energy Administration; state senator  as ; and  Majority Leader  as chief legislative officer. Other notable Cabinet nominations included  mayor  as Secretary of Housing and Community Development, former  commissioner  as ,  as Secretary of Veterans Affairs, and former  general manager  as .\n\nAll but two of Moore's cabinet nominees were unanimously confirmed by the : Schiraldi, who faced opposition from Republicans over his policies toward juvenile justice reform; and Butler, whose critics claimed had not done enough to address complaints of racism and disparate treatment of Black officers in the Maryland State Police.\n\n\nDuring an August 2006 interview with , Moore said he identified as a \"social moderate and strong fiscal conservative\". In September 2022, he reiterated his position on fiscal issues as being \"fiscally responsible\". During his gubernatorial campaign, he was described as center-left, as well as .\n\nMoore has cited , , and  as his political role models.\n\n\n\n, 2023]]\nMoore supports hiring more probation and parole officers, pursuing police misconduct allegations, and increasing resources for law enforcement agencies. In February 2022, he unveiled a public safety plan that includes improving offender services, improving police diversity, and supporting and funding community-based policing and violence intervention programs. Moore says he \"believes in policing with maximum accountability and appropriate intensity\", and would provide funding for community-based violence intervention programs to address violent crime. In an interview with  on August 30, 2022, Moore said that he would tackle crime in Baltimore by investing in violence intervention programs like Safe Streets and We Our Us. In September 2022, Moore said he would use the \"bully pulpit\" of the governor's office to help recruit officers and would give the state's  a seat at the table, telling '''', \"I don't think that you can be serious about actually implementing reforms if the agencies that have to be reformed are not part of the process.\"\n\nMoore has blamed his predecessor, Governor , for increased violent crime in Maryland, citing his lack of collaboration between his administration and local leaders and legislators. During his campaign, he called on Hogan to target state resources toward preventing gun violence in Baltimore and campaigned on addressing crime in the city through better cooperation between the city and state, and to leverage these relationships on the federal level to bring more resources into the city. In January 2023, Moore told  that he supported a bill that would prohibit charging juveniles with .\n\nIn January 2023, following the release of videos capturing the arrest and police assault of , Moore condemned the brutality of the police and thanked the  for opening an investigation into Nichols's death. He later said in an interview that Nichols's death only highlighted the need to tackle injustice head-on.\n\nIn February 2023, Moore pledged $11 million in funding for the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center, an agency that serves as a data-sharing platform for law enforcement officials across the state. He also said that his administration would not use a  for traffic stops and arrests after a ''Baltimore Banner'' investigation found that Maryland State Police supervisors previously demanded troopers hit targets for traffic stops and arrests. In June 2023, Moore released $5 million in funding from the  toward youth intervention efforts to deter violent crime around the state.\n\nIn July 2023, following mass shootings in  and Salisbury that left a combined three dead and 34 injured, Moore released a statement expressing his condolences and spoke in support of gun violence prevention efforts in Baltimore. He ruled out calls to form a special session to pass legislation to address gun violence, saying it was not needed, but said he supported increased policing and longer sentences for repeat violent offenders.\n\nIn January 2024, Moore introduced three bills aimed at improving public safety, including one to create apprenticeships in public safety to increase law enforcement retention and another to compensate victims of crime. He also expressed support for lengthening probation periods for violent juvenile offenders and increasing the severity for gun crimes from misdemeanors to felonies, and another bill to restrict sex offenders' ability to earn \"good time\" credits that reduce their sentence following the murder of . He also supported a bill that would allow minors to be charged with certain crimes and enable courts to extend probation limits for juveniles.\n\nIn October 2024, after a  student with a prior criminal record was charged with first-degree murder, Moore ordered a review of how state agencies share information about public school students with violent criminal records.\n\n\n, 2023]]\nAs governor, Moore is a member of the a constitutionally appointed body that oversees many aspects of the state's financesalong with the  and the . During his first board meeting in January 2023, Moore said the state would work to include more diverse businesses in state contracts.\n\nIn November 2022, Moore said that he would not support spending state funds to keep the  in Maryland. The Commanders are contractually obligated to play at  until September 2027. In April 2023, he said he supported spending some taxpayer money on a new Commanders football stadium \"if we know there's going to be a significant societal return on the investment\".\n\nIn December 2022, Moore said he supported bringing the new  headquarters to Prince George's County, calling it a \"personal priority\". In March 2023, Moore joined Democratic members of Maryland's congressional delegation and Prince George's County Executive  in co-signing a letter to President  asking him to get involved in the FBI's headquarters selection process. In November 2023, the  announced that it would locate the FBI's new headquarters in .\n\nIn February 2023, Moore announced a $600 million five-year partnership with the  to develop properties around . In September, he and Orioles CEO  announced a  that would extend the team's lease by 30 years, open development rights inside the park to private developers, and give the Orioles control over stadium operations and maintenance. The stadium lease was finalized in December, but an agreement on the team's ground lease and redevelopment plan was postponed until 2027 following concerns from Senate President .\n\nIn May 2024, Moore signed into law a bill that would transfer ownership of the  to the Maryland Thoroughbred Racetrack Operating Authority, allowing for a state-funded, multi-million dollar renovation project of the race course's track to begin and for the construction of a new training center at a separate location. The bill would also consolidate thoroughbred racing in Maryland to Pimlico and have the Maryland state government assume responsibility over racing operations at the course by next year.\n\n\nMoore supports the  reform effort, testifying before the state legislature to urge its passage. During his campaign, he said that he would \"work closely with local governments to make sure they are on board with their commitments to the Blueprint\". In September 2022, Moore said he would institute  and apprenticeship and trade programs in schools, and promised increases for school construction, educator wages, after-school programs, tutoring, child care, and early childhood education. In his first budget in January 2023, Moore proposed allocating $500 million toward funding the Blueprint, which was later increased to $900 million by state legislators.\n\nMoore does not support the expansion of s, saying that he wants to focus on improving public school districts, but wants to ensure accountability for current charters. In his first budget, in January 2023, Moore cut funding for the state's Broadening Options and Opportunities for Students Today (BOOST) program to provide scholarships to students attending charter schools by $2 million, and introduced new eligibility limits for current BOOST students and their siblings. In an interview with '''', Moore said he intended to get rid of the BOOST program in a few years, adding, \"The focus that I have, the focus that our administration is going to have, is making sure that we are creating and developing world-class public schools for our students.\" The budget was amended to reduce these cuts by $1 million in March 2023, and signed into law in April.\n\nMoore supports creating a \"service year option\" in schools, which would enable high school graduates to do a gap year \"in exchange for job training, mentorship, and other support including compensatory tuition at a state college or university.\" On January 19, 2023, Moore signed an executive order creating the Maryland Department of Service and Civic Innovation, a cabinet-level agency responsible for establishing a service-year option for all high school graduates. In February, he introduced the SERVE Act to create the \"service year option program\", which would pay young people $15 per hour for at least 30 hours a week for work in service to the community. The SERVE Act was signed into law in April 2023. The service year program launched with 280 participating students in October 2023.\n\nIn November 2022, Moore called a plan to cancel up to $20,000 in  a \"good first step\" and said he would push the Biden administration to forgive more federal student debt if elected governor.\n\nIn May 2023, during a commencement speech at , Moore criticized efforts to  and  in schools, suggesting that politicians who sought to \"silence or rewrite the history of Black and brown people are actually afraid of people understanding their power\".\n\nIn June 2023, Moore said he opposed the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling in '''', which held that race-based  in college admissions violated the , calling it a \"misguided ruling\".\n\n\nDuring his campaign, Moore criticized the Hogan administration for a \"failure of executive leadership\" on fighting . He supports the renewable energy goals set by the state's Clean Energy Jobs Act of 2019, which called for a 50% reduction in  and an electrification of the state's vehicle fleet by 2030, and has said the state should pursue \"more ambitious goals\" beyond . He also proposed regulations to achieve 100% clean energy use by 2035 and net zero carbon emissions by 2045, electrify the state's fleet, and prioritize environmental-justice funding. Moore also said that he would establish a \"cap-and-invest\" program in Maryland, which would tax polluters to provide revenue for clean energy infrastructure and relief in communities of color, and promised to hire a \"climate czar\" in his administration, whom he appointed in November 2023.\n\nMoore said he would support  by promoting \"accountability and enforcement\" in Maryland, as well as in neighboring states, use federal funds to upgrade water and wastewater systems, and by increasing the number of environmental inspectors. In October 2022, he told '''' that he would develop a plan to accelerate projects to improve water quality and cut carbon emissions in his administration's first 100 days, and supported the restoration of the state's Chesapeake Bay Restoration Fund. In July 2023, Moore signed an executive order to refocus cleanup efforts onto shallow areas of the bay, and another establishing the Council on the Chesapeake and Coastal Bays to research state policy on oyster restoration and harvesting. In October 2023, he was appointed as the chair of the .\n\nIn April 2022, Moore signed a  pledge to support legislation to get Maryland to use 100 percent carbon-free electricity by 2035 and to remove trash incineration from the state's \"clean energy\" classification. In March 2023, he set a goal of achieving 8.5 gigawatts of  generation in the state by 2031, which was later codified after he signed the POWER Act in April 2023.\n\nIn October 2022, Moore told ''Lancaster Farming'' that he would support farmers by eliminating burdensome regulations, preserving farmland, and giving farmers technical assistance and financial resources.\n\nIn February 2023, Moore introduced the Clean Transportation and Energy Act, which increases incentives for people and businesses looking to purchase s and s. In March 2023, he said he supported adopting California's Advanced Clean Cars II (ACC II) regulation, which would phase out the sale of gas-powered cars in the state by 2035. In April 2023, he signed the Clean Transportation and Energy Act and several other bills aimed at strengthening the state's offshore wind energy industry into law. In August 2023, Moore said he supported a proposal by then-Governor Hogan to delay  on new cars from three to six years, despite initially withdrawing the proposal earlier in his term due to equity concerns, after the  found that the change would have no severe impacts on equity.\n\n\n rally in , 2023]]\nIn 2022, Moore supported a bill to ban the possession and sale of s in Maryland. He supports creating a firearms database to help law enforcement track guns used in crimes. In June 2022, Moore condemned the Supreme Court's ruling in '''', calling it a \"misguided and dangerous decision.\" He also opposed Governor Hogan's decision to suspend the state's \"good and substantial reason\" standard for obtaining a concealed carry permit following the ruling.\n\nIn January 2023, Moore attended a  rally in , where he said he would support the Gun Safety Act of 2023. The bill would increase the requirements and fees to obtain a handgun permit, strengthen  requirements, and prohibit gun owners from carrying guns near schools, government property, construction areas, or entertainment venues, and from entering someone's property while carrying a firearm unless given permission by the owner. Moore signed the bill into law on May 16, 2023. That same day, the  (NRA) filed a lawsuit in federal court challenging the law's location restrictions. In September 2023, two days before the law was set to go into effect, U.S. District Judge  blocked sections of the bill restricting open carry near public demonstrations and private buildings, but upheld the remainder of the bill.\n\nIn November 2023, Moore expressed disappointment with a  ruling that struck down a provision of the state's Firearm Safety Act of 2013 that required handgun owners to obtain a \"handgun qualification license\" to buy a handgun.\n\n\nIn an interview with '''' before becoming governor, Moore expressed support for the End-of-Life Options Act, which would allow terminally ill adults to request .\n\nIn January 2023, Moore proposed providing members of the  with free health and dental care; legislators later amended the bill to cap monthly reimbursements at $60 a month. In May 2023, he signed into law the Josh Siems Act, a bill that would require emergency rooms to include fentanyl testing in toxicology screens.\n\n\nMoore has described himself as a \"\". He supports the  in eviction cases, saying that providing tenants with access to counsel is \"the just thing to do and it is the right thing to do\". On his campaign website, Moore says he would address the \"unfair appraisal values in historically redlined neighborhoods\" and provide increased funding for the . During a town hall in August 2023, Moore suggested that nonprofits could be used to help lower housing costs in addition to increasing the state's affordable housing inventory and supporting current homeowners.\n\nIn January 2024, Moore introduced bills to increase federal funding and reducing barriers for affordable housing projects in the state, especially those around s, as well as legislation establishing a \"Tenant's Bill of Rights\" and providing additional protections to renters against evictions. While Moore's tenant protections bills passed the legislature unchanged, legislators opted to weaken the Housing Expansion and Affordability Act by removing provisions that would block jurisdictions from using an adequate public facilities ordinance to block the construction of affordable housing and modifying the qualifications needed for affordable housing projects to be eligible for density bonuses.\n\nIn October 2024, Moore signed an executive order aimed at removing 5,000 of Baltimore's 13,000 vacant homes within five years.\n\n\nMoore supports a balance between securing the United States' borders and creating  for those already in the country. In June 2023, Moore announced he would support efforts to strengthen the federal  policy for immigrants living in the United States. He also said he did not support sending members of the  to the .\n\n\nMoore supported legislation introduced and passed during the 2022 legislative session that created a , and another bill that would regulate marijuana possession should the referendum pass in November. During his campaign, he has talked about implementing a recreational cannabis industry with a focus on equity \"so that communities that have experienced the greatest disparities benefit the most.\" In October 2022, Moore praised President 's pardon of thousands of people convicted of marijuana possession under federal law, and said that he would \"fight to expunge the records of those arrested for marijuana possession [as governor]\".\n\nIn January 2023, Moore signed an executive order releasing $46.5 million to start developing the framework for a recreational marijuana industry in the state, with a majority of the released funds going toward grants for minority-owned firms. In May 2023, he signed a bill regulating the state's recreational marijuana industry.\n\nIn May 2023, Moore allowed a bill that prohibits police from stopping a vehicle solely based on if they smell marijuana to become law without his signature.\n\nIn June 2024, Moore signed an executive order pardoning about 100,000 people with low-level cannabis-related convictions in Maryland.\n\n\n at a campaign event in November 2022]]\nIn July 2019, Moore criticized President 's  toward the city of Baltimore.\n\nMoore supports a  to the . In December 2022, he attended the Jewish Community Relations Council of Greater Washington's legislative breakfast, where he said he would be \"very aggressive\" in promoting trade between Maryland and  and promised that one of his first overseas visits would be to Israel. He expressed solidarity with Israel amid the , and later supported an immediate ceasefire in the . In October 2024, Moore criticized a  event at the  held on the one-year anniversary of the October 7 attack to honor Palestinian civilians killed in the Israel–Hamas war, saying that he felt that it was an \"inappropriate date for such an event\".\n\n\nIn June 2021, Moore opposed  introduced by state senator , calling it \"voter suppression\". In September 2022, Moore said he opposed a lawsuit filed by state delegate  against the Maryland State Board of Elections to block the early counting of Maryland's mail-in ballots in the 2022 elections, alleging that Cox was trying to sow distrust and uncertainty in the electoral system. In April 2023, Moore signed a bill to allow counties to begin counting mail-in ballots before Election Day. Before this bill was enacted, Maryland was the only state that restricted the processing of absentee ballots until after Election Day, according to the .\n\n, 2023]]\nIn 2022, Moore said he supported the Inclusive Schools Act, a bill introduced in the 2022 legislative session that bans schools from discriminating against students based on their sexual orientation and gender identity. He also supported the Trans Health Equity Act, a bill that would have required the state's  program to cover gender-affirming treatment. In December 2022, Moore praised the signing of the , which codifies same-sex and interracial marriage rights. On March 31, 2023, Moore became the first Maryland governor to recognize  when he issued an official proclamation. In May 2023, he signed the Trans Health Equity Act into law and allowed a bill furthering an earlier repeal of the  to become law without his signature. In June 2023, Moore signed an executive order to protect people or entities that provide gender-affirming care from legal punishments by other states.\n\nIn June 2022, following the 's ruling in '''', Moore said that he would support an amendment to the  to enshrine abortion access. He also pledged to release $3.5 million in funding for the Abortion Care Access Act, a bill passed in the 2022 legislative session that would expand the types of medical professionals who can perform , on his first day in office. On January 19, 2023, Moore signed his first executive order releasing $3.5 million in funding for training healthcare providers in abortion care under the Abortion Care Access Act. In February 2023, Moore joined the , an interstate gubernatorial agreement led by   intended to strengthen abortion access in member states. In May 2023, he signed a pair of bills into law aimed at protecting patients seeking an abortion and increase access to abortion medication, and a bill creating a  on codifying the right to abortion access into the Maryland Constitution. In February 2024, Moore criticized the 's ruling in '''', which held that s had the same rights as children, calling it \"out of step\".\n\nIn April 2023, after a federal court ruling in '''' repealed the 's approval of , Moore said the state would begin stockpiling enough of the abortion pill to last two and a half years. In June 2023, he voted to approve $1.3 million toward purchasing 30,000 doses of mifepristone and 5,000 doses of .\n\nIn April 2023, following an investigation by Maryland Attorney General  into  in the , Attorney General  released a 463-page report accusing the archdiocese of covering up more than 600 cases of child sexual abuse against 156 Catholic priests over 60 years. On April 11, 2023, Moore signed the , which eliminates the  on child sexual abuse lawsuits.\n\nIn May 2024, Moore signed into law a bill to ban the sale of speculative tickets and require ticket vendors to provide consumers with the full price of the ticketincluding taxes and feesand refunds if the ticket is counterfeit or if the event is canceled.\n\n\n, March 2024]]\nMoore opposed Governor Hogan's decision to cancel the , and said during his campaign that he supported restarting the rail project. During his campaign, he called for an \"intermodal Red Line, that is built quickly, cost-effectively, and with community input on stops, disruptions, and impact on local businesses\". In November 2022, Moore said he would support creating a regional transit authority for working on projects. On June 15, 2023, Moore announced that he would seek federal funding to restart efforts to build the Red Line.\n\nMoore does not support Governor Hogan's plan to widen portions of the  and  using s, saying that he would instead support a transit line alongside I-270 and a proposed transit line from  to . Critics have accused Moore of  on this stance after he told the Maryland Transit Opportunities that he would be willing to dedicate federal funds to the project, issuing a statement afterwards saying that he would be open to toll lanes if there were strong public consensus. In a radio interview with  in July 2022, he said he preferred a \"new type of proposal\" for the I-270 toll lanes plan that included s, increased transit, and greater collaboration with local \"stakeholders.\" In August 2023, Moore requested $2.4 billion in federal funding to add s to parts of the Capital Beltway and I-270, and to rebuild the .\n\nIn December 2022, Moore said he would view all transportation issues, including the I-270 and I-495 expansion efforts, through a \"lens\" of equity, environmental protection, and local partnership.\n\nIn his first budget in January 2023, Moore proposed allocating $500 million toward unspecified transportation projects. When asked by the  if this money would be used for the Red Line, Moore said that he had spoken with federal officials about restarting the line and that he did not want to \"start from scratch\". He also said he planned to use federal funds and public-private partnerships in transportation projects, including the  and Red lines. The budget was amended to reduce this funding to $100 million, but also gave the governor the ability to tap the state's \"rainy day\" fund for an extra $100 million.\n\nIn July 2023, after the  announced that the opening of the  would be delayed until spring 2027, Moore promised to complete the Purple Line during his tenure and to prevent future delays. After the Purple Line was further delayed in March 2024, Moore blamed his predecessor, Larry Hogan, for creating \"boondoggles of challenges\" that led to delays on the rail line project.\n\nIn December 2023, facing a long-term budget shortfall, Moore announced a six-year plan to cut the state's transportation budget by $3.3 billion, or eight percent, including a $1.6 billion cut to \"all major highway expansion construction projects\" and a $652 million cut to transit expansion projects. The proposed plan would reduce commuter bus services and lines, delay the state's transition to es, and cancel plans to expand the . He later announced a one-year infusion of $150 million to the state's transportation fund, with most of the added funding being used to restore highway user revenue funding, to ease the effects of the cuts. Although the legislature included provisions to raise fees on vehicle registration for electric vehicles and heavier cars to prevent drastic cuts to the state's transportation projects, the Moore administration again proposed $1.3 billion in cuts to Maryland's transportation budget in September 2024, which would delay various infrastructure projects around the state, including the widening of the  and the state's transition to electric buses.\n\nIn March 2024, following the , Moore declared a state of emergency and called the disaster a \"global crisis\". He also thanked Maryland Transportation Authority Police officers for closing the bridge after receiving mayday calls from the '''', which prevented additional deaths during the collapse. In the legislature, Moore supported the PORT Act, a bill introduced by Senate President  to provide $60 million in financial assistance to workers and businesses affected by the subsequent closure of the  and introduced a bill that would create a permanent state scholarship for the children of surviving spouses of maintenance workers killed during the bridge collapse, which was later amended into the PORT Act.\n\nIn October 2024, Moore said he supported the widening of .\n\n\n\nBefore taking office, Maryland's economic outlook was among the lowest in the nation, according to the . Over the past decade, the state's  (GDP) had only grown by 11 percent, compared to a 23 percent growth nationally, and ranked in the bottom 10 states in several economic factors, including economic momentum, change in personal income, and population growth. At the same time, the state had a $2.5 billion budget surplus from a combination of  and a tightening of state spending, $2.9 billion in its \"rainy day fund\", and low unemployment numbers.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Moore introduced the Innovation Economy Infrastructure Act, which would provide $10 million in grants for \"infrastructure projects in eligible technology sectors\"; the Access to Banking Act, which incentives banking institutions to locate in low- and moderate-income areas of the state; and the Broadband Expansion Act, which initially offered tax incentives to the broadband internet industry but was later watered down to a bill to study how to incentivize broadband expansion. All three bills were signed into law in May 2023.\n\nIn May 2023, Moore signed an executive order creating the Innovation and Impact Council, which would investigate ways the state could partner with businesses and nonprofits to address social and equity issues. In June, he signed another executive order to establish the Maryland Economic Council, which was tasked with developing economic development strategies for the state.\n\nIn August 2023, following a report from the Maryland Department of Legislative Services predicting that the state's budget deficits would increase to $1.8 billion annually by 2028, Moore cautioned that the state would enter a \"season of discipline\". He also pledged to hire a chief performance officer, later naming Asma Mirza, the deputy for implementation management for the White House Infrastructure Implementation Team, to the position.\n\nIn October 2023, Moore said he would support giving municipalities the ability to designate local \"tourism zones\".\n\n\n union members, 2023]]\nBefore taking office, the Maryland Department of Legislative Services reported a \"historically high\" level of vacancies in state government, with only three departments in the executive branch having vacancy rates lower than 10 percent. During his campaign, Moore promised to fill 5,000 vacancies within his first year in office, and included raises up to 18 percent for state employees to incentivize recruitment and retention. As of October 2023, only 791 positions had been filled, according to data from the Maryland Department of Legislative Services.\n\nIn February 2023, Moore said he would scrap the 's controversial contract process to run concessions operations at . In March, he promised to include a \"labor peace\" agreement in future BWI concessions operations contracts. The BWI contract bidding process restarted in September 2023, and includes provisions to include the labor peace agreement, which would allow service workers to unionize but prohibited .\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Moore will introduce the Families Serve Act, which would allow employers to give preference to s in hiring; and the Time to Serve Act, which doubles the amount of days of leave state employees can take to fulfill duties in military reserves. He also supported bills to ban discrimination toward military members in hiring.\n\n\nDuring his campaign, Moore said that he would accelerate the state's incremental increase to a minimum wage of  by 2023. He also supports indexing the state's minimum wage to inflation. At the beginning of the 2023 legislative session, Moore introduced the Fair Wage Act, a bill that would accelerate the state's minimum wage build-up to reach $15 an hour by October 2023 and index the minimum wage to the  starting in July 2025, with increases capped at five percent per year. The Senate Finance Committee amended the bill to remove provisions linking it to the consumer price index and delayed the wage increase until January 1, 2024. Moore signed the bill into law on April 11, 2023. He also allocated $218 million in his first budget to support state service providers in keeping up with the accelerated wage increase.\n\n\nDuring his tenure as CEO of the , Moore pushed for New York legislators and Governor  to expand the state's child tax credit, and lobbied for the issue to be mentioned in Cuomo's State of the State speech.\n\nDuring his campaign, Moore repeatedly said that he does not anticipate raising taxes as governor, but said in September 2022 that he planned to work with the legislature to fix what he described as the state's \"upside-down taxation system\". In January 2024, he expressed openness to raising taxes to address the state's budget shortfall, but said that any conversation about taxes would have a \"very high bar\".\n\nIn May 2022, following a spike in gas prices as the result of the , Moore said he supported staving off automatic increases to the state's , arguing that voters needed immediate relief and later calling it a \"regressive tax\". In September 2022, Moore told the Maryland Family Network that he would support child care programs by subsidizing the service through tax credits for low-income families. He also expressed interest in eliminating either the state's  or  to make the state more attractive to retirees. In June 2023, Moore said he supported shifting transportation funding away from the state's gas tax as well as decoupling it from inflation, but opposed calling a special session to do so, instead preferring to pass tax reforms during the 2024 legislative session.\n\nIn his first budget in January 2023, Moore introduced the Family Prosperity Act, which allocates $171 million toward making permanent the  passed by lawmakers in 2021, and the Keep Our Heroes Home Act, which provides $33 million for expanding tax exemptions for military retirement income; legislators later scaled down the Keep Our Heroes Home Act to only raise the state's income exemption limit to $20,000 for older veterans and $12,500 for younger ones. Moore signed both bills into law in April and May 2023, as well as another bill to allow workers to deduct  from their .\n\n\n in 2010]]\nIn September 2010, Moore testified in support of reauthorizing the  federal assistance program. In July 2021, he opposed Governor Hogan's decision to end expanded federal unemployment benefits provided by the  early. In December 2022, Moore said he supported indexing the state's maximum unemployment insurance payment to inflation.\n\nIn August 2022, Moore supported protests led by veterans at the  to pass the , which would provide benefits for veterans exposed to s and other toxic phenomena.\n\nDuring his gubernatorial campaign, Moore said he supported establishing a state \"\" program, which would cost roughly $100 million per year and be seeded with $3,200 for every child born on Medicaid, to target the racial . If enacted, it would be the largest baby bond program ever enacted in the United States.\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Moore introduced the ENOUGH Act, a bill to provide $15 million in grants toward underserved communities.\n\n\n\nMoore met  in  in 2002. They moved to the  community in  in 2006. The couple eloped in Las Vegas while he was on a brief leave from Afghanistan and were married by an . Their official wedding ceremony was held on July 6, 2007. They have two children, born 2011 and 2013.\n\nIn late 2008, the Moores moved from Riverside to , where they lived until Moore's election as governor in 2022. They reside in , the official residence of the Maryland governor and First Family in .\n\nFrom 2015 to 2023, Moore attended services at the Southern Baptist Church in east Baltimore.\n\nIn July 2023, Moore received an honorary degree from the . He is a member of the . His ancestor Prince Ames served in the  in the Revolutionary War.\n\n\nMoore's decorations and medals include:\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 217,524\n| percentage = 32.4\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 202,175\n| percentage = 30.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 141,586\n| percentage = 21.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 26,594\n| percentage = 4.0\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 25,481\n| percentage = 3.8\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 24,882\n| percentage = 3.7\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 13,784\n| percentage = 2.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 11,880\n| percentage = 1.8\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 4,276\n| percentage = 0.6\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 2,978\n| percentage = 0.4\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 1,293,944\n| percentage = 64.53\n| change = +21.02\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes = 644,000\n| percentage = 32.12\n| change = -24.23\n}}\n\n| party = Libertarian Party (United States)\n| votes = 30,101\n| percentage = 1.50\n|change = +0.93\n}}\n\n| party = Working Class Party\n| votes = 17,154\n| percentage = 0.86\n| change = N/A\n}}\n\n| party = Green Party (United States)\n| votes = 14,580\n| percentage = 0.73\n| change = +0.25\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''The other Wes Moore : one name, two fates'', New York : Spiegel & Grau, 2010. \n* ''Discovering Wes Moore : My Story'', New York : Ember (Random House), 2013. \n* ''The work : searching for a life that matters'', New York : Spiegel & Grau, 2015. \n*Wes Moore;     "pages": }\n'''Joanne Claybon Benson''' (born March 11, 1941) is an  who represents  in the . She formerly represented District 24 in the .\n\n\nBenson was born on March 11, 1941, in . She attended  and then graduated from  with a  in education in 1961. She later attended  where she earned her  in curriculum instruction in 1972.\n\n\nBenson was a member of House of Delegates from 1991 to 2011. She served on the House Health and Government Operations Committee and its health occupations subcommittee, long-term care subcommittee, and its minority  subcommittee. She is also a member and former chair of the . She still presides at the Caucus meetings, providing an inspirational prayer as the Caucus' chaplain.\n\nIn 2010 she defeated incumbent state senator  and was sworn into office in January 2011. In 2020 she was selected to be the Senate's Deputy Majority leader and has been chairman of the Senate Rules committee since 2019.\n\nIn 2019, Benson worked with   to  the sentence of Curtis Brooks, who had been sentenced as a juvenile to life in prison without parole.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Benson introduced legislation to ban the manufacture or sale of s.\n\n\nIn 2022, Benson voted against legislation to legalize  in Maryland. She also voted against a bill to place a referendum legalizing recreational marijuana on the 2022 ballot.\n\n\nIn 2019, Benson voted in favor of legislation to raise the state's minimum wage to , but expressed disappointment with the date's effective date of 2025.\n\n\nIn 1991, Benson voted in favor of legislation to protect the right to abortion in Maryland.\n\nBenson opposed the Religious Freedom and Civil Marriage Protection Act, a bill introduced in 2011 to legalize , saying that she did not view gay marriage as a civil rights issue. Although she was absent for the vote on the bill, she said she would have voted against it. In 2012, she voted against the .\n\nIn 2022, Benson supported legislation to provide  to all Maryland workers, saying that paid family leave \"should not be viewed as a privilege, but as something that is humane and just\".\n\n\nIn 2013, Benson voted in favor of legislation to raise es in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Benson introduced legislation to hold the  to promises it made for the widening of  and  and modernizing the . The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 101–35 in March, but did not receive a vote in the Senate.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Catherine I. Riley''' (March 21, 1947 – September 30, 2024) was an American lobbyist, civil servant and politician from . She represented  in the  from 1975 to 1982 and in the  from 1983 to 1990.\n\n\nCatherine I. Riley was born in , on March 21, 1947. She attended parochial schools in . She graduated in 1969 with a  from .\n\n\nRiley served in  representing  from 1975 to 1982. She also represented  in the  from 1983 to 1990. She ran as a .\n\nIn 1995, Governor  hired Riley to his legislative lobbying team. She continued in that role and was appointed by Glendening to serve on the  on May 21, 1999. She was appointed head of the Commission on October 18, 2000 by Glendening after  announced he was stepping down. She served in that role until 2003.\n\n\nRiley was friends with fellow senator  She died on September 30, 2024, at the age of 77.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| footnotes           = \n}}\n'''Mark Kennedy Shriver''' (born February 17, 1964) is an American  politician who served as a member of the  for two consecutive terms, from 1995 to 2003.\n\nSince 2014, he has served as President of Save the Children Action Network, where he campaigns to end child mortality. He is also Senior Vice President of U.S. Programs & Advocacy of Save the Children.\n\n\nShriver was born in  He is part of the , since his mother was . He is also a part of the prominent  since his ancestor  was a delegate of , who signed the Maryland Constitution and Bill of Rights at Maryland's Constitutional Convention of 1776. His father is , the first director of the  upon its establishment by President John F. Kennedy on March 1, 1961, a former ambassador to  and the 1972 Democratic vice presidential candidate. His sister, , is a former journalist and the former First Lady of  (she was married to former Governor of California  until mid-year 2011). His brother, , served as a city council member and mayor of Santa Monica, California. \n\nShriver attended high school at the , in , , and graduated in 1982. Afterward, he earned a  from the  in 1986, and a  in public administration from  in 1993.\n\nShriver's godfather is former professional tennis player .\n\n\nFrom 1989 to 1994, he was a member of the Maryland Juvenile Justice Advisory Council. Starting in 1991, he also served on the board of directors of the Public Justice Center. From 1991 to 1992, he served on the Maryland Governor's Task Force on Alternative Sanctions to Incarceration. From 1994 to 1995, he served on the Maryland Governor's Commission on Service.\n\nIn 1994, he was elected to the , the lower house of the  , representing , District 15, and was reelected in 1998. He did not seek reelection in 2002 and was succeeded in that post by .\n\nIn addition to serving as a delegate, he worked on the Task Force on the Maryland Prepaid-Tuition Savings Program in 1996, and on the Task Force to Study the Governance, Coordination, and Funding of the  from 1998 to 1999. He was a Founder and Executive Director of The Choice Program, an at-risk youth intervention project of the Shriver Center at  established in 1987. He then served on the Advisory Board on After-School Opportunity Programs from 1999 to 2003. From 2000 to 2001, he served on the Judith P. Hoyer Blue Ribbon Commission on Early Child Care and Education.\n\nIn 2002, he ran for  from the 8th  of Maryland, but was defeated in the Democratic primary by . Van Hollen received 43.5% of the vote to Shriver's 40.6%.\n\nShriver joined Save the Children in 2003, serving as Senior Vice President for U.S. Programs until 2013. In that capacity, he created and oversaw the agency's early childhood education, literacy, health, and emergency preparedness and response programs in the United States.\n\nAs president of Save the Children Action Network, he is working to build bipartisan political will to increase access to early-childhood education in the United States and to end preventable deaths of mothers and children around the world. Shriver told '''' in 2016: \"We're actually engaged in elections, and we're trying to support candidates who are good on [kids'] issues. And we're going to try and defeat those who aren't. So we want to be the NRA for kids. We want to be a movement, but we want to have political juice as well.\"\n\nIn 2021, Shriver became the President of .\n\n\nOn June 26, 1992, Shriver married Jeanne Ripp (born 1965), territory manager for  Travel Related Services. The Kennedys  Kennedy Family Tree  PBS | date = October 2, 2003 | work =  | publisher =  | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090313091721/https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/kennedys/sfeature/sf_tree_text.html | archive-date = March 13, 2009}} Shriver resides in , with his wife Jeanne and their three children.\n\nMark Shriver has written a memoir about his father, ''A Good Man: Rediscovering My Father, Sargent Shriver''. In 2013, Shriver won a  for the book. In 2016, he wrote a second book, ''Pilgrimage: My Search for the Real Pope Francis''.\n\n\n*Honorary Doctorate, , 2016.\n*Honorary Doctorate, , 2015.\n*Honorary Doctorate, , 2013.\n*Honorary Doctorate, , 2010.\n*Honorary Doctorate, , 1994.\n*Legislative Sponsor Award, Maryland Children's Action Network, 1999, 2000, 2001.\n*Environmental Leadership Award, Maryland , 1999, 2000, 2001.\n*Leadership Award, Maryland Alliance of , 2001.\n*Award of Excellence, , 2002.\n*Outstanding Legislative Leadership Award, The Arc of Maryland, 2002.\n*Father of the Year Award, Mother's Day/Father's Day Council, 2008.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael G. Lenett''' is an American former politician from  and a member of the . He lost the Democratic primary election for renomination to his  to sitting Delegate  54% to 46%. Lenett's term expired December 31, 2010. He represented Maryland's district 19 in .\n\nBorn in , Lenett received a B.A. from  and an M.A. from  before attending the  for a J.D. and an LL.M. degree. He was a professor at 's National Law Center, and worked for the firm Cuneo, Giblert, & LaDuca.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
