    "pages": }\n'''Marc Alan Korman''' (born September 21, 1981) is an American politician from . He is a member of the  who currently serves in the , representing  in . He previously served as the Majority Leader of the Maryland House of Delegates from January to May 2023.\n\n\nKorman was born in  on September 21, 1981. He graduated from  in 1999, and entered the  at 17 years old, where he earned a  degree in history in 2002; , where he earned an  degree in government with honors in 2007; and the , where he earned a  degree  in 2010.\n\n\nKorman first got involved with politics at USC, unhappy about the 's decision in . Following the ruling, Korman joined, and later became president of, the university's Young Democrats Club. He also interned for California governor  and worked as a staff assistant at the Kalsman Institute at . After graduating from USC, Korman began working as a legislative aide to Congressmen  of  and  of .\n\nKorman was admitted to the  in 2010 and the  in 2011. Since 2010, he has worked as an associate at the law firm , practicing in communications and transportation litigation.\n\nKorman declared his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 16 on June 10, 2013. Korman won the Democratic primary election, receiving 21.8 percent of the vote, and later won the general election with 22.1 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nKorman was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. On January 5, 2023, Speaker of the Maryland House of Delegates  named Korman as the House Majority Leader, succeeding . He stepped down as Majority Leader following the conclusion of the 2023 legislative session to become the chair of the Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\n\n* Member, Appropriations Committee, 2015–present (education & economic development subcommittee, 2015–2018; oversight committee on personnel, 2015–present, chair, 2019; capital budget subcommittee, 2019–present; chair, transportation & the environment subcommittee, 2019–present)\n* Member, Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight, 2019–present\n* Member, Legislative Policy Committee, 2020–present\n* House Chair, Spending Affordability Committee, 2021–present\n* Member, Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 2015–2020\n\n\n* Chair, Montgomery County Delegation, 2019–present (vice-chair, land use, transportation, & public safety committee, 2015–present)\n* Member, Maryland Military Installation Legislative Caucus, 2017–present\n* Co-Chair, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019–present\n\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Korman introduced legislation that would strengthen the state's plan to make 50 percent of its bus fleet zero-emission by 2030, instead requiring that more than 50 percent of Maryland's fleet be zero-emission by 2030. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 112-22.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Korman introduced legislation that would allow 16- and 17-year-olds to consent to receive vaccines without parental permission.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Korman introduced legislation that would apply the state's . The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor Hogan on May 7, 2020. The Maryland General Assembly voted to override the gubernatorial veto on February 12, 2021.\n\n\nDuring his campaign for House of Delegates, Korman proposed a three-point plan for improving  services that included increasing funding for operations oversight, improving the aesthetics of stations, and establishing a dedicated funding source for the system. In May 2016, Korman and  released a list of Metro reform proposals, including ideas involving dedicated funding, the make-up of the  board, and vendors in stations to boost revenue. During the 2018 legislative session, Korman introduced legislation that would give the Washington Metro its own dedicated source of funding. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 25, 2018.\n\nKorman is regarded as a leading critic of proposals made by Governor  to widen the , the , and . During the 2019 legislative session, he introduced legislation that would require the governor's plan to complete an environmental assessment before moving forward. In 2020, Korman introduced legislation that would enshrine a number of pledges made by  Greg Slater on public-private partnership projects. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 97-36. The measure was re-introduced during the 2021 legislative session, during which it again passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 101-35.\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Korman introduced legislation requiring the  to provide more notice of sidewalk closures when they issue a permit allowing their closure. The bill received an unfavorable report from the Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Korman introduced legislation that would connect  to routes in  and .\n\n\nKorman met his future wife, Rebecca, while on a  trip with other Hill staffers in 2004. The couple married in June 2007, and together have two children, a daughter, Abby, and son, Harrison.  They are Jewish, and live in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Tony Edward Fulton''' was an  who served in the , representing the 40th legislative district, which lies in the central, northwest section of .\n\n\nFulton, the son of George Edward and Helen Darling Fulton, was born in  on December 9, 1951 where he grew up and was a member of the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church. Later was a member of New Psalmist Baptist Church until the time of his death. He graduated from the  in 1969 where he played . In 1973, he received his  in political science from  where he also played on the legendary . He earned an  in public administration from the  in 1975. He was married to the former Jacqueline Carter for 29 years, the couple had two children; Fulton died of cancer, May 20, 2005.\n\n\nAfter an unsuccessful try, Fulton was elected to the  in 1986 with his term starting January 14, 1987. He was a member of the Environmental Matters Committee from 1987 to 1992, from 1995 to 1996 and from 2004 until his death. He served on the environment, the housing & real property and the natural resources & ethics subcommittees in 2005. Fulton was a member of the Judiciary Committee in 1993, the Commerce and Government Matters Committee in 1994 and the Economic Matters Committee from 1996 to 2004. While on the Economic Matters committee he was a member of its science & technology, worker's compensation subcommittee, 1999–2004, corporations work group, deathcare industry work group, electric universal service program work group and chaired the unemployment insurance subcommittee from 2003 to 2004.\n]]\nFulton also served as the House Chairman of the  Special Joint Committee on Group Homes from 1995 to 1997 and was a deputy majority whip from 1995 to 1998.     "pages": }\n\n'''Kathryn Fry Hester''' (born December 31, 1974) is an American politician who has served as a  member of the  from the , based in  and , since 2019.\n\n\nHester was born on December 31, 1974. She attended  in 1997, earning a  degree in agricultural and biological engineering. After graduating, she worked as a senior analyst at  from 1998 to 2001 and as the manager of research and advocacy at SustainAbility from 2001 to 2009. She also is a Maryland  and volunteers for WISP Ski Patrol.\n\nHester got involved in politics following the  out of concern that political divisiveness in  was spilling over into her community. Hester joined liberal groups like  and Do the Most Good and created a small group called Building Bridges with the aim of bringing civility back to her community. She attended the  on Washington with her two daughters, Sierra and Alexa.\n\nIn July 2017, Hester filed to run for Maryland Senate, challenging  incumbent . She was uncontested in the Democratic primary, and  viewed the District 9 Senate election as a potential pickup opportunity given the .  ranked her election among the eight most competitive elections in the  that year. She defeated Bates in the general election by 531 votes, and was the only Democrat to oust a Republican senator in Maryland in the .\n\n\n\nHester was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. She is the first Democrat to represent District 9 in the Maryland Senate since Senator  in 1994.\n\n\n* Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee, 2020–present (alcohol subcommittee, 2020–present; health subcommittee, 2020–present)\n* Joint Committee on Cybersecurity, Information Technology and Biotechnology, 2019–present\n* Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee, 2019–present\n* Protocol Committee, 2020–present\n* Judicial Proceedings Committee, 2019\n* Joint Audit Committee, 2019\n* Work Group to Study Shelter and Supportive Services for Unaccompanied Homeless Minors, 2019–2020\n\n\n* Women Legislators of Maryland, 2019–present\n\n\nHester is a self-described , seeking to find common ground with Republicans.\n\n\nIn March 2019, Hester worried that a bill banning the use of  in Maryland would hurt farmers, including those in her district. After the bill passed the legislature passed the Maryland Senate, she proposed passing legislation to help egg farmers transition to different kinds of materials, appealing to a compromise offered by Republican senator .\n\nIn 2020, Hester worked alongside   to secure $8.25 million dollars in funding from the state to support   's Safe & Sound Plan, a multi-phase proposal to advance flood mitigation projects and support local business and property owners in .\n\nIn 2021, the Maryland  gave Hester a perfect score in their annual environmental scorecard.\n\n\nIn November 2023, Hester and eight other state senators signed a joint letter that threatened to defund immigrants rights group  because it had called for an immediate ceasefire in the  and condemned the \"utilization of US tax dollars to promote the ongoing violence.\"\n\n\nIn March 2019, when the Maryland General Assembly was deciding whether to override  's veto of a $15 minimum wage bill, Hester was tempted to vote against the minimum wage veto override, joining Republican senators who said a $15 wage would lead to job losses and hurt places in her district. She ultimately decided to vote to override the governor's veto on the bill, viewing it as a step toward economic equity, but she also supported GOP proposals to vary the minimum wage in different parts of the state and offered an amendment to give certain small businesses more time to pay the higher wage, both of which were rejected by Senate Democrats.\n\nIn April 2019, Hester convened a bipartisan workgroup consisting of Democratic senators  and  and Republican senators , , and  to look at possible aid for small business owners in light of the $15 minimum wage veto override.\n\nA 2021 analysis by the Maryland Free Enterprise Foundation, a business advocacy group, gave Hester a score of 33 percent, making her the second most business-friendly Democrat in the Maryland General Assembly.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Herbert H. McMillan''' (born May 30, 1958) is a Republican former member of the , representing District 30 in  from 2003 to 2007 and from 2011 to 2019. He served alongside Democrat  and Republican . In 2006 he challenged District 30 Senator , a Democrat, who defeated him 53 percent to 47 percent. In 2022, McMillan unsuccessfully ran for the Republican nomination for Anne Arundel County executive.\n\n\nMcMillan graduated from the  in 1980 with a  degree in  and later completed graduate studies in public administration at Central Michigan University in 1990.\n\n\nMcMillan served in U.S. Navy from 1980 until 1991. He received a Navy commendation medal in 1988. He has served in the U.S. Naval Reserve since leaving active duty with the Navy. McMillan has also been a pilot for  since 1991.\n\nMcMillan first started his public service by being elected as an Annapolis Alderman representing 5th Ward. He served from 1997 to 2001. In 2001 he ran for Mayor of Annapolis and was soundly defeated. The next year he ran for a seat in the Maryland House of Delegates. During his term on the city council, he was on the Economic Matters and Housing and Human Welfare Committees. He also chaired the Rules Committee during his tenure.\n\nWhile in his first term in the House of Delegates, McMillan served on the Judiciary Committee. Following his first term in the House, McMillan ran for the State Senate and was defeated by incumbent John Astle. Four years later he was reelected to the House. In his second term he served on the Environmental Matters Committee, and then the Health and Government Operation Committee in 2015. McMillan was also appointed as the Chief Deputy Minority Whip, a position he held till his retirement form the House of Delegates. He was also a member of the Anne Arundel County Delegation, where he was the chair of the Capital Projects/Bond Bill Subcommittee, from 2011-2018. Finally, he was a member and founder and chair of the Maryland Taxpayers Protection Caucus, the Maryland Bicycle and Pedestrian Caucus, the Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, and the Maryland Veterans Caucus.\n\nOutside of his legislative work, he was president of the West Annapolis Parent-Teacher Association from 1990–91, the vice-president of the Hunt Meadow Homeowners Association from 1991 until 1996, and a board member of the Anne Arundel County Economic Opportunity Committee from 1998 until 2002.\n\nHe is also a member of the U.S. Naval Academy Alumni Association, the , the , the St. Mary's Royal Blue and the Annapolis Touchdown Club. He received the Taxpayers Advocate Award from the Maryland Taxpayers Association in 2002.\n\nIn 2022, McMillan sought the Republican nomination for Anne Arundel County executive, finishing second to County Council member Jessica Haire in a five-person race.\n\n\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 30A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:Table TBD\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 30'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland Senate – District 30'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:Table TBD\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 30'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Deb Rey''' (born July 15, 1967) is a former American politician who represented District 29B in the  from 2015 to 2019. In November 2018, she was unseated by Democratic challenger, and former Army Ranger, .\n\n\nRey attended  in . She graduated from  with a B.S. in Political Science in 1989. She earned a M.S. in Management from  in 2004.\n\nRey served in the  from 1989 to 2009, achieving the rank of major (O-4). After retiring from the Air Force, she moved to . She was elected president of the Republican Women of St. Mary's County in 2010, and president of the Republican Club of St. Mary's County in 2012. She was selected as the St. Mary's County Republican Woman of the Year for 2013.\n\n\n\n\nRey was elected in 2014 to the  from District 29B, which covers the southern part of . She defeated  by 76 votes.\n\nRey sought re-election in 2018, but was defeated by  by 942 votes.     "pages": }\n'''Don H. Dwyer Jr.''' (born February 11, 1958) is an American former politician and former member of the . He served the 31st District of  from January 8, 2003, to January 14, 2015. A member of the , Dwyer is known for his conservative positions on certain issues, including outspoken opposition to . He was reelected by 25 votes in the  and reelected again in 2010. He was defeated in the June, 2014 Republican primary, thought to be largely due to his legal troubles. Since 2017, Dwyer has lived in Clearwater, Florida.  Dwyer chairs the Board of Supervisors for the Clearwater Cay Community Development District.\n\n\n\nDwyer has admitted to drinking on a \"pretty regular\" basis, beginning at the end of the 2011 legislative session. He has also spoken of attending counseling sessions and  meetings to cope with alcohol dependency.\n\nOn August 22, 2012, Dwyer was operating a motorboat on the  when he collided with another vessel, seriously injuring himself, John Moran IV, his companion and former police officer, and five others. Among the others injured were three children, including a 5-year-old girl who fractured her skull. Dwyer's  tested three times the legal limit of 0.08. He admitted to operating the boat under the influence at a news conference held outside , adding that he regretted his actions. On August 6, 2013, Dwyer pleaded guilty to the charges but appealed his 30-day jail sentence.\n\nWhile he was appealing, early on the morning of August 20, 2013, Dwyer was pulled over by an  sheriff's deputy in his 2001  for suspected intoxication. After showing signs of alcohol intoxication, failing field sobriety tests, and refusing a to submit to a  examination, he was arrested and transported to the Eastern District for booking.\n\nHe was again found guilty and received an additional 30-day sentence for that offense, for a total of 60 days in jail.  He did not resign his seat.\n\nDwyer claimed his drinking that led to the boat accident was a result of marital problems and feeling betrayed by fellow lawmakers who supported legislation in favor of  in Maryland. Dwyer said \"I felt a tremendous amount of pressure in my family. You take those personal issues [and] add betrayal on the professional side, and it really gets to be overwhelming.\"\n\n\n\nAt a May 2013 fundraiser for his political campaign, Rep. Dwyer hosted an auction of s during a \"Gun Rights and Liberty BBQ\".\n\n\n*'''2002 General Election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 31'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2006 General Election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 31'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2010 General Election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 31'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 Republican Primary Election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 31B'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* (archived from  on January 11, 2016)\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Mary Courtney Watson''' (born September 8, 1962) is a  member of the . She was previously a member of the  from 2006 to 2014, and she was a member of the  from 2002 to 2006.\n\n\nWatson was born in , . She graduated from  in  and attended  and , where she earned a  degree in business in 1984 and a  degree in 1986. After graduating, she started her own business, which she operated until 1991. Afterwards, she became the vice-president of sales at Rossmann-Hurt-Hoffman, a local insurance company. After finding out about crowding at , Watson joined a local parents committee in 1997 to lobby for strengthening county laws that limit development around crowded schools. She later co-founded County-Wide Citizens for the 12th High School, which lobbied for the opening of a new elementary school near  and a 12th high school in northwest Howard. The elementary school, Bellows Spring Elementary School, opened in 2003 and the high school, , opened in 2005. She was eventually appointed to Howard County's Adequate Public Facilities Ordinance Committee by county executive .\n\nIn April 2002, Watson filed to run for the , seeking to succeed board chairwoman Jane B. Schuchardt. She won the nonpartisan primary election in September, receiving 62 percent of the vote. At the time of her election, Watson was the youngest person on the Board of Education and was the only member with a child in the county school system. She won the general election with 67.6 percent of the vote.\n\nIn December 2005, Watson announced her candidacy for the Howard County Council in District 1, seeking to succeed county council chairman Christopher J. Merdon. She won the general election with 52.3 percent of the vote.\n\nIn September 2013, Watson announced her candidacy for , seeking to succeed . She was defeated by state Senator , receiving 48.7 percent of the vote in the general election.\n\nIn March 2015, Watson launched Bridge to Give, a charitable organization. The organization did not collect any money or donations, instead using  as a tool to bring awareness of need in different areas of the community.\n\n\nIn November 2015, Watson endorsed  in the . In 2016, Watson served as DNC delegate from  in the , pledged to Clinton. She was a presidential elector in the  from , pledged to Clinton and , when she signed a letter demanding an intelligence briefing on the alleged . After Clinton's defeat, Watson said she supported Electoral College reform.\n\nFollowing the , Watson led volunteer recovery and relief efforts in the city.\n\nIn August 2017, motivated by the results of the  and the presidency of , Watson filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in , challenging Delegate . The district was one of the few legislative districts targeted by the . She won the Democratic primary with 65.6 percent of the vote. Ahead of the general election, she was endorsed by former president . She was criticized by progressives for supporting Governor 's re-election campaign over Democratic nominee . She defeated Flanagan in the general election, receiving 57.4 percent of the vote.\n\n\nWatson was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019.\n\nIn 2020, she again served as a DNC delegate from Maryland's 7th congressional district in the , pledged to . Ahead of the presidential election, Watson and  led an effort to get voters to apply for  to vote in the election. She again applied to run as a delegate to the , pledged to Biden, but was denied by the .\n\n\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, 2019–present (banking, consumer protection & commercial law subcommittee, 2019–present; property & casualty insurance subcommittee, 2019–present; chair, workers' compensation subcommittee, 2022–present)\n\n\n* House Chair, , 2021–present\n* Vice-Chair, Democratic Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2019–present\n\n\n\nIn 2021, Watson co-sponsored legislation that would allow restaurants and bars to permanently legalize alcohol delivery if it was bought along with prepared food. The bill passed and became law on May 18, 2021.\n\n\nDuring her 2002 campaign, Watson supported providing enrichment programs for children who do not qualify for  or  classes. She also supported increasing pay for teachers and creating incentives to keep teachers at under-performing schools.\n\nIn September 2014, Watson unveiled a 17-point education platform as part of her campaign for Howard County executive. The plan's key points included creating an education liaison between county government and the county Board of Education, recruiting local businesses to create tech mentorships, and providing financial support to build new high schools and elementary schools to tackle school overcrowding.\n\n\nIn May 2010, Watson voted to halve funding for Healthy Howard, a county program to provide health care services to uninsured individuals, because she felt it wasn't helping enough people for the cost.\n\nWatson supports the  and expressed worries about how possible changes to it could affect Marylanders during her 2018 campaign.\n\n\nWatson introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that established a grant program to assist areas with infrastructure repairs and watershed restoration efforts associated with flood events. The bill passed and became law on May 25, 2019.\n\nWatson introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would allow local governments to seek funding from the Chesapeake Bay Restoration Fund for local climate resiliency projects. The bill passed and became law on May 8, 2020.\n\n\nIn February 2014, Watson said that she supported increasing the state minimum wage from $7.25 to $10.10 an hour. In December 2021, she sent a letter to the Howard County council asking its members to table legislation to raise the county's minimum wage to $16 an hour until discussions regarding minimum wage were held at the state level.\n\nIn June 2021, Watson criticized Governor Hogan's decision to end expanded unemployment benefits provided under the .\n\n\nDuring her 2014 executive campaign, Watson supported providing free  to the county's senior population.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Andre V. Johnson, Jr.''' (born June 19, 1971) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for  in . He previously represented District A in the Harford County Council from 2018 to 2022.\n\n\nJohnson was born at  in , and attended , graduating in 1990. After graduating, he served in the  as an armored crewman, and was deployed in . He retired from the Army in 2015 as a staff sergeant. Johnson later worked as an investigator for the Baltimore Department of Housing and Community Development, and as a police officer for the  from 1997 to 1999.\n\nIn 2018 Johnson ran for the Harford County Council in District A, seeking to succeed retiring county councilmember Mike Perrone. He won the Democratic primary over former county councilmember Dion Guthrie by a margin of 199 votes out of 2,633 votes cast. He won the general election on November 6, 2018, defeating  challenger Donna Blasdell and becoming the first Edgewood resident elected to the county council.\n\n\nJohnson was sworn in to the Harford County Council on December 4, 2018.\n\nIn February 2019, after it was reported that state delegate  had described a district in Prince George's County as a \" district\" in a conversation with another legislator, Johnson said he wanted to hear Lisanti explain in her own words what transpired. After speaking to Lisanti, he called on her to resign.\n\nIn June 2021 Johnson announced that he would run for the  in District 34A. He won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, and ran on a \"Johnson & Johnson\" ticket with incumbent Democratic state delegate  in the general election. He won the general election on November 8, 2022, coming in first with 29.59 percent of the vote.\n\n\nJohnson was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is the first African American to represent Harford County in the . Johnson is a member of the House Economic Matters Committee.\n\n\n\nIn October 2019, following what police called a \"targeted shooting\" in Edgewood, Johnson called for increased community engagement and working closely with law enforcement to combat gang violence.\n\n\nIn April 2019 Johnson voted against a resolution to expand the Edgewood/Joppa Enterprise Zone to include land meant for a proposed Abingdon Business Park warehouse project, saying that while he supported the enterprise zone's expansion, he had concerns over the expansion's support for the proposed warehouse. In July 2019, he attended a protest against the warehouse's construction.\n\nIn February 2022 Johnson said he supported imposing a moratorium to block the proposed construction of a 5.2&nbsp;million square foot \"mega warehouse\" on the Perryman Peninsula. In April 2022, Johnson voted for a bill that would place a building development moratorium on the Perryman Peninsula.\n\n\nIn January 2021 Johnson called on   to resign following his opposition to certifying the results of the . Harris responded to Johnson a few days later, calling Johnson's calls a \"petty political machination\" and attacking Johnson for failing to curb drug use and crime in his district. Johnson maintained that it was not a partisan issue and that Harris' response was dismissive of his point.\n\n\nIn December 2021 Johnson voted against the Harford County Council's redistricting plan, which passed on a party-line vote of 6–1. The redistricting map was vetoed by county executive  on December 28, but the county council voted to override the veto on January 4, 2022, with Johnson again voting against the redistricting plan.\n\n\nJohnson is married and has five children.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Alfred Clinton Carr Jr.''' (born November 2, 1965) is an American politician and public servant from . Carr is a member of the . He was a member of the , representing Maryland's District 18 in .\n\n\n\nCarr was born in , Ohio, on November 2, 1965.  Carr’s 5th great grandmother was , sister of . He is a descendent of Judath Barnett, a free woman of color, and Jefferson's nephew, .\n\nCarr earned a  from the  in electrical engineering with honors in 1988. He also holds a Certificate in Local Government Studies from the .\n\n\nCarr was a member of House of Delegates from December 20, 2007, to January 11, 2023. He served on the House Environment and Transportation Committee and its subcommittees on Real Property, Local Government, and Land Use & Ethics. He was House Chair of the Joint Committee on Federal Relations, which guides the relationship between State and Federal governments. He was a member of the  and chair of its Metropolitan Washington Committee, which vets legislation related to local utilities. Carr is also a member of the .\n\nIn his first year in the legislature, two of the bills he sponsored, House Bills 742 and 1604, were passed and signed into law by the governor. Focusing on sustainable solutions, he has secured passage of legislation on education, environmental protection, clean energy, economic development, consumer protection, transportation, open government, public safety, affordable housing, and historic preservation.\n\nCarr has consistently received endorsements and high ratings from environmental advocacy groups, consumer protection organizations, and the Montgomery County teachers, police and fire fighters.\n\nOn April 15, 2022, Carr withdrew his re-election bid to the Maryland House of Delegates, instead seeking to run for the 4th District of the . He was defeated by  mayor Kate Stewart in the Democratic primary.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*http://www.alcarr.org/\n*http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa14770.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

McClenahan''' (February 7, 1941 – May 11, 2017) was a member of the  for District 38, which covers , , & .\n\n\nDelegate McClenahan was appointed to the Maryland House of Delegates to replace  who was appointed to the .  He was defeated in the 2002 primary election by . He died on May 11, 2017, at the age of 76.\n\n\nHe attended  in , which is in .\n\n\nPrior to joining the Maryland House of Delegates, McClenahan was a project director for the Somerset County Community Action Agency from 1966 until 1976. Since 1979, he has been a partner and chair of Landmark Insurance, Inc.\n\nIn addition to his career, Delegate McClenahan is also active in many organizations, including being a member of the board of directors for the Lower Shore Sheltered Workshop from 1971 until 1978, the  Foundation since 1980, and the United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore since 1986.  McClenahan was also the chair of the Committee to Build Somerset County Public Golf Course, a member of the Lower Eastern Shore Mayors' Association, the Crisfield Area Chamber of Commerce, the  Foundation, and the Tangier Sound Music Festival. He was also a member of the Delmarva Water Transport Committee, and the Delmarva Industrial Developers Association.\n\n\nDuring Delegate McClenahan's tenure in the Maryland General Assembly, he served on the Economic Matters Committee, the Joint Committee on Health Care Delivery and Financing, the Joint Committee on Protocol, and the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review.     "pages": }\n'''John W. E. Cluster Jr.''' (born April 9, 1954) is a former member of the , representing the 8th district in .\n\n\nCluster was appointed as delegate to Baltimore County's  by Governor  to replace Republican , who was named Maryland Insurance Commissioner.\n\nCluster was appointed on July 11, 2003, and sworn in on July 29, 2003. He was defeated in his bid for election in 2006 by Democrat . On November 2, 2010, Cluster regained his seat in the Maryland General Assembly, serving until he resigned July 31, 2016.\n\n\nCluster graduated from  in southwest Baltimore in 1972.  After high school he attended .\n\n\nCluster was a patrolman for the  from 1975 until 1979 when he was promoted to Corporal.  He maintained this rank until 1983 when he was promoted to Sergeant, a position he held until 1989 when he retired.  He later worked for the Department of Juvenile Services as the Director of Capital Planning and Facilities Management.\n\nDuring his time in the Maryland House of Delegates, he was a Member of the Environmental Matters Committee and several subcommittees including the ethics subcommittee in 2004, the local government & bi-county agencies subcommittee, the motor vehicles & transportation subcommittee, the natural resources & ethics subcommittee from 2005 until 2006, and the natural resources subcommittee from 2006 until 2007.  His caucus membership included the Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus and the Maryland Veterans Caucus.\n\nCluster is still active in his community. He has been a member of the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge #4 since 1975. He is a former member of the Board of Directors for the Baltimore County Retired Police Association. Additionally, he has been President of the Parkville Business and Professional Association since 2000 and he was a member of the Loch Raven Recreation Council and the Parkville Recreation Council.\n\n\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Melvin A. Steinberg''' (born October 4, 1933) is an American politician who served as the fifth  from 1987 to 1995 under Governor . He was also  of the  from January 1983 to 1987, and a member of the State Senate from 1967 until his election to the position of lieutenant governor.  Steinberg graduated from the  with an  degree in 1952 and with a  degree in 1955.\n\nThe relationship between Steinberg and Schaefer was strained, with each publicly criticising the other and extensive coverage being devoted to their personal relationship. Despite their differences, they worked together for eight years (1987&ndash;1995), winning two elections in the process. Steinberg ran for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 1994 launching his campaign pledging a war on crime, but was defeated by , who went on to become governor. Steinberg then took up a career in lobbying. In 1998, he drew criticism for supporting the Republican candidate for Governor, , rather than endorsing Glendening in his bid for re-election; Sauerbrey was a critic of abortion and of gun control, positions opposite those held by Steinberg. In 2018, he again endorsed the Republican nominee for governor, incumbent , over the Democratic nominee, .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''A. Wade Kach''' (born July 19, 1947) is an American politician and member of the .\n\n\nKach was born in , Maryland, on July 19, 1947. He attended public schools in Baltimore, including .  He began college at  before settling at , now , where he received his  in 1970. Early in life, Kach began to work for his  principles, chairing the Maryland Federation of College Republicans in 1970.\n\n\n\nKach started his career as a middle school math teacher in . After 22 years in the classroom, he transitioned to the Audit Office of the school system, reviewing the spending of all schools in the county.\n\nHe was a member of the Republican State Central Committee in  from 1970-73. He was first elected as a member of the  in 1975.  Since then, he was elected as a delegate to the  in 1988 and 2000.\n\nHe is a member of the Baltimore County Council, representing the Third District. He won with over 60% of the vote in both the primary and general elections in 2014, unseating incumbent Councilman Todd Huff (R) and defeating Laurie Taylor-Mitchell (D). In 2018, Kach was re-elected to the Council. As a member of the , he represented District 5B, part of , for 40 years up to 2014.  He won 98.9% of the vote in 2006 while running unopposed.  In 2002 he defeated Democrat Stephen C. Kirsh and Independent William T. Newton with 71.2% of the vote in the new 5B District.\n\nFrom 1994 to 2002, his district was 9A, which he represented with fellow Republican Martha Scanlan Klima.  Again, they both defeated Stephen C. Kirsch.\nPrior to 1994, Kach represented District 10 in Baltimore County along with former governor .\nBefore the 1994 election, District 10 was represented by Kach, Ehrlich, and former gubernatorial candidate .\n\nActive in his community, Kach is a member of the Timonium Optimists, the North Baltimore County Republican and Civic Organization, and the Ashland Community Organization. Kach is also a past member  of Maryland, the Reisterstown-Owings Mills-Glyndon Coordinating Council, and the Reisterstown-Owings Mills-Glyndon Chamber of Commerce.\n\nHe has received many honors including an award from the Maryland Society of Accountants in 1999 and the , Founder's Award, from the House of Delegates in 2006 and, in 2017, the  for personal courage and dedication.\n\nIn elected office for over 48 years, Kach is the longest serving Republican elected official in Maryland history.\n\nIn October 2024, Kach announced that he would not run for re-election to the Baltimore County Council in 2026.\n\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates - District 5B''' Retrieved on March 24, 2024\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 5B''' Retrieved on September 11, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 5B''' Retrieved on September 11, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9A''' Retrieved on September 11, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9A''' Retrieved on September 11, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 10''' Retrieved on March 24, 2024\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa12250.html\n* http://www.elections.state.md.us/elections/2006/results/general/office_House_of_Delegates.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Richard A. La Vay''' (born July 16, 1953), is an American politician and businessman who served as a member of the  for District 15, which covers western . First elected in 1990, Delegate La Vay served for 12 years before he decided not to seek reelection in 2002. In the 2002 election,  and  won seats vacated by La Vay and .\n\n\nBorn in , La Vay graduated from , in . He received his Bachelor of Science degree in economics in 1975. He later attended . La Vay attended  from 2005 to 2007, where he studied strategy and policy.\n\n\nLa Vay started his career as principal and Chief Financial Officer for the La Vay Companies, from 1978 until 1995. In addition to his work, he is active in several community organizations. He was a board member of Citizens for Fair Representation in 1992. He was also president of the Stepping Stones Homeless Shelter in  in 1994. He is a member of the Maryland Building Industry Association.\n\nLa Vay has received several awards over his career, including 1st Place in the Finest for Family Living by the Suburban Maryland Building Industry Association (SMBIA). He also received the Alexandria Civil Neighborhood Revitalization Award. La Vay is a regular contributor to the '''' Sunday Section with an article called \"Close to Home\".\n\n\nOver his 12 years in the , La Vay was a member of the Economic Matters Committee from 1991 through 1994, and again from 1997 through 2003. He was selected to be the Minority Whip from 1995 until 1996. Additionally, he was a member of the Appropriations Committee, Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, and the Legislative Policy Committee, from 1995 until 1996. He was on the Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer in 1996. the Special Joint Committee on Competitive Taxation and Economic Development from 1996 until 1997, the Joint Committee on Fair Practices from 1997 until 1998 and the Joint Advisory Committee on Legislative Data Systems from 1999 until 2003. Finally, he served on the Special Committee on Gaming from 2001 until 2003 and was a member of the Bi-County Committee and the Montgomery County Delegation.\n\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15''' Retrieved on Nov. 20, 2007\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15''' Retrieved on Nov. 20, 2007\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15''' Retrieved on Dec. 16, 2007\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/former/html/msa12259.html\n* http://www.suburbancapital.com/about_us/staff/richard_lavay.htm\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''Neil Conrad Parrott''' (born July 30, 1970) is an American politician who was a member of the  from 2011 to 2023.\n\nBorn and raised in Maryland, Parrott graduated from the  and . He began his career as a traffic engineer for the  and the city of . Parrott first became involved in politics in 2002 and was elected as a  to the Maryland House of Delegates in 2010, first representing  from 2011 to 2015 and then  until 2023. During his tenure, Parrott organized efforts petitioning laws passed by the Maryland General Assembly to  and , which were upheld by voters.\n\nParrott ran for the  in  in  and , losing both times to incumbent  . He ran for the 6th district for a third time in , in which he was defeated by Democratic nominee  in the general election.\n\n\nBorn in , Parrott graduated from  in 1988. He went on to the  where he graduated with a  degree in  in 1994. He later attended graduate school and in 2006 graduated from  with a .\n\nParrott began his career at the  where he was a . He went on from there to become the Deputy Director of Engineering in the  Department of Public Works, where he helped hire a new traffic engineer for the city and purchase the extension of new sidewalk along the Golden Mile section of . Parrott and his wife moved to  in 1999, where he started a consulting company, Traffic Solutions Inc., in 2007.\n\n\nParrott first got involved with politics in 2002, successfully suing the  over the removal of a monument for the  in a public park in Frederick, Maryland. In April 2009, he got involved with the , organizing bus trips to  to protest the . In July 2009, Parrott filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in .\n\n\nParrott was sworn in as a member of the Maryland House of Delegates on January 12, 2011, representing . He was redrawn into  during the .\n\nIn February 2013, Parrott was one of three House members who voted against reprimanding state delegate , who failed to disclose a  when pushing for legislation that would have allowed him to regain his suspended real estate license.\n\nIn January 2015, Parrott said he would apply to fill a vacancy in the  left by the resignation of . State delegate  was ultimately appointed to the seat and sworn in on February 2, 2015.\n\n\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2011–2018 (estates & trusts subcommittee, 2011–2014; juvenile law subcommittee, 2015–2018)\n* Assistant Minority Whip, 2015–2021\n* Member, Environment and Transportation Committee, 2019–2023 (housing & real property subcommittee, 2019–2023; motor vehicle & transportation subcommittee, 2019–2023)\n\n\nIn July 2012, Parrott founded an organization, MDPetitions.com, and started an accompanying website to coordinate efforts to petition laws he opposed to be placed on s. In an interview with '''', he said he started the website with the goal of \"taming the  so it wouldn't pass legislation that most Marylanders oppose\".\n\n\nThat year, Parrott successfully placed ballot initiatives for three laws–the , offering , and the state's congressional  map. These petitions, despite being rejected by voters, earned Parrott the  Man of the Year award.\n\nIn April 2013, Parrott said he would not seek a ballot referendum against a law banning  and requiring licenses to buy , which he had likened to a , instead backing a lawsuit from the  against the law.\n\nIn 2014, Parrott again sought to place two referendums seeking to repeal legislation on the ballot–a 2013 bill abolishing the , and a 2014 bill prohibiting discrimination against  Marylanders in housing and employment, nicknamed the \"Bathroom Bill\" by its detractors. However, both petition attempts fell short of the 55,736 signature threshold to get on the ballot.\n\n\nIn March 2013, Parrott joined a  lawsuit that sought to overturn the results of the 2012 redistricting referendum, asking the courts to hold a new election using different ballot language.\n\nIn June 2015, Parrott joined another Judicial Watch lawsuit against Maryland's congressional districts, claiming that the state's redistricting plan was unconstitutional.\n\nIn November 2021, ahead of the special legislative session to pass the newly drawn redistricting maps, Parrott said he supported the maps drawn by Governor 's Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission (MCRC). He had participated in the MCRC's public hearing process, during which he advocated for adopting . In December 2021, Parrott and Judicial Watch filed a lawsuit that sought to repeal the state's newly redrawn congressional map, which he described as a \"political \". The new map would have likely protected incumbent Democratic U.S. Representatives and gave Democrats a realistic chance of defeating U.S. Representative , the lone Republican in Maryland's congressional delegation, by adding more Democratic voters to his district. In March 2022, Circuit Court Judge  ruled for Parrott, striking down the congressional maps that she called a \"product of extreme partisan gerrymandering\". The Maryland General Assembly passed a new redistricting plan shortly after the ruling, during which Parrott introduced an amendment to swap out the new map with the MCRC-drawn map. The amendment was rejected by a 42-92 vote.\n\n\n\n\nOn November 22, 2019, Parrott announced that he would run for the  in , challenging incumbent Democratic U.S. Representative .\n\nParrott was defeated by Trone in the general election on November 4, 2020, receiving 39 percent of the vote to Trone's 58 percent.\n\n\n\nImmediately following his defeat in 2020, Parrott filed to run for the U.S. House of Representatives in Maryland's 6th congressional district, again challenging Trone. He announced his candidacy on November 17, 2021. Parrott defeated '''' journalist Matthew Foldi in the Republican primary election on July 19, 2022.\n\nDuring the general election, Parrott was heavily outspent by Trone, who had had a 14-1 cash-on-hand advantage and spent $12 million to self-fund his campaign. Despite this, he had received more individual contributions from Maryland. The  targeted the district, which was redrawn to be almost evenly divided between Democratic and Republican voters. The district was also described as the only competitive district in Maryland, with '''' giving Parrott a 53 percent chance of winning and '''' rating it as \"highly competitive\".\n\nParrott was defeated by Trone in the general election on November 8, 2022. He conceded to Trone on November 11. Political analysts, including 's Mileah Kromer, saw Trone's ability to self-fund and controversial Republican gubernatorial nominee  as factors that led to Parrott's defeat. Following his defeat, he called on the  to embrace .\n\n\n\nOn June 27, 2023, Parrott formed an exploratory committee to explore a potential third run for the district in , seeking to succeed U.S. Representative David Trone, who  in 2024. He officially entered the race on February 9, 2024, hours before the candidate filing deadline. Parrott was seen as a frontrunner, alongside former state delegate and 2022 gubernatorial nominee , in the Republican primary, during which Parrott ran on a platform including securing the border, increasing , tough-on-crime policies, and widening local highways.\n\nParrott won the Republican primary election on May 14, 2024, and faced  in the general election. Parrott positioned himself as someone who lives and has raised a family in the district, contrasting himself with McClain-Delaney, who lives in . He also campaigned on the issues of transportation, immigration, and the economy, and pledged to join the  if elected to Congress. Parrott was defeated by McClain-Delaney on November 5, 2024. The election for the 6th district was the most competitive in the state. Parrott would have been the first member of Congress from one of Maryland's three panhandle counties since , who represented the 6th district from 1969 to 1971, had he won the race.\n\n\n\nParrott has described himself as \"\". During the 2011 legislative session, he introduced a bill to establish a right to life for all humans that starts \"from the beginning of their biological development\". During the 2013 legislative session, Parrott introduced a bill that would ban  past 20 weeks, with exceptions for medical emergencies. The bill failed to pass out of committee. During his 2022 run for congress, Parrott said he would support a federal 15-week ban on abortions.\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Parrott opposed a bill requiring insurance companies to cover  (IVF) treatments for same-sex married couples, writing in an email to his constituents that the bill would increase premium costs and would be harmful to children who were born into families with two mothers. He also testified against the bill on the House floor, during which he argued that children born into families with a mother and a father were more likely to succeed economically and socially, that the bill would \"intentionally put a child into a family where the father will knowingly be absent\", and suggested that legislators would eventually pass a bill requiring insurance companies to cover the cost of hiring a  to carry a child for same-sex married men. During his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott said that he supported IVF and addressed his concerns about the bill's financial impact, but did not address his comments about its effect to children raised by same-sex married couples.\n\nIn 2017, Parrott said he opposed a bill that would provide state funding to abortion services providers. In November 2019, he said he supported a  and codifying the . In May 2022, Parrott promoted a petition that sought to create a ballot referendum to repeal the Abortion Care Access Act, a bill that would provide $3.5 million to expand who could provide abortion services.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Parrott opposed proposals to create a ballot referendum on the right to abortion access. In June 2022, Parrott celebrated the 's ruling in '''', calling it a \"great decision\". In February 2024, he urged voters to vote against  to codify abortion rights into the Maryland Constitution and criticized federal legislation to restore the '''' decision.\n\nIn 2020, Parrott introduced a bill that would require minors to receive parental consent to get an  (IUD).\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott said he supported abortions in cases of rape, incest, and threat of life to the mother, but declined to say if he supported any federal restrictions on abortion, saying that the issue should be decided at the state level.\n\n\nParrott supports requiring voters to show a government-issued  before casting a ballot in elections.\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Parrott introduced a bill to make the signatures of proposed ballot referendums private. The bill failed to move out of committee. In 2013, he introduced a bill that would require language used on referendum petitions to match the language used on the ballot. In 2015, Parrott introduced a bill that would delay primary elections if they fall on religious holidays. In May 2015, he said he opposed a bill that would restore voting rights for ex-felons and used his MDPetitions.com organization to forward emails opposing the bill to Governor , who later vetoed the bill. During the 2021 legislative session, Parrott introduced a bill that would require the Maryland State Board of Elections to verify signatures on mail-in ballots.\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott said he supported proposals that would require Maryland to use an  to draw its congressional districts, as well as requiring candidates for office live in the districts in which they run. He also supported a constitutional amendment to enact s on members of the U.S. House of Representatives and , but said he would not \"term limit myself\" if such an amendment does not pass.\n\n\nIn January 2012, Parrott said he opposed a bill levying a sales tax on digital purchases, which he called an \"app tax\". In March 2020, he said he supported the .\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Parrott introduced a bill that would allow individual counties to set their own minimum wage rates. The bill was seen as a response to Governor O'Malley's proposal to raise the state minimum wage to $10.10 an hour by 2016. He introduced the bill in 2019 in response to bills that would raise the state minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2026, later unsuccessfully attempting to amend the $15 minimum wage bill to add his county-by-county minimum wage bill.\n\nIn February 2017, Parrott voted against a bill that extending the state's energy efficiency program, criticizing its utility bill fee as a \"regressive tax\". In October 2024, Parrott said he supported the  and cutting regulations to increase domestic energy production, and criticized the  for reducing the amount of federal land that could be used for .\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott supported a  to the U.S. Constitution. He also supports keeping the  in place and moving toward a . Parrott supports cutting regulations to incentivize home construction and requiring federal housing vouchers and tax credits to be conditioned on localities building more housing.\n\n\nIn September 2015, Parrott participated in a \"Stop the \" rally in \n\nParrott criticized the , claiming that it motivated Russia to begin its . He initially expressed openness to voting for legislation to provide  amid the invasion, but told '''' in October 2024 that he opposed providing aid to Ukraine, instead advocating for U.S.-led negotiations to peacefully end the war.\n\nParrott supports the use of military force and  to counter , as well as providing U.S. military aid to  and . He also opposed calls for a ceasefire in the  as well as a  to the , and suggested that civilians displaced from the war should seek asylum in .\n\n\nIn January 2013, Parrott said he would support Governor 's bill to require a license to purchase a handgun if the bill also included provisions to expand the . He also criticized the bill's provisions banning assault rifles and limiting magazine capacities. In 2018, Parrott introduced legislation to adopt the , which would allow homeowners to use  against unlawful intruders.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session and following the , Parrott introduced a bill that would restore the death penalty in cases of . The bill, which was named the Capital Gazette Shooting Memorial Act, was criticized by relatives of victims of the mass shooting. He also said he opposed a bill that would require s for  purchases.\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott said he believed that gun legislation should be left up to the states, but supported a bill to make s issued in one state valid in all other states.\n\n\nParrott opposes the  and has repeatedly called for its repeal.\n\nIn May 2020, Parrott joined a lawsuit with state delegates  and  against Governor 's  restrictions, claiming that his orders violated the  of the . In May 2020, the lawsuit was dismissed by U.S. District Judge . Plaintiffs of the lawsuit initially appealed Blake's ruling, but withdrew the lawsuit altogether in July 2020. In November 2021, he criticized , saying at a campaign rally that people should \"have a choice whether they want to get vaccinated against COVID-19\".\n\nIn November 2020, Parrott said he opposed legalizing , believing that it would lead to the legalization of , thereby leading to increased traffic accidents.\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott opposed expanding government health care programs and setting limits on prescription drug prices, arguing that pharmaceutical companies needed to be rewarded for their investments before bringing new drugs to the market. He also called for the repeal of the , but expressed openness to retaining provisions regarding prescription drugs.\n\n\nIn March 2019, Parrott introduced an amendment to the state budget that would require the  to confirm an individual's immigration status before granting  benefits. The amendment was rejected by a 41-98 vote.\n\nDuring his 2020 congressional campaign, Parrott blamed undocumented immigrants at the  for the , and said he would support closing the border. He also said he supported a physical or electronic southern border to stop illegal immigration. During his 2024 congressional campaign, he cited the  as the United States' top foreign policy challenge, blaming it for  and the smuggling of  and .\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott said he supported completing the  and reinstating the  policy. He criticized the Bipartisan Border Security Bill negotiated by Senators  and , calling it a \"non-starter\" and would alllow 5,000 illegal immigrants to cross into the United States daily, and vowed to block federal funding for \"\". He also blamed immigrants for high crime rates, economic instability, housing prices in  and promoted  claiming that the 's response to hurricanes in  and the  were hindered by the Biden administration of spending FEMA disaster relief funds on housing and food for illegal immigrants. In September 2024, Parrott criticized the Frederick Board of Aldermen's vote to allow s who reside in the city to vote in local elections.\n\n\nIn 2016, Parrott unsuccessfully ran for delegate to the , pledged to U.S. Senator . In November 2019, Parrott predicted that the  would backfire on national Democrats, comparing it to how Republicans backfired from the . He supported President 's reelection bid in 2020, participating in a \"Trump Bus\" rally in September 2020.\n\nFollowing the , Parrott traveled to  to observe ballots being counted. Following the , he said the majority of attendees at the preceding rally \"were simply there to support fair elections\", and were unaware \"that some people were going to try to take over the rally and make it violent\". In July 2022, Parrott said he would have voted against certifying the election results in Pennsylvania and . In February 2024, he said he opposed removing  from the  ballot under the , saying that he believed that the January 6 Capitol attack was not an insurrection.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Parrott introduced a bill that would require law enforcement officers to read individuals their  during a traffic stop and search. In 2020, Parrott introduced legislation that would exempt law enforcement officers who live in Maryland but work in other states from taking handgun training.\n\n\nIn January 2005, Parrott participated in a protest in  against a Baltimore lawsuit that would give gay people the right to marry, where he spoke against the Montgomery County Board of Education for mandating gay marriage and gay sex education. During his tenure in the legislature, Parrott was known as an opponent of , opposing bills to repeal the state's . In 2014, he opposed a bill to ban discrimination against transgender Marylanders in housing and employment, claiming it would \"radically change our society and put our families and children at risk\". Parrott also introduced a bill that would withhold state funding from colleges that offer , which failed to pass out of committee. In 2015, he criticized a bill that would allow  to change their gender marker on their birth certificate without proof of . In 2018, Parrott opposed a bill that would ban , claiming that it violated the First Amendment. In 2020, he expressed disappointment the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling in '''', which held that the  also protected against discrimination on the basis of  and , saying that he believed that Congress should have passed a law addressing the issue instead. During his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott supported banning transgender minors from using s or undergoing gender-affirming surgeries, and prohibiting transgender athletes from competing in women's sports teams.\n\nIn March 2005, Parrott wrote a  for '''' arguing that  patients who are given life-saving medication should be tattooed \"in a spot covered by a bathing suit\" to prevent potential sex partners from becoming unknowingly infected. During his run for the Maryland House of Delegates in 2010, he said he no longer supported the idea, citing advancements made in medicine to treat HIV. Parrott responded similarly to  raising the issue in the .\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Parrott voted for an amendment to the state budget that condemned antisemitism amid the . In 2020, he voted against a bill to ban placing s and other  on a person's property without their consent. During his 2024 congressional campaign, Parrott defended his vote on the anti-hate symbols bill, telling '''' that he had concerns with the bill's interpretation and was worried that the bill would allow property owners to interpret political signage as intimidation. The bill explicitly banned the display of swastikas and s, but otherwise interpreted hate symbols as \"an item or symbol used to threaten or intimidate a person or a group of persons\".\n\nIn 2017, Parrott opposed a federal bill that would remove a  from , claiming that its sponsors were \"progressive Democrats who are trying to erase history\".\n\nIn 2019, Parrott introduced a legislation that would declare exposure to  as a public health crisis. The bill failed to move out of committee.\n\nIn November 2019, Parrott said he supported .\n\nDuring the 2020, 2021, and 2022 legislative sessions, Parrott opposed a bill that would remove marriage as a defense for rape and . During a floor debate on the bill in February 2022, he claimed that the bill was unnecessary and would criminalize regular physical contact between spouses. After the issue was raised by  in the , Parrott defended his vote on the bill by saying that \"having workplace sexual harassment laws in marriage doesn't make sense\" and blamed Democrats for the bill failing to pass after it was amended in the Maryland Senate. The bill was reintroduced during the 2023 legislative session, during which it passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn October 2021, Parrott supported, but did not sign onto, a pair of letters to West Virginia officials asking about annexation of  to West Virginia, citing the state's ban on fracking and the General Assembly \"not caring about the needs of Western Maryland\".\n\n\nParrott got engaged to his wife, April (née Wise), in March 1999, and married in July. Together, they have three children, including two daughters and a son. He describes himself as a devout .\n\nIn October 2002, Parrott was detained for shoving a police officer after he and his group, Friends of Frederick, were removed from a parade in , for displaying a \"Save the Ten Commandments\" banner to protest calls for the removal of a Ten Commandments Monument in the Bentz Street Graveyard Memorial Park. Prosecutors declined to file charges against Parrott.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Melvin Herbert Evans''' (August 7, 1917 – November 27, 1984) was a  politician, who served as the appointive and the first elected , serving from 1969 to 1975. After serving as governor he was  from the U.S. Virgin Islands to the  from 1979 to 1981.\n\nEvans was born in  on the island of , and attended , , and the . He became the Virgin Islands health commissioner and was appointed governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands in 1969. He became the first elected Governor in 1970 and served a four-year term from 1971-75. Evans was a man and served as a delegate to the  and s.\n\nOn November 7, 1978, Evans was elected  as a . He defeated Democrat Janet Watlington, an aide to outgoing delegate , with 10,458 votes (52%) to 9,588 votes (48%). Evans served as delegate in the House from January 3, 1979, to January 3, 1981. He was unsuccessful for reelection in 1980, losing to former delegate de Lugo.\n\nEvans was appointed , and served until his death. He is interred in Christiansted Cemetery on St. Croix.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  (includes link to photo)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n}}\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
