    "pages": }\n|children         = 3\n|education        =  (, )\n|signature        = Anthony G Brown Signature.gif\n|allegiance       = \n|branch           = \n|serviceyears     = 1984–2014\n|rank             =   (retired)\n|unit             =  (Active) (Reserve) (OIF) (Reserve)\n|battles          = \n|mawards          = \n|module           = \n}}\n'''Anthony Gregory Brown''' (born November 21, 1961) is an American lawyer and politician serving as the . He also served as the  for  from 2017 to 2023 and as  from 2007 to 2015. He was the 's nominee for  in the , losing to Republican  in a close race.\n\nBrown served two four-year terms in the , representing  from 1999 to 2007.\" \". Political biography.  . Retrieved February 14, 2007. He was elected to the lieutenant governorship in  on the Democratic ticket with  ; both were re-elected in . He is a retired  in the , having served in the U.S. Army for over thirty years. While lieutenant governor, Brown was the highest-ranking elected official in the nation to have served a tour of duty in Iraq. In , Brown ran unsuccessfully for the governorship, losing to  nominee . In 2016, Brown was elected to the U.S. House. His district covered most of the majority-black precincts in , as well as a sliver of .\n\nIn October 2021, Brown announced that he would not seek reelection to the U.S. House in  and would instead  for . He won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022. He defeated Republican lawyer  in the general election on November 8, 2022, becoming Maryland's first Black attorney general.\n\n\nBrown was born in 1961 in , to immigrant parents. His father, Roy Hershel Brown, a physician, was born in , Cuba; was raised in , Jamaica; and later came to the U.S. to attend . Roy received his medical degree in , Switzerland, where he also met his future wife, Lilly I. Berlinger. The couple married and Lilly moved with Brown to , where they had Anthony, his sister, and three brothers.\n\nThe family lived in , in Suffolk County on Long Island, where Anthony attended public schools, graduating from  in 1979. In his senior year, Brown became the first African American to be elected president of Huntington High School's student council. After high school, Brown started at the  at , where he had an appointment. He quickly switched to , where he majored in government and resided in . At Harvard, Brown served on the Student Advisory Committee at 's . Since Harvard did not offer ROTC at the time, in his second year, Brown enrolled in the  program at  and earned a two-year scholarship. In 1984, Brown graduated with an A.B. '''', and as a .\n\n\nUpon graduation, Brown received a commission as a  in the U.S. Army. He served on active duty for five years. He graduated first in his flight class at , and received his aeronautical rating as an .  He also completed airborne training, receiving both the  and the . During his time on active duty, Brown served as a helicopter pilot with the Aviation Brigade,  in Europe. During that period of active duty, Brown held positions as platoon leader for a target acquisition, reconnaissance and surveillance platoon,  of a general support aviation company, a  , and the flight operations officer for Task Force 23.\n\n\nAfter completing his active duty service, Brown returned to graduate school, entering Harvard Law School in 1989 and earning his JD degree. He attended  at the same time as future President ,  and actor . Brown was a member of the . His third-year paper, written under the supervision of , analyzed the scope of the 's protections against unreasonable search and seizure in the military. Brown was chair of the Membership Committee of the Black Law Students Association. Brown graduated from Harvard Law, with a  in 1992.\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Brown completed a two-year clerkship for  of the . In 1994, he joined the Washington, D.C. office of the international law firm of Wilmer Cutler Pickering (now ). Brown practiced law with the late , a renowned civil rights attorney and former president of the , and , who was the  for the District of Maryland from 1967 to 1970 and was the 40th . In 1998, Brown received Wilmer's  Award for his work in representing indigent clients. In 1999, Brown worked for Merrill Lynch for five months. Brown joined the Prince George's County land use and zoning law firm Gibbs & Haller in 2000, after having been elected to the .\n\n\n\nBrown continued his military service transferring from the Army's Aviation Branch to the Judge Advocate General's Corps as a  (JAG) in the . Brown began his service as a JAG with attending  at the  and then the 10th LSO in , where he held numerous assignments, including in the areas of international law and claims law. Brown ultimately attained the rank of  in the  before reaching the point of mandatory retirement for a colonel with 30 years of commissioned service in July 2014.\n\nHis assignments included commander of the 153rd Legal Support Organization in , where, in addition to supporting deploying service members and their families with legal services, he mobilized eighteen soldiers to , in support of the   mission to Iraq. Prior to his tenure with the 153rd LSO, Brown was the staff judge advocate for the 353rd Civil Affairs Command headquartered at , New York.\n\nIn 2004, Brown, then a member of the Maryland House of Delegates, was deployed to  as part of . Brown served in , , , and  with the  as senior consultant to the Iraqi Ministry of Displacement and Migration. Brown received the  for his distinguished service in Iraq.\n\n\n\nBrown's political career began in 1998, when he was elected to serve in the , representing the 25th district in . Brown ran on a Democratic Party ticket with Senator , Delegate , and Delegate . He served two terms in the Maryland House of Delegates and rose to several positions of leadership. During his first term, Brown served on the House Economic Matters Committee. He was appointed vice chair of the Judiciary Committee in 2003. In 2004, Speaker of the House  appointed Brown to the position of , the fourth-ranking position in the House.\n\n\n\nIn 2006, Brown was elected  on a ticket with , the former . The pair were the only challenging candidates to defeat an incumbent gubernatorial ticket in the 2006 election cycle. On January 17, 2007, Brown was sworn in as Maryland's 8th lieutenant governor. Both Brown and O'Malley were reelected by a 56% to 42% margin on November 2, 2010. Brown was the first person elected lieutenant governor directly from the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nGovernor O'Malley tasked Brown to lead the O'Malley-Brown administration's efforts on several policy fronts, including efforts to expand and improve health care, support economic development, help victims of , increase access to higher education, and provide veterans with better services and resources.\n\nIn July 2010, Brown was elected chair of the , a position he served in for a term of one year.\n\n\n\nAs co-chair of the Maryland Health Care Reform Coordinating Council and Maryland's Health Quality and Cost Council, Lt. Governor Brown led the O'Malley-Brown administration's efforts to reduce costs, expand access, and improve the quality of care for all residents of the state. In June 2012, Brown was named \"Maryland's Public Health Hero\" by the Maryland Health Care for All! Coalition. He assisted in the implementation of the , which according to a \"non-partisan\" 2012 study using Obama administration numbers and various state agency projections, would save Maryland $672 million by 2020. In both 2011 and 2012, Brown led legislation through the  to create a .\n\nBrown was severely criticized for his leadership of the development of the health insurance exchange. As of April 14, 2014, it had enrolled only 66,203 individuals (including family members on shared plans). The O'Malley administration apologized for the \"botched\" launch of the web site and had to seek emergency funding legislation to make stopgap changes to the site. The state paid a contractor $125.5 million to develop and operate the failed site. Due to the failed rollout, the state incurred an estimated $30.5 million in unnecessary  spending. The web site failure was the subject of a federal investigation into the costs associated with developing the exchange and the site's performance failures. The state announced that it was considering scrapping its failed online health exchange altogether and hiring a new contractor to build a new online exchange using technology employed by the state of Connecticut, at an expected cost of tens of millions of dollars. The  relaxed rules for residents of states like Maryland with dysfunctional online health care exchanges, allowing consumers to bypass the exchanges altogether to buy health insurance.\n\nBrown led efforts to address  among racial and ethnic groups in Maryland. In 2012, he developed created Health Enterprise Zones, which would use incentives to increase the number of primary care providers and other essential health care services in underserved communities. The goal is to reduce preventable diseases, such as asthma and diabetes.\n\n\n\nBrown led the administration's economic development portfolio. He served as chair of numerous economic development initiatives, including the Joint Legislative and Executive Commission on Oversight of Public-Private Partnerships, the Governor's Subcabinet on  (BRAC), and the FastTrack initiative&nbsp;– part of Maryland Made Easy (www.easy.maryland.gov)&nbsp;– to streamline the state permitting process for businesses and developers.\n\n\n\nBrown became one of the leading champions for the increased use of  to advance infrastructure projects in Maryland. Governor Martin O'Malley appointed Brown to serve as Chair of the Joint Legislative and Executive Commission on Oversight of Public-Private Partnerships. The fifteen-member Commission was established in 2010 under House Bill 1370 to evaluate the State's framework and oversight of public–private partnerships. Under Brown's leadership, the Commission worked to increase the potential for private investment in public infrastructure projects. The commission submitted its final report to the Governor and General Assembly in January 2012, which included assessing the oversight, best practices, and approval processes for ; evaluating the definition of public-private partnerships; making recommendations concerning the appropriate manner of conducting legislative monitoring and oversight of public-private partnerships; and making recommendations concerning broad policy parameters within which public-private partnerships should be negotiated.\n\n\n\nBrown was tasked by Governor O'Malley to lead the  Subcabinet and the implementation of Maryland's BRAC Plan, which ensured the State of Maryland would be ready for the 28,000 households that came to the state as a result of the BRAC process. It was estimated that between and 45,000 to 60,000 jobs would be created in Maryland by 2016 due to BRAC. Since 2007, the BRAC Subcabinet met regularly with BRAC stakeholders to coordinate and synchronize the State's efforts with public and private partners to address BRAC needs. The BRAC Plan set forth new initiatives and priorities to address the human capital and physical infrastructure requirements to support BRAC, as well as to seize the opportunities that BRAC presents, while preserving the quality of life already enjoyed by Marylanders. Several of the larger moves included the Army's Communications–Electronics Command () to  from , New Jersey, and the Air National Guard Readiness Center at . The  was relocating to  from northern Virginia and  was moving to the  to create the  at Bethesda.\n\nIn 2011, the Association of Defense Communities recognized Brown as their Public Official of the Year for his leadership on BRAC.\n\n\nIn August 2008, his cousin Kathy was murdered by her estranged boyfriend. Building on his legislative experience and personal perspective, Brown has championed reforms to fight domestic violence and provide improved support to victims.\n\nIn 2009, Brown led efforts to improve domestic violence laws and take guns out of the hands of domestic abusers by allowing judges to order the abuser in a temporary protective order to surrender any firearms in their possession.\n\nDuring the 2010 Legislative Session, Brown worked with the General Assembly to pass legislation allowing a victim of domestic abuse to terminate a residential lease with a copy of a final protective order. During the 2012 Legislative Session, Brown gained the administration's goal of extending unemployment benefits to a victim of domestic violence who decides to leave employment because the abuser is a threat at the workplace.\n\nBrown also led efforts to expand the availability of hospital-based Domestic Violence Screening programs at Maryland hospitals to help identify victims of domestic violence and connect them to support services. In 2010, he helped launch Maryland's fifth hospital-based domestic violence program at Prince George's Hospital Center in Cheverly. In 2011, Brown helped launch a sixth hospital-based program at Meritus Medical Center in Hagerstown, Maryland. Similar programs are in place in the Baltimore region at Anne Arundel Medical Center, Mercy Medical Center, Sinai Hospital, and Northwest Hospital.\n\n\nUnder the O'Malley Brown Administration, Maryland's students made dramatic improvements in nearly every statistical category, and Maryland's schools were ranked # 1 in the country for 4 years in a row.\n\nBrown lead the O'Malley-Brown administration's efforts to increase taxes to support education and other programs. They raised taxes over 40 times during their tenure. The administration took steps to make a higher education more accessible and affordable for all Marylanders, including making record investments in community colleges and working to keep an education affordable at four-year public colleges and universities. As a result, the number of  college graduates, number of associate degrees, and the number of bachelor's degrees awarded in Maryland all increased since the team took office in 2007.\n\nIn 2010, Lt. Governor Brown launched the Skills2Compete initiative, which promotes programs and activities that lead to increasing the skill level of Marylanders though the attainment of a post-secondary credential, apprenticeship program or degree.\n\n\nBrown was the nation's highest-ranking elected official to have served a tour of military duty in Iraq and he led the O'Malley-Brown Administration's work to improve benefits and services for Maryland's veterans.\n\nIn 2012, Brown announced the launch of Maryland Homefront: the Veterans and Military Family Mortgage Program, which helps qualified current and former military members find homes by giving them a discounted mortgage interest rate and help with closing costs. Also in 2012, Brown helped pass legislation that allows notation of 'veteran' status on drivers' licenses and identification card.\n\nDuring the 2008 session of the Maryland General Assembly, Brown led the administration's successful efforts to pass a sweeping veterans package, including passage of the Veterans Behavioral Health Act of 2008. The legislation sets aside $2.3 million for the expansion of direct services to OIF/OEF veterans living with behavioral and mental health problem. The legislation also named Brown chair of the Maryland Veterans Behavioral Health Advisory Board.\n\nOther legislation passed as part of the \"Maryland's Commitment to Veterans\" package includes:\n* Expansion of state scholarship fund for OIF/OEF veterans and their dependents;\n* Protection of state-funded business loan program for veterans and service-disable veterans;\n* Creation of reintegration program for members of the  returning from service in Iraq and Afghanistan; and\n* Expansion of state veteran service centers in rural communities.\n\n\nDespite being a classmate of , in September 2007, Brown initially endorsed  for  in the . He campaigned for her in several states, including  and . In June 2008, Brown subsequently  Obama.\n\nIn July 2008, Brown was appointed to the 's Platform Committee and served on the Platform Drafting Committee. Brown led the efforts to strengthen the 's commitment to veterans and ensuring that the  be named as a \"national treasure\". Brown was a \"Party Leader/Elected Official\" delegate to the  in , Colorado, in late August 2008 and cast his vote for then-Senator Obama, along with 98 members of the Maryland delegation.\n\nBrown was named co-chair of the  for the  on November 14, 2008.\n\n\n\nAnthony Brown announced his candidacy for  in the  on May 10, 2013, at Prince George's County Community College. He chose , county executive of , as his running mate in June 2013. Brown was endorsed by  ,  , U.S. Congressman ,  President , and  Mayor . Brown faced   and   in the Democratic primary. Brown won the June 2014 Democratic primary and became the Democratic nominee for governor but was defeated by Republican nominee  in the general election on November 4, 2014.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n  |change     =\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n;2016\n\nOn March 12, 2015, '''' reported that Brown would run for the U.S. House of Representatives seat for Maryland's 4th district, which was being vacated by , who was running for the US Senate. He won a crowded six-way Democratic primarythe real contest in this heavily Democratic, black-majority districtwith 41 percent of the vote.\n\nBrown won the seat in the general election, taking over 73 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n*  (Vice Chair, 2017–2021)\n** \n** \n* \n* \n** \n** \n* \n** \n** \n** \n** \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n; 2022\n\n\n, 2022]]\nBrown said that he would not seek re-election to the House of Representatives on October 25, 2021, instead announcing that he would run for Attorney General of Maryland.\n\nDuring the primary, Brown received endorsements from U.S. Senators  and , and U.S. Representatives , , and . He also received endorsements from the  and the .\n\nIn May 2022, an investigation from '''' alleged that Brown violated state election laws by using funds from his congressional campaign account to bankroll his bid for attorney general.\n\nBrown won the Democratic primary election on July 19, 2022, defeating former   with 55.1 percent of the vote. He defeated Republican lawyer  in the general election on November 8, 2022.\n\n\n, January 2023]]\nBrown was sworn in on January 3, 2023, becoming Maryland's first Black attorney general.\n\nBefore Brown took office in 2023, the Maryland Attorney General's office launched an investigation into allegations of sexual abuse perpetrated by members of the . Brown inherited the investigation, and, in April 2023, released a 463-page report accusing the Archdiocese of covering up more than 600 cases of child sexual abuse against 156 Catholic priests over 80 years. Following its release, he said that the Attorney General's office had ongoing investigations into sexual abuse allegations in the  and the .\n\nIn January 2023, ahead of his swearing in, Brown said he supported legislation that would allow him to sue companies and individuals for civil rights violations. He also set out multiple goals for his time in office, including increasing salaries and employment in the Attorney General's office, enforcing environmental regulations, and investigating . The Maryland General Assembly passed bills during its 2023 legislative session that gave the Attorney General's office the authority to prosecute police-involved deaths and civil rights violations in housing and employment, which were signed into law in May 2023.\n\nBrown was an at-large delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\n\n\nBrown married Patricia Arzuaga in 1993, and they had two children, Rebecca and Jonathan, before their divorce in 2009. Jonathan was adopted.\n\nBrown married Karmen Walker on May 27, 2012. She is the widow of Prince George's County police officer Anthony Michael Walker. He became the stepfather of Walker's son Anthony. Both Anthony and Brown's son Jonathan were in the same grade at the same Catholic school in 2012. Walker is a director of government relations with . Brown is .\n\n\n\n\nBrown's personal awards include:\n\n\n\nBrown was also awarded the , and the . He is  and  qualified, and is authorized to wear one .\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*   official U.S. House website\n* \n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Shirley Nathan-Pulliam''' (born May 20, 1939) is a former  from  and a member of the . She was the first African-Caribbean woman to be elected to the . Pulliam resigned in 2019 due to poor health.\n\n\nNathan-Pulliam was born in ,  on May 20, 1939.  She attended  in . While studying there she met her husband, a member of the , they married and moved to , in 1960.\n\n\n\nShe earned her bachelor's degree in nursing from the  in 1980 and a master's degree in administrative science from the  in 1984. In addition to owning her own business, she has been a faculty associate in nursing for Johns Hopkins. Before being elected in 1994, Nathan-Pulliam was active with Democratic Party organizations at the state and national level, as well as with  and various professional nursing organizations. Nathan-Pulliam has received a number of awards for her advocacy on health care.\n\n\nNathan-Pulliam represented Maryland's 44th Legislative Districtlocated in parts of  and while in the Maryland General Assembly. She was a member of the Education Health and Environmental Affairs Committee. While in the Maryland House of Delegates, Nathan-Pulliam served as a deputy majority whip and as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee. She was also a member of both the  and of Women Legislators of Maryland.\n\n\n* voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax whilst simultaneously reducing income tax rates for some income brackets - Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for individuals who are not permanent residents, under certain conditions - Higher Education -Tuition Charges -Maryland High School Students, 2007 (HB6)\n\n\n\nSenator Pulliam did not run in the 2020 elections because of health concerns. On January 30, 2023, her name was placed on the facade of the newest multi-million-dollar wing of the  Nursing school. She was first elected to the council in 2022 as a . Previously, she served as a member of the  representing district 47B from 2019 to 2022.\n\n\nFisher was born in New York, New York. Her father is a  n and her mother is an  who moved to the United Kingdom as a teenager to escape . Her parents were small-business owners in . She graduated from the  with a  in government and politics in 2010. While attending the university, she became a member of the sorority . Fisher earned a Juris Doctor at the Dickinson School of Law,  in 2013 and was admitted to Maryland Bar. She then worked as an assistant State's Attorney in Prince George's and is now in private practice.\n\n\nFisher was sworn in as a Delegate on January 9, 2019, and assigned to the House Judiciary committee. She also serves at the Assistant Majority Leader.\n\nIn June 2021, Fisher announced that she would not seek re-election to the House of Delegates, instead opting to run for .     "pages": }\n'''Richard K. Impallaria''' (born November 1, 1962) is an American politician who served as a member of the , representing  in  and  counties, from 2003 to 2023.\n\n\nImpallaria was born in , . He attended  in . Prior to entering politics, Impallaria owned his own auto body shop in . He was also a chair of Citizens for Property Rights, Essex-Middle River Community in Action, is the former president of the Joppatowne Chapter of the Jay Cees Men's Club.\n\nImpallaria first got involved with politics in 2000, when he helped garner support for a referendum to repeal Senate Bill 509, which gave Baltimore County the power to condemn land in  and  for redevelopment. The referendum succeeded in repealing the legislation, passing in the November general election with 70 percent of voters voting to repeal it. Following the bill's defeat, Impallaria unsuccessfully tried to sell land in Essex for $1 million to the county for redevelopment.\n\nIn 2002, Impallaria ran for the Maryland House of Delegates, seeking to succeed state delegate . He won the Republican primary with 13.7 percent of the vote, coming in third place behind  and . In October 2002, state senator , state delegates  and , and 's campaign manager R. Karl Aumann asked Impallaria to withdraw from the House of Delegates election, expressing concerns over his criminal record. Impallaria won the general election on November 5, 2002, coming in third place with 17.0 percent of the vote.\n\n\nImpallaria was elected to the House of Delegates in 2002. He was sworn in on January 8, 2003, and was subsequently re-elected in 2006, 2010, 2014, and 2018. In 2022, Impallaria was redrawn into District 7B, where he ran for re-election but was defeated in the Republican primary in District 7B by state delegate  in July 2022.\n\n\nImapllaria was assigned to the following committees:\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, 2003–2023 \n** Property and casualty insurance subcommittee, 2003–2015\n** Public utilities subcommittee, 2003–2010, 2015–2023\n** Unemployment insurance subcommittee, 2003–2006, 2017–2023\n** Alcoholic beverages subcommittee, 2007–2017\n** Workers' compensation subcommittee, 2011–2023\n** Consumer protection and commercial law subcommittee, 2012–2015\n* Joint Committee on Unemployment Insurance Oversight, 2015–2023\n* Deputy Minority Whip, 2015–2016\n\n\nIn June 2018, state delegate  accused Impallaria of sending out campaign mailers attacking Szeliga by calling her a closet . Impallaria initially declined responsibility for this, but after Szeliga emailed him to say she would inform their GOP colleagues about the fliers targeting her, he forwarded the email to every member of the House Republican caucus in which he referred to himself as the \"evil genius\" responsible for the attacks on Szeliga.\n\nIn January 2019, the Office of the State Prosecutor charged Impallaria's chief of staff, Tyler Walch, for violating state election law for making robocalls to Szeliga's constituents without disclosing who paid for and who authorized the message. The calls misleadingly claimed that Szeliga was a supporter of the  and had voted in favor of a bill that would make it illegal to discriminate against someone on the basis of . The , the non-profit social equity organization mentioned on the robocalls, said that no one with the organization was contacted by Impallaria or his campaign in connection with the call. Impallaria denied any knowledge about the call, saying that he never approved or paid for it. In April 2019, his chief of staff was convicted and sentenced to 100 hours of community service and a $1,000 fine for violating the authority line requirements of Maryland election law.\n\nIn May 2019, the  asked Impallaria to resign from the , saying he was \"unworthy of the title Delegate\" following a controversy over a campaign robocall, a history of traffic violations, and a lawsuit against party officials. Impallaria refused to resign, saying that it was up to his constituents to decide whether he stays in the .\n\n\n\n\nIn January 2012, Impallaria declared his candidacy for the  in , challenging incumbent U.S. Representative . Impallaria, a resident of the town of Joppa, lived nine-tenths a mile outside of the 2nd district. During the primary election, he was endorsed by delegate  and ran on a platform of opposing  and in-state tuition for illegal immigrants. Impallaria was defeated in the Republican primary by state senator , receiving 23.8 percent of the vote and coming in second place.\n\n\n\nIn January 2020, Impallaria again ran for the United States House of Representatives in Maryland's 2nd congressional district, challenging incumbent U.S. Representative Dutch Ruppersberger. He was defeated by state senator  in the Republican primary election, placing fourth with 16.2 percent of the vote.\n\n\nIn 1982, Impallaria was charged with four counts of assault with intent to murder as a result of allegations that, \"He tried to run down four people, including his mother and brother,\" and subsequently served three years probation for battery charge as a result of that incident.\n\nIn August 2003, the  issued a citation to Impallaria after concrete, dirt, and other debris was dumped into a stream that leads into the  from his property. In November, he was again issued a 30-day citation over pollution to the stream, and gave him 30 days to clean up the rubble.\n\nIn July 2011, Impallaria filed a lawsuit as a  against Harford County sheriff Jesse Bane, alleging that Bane failed to prevent the withholding of personal property and license tags by T & S Towing, a local towing service company. In December 2011, Baltimore County Circuit Judge Barbara K. Howe dismissed Impallaria's claim with .\n\nIn August 2016, Impallaria was arrested in , and charged with . In April 2017, he was convicted and sentenced to two days in jail. He was originally sentenced to 60 days due to his previous traffic record, which includes over 50 various citations.\n\nOn July 27, 2022, Impallaria was charged with multiple counts of theft and misconduct in office, alleging that he misused state funds involving a personal cottage and a district office in Essex, which is located outside of his district. On September 2, he was charged with illegal ammunition and gun possession by a prohibited individual. On January 13, 2023, Impallaria agreed to plead guilty to the misconduct charges and pay $44,100 in restitution to the state in a plea deal with prosecutors; after completing these actions, his case was converted to a probation before judgement status in June 2023, removing the convictions from his record. In April 2023, he again agreed to plead guilty to the firearm possession charge and was sentenced to 18 months of unsupervised probation by Circuit Court Judge Robert Cahill.\n\n\n\nIn March 2013, Impallaria voted against a bill that would repeal  in Maryland. In October 2015, Impallaria, whose cousin died of an , said he would support sentencing drug dealers to death.\n\n\nIn March 2011, Impallaria said he opposed Governor 's $1.5 billion proposal to spur offshore wind development in the state, calling the plan \"a boondoggle that every single resident in the state is going to be shaken down to finance\". The proposed plan would have raised the electric bill of every state resident over the next 20 years to pay for offshore wind farms in the state.\n\n\nIn 2004, Impallaria confronted four lobbyists for immigrants' issues during a hearing on a bill to study the fiscal impact of , who he says referred to him as \"\" during testimony on the measure. Following the testimony, Impallaria followed the lobbyists into the hallway to ask the advocates if they were illegal immigrants, which they refused to answer.\n\nIn 2007, Impallaria said he opposed a bill introduced by state delegate  that would allow  to attend public colleges and universities while paying in-state tuition.\n\n\nDuring his time in the Maryland House of Delegates, Impallaria repeatedly introduced bills that would allow s and  to operate electronic gambling machines in their clubs. During the 2011 special legislative session, he introduced an amendment allowing veterans organizations to operate gambling machines in their clubs, which passed.\n\nIn 2005, Impallaria voted to pass a bill that would legalize slot machines at four locations in the state, which passed by a vote of 71-66.\n\n\nIn April 2013, Impallaria voted against the Firearm Safety Act of 2013, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nIn March 2014, Impallaria voted against a bill to raise the state minimum wage to $10.10 an hour by 2017.\n\n\nIn January 2020, Impallaria said he supported 's .\n\n\nIn 2022, Impallaria voted against a bill that would provide 12 weeks of partially paid leave to recover from childbirth or serious illnesses, or to care for a loved one.\n\n\nIn 2022, Impallaria said he supported a  bill that would have allowed farmers to repair their own farm equipment. The bill was rejected by the House Economic Matters Committee on March 7, 2022.\n\n\nIn 2010, Impallaria said he opposed allowing  students to access LGBT-related political, advocacy, and community support websites, using the term \"homo promo\" in a mass e-mail.\n\nIn 2011, Impallaria said he opposed a bill that would allow  to use . He also said he did not believe that employers should be required to accept a worker's decision to change their gender expression, and expressed concerns that anti-LGBT discrimination laws would lead to situations where \"halfway through the school year, you have a schoolteacher that used to be Mr. Bob that's now Miss Sally\".\n\nIn 2012, Impallaria voted against the , which legalized same-sex marriage in Maryland.\n\nIn 2019, Impallaria voted not to censure state delegate  after she used a  to refer to a legislative district in , saying it would be inappropriate of him to judge Lisanti when he didn't have firsthand knowledge of what happened. He was the sole vote against the censure.\n\nIn March 2022, Impallaria introduced an amendment to an abortion rights bill that would require all aborted fetuses to be given religious burials and prohibit the sale of aborted fetal remains or tissue. The amendment failed on a vote of 38-88.\n\n\nIn 2011, Impallaria said he opposed a $1,500 fine proposed by Governor Martin O'Malley for bad driving, calling it a \"money grab\" that the governor was \"trying to slip in\".\n\nIn March 2013, Impallaria voted against a bill to raise the state gas tax and index future increases to inflation to replenish the state's transportation fund, which passed by a 76-63 vote.\n\nOn April 13, 2015, the Maryland House of Delegates voted to repeal the unpopular mandate colloquially known as the , by a vote of 138-1. He was the sole vote against the repeal.\n\nIn March 2016, Impallaria was one of two state delegates to vote against a bill that cuts the cost of a death certificate or a birth certificate from $24 to $10.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Thomas \"Tom\" S. Hutchinson''' (born May 25, 1965) is an American politician, business owner, and triathlete. He is currently a member of the  for .\n\n\nHutchinson graduated from  with a Bachelor of Science degree in computer science. He later received a  degree from . He and his family purchased a home in , in 2003, where they stayed weekends before moving there permanently in 2010.\n\nIn January 2014, Hutchinson was elected to serve as the president of Cambridge Main Street. During his tenure, downtown  experienced a re-emergence of restaurants, retail, beautification, and tourism.\n\nAlso in 2014, Hutchinson collaborated with local officials and the  to host a full distance  event in the county. He would participate in the triathlon in 2017, coming in 732nd place out of 1,522 participants.\n\nSince 2020, Hutchinson has run his own home improvement company, Hutchinson Home Services LLC.\n\nIn March 2022, Hutchinson announced his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 37B, seeking to succeed state delegate , who had announced a run for the . He ran on a slate with incumbent state delegate , and won the Republican primary on July 19 with 35.4 percent of the vote and as the top vote-getter in  and  counties.\n\n\nHutchinson was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Health and Government Operations Committee.\n\n\nHutchinson has a daughter named Helen.\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Lesley Jeanne Lopez''' (born November 28, 1983) is an American politician who is a member of the  from . A member of the , she unsuccessfully ran for the  in  in , losing to  in the Democratic primary election.\n\n\nThe oldest of three siblings, Lopez was born in , Bermuda, while her mother Patricia was serving on active duty in the . She grew up in  in a . As a child she was adopted by her stepfather, Emsley Lopez, also a naval officer. Her paternal grandparents migrated to the United States from the .\n\nLopez attended schools in . While in elementary school, she survived a  in which a man from a neighboring apartment complex began shooting at her classmates. She later attended the , where she earned a B.A. in political science, and , where she earned an  in management.\n\n\n\nAfter graduating, Lopez worked as a journalist for 's '''', , , '''', and the . She also worked as an adjunct professor of communications at George Washington University, where she became a member of  Local 500.\n\nLopez first became involved with politics while working with immigrant families. She served as the press secretary for U.S. Representative  from 2008 to 2011, afterwards serving as the communications director for the  until 2013. In this capacity, she helped pass the  through the U.S. Senate and reauthorize the , which was expanded to include protections for .\n\nLopez later worked as the communications director for various other organizations, including the , the , and the , from 2014 to 2017. Since 2017, she has worked as the chief communications director for .\n\n\nIn 2017, after state delegate  announced that he would run for the Montgomery County Council at-large district in 2018, Lopez filed to run for state delegate in District 39. She ran on a slate with state senator  and state delegates  and . Lopez won the Democratic primary election on June 27, 2018, placing first with 21.3 percent of the vote.\n\nLopez was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She was a member of the Judiciary Committee from 2019 to 2022, afterwards serving on the Health and Government Operations Committee. Lopez ran for re-election in , during which she formed a slate with union activist Clint Sobratti, who sought to unseat incumbent delegate . All three incumbents, including Acevero, won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022.\n\nDuring the , Lopez endorsed U.S. Senator .\n\n\nIn March 2022, Lopez was voted in as the president of the Women's Caucus of Maryland by a 50–12 vote, one year ahead of when she was due to become its president under the caucus's traditional order. In response, the 11  members of the caucus resigned from the caucus in protest, later demanding it be renamed to the \"Democrat Women's Caucus of Maryland\". Lopez defended her election, saying in an interview with '''' that she \"had some plans of what I wanted to do [as caucus president] when I moved up so I accelerated the timeline\" and had approached state senator , a Republican, about joining her leadership team, but she declined. She had also sent handwritten notes to each of the members who had left the caucus. Republicans have since declined to rejoin the caucus, and have discussed forming their own.\n\n\n\nOn June 1, 2023, she announced her candidacy for the  in  to succeed outgoing U.S. Representative . During the Democratic primary, she received endorsements from several members of the legislature and ran on a platform of gun safety, addressing the opioid crisis, and protecting reproductive rights. Lopez was unable to put together a robust campaign and was defeated by former  deputy administrator  in the Democratic primary election on May 14, 2024, placing fifth with 4.6 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn September 2019, Lopez joined Maryland Attorney General  and 43 other members of the Maryland General Assembly in co-signing a letter to U.S. Education Secretary  asking for information about her implementation of the federal  program.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Lopez endorsed a bill to expand  to employees at .\n\nIn April 2024, Lopez expressed concerns with efforts to  and called for federal protections against book bans. She also supported increasing funding for local school districts and teachers, and hiring more support personnel in schools.\n\n\nIn August 2019, Lopez said she opposed the 's decision to repeal limits for  permits for business owners, pointing out that the decision followed mass shootings in , and .\n\nIn 2020, Lopez introduced a bill requiring firearms to be stored in an area where a minor could not gain access to it.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Lopez introduced legislation to ban s. The bill failed to pass out of committee. She reintroduced the bill in 2022, during which it passed and became law without Governor Hogan's signature. Following the bill's passage, Lopez was invited to the  by President , where he announced a new  rule regulating privately made firearms.\n\n\nLopez supports a  to the . In October 2023, amid the , Lopez said she supported Israel's right to defend itself and called for humanitarian aid to Palestine.\n\n\nIn June 2020, Lopez pledged to stop taking campaign contributions from the .\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Lopez introduced a bill to allow municipalities to establish police accountability boards.\n\n\nIn 2019, Lopez introduced a bill to expand the state's child pornography laws to include  and . The bill unanimously passed the Maryland General Assembly.\n\nIn May 2022, following the leak of a draft majority opinion for the  case '''', Lopez sent a letter on the behalf of the Women's Legislative Caucus of Maryland to Governor , asking that he release the $3.5 million in funds to train abortion care providers as part of the Abortion Care Access Act. Hogan denied her request, effectively delaying the law's implementation until July 2023. During her 2024 congressional campaign, Lopez said that she would support codifying the '''' decision on the federal level.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Lopez introduced a bill prohibiting the  correctional staff from discriminating against  individuals and would allow these individuals to be housed in a facility that aligns with their .\n\n\nLopez is married to her husband Richard Kelly, an app developer at . The couple married on September 23, 2018, in a ceremony at the . Together, they have two children.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Edward \"Ned\" Carey''' (born February 7, 1962, in ) is an American politician who was  member of the  for , based in , from 2015 to 2023.\n\n\nCarey was born in , where he has lived for his entire life. He attended , and earned a  in urban planning from  in 1984.\n\nBefore serving in the House of Delegates, Carey worked as the chief administrative officer at . He was also a former member of the Anne Arundel County Spending Affordability Committee, where he served two terms as chairman, and on the boards of , the Chesapeake Arts Center in Brooklyn Park, Opportunity Builders Inc. and other local institutions.\n\n\nCarey was elected to the House of Delegates in the 2014 General Assembly elections, succeeding former delegate . He has been described as one of the most conservative Democrats in the House, earning a score of 26 percent in an analysis from , the highest among other Democrats in the .\n\nShortly after being sworn into office in 2014, Delegate Carey joined the Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus as a means of expressing his commitment to protecting and promoting pro-sportsmen legislation at the capitol. During the 2015 legislative session, Carey cosponsored House Bill 464, which would allow for reciprocity in honoring out-of-state concealed carry permits. He also introduced House Joint Resolution 5, which would extend the goose hunting and duck hunting season on the  to run through February of each year.\n\nIn April 2022, Carey announced that he would not seek re-election to the House of Delegates in 2022.\n\n\n* Economic Matters Committee, 2015–2023 (banking, economic development, science and technology subcommittee, 2015–18; consumer protection and commercial law subcommittee, 2015–18; chair, unemployment insurance subcommittee, 2019–2021; vice-chair, alcoholic beverages subcommittee, 2019; chair, property & casualty insurance subcommittee, 2021–2023)\n* Regional Revitalization Work Group, 2015–2023\n* House Chair, Joint Committee on Unemployment Insurance Oversight, 2019–2023\n\n\n* Chair, , 2019–20 (chair, education subcommittee, 2015; chair, alcohol subcommittee, 2016–2023; member, capital budget subcommittee, 2016–2023; vice-chair, 2018)\n* Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2015–2023\n* Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2019–2023\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Bernard C. \"Jack\" Young''' (born June 26, 1954) is an American politician and former mayor of , . A member of the , Young was elected to the  in 1996, representing Baltimore's second district. In 2010, Young became City Council President following  taking over as mayor due to the indictment of . On April 2, 2019, Young was named acting mayor during the leave of absence by Mayor . Following Pugh's resignation on May 2, 2019, Young was fully vested as mayor of the city. In October 2019, Young announced that he was running to retain his position as Mayor in the . He lost the Democratic nomination for mayor, despite raising more money than the other candidates. Instead,  won the nomination for mayor in the 2020 general election, which he went on to win.\n\n\nJack Young graduated from Northern High School in Baltimore and attended Baltimore City Community College.\nYoung was originally elected to represent Baltimore City Council District 2 in 1996, which he represented until 2003 when district lines were redrawn. After redistricting, he represented District 12 until he was appointed as City Council President in February 2010 to fill the vacancy left when  was elevated to mayor.\n\n\nAt , Young first worked in the cafeteria and mailroom before joining the  department as a file clerk and eventually an administrator, helping  the department archives. By the late 1980s, Young began spending his evenings and weekends serving on the staff of Baltimore City Council member . From 2007 to 2010, Young was a manager at the Maryland Department of Human Resources. He has been a member of the Historic East Baltimore Community Action Council since 1995, and is a co-founder of the Broadway Development Foundation.\n\nYoung created controversy in 2009 when he said that \"it should be required that all top-level people live in the city,\" referring to a report by the ''Baltimore Examiner'' that most Baltimore City police commanders don't live in the city. On February 1, 2010, WBAL-TV's Jayne Miller reported that Young himself owned a home in Harford County for which he had signed an affidavit that declared the Harford County home was his primary residence. Young said the house in Harford County had served as his summer home until he sold it in 2005.\n\nIn February 2010, Councilman Young was unanimously nominated to fill the position of City Council President after former City Council President Stephanie Rawlings-Blake was sworn in as Mayor of Baltimore following the resignation of former Mayor .\n\n\nYoung was elevated to Acting Mayor on April 2, 2019, when then Mayor  went on an indefinite leave of absence to recover from pneumonia. The announcement coincided with a scandal over a \"self-dealing\" book-sales arrangement by Pugh. On May 2, 2019, Pugh resigned and Young became mayor of the city.\n\nIn July 2019, Young said that Baltimore would not assist  agents with immigration raids. He said in a statement: \"Immigrants who call Baltimore home should not live in fear of family separation and deportation, and I will continue to do all that is in my power so that all Baltimore residents, including immigrants, feel safe and welcome in our city.\"\n\n\nAfter the first campaign finance reporting date in mid-January 2020, Young led all candidates with $960,000 cash on hand,  reported having about $840,000,  had nearly $430,000 cash on hand and  had raised $100,000.  Despite this, he would eventually finish 5th in the Democratic .\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David D. Rudolph''' (born June 12, 1949) is an  from  and a member of the . He was a member of the , representing Maryland's  from 1995 to 2002 and  from 2003 to 2015.\n\n\nDavid D. Rudolph was born on June 12, 1949, in . He was raised in  and graduated from  in 1967. He graduated with a  in history/political science from  in 1971. Rudolph graduated with a  from the  in 1977. He graduated with a  from Wilmington University in 1998.\n\n\nIn 1973, Rudolph started his teaching career with .  and taught at  for 4 years.  In 1977, he was promoted to the school's Assistant Principal.  He also spent 2 years as Assistant Principal at .  In 1988, he was promoted to Principal at . He was also Principal of the  from 1994 to 1997, and of  from 1997 to 2000. Along with his duties as a State Delegate, David also serves as Director of the Teacher Education Program at .\n\n\n\nRudolph was elected as a member of the  in 1994. He started by representing  from January 11, 1995 to 2002. He then represented  from 2003 to January 14, 2015.\n\nHouse Chair, Joint Committee on Base Realignment and Closure, 2007-. Vice-Chair, Economic Matters Committee, 2007- (chair, property & casualty insurance subcommittee, 2007-; member, banking, economic development, science & technology subcommittee, 2007-; unemployment insurance subcommittee, 2007-; workers' compensation subcommittee, 2007-). Member, Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2007-. Member, Commerce and Government Matters Committee, 1995-98 (ethics & elections subcommittee); Ways and Means Committee, 1999-2003 (finance resources subcommittee, 1999–2000; children & youth subcommittee, 2001–03); Health and Government Operations Committee, 2003-06 (health insurance subcommittee, 2003–04; public health subcommittee, 2004–05; public health & long-term care subcommittee, 2005–06; chair, health occupations subcommittee, 2003–04; chair, pharmaceuticals subcommittee, 2004–06); Joint Audit Committee, 1999–2002; Special Committee on Higher Education Affordability and Accessibility, 2003–04; Joint Committee on the State's Emergency Medical Response System, 2003-05. Chair, Cecil County Delegation, 1995-2002. Member, Maryland Rural Caucus, 2002-; Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2005-; Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2005-. Member, Task Force on School Leaders, National Conference of State Legislatures, 2002; National Legislative Association on Prescription Drug Prices, 2005-.\nMember, Governor's Executive Advisory Council, 1991; Commission to Save the Lighthouses, 1995–96; Bainbridge Re-Use Advisory Committee, 1996–97; Task Force to Study the Preservation and Enhancement of Maryland's Heritage Resources, 1998-2001 (protection & preservation committee); Governor's Task Force on Eastern Shore Economic Development, 1999–2001; Maryland Task Force on the Principalship, State Department of Education, 1999–2001; Bainbridge Development Advisory Board, 1999-; Task Force to Study College Readiness for Disadvantaged and Capable Students, 2000–01; Tri-County Council for the Lower Eastern Shore of Maryland, 2001-; Maryland K-16 Partnership for Teaching and Learning Work Group, 2003-; Upper Shore Regional Council, 2003-; Task Force on the Establishment of a Prescription Drug Repository Program, 2005–06; Social Studies Task Force, 2005-; Task Force to Convene a Summit on Civic Literacy in Maryland, 2006; Cecil/Harford Bridges Work Group, 2006. Co-Chair, Task Force on the Availability and Affordability of Property Insurance in Coastal Areas, 2007-08. Member, Climate Change Commission, 2007-. Co-Chair, Commission to Study the Title Insurance Industry in Maryland, 2008-.\n\n\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000 \n* voted for Jessica’s Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007 \n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008 \n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland’s drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009 \n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland’s budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State’s aging fleet, 2009 \n\nFor the past four years, Delegate Rudolph has annually voted to support classroom teachers, public schools, police and hospitals in Cecil County. Since 2002, funding to schools across the State has increased 82%, resulting in Maryland being ranked top in the nation for K-12 education.\n\n\nRudolph is married to Diana. They have three children.\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.drudolph.org/\n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa12302.html \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Melissa R. Wells''' (born October 3, 1983) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2019.\n\n\nWells was born on October 3, 1983. She attended  in 2006, where she earned a  degree in political science and law and sociology. She later attended American University in 2010, where she earned a  degree in public policy. After graduating, she worked as a policy assistant for the  until 2014 and as a field advisor at Triple Point Interactions and program associate at  until 2015. She is currently the regional director of the Baltimore-DC Building Trades Union.\n\n\nWells was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She served as a member of the Environment and Transportation Committee from 2019 to 2022, afterwards serving in the Ways and Means Committee. In November 2019, Wells unsuccessfully ran for assistant majority leader of the House of Delegates, losing to state delegate  in a 25-13 vote among the class of freshman Democratic legislators. Since 2020, she has served as Deputy Majority Whip. Since 2023, she has served as chief deputy majority whip.\n\n\n\nIn March 2019, Wells voted against a bill that would allow  to have its own private police force.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Wells introduced bills that would require prosecutors to undergo , and another that would create a referendum in  on transferring control of the  back to the city.\n\n\nIn March 2022, Wells said that she would \"reluctantly\" vote for the Climate Solutions Now Act, an omnibus bill to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 60 percent by 2030, saying that she felt that the bill \"did not do enough to ensure strong labor standards\".\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Wells voted against a bill that would allow s to carry guns in Baltimore schools.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Wells introduced legislation to codify and extend the state's  eviction moratorium until April 2022, and another that would extend judges' ability to delay eviction proceedings. In 2022, she introduced a bill that would allow judges to grant a  in eviction proceedings to allow parties to seek legal representation.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Wells introduced legislation to prohibit auto insurers from using a policy holder's  to set rates. The bill was heavily amended following auto insurance industry lobbying before passing the Maryland House of Delegates and did not receive a vote in the .\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Wells introduced a bill that would cap  fares at a monthly rate.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He previously represented the 40th district in the  from 2015 to 2019.\n\n\n in 2009]]\nHayes was born in , . He was raised by his grandmother and grew up in Baltimore. He attended , earning a  degree in political science in 2000.\n\nSince 2010, Hayes has served as the Chief of Staff of the Baltimore City Department of Social Services.\n\n\nIn 2014, Hayes defeated two-term incumbent  to win a seat in the House of Delegates. He was sworn in on January 14, 2015.\n\nOn July 29, 2017, Hayes announced his bid for State Senate, challenging appointed state Senator  for the seat formerly held by Mayor . He defeated Robinson in the Democratic primary, earning 65.4 percent of the vote. He ultimately won the general election unchallenged and took office on January 9, 2019.\n\nFollowing the death of   in October 2019, Hayes was seen as a possible candidate in the subsequent . Later that month, he said that he would not run for the seat.\n\nIn 2020, Hayes ran for national delegate pledged to  in  at the . He won the primary election, receiving 18.4 percent of the vote. He also served as a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\n* Member, Finance Committee, 2019–present (energy & public utilities subcommittee, 2019–present)\n* Member, Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 2019–present\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on Behavioral Health and Opioid Use Disorders, 2019–present\n* Member, Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2020–present\n* Member, Executive Nominations Committee, 2021–present\n* Member, Health and Government Operations Committee, 2015–2019 (government operations & long-term care subcommittee, 2015–2017; health facilities & occupations subcommittee, 2015–2017; government operations & estates & trusts subcommittee, 2017–2019; health facilities & pharmaceuticals subcommittee, 2017–2019)\n* Member, Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 2015–2019\n* Member, Public Safety and Policing Work Group, 2015–2016\n* Member,  Work Group, 2018\n* Member, Opioid Work Group, 2018\n\n\n* Chair, , 2019–2020\n* Member, , 2015–present\n* Vice-Chair, , 2020–present\n\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Hayes introduced the \"Time to Care Act\", a bill that would provide Maryland workers with up to 12 weeks of .     "pages": }\n'''Michael Joseph Hough''' (; born November 4, 1979) is an American politician who served in the , representing  in  and , from 2015 to 2023. A member of the , Hough previously represented  in the  from 2011 to 2015. Hough unsuccessfully ran for  in , losing to county councilmember Jessica Fitzwater.\n\n\nHough was born in  on November 4, 1979. He was one of three children, and was raised in . Hough graduated from , afterwards enlisting in the , serving as a missile maintenance technician from 1998 to 2002, and attending the , where he earned an  in applied sciences. During his service, his parents moved from Montgomery Village to , prompting him to also move to Frederick County. Hough later earned a  in political science from  in 2007.\n\nAfter serving in the Air Force, Hough worked as a sales associate for  from 2002 to 2004, after which he became a legislative aide to Maryland state senator  until his election to the Frederick County Republican Central Committee in 2007. He served as the chair of the central committee in 2008, during which he organized support for Republican candidates in the  and  elections.\n\n\n\nIn 2009, Hough launched a campaign for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 3B.\n\nIn January 2010, Hough applied to fill a vacancy in the Maryland House of Delegates left by the resignation of state delegate , who resigned to become an executive assistant to  mayor Randy McClement. He was nominated to fill the vacancy by the Frederick County Republican Central Committee alongside  and John Lovells; Governor  appointed Jenkins to the seat later that month. Afterwards, Hough targeted Jenkins in the Republican primary. During his campaign, he was able to outraise Jenkins walked from  to , a distance of , to meet with voters. He also ran on a platform of opposing tax increases, privatizing government services, and deregulation.\n\nHough was sworn in to the Maryland House of Delegates on January 12, 2011, where he served on the Judiciary Committee during his entire tenure and as assistant majority leader from 2013 to 2015. In 2012, he served as a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\nIn February 2014, Hough announced that he would run for the Maryland Senate in District 4, challenging incumbent state senator , whom he criticized for voting for O'Malley's budgets and for a bill providing health insurance to uninsured individuals. In May 2014, an Emmitsburg resident filed an ethics complaint against Hough for using taxpayer funding to send him a birthday note on an official letterhead, noting that he wasn't even one of Hough's constituents (instead living in Brinkley's district). Hough disputed the complaint, saying that he received approval from state ethics advisors to send birthday messages so long as he paid for the postage. During the Republican primary, he received endorsements from U.S. Representative , former U.S. Representative , and state delegates , , and . Hough defeated Brinkley in the Republican primary election on June 24, 2014, receiving 67.7 percent of the vote to Brinkley's 32.3 percent. He faced Democratic nominee Dan Rupli in the general election, during which he donated campaign funds to other Republican nominees in local races. He defeated Rupli with 67.7 percent of the vote in the general election on November 4, 2014.\n\nHough was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 14, 2015, where he served on the Judicial Proceedings Committee during his entire tenure. During the , Hough served as the chair of 's campaign in Maryland. '''' described Hough as being \"one of the most prolific fundraisers\" in the Maryland Senate; during the 2018 elections, Hough helped raise funds for the Senate Republican Caucus Committee and the Frederick County Republican Victory Slate to support Republican nominees in the  and the .\n\nFrom 2015 to 2017, Hough worked as a policy advisor for the , afterwards working as the chief of staff to U.S. Representative . During the , he canvassed and phonebanked for  in . Hough was in the  during the , during which he called on Trump to call on demonstrators to stand down.\n\nDuring his 2018 re-election campaign, Hough raffled away an  with 250 rounds of ammunition. Frederick County Sheriff Chuck Jenkins questioned the legality of Hough's AR-15 rifle, noting that he did not obtain a raffle permit from the county permitting office; however, Hough said that he did not need one as county law regarding raffle permits only applied to nonprofit organizations.\n\nIn October 2020, the Maryland Senate Republican Caucus voted to elect Hough to serve as Senate minority whip, replacing state senator , who opted against reelection to the position, which was seen by the media as the Senate Republican caucus becoming more conservative as to push back on the perceived leftward shift of the  following the election of  as Senate president. In this capacity, Hough promised to work with Democratic lawmakers on issues including police reform, but lobbied against bills opposed by the  such as the . He stepped down as minority whip on October 4, 2021, to focus on his campaign for Frederick County executive. He was succeeded by state senator .\n\n\n\n\nOn May 17, 2021, Hough announced that he would run for Frederick County Executive in 2022, seeking to succeed term-limited county executive Jan Gardner.\n\nDuring his campaign, Hough sought to cast himself as a , running on a platform of cutting es and government spending, expanding county highways including  , and slowing  through the preservation of farmland. He also outraised and outspent his Democratic opponents throughout the election, becoming the first Frederick County executive candidate to spend more than $1 million during the campaign, and received endorsements from Governor  and Democratic state legislators , , and \n\nHough ran unopposed in the primary election and faced county councilmember Jessica Fitzwater in the general election. Hough sought to associate Fitzwater with the  with incumbent county executive Jan Gardner and criticized her for \"doing nothing\" in response to ' illegal use of seclusion and restraint on disabled students, and warned that electing Fitzwater would transform Frederick County into \" North\". He also sought to associate himself with Hogan and distance himself from Republican gubernatorial nominee .\n\nHough was narrowly defeated in the general election by Fitzwater, who edged out Hough by a margin of 989 votes. Despite his loss, he outperformed other statewide Republican nominees in the county, including Cox, , and , and congressional nominee . Following his defeat, Hough declined to  in  after  announced he would vacate the seat in 2024 to .\n\n\nHough is married to his wife, JoeyLynn, who grew up in  and whom he met at the Cheyenne Club in . Together, they have three children and live in . While Hough was a member of the Maryland General Assembly, his family would rent a home in  and his children would attend  from January to April, afterwards transferring back to . JoeyLynn was elected to the Frederick County Republican Central Committee in 2018, and later sought election to the 's executive committee, but lost to .\n\nWhen Hough was 25 (2004 or 2005), he sued his parents and took custody over his younger brother. Also when he was 25, his father committed suicide.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Hough voted against repealing the death penalty in Maryland. In 2019, he cited this vote in voting against a bill to legalize .\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Hough introduced legislation to require police to pursue criminal charges against a person before they could use . He also expressed concerns with proposals to limit the police use of es and s against youths, which he claimed would make juvenile facilities more dangerous.\n\nIn 2017, Hough introduced a legislation to increase sentences for drug dealers who knowingly sell , which passed and was signed into law by Governor . He also supported a bill that would prohibit police from asking detainees about their immigration status.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Hough introduced a bill to make strangulation a first-degree felony assault. He also introduced a bill to make gun theft a felony offense and to increase penalties for repeat firearm offenders.\n\nIn 2021, Hough opposed legislation to remove the governor of Maryland from the state's parole board and criticized legislators for removing an amendment that would require six parole board members to vote to grant parole, and another bill that would prohibit state governments from holding  with . He also supported a bill ban the use of  by police officers and initially supported a bill to make police misconduct records publicly accessible, but ultimately voted against the bill after an amendment allowing unsustained complaints to remain in the public record was adopted.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Hough supported a bill to raise the salary for the Frederick County Sheriff, and criticized Democratic legislators after the bill narrowly failed in the House of Delegates. During his 2022 county executive campaign, he said he supported Frederick County's 287(g) agreement, criticizing its opponents for making a \"terrible demagoguery of this program\", and expressed support for adding the  to the county public services ordinance.\n\n\nAs a state legislator, Hough protested against bills granting voting rights to student members of boards of education. He supported Governor 's executive order mandating a post- start date for schools and opposed legislation passed in 2019 overturning the executive order. Hough initially voted for the , but voted against overriding Governor 's veto of the bill, citing the economic impact of the .\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Hough introduced legislation that would allow homeschooled students to participate in public school sports teams.\n\nIn 2015, Hough introduced a bill that would require parent to consent before schools could survey students about their drug use or sexual activity, which he called a \"troubling trend\".\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Hough introduced legislation creating  for bullies in public schools, which died in committee.\n\nIn December 2021, after the  uncovered thousands of incidents of seclusion and restraint on students with disabilities in , Hough called on the Maryland superintendent of schools to open an investigation into the matter. During the 2022 legislative session, he supported a bill to ban seclusion in schools.\n\nDuring his 2022 county executive campaign, Hough committed to increasing education funding in Frederick County.\n\n\nHough opposes providing clean energy credits to s. In February 2020, Hough questioned whether a bill to ban balloon releases was necessary, arguing that the state's anti-littering laws already made balloon releases illegal and that the penalties for releasing a balloon were too lenient.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Hough introduced legislation that would require legislative hearings to be livestreamed. In 2019, he supported a bill that would require legislative sessions to be livestreamed, which was withdrawn after House Speaker  and Senate President  said they would begin livestreaming sessions in 2020.\n\nIn 2017, Hough introduced an ethics reform bill that would ban non-elected members of county decision-making boards to resign after creating campaign finance accounts and to disclose donations of at least $500, and ban campaign contributions from businesses with pending applications. The bill was seen as a response to an ethics reform bill introduced by Frederick County Executive Jan Gardner, who criticized Hough for not proposing sections of his bill as amendments to her own. After neither ethics bills passed, Hough and Gardner agreed to merge the two bills; the compromise bill was reintroduced in 2018, during which it passed and became law.\n\nAlso in 2017, Hough opposed a bill that would require Maryland use an  to draw its congressional districts if six other states agreed to do the same. In March 2019, after the  in '''' struck down Maryland's redistricting plan as unconstitutionally gerrymandered, Hough said he supported maps proposed by Governor , which would have redrawn  to include Frederick and  counties, thereby making it more favorable to Republicans. He supported the 's decision in ''Benisek v. Lamone''.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Hough proposed changing the Senate Rules to limit state senators to introducing 20 bills per year, excluding administrative bills, local bills, and committee bills, which he argued would make the legislature more productive and cut down on perennially failing bills. Hough's proposal was not adopted by the Senate Rules Committee, though legislators expressed openness to the idea of a bill limit and said that they would study the issue over the summer.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Hough opposed legislation to abolish the Maryland Handgun Permit Review Board, which he called a \"check and balance\" against \"nameless, faceless bureaucrats\".\n\nIn 2019, Hough introduced a bill that would allow the  to expand payment methods for handgun permits to include electronic payments.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Hough introduced legislation to allow people with  licenses to purchase and carry firearms. The bill unanimously passed the Maryland Senate, but died in the House of Delegates. He also opposed a bill creating a gun buyback program in Maryland, saying that criminals would sell inoperable guns back to the state instead of working assault weapons.\n\nIn April 2020, Hough delivered a letter to Governor  calling him to reopen gun shops amid the , noting that governors in New Jersey and Maine allowed gun shops to remain open.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Hough voted to sustain Hogan's veto on a bill requiring background checks for shotgun and rifle sales, arguing that the bill would \"punish\" sportsmen and farmers, and that legislators should instead prioritize legislation to reduce gun violence.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Hough introduced a bill that would allow speed up evictions of dangerous tenants from fourteen to seven days.\n\nDuring his 2022 county executive campaign, Hough blamed the Frederick County government for the county's affordable housing shortage, arguing that the county's property taxes were \"burdening\" residents and developers, and argued that the county should focus development in areas outside of Frederick, claiming that it would lessen the burden on roads and schools. He also opposed the construction of the county's 209,000 square-foot facility, saying that he would issue a stop-work order on construction for the project and create an independent commission to investigate the county's $20 million purchase of land for the facility.\n\n\nDuring debate on a bill to raise the minimum wage in 2014, Hough introduced an amendment exempting businesses within 90 miles of the state border from the wage increase, which was rejected by the House of Delegates. During the 2019 legislative session, he opposed legislation to raise Maryland's minimum wage to , which he said would eliminate starting jobs for teenagers.\n\n\nHough is  and supported legislation to restrict abortions while serving in the Maryland General Assembly. During his 2014 state senate campaign, he criticized Brinkley for not supporting efforts to overturn the results of , which upheld a state law codifying the 's decision in ''''. In September 2015, amid the , Hough wrote a letter to Brinkley, now the Maryland Budget Secretary, calling on him to eliminate the use of state funds to support .\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Hough opposed a bill to remove \"\" as the official state song, defending the song against criticisms from other legislators who called it \"racist\".\n\nDuring debate on a bill to raise the  to 21 years old in 2019, Hough introduced an amendment that would keep the age limit at 18 years for members of the military, which was added to the bill. In November 2019, he met with President  and other White House officials to discuss federal legislation to increase the smoking age to 21, during which he expressed opposition to the proposal.\n\nIn September 2020, following President 's executive order establishing the Interagency Task Force for Building and Rebuilding Monuments to American Heroes to create a \"\", Hough wrote a letter to the committee to recommend a memorial dedicated to anti-communist . The proposal was opposed by Chambers' family, who wrote an op-ed to the '''' thanking Hough for proposing the monument but asking him to withdraw Chambers' name from consideration.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Hough spoke against a bill to eliminate the  on  cases, criticizing state delegate , who introduced the bill, for going back on his agreement with the Maryland Catholic Conference to introduce no further legislation on child sexual abuse lawsuits after legislators passed a bill expanding the statute of limitations from 25 to 38-years-old, but including a  to prevent lawsuits against the .\n\n\nIn 2021, Hough opposed a bill to extend the state's  to undocumented immigrants, and criticized Governor 's RELIEF Act, which provided more than $1 billion in tax relief and stimulus checks to small businesses and families, for not going far enough. During the 2022 legislative session, he introduced a bill to decouple Maryland's  from inflation.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
