    "pages": }\n'''Sharon Green Middleton''' (née '''Green'''; May 1, 1954) is an American politician who has been a member of the  since 2007 and its vice president since 2016. A member of the , she briefly served as acting president of the Baltimore City Council following 's ascension to mayor following the resignation of .\n\n\nMiddleton was born in  on May 1, 1954 to mother Martha V. Green (née Martha Virginia McDaniel), a retired telephone operator and day care worker, and father Kennedy Carl Green, a steelworker. She graduated from  with a  degree in secondary education in 1976, afterwards working as a teacher for  for two decades, afterwards working as a specialist for the  and the  until her retirement in 2006.\n\n\nIn February 2007, after  was appointed president of the Baltimore City Council following the election of  as , Middleton applied to serve the remainder of Rawlings-Blake's term on the Baltimore City Council. The Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee unanimously voted to nominate her to the seat. Middleton's nomination was confirmed by the Baltimore City Council and she was sworn in on February 26, 2007. She ran for and was elected to a full four-term in 2007.\n\nFollowing the resignation of Baltimore mayor Catherine Pugh in April 2019, Middleton temporarily became the acting president of the Baltimore City Council. She served in this position until May 6, 2019, when the Baltimore City Council voted unanimously to elect  as its new president.\n\n\nIn December 2019, Middleton was elected president of the Maryland Association of Counties, becoming the lobbying group's first African American from Baltimore to hold the position.\n\n\nMiddleton was married to Glenard S. Middleton Sr., who was the leader of  (AFSCME) Local 67 until its merger with AFSCME Local 3 in 2023. They were married from 1980 until his death on November 7, 2024. Together, they had a son and a stepdaughter, both of whom work in Baltimore city government as of November 2023.\n\n\n\nIn January 2014, Middleton said she supported a proposal that would require one-third of Baltimore's residential liquor stores to close within two years, claiming that it would help fight crime in the city.\n\nIn September 2014, following a '''' investigation that found that the city of Baltimore had covered the costs for more than 100  settlements or verdicts since 2011, Middleton called on the  to improve its training programs to help officers deal with different personalities on the streets. In September 2019, she opposed a bill that would end the use of \"s\" in city police misconduct cases.\n\nIn May 2022, amid an increase in violent crime in Baltimore, Middleton called for an increase in neighborhood patrolling and questioned the effectiveness of community violence intervention programs, including the Mayor's Office of Neighborhood Safety and Engagement (MONSE).\n\n\nIn January 2014, Middleton voted against a bill implementing a 10-cent fee on paper and plastic bags in stores, saying that she instead wanted the city to develop a comprehensive litter control program.\n\n\nIn September 2013, Middleton voted against a proposal to convert Baltimore's old  chemical plant to a waterfront development, citing concerns about safety and criticisms toward subsidies provided to the project.\n\nIn September 2016, Middleton voted against a bill that would have required developers receiving tax incentives to build affordable housing units.\n\nIn February 2018, Middleton voted for a bill to provide $4 million in tax breaks toward the redevelopment of the Northwood Plaza shopping center.\n\nIn June 2019, following an  study that uncovered disparities in water affordability among African Americans in Baltimore, Middleton introduced a bill to reform the process for disputing city water bills and provide financial assistance to certain city residents for water and sewer bills.\n\nIn January 2021, Middleton introduced a bill that would require landlords with 10 or more units to offer tenants  payment alternatives. After the bill was vetoed by Mayor , she introduced another bill to create a program providing grants to low-income residents to pay their security deposits, which passed and was signed into law by Mayor Scott.\n\nIn January 2022, Middleton proposed using  funding to support Baltimore's existing housing programs, especially the weatherization assistance program, which she claimed weren't \"getting the job done\".\n\n\nIn October 2007, amid a dispute between the Baltimore Teachers Union and , Middleton introduced a nonbinding resolution supporting the union.\n\nIn March 2017, Middleton voted for a bill to raise the minimum wage in Baltimore to .\n\nIn December 2020, Middleton voted for a bill to provide job protections to hospitality workers laid off during the COVID-19 pandemic. After the bill was vetoed by Mayor Young, she voted against overriding the mayor's veto.\n\n\nIn July 2020, Middleton voted against a bill creating a city-wide referendum on placing a three-term limit on city elected officials.\n\n\nIn March 2019, Middleton said she supported the removal of s along , saying that her constituents were tired of \"experiments\". In January 2024, she called for a hearing on the city's bike infrastructure, citing community concerns over bike lanes in certain parts of the city. At the hearing, Middleton claimed that bike lanes were \"unfair\" to families with cars.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James Edward DeGrange Sr.''' (born September 24, 1949) is an American politician from  and a member of the . He completed his third term in the , representing Maryland's district 32 in , at the end of 2018.\n\n\nDeGrange was born in , but grew up in Anne Arundel County. He graduated from  in 1968 and attended . He served in the  from 1968 to 1974. He is the Vice-President of the DeGrange Lumber Company.\n\n\nDeGrange's political career began with his service on the  Commission, on which he served from 1991 to 1999. In 1994, he was elected to serve on the Anne Arundel County Council. After one term on the council, he ran for and won the district 32 seat in the State Senate. DeGrange sat on the Budget and Taxation Committee and served as Vice-Chair of the Executive Nominations Committee.\n\nDeGrange currently lives in Baywood, Delaware. He is Catholic.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kumar Prabhakar Barve''' (; born September 8, 1958) is an American  politician. He is a member of the Maryland Public Service Commission, to which he was appointed by  in May 2023. He was previously a member of the , representing district 17 in , from 1991 to 2023. He was the first  to be elected to a state legislature in the United States. From 2002 to 2015, Barve served as  of the House of Delegates.\n\nHis legislative work focused largely on protecting the environment, improving health care, and the promotion of the high-tech industry in Maryland. In 2015, he was appointed to chair the House Environment and Transportation Committee, which oversees transportation, the environment, agriculture, ethics, and housing and real property law. He sponsored both the 1995 Health Access Act that place limits on HMOs for the first time and legislation that created the Technology Development Corporation of Maryland.\n\nHe unsuccessfully ran for Congress in 2016 in , losing the Democratic Primary to the eventual winner, State Senator .\n\n\nBarve was born on September 8, 1958, in , to  parents. The family later moved to , where he attended  in . In 1980, Barve graduated from 's  with a  degree in Accounting.\n\n\nBarve was first elected to the House of Delegates in 1990, finishing third in the contest for district 17's three seats behind incumbents  and  but ahead of four other challengers. As a result of his victory, Barve became the first Indian-American to serve in a state legislature. He took office in January, 1991, and was appointed to the House Economic Matters Committee, which considers legislation related to business and labor policy and regulation.\n\nAfter his first re-election in 1994, Barve rose in leadership with his appointment as chair of a subcommittee, first the Real Property subcommittee in 1995 and 1996, and later the Science and Technology Subcommittee from 1997 to 2003. Also in 1995, he was elected to chair the Montgomery County Delegation to Annapolis. Barve was re-elected in 1998, 2002, 2006, and 2010.\n\nFollowing the election of a new Speaker, , in 2003, Barve was appointed to serve as , the leader of the Democratic majority and second in command to the Speaker. He served for two years on the Environmental Matters Committee before moving again to the Ways and Means Committee, where he oversaw tax policy as Chair of the Revenues Subcommittee from 2007 to 2010. In additional, he serves on a number of major joint committees, including the Legislative Policy Committee, Spending Affordability Committee, as chair of the Joint Information Technology and Biotechnology Committee, and as house chair of the Joint Committee on Transparency and Open Government.\n\nIn 2015, Barve left his post as majority leader to become chair of the renamed Environment and Transportation Committee. His appointment coincided with the election of a new Republican Governor,  and debate over a number of significant environmental issues. Among the significant pieces of legislation Barve's committee worked on in the first year of the new term were a moratorium and public health study on fracking, a major reform to the state's stormwater protection fee, and debate over regulations which will require farms to severely limit the phosphorus that runs from their lands into the Chesapeake Bay.\n\nBarve's work as a legislator over the length of his career has focused on a broad range of issues. In 1995, he successfully sponsored the first state bill in the nation to regulate HMOs, the Maryland Health Access Act of 1995. The act allows health care patients to see doctors outside of the network of HMO providers, ensures that HMOs can't bar providers from sharing information if it jeopardizes patient care, and prohibits the use of financial incentives by HMOs that curtail and compromise care. He later co-sponsored the law that bars insurance companies based in Maryland from using pre-existing conditions to deny coverage.\n\nBarve has also worked extensively on the promotion of technology and of high tech businesses. He authored Maryland's version of the  (UCITA). The Act both affirms the intellectual-property rights of software developers and provides unprecedented consumer protections to purchasers of computer equipment. He sponsored legislation that created the Technology Development Corporation of Maryland, which promotes high-technology business development in Maryland.\nIn 1999, Barve's bill to define the powers of corporations in making certain gifts passed both houses and was signed by the governor.\n\nIn the , Barve endorsed  for president.\n\nOn April 6, 2023, Governor  announced he would appoint Barve to the . He resigned from the Maryland House of Delegates on May 1, 2023.\n\n\nIn November 2007, Barve was cited by Gaithersburg Police for driving under the influence of alcohol while operating a vehicle. On July 17, 2008, Barve pleaded guilty and received a probation before judgement, and suspension of all but $200 of a $1,000 fine.\n\nIn 2008, it was reported that Barve and his wife were inappropriately receiving a Homestead Property Tax Credit on two properties that they had owned separately prior to their marriage. Barve indicated that he had assumed  would delete the tax credit on the property his wife had owned prior to their marriage once the couple declared his residence in Gaithersburg to be their primary joint residence. While early reports were critical of Barve, the Associate Director of Assessments and Taxation for Maryland later told reporters than nothing improper had taken place, and that such errors had occurred repeatedly in cases where individuals owned homes and then later married. Barve pledged that he would re-pay any money that the couple did not pay earlier due to the error.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Steven James Arentz''' (born April 17, 1951) is an American politician from the  who is a member of the  representing the  since 2013. He was previously the president of the  from 2010 to 2013.\n\n\nArentz was born in , and grew up in , where he attended the  and the . He later attended . Arentz previously owned his own business, Hemingway's Restaurant, until its closure in October 2010, and has worked as a realtor for  since 2003.\n\nArentz is married to his wife, Biana, and has two children.\n\n\nIn 2010, Arentz was elected to the Queen Anne's County Board of Commissioners and served as chair of the Roads Board and Sanitary Commission until November 19, 2013. At the same time, he served as a member on the Queen Anne's County Board of Health and on the Task Force on Government Sustainability. Following his resignation from the county commission, businessman James Moran was appointed to serve the remainder of his term.\n\n\nIn August 2013, following the resignation of Senate minority leader , Arentz applied to serve the remainder of Pipkin's term in the . After  was appointed to the seat, he applied to fill Hershey's seat the Maryland House of Delegates. The Republican Central Committees in Queen Anne's, , and  counties voted to recommend Arentz to the seat in October 2013, and Governor  appointed him to the seat later on November 12. Arentz was sworn in on November 19, 2013. He was elected to a full four-year term in .\n\nArentz was a member of the Appropriations Committee from 2014 to 2015, and has served on the Economic Matters Committee since 2015. He also served as the Deputy Minority Whip for the Maryland House Republican Caucus from 2017 to 2020.\n\n\n\nArentz supported the Four Seasons project, a proposed waterfront housing development on . In July 2013, opponents of the housing project filed an ethics complaint against Arentz, claiming that he would benefit from the project since it was a few hundred yards away from a commercial building that he owned, a conflict of interest that plaintiffs said should have prevented him from voting on a measure to approve the developers' request for a wetlands permit. Arentz rejected any conflict of interest, saying that he would \"gain nothing more than any other citizen in this county who has a business\". Other members of the Queen Anne's County Board of Commissioners also defended Arentz's vote on the bill, predicting that Arentz would from being a realtor before he could sell any homes built at Four Seasons.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Arentz introduced legislation that would limit the amount of time students spent on school laptops. He reintroduced the bill in 2018.\n\nIn 2015, Arentz introduced a bill that would establish a two-way text messaging tip system for reporting bullying at schools.\n\nIn March 2021, Arentz voted against legislation to provide free  in school bathrooms.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Arentz spoke in support of a bill that would allow the use of  to catch clams south of the .\n\nIn October 2017, Arentz said that he supported , but complained that  along state highways were taking away farmland and not creating jobs. He opposed the , casting doubt onto the bill's goals to achieve 100 percent renewable energy dependency, questioning whether the state could recoup for the energy lost from the transition away from , and predicting that the bill's cost would fall onto ratepayers.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Arentz voted against a bill to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour. In 2019, he opposed a bill to raise the state's minimum wage to .\n\nIn April 2018, Arentz voted against the Reform on Tap Act, a bill backed by Comptroller  to deregulate the state's craft beer industry.\n\nIn April 2022, Arentz said he opposed legislation that would provide workers with 24 weeks of , which he said would hurt businesses.\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Arentz introduced legislation that would extend state hate crime protections to first responders. The bill died in committee.\n\nIn March 2021, Arentz voted against legislation to repeal \"\" as the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''William Joseph Wivell''' (born June 9, 1964) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2015. A member of the , he was previously a member of the  Board of Commissioners from 1998 to 2010, and from 2014 to 2015.\n\n\nWivell was born in ,  on June 9, 1964. He attended  in  and graduated from  with a  degree in 1984. He later graduated from  with a  in 1986, and from  with an   in 1991. Wivell currently works as a business administrator at the .\n\nIn 1998, Wivell was elected to the , where he served until he retired in 2010 to \"take a break from public life to focus on other things\". In 2008, he applied to fill a vacancy in the Maryland House of Delegates following the resignation of . Wivell was re-elected to the Board of County Commissioners in 2014, where he served until Governor  appointed him to serve in the Maryland House of Delegates in February 2015, filling a vacancy left by the resignation of delegate  to serve in the .\n\nWivell is an endowment life member of the .\n\n\nWivell was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on March 16, 2015. He was a member of the Appropriations Committee from 2015 to 2016, afterwards serving on the Environment and Transportation Committee until 2022. Since 2023, Wivell has served on the Economic Matters Committee.\n\nIn January 2020, Wivell was named as the co-chairman of the Washington County Trump Leadership team.\n\nIn August 2020, following the resignation of state Senator , Wivell applied to fill the vacancy he left in the Maryland Senate. The Washington County Republican Central Committee and   would end up nominating delegate  to fill the vacancy.\n\nIn October 2021, Wivell was one of five Maryland state legislators from , , and Washington counties who sent a pair of letters to  officials asking about annexation of  to West Virginia. These letters caused a local uproar, with Allegany County officials calling the request a political stunt, an embarrassment and unneeded distraction. Following criticism from local officials and some constituents, Delegate  and State Senator  issued a letter withdrawing support for the secession proposal.\n\n\nWivell is married to his wife, Robin (née Lynne), who unsuccessfully ran for the Washington County Board of Commissioners in 2010 and briefly ran for the Washington County Board of Education in 2016.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Wivell introduced a bill to provide sales tax exemptions for development at . In March 2017, he voted against legislation to dissolve the PenMar Development Corporation, a state-owned company tasked with redeveloping Fort Ritchie.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Wivell introduced a bill that would require state colleges to accept 100- and 200-level course credits from community colleges. In 2021, he expressed concerns with the 's costs having voted against the bill during the 2020 legislative session and to sustain Governor 's veto of the education reform bill.\n\n\nWivell supports the  and opposes  laws, instead favoring legislation to improve mental health treatment. In 2018, following the , he voted against bills to ban s and rapid fire trigger activators.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Wivell introduced legislation that would ban  in jails. The bill died in committee, and was subsequently reintroduced in 2019 and 2020.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Wivell opposed a bill that would prohibit police from asking detainees about their immigration status, which he said would put Marylanders \"at risk\".\n\nIn 2019, Wivell introduced a bill that would make s optional when hiring state correctional officers.\n\n\nWivell opposes state funding for abortions. During the 2017 legislative session, he introduced legislation that would place restrictions on late-term abortions, including a bill that would ban \"dismemberment abortion\" with exemptions for life of the mother. During the 2022 legislative session, during debate on the Abortion Care Access Act, Wivell introduced an amendment that would remove $3.5 million in state funding for clinician training, instead requiring taxpayers to check off on their taxes if they want to contribute to the funds. The amendment was rejected in a 39-87 vote. In 2023, during debate on a bill creating a statewide referendum on enshrining '''' into the , he proposed amendments that would require the constitution to guarantee constitutional rights to the \"preborn\", and another that would limit the bill to cover only abortions instead of all reproductive health. Both amendments were rejected by the House of Delegates.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Wivell supported a resolution endorsing a  to create a constitutional amendment on s.\n\nIn 2021, Wivell introduced a bill that would remove party affiliation from absentee ballot envelopes. The bill passed the House of Delegates, but did not receive a vote in the Senate. It was reintroduced in 2022.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Wivell was one of two state delegates to vote against the , a bill that would abolish the  on  cases.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Wivell introduced a bill that would decouple the state's tax code with the federal tax code.\n\n\nWivell supports the widening of .\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Wivell introduced legislation to ban tree planting alongside  along agriculturally-zoned properties.\n\nIn February 2017, Wivell voted against a bill that would make it illegal to block a four-way intersection.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Wivell introduced bills that would allow adults to ride scooters without helmets and to end mandatory  for low-mileage vehicles.\n\nIn 2019, Wivell introduced legislation that would require s to display your speed as a car approaches.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Wivell introduced a bill that would allow municipalities to enforce laws against driving dirt bikes on public roads.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Keith E. Haynes''' (born February 15, 1963) is a former  and lawyer.  Haynes was first elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in 2002 and re-elected in 2006. He represents the 44th Legislative District () in the .   As a lawyer, Haynes was a Senior Attorney with the Law of Offices of , P.C. and practiced in Maryland and  the District of Columbia in the practice areas of Products Liability, Asbestos Litigation, Toxic Torts and General Civil Litigation. In June 2021, Haynes announced that he was retiring from the Maryland General Assembly.\n\n\nHaynes was born in . He attended , where he earned a  degree in political science with a concentration in law and political philosophy. At , he earned a  (cum laude). He then graduated from the  with a Juris Doctor Degree  He has been admitted and is a current member of the Maryland Bar and  the District of Columbia Bar.  Haynes has also been admitted to practice before the United States District Court for the District of Maryland; the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit; and the United States Supreme Court. As a practicing attorney, he is a member of the American Bar Association; the National Bar Association; the Federal Bar Association; the Maryland State Bar Association; the Bar Association of Baltimore City; the Monumental Bar Association; the Maryland Trial Lawyers' Association and the American Trial Lawyers' Association.\n\n\nDelegate Haynes was a member of the House of Delegates from January 8, 2003 to December 2021. He was chosen by  to be a Deputy Majority Whip in 2006.  He was a member of the  where he served as Vice-Chair of the Health and Human Resources Subcommittee.  As a member of the  House Appropriations Committee, Haynes also served on the Capital Budget Subcommittee; Oversight Committee on Pensions; Juvenile Services Facilities Work Group; and the Oversight Committee on Personnel (2004–2006). In addition to serving on the Appropriations Committee, Haynes wasy  a member of  the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review (AELR); Joint Audit Committee and the Special Joint Committee on Pensions.  He served as  the Vice Chairman of the  and is the former Vice President of the Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland Foundation (2004–2006) and a member of the .\n\n\n*Co-sponsored HB 860 (Baltimore City Public Schools Construction and Revitalization Act of 2013). Signed by the Governor on May 16, 2013, the new law approved 1.1 billion dollars to construct new schools in Baltimore City.\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted in favor of prohibiting ground rents in 2007(SB106)\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax by 20% - Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* voted in favor of prohibiting ground rents in 2007(SB106)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted in favor of slots (HB4) in the 2007 Special session\n\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 44th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:''' (only the top 6 finishers are shown)\n:\n\n\n'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 44th District''' Retrieved on Mar. 3, 2007   \n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\nAdditional Information about Keith E.     "pages": }\n'''April R. Rose''' (born 1968 or 1969)  is an American politician who is a member of the  who represents the  in the . She has also served as the Assistant Minority Leader since 2021.\n\n\nRose was born in , in 1968 or 1969. She graduated from  and attended  from 1986 to 1987.\n\nRose worked as an underwriter for  from 2001 to 2005, afterwards working as a licensed real estate salesperson for Main Street America Reality until 2008. She has worked as an IT recruiter for NMR Consulting since 2009.\n\nRose first got involved in politics in 2002 as a member of the South Carroll Republican Club, eventually becoming its president. She was also a member of the Carroll County Republican Central Committee from 2004 to 2010. In 2008, Rose started working as an events coordinator for the  before resigning after party chair James Pelura fired the party's executive director  in July 2009, which sparked infighting between Pelura and members of the  that eventually ended in Pelura's ouster. In 2010, she became a communications coordinator for the Maryland Republican Caucus.\n\nIn 2014, Governor  appointed Rose to the Carroll County Board of Elections.\n\n\nRose was appointed by Governor  to fill a vacancy left by state delegate , who was appointed to fill a vacancy in the  left by state senator . She was sworn in on March 16, 2015, and was elected to a full four-year term in . Rose was a member of the Health and Governments Operations Committee from 2015 to 2017, and has served in the Ways and Means Committee since 2017.\n\nDuring the , Rose said she initially supported Texas governor  but supported  once he became the Republican nominee, agreeing with his positions on fiscal issues and citing her distrust for .\n\n\nRose is married and has four children.\n\n\n\nRose self-identifies as \"\" and opposes . During the 2016 legislative session, she supported legislation to ban abortions past 20 weeks of pregnancy. In 2019, Rose introduced an amendment to the state budget that sought to remove  funding for abortions, which was rejected in a 41-93 vote. In March 2022, during debate on the Abortion Care Access Act, she introduced an amendment to reappropriate the bill's $3.5 million in funding for clinical training, which was rejected in a 41-85 vote. In May 2023, after Governor  signed a bill creating a  on codifying abortion access into law, Rose released a statement calling the bill \"radical\".\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Rose supported legislation that would sentence people convicted of mass murder or killing a police officer to death.\n\nIn July 2020, amid nationwide , Rose organized a \"\" rally in Annapolis.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Rose said she opposed the Police Reform and Accountability Act, an omnibus police reform bill that repealed the  and regulated the types of  police could use in arrests.\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Rose supported legislation to limit standardized testing in kindergarten and ban testing in prekindergarten.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Rose introduced legislation that would allow computer science classes to qualify toward foreign language credits required for high school graduation. In 2021, she introduced a bill that would count computer science classes toward math credits.\n\nIn March 2020, Rose said she supported some of the policy items in the , including its college and career readiness initiatives, but said that it would be \"fiscally irresponsible\" to move forward with it during the . She also opposed tax increases to pay for the Blueprint reforms.\n\nIn May 2020, amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Rose signed onto a letter asking the county health department to allow  to have outdoor graduations. The county health department rejected the request, citing Governor 's executive orders. In June, she participated in and spoke at a Reopen Maryland rally to call for the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions. Rose has signed onto letters asking the  to lift the county's in-school , calling it \"unscientific\".\n\n\nIn January 2019, Rose said she supported , but opposed building  over farmland.\n\nIn May 2021, Rose expressed interest in removing the state-imposed restriction requiring Carroll County to preserve 100,000 acres of agriculture, saying that the land preservation limited county housing opportunities.\n\n\nIn March 2007, Rose said she supported the  and criticized media coverage of the war. In October 2016, she said she did not support allowing more , arguing that the country should first support its homeless veterans.\n\n\nRose supports the  and opposes gun control laws, arguing that they increase crime and make people less safe. She also supports legislation to make Maryland a . In July 2022, following the 's ruling in '''', Rose signed onto a letter to the  asking him to address the issue.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Rose said she opposed legislation to raise the state minimum wage to , arguing that it would worsen competition between Carroll County and .\n\n\nIn March 2019, Rose said she supported Governor 's proposed redraw of Maryland's congressional mapswhich saw  redrawn to include  and Carroll counties, thereby making it more favorable to Republicans.\n\n\nIn August 2024, Rose endorsed the , a federal bill that would require voters to show  when registering to vote.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Cathi Forbes''' (born June 15, 1965) is an  of the  who represents District 43B in the . Governor  first appointed her to succeed former state delegate  in 2019, in what was then District 42A. She was then elected to a four-year term in 2022, representing District 43B, which was drawn based on the 2020 Census.\n\n\nForbes was born on June 15, 1965, in . She graduated from  in  and attended  in , , where she earned a  degree in English language and art history in 1987. She worked in  as an editorial assistant at a magazine and as administrative assistant with an advertising agency, where she met her husband, John Patterson.\n\nIn 1990, Forbes and Patterson moved to , where she worked for Barton Cotton, a company that makes greeting cards. They moved to  in 2000.\n\nIn 2000, Forbes established the Coalition for Open Government to oppose a $75 million expansion of the Baltimore County Detention Center, the county's main jail center. She argued that county officials had decided to expand the jail without seeking public input. In addition, she pointed to a 1995 study that called for building a new jail on a much larger 40- to 50-acre plot to accommodate expansion.\n\nIn December 2007, Forbes and a few others formed Towson Families United, seeking to pressure school and county officials to either build a new school in Towson or reopen one of the three that closed in the late 1970s, a plan that was opposed by county executive  In May 2008, the school board voted to build a new school on the campus of the Ridge Ruxton School.\n\nIn 2014, Forbes became a mediation coordinator for the Baltimore County Orphans' Court.\n\nIn September 2019, following the resignation of state delegate Steven Lafferty, Forbes applied to fill his vacancy in the Maryland House of Delegates. The Baltimore County Democratic State Central Committee voted to recommend appointing Forbes to fill the vacancy on September 25, and Governor Larry Hogan appointed her to the House of Delegates on October 9, 2019.\n\n\nForbes was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on October 29, 2019.\n\n\n* Member, Appropriations Committee, 2020–present \n* Chair, Oversight Committee on Pensions, 2023–present\n* Member, Capital Budget subcommittee, 2023–present\n* Education & Economic Development subcommittee, 2020–present\n* Member, Oversight Committee on Personnel, 2020–2022\n\nSource:\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2021–present\n* Honorary Lifetime Membership Award, Maryland PTA, 2012–present\n* Member, Board of Directors, Children's Playhouse of Maryland, 2015–present\n* Member, League of Women Voters\n* Member, Sierra Club\n\nSource:\n\n\n\nForbes supports the , a recommendation from the Kirwan Commission. She also supported legislation introduced in the 2020 legislative session that would provide $2.2 billion for local school construction.\n\nForbes has been a vocal advocate in favor of replacing Towson High School, the oldest and most overcrowded high school in the county. Two new high schools ware included in the 2022 budget.\n\n\nForbes introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would require all state-owned buildings to install s on their roofs. The bill did not receive a vote during the session. In January 2022, Forbes introduced legislation, HB1165, to require new state-funded construction or renovation projectsincluding new schoolsto be high-performance “green” buildings.\n\n\nAfter hearing about racist and anti-Semitic language that continues to exist on older property deeds, in the form of covenants, Forbes introduced HB1077 in 2020. It made such language easier to remove by homeowners, by waiving any fees associated with the removal. Her bill passed unanimously into law in 2020, and received national media attention.\n\n\nIn September 2020, Forbes resisted a planned 57-unit affordable housing complex, due to the possible loss of a historic Black neighborhood that was currently there.\n\n\nForbes introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that gave Baltimore County Public Library staff the right to form a union and receive . The bill passed and went into effect without Governor Hogan's signature. The employees voted in March 2022 to form a union.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kenneth N. Harris, Sr.''' (July 17, 1963 – September 20, 2008), a member of the , was a candidate for  President.  He served on the city council since 1999, representing 's 4th Council District, until 2007. On September 20, 2008, Harris was shot and killed outside of a jazz club in northeast Baltimore.\n\n\nKen Harris was born to Sylvia Harris, a single teenage mother in the  neighborhood of Baltimore City. Growing up in a rough area, Ken saw first hand what a crime-ridden community looked like. He put all of his energy into school, learning at an early age that he didn't want to wind up in gangs or worse. Harris graduated from  and was MVP of their baseball team in 1981. Although Harris had been drafted by the , he enrolled at Morgan State University to further his education. On August 25, 1985, Harris married the former Annette Barnes and from this union, Nicole and Kenneth Jr. were born.\n\nAfter completing a B.S. in  at Morgan in 1989, Harris first worked for . In 1997 he was hired as director of membership and business services for the Downtown Partnership of Baltimore and a few years later he was hired as an executive at . Harris served as President of the Leith Walk Elementary School  and coached in the Northwood Baseball League.\n\n\nHarris was elected to the Baltimore City Council in 1999. He represented the fourth district, located in North-Central Baltimore. In addition to his committee responsibilities, Harris was a frequent speaker at City Schools, delivering motivational speeches focused on what young people need to succeed. Harris established the \"Bridge to Manhood\" in 2005, a program that sends successful African-American men into City Schools to talk with boys about overcoming the odds. He was a leader on the Council to combat secondhand smoke through a citywide .\n\nHarris chaired the Education, Housing, Health, and Human Services Committee, was a member of the Land Use and Transportation Committee, and chaired the Highways and Franchise Subcommittee.\n\n\nHarris launched a  on January 29, 2007. Harris was endorsed by ,  and the . Harris' campaign failed to gain traction, and he ultimately won 11 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary, far behind Michael Sarbanes and incumbent and ultimate winner .\n\n\nOn September 20, 2008, at approximately 1:45 in the morning, Harris was shot outside of the New Haven Lounge in northeast . Four men, with their faces covered and at least one of them armed with a hand gun, surprised Harris and the club's owner during an apparent robbery attempt at the club's front entrance. Harris was chased to his car by one of the men when the assailant shot through the window of Harris' , striking him in the chest.  The men then robbed the club and fled out a back door leading to an alley behind the shopping center.  Harris was taken to  where he was pronounced dead shortly after 2:00 am.\n\nOn November 14, 2008, Baltimore City police announced the arrest of two suspects in the case. Ultimately, three individuals would stand trial:  22-year-old Charles Y. McGaney and 17-year-old Jerome Williams were convicted in Baltimore City Circuit and sentenced to life plus 30 years.  22-year-old Gary A. Collins was convicted of the robbery of club patrons, but not the murder of Harris.\n\nMore than 1,500 people, including Governor , former Governor , Senator  and Congressman , attended his funeral at the Murphy Fine Arts Building on the campus of . All state of Maryland flags were flown at half-staff on the day of his funeral.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Cathy Vitale''' (born 13 August 1964) is a Circuit Court Judge for . A Republican, she represented  in the  from January 12, 2011, to February 23, 2015, resigning to serve on the bench.\n\nVitale began her public service in 1994, when she was elected to serve as a member of the Anne Arundel County Republican Central Committee. She was the chairman for the committee from 1998 to 2000.\n\nShe was the appointed to the County Council following a vacancy from the 5th District. She was then elected in her own right in 2002, and again in 2006. During her time there, she served as the council vice chair from 2008 to 2009, and as its chair in 2009.\n\nDue to term limits, Vitale was barred from running for the county council again. Instead she ran for the open seat of District 33A, in the Maryland House of Delegates. Vitale served on the Environmental Matters Committee from 2011 to 2014 and then the Environment and Transportation Committee in 2015. She was also a member of the Anne Arundel County Delegation Committee, where she served as the subcommittee chair for Alcoholic Beverages.\n\nShe is a graduate of the  (1985) and the  (1989).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Chao Wu''' (born 1976/1977) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for  in  and  counties. He was previously a member of the  from 2018 to 2022.\n\n\nWu attended the , where he earned a  degree in 2001; the , where he earned a  degree in electrical and computer engineering in 2003; and the , receiving a Doctor of Philosophy degree in electrical and computer engineering in 2009. While at the University of Maryland, Wu served as president of the local  (CSSA) chapter. As CSSA president, Wu campaigned against  and perceived biased content in '''' towards the  in Beijing.\n\nAfter graduating, Wu worked in the private and public sectors, specializing in data science, machine learning, artificial intelligence, quantum computing, cybersecurity and enterprise risk management. Wu represented the  on the Columbia Association's board of directors until 2018, and served as a board member of the River Hill Village Association from 2012 to 2018. During this time, Wu was instrumental in initiating 's  agreement with .\n\nIn November 2017 Wu filed to run for the Howard County Board of Education. He won the nonpartisan primary election on June 27, 2018, and later won election to the board on November 6. In December 2020, Wu was elected as the Board of Education's chairperson, becoming the first Asian American to lead the board. In October 2021, Wu was named to serve as a board member to the Maryland Association of Boards of Education.\n\nIn February 2022 Wu filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates. He won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, and later won the general election on November 8, narrowly defeating incumbent state delegate  with .\n\n\n\nWu was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Ways and Means Committee.\n\n\nWu lives in . He is a father of two children.\n\n\nIn June 2021 Wu voted against ending the school system's  program. The school board voted 5–3 to continue the program.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jay A. Jacobs''' (born January 28, 1953) is an American politician from the  who is a member of the , representing the  since 2011.\n\n\nJacobs was born on January 28, 1953, in . He graduated from . Jacobs has owned his own business, Jay A. Jacobs Complete Kitchens and Baths LLC, since 1986.\n\nJacobs served as the mayor of , from 1999 to 2011. He was mayor when  struck the fishing town in 2003, which damaged more than 100 buildings, including half of the town's motels and inns, and the town's public pier.\n\n\nIn July 2009, Jacobs announced that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 36, seeking to succeed retiring state delegate . He ran unopposed in the Republican primary election, and defeated Democratic nominee Arthur Hock in the general election in November 2010. He was sworn in as a member of House of Delegates on January 12, 2011, and has served as a member of the Environment and Transportation Committee during his entire tenure. Jacobs has also served as the chair of the House Republican Caucus since 2013.\n\n\n\nJacobs is married to his wife, Dawn, who served as the mayor of Rock Hall, Maryland, from 2019 to 2023. Together, they have two adult daughters.\n\n\n\nIn 2011, Jacobs opposed legislation to ban , suggesting that the state instead establish sanctuaries for menhaden.\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Jacobs said he opposed legislation that would require the  to cover the costs of managing fisheries with fishing license fees.\n\nIn 2014, Jacobs introduced legislation to allow the use of  to catch clams south of the . In 2016, Jacobs introduced a bill that would allow hydraulic clamming south of the .\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Jacobs opposed legislation that would require the state to track air pollution from s.\n\n\nIn January 2020, Jacobs said he opposed the , citing its cost. He later predicted that the Blueprint would require the state to raise taxes to fully implement, which would \"stir up\" voters.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Jacobs introduced legislation to provide voting rights to the student member of the Kent County Board Education. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nIn January 2012, Jacobs said he opposed .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Jacobs introduced a bill that would prohibit the state from entering into an agreement waiving its authority under the  relating the relicensure of the .\n\n\nIn July 2012, Jacobs celebrated a federal court decision overturning the state's ban requiring gun owners to show \"good or substantial reason\" to . During the 2013 legislative session, he voted against the Firearm Safety Act of 2013, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Jacobs voted against the , which legalized same-sex marriage in Maryland, saying that he believed that \"conventional marriage is opposite sex couples\".\n\nIn 2014, Jacobs said he supported a bill to ban the sale of extreme-strength liquors in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Jacobs voted against a bill to index the state's  to inflation to pay for transportation projects.\n\n\nIn January 2014, Jacobs said he opposed the legalization of  and a bill to raise the minimum wage, which he claimed would threaten businesses on the .\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Jacobs introduced, but later withdrew, legislation that would ban a proposed second Bay Bridge from being built in Kent County.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ashanti Martinez''' (born April 25, 1996) is an American politician. He is currently a member of the  from  in , having been appointed to the seat by Governor  to fill a vacancy left by the appointment of  to the . He previously ran for the House seat in 2018 and 2022.\n\n\nAshanti Martinez was born on April 25, 1996, in  He grew up in a working-class family and was educated at . He first got involved with politics when he was 14 years old as a member of the Prince George's County Young Democrats. In 2016, Martinez worked on the  of state delegate . After graduating from  with a  in political science in 2018, he worked as the director of constituent services for  Tom Dernoga. He then worked as a research and policy analyst for . Martinez also worked as an intern for U.S. Representatives  and , an aide to the Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, and as a campaign manager for  candidate .\n\nIn April 2017, Martinez announced that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 22. He was defeated in the Democratic primary, placing fifth with 10.1 percent of the vote.\n\n rally, 2020]]\nIn August 2021, Martinez announced that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 22, challenging incumbent state delegate . During the primary, he ran on a platform of improving education, transportation, infrastructure, health care, criminal justice reform, and the environment. He also ran on the issue of , highlighting Healey's opposition to . Martinez received endorsements from Pro-Choice Maryland Action and CASA de Maryland. Martinez came in fourth place in the Democratic primary, receiving 13.91 percent of the vote. Following his defeat, he became chief of staff for Prince George's County councilmember Krystal Oriadha.\n\nIn January 2023, Martinez filed to run for the nomination to fill the vacancy left by  in District 22 of the Maryland House of Delegates. He was the only one to apply to the open seat and was nominated by the Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee on February 9.\n\n\nMartinez was into the Maryland House of Delegates on February 24, 2023. He is a member of the House Health and Government Operations Committee. Martinez is the first Latino to represent District 22, and the first  person to represent Prince George's County in the .\n\n\n\nIn May 2022, Martinez signed a  resolution to move Maryland to 100 percent carbon-free electricity by 2035 and to remove  from the state's \"clean energy\" classification.\n\n\nIn June 2021, Martinez attended and spoke at a rally against gun violence in .\n\n\nMartinez supports .\n\n\nIn January 2024, Martinez attended and spoke at a rally at the  to support a resolution calling on  to support a ceasefire in the .\n\n\nIn October 2021, Martinez spoke in support of the .\n\n\nIn May 2022, Martinez attended the Lets Say Gay Parade at the , where he spoke in support of the Trans Health Equity Act, a bill that would require the state's  program to provide coverage for . In May 2023, he and delegate  signed onto a letter condemning the censure of two transgender legislators and in Montana and Oklahoma.\n\nMartinez supports bringing the new  headquarters to Prince George's County.\n\n\nMartinez is openly gay, coming out to his family at age 13. He lives in .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Paul G. Pinsky''' (born March 5, 1950) is an American educator, politician from . A member of the , he is currently the Director of the Maryland Energy Administration. He was previously a member of the , representing  in .\n\n\nPinsky was born in ,  on March 5, 1950, where he attended . He left New Jersey to attend  in , where he earned a B.A. degree in public affairs in 1972. While at GWU, Pinsky attended protests in Washington, D.C. that opposed the  and the  in  and supporting . He and his wife attended a national labor demonstration in the 1980s. After graduating, Pinsky worked as an educator for  from 1976 to 1995 and worked as an organizer for the Maryland State Teachers Association until 2014. From 1983 to 1987, he served as president of the Prince George's County Educators' Association, a labor union that represents over 6,000 professional school employees.\n\nIn 1986, Pinsky was elected to the , defeating incumbent David Bird in the Democratic primary election.\n\nPinsky has been a member of Progressive Maryland since 2001.\n\n\n\nPinsky was a member of the  from 1987 to 2023, first being elected to the .\n\nIn 1994, Pinsky challenged incumbent Democratic senator . During the primary election, O'Reilly resigned from the state senate to take an appointed post on the state Workers' Compensation Commission. Following his resignation, Democratic Party officials and aides of Senate President  sought to appoint someone other than Pinsky to fill his vacancy, worrying that he would be \"too liberal\" and not enough of a team player. Pinsky was appointed to serve the rest of his term. He defeated  city councilmember Charles J. Kenny Jr. in the Democratic primary, receiving 74 percent of the vote.\n\nPinsky has been a member of the  since 1994. Along with state senator , he is the longest serving member of the Maryland Senate.\n\nIn February 2019,  condemned comments made by Pinsky during a debate on a bill that would return control of school calendars to local school boards as an effort to link   to former  . In an interview later, Pinsky said that he had nothing to apologize for, saying \"If the senator conjures something in his head, so be it.\"\n\nFollowing the resignation of Senate President Thomas Miller in October 2019, Pinsky tested the waters of running for Senate president.\n\nIn December 2022, governor-elect  named Pinsky to serve as the director of the Maryland Energy Administration.\n\n\n;Maryland Senate\n* Chair, Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee, 2019–2023 (vice-chair, 2015–2019; member, 1994–2023; health subcommittee, 1994–2002; licensing & regulatory affairs subcommittee, 1999–2002; ethics & election law subcommittee, 2003–2006; special committee on renewables & clean energy, 2007–2010; chair, education subcommittee, 2003–2023, member, 1998–2023; co-chair, environment subcommittee, 2011–2014, 2017–2018, chair, 2007–2010, member, 2015–2023)\n* Chair, Executive Nominations Committee, 2019–2023; Rules Committee, 2019–2023\n* Chair, Legislative Policy Committee, 2019–2023\n* Chair, Joint COVID-19 Response Legislative Work Group, 2020–2023\n* Member, Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 1995–2003\n* Member, Special Committee on Substance Abuse, 2001–2013\n* Member, Senate Special Commission on Medical Malpractice Liability Insurance, 2004\n* Member, Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer, 2007\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2003–2015 (member, 1999–2003)\n\n;House of Delegates\n* Member, Environmental Matters Committee, 1987–1994.\n\n\n* Senate Chair, , 2001–2003\n* Member, Maryland Green Caucus, 1996–2023\n* Maryland Bicycle and Pedestrian Caucus, 2003–2023\n* Maryland Educators Caucus, 2005–2023\n* Member,  (agriculture, environment & energy committee, 2007–2008; agriculture & energy committee, 2008–2023; education committee, 2008–2023; environment committee, 2008–2023)\n* Member, Southern Legislative Conference (energy & environment committee, 2008–2023)\n\n\nPinsky has been described as one of the most liberal members of the Maryland legislature. He has gained a reputation as a champion of progressive causes, especially in relation to education and the environment.\n\n\nIn 1988, Pinsky voted in favor of an amendment to an abortion bill that would have loosened the restrictions on Medicaid-financing of abortions. In 1991, he voted in favor of a bill that would keep abortion legal in Maryland.\n\n\nIn May 2020, Pinsky sharply criticized Governor Hogan for his administration's acquisition of incomplete COVID-19 testing kits from . During the 2021 legislative session, Pinsky supported legislation introduced by senator  that would set new rules for emergency procurements. The bill passed and became law following a gubernatorial veto override on December 6, 2021.\n\n\nPinsky introduced legislation during the 2001 legislative session that would ban advertising in schools and prevent schools from entering into exclusive agreement with snack companies. The bill was killed in the Senate, where legislators voted 26–18 to bar the proposal from coming to the Senate floor.\n\nPinsky introduced legislation during the 2002 legislative session that would dismantle the elected school board of  and replace it with an all-appointed panel that would serve for four years, and replace the position of superintendent and replace it with a chief executive officer.\n\nPinsky introduced legislation during the 2005 legislative session that would implement new limitations on sugary snacks in schools and require that schools attach timers to in-school vending machines that would shut them down automatically.\n\nPinsky introduced legislation during the 2016 legislative session that would give legislators a role in selecting the state superintendent. The bill was withdrawn after its sponsors determined that it did not have enough support in the Maryland Senate to withstand a veto from Governor Hogan.\n\nPinsky introduced legislation in the 2018 legislative session that would provide tuition-free  for families that make less than $150,000 a year. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on May 4, 2018.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Pinsky led a three-year effort of getting the  to pass the  reforms of public schools. In February, Pinsky voted down a bill that would expand the number of schools that can participate in the state's  program, saying that the program needed to be studied more before it could be expanded. He also supported a bill that would overturn Governor Hogan's mandate requiring schools to start after Labor Day. In April, he supported a bill that would provide an additional $700 million in funding for Maryland public schools over two years.\n\nPinsky introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would ensure access to high-quality course and extracurricular offerings to students of virtual schools, requires teachers of a virtual class to be employees of the county, and cap the number of students from a single school to attend the county's virtual school to 10 percent.\n\n\nPinsky previously introduced legislation that would have decreased the number of signatures an  would need to make it on a ballot.\n\nIn 2016, Pinsky proposed turning control over  to a commission made up of legislative appointees provided that Republican states do the same.\n\nPinsky introduced legislation in the 2018 legislative session that would require presidential candidates to release their s to appear on the ballot in Maryland.\n\nPinsky introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would have created a ballot initiative that, if passed, would allowed gubernatorial candidates to select their  following the primary election.\n\nPinsky introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would create a tiered system for using public funds to match qualifying gubernatorial  through the state's Fair Campaign Finance Fund. The bill passed and became law on May 30, 2021.\n\nDuring the 2021 special legislative session, Pinsky dismissed criticisms from Republicans that accused Maryland Democrats of passing congressional maps of using  to draw a map that heavily favors the Democrats, saying that if Republicans opposed gerrymandering, they should support the federal . In August 2021, Pinsky attended a rally outside the  with hundreds of state legislators to pressure the  to pass the For the People Act.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Pinsky introduced legislation that would give candidates the option of receiving public contributions from the state's Fair Campaign Financing Fund if they meet certain low-dollar fundraising thresholds and agree to spending limitations. He also supported legislation that would require vacancies in the Maryland General Assembly to be filled using  instead of gubernatorial appointments.\n\n\nIn 2008, Pinsky introduced the Global Warming Solutions Act, which requires that greenhouse gases be cut by 90 percent from all businesses in the state by 2050. An amendment introduced by senator  and backed by the administration of Governor  weakened the bill's function by making this an advisory goal.\n\nIn 2011, Pinsky was arrested at a civil disobedience protest in front of the  against the construction of an oil pipeline.\n\nIn 2016, Pinsky introduced the Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reduction Act, which requires the state to cut its greenhouse gases by 40 percent of its 2006 levels by 2030. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 13, 2016.\n\nIn 2017, Pinsky attended an activist rally outside of the  to promote legislation that would ban  in Maryland.\n\nIn 2021, Pinsky introduced the Climate Solutions Now Act, which would increase the state's goal of cutting carbon emissions from a 40 percent reduction from its 2006 levels to a 60 percent cut by 2030. He was critical of an amended version of the bill that reduced the reduction goal to 50 percent introduced by leaders of the , arguing that the changes \"reflect a lack of urgency the leadership in the House of Delegates feels about confronting climate change\". After negotiations on Pinsky's bill broke down in the final weeks of the legislative session, Pinsky tried to tack the bill's priorities onto other separate bills. Negotiations on a climate bill continued following the end of the legislative session. Pinsky reintroduced the legislation during the 2022 legislative session, promising alongside delegate  to move quickly on passing the bill to override a gubernatorial veto.\n\nOn its 2021 legislative scorecard, the Maryland  gave Pinsky a score of 100 percent.\n\nPinsky is a skeptic of , saying that living through scares like  and  has made him unsure of its safety.\n\n\nDuring his 1998 state senate campaign, Pinsky ran on providing  to all Marylanders. In 2018, he was the leading sponsor on the Senate version of the Healthy Maryland Act, which would institute ,  legislation in Maryland.\n\nIn 1999, Pinsky voted against a bill that would ban  in Maryland.\n\n\nIn 1987, Pinsky voted against legislation that would return s to eight counties on the  under the pretext that they were only used by nonprofit organizations for charitable purposes. In 2003, Pinsky opposed a bill that would legalize slot machines in Maryland and earmark almost half of the revenue for public education, arguing that the track owners' share of the profit was far too generous. In 2012, Pinsky opposed legislation that allow a new casino in  and add -style table games at Maryland's five other slots venues, saying that he thinks the county should focus its economic development efforts elsewhere.\n\n\nIn 2013, Pinsky voted in favor of a  bill that would require fingerprinting of gun buyers, implement new limits on firearm purchases by the mentally ill, and mandate bans on assault weapons and on magazines that hold more than 10 bullets.\n\n\nPinsky introduced legislation in the 1997 legislative session that would have raised the  from $5.15 to $7.70 over two years. The bill was killed in the Senate Finance Committee, receiving a 8-3 unfavorable vote. In 2014, Pinsky proposed continuing to increase the state's minimum wage beyond $10.10 per hour and increasing the base wage for tipped workers.\n\n\nIn 1996, Pinsky and state senator  nearly derailed a plan by Senate President  to build two new football stadiums in  and  by introducing legislation that would prohibit public funds from going towards the construction of the stadiums.\n\nIn 2012, Pinsky voted in favor of legalizing  in Maryland.\n\nIn 2013, Pinsky voted in favor of repealing the  in Maryland.\n\n\nPinsky introduced legislation in the 1996 legislative session that would have taxed corporate executives' incomes at a rate more than 20 times greater than the tax on the salaries of the companies' lowest- paid employees.\n\nIn 2012, Pinsky defended legislation that would significantly raise taxes on Marylanders earning half a million dollars or more.\n\nIn 2013, Pinsky voted in favor of legislation that raises taxes on gas to replenish the state's transportation fund.\n\n\nPinsky was married to Joan Rothgeb, who died from  on March 12, 2020. He and his wife had two daughters. He lives in .\n\n\n* Legislative Award, , 1994\n* Betty Tyler Award, , 1992\n* Outstanding Contribution to Youth Award, Prince George's County Council of PTAs, on behalf of Prince George's County Educators' Association\n* Outstanding Contribution to the Community Award, Prince George's County Chapter, \n* Citation, Maryland Healthy Air Act Coalition, 2006\n* Certificate of Appreciation, , 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011\n* Climate Champion Award, , 2009\n* Legislator of the Year, Maryland , 2012\n* Consumer Hero, Maryland Consumer Rights Coalition, 2013, 2014\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Brandon Maurice Scott''' (born April 8, 1984) is an American politician serving as the , since 2020. He was the president of the  from 2019 to 2020, having been elected to the position to replace  following 's resignation, as well as a member of the  from the second district from 2011 to 2019. A member of the Democratic Party, Scott was a candidate for  during the , in which he ran on a ticket with Jim Shea.\n\n\nScott was born and raised in . As a child he admired Congressman  and saw him as a role model. He ran  and  at  where he graduated in 2002. He went on to receive a degree in  from  in 2006.\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter graduating from college, Scott worked as a liaison for City Council President . In 2011, he was elected to serve as the city councilperson for the second district, making him one of the youngest ever elected to city office. He was the chair of the Public Safety Committee and a member of the Budget and Appropriations and Judiciary and Legislative Investigations committees. In early 2018, he passed a bill creating an open data policy in Baltimore. As a council member, Scott oversaw the reinstatment of Council Oversight of the Baltimore Police Department. In May 2019, the Baltimore City Council unanimously voted to elevate Scott to serve as the City Council president, serving the remainder of the term of , who ascended to the mayoralty following the resignation of Baltimore mayor .\n\nScott has participated in the 300 Man March, a nonviolence group. While serving as city councilperson, he voted against an aerial surveillance program for the  and supported reductions in police funding, cutting 22 million dollars from the city's policing budget in 2020.\n\nOn February 16, 2018, Baltimore attorney Jim Shea announced the selection of Scott as his running mate in . Scott would later appoint Shea to serve as Baltimore's solicitor under his mayoral administration.\n\n\n\n\n\nScott announced his campaign for  on September 13, 2019, at a press conference in his childhood neighborhood of Park Heights. On June 9, 2020, Scott was declared the winner of the Democratic primary, defeating the incumbent mayor Jack Young. Scott was perceived as more progressive than Young. This all but assured him victory in the November general election. Democrats have a nearly 10-to-1 advantage in registered voters, and for years the Democratic primary has been the real contest. As expected, he won the November 3, 2020, general election in a landslide, with a nearly 3-to-1 margin over his nearest opponent, independent Bob Wallace. For the second election in a row, the Republicans were pushed into third place.\n\n\n\nScott ran for the second term as mayor in 2024, announcing his reelection campaign on November 18, 2023. He was considered vulnerable, as polls found that Baltimore residents were split on his performance as mayor. During his tenure, Scott faced criticism for his handling of important issues in the city, including schools, constituent services, and crime. However, Scott's response to the , as well as his progress in growing the economy and reducing homicides, allowed him to make inroads with voters and boost his approval rating. On May 14, 2024, Scott won the city's Democratic primary for his second term as mayor of Baltimore, once again narrowly beating his rival, . He won re-election after defeating Republican challenger Shannon Wright on November 5, 2024, becoming the first Baltimore mayor since  to win a second term.\n\n\nInaugurated in a small, socially distanced ceremony on December 8, 2020, Scott vowed to take on both \"public health emergencies\"  gun violence and the . Taking the office at age 36, Scott is the youngest mayor in Baltimore's history. He was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\nOn his first day in office, Scott signed an order mandating an end to restaurant dining, both indoor and outdoor, and capping retail activity, religious gatherings, gyms, malls, casinos, and museums to 25 percent capacity. Scott lifted Baltimore's  and state of emergency declaration on July 1, 2021. In August 2021, Scott reinstated the city's mask mandate following a 374 percent increase in COVID-19 infections in July. The mask mandate expired on March 1, 2022.\n\nIn January 2021, Scott and   started a confidence campaign called \"GoVax Maryland\" encouraging citizens to get vaccinated. In February, Scott launched a new partnership with local universities to boost confidence in and combat misinformation about s.\n\nIn March 2021, Scott expressed frustration with the Hogan administration after state health officials denied his request to set aside 50 percent of state's COVID-19 vaccine doses for the state-run mass-vaccination sites in the city. Hogan responded to these criticisms by telling him to \"talk to his health department,\" which he claimed was telling the state health department to send vaccines elsewhere because they had too many. Scott refuted Hogan's charges, calling them \"categorically untrue.\"\n\nIn May 2021, Scott delivered a letter to Hogan asking him to impose a temporary statewide eviction moratorium while local jurisdictions continued to distribute federal rent relief funding to tenants and landlords. In January 2022, Scott declined requests from housing advocates to institute an eviction moratorium in Baltimore, saying that he didn't have the power to do it on his own and that action would need to come at the state level.\n\nScott tested positive for  on October 4, 2021. He returned to  on October 15, 2021, after testing negative.\n\n\n  and Governor , 2022]]\nDuring his mayoral campaign, Scott vowed to \"reduce homicides by 15 percent each year in my term, getting us to below 300 homicides in my first year as mayor\" by studying the flow of guns into Baltimore and implementing violence reduction strategies. He also rallied on reforming police spending after leading the charge to cut $22.4 million from the city's $550 million police budget, half of which was for \"unallocated\" funds. Despite this, Scott's first budget, introduced in April 2021, included a $28 million increase in the city's police budget. This proposed increase was met with criticism by Baltimore residents. Scott pushed back against this criticism by asking people to \"look at the full picture behind violent crime rather than the \"simple conflict\" that leads to the loss of life.\" His budget was approved without amendments on June 8, 2021. In April 2022, Scott again proposed a $5 million increase in the city's police budget, which was met with further criticism.\n\nIn January 2022, Scott implemented the Group Violence Reduction Strategy in the city's Western Police District. This program targets outreach to individuals who are identified as being likely victims or perpetrators of gun violence within the city and stresses community based policing strategies. The four central tenets of the program are the reviewing of gun violence incidents, direct outreach, life coaching, and strategic policing. In December 2022, Scott announced that the district had seen a 33.8% decrease in gun violence. It was also announced that this program would be expanded to other districts in 2023 and 2024.\n\nIn February 2022, Scott was named one of 10 new co-chairs of .\n\nIn May 2022, Scott and the Baltimore Police Department launched the Strategic Management and Alternative Response Tactics (SMART) initiative. The goal of this program is to free up city resources by redirecting non-emergencies and mental health crisis to other services, while limiting false alarm calls. The program then in turn hopes to allow officers more time to engage positively with communities and build trust.\n\nIn June 2022, Scott filed a lawsuit against , alleging the company flooded the city with s which he believes contribute to bloodshed in the city's streets; the lawsuit was settled for $1.2 million in February 2024. In the same month, Scott also signed a bill to implement a Police Accountability Board as mandated by the States' . The bill allows up to two former police officers to serve on the 17-person board that will recommend action against officers with alleged misconduct.\n\n\nIn July 2023, following a  that left two dead and 28 injured, Scott released a statement expressing condolences and called for further crackdowns on illegal guns coming in from other states and criticized people who uploaded videos of the incident to social media for not intervening. He also defended the role of the police and the city's Safe Streets gun violence program against criticism, saying the focus should \"instead be on a few people who cowardly decided to shoot up a big block party celebration for a community\".\n\nIn March 2024, '''' reported that homicides and shootings overall were trending downward city-wide since 2022.\n\n\nIn May 2021, Scott removed owner-occupied homes that faced tax sale s from the city's annual tax sale, an online auction that the city uses to collect overdue bills. In September 2021, he announced that Baltimore would purchase the liens of 454 owner-occupied homes to keep them out of the city's tax sale process. In April 2022, Scott removed all owner-occupied homes from the city's tax sale and postponed the auction until June.\n\nIn May 2021, Scott delivered his first veto of his mayorship on a bill that would give renters more options when paying security deposits.\n\nIn June 2021, Scott launched a fund to cover up to $2,000 in security deposits for low-income tenants, funded with $3.3 million in supplemental funds from a fiscal year 2020 pandemic-related .\n\nOn January 25, 2022, a fire at an unoccupied rowhouse building killed three firefighters and left another on life support. In response to the fire, Scott announced a citywide review of its operations related to vacant properties.\n\nIn February 2022, Scott announced that the city would spend $90.4 million in funding received from the  to purchase two hotels to provide 275 beds for the city's homeless population.\n\nIn December 2023, Scott's administration joined other community leaders in announcing an $8 billion plan to revitalize some parts of the city blighted by abandoned or vacant properties. In March 2023, the administration announced its support for a Baltimore City Council proposal to make some vacant properties available for purchase starting at $1, though critics of the proposal have suggested that such a policy would not directly benefit current residents or legacy residents of Baltimore.\n\n\nIn April 2022, Scott announced a  pilot program to provide 200 young parents between the ages of 18 and 24 with payments of $1,000 per month over two years. The funding for the 4.8 million dollar project comes from the  The pilot program began distributing the funds to lottery winners in August 2022. In order to enter the lottery, applicants needed to be US citizens, below 300% of the federal poverty level, a parent or guardian of a child, and within the age requirements of program when the applications closed.\n\n\n site with Governor , 2024]]\nIn April 2021, Scott announced that he would be working to revive the  project that was killed by . The project plan to build an east–west rail line would have created a rise in economic development while also creating new connections for isolated low-income neighborhoods.\n\nIn June 2021, Scott announced his opposition to a proposal to construct a  connecting Baltimore and , delivering a letter to the  urging them to reject the project.\n\nIn September 2021, Scott criticized the state's proposed transportation budget, which included $500 million in investments for the  in , for not including enough funding for infrastructure projects in Baltimore. In order to help prioritize projects in the city, Scott created The Mayor's Office of Infrastructure Development in June 2022 and appointed Matthew Garbark to head the department.\n\nIn November 2021, Scott joined President  in a visit to the , where he hailed the  as a plan to rebuild America and create \"good-paying, union jobs.\"\n\nIn April 2022, Scott launched the \"Let's Ride to Work\" program, which is a partnership between Mayor's Office of Employment Development and  which is being funded by the . The program would allow newly employed workers up to 40 free rides to and from work.\n\nScott was notified of the  minutes after the collision on March 26, 2024. Talking to reporters in the hours following the incident, Scott emphasized that rescue operations were his top priority. Scott received national media attention during the event, prompting a rise in racist remarks directed towards him on social media.\n\n\n with Governor ]]\nScott became engaged to his girlfriend, Hana Pugh, on December 25, 2023. Their first child was born the following day. They married on August 11, 2024. In September 2024, Scott and his wife announced that they were expecting a second child, a baby girl. Scott lives in .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John F. Wood Jr.''' (January 13, 1936 – June 9, 2023) was an American  politician who represented  from 1987 to 1994 and  from 1995 to 2015 in the .\n\n\nJohn F. Wood Jr. was born on January 13, 1936, in . He attended  and served in the  as a sergeant from 1952 to 1960.\n\n\nWood was the owner and operator of Wood's Food Rite from 1962 to 1993. He worked as a partner for Cross and Wood Insurance Brokers from 1993.\n\n\nWood served as a member of the  for 28 years (1987 to 2015). He served as a . He represented  from 1987 to 1994. He then represented  from 1995 to 2015. In his time he served on the House Appropriations and Legislative Policy Committees and its public safety, administration, and personnel oversight subcommittees.\n\nWood acted as the Chair of the Commerce and Government Matters Committee from 1999 to 2003 and the chair of the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2003-0.\n\n\n*Voted against the  (HB359)\n\n\nWood was married and had nine children.\n\nWood died at his home in , on June 9, 2023, at the age of 87.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
