    "pages": }\n\n'''Adelaide C. Eckardt''' (born September 8, 1943) is an American politician who was a member of the , representing District 37.\n\n\nAdelaide C. Eckardt was first elected in 1994 to represent the new District 37B.  District 37B covers parts of , , , &  counties.\n\nShe defeated Democratic incumbent Robert Alan Thornton Jr. and served with fellow Republican .  She ran in 1990, but was defeated by , Robert Alan Thornton Jr., and Democrat Samuel Q. Johnson III.\n\nIn 1998, Eckardt was reelected along with .  Again in 2002, Eckardt and Schisler won with little competition.  Finally, in 2006, Eckardt won reelection, this time with fellow Republican, .  Schisler was appointed to the chair of the  by Governor  in May 2003.\n\n\nLike fellow House Republican , Eckardt got her career start in nursing. Eckardt attended  School of Nursing and received her R.N. degree.  She later attended the  School of Nursing attaining her B.S. in 1978, and later her M.S. in 1981. She practiced as a Registered Nurse-Psychiatric Clinical Nurse Specialist.\n\n\nA few years later, Eckardt became an adjunct member of the faculty at .  Later that same year, she became a Psychiatric Nurse Clinical Specialist at Eastern Shore Hospital Center and worked there until 2003. During that same time, she also served as an adjunct member of the faculty at the .  She remained on the faculty from 1991 to 1999.\n\nEckardt's remained active in her field, but shifted to a more administrative and legislative role.  She joined the Executive Committee of the Maryland Hospital Association in 1993 and has served on the Board of Directors for Leadership Maryland, Inc., a non-profit organization committed to the betterment of Maryland, since 2001.\n\nCurrently, Eckardt is a board member of the Chesapeake Health Planning Systems, a member of the  Maryland Nurses Association, the American Nurses Association, the American Ortho-Psychiatric Association, and , the honor society of nursing.\n\nShe is a past recipient of the Psychiatric Nursing Award from the University of Maryland Graduate School of Nursing in 1981. In 1986 and again in 1991, Eckard was named Nurse of the Year, District 4, by the Maryland Nurses Association. In 1988, she won the Rosalie S. Abrams Legislative Award from the Maryland Nurses Association. She received the Outstanding Board Member Award from the Maryland Nurses Association in 1992. Later she received the Outstanding Rural Legislator Award from the Rural Maryland Council in 2003. Additionally in 2003, she received recognition for her efforts from Local Management Board. Finally, she was listed as a member of Maryland's Top 100 Women by the ''Daily Record'', a local newspaper, in 2003, 2005, and 2007.\n\nIn July 2022, Eckardt was defeated in the  by state delegate . Following her defeat, she announced on July 25, 2022, that she would run in the  mayoral special election on August 23, 2022. No candidate received the majority of the vote, forcing a runoff between Eckardt and former Cambridge commissioner Steve Rideout on September 20, 2022. She was defeated by Rideout 55%-45%. In November 2022, Governor-elect  announced that Eckardt would serve on the steering committee of his transition team.\n\n\n* voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006(SB154)\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted for  in 1999 (HB703)\n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted against police transparency in 2021 (HB1090)\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 37B'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 37B'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 37B'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 37B'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 37'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Cheryl E. Pasteur''' (born 1948/1949) is an American politician. She is a member of the  for  in . She previously served on the  from 2018 to 2022.\n\n\nPasteur graduated from the  with a  degree in English education in 1971. She later attended , where she earned a  in urban education in 1975.\n\nPasteur is a former teacher at  and  as well as a former principal for Old Court Middle School and . From 1983 to 1988, she worked for the . Pasteur retired from teaching in 2012.\n\n\nIn November 2018, Pasteur was elected to the Baltimore County School Board in Councilmanic District 2, receiving 66.1 percent of the vote in the general election. In December 2019, Pasteur challenged incumbent board chair Kathleen Causey in the election for chair of the Baltimore County School Board. Pasteur received six votes for the chair position, while Causey received five. Despite this, Causey continued to serve as the board's chair, as board policy requires a candidate to receive seven votes to become chair. In December 2021, the school board selected Pasteur to serve as its vice chair.\n\nIn June 2019,   and   named Pasteur to serve on the  Funding Formula Workgroup. In January 2020, the Baltimore County School Board voted to endorse the recommendations of the .\n\nIn February 2022, Pasteur filed a declaration supporting a lawsuit challenging Baltimore County's new council districts for diluting the power of Black voters.\n\nPasteur resigned from the school board on February 11, 2022, to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 11A. In June 2022, Governor  appointed retired middle school teacher Felicia Stolusky to serve the rest of her term. Pasteur was the only candidate to run for the district.\n\n\nPasteur was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. She is a member of the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\nIn 2012, the  opened an investigation into Randallstown High School, where Pasteur was a principal at the time of the investigation, after two anonymous sources reported cheating on state testing. A confidential report obtained by Project Baltimore in May 2020 found \"improbable gains\" on the state assessments of sixteen students at the school, resulting in two school employees being banned from future state assessments. Pasteur says in the report that she was \"unaware of any testing improprieties\", but two witnesses told state investigators that she was aware of the cheating. Pasteur announced her retirement weeks after Randallstown High School was reported for allegedly cheating on state testing, and she officially left the school weeks before the results of the investigation were released. Pasteur responded to the Project Baltimore report in a radio interview in June 2020, confirming some of the reported details but denying that she was connected to the alleged cheating or that she retired to \"slip out\" of the investigation.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''David R. Brinkley''' (born September 24, 1959) is an American politician who served as the Secretary of Budget and Management for the  state of  from 2015 to 2023.\n\n\nDavid Brinkley was born in ,  the only son of Dr. George Ross Brinkley and Jean Brinkley. He was raised in  and graduated from  in 1977.\n\nHe attended  and received a Bachelor of Science degree at the  in 1981.\n\nHe entered the life insurance business with Acacia Mutual Life Insurance Company, and earned his professional designations – Chartered Life Underwriter (CLU) & Chartered Financial Consultant (ChFC) – from  in  in October, 1984.\n\nDuring the early-1980s, David was an / with the New Market District Volunteer Fire Company, and a volunteer EMT driver as  initiated its  program.\n\n\nIn 1994,  Brinkley was elected to the , serving two terms representing District 4A. He was elected to the House of Delegates along with  defeating Thomas H. Hattery and Thomas Gordon Slater.  Incumbent George Littrell ran for the State Senate seat left open by .  Littrell was defeated by .\n\nAs a member of the House of Delegates, he was Deputy  from 1997 to 1998. In 1998, Stull and Brinkley easily won re-election defeating Democratic challenger Valerie M. Hertges.\n\n\nIn 2002, Brinkley was elected to the , representing District 4, which covers  and .  He defeated Republican incumbent  in the primary election.  He went on to overwhelmingly defeat Timothy Schlauch in the general election.\n\nIn 2006, he defeated Republican challenger Paul Chamberlain in the .  He ran unopposed to any  in the general election and convincingly defeated the s.\n\n\nHe was the Senate  from 2007 to 2008.\n\nIn 2010, he was selected as Minority Whip alongside Senator  who was selected as Minority Leader. When Kittleman resigned in 2011, Brinkley again ran for , but was rejected in favor of the conservative Senator . \nBrinkley immediately resigned his position as Minority Whip upon losing the election to the more conservative Jacobs.\nBrinkley returned to the position of minority leader in 2013 following a five-year hiatus.\n\n\n* Finance Committee, 2013-2014\n* Budget and Taxation Committee, 2003-2013\n** Education, business & administration subcommittee (2003–06, 2011-)\n** Health & Human Services subcommittee, (2007)\n** Pensions subcommittee (2007, 2011-)\n** Health, education & human resources subcommittee (2008–10)\n* Joint Audit Committee (2004-)\n* Rules Committee (2007-)\n* Executive Nominations Committee (2007-)\n* Legislative Policy Committee (2007-)\n* Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review (2007-)\n* Spending Affordability Committee (2008-)\n* Special Joint Committee on Pensions (2011-)\n* Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families (2003–08)\n* Spending Affordability Committee (2007–08)\n* Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics (2007–10)\n* Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer (2007)\n\n\n\n* Agricultural Stewardship Commission (2005–06 )\n* Senate Special Commission on Electric Utility Deregulation Implementation (2005–06)\n* Maryland Rural Caucus (2003-)\n* Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus (2003-)\n* Maryland Veterans Caucus (2004-)\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, 85-year-old Republican incumbent U.S. Congressman  was placed into a district that Obama won. Portions of Baltimore and Harford counties as well as Carroll County were taken away from the 6th District during redistricting. More of Montgomery County was put into the district, while another part of Montgomery County was removed and added to northern Frederick County to reform the 8th District. His current district has Obama at just 40%, while the newly redrawn district has Obama at 56%.\n\nIn November, his Chief of Staff, Bud Otis, was reportedly soliciting the support of  to run for his seat should he decide to retire. On November 30, 2011 '''' reported that Brinkley will run for  and, “if necessary,” will primary Bartlett, according to his friend and supporter, state Delegate .\nIn the Republican primary election in 2012, Brinkley won nearly 20% of the vote, falling short of Bartlett's 43.6%. Retrieved on May 21, 2015 Bartlett went on to lose the general election to Democrat .\n\n\nBrinkley faced another Republican challenge from Delegate , who aligned himself with the more conservative Tea Party faction Hough accused Brinkley of being a \"tax-and-spend liberal\" and of cooperating too much with the Democratic majority and then-Governor . Hough crushed Brinkley in the primary election, 68%-32%.\n\nNewly elected governor  appointed Brinkley to the position of Secretary of Budget and Management in January 2015.\n\n\n* '''2014 Republican Primary Race for Maryland State Senate&nbsp;– District 4''' Retrieved on May 21, 2015\n:\n* '''2010 Race for Maryland State Senate&nbsp;– District 4''' Retrieved on May 21, 2015\n:\n* '''2006 Race for Maryland State Senate&nbsp;– District 4''' Retrieved on Oct. 4, 2007\n:\n* '''2002 Race for Maryland State Senate&nbsp;– District 4''' Retrieved on Oct. 4, 2007\n:\n* '''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– District 4A''' Retrieved on Sept, 07 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n* '''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– District 4A''' Retrieved on Sept, 07 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* https://web.archive.org/web/20070204032251/http://www.dbrinkley.com/home.html\n* http://www.marylandlegalhistory.com/msa/mdmanual/05sen/html/msa12193.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Hattie N. Harrison''' (February 11, 1928 &ndash; January 28, 2013) was an  who served in the  from 1973. Harrison was the chairperson of the  Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, and was the first African-American woman to chair a legislative committee in Maryland.\n\n\nBorn in Lancaster, South Carolina, Harrison attended the Charlotte, North Carolina and Baltimore City public schools. She is a graduate of the Antioch College after which she became a teacher. She was a member of the Democratic State Central Committee, Baltimore City from 1970 to 1974, and a member of the Eastside Democratic Organization. In 2005, she received the Casper R. Taylor, Jr. Founder's Award from the Speaker's Society of the Maryland House of Delegates. Harrison died on January 28, 2013. At the time of her death, she was the longest serving delegate to the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\n\n]]\nAt the time of her death, she had been a member of the Economic Matters Committee since 1973 and served on its science & technology subcommittee. She was a member of the  (formerly Maryland Legislative Black Caucus) and the Women's Legislators of Maryland.\n\n\n* voted for  in 1999 (HB703)\n* voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted in favor the Tax Reform Act of 2007 (HB2)\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 45th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Benjamin F. Kramer''' (born March 5, 1957) is an  who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2019. A member of the , Kramer previously represented the district in the  from 2007 to 2019.\n\n\nKramer was born in  on March 5, 1957. He was one of three children born to father , who would later serve as a state senator and , and mother Betty Mae. Kramer's sister, , would later serve as a state senator and as  from 2015 to 2023. He attended , graduating from , and later attended the , where he received a  degree in law enforcement in 1979.\n\nKramer owns the Wheaton Speedy Car Wash and a real estate business. He was a member of the Montgomery County Liquor Control Task Force and the Montgomery County Police Department Citizens Advisory Board.\n\nIn 1994, Kramer unsuccessfully ran for the Montgomery County Council, losing to incumbent  county councilwoman Nancy Dacek in the general election. He ran for an at-large seat on the county council in 1998, during which he was defeated in the Democratic primary, placing seventh in the eight-way primary.\n\n\n\nIn 2006, Kramer ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 19. He won the Democratic primary on September 12, placing third with 14 percent of the vote and edging out his opponent, Paul Griffin, by a margin of 307 votes. He was sworn in on January 10, 2007. Kramer was a member of the Judiciary Committee from 2007 to 2010, afterwards serving in the Economic Matters Committee for the remainder of his tenure.\n\nIn 2009, Kramer unsuccessfully ran in the Montgomery County Council District 4 special election, in which he was defeated by .\n\nIn August 2017, a day after state Senator  announced that he would  in  in 2018, Kramer announced that he would seek to succeed Manno in the Maryland Senate. He ran unopposed in both the primary and defeated  nominee David Jeang general election, and was sworn in on January 9, 2019. Kramer has served as a member of the Finance Committee during his entire tenure.\n\n\nKramer is married to his wife, Tammy. Together, they have three children. He is . Kramer's nephews, Brandon and Lance, were the director and producer for the 2021 documentary ''''.\n\n\nKramer is a  who has been described by '''' as \"more pro-business than most of his Democratic colleagues\".\n\n\nKramer supports providing s with state funding.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Kramer introduced a bill to expand  instruction in schools. After the bill died in committee, he penned a letter to the  asking the agency to elaborate its requirements for Holocaust education, led to the agency requiring lessons on the Holocaust in fourth- and fifth-grade social studies classes. The bill was reintroduced in 2023 along with another bill that would set aside $500,000 annually to fund school field trips to museums dedicated to teaching about the Holocaust or African American history.\n\nIn 2021, Kramer introduced legislation that would require the chancellor of the  to act on the behalf of all the system's institutions in all aspects of , and supported another bill to extend collective bargaining rights to Maryland community college employees. Both bills passed and became law.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Kramer expressed concerns with the costs of a bill to incentivize  development in Maryland. He voted for the bill when was reintroduced in 2012.\n\nIn 2018, Kramer introduced legislation that would place  on  for upstream pollution in the  by limiting Maryland's ability to enter into procurement contracts with companies that have not been meeting  Chesapeake Bay cleanup goals.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Kramer introduced legislation to levy a  on corporate polluters, which would charge $15 per metric ton of  emitted from non-transportation fossil fuel combustion. He reintroduced the bill in 2021, during which it was defeated in committee.\n\nIn 2021, Kramer introduced a bill that would require the  to consider  while reviewing applications for new generating facilities. In 2022, he introduced legislation that would require counties develop  plans. The bill was reintroduced in 2023.\n\n\nKramer is a self-described  who has described the  (BDS) movement as antisemitic.\n\nIn December 2013, following the , Kramer wrote to Governor  asking him to prevent state funding from going toward organizations that supported the boycott. During the 2014 legislative session, he unsuccessfully sought to place financial penalties on the  for supporting the , despite UMBC saying that it would end its affiliation with the ASA. The legislature instead opted to pass a resolution condemning the BDS movement, making Maryland the first state to do so, which Kramer said was \"not the victory we should have had\". Kramer's anti-BDS bill was also condemned by Archbishop , who issued a statement expressing \"grave concern\" over the effort and with Kramer's comparison between BDS and . During the 2017 legislative session, Kramer introduced a bill that would prohibit the state from contracting with companies that support the BDS movement. After the bill failed to pass, Governor  signed an executive order codifying it into law.\n\nIn July 2019, Kramer wrote a letter to the  city council and mayor Kate Stewart condemning the city's screening of '''', a documentary which he described as antisemitic.\n\nIn November 2023, Kramer led a letter signed by eight other state senators that threatened to defund immigrants rights group  because it had called for an immediate ceasefire in the  and condemned the \"utilization of US tax dollars to promote the ongoing violence\". He called CASA's subsequent apology a \"good first step\" but added that \"there's still work to be done\".\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session and in response to 's \"Reform on Tap\" efforts, Kramer introduced legislation creating a task force to study which agency is best suited to regulate the alcohol industry in Maryland. As a member of the task force, Kramer criticized Franchot for not including any advocates for public health or public safety in his task force to craft the Reform on Tap proposals, which the committee voted 17–4 to reject later that year and recommended removing the 's ability to regulate the alcohol industry. During the 2019 legislative session, Kramer introduced legislation to do so, which passed and became law.\n\nIn February 2019, Franchot accused Kramer of being \"corrupt\" and having a conflict of interest by introducing the bill, noting that his family's real estate business rents space to a county-owned retail alcohol outlet. Kramer rejected these accusations and subsequently accused Franchot of taking  from the alcohol industry that influenced his \"Reform on Tap\" proposals, which Franchot denied. While testifying on the bill later that month, Kramer compared Franchot to  in claiming that he had \"extorted\" campaign contributions from liquor lobbyists, which Len Foxwell, Franchot's chief of staff, called \"beyond offensive\" and \"slanderous\", and led Franchot to file an ethics complaint against Kramer. Kramer criticized Governor  for appointing Foxwell to the alcohol commission, which he called a \"political favor\".\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session and following the death of Noah Leotta, a Montgomery County police officer who was killed by a drunk driver while on DUI patrol, Kramer introduced a bill to expand the use of s, which passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Kramer introduced a bill that would prohibit retail pet stores from selling puppies and kittens, which passed and was signed into law by Governor Larry  Hogan. In May 2022, he participated in and spoke at a protest against Inotiv, a drug research firm headquartered in Montgomery County, after the  released a video accusing the firm of mistreating and killing thousands of animals in its studies.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Kramer introduced a bill creating a program that would have the  perform daily check-in calls to seniors and notify guardians if they do not answer the call. The bill passed and became law, and was implemented in January 2020. In 2022, he opposed a bill that would set restrictions on who the  could appoint as Maryland Secretary of Aging, which he called a \"slippery slope\".\n\nIn July 2020, after Governor  announced plans to hold a full in-person election for , Kramer participated in and spoke at a  rally protesting Hogan's decision, where he accused the governor of prioritizing his autobiography over Maryland's right to vote. During the 2021 legislative session, he introduced a bill that would allow voters to opt into a list that allows them to receive mail-in ballots for every future election, which passed and became law.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Kramer introduced legislation that would allow victims of hate crimes to sue their perpetrators to recoup emotional and financial damages.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Kramer opposed a bill that would raise taxes on  hotels by one percent, expressing concerns that the bill would increase tourism to beaches in Delaware or New Jersey.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Gabriel Acevero''' (born October 23, 1990) is a Trinidadian–American organizer, activist and politician representing  39th House district. On November 6, 2018, Acevero finished in first place with 31% of the vote and became the first openly gay , and one of the youngest people, elected to the . Acevero is a member of the .\n\n\n\nAcevero was born on October 23, 1990, in ; the youngest of six children to Ingrid Acevero (née Ingrid Renn) - a government employee and labor activist, and Michael Acevero - an insurance advisor and field underwriting manager. His paternal family is  and his mother is . Acevero was raised in the town of  and attended Richmond Street Boys Anglican School in the capital, . He graduated from Couva Government Secondary School in 2007, where he excelled on the school's debate team. Later that year, his family immigrated to the United States, settling in Maryland. Acevero started college at 16, earning his associate degree in international relations from  and a bachelor's degree in political science from the  (UMBC) in 2011 at the age of 20. He was a student activist in college, volunteered for political campaigns, and was active in the .\n\nAfter college, Acevero worked as an issue organizer. He was involved in the successful  () and  (Marriage Equality) campaigns in 2012, which resulted in Maryland becoming the first state to approve both measures at the ballot box. Then, in 2014, he worked on transgender equality. In 2015, he was recognized by the  as one of its \"100 Black LGBTQ Emerging Leaders to Watch\" for his advocacy and efforts to reform Maryland's justice system.\n\nA  activist, Acevero helped organize and participated in protests during the  Acevero joined the coalition of activists and organizations that pushed for the repeal of Maryland's  (LEOBR) following Freddie Gray's death. Before running for office, he was involved in  efforts in Maryland.\n\nAcevero joined the Maryland  campaign and organized low-wage workers and community groups to support raising the minimum wage in Montgomery County. The County Council overwhelmingly approved the bill, which was signed into law in 2017.\n\nIn December 2017, Acevero was one of a group of activists, labor leaders, clergy, and lawmakers arrested on the steps of Capitol Hill for engaging in an unlawful demonstration. The group was hoping to pressure Congress to include legislation for undocumented immigrants who came to the US as children (known as ).\n\nHe was also behind the push that led to renaming a , elementary school in honor of gay civil rights leader . In his testimony before the , Acevero criticized the 's decision to remove LGBTQ people off the  and the : \"We have a hostile administration that is intent on erasing LGBTQ folks, recently taking us off the Census and banning transgender Americans from serving their country. Now more than ever we need to affirm LGBTQ youth, and that's why Bayard Rustin is such a powerful name for this school\". The Montgomery County Board of Education voted to approve changing the school's name to Bayard Rustin Elementary.\n\n\nAcevero ran in the three-member house district, which includes parts of , , , , and . He won the Democratic primary on June 26, 2018, defeating three-term incumbent Delegate  and two-term incumbent Delegate  in the hotly contested primary. He faced minimal Republican opposition in the general and was elected on November 6, 2018, at the age of 28. Acevero was sworn in on a copy of 's 1963 book, '''', and assumed office on January 9, 2019. He serves on the House Appropriations Committee and is a member of the Maryland Legislative Black Caucus, the Latino Legislative Caucus, and the Montgomery County Delegation.\n\nIn December 2019, Acevero attended a rally in , to support the .\n\nIn 2020, Delegate Acevero endorsed  for the . During the , he urged voters to cast an \"Uncommitted\" protest vote against President  for his handling of the .\n\nIn the 2022 Democratic primary, other members of the House district campaigned for another Democrat to replace Acevero. Nonetheless, Acevero won reelection to the ticket.\n\n\nAcevero is openly gay.\n\n\n\nIn 2022, Acevero voted in support of  and voted in favor of HB 1, \"Constitutional Amendment – Cannabis – Adult Use and Possession.\" He was one of two Democrats to vote against House Bill 837, which is another Cannabis Reform bill. The bill aimed to study the racial impacts of cannabis legalization, create a public health fund, alter civil and criminal penalties, and create a process of  for possession of the drug. Acevero stated that, despite supporting cannabis legalization, he believed that certain aspects of the legalization need to be addressed before the state can move forward. He said the bill \"does not create true racial equity related to minority ownerships of licensed growing, processing and dispensing businesses.\"\n\nDelegate Acevero introduced his own bill HB1342, \"Cannabis - Legalization and Regulation (Cannabis Legalization and Equity Act)\", in 2022 which would legalize \"the possession and use of a certain amount of cannabis by a person of at least a certain age; providing for expungement of records, dismissal of charges, and commutation of sentences in certain cases involving cannabis-related charges; providing for a system of regulation of the sale of cannabis by the Maryland Department of Health and local jurisdictions; and providing for the taxation of the sale of cannabis in the State.\"\n\n\nAlthough he serves on the Appropriations Committee, Acevero has primarily introduced criminal justice legislation to include . He has sponsored legislation to restrict police officers' use of force and to repeal Maryland's Law Enforcement Officer's Bill of Rights.\n\nDuring his first session as a delegate, Acevero introduced \"Anton's Law,\" a bill that reformed the  to require transparency in investigations of complaints against law enforcement officers. The bill was named for Anton Black, a 19-year-old African-American man who died in police custody in . In July 2020, Acevero accused local union leaders of using \"strong-arm tactics\" to slow down Anton's Law. Gino Renne, president of Montgomery County Government Employees Organization Local 1994 (MCGEO), had expressed concern over Acevero's support of the legislation. Rene asked him to attend a meeting, where Acevero claims Renne and others pressured him to drop Anton's Law. Renne fiercely denied Acevero's accusations, calling them a \"bold-face lie.\" During the 2021 legislative session, the Maryland General Assembly passed Anton's Law as part of the . The law took effect on October 1, 2021.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Acevero introduced legislation to prohibit school districts from contracting with local law enforcement agencies to station  in public schools.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Acevero expressed support for the . He noted that \"What we're trying to do here is change the trajectory of this state ... All of us will win when we invest in education\". He also sponsored HB0489, a bill that establishes the Commission on History, Culture, and Civics in Education. The commission would aim to recommend ways to enhance the teaching of US and Maryland history, culture, and civics to the State Board of Education and the State Department of Education, and it would report findings and recommendations annually by December 30.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Acevero and state senator  introduced legislation to establish a universal  system in Maryland.\n\n\nIn 2021, Acevero spoke in support of the Dignity Not Detention Act that would prevent counties from contracting with  (ICE). Delegate Acevero described the tactics of ICE as being similar to the  during .\n\n\n during the ]]\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Acevero introduced a resolution calling on  to support a ceasefire in the .\n\n\nIn 2019, Acevero was the lone dissenting vote in the Maryland General Assembly on a motion to allow Republican legislators to introduce a bill to change the boundaries of Maryland's  and  congressional districts due to a  ruling. Due to the timing of this legislation and because it did not adhere to the Court's recommendation of using a nonpartisan redistricting commission to draw the new borders, Acevero could not support the bill in its introduced form.\n\nIn 2021, Acevero was the only Democrat in the entire  to vote against House Bill 1, the legislature's congressional redistricting plan, citing concerns of the heavy use of  and splitting up of communities. He also voted present on amendments to replace the map created by the Legislative Redistricting Advisory Commission with one drawn by the Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission. He called on legislators from both parties to support the , due to its creation of state-level commissions for drawing Congressional Lines. In 2022, the Maryland Congressional Map was ruled unconstitutional, marking the first time a Democratic-drawn map has been struck down by a court during this redistricting cycle. The Maryland judge called it a \"product of extreme partisan gerrymandering.\"\n\n\nIn 2019, Acevero helped write a bill regarding diaper-changing stations in men's restrooms and worked on school funding issues.\n\nIn 2020, Acevero co-sponsored legislation to look into the possibility of distributing  in Maryland.\n\nIn May 2023, Acevero and delegate  signed onto a letter condemning the censure of two transgender legislators and in Montana and Oklahoma.\n\n\nAcevero supports , introducing legislation during the 2019 legislative session to direct 25% of the income generated from medical and recreational cannabis taxation is redirected into an investment account and the returns are then proportionally given to the citizens of Maryland. House Bill 1089 was referred to the House Appropriations Committee but did not move out of committee. Acevero called the idea as a \"form of social security, and it is one of the most transformative policies that we can enact at the state and federal level to put a dent in extreme poverty,\" and pointed to  to combat income inequality.\n\n\nThe  named Acevero one of its \"100 Black LGBTQ Emerging Leaders to Watch\" in 2015.\n\n'''' magazine named Acevero one of its \"50 Champions of Pride\" in its June 2018 issue.\n\n'''' named Acevero one of its \"Black LGBTQ Power 100 in 2018,\" and '''' named him one of its 10 favorite LGBTQ candidates of 2018.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  (archived)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Christopher T. Adams''' (born June 19, 1972) is an American politician who has served as a Republican member of the , representing , since 2015.\n\n\nAdams was born on June 19, 1972, in , where he attended  in 1990. He graduated from  with a  in business management in 1994 and a  in 1996. A fifth generation  native, he is married and has three children.\n\nAdams worked as a salesman from 1992 to 1995 and sales manager from 1995 to 2001 at Value Carpet One. He has served as president of Value Carpet One since 2001.\n\nIn October 2013, Adams declared his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates. He prevailed in the Republican primary alongside , earning 24.5 percent of the vote. He won the general election with 30.3 percent of the vote.\n\n\nAdams has served as a member of the  since January 14, 2015, representing . He served as the House  from April through December 2021.\n\nIn 2018,  listed Adams as one of the ten most vulnerable House incumbents in the June 2018 General Assembly primaries. Adams would survive his primary with 29.9 percent of the vote and would be re-elected with 33.9 percent of the vote in the general election.\n\n\n* Economics Matters Committee, 2015–present (business regulation subcommittee, 2015–present; property & casualty insurance subcommittee, 2015–2018; unemployment insurance subcommittee, 2015–2018; banking, consumer protection & commercial law subcommittee, 2019–present)\n* Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2021\n* Legislative Policy Committee, 2021\n\n\n* Deputy Minority Whip, 2021\n* Minority Whip, 2021\n* House Chair, Dorchester County Delegation, 2015–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2015–present \n* Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2015–present (house executive board, 2016–present)\n\n\nAdams is a self-described  who believes that the  should be the basis for which lawmakers operate.\n\n\nIn 2019, Adams voted to sustain Governor 's veto on legislation that would increase the state's minimum wage to .\n\nAdams opposed legislation introduced in the 2021 legislative session that would require government-funded construction projects to pay s on contracts over $250,000 or when at least 25% of a project's construction costs are from state funds, arguing that the bill would hurt small, minority- and women-owned contractors the most and raise costs for smaller governments. The Maryland General Assembly voted along party lines to override Governor Hogan's veto on the bill in April 2021.\n\nFollowing the , Adams defended Governor Hogan's decision to cut , saying that the most direct way to get money to people \"is to put them back on the payroll working\".\n\n\nDuring his 2014 campaign, Adams said that he supports initiatives aimed at restoring , eliminating raw sewage discharge, cleaning Maryland's , dredging the , and improving  in  and , as a means of improving the water quality of the .\n\nAdams introduced legislation during the 2018 legislative session that would have prohibited the construction of a  30 miles off the coast of . The bill received an unfavorable committee report.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Adams was one of ten delegates who voted against the Clean Energy Jobs Act, a bill that would require electric utilities use 50 percent renewable energy by 2030. Adams was one of six Republican delegates to receive a score of 0 percent on the annual Maryland  scorecard.\n\nAdams proposed an amendment to a water contamination bill introduced during the 2021 legislative session that would have blocked the bill from taking effect without greater guidance from state and federal environmental regulators. The amendment failed to pass in a vote on 42-89.\n\n\nAdams proposed an amendment to prescription drug pricing legislation passed during the 2019 legislative session that would have set up a pharmacy benefits manager for the state. The amendment failed to pass in a vote on 39-95.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Adams voted against legislation that would provide free menstrual products in school bathrooms.\n\n\nAdams introduced legislation during the 2016 legislative session that would allow counties to reverse a state rule requiring fire sprinklers to be installed on new and renovated single-family homes.\n\nAdams opposed tenant relief legislation passed during the 2021 legislative session that increased filing fees for cases other than summary ejectments in the state's district courts from $18 to $28,saying that the fee increase was a \"slap in the face\" for Maryland landlords alongside other tenant relief proposals.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 special legislative session, Adams supported the congressional redistricting maps proposed by the Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission appointed by Governor Hogan. In December 2021, Adams joined delegate  and Fair Maps Maryland in filing a lawsuit against Maryland's new congressional maps, alleging they violated the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Chanel Branch''' (born February 6, 1980) is an  who represented the  in the  from 2020 to 2023. Governor  appointed Branch to replace  after Glenn resigned and pleaded guilty to federal corruption charges.\n\n\nBranch was born on February 6, 1980, in , where she graduated from . She attended  and the .\n\nIn July 2017, Branch's son was murdered in Baltimore City. She lobbied, alongside her father, Delegate , for stricter sentences for handgun violations  and for $3.6 million to expand Safe Streets, an anti-violence initiative. Since 2019, she has been a member of Safe Streets and Mothers of Murdered Sons & Daughters.\n\nIn the summer of 2019, Branch filed to fill a vacancy in the  that was left by the appointment of  to serve as the council's president. In October 2019, Branch announced her candidacy for the , seeking to challenge councilmember Danielle McCray, who won the nomination over Branch. Branch dropped out of the race for the  on February 4, 2020.\n\nIn January 2020, after the resignation of Delegate Cheryl Glenn following federal corruption charges, Branch applied to fill the seat vacated by Glenn in the Maryland House of Delegates. The Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee voted to recommend Branch to the seat, with three members, including herself, voting for Branch and the other four members split among three other candidates. During the committee vote, party officials prevented reporters from entering the meeting room, saying that media was not allowed at the request of Humanim, the non-profit that owned the building. Reporters were later allowed to attend the second half of the meeting. Following this incident, 45th District residents delivered a letter to Baltimore Democratic leaders, alleging that the process of filling a House of Delegates vacancy violated party bylaws and the Maryland Open Meetings Act. The letter called for Governor Hogan and the Baltimore City Democratic State Central Committee to reject the nomination and do the vote over. Governor Hogan appointed Branch to the Maryland House of Delegates on January 28, 2020.\n\n\nBranch was sworn in as a member of the Maryland House of Delegates on January 28, 2020.  She was assigned to the House Ways and Means committee and is member of the  and the Women Legislators of Maryland.\n\nBranch filed to run for a full term in the 2022 elections. She lost the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, finishing fourth behind , who had bested her by 116 votes.\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\nBranch introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would establish specialized  in Baltimore to expedite some firearm cases and, when appropriate, offer resources and support services instead of incarceration.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Douglas J. J. Peters''' (December 28, 1963 – December 30, 2023) was an American politician from  and a member of the . He served in the  representing the 23rd district in  from January 10, 2007 to July 31, 2021. In June 2021, Peters announced he wouldn't seek re-election in 2022; in July 2021, he was appointed to the unpaid 's Board of Regents and announced he would resign from the senate.\n\n\nPeters grew up in Silver Spring, MD and graduated from Springbrook High School where he was a member of the two-time Maryland AA State Championship Football teams in 1979 and 1980.  Peters earned a  in finance from the  and a  from the . He became President and Chief Executive Officer of The Peters Group, and through his business became involved with the Prince George's County Chamber of Commerce, Prince George's County Board of Trade and the Greater Washington Board of Trade. Peters was also a Captain in the , and earned a  during . In 1998, Peters successfully ran for a seat on the city council of , and four years later won a seat on the Prince George's county council.\n\n\nPeters was elected to the State Senate in 2006 and took office in 2007. He sat on the Budget and Tax Committee and co-chaired the Veteran's Caucus.\n\nOther committees and subcommittees:\n\n* Capital Budget Subcommittee (Member 2008–2021, Vice-Chair 2011–2021)\n* Education, Business and Administration Subcommittee (2007)\n* Health, Education and Human Resources Subcommittee (2008–10)\n* Health and Human Services Subcommittee (2011–2021)\n*  (2007–2021)\n*  (2008–2021)\n*  (2011–2021)\n*  (Member 2009–2021; Chair 2011–2021)\n* Prince George's County Delegation (Vice-Chair 2008–09; Chair 2009–2021)\n* Maryland Doctor's Caucus (Member 2010–2021)\n* Southern Legislative Conference (fiscal affairs & government operations committee (Member 2008–2021)\n\n\nPeters was married and had six children. Davis''' (born October 11, 1959) is an  who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2019. A member of the , she previously served as a member of the  from 2010 to 2018.\n\n\nDavis was born in , on October 11, 1959. She graduated from  and later attended  with a  degree in criminology, and the , where she earned a  degree. Davis was admitted to the  in 1995 and to the  in 1996.\n\nIn 2010, Davis was elected to the Charles County Board of Commissioners, representing the Charles County District 2. During her two terms as commissioner, she gained the reputation as a maverick, often voting against the majority on issues large and small. During her second term, she also served as the Chair of the Board of Trustees for the Local Government Insurance Trust, becoming the first African-American to serve as LGIT Chair.\n\nIn January 2018, Davis announced that she would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 28. The district was targeted by the  in the general election, in which Davis placed third with 23.8 percent of the vote, behind incumbents  and .\n\n\nDavis was sworn in on January 9, 2019. She was a member of the Judiciary Committee from 2019 to 2022, and has since served as a member of the Environment and Transportation Committee. She is also the House Chair of the Charles County Delegation and is a member of the  and the Women Legislators of Maryland.\n\n\n\nDavis supports the removal of s (SROs) from public schools, noting that SRO programs in Charles County disproportionally affected Black and brown students, and reforms to make policing more equitable and humane.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Davis expressed concerns with a bill that would require judges' names to be included in all online records, worrying that the bill would have a \"chilling effect\" on judges' independence.\n\nIn 2020, Davis introduced legislation that would require prosecutors to submit additional information about s before they could testify in a court case to identify whether they have a conflict of interest in the case. She also supported efforts to repeal the .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Davis introduced legislation that would establish a statewide  policy. The bill died in committee without a vote. She also supported a bill that would require counties to have a citizen review board for law enforcement officers. She also supported a bill to remove the  from the state's parole board.\n\nIn 2023, Davis introduced a bill that would establish a division in the office of the  to oversee the . The bill passed the Maryland Senate, but died in the House Rules Committee.\n\n\nIn August 2019, Davis criticized Charles County's \"Fresh Start Academy\" pilot program, which separates violently disruptive students in kindergarten through second grade into smaller environments, saying that the county school system should instead prioritize improving its ratio of counselors to students.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Davis introduced legislation to would expand access to  (SNAP) assistance to eligible college students. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn 2022, Davis opposed legislation to break up the  to create a new Charles County Community College.\n\n\nIn June 2017, Davis voted against the creation of a Watershed Conservation District in northwest Charles County surrounding the  watershed.\n\n\nIn March 2016, Davis sought to postpone a bill to allow for the growth and dispensing of  in Charles County, saying that she believed the county had not fully looked into the issue and wanted to get the  involved in the discussion. She voted against the bill when it came up for a vote. During the 2022 legislative session, Davis voted against a bill creating a statewide referendum on , saying that she did not think the state is not ready for legalization.\n\n\nIn January 2017, Davis attended the  in , D.C.\n\n\nDuring her tenure as county commissioner, Davis supported the Cross County Connector, a proposed four-lane highway connecting east and west Charles County.\n\nDuring her 2018 House of Delegates campaign, Davis said she opposed a bus rapid transit system implemented by the  as an interim solution while the state studies potential light rail projects in southern Maryland. She supports the , a 19-mile rail project from  in  to , calling it a \"future driver of economic development\". In 2021, Davis introduced legislation to provide $25 million toward design and engineering work for the proposed transit line, which passed and was signed by Governor .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Chris Tomlinson''' (born August 29, 1986) is an American politician who is a member of the  for  in . He previously served as the third vice chairman of the  from 2020 to 2022.\n\n\nTomlinson graduated from  in 2004, and later attended , where he earned a  degree in electronic media and film in 2009.\n\nTomlinson first got involved in politics in 2015 when he unsuccessfully ran for the mayor of . His candidacy was challenged by the town's Board of Supervisors of Elections, who denied his certification after arguing that he did not live in the town when he filed to run for mayor. Tomlinson challenged the board's decision, claiming that he had lived in the town since April 2014. The board reversed its decision a few days later, allowing Tomlinson to run for mayor. Tomlinson was defeated in the mayoral election by incumbent mayor Ryan Warner, receiving 27.3 percent of the vote.\n\nIn 2017, Tomlinson began working in the , eventually becoming a manager in the agency's Office of State Procurement. In November 2017, Tomlinson was appointed to the Carroll County Republican Central Committee.\n\nIn 2022, Tomlinson filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 5. During the primary, he ran on a ticket with state Senator  and state Delegate . Tomlinson won the Republican primary election on July 19, 2022, coming in second place behind Rose. He ran unopposed in the general election.\n\n\nTomlinson was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023, with the start of the Maryland General Assembly's 445th legislative session. He is a member of the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\nTomlinson supported President  in the , attending a Trump rally in  in December 2019.\n\nDuring his 2022 House of Delegates campaign, Tomlinson said he planned to introduce legislation in the 2023 legislative session that would improve human resources practices in state government by requiring the fiscal notes of bills to include the number of new employees needed to accomplish the legislation's goals. He also said he supported legislation to limit the powers of the .\n\nIn August 2024, Tomlinson endorsed the , a federal bill that would require voters to show  when registering to vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James M. Kelly''' (born July 5, 1960) is a Washington, D.C. lobbyist and a former Maryland politician. He was first elected in 1994 to represent , which covers a portion of . An officer in the , he became Assistant Commandant for Reserve in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2021.\n\n\nKelly was first elected in 1994 when he defeated Democrat  for the new  seat. Previously, there was a District 9 that was served by , , and . Klima went on to win District 9A's election.  In the 1998 Republican primary election, Kelly was unchallenged.  Furthermore, he was unchallenged in the general election, as well.\n\nKelly resigned from his position in 2001 and was replaced by his wife, , by Governor . Kelly resigned his position as he was appointed by President  to serve in the  as his Special Assistant for Intergovernmental Affairs.\n\n\nKelly Attended  in .  After serving time in the military, Kelly joined the Maryland State Police and went to college, receiving his B.S. in business administration and finance from the  in 1988.\n\nWhile working in the White House, Kelly earned his Master of Arts degree in National Security and Strategic Studies through the .\n\n\nAs mentioned previously, Kelly enlisted in  in 1977 and attended , graduating in 1990.  He has since been promoted to .  Kelly was also a Maryland State Trooper for the Maryland State Police from 1984 until 1989.\n\nKelly worked as a commercial lending and troubled-loan restructuring officer from 1989 until 1994. He was a small business owner from 1995 until 1997.  In 2001, Kelly was hired as senior advisor to Undersecretary for Memorial Affairs for the U.S. .\n\nKelly received numerous awards during his career.  He is a member of the Reserve Officers Association and the Maryland Troopers Association.  He was a recipient of the Award for Duty Beyond the Call of Duty as Maryland State Trooper, which he received in 1985. He also received the award for Outstanding Junior Officer from the U.S. Coast Guard Marine Safety Office in 1994. He holds a Certificate of Achievement from the Maryland Federation of College Republicans  in 1995. In 1996, he was selected as Legislator of the Year by the Alliance for the Mentally Ill . Additionally, he was selected as Outstanding Junior Officer in entire Fifth District from the U.S. Coast Guard in 1997. Also in 1997, Kelly received the Certificate of Achievement from the Maryland Association of Psychiatric Support Services.\n\nIn 2001, as mentioned previously, Kelly was tapped by President Bush to work for the White House.  Kelly was responsible for briefing the President on state, local, and tribal issues throughout the United States.\n\nIn 2005, together with Ken Meyer, Duane Parde and Daniel J. Ostergaard, he opened a lobbying firm in DC.\n\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9B''' Retrieved on Nov. 14, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9B''' Retrieved on Nov. 14, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/former/html/msa12252.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jesse Tyler Pippy''' (born August 6, 1982) is an American politician who was elected on November 6, 2018, to serve a 4-year term in the  representing , which encompasses parts of  and .\n\n\nPippy was born August 6, 1982. He grew up in a military family and lived in  and . He attended , where he earned a B.A. degree in political science and then a  degree at the .\n\nPippy first got involved with politics in 2014 when he unsuccessfully ran for the  in . Afterwards, he became the chair of the Frederick County Young Republicans organization. In 2016, he was appointed by Governor  to serve as Commissioner on the Frederick County Board of License Commissioners, succeeding chairman Dick Zimmerman; he was later elected Chairman. Pippy resigned from the liquor board on August 7, 2018.\n\nIn August 2017, Pippy filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 4. He won the general election, receiving 19.7 percent of the vote.\n\nPippy married his wife, Lindsey May Carpenter, in  in 2014. Together, they have two boys.\n\n\n\nPippy was sworn in to the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019.\n\nIn June 2021, Pippy announced he would seek the State Senate seat in District 4 being vacated by , but in September 2021 he withdrew his candidacy. In February 2022, he announced that he would seek re-election to the House of Delegates.\n\n\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, 2021–present (banking, consumer protection & commercial law subcommittee, 2021–present; property & casualty insurance subcommittee, 2021–present; public utilities subcommittee, 2021–present)\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2019–2020 (juvenile law subcommittee, 2019–2020; public safety subcommittee, 2019–2020)\n\n\n* Chair, Frederick County Delegation, 2020–2021\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2019\n* Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2019–present\n* Secretary, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019–present\n* Chair, Minority Caucus Steering Committee, 2020–present\n* Member, Emerging Leaders Program, State Legislative Leaders Foundation, 2020–present\n\n\n\nIn March 2022, during a debate on legislation that would expand abortion access, Pippy introduced an amendment that would allow only physicians to provide abortion services. The House of Delegates voted to reject the amendment on a vote of 40-84.\n\n\nIn March 2021, Pippy voted against legislation that would require businesses to create telework policies.\n\n\nIn March 2021, Pippy opposed a proposal by Governor Hogan that would give state employees a $1,000 bonus for working during the coronavirus pandemic, saying that he felt the government needed to do more to help private sector employees.\n\nIn June 2021, Pippy said that he supported Hogan's decision to end expanded unemployment benefits provided by the .\n\nIn August 2021, Pippy said that he opposed extending Maryland's state of emergency status for the .\n\n\nPippy introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would recognize human trafficking as a \"crime of violence\" in Maryland. The bill passed and became law on April 18, 2019. He also introduced legislation that would expand the state's child pornography laws to include lascivious acts and computer-generated images, which passed and became law on April 30, 2019.\n\nPippy introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would replace the term \"gang\" with \"criminal organization\" in the state's criminal law code. The bill passed and became law on May 8, 2020. He also introduced legislation that would make strangulation a first-degree felony assault, which passed and became law on May 8, 2020.\n\nPippy introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would allow individuals to apply for a court order to obtain information from an electronic device of interest through fax or email. The bill passed and became law on May 30, 2021.\n\nIn February 2021, Pippy said that he opposed removing s from schools.\n\n\nPippy introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would fine healthcare facilities that engage in patient brokering.\n\n\nIn March 2021, during a debate on legislation that would require counties to end their  with , Pippy unsuccessfully attempted to amend the bill to create exemptions for Frederick County.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John Frederick \"Johnny\" Mautz IV''' (born September 19, 1970) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  from District 37 since 2023. A member of the , he previously represented District 37B in the  from 2015 to 2023.\n\n\nMautz was born at  in Massachusetts, to father John Mautz and mother Diana Mautz. His father was stationed at Fort Devens before moving to the  to start a dental care company. He graduated from , and received a  degree in political science from the  in 1994 and a  degree from the  at  in 1997.\n\nBefore serving in the Maryland House of Delegates, Mautz served as a counsel on the  from 1997 to 2002. Afterwards, he served as a Special Assistant to the Deputy Chief of Staff for   from 2002 to 2005, and as legislative director for   from 2009 to 2014.\n\nMautz married his wife, Rebecca (née Shoap), in May 2005; they are now separated. They had two children. Mautz owns the Carpenter Street Saloon in .\n\n\n\nMautz was elected to the House of Delegates in , succeeding delegates  and . He was sworn in on January 14, 2015, and was a member of the Economic Matters Committee.\n\nDuring the , Mautz supported businessman .\n\nIn February 2022, after much speculation, Mautz filed to run for , challenging incumbent state Senator Adelaide Eckardt in the primary. He defeated Eckardt in the Republican primary on July 19, and won the general election on November 8, 2022. Mautz was sworn in on January 11, 2023, and is a member of the Finance Committee.\n\n\n\nIn March 2022, during debate on a bill to ban s, Mautz introduced an amendment to create a special unit on firearm violence in . The amendment was rejected in a 41-88 vote.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Mautz supported legislation to increase penalties for gun crimes, pointing to the murder of 's Deputy Glenn Hilliard in June 2022, which involved an illegal firearm. He also added that he would support reinstating the  for murdering law enforcement officers. Mautz later called for Governor  to call a special legislative session on gun violence following the .\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Mautz voted against a bill to raise the minimum wage to  by 2025, which he worried was \"too aggressive\" of an increase for Eastern Shore business owners.\n\nIn 2021, during debate on a bill allowing counties to implement es, Mautz introduced an amendment that would require any income tax increases to be subject to a countywide referendum. The amendment was rejected by a 42-94 vote.\n\nIn 2022, Mautz voted against a bill to implement a statewide  program.\n\n\nIn March 2017, Mautz voted against a bill to ban harvesting in oyster sanctuaries. In January 2020, Mautz voted against overriding Governor 's veto on House Bill 720, which establishes a consensus-based process involving environmentalists, watermen and seafood sellers to create a new oyster fishery management plan for the state, citing concerns that the bill could cause economic harm to communities on the .\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Mautz introduced a bill to provide a tax break to individuals who donate  to food programs. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan.\n\nIn July 2023, Mautz called for federal  on imported crab meat, claiming that Venezuelan crab meat was hurting local crab fisheries.\n\n\nIn April 2018, Mautz voted in favor of House Bill 888, which restricts the sale and possession of s, and House Bill 1302, which authorizes a person to petition for an extreme risk prevention order with a court or law enforcement agency when it may be determined that a person is either an extreme risk to himself or to others. Following the vote, Mautz issued a written apology to his constituents, saying that he had not read the bills and intended to vote against them. Governor Hogan would sign HB 1302 into law, but vetoed HB 888.\n\nIn 2019, Mautz said he opposed bills to further regulate  and s, imploring legislators to instead pass legislation focusing on the mental health of gun owners.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Mautz introduced an amendment to the Gun Safety Act, a gun control bill that increased requirements to obtain a handgun permit and limited where guns could be publicly carried, to protect armed civilians responding to a threat against another person from criminal charges under the bill. The amendment was rejected in a 19-27 vote. He later called the bill \"unconstitutional\" and supported the 's lawsuit against it.\n\n\nIn March 2018, Mautz voted against the Reform on Tap Act of 2018, which would have repealed certain limits on micro-breweries, farm breweries, and limited beer wholesalers.\n\nIn March 2021, Mautz voted against the Maryland Driver Privacy Act, which would prohibit state and local government agencies from providing records or data to  for the purpose of civil immigration enforcement, insisting that the bill extended extra protections to undocumented immigrants with drivers' licenses.\n\nIn 2023, Mautz introduced an amendment to the Trans Health Equity Act that would ban  for minors. The amendment was rejected in a 14-29 vote.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Clarence K. Lam''' (born November 26, 1980) is an American politician and physician who has served in the  representing the  since 2019. A member of the , his district stretches across  and  counties and includes parts of  and . Lam previously represented the district in the  from 2015 to 2019.\n\nLam ran for the  in , in which he was defeated by state senator  in the Democratic primary election.\n\n\nLam was born in . He is a second-generation Asian American, with his mother immigrating to the U.S. from  and his father immigrating from . After graduating from , Lam attended , where he earned a  degree in political science and biology in 2003; the , where he earned a  degree in 2008; and , where he earned a  degree in 2011.\n\nWhile at UMB, Lam was the president of the campus student body and worked as a research analyst for the  from 2005 to 2006.\n\nLam has worked as a  at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health since 2009. He has also served on the board of directors of  since 2011. During the  and following the 2020 legislative session, Lam worked as the interim director of the Johns Hopkins Occupational Health Services, in which he coordinated the screening of health care workers and treatment of COVID-19 patients.\n\n\nFrom 2009 to 2013, Lam worked as a legislative aide to state delegate . He also served as the executive director of the Asian American and Pacific Islander Leadership Council of the  and as a member of the Howard County Spending Affordability Advisory Committee from 2011 to 2014. From 2012 to 2015, he was a member of the Governor's Commission on Asian-Pacific American Affairs.\n\nLam was elected to the Howard County Democratic Central Committee and became the chapter president of the local  in 2010. He was elected to the board of directors of the village of  in 2011, serving until 2015. In 2012, Lam served as a delegate to the , pledged to President .\n\n\n\nLam was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in , during which he ran on a slate with state senator  and candidates  and . He was sworn in on January 14, 2015. He was a member of the Environment and Transportation Committee from 2015 to 2017, afterwards serving in the Appropriations Committee until 2019.\n\nOn February 13, 2018, Lam announced that he would  in District 12, seeking to succeed Kasemeyer, who had announced his retirement. His candidacy was backed by the district's other two state delegates, Ebersole and Hill. The district was targeted by the  in their \"Fight for Five\" campaign in 2018. Lam won the Democratic primary on June 26, 2018, defeating Howard County councilmember Mary Kay Sigaty with 72.6 percent of the vote, faced Republican Joseph Hooe in the general election, who he defeated with 33.8 percent of the vote. He was re-elected in .\n\n\n\nLam was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. He was a member of the Health and Environmental Affairs Committee until 2023, afterwards serving as a member of the Finance Committee. He has also served on the Executive Nominations Committee since 2019 and became the committee's vice chair in October 2023, making him the first Asian American to serve as chair or vice chair of a Senate committee. As of 2024, Lam is the only physician and only Asian American in the Maryland Senate.\n\nIn 2020, Senate President  appointed Lam to chair the Joint Committee on Fair Practices alongside . In this capacity, he became a frequent critic of  and his administration, and investigated the circumstances surrounding the $238,250  paid to , the former director of the Maryland Environmental Service and Hogan's chief of staff. He also criticized the  following the .\n\n\n\nOn November 30, 2023, Lam announced that he would  in , seeking to succeed retiring U.S. Representative . If elected, he would be the first Asian American to represent Maryland in Congress. During the Democratic primary, which largely developed into a three-way race between Lam, , and , Lam campaigned on health-related issues and received support from various advocacy groups and Howard County-based legislators. Lam was defeated in the Democratic primary election by Elfreth on May 14, 2024, placing third with 11.7 percent of the vote.\n\n\n, 2023]]\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Lam introduced a bill to ban  in public schools.\n\nIn 2023, Lam introduced legislation to create two appointed positions on the county board of education. The bill died after Lam and , a cosponsor, decided against bringing it up for a vote on the final work day of the .\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Lam introduced legislation that would require  to fill vacancies in the . He also introduced the Student Voter Empowerment Act, which would require higher education institutions to encourage students to vote in elections.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Lam introduced a bill to ban deliberate balloon releases. The bill was reintroduced by state delegate  in 2021, during which he amended the bill to set penalties for mass balloon releases.\n\nIn March 2023, during debate on a bill establishing the framework for the state's , Lam introduced an amendment requiring \"on-site consumption\" establishments to follow the state's Clean Indoor Air Act. The amendment was adopted.\n\n\nLam opposes efforts to repeal the . During his 2018 Senate candidacy, he ran on a platform that included expanding health care access, especially coverage for pregnant women, and taking steps toward . Lam frequently criticized the Hogan administration's decision-making during the , including the distribution and contracting of the . In April 2021, he was one of two state senators to vote against confirming Dennis Schrader as Secretary of the , citing criticism of his COVID-19 vaccine rollout.\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Lam introduced a bill to make it easier for physicians to . The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor . In 2019, he introduced a bill that would allow medical professionals to prescribe , a HIV-prevent drug, to minors, which passed and became law.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Lam introduced legislation to extend temporary unemployment benefits to workers who lost their jobs during the COVID-19 pandemic. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn March 2022, Lam said he supported legislation to prevent state health officers from being fired without reason.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Lam introduced the Access to Care Act, which would allow undocumented immigrants to buy into the state's health exchange. The bill was reintroduced during the 2024 legislative session.\n\n\nIn 2017, Lam supported the Maryland Trust Act, which would prevent the use of state and local funding for .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Lam introduced the Maryland Driver Privacy Act, which would prohibit federal agencies from accessing state databases unless it had a  and blocked the state from providing agencies with photos of individuals for immigration investigations. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor Larry Hogan. The Maryland General Assembly overrode Hogan's veto during the special legislative session later that year.\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Lam introduced legislation to ban dogfighting paraphernalia.\n\nIn 2017, Lam introduced legislation to provide immunity to first responders to provide aid to animals during emergencies.\n\nIn 2020, Lam introduced legislation to make  permanent in Maryland.\n\nIn 2021, Lam introduced legislation to ban the use of  in criminal court proceedings. The bill passed and went into effect without Governor Larry Hogan's signature.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session and following reports that Governor  and his administration was using the messaging app , which automatically deletes messages, in official state communications, Lam introduced legislation that would revise the Maryland Public Information Act to include messages sent in the app.\n\nIn March 2022, Lam spoke in support of a bill to provide $3.5 million toward training doctors on abortion care.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Lam spoke against a proposed amendment that would require minors to get parental consent to receive . The amendment was rejected in a 14-29 vote. He also introduced legislation to repeal , which passed and became law without Governor 's signature, and another bill that would cut state funding from school systems that refuse to instruct state-approved curriculum. During the 2024 legislative session, Lam introduced a bill to protect health care providers from liability if they provide gender-affirming care to out-of-state patients.\n\n\nIn March 2014, Lam said he would only support \"progressive\" tax increases.\n\n\nLam has a daughter.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph F. Vallario Jr.''' (born March 4, 1937) is an American politician who represented district 23B in the  and was the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. Vallario was first elected in 1974 and was the longest serving chairman in the .\n\n\nVallario attended Washington, DC, parochial schools, the  (since merged into ), B.C.S. (commercial science) and M.C.S. (commercial science), 1959; , and the Mt. Vernon School of Law, LL.B., J.D., 1963 (Now the ). Admitted to Maryland Bar in 1964, he is an attorney and a member of the American and Maryland State Bar Associations. Vallario is a past president of the Prince George's County Criminal Trial Lawyers Association and a member of the .\n\nHe was featured in the  documentary, \",\" for his role in being opposed to a bill seeking to increase the statute of limitations of sexual abuse victims.\n\n\nDelegate Vallario had been the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee since 1993 and a member of the Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, also since 1993. He served on the Legislative Policy Committee, the Article 27 (crimes & punishments) Revision Committee and is a past member of the Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, the Drunk and Drugged Driving Task Force (1988–90), the Joint Task Force on Maryland's Procurement Law (1993–94), and the Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer (1996 & 2002). He was the Co-Chair of the Task Force to Examine Crime Victims' Rights Laws in Maryland (1996–2003), a member of the Special Committee on Gaming (2001), a member of the  and the past chair, Prince George's County Delegation. National Conference of State Legislatures (law & criminal justice committee). Vallario has been an active supporter of victims rights as well as a proponent for strengthening Maryland's laws against child predators. He has opposed legalizing , but in March 2011 he voted as chairman for a bill to do just that in the Judiciary Committee. He was criticized for that vote, with Del.  saying, \"The chairman did what he was told. That's why he's chairman.\" Vallario was attacked in a lengthy  article published August 3, 2013, for his conflict of interest in having legally represented many drunken drivers and then using his Chairman position to pardon them.\n\n\n]]\n\n\n*refused to allow a vote on a bill decriminalizing possession of small amounts of marijuana, claiming \"Bad message to the kids.\" The bill would have subjected people caught with 10 grams or less to a civil fine of $100.\n\n\n*co-sponsor of HB6, requiring custodial interrogations in capital cases be recorded.(became law Chapter 360)\n\n\n* voted for Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154) \n\n\n* voted against slot machines in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted for \"No-Knock\" Warrants (HB557), (became law Chapter 560)\n\n\n*voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)\n\n\n*2010 Most Influential Maryland Legislators (Top 20)\n\n\n\n\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\nVallario lost in the primary election held on June 26, 2018.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
