    "pages": }\n\n'''Isiah \"Ike\" Leggett''' (born July 25, 1944) is an American politician from the  of  and former executive of . He is a member of the \n\nBorn in , Leggett attended  in  and, after serving in the  with the , earned a  degree from  in  In 1986, he became the first  elected to the county council in  and served on the council through 2002.\n\nFor two years, Leggett served as the chairman of the  before leaving that position to run for office once again. Leggett was elected  of Montgomery County in 2006, the first African-American to hold that office.\n\n\nLeggett was born on July 25, 1944, in  and grew up with twelve siblings in . In Alexandria, he played  for . He attended  in , working through school as a groundskeeper in a work-study program and graduating in 1967. In his time as an undergraduate, he was a student leader in the  movement and twice met  He led the on-campus civil rights movement while at the same time commanding the   (ROTC) unit. He was elected president of his class during his senior year and is a member of , the first intercollegiate fraternity established for African-Americans. In 1968, Leggett served as a captain in the United States Army during the Vietnam War, first in combat with a Military Advisory Unit attached to the Army of the Republic of Vietnam and then as a public affairs officer with the 7th Support Battalion/199th Light Infantry Brigade. He was awarded the Bronze Star for Service. In 1974, he received  and  degrees from  in , graduating first in his law school class, followed soon after by a Master of Laws degree from . He returned to Howard as a professor in their law school in 1976 and continued teaching at the law school through his election as County Executive in 2006, except for a stint as a  under President  in 1977.\n\n\nLeggett's first participation in county government was as an appointed member of the Montgomery County Human Relations Committee, on which he served from 1979 to 1986. He was later named Chair of the committee. In 1986, he was elected as an at-large member of the Montgomery County Council, becoming the first African-American ever to serve on the council. To this day, only one other African-American has been elected to county government office at large. He was re-elected to the seat three more times, and served three one-year terms as council president. During his time on the council, he chaired the council's transportation and environment committee and played a role in passage of a county living wage law and a public . In 1992, a former county council aide of Leggett's accused him of sexual harassment in a widely publicized case, but the accusation was dismissed by a jury. In 2002, Leggett declined to run for re-election to the county council. He was widely viewed as a potential running mate for Democratic nominee  in that year's gubernatorial race. However, Townsend chose Admiral  instead. Townsend and Larson lost in November when Maryland elected  to be its first Republican governor in 40 years and Lieutenant Governor  as its first African-American statewide elected official. When his term on the council was completed in December of that year, Leggett was elected as chairman of the Maryland Democratic Party. Leggett's chairmanship was seen by some Democratic activists as important to maintaining the African-American base of the Maryland Democratic Party and rebuilding the party's strength following the 2002 gubernatorial loss.\n\n\nFollowing the election of 2004, Maryland politicians started announcing their intentions for the . Among them was three-term County Executive , who was in the early stages of a run for governor. In December 2004, Leggett left his position as Chair of the Maryland Democratic Party to begin a  to replace Duncan as Montgomery County Executive. In the Democratic primary election Leggett squared off against a former colleague from the council, . Leggett and Silverman engaged in a long series of debates beginning almost a year before the election. But despite being outspent by Silverman by more than five to one, Leggett won the Democratic nomination for executive by 61.3 percent to 35.5 percent in the primary election on September 12, 2006. He then faced Republican nominee Chuck Floyd and independent anti-tax advocate  in the general election. Leggett easily won the November election with 68 percent of the vote to Floyd's 22 percent and 10 percent for Ficker. He carried 239 of the county's 241 voting precincts.\n\n\nIn the early days of his administration, Leggett took the lead on a number of controversial issues. To help alleviate transportation funding difficulties and move County transit projects forward, he proposed a statewide gas tax increase, a position he first articulated in his race for County Executive. This proposal, which happened in the midst of a state budget crunch and in response to high levels of  in the county, was supported by the County Council but largely ignored by incoming  . Leggett continued to advocate for the increase throughout his term.\n\nLeggett dealt with the major local issue of a hiring site for ers from the city of  and the surrounding upper county area. During the term of Leggett's predecessor , Gaithersburg had struggled to find space within the city limits that the county could lease for use as a location where the day laborers could wait for employers. The owners of virtually all of the more than 30 sites considered by the city government had refused to grant a lease for this purpose, and in the one case where the property owner was willing to consider the use, the county's efforts to lease the property fell through after the property owner backed out. The debate became caught up in a larger national debate about the role of  in American society. Leggett located a site for day laborer center on county-owned land with his first several months in office. Despite opposition from anti-immigrant voices, the center has served hundreds of workers and employers without incident.\n\n\nLeggett was unopposed in the 2010 Democratic Party primary for County Executive. In the general election, he was opposed by Republican Party candidate Douglas Rosenfeld. In the November balloting, Leggett won reelection with 66 percent of the vote to 34 percent for Rosenfeld, carrying 227 of the county's 252 precincts.\n \n\nLeggett won the Democratic nomination for a third term, gaining 45 percent of the vote to 33 percent for former county executive Doug Duncan and 22 percent for councilmember Phil Andrews, and winning 80 percent of county precincts. In the fall general election Leggett defeated the Republican candidate James Shalleck by 65-35 percent, winning 212 of 245 voting precincts. Leggett declared before the passage of term limits in the county in 2016, that he would not run for re-election.\n\nLeggett was elected as president of the Maryland Association of Counties in January 2015. In January 2017, he vetoed a bill which would have gradually raised the county minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2020.\n\n\n\nLeggett is currently married to his second wife, Catherine.\n\nLeggett and his wife are longtime philanthropic supporters of , with Catherine receiving an honorary degree in 2019. In September 2024, the college dedicated its Math and Science Building to Catherine and Isiah.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  at the Maryland State Archives\n*  \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Justin D. Ross''' (born April 18, 1976) is an  who served in the  from 2003 to 2012. He was first elected to the House in 2002 to represent District 22, which covers .\n\nRoss retired from the House of Delegates in November 2012. Ross served as a top lieutenant to Maryland House Speaker Michael E. Busch. In his roles as Chief Deputy Majority Whip from 2006-2012, Ross is widely credited in delivering the last minute votes needed to pass marriage equality in February 2012. Later that September during a rare special session of the Maryland Legislature, Ross again was able to help secure the votes for legislation that allowed for MGM National Harbor to open in Prince George's County. He was given the nickname \"Mr. 71\" (the number of votes needed to pass a bill) by then Speaker Michael Busch for his ability to secure the votes in the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nOn July 1, 2013, Justin joined with Timothy A. Perry, Josh White and Jonas A. Jacobson to form the Annapolis government relations firm of Perry, White Ross & Jacobson . PWRJ quickly became among the very elite of government relations firms in Maryland.  On July 1, 2021, Ross left PWRJ and began a new role as Senior Vice President for Global Programming for Next Level Sports & Entertainment (NLSE). NLSE is the only Black-owned sports network in the world is available in approximately 30 Million US Homes on providers such as Verizon Fios, Direct TV, AT&T, Fubo, & Distro.\n\n\nRoss was born in , Maryland to David G. and Jane L. Ross, on April 18, 1976.  Ross attended the public schools of Prince George's County and graduated from  in 1994, where he wrestled and was the County champion at 145&nbsp;lbs. Ross matriculated to the  and received his  in government and politics in 1998. Ross earned his M.S. n Real Estate Development from the Ed St. John School of Business at Johns Hopkins University.\n\n\nAfter graduating from college, Ross became a real estate broker.  He spent more than a decade as an associate at NAI Michael Companies, working on all aspects of commercial property development and leasing. He then served as vice president of the AFL-CIO Investment Trust Corporation.\n\nOn July 1, 2013, Justin joined with Timothy A. Perry, Josh White and Jonas A. Jacobson to form the Annapolis government relations firm of Perry, White Ross & Jacobson   On July 1, 2013, Justin joined with Timothy A. Perry, Josh White and Jonas A. Jacobson to form the Annapolis government relations firm of Perry, White Ross & Jacobson . PWRJ quickly became among the very elite of government relations firms in Maryland.  On July 1, 2021, Ross left PWRJ and began a new role as Senior Vice President for Global Programming for Next Level Sports & Entertainment (NLSE). NLSE is the only Black-owned sports network in the world is available in approximately 30 Million US Homes on providers such as Verizon Fios, Direct TV, AT&T, Fubo, & Distro.\n\nRoss is also a partner in the Prince George's County based commercial real estate development firm RISE IP along with partners Brad Frome and MaeAnna Hassell.\n\n\nRoss began serving in the House of Delegates on January 8, 2003. He served on the House Ways and Means Committee and its election law and revenues subcommittees where he spent his entire career. In 2005, Ross helped lead the successful effort that required Prince George's County liquor stores to close at midnight (instead of 2am) and increased fines for penalties for stores that were poorly run. During the 2007 session of the , Delegate Ross sponsored HB554 which was cross-filed with State Senator .  These bills both sought to allow specified convicted felons, who have been released and completed their conditions of parole and probation, the right to vote. The legislation passed both houses and was signed into law by Governor O'Malley. In 2011, Ross,  as Chairman of the County Affairs Committee, shepherded then-Prince George's County Executive Rushern Baker's ethics reform legislation through the Maryland General Assembly.\n\nRoss is widely credited in delivering the last minute votes needed to pass Marriage Equality in February 2012. Later that September, during a rare special session of the Maryland Legislature, Ross again was able to help secure the final votes for legislation that allowed for MGM National Harbor to open in Prince George's County. He was given the nickname \"Mr. 71\" (the number of votes needed to pass a bill) by former Speaker Michael Busch for his ability to secure the votes in the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\n\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted against slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted in favor of the Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* voted in favor of \"Dream Act\"  in-state tuition for students who attended Maryland highschools for at least 2 years. (HB6)(2007) \n* sponsored House Bill 30 in 2007, Establishing the Maryland Education Fund.\n\n\n*2010 Most Influential Maryland Legislators (Top 20)\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://archive1.mdarchives.state.md.us/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa13993.html\n* http://www.elections.state.md.us/elections/2002/results/index.html\n* http://www.justinross.us/\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Christian J. Miele''' born February 28, 1981) is an American politician and lawyer who served as a member of the  from the  from January 5 to January 11, 2023, and a member of the  from the  from 2015 to 2019. A member of the , Miele served as the deputy secretary of the Maryland Department of Disabilities in the administration of Governor  from 2019 to 2023.\n\n\nMiele was born in  on February 28, 1981 to an  father. Miele was raised in New Jersey and graduated from , afterwards moving to Maryland to attend , where he was a member of the  fraternity and earned a  degree in political science in 2004 and a  degree in professional studies in 2008; and , where he was a member of the  fraternity, served as the president of the , and earned a  degree in 2014.\n\n\nAfter graduating from Towson, Miele worked as the university's coordinator for fraternity and sorority life from 2006 to 2010. While attending Emory, he co-founded and worked as the editor-in-chief for the ''Emory Corporate Governance and Accountability Review'' law journal, interned for the 's criminal division, and clerked for Maryland Court of Appeals justice  Miele was admitted to the  in 2017, after which he worked for injury law firm Pinder Plotkin LLC, first as an associate from 2017 to 2023 and then as a partner since 2023. Miele has also worked as a public information officer for the  government since 2023.\n\n\n (left) swears Miele (right) into the Maryland House of Delegates, 2015]]\nIn August 2013, Miele announced that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 8. He won election to the seat in the , and was sworn in on January 14, 2015. Miele served on the Health and Government Operations Committee during his entire tenure. Following his election, Miele was considered a rising star within the .\n\n'''' described Miele as a . During his 2014 House of Delegates campaign, he expressed support for legislation to legalize , decriminalize marijuana possession, and repeal the death penalty. In the legislature, he successfully introduced the Hire Our Veterans Act, which incentivized businesses to hire military veterans; Janet's Law, which requires physicians practicing without insurance to disclose their lack of coverage to patients; and legislation to discourage bullying in public schools. Miele also introduced bills to strip lawmakers convicted of felonies of their pension benefits, and supported bills to decriminalize  and to establish an  to draw Maryland's political maps.\n\nIn November 2015, Miele was named as a co-chair for 's  in Maryland.\n\n\n\n\nOn June 8, 2017, Miele announced that he would run for the  in District 8 in , challenging incumbent Democratic state senator . His candidacy was endorsed by Governor  and the  in their \"Drive for Five\" campaign. The election was seen as one of the most competitive in the Maryland Senate, as Miele was expected to benefit from having Hogan's endorsement, who won the district by 37 points in , but Klausmeier was seen as being the slight favorite due to her high name recognition and strong community roots. Both candidates ran campaigns focused on local issues, including school overcrowding and the .\n\nKlausmeier defeated Miele in the general election on November 6, 2018, edging out Miele by a margin of 1,061 votes, or 2.3 percent. Following his defeat, in January 2019, Governor  appointed Miele to serve as the deputy secretary of the Maryland Department of Disabilities, replacing , who moved to a position within the Maryland Department of Budget and Management. In this capacity, Miele oversaw the department's legislative portfolio and managed its policy team.\n\n\n\nOn July 2, 2021, Miele announced that he would run for the  in District 34, seeking to succeed , who retired to . He won the Republican primary election with 73.7 percent of the vote, defeating businessman Walter Tilley, and faced Democratic nominee and former state delegate , who defeated Miele in the general election with 50.55 percent of the vote, or by a margin of 591 votes, on November 8, 2022.\n\n\n}}\nFollowing his defeat, in December 2022, Governor Larry Hogan appointed Miele to the  to replace Cassilly, who vacated the seat after winning the Harford County executive election. He was sworn in on January 5, 2023. Miele served in this position for one week until the start of the 's 445th legislative session on January 11, 2023.\n\n\nMiele is married to his wife, Jessica (née Minacapelli). Together, they have two children. Following his defeat in the 2018 Maryland Senate election, Miele and his family moved from  to .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kevin B. Kamenetz''' (November 26, 1957 – May 10, 2018) was an American politician who was the 12th  of , serving between 2010 and May 10, 2018, when he died suddenly while in office. , ''Baltimore Sun'', May 10, 2018. He was a member of the . He previously served as a four-term County Councilman representing the Second District of Baltimore County. On September 18, 2017, Kamenetz declared his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the .\n\n\n\nKamenetz was born on November 26, 1957, in , to Miriam and Irvin Kamenetz, a pharmacist who owned an  pharmacy. He attended and graduated from the , a private preparatory school for boys. He earned a bachelor's degree from the  in 1979, he graduated from  with a  in 1982, and he passed the Maryland Bar that same year.\n\nKamenetz worked as a prosecutor in the Office of the  for  from 1982 to 1987, and practiced law for over 30 years.\n\nHe was admitted to practice before the Bars of the , the , and the .\n\n\n\nKamenetz was elected to the Democratic State Central Committee for terms in 1982, 1990, 1994, and served as Baltimore County Chair from 1993 to 1994.\n\n\nKamenetz was elected to the  in 1994 and was re-elected in 1998, 2002, and 2006, serving a total of 16 years. His fellow members of the Council elected him Chairman in 1996, 1999, 2003, and 2008. He served as Chair of the Council's Spending and Affordability Committee.\n\n\n\nOn November 2, 2010, Kamenetz was elected as the 12th , succeeding James T. Smith, Jr.\n\nBaltimore County launched its landmark \"Schools for Our Future\" program, a $1.3 billion ten-year school construction and renovation initiative designed to meet the needs of ’s educational facilities by eliminating existing and projected overcrowding, modernizing learning environments, and improving safety. Through the program, Baltimore County is building 16 new schools and performing 19 major additions and renovations, reducing the number of  without central air conditioning from 90 in 2010 to 13 in 2017.\n\nIn December 2012, he had proposed building a new fire station in Towson Manor Park, a  that represented the only green space in the Towson Manor Village neighborhood. The then-existing fire station in Towson was old and located in a site that could possibly be redeveloped for commercial purposes. The property was ultimately sold, and the proceeds used to pay for the new fire station. But the county was able to find space on underused land it already held in downtown Towson, leaving Towson Manor Park untouched. Three Baltimore County Schools and a police station, all on the county's east side, were also affected by similar land sales to developers.\n\nIn 2016, Kamenetz was elected President of the Maryland Association of Counties, a   that serves Maryland’s counties by articulating the needs of local government to the . Maryland Association of Counties is the only organization serving the needs of county elected officials and governments across Maryland.\n\nHe served on the board of the Baltimore Metropolitan Council (Chair, 2012), the Baltimore Regional Transportation Board (Chair, 2013), the Board of Visitors, and the .\"\". ''Maryland State Archives''. Retrieved May 16, 2017.\n\n\n\n\n\nOn September 18, 2017, Kamenetz announced his candidacy for Governor of Maryland in the , running against incumbent .Hicks, Josh (September 17, 2017). \"\". ''The Washington Post''.\n\n\n\nKamenetz resided in  with his wife, Jill Kamenetz, and their two sons.\n\nKamenetz died in the early hours of May 10, 2018. He had awoken at 2 a.m., complaining that he felt unwell, and was taken to the  in , where he was pronounced dead at 3:22&nbsp;a.m., after going into . It is believed that Kamenetz suffered a heart attack, though his family chose not to have an autopsy performed.\n\nFlags throughout Maryland were ordered to be flown at half-staff by  .\n\nTwo weeks later, the County Council chose Kamenetz's chief of staff, Donald I. Mohler III, to serve out the remaining months of his term.\n\n\n\nIn 2010, Kamenetz received the Valleys Planning Council’s McHarg award for his efforts to reduce density, protect environmentally sensitive land and watersheds, and secure Baltimore County’s rural heritage.\n\nIn 2013, Kamenetz received the Outstanding Performance and Community Service Award from the Baltimore County Branch of the  in recognition of his outstanding leadership of Baltimore County government and the significant increases in diversity among County employees.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Benjamin Thomas Brooks Sr.''' (born April 23, 1950) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  for , based in , since 2023. A member of the , he previously represented the district in the  from 2015 to 2023.\n\n\nBenjamin Thomas Brooks Sr. was born in  on April 23, 1950. He graduated from Ebenezer High School. After graduating, Brooks served in the  from 1969 to 1972, where he worked as a telephone repairman and earned the Accommodations Medal, Army Good Conduct Medal, , and the , and afterwards attended , where he earned a  degree in accounting in 1976.\n\n\nAfter graduating from South Carolina State, Brooks worked as an accountant for , first as a junior accountant from 1976 to 1978 and then as a cost accountant until 1987. He has run his own tax service company, B & R Brooks Professional Tax Service, since 1987 and his own investment firm, Brooks Family Investments Inc., since 2004.\n\nBrooks first got involved in politics in 2010, when he was elected as a member of the Baltimore County Democratic Central Committee. In December 2010, Baltimore County Executive  appointed Brooks as chair of the county's liquor board, where he served until 2013.\n\n\nBrooks ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 10 in , during which he won the Democratic primary alongside  and incumbent . He was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015, where he served on the Economic Matters Committee during his entire tenure and as the chair of its public utilities subcommittee from 2019 to 2023. Brooks also served as deputy majority whip from 2017 to 2023. In 2019, Brooks sought to run for , challenging incumbent , but missed the deadline for filing to run. Despite this, Brooks received 24 votes in the treasurer election.\n\nIn 2022, Brooks ran for the Maryland Senate in District 10, seeking to succeed retiring state Senator . During the Democratic primary, he was endorsed by Kelley and ran on a slate with Adrienne Jones, , and . He also faced colleague Jay Jalisi, whom he defeated with 37.6 percent of the vote. Brooks was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 11, 2023, and has since served on the Education, Energy, and the Environment Committee.\n\nBrooks is a member of the  and the Maryland Veterans Caucus. He was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\nBrooks married his wife, Irene Theresa, on August 10, 1974. Together, they have three children. He is a member of the St. Gabriel Roman Catholic Church in .\n\n\nIn November 2015, Brooks signed onto a letter calling on Governor  to allow  into Maryland after Hogan said that he would ask the  to stop sending such refugees to the state.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Brooks introduced a bill to create timelines for Maryland's remaining power plants to transition away from coal and establish a transition fund to mitigate economic impacts for employees. The bill was withdrawn after he and Senate sponsor  announced a deal with  that would cause the  to stop burning coal in 2030.\n\nIn November 2020, Brooks expressed support for stricter regulations on police. He attended a simulated police training exercise hosted by the Maryland , which he said gave him emphasize with the split-second decisions officers have to make, but did not change his mind on policing reforms.\n\nIn October 2021, Brooks joined a lawsuit against the 's redistricting plan, which resulted in a new map with a second minority opportunity district.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Brooks introduced legislation to establish the Maryland Native Plants Program to encourage garden centers to plant native vegetation. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Hasan \"Jay\" Jalisi''' (born November 17, 1965) is an  who was a  member of the  for , based in , from 2015 to 2023. In 2022, he unsuccessfully , placing second to state Delegate .\n\n\nJalisi was born on November 17, 1965, in , . His family is from  and later moved to Pakistan, and then to , where his father taught at a medical school. He graduated from  in  and later attended the , where he earned a  degree in 1990. After graduating, he moved to the  and worked positions at  and the . He came to Baltimore in 1997 to attend , where he earned a  degree in international health systems in 1998. While at Hopkins, Jalisi got into , using money from family members to buy an apartment building where he lived after learning it was in foreclosure. He was previously a medical doctor and has co-authored two medical textbooks on diseases of the ears, nose, and throat, but eventually stepped back from his medical career to become a full-time real estate investor.\n\nIn December 2013, Jalisi filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 10. He won the Democratic primary, receiving 17.4 percent of the vote, coming in second only behind Delegate . Jalisi won the general election with 28.7 percent of the vote.\n\n\nJalisi was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. Up until the appointment of , he was the only  serving in the .\n\nIn November 2019, Jalisi filed to run in the  to fill out the term of the late , and in the overlapping  for the same congressional seat. He was defeated by  in the Democratic primary for both elections.\n\nIn April 2022, Jalisi filed to run for Maryland Senate to succeed retiring Senator . He was defeated in the Democratic primary, placing second to state Delegate Ben Brooks.\n\n\n* Member, Environment and Transportation Committee, 2015–2023 (housing & real property subcommittee, 2015–2018; motor vehicle & transportation subcommittee, 2017–2018; natural resources, agriculture & open space subcommittee, 2015–2023; local government & bi-county agencies subcommittee, 2019–2023)\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2015 (civil law & procedure subcommittee, 2015; criminal justice subcommittee, 2015)\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Asian-American and Pacific-Islander Caucus, 2015–2019 (treasurer, 2016–2019)\n* Member, , 2015–2018\n* Member, Maryland Military Installation Legislative Caucus, 2017–2023\n\n\n\nIn February 2015, Jalisi's daughter filed for a  against him, accusing him of slapping her during an altercation at his wife's home in . A temporary restraining order was granted, then extended on March 2 after neither Jalisi nor his attorney appeared in court. On March 9, Jalisi and his daughter entered into a consent agreement without a finding of abuse, preventing him from visiting his daughter for a year. Following the incident, House Speaker  moved Jalisi from the House Judiciary Committee to the House Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\nIn March 2019, an ethics committee investigation found that Jalisi subjected his staffers, particularly female employees, to  and  over a span of five years. The report also said that Jalisi ignored repeated requests from House Speaker Busch and other top lawmakers to take  classes, which led to Busch withdrawing his use of state funds to pay his staffers. Jalisi denied the allegations, denouncing the investigation as a \"nasty smear campaign and a sham investigation\". On March 27, the House of Delegates voted unanimously to reprimand Jalisi. In December 2020, a District Court Judge ordered Jalisi to pay more than $19,500 in back pay and damages to a former legislative aide who did not receive payment for the month he worked for his office.\n\nIn October 2014, Jalisi was fined $2,500 for misusing campaign funds.\n\n\nIn October 2014, the  fined Jalisi $15,000 for lead paint hazards related to at least two apartments in a  condominium.\n\nIn March 2021, a tenant filed a lawsuit against Jalisi's property management firm, HMJ Management Company, for failing to fix water leaks in her bathroom, causing her to slip on the wet floor and hit her head against the wall and a toilet paper stand. The toilet paper stand lodged in her throat and left her unable to call for help, requiring her to receive spinal surgery and leaving her with chronic neck and back pain that left her unable to work.\n\n\n\nJalisi introduced legislation in the 2016 legislative session that would limit  and . The bill was amended to create a task force to investigate the Department of Juvenile Services' policies on strip-searching and shackling. The bill passed and became law on May 19, 2016.\n\n\nIn September 2017, the Maryland  gave Jalisi a score of 71 percent on its annual legislative scorecard, making him one of three Democrats not to receive a perfect score.\n\n\nIn February 2022, Jalisi declined to vote on legislation that created a framework for legalizing . In April 2022, Jalisi again declined to vote to override a gubernatorial veto on the bill, citing religious reasons.\n\n\nIn April 2021, Jalisi voted in favor of a bill that would create a constitutional ballot referendum that would require lawmakers to live in the districts they represent. The bill passed both chambers of the Maryland General Assembly and will be decided by voters in the 2022 elections.\n\nJalisi introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would prevent car insurance companies from using a person's  in setting a policyholder's premium. The measure was unanimously rejected by the Economic Matters Committee in favor of identical legislation introduced by Delegate .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Charlotte Crutchfield''' (born December 8, 1963) is an  from . She is a  member of the  who currently represents  in .\n\n\nCrutchfield was born in  on December 8, 1963. She attended , where she earned a  in economics in 1986, and the , where she earned a  in 1989. She was an assistant  for Montgomery County from 1991 to 1992. She also served as an associate  at  from 1996 to 2002. Crutchfield is a practicing attorney in the area of .\n\nCrutchfield first ran for the House of Delegates in 2014, coming in fourth place with 15.7 percent of the vote. She expressed a \"very strong interest\" in running again in 2018, eventually filing to run on January 10, 2018. She came in second place in the Democratic primary election, receiving 17.6 percent of the vote.\n\n\nCharlotte Crutchfield was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She, along with  and , became the first Black women elected to represent Montgomery County in the House of Delegates.\n\nOn May 20, 2020, Crutchfield wrote a letter to Governor  urging him to grant clemency to Eraina Pretty, the longest-serving female prisoner in Maryland, after she tested positive for . Crutchfield wrote, \"Though she was convicted of a violent crime, she is not a violent person. There is no reason to believe that if Ms. Pretty were released she would pose a danger to society.\" A Baltimore circuit judge granted the release of Pretty on December 14, 2020.\n\n\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2019–present (family law subcommittee, 2019–2020; public safety subcommittee, 2019–2020; chair, juvenile law subcommittee, 2020; member, civil law & procedure subcommittee, 2021–present; chair, family & juvenile law subcommittee, 2021–present)\n\n\n* Secretary, , 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2021–present\n\n\nCrutchfield is a military widow. She has two children and lives in .\n\n\n\nCrutchfield introduced legislation during the 2021 legislative session that would allow individuals convicted of  as minors to have their convictions reviewed.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Crutchfield introduced legislation to create a separate, pre-release mediation unit for women in the state prison system. She introduced legislation during the 2021 legislative session that would repeal the prohibition on prosecuting  against a victim who is the spouse of the assailant. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 125-4. The bill was re-introduced during the 2022 legislative session, during which it passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 125-6 and the Senate by 46-0.\n\nCrutchfield introduced legislation during the 2022 legislative session that would allow  victims to bring civil action against the person who committed the act. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 94-41.\n\n\nDuring her 2018 campaign, Crutchfield said that she would vote to legalize . During her first term, Crutchfield co-sponsored various bills to  legal records related to marijuana possession.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jonathan Bartlett Jennings''' (born March 27, 1974) is an American politician and farmer who has served as a member of the  representing the  since 2011. A member of the , he previously represented the district in the  from 2003 to 2011, and served as the minority leader of the Senate from 2014 to 2020.\n\n\nJonathan Bartlett Jennings was born in  on March 27, 1974. He grew up in , and graduated from , and later attended , where he earned an  in 1995, and the , where he earned a  degree in business administration in 1997.\n\nJennings worked as a full-time  cattle farmer from 1992 to 2008, becoming a part-time beef and horse farmer after joining the . As an Airman 1st Class, he was activated for military service at  in Georgia during his first term as a state senator in 2011, causing him to miss the entire session. Jennings also co-owns the Mill of Hereford, an animal feed store, owns his own consulting company, and serves as a volunteer firefighter for the Jacksonville Volunteer Fire Company.\n\nJennings first became involved in politics as a staff assistant to U.S. Representative  from 1997 to 1998.\n\n\nJennings ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in 2002, on a platform that included issues involving school crowding and over-development. He was sworn in on January 8, 2003. He served as a member of the Environmental Matters Committee and as a deputy minority whip from 2003 to 2006, afterwards serving in the Ways and Means Committee from 2007 to 2009 and the Judiciary Committee from 2009 to 2011.\n\nIn October 2009, after state senator  announced that he would  in  in 2010, Jennings entered the race to succeed him. In the Republican primary election, he faced former Maryland Insurance Commissioner , whom he defeated with 61 percent of the vote.\n\n\nJennings was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 12, 2011. He served as a member of the Health and Environmental Affairs Committee from 2011 to 2015, afterwards serving in the Finance Committee until 2023, when he was assigned to the Budget and Taxation Committee. In November 2014, after Senate minority leader  was defeated in the Republican primary election, Senate Republicans voted to elect Jennings as the next minority leader. In this capacity, he pushed for legislation introduced by Governor , which were generally business-friendly and against tax increases. Jennings served in this position until October 2020, when he opted against running for reelection.\n\n at Ropewalk, 2023]]\nDuring the annual Maryland Association of Counties conference in , Jennings hosts an annual \"gathering in the sand\" at the Ropewalk restaurant. The bipartisan gathering has become one of the most popular events during the annual conference.\n\nJennings was a delegate to the , pledged to businessman . In an interview with ''The Baltimore Sun'' following , he said that he was \"neutral\" in the presidential election and held concerns about Trump and his communication style, but said he would support him as the party's nominee.\n\n\nJennings is married to his wife, Michelle Slusher. Together, they have two children and live in . In 2000, Jennings won in the  after reeling in a 158-pound shark, for which he was awarded $6,500.\n\nIn 2008, Jennings lost  to enlist in the Maryland Air National Guard.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2009 legislative session, Jennings introduced legislation to allow farmers to sell  to consumers who buy a \"cow share\".\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Jennings voted against overriding Governor 's veto of a bill that prevented businesses from asking job applicants about their criminal history before the first in-person interview. He also introduced a bill that would allow the governor to declare a  in Baltimore amid its high crime rates.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Jennings was one of five Republicans to vote for a bill to provide $1 billion toward renovations to .\n\nIn March 2017, Jennings launched a  against a bill to prohibit the state from using vouchers to improve struggling schools, during which he attempted to read off every page of the Every Student Succeeds Act. The filibuster was ended by Senate Democrats after an hour.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Jennings opposed a bill that would restore control over school calendars to local boards of education, overturning an earlier executive order by Governor  that mandated a post- start for school districts.\n\nIn September 2019, Jennings expressed concern with the Blueprint for Maryland's Future Funding Formula Workgroupwhich was tasked with developing funding formulas for local school systemswas creating its formulas behind closed doors, saying that it would make people \"lose trust in government\". During the 2020 legislative session, he initially said that he would be willing to negotiate the education reforms proposed in the  and vowed to oppose any potential tax increases to pay for the reforms, but later said that legislators should delay passing the bill into the next year amid uncertainty with the . During debate on the bill, he introduced an amendment to minimize student-to-teacher ratios in public schools, which was adopted by the Senate.\n\n\nJennings supports the expansion of gambling in Maryland, but voted against a bill in 2007 to create a statewide referendum on establishing casinos at five locations in the state, which he called \"the hardest vote\" he ever had to take.\n\n\nJennings opposes gun control laws, instead preferring reforms to mental health services.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, after a student was suspended for two days for making a gun-shaped pastry, Jennings introduced a bill to ban schools from suspending children who make gun gestures. He also opposed the Firearm Safety Act, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s, and attended a rally outside the  to protest the legislation.\n\nIn 2019, after a staff member was shot inside , Jennings introduced a bill to allow s to carry guns inside school buildings.\n\n\nJennings supports providing full funding for the state's trauma care system, saying that he would put \"everything on the table\", including raising taxes, to increase funding for the services. He supports the  and voted to legalize  in 2014.\n\nIn 2018, Jennings supported a bill to impose a new tax on health insurers to help stabilize the state's .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Jennings supported a bill banning medical debt collection agencies from garnishing the wages or placing s on homes of people who owed medical debt, and limiting payments made toward medical debt at five percent of a person's income.\n\n\nDuring the 2006 legislative session, Jennings voted to overturn a committee vote to kill a bill proposing an amendment to the  to ban . The measure failed in a 61–78 vote. In 2012, he voted against the , which legalized same-sex marriage in Maryland. In 2019, during debate on a bill to allow residents to apply to a  with the \"X\" gender identifier, Jennings expressed concern that the bill would cause confusion for police officers.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Jennings expressed skepticism toward proposals to adopt automatic voter registration in Maryland. In June 2020, he wrote a letter to the Maryland State Board of Elections following Maryland's June 2 primary election, which was conducted largely using , to express concern about potential  if mail-in ballots were used in the general election.\n\nIn 2018, Jennings criticized legislation to repeal \"\" as the state's official anthem as a \"participation trophy bill\", instead favoring a bill to replace the anthem's controversial pro- lyrics. During debate on the bill, he introduced an amendment to remove the bill's preamble, which called the song's lyrics \"controversial, inappropriate, and do not represent the ideals and values of Marylanders today\", which was rejected in a 25–21 vote.\n\n\nJennings has described himself as a \"guy who hates taxes\". During the 2015 legislative session, he supported proposals by Governor  to repeal  and to create tax exemptions for businesses and retired service members.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Jennings supported legislation to repeal a law that required the state to use a scoring system to decide which transportation projects to prioritize, arguing that the system would cause urban transit projects to be prioritized over rural road projects.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Erek Lawrence Barron''' (born 1974) is an American attorney and politician serving as the  since 2021. He is a former member of the  from the .\n\n\nBarron was born in , and attended the  in . In 1996, he graduated from the  with a Bachelor of Arts degree in English. Three years later, he earned a  from the  and was admitted to the Maryland Bar the same year. He later earned a Master of Laws, with a focus on International Law and National Security Law, from . \n\n\nBarron has worked for the Maryland law firm of Whiteford, Taylor & Preston and is a member of the . Barron is a former prosecutor and has worked as an assistant state's attorney for Prince George's County and Baltimore City (2001–2006), a trial attorney in  (2006–2007), and counsel and policy advisor to the  and Senator  (2007–2009).\n\n\nBarron first won election to the  in 2014. He was sworn into office on January 14, 2015. In 2015, he and three other male legislators joined the Women's Legislators of Maryland Caucus, becoming the first men to join a women's caucus in the .\n\nIn 2019,   appointed Barron to chair the Joint Committee on Fair Practices. In this capacity, he investigated the circumstances surrounding the $238,250  paid to , the former director of the Maryland Environmental Service and the chief of staff of Governor . Barron later recused himself from the McGrath case after becoming U.S. attorney, citing his role in the investigation.\n\n\n* Co-chair, Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight, 2019–2021\n* Member, Health and Government Operations Committee, 2015–2021 (health facilities & occupations subcommittee, 2015–2016; government operations & long-term care subcommittee, 2015–2017; estates & trusts subcommittee, 2016–2017; government operations & estates & trusts subcommittee, 2017–2019; public health & minority health disparities subcommittee, 2017–2021; government operations & health facilities subcommittee, 2020–2021)\n* Member, Legislative Policy Committee, 2020–2021\n\n\n (left) and Governor  (right), 2022]]\nOn July 26, 2021, Barron was nominated to be the United States attorney for the District of Maryland. On September 23, 2021, his nomination was reported out of committee by . On September 30, 2021, his nomination was confirmed in the  by . On October 7, 2021, he was sworn into office by Chief Judge . He is Maryland's first  U.S. attorney.\n\nOn August 24, 2022, Barron announced a $3.5 million plan for addressing violent crime in Baltimore, which included new hires for the office's violent and organized crime section and pursuing repeat violent offenders \"for any and all wrongdoing that meets our priorities, especially fraud.\"\n\n\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Barron pushed for the Justice Reinvestment Act to include a repeal of  sentencing laws. In March, the House Judiciary Committee voted 17–3 to adopt the \"Barron-Wilson amendment\" repealing mandatory minimums for nonviolent drug offenders while increasing penalties for leaders of gangs and . He also introduced legislation to prohibit  and  from including questions about criminal history on their applications.\n\nIn August 2016, Barron and four other state legislators sent a joint letter to   to review the constitutionality of setting bail without considering whether a defendant could afford to pay under the . The Attorney General's office responded to the letter in October by issuing an opinion stating that such a system was a possible violation of . In November, the Standing Committee on Rules of Practice and Procedure of the  voted 18–5 to recommend a policy change to prohibit Maryland judges from setting bail that is too high for defendants to pay unless the defendant is considered a flight risk or a danger to society. In February 2017, the Court of Appeals voted unanimously to adopt the rule change. During the 2017 legislative session, Barron sought to enshrine the court rule change into law.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Barron introduced legislation to ease the process for prosecutors looking to overturn convictions deemed to be tainted or unjust. The bill passed and became law. He also introduced a bill to require county jails to provide addiction screening, counseling, and treatment with the use of , , and . The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor  on May 13, 2019.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Barron introduced legislation to ease restrictions on when prosecutors could use  in cases of , and another bill to designate witness intimidation a crime of violence.\n\n\nIn April 2019, Barron and   launched \"Biden for Maryland\", becoming the first two Maryland lawmakers to endorse his bid for president.\n\n\nIn May 2016, Barron and  released a list of Metro reform proposals, including ideas involving dedicated funding, the make-up of the  board, and vendors in stations to boost revenue. During the 2018 legislative session, he introduced legislation to raise the state's annual contribution to Metro by $125 million a year if  and the  agreed to do the same.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kathy Szeliga''' (born October 10, 1961) is an American politician who has served as a  member of the  since January 12, 2011, and as Minority Whip from 2013 to 2021. Szeliga was the Republican nominee for the  in  to replace , who retired.\n\n\nSzeliga was born in , , in October 1961. She is of  descent. She was raised in a military family, her father being a  in the . Szeliga married her husband in 1980, and the couple struggled financially at first. Szeliga worked as a dishwasher, a maid, and a housekeeper. She entered college in her 30s, enrolling at  and graduating  with a  degree in elementary education. She began working as a teacher in  and started a construction business with her husband.\n\nSzeliga first got involved with politics in the mid-1990s, organizing opposition against the Maryland School Performance and Assessment Program, a controversial test used to assess schools. She became involved with state politics after a family friend, , was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates. She worked as a legislative aide to Kelly, then for Delegate , and eventually became chief of staff for then-State Senator . She decided to run for Delegate after Del.  decided to run for the State Senate. She was elected and immediately placed on the Appropriations Committee.\n\n\nSzeliga was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2011. She served as a member of the Appropriations Committee from 2011 to 2015, the Transportation Committee from 2015 to 2016, and the Health and Government Operations Committee since 2017. From 2013 to 2021, Szeliga served as the House Minority Whip, making her the highest-ranking elected Republican woman in Maryland. A founding member of the Maryland Freedom Caucus, '''' has described Szeliga as one of the most vocal conservatives in the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nIn May 2024, Szeliga faced criticism after making a  post denouncing a video of \"Queers for Palestine\" protesters blocking a Florida interstate to bring attention to the , writing, \"These 'queers' need a one-way ticket to Gaza to see how  feels about their lifestyle choices.\" In an interview with , Szeliga rejected criticisms that her post was homophobic or anti-LGBTQ, saying that it was meant to be \"informational\".\n\n\nIn June 2018, Szeliga accused state delegate  of sending out campaign mailers attacking Szeliga by calling her a closet . Impallaria initially declined responsibility for this, but after Szeliga emailed him to say she would inform their GOP colleagues about the fliers targeting her, he forwarded the email to every member of the House Republican caucus in which he referred to himself as the \"evil genius\" responsible for the attacks on Szeliga. The calls misleadingly claimed that Szeliga was a supporter of the  and had voted in favor of a bill that would make it illegal to discriminate against someone on the basis of .\n\n\n\nIn February 2022, Szeliga filed a lawsuit against the state's newly enacted congressional maps, arguing that the maps violated the 's requirement that districts be compact and respect natural boundaries. On March 26, 2022, Judge  ruled that the congressional maps were unconstitutional, calling them a \"product of extreme partisan gerrymandering\". Shortly after the ruling, House Speaker  released a statement on Twitter expressing disappointment in the ruling against the maps. Szeliga responded profanely to this statement, in a now-deleted tweet saying \"Bitches!! The court is not gonna like to see that. The seven judges that get to see this and make a final decision will not like this press release. That is even better for us\". She later apologized for the tweet, saying it was intended to be private and was inappropriate.\n\n\n\n\nSzeliga announced in November 2015 that she would be running for the Republican nomination to replace Senator  in the 2016 US Senate election in Maryland. She was the first Republican in the 2016 Senate primary to release ads on television. On April 15,  announced they had bought $25,000 worth of radio airtime to promote Szeliga ahead of the April 26 primary. Szeliga won the primary on April 26, 2016, and faced Representative  in the general election on November 8, 2016, in which she was defeated by a landslide 61% – 36% spread.\n\n\n\nIn April 2020, Szeliga co-signed a letter calling on the  to share data on the 2,000 inmates released during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nIn August 2020, Szeliga condemned Montgomery County Health Officer Travis Gayles's decision to block private schools from holding in-person classes during the pandemic, calling it a \"blatant abuse of power by an unelected bureaucrat\".\n\nIn June 2021, Szeliga celebrated Governor 's decision to end early the $300 supplemental weekly  provided by the .\n\n\nIn 2020, Szeliga introduced a raft of anti-crime bills, including bills that would make gun theft a felony and another requiring individuals incarcerated for violent crimes to serve 90 percent of their term before they're eligible for parole.\n\nIn 2021, Szeliga opposed Anton's Law, a bill that would allow certain officer misconduct records to be available for public inspection, arguing that the bill would allow the disclosure of unfounded claims against police officers. She also opposed the Police Reform and Accountability Act, an omnibus police reform bill.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Szeliga introduced a bill to repeal the Juvenile Justice Reform Act, a bill that was introduced and passed in the previous year's legislative session that restricted the state's ability to charge juveniles for most offenses.\n\n\nIn September 2017, Szeliga joined delegates  and  in signing a letter to Harford County Executive  urging him to stop issuing permits for homes being built in , after an auxiliary men's organization of the  said that its builders would only sell homes in the community to Ahmadi Muslims. Shades and Springs Inc., the company building the homes, denied that they would only sell to Ahmadi Muslims, saying that its homes would be open to all.\n\nIn April 2023, Szeliga wrote to the  to express concerns with a proposal to convert the LaFarge quarry in  into an industrial park, asking the agency to study the property before allowing development.\n\n\nIn March 2019, Szeliga opposed a bill that would allow local school districts to decide their class calendar, which undid an earlier executive order by Governor  that mandated a post- start for schools statewide.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Szeliga introduced a bill to establish a full-time . She also opposed the legislature's veto override of the , calling it \"financially irresponsible\".\n\nIn April 2023, Szeliga sent a letter to State Superintendent Mohammed Choudhury accusing the  of hiding scores from failing scores by altering data files available on the department's website. An investigation conducted by the state inspector general found no evidence of these claims.\n\n\nDuring her Senate campaign, Szeliga was critical of the .\n\n\nIn 2013, Szeliga voted against a bill that banned s and required a person to obtain a license to buy a handgun. In August 2016, during a meeting with gun control activists and gun violence victims, she said she supported stricter enforcement for existing firearms laws but opposed stricter regulations. During the 2018 legislative session, Szeliga introduced the Parishioner Protection Act, a bill that would allow churchgoers to carry firearms. The bill was reintroduced in 2019.\n\n\nDuring her Senate campaign, Szeliga said she opposed the , saying that it hurt small businesses. She did not support its repeal, saying that she instead supported making it more workable. Szeliga also said she supported privatizing parts of medical care provided by the , but opposed a full privatization of the department.\n\nIn April 2023, Szeliga voted against a bill to establish a framework for a legal marijuana industry in Maryland following the passage of , saying she opposed the bill's various provisions in the licensing process and zoning requirements for dispensaries.\n\n\nDuring her Senate campaign, Szeliga said she opposed  on the . During the 2020 legislative session, she introduced a bill that sought to protect Harford County's  agreement with the .\n\nIn February 2021, Szeliga opposed a bill to extend the state's  to undocumented immigrants.\n\n\nSzeliga opposes increases to the minimum wage, calling it a \"short-term fix\" and saying that low-wage earners are more interested in a career than a bump in salary.\n\n\nDuring her Senate campaign, Szeliga said she opposed  over policy disputes.\n\nIn June 2016, Szeliga distanced herself from comments made by then-presumptive Republican presidential nominee  against Judge , a federal judge of Mexican descent, calling them \"insulting\" and \"racist\". In October 2016, she said he was \"appalled\" by . She later endorsed Trump in the . Szeliga also attacked  for her use of a  while serving as .\n\nIn February 2019, Szeliga assisted Maryland  representative  in assembling a \"Trump 2020 Leadership Team\" in Maryland.\n\nIn August 2020, Szeliga joined five other Republican state delegates in signing an  letter against providing additional federal assistance to cash-strapped states and counties, calling it a \"bailout\" for states that haven't managed their fiscal affairs properly.\n\nIn November 2020, Szeliga retweeted posts from House Minority Whip  and a video clip from  that questioned the results of the . In July 2022, Szeliga defended U.S. Representative  after the  said he had met with Trump to discuss a strategy on blocking the results of the presidential election in certain states, comparing it to supporters of  questioning the results of the .\n\nIn May 2024, Szeliga signed onto a letter condemning the jury's guilty verdict in the , calling the ruling a \"political prosecution from a kangaroo court and left-leaning prosecutor\" that is turning the U.S. justice system into a \"third world parody of law and order\".\n\n\nIn January 2018, Szeliga said she opposed a bill to require employers with more than 15 workers to provide employees with paid sick leave, calling it \"overly prescriptive\".\n\n\nIn February 2019, Szeliga supported a proposal to create a 2020 referendum to establish an  in Maryland.\n\n\nSzeliga has repeatedly introduced bills aimed at prohibiting  students from participating in girls' sports teams in schools. In March 2014, she voted against a bill banning discrimination against transgender people, writing that it would \"jeopardize the safety of women and little girls by allowing predators and pedophiles access to the women's bathroom, locker rooms, shower rooms and other similar places.\" During the 2022 legislative session, Szeliga introduced an amendment to the Inclusive Schools Act, a bill to ban public schools and boards of educations from discriminating against students on the basis of sexual orientation, gender identity, or sex, that would have blocked public schools from discussing gender and sexuality in the classroom. The amendment was blocked by a 95-37 vote. This amendment was criticized by the Maryland State Education Association, who likened it to the \"\" law in Florida.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Szeliga introduced a bill with state delegate  that would require legislative sessions to be livestreamed. The bill was withdrawn after House Speaker  and Senate President  said they would begin livestreaming sessions in 2020. On January 30, 2020, the Maryland General Assembly livestreamed its first legislative session on YouTube.\n\nDuring her Senate campaign, Szeliga said she would reject any  nominee that supported abortion rights. In February 2021, she joined state delegates  and  at a protest against abortion outside the . In February 2023, Szeliga said she opposed a bill that would create a  on codifying the right to abortion access, saying that \"Maryland's current abortion laws are radical and should not be enshrined in our constitution\". to Later that month, she proposed an amendment to the bill that would ban late-term abortions.\n\nDuring protests against the  in June 2020, protesters in the  of Baltimore tore down and threw a  into the  canal of the . Following this incident, Szeliga called to protect the statue, calling its removal \"shameful\".\n\nIn March 2021, Szeliga opposed a bill to remove \"\" as the official state song, likening the bill to .\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Szeliga introduced the \"Commonsense Tax Cut Act of 2019\", a bill to lower the state's income tax rate by 0.25%. The tax cut would have cost the state an estimated $400 million.\n\nIn March 2021, Szeliga introduced an amendment to eliminate taxes on  and  services.\n\nIn March 2022, Szeliga called on Governor  to provide $1,000 in tax relief to every Maryland resident. In June 2022, she said she supported a suspension of the state's  for the remainder of the year following the .\n\n\nSzeliga met her future husband, Mark, in  when she was a high schooler. The two moved to  when she was 18, and married in 1980. After the birth of her first child, they moved to . She is an .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Phillip D. Bissett''' (born September 11, 1956), was a member of the , District 30 in  and is a former Republican candidate for  Executive.\n\n\nBissett was appointed to replace the late  in the  in 1991. He served until 1999 when he was defeated by  for his seat in  District 30.\n\n\nBissett attended .  After high school he attended .\n\n\nBissett has been active in the  for many years.  Prior to serving as State Delegate in the , he was a member of the County Executive's Transition Team for Anne Arundel County in 1990. He has also served on the State Commission on the Capital City and the South County Environmental Commission.\n\nWhile a member of the House of Delegates, Bissett served on several committees including: the Judiciary Committee from 1991 until 1999 and the Joint Committee on Federal Relations from 1994 until 1999. He was the Chair of the  from  1995 until 1999 and a member of the .  Finally, he was the Maryland Vice-Chair of the  (ALEC) from 1997 until 1999.\n\nSince leaving his elected position, he has served as Director of the Maryland Area Regional Commuter () Train and Commuter Bus Service from 2004 until May 17, 2005. He was a Delegate to the Republican Party National Convention,  and . He was co-chair of the Anne Arundel County  Campaign in 1992. He is a former member of the Anne Arundel County Republican Central Committee and a current member of the Loch Haven Civic Association.  He is a past member of the Young Republicans of Anne Arundel County.\n\nBissett was the  nominee for County Executive in 2002, losing a close race to  despite being outspent 6-to-1. Bissett served as Director of Maryland's  under Governor  until May 17, 2005, when he stepped down. Bissett campaigned for a second try to be County Executive in 2006, again losing a close race to John Leopold by 1.65% of the vote.\n\nBissett has won several awards in his career including Legislator of the Year from the State's Attorneys' Association in 1994 and the Legislator of the Year from the Judiciary Committee of the Maryland Chamber of Commerce in 1997.\n\n\n*'''2002 election for Anne Arundel County Executive'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 30'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 30'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 30'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*, Annapolis Capital, 1/16/2005\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Frank Melvin Conaway Jr.''' (born January 4, 1963) is an American politician who serves as a member of the  representing the .\n\n\nConaway was born in  to Frank M. Conaway Sr., who was a member of the Maryland House of Delegates and later as the clerk of the Baltimore City Circuit Court, and Mary Conaway, who served as the Baltimore Register of Wills. He attended  and later attended  and  from 1980 to 1984, and graduated from  in 1999 with a  degree in business administration.\n\n\nAfter attending Morgan State, Conaway worked for construction firms Monumental Paint Contractors and Allied Bendix Corporation until 1986, when he started his own company, Frank M. Conaway Jr. & Associates Co., and  business F-Dreams, Inc., which Conaway says was bankrupted by the . Afterwards, he worked as a sales representative for various companies, including , from 1989 to 2005.\n\nIn 1992, Conaway and his father accused Olan Mills of firing them after Conaway Sr. caught the company using a secret racial code to alert employees when they were scheduled to work at Black churches, which the company used to steer the Conaways away from more lucrative white parishes. Olan Mills defended their use of racial codes as a \"sales tool so that employees can take in the proper portrait samples for the community we're serving as customers\". Following his firing, Conaway Jr. filed a discrimination complaint with the company.\n\nConaway is the author of the book ''Baptist Gnostic Christian Eubonic Kundalinion Spiritual Ki Do Hermeneutic Metaphysics: The Word: Hermeneutics'' and ''The 20 Pennies a Day Diet Plan''.\n\n\nIn 1999, Conaway unsuccessfully ran for President of the , losing to  in the Democratic primary.\n\nIn 2006, Conaway successfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 40. He was sworn in on January 10, 2007, and has been a member of the Judiciary Committee during his entire tenure.\n\n\nConaway was married to his wife, Latesa Elaine Thomas, and had three childrenFrank III, Kelly, and Lacyndaprior to their divorce in 2006. In 2003, Thomas obtained a domestic violence protective order against Conaway, stating in court documents that he had \"threatened to kill\" her and had \"pushed her face through a back door window\".\n\nAccording to court documents obtained by the '''', Conaway has , for which he has been taking medication.\n\n\nIn late October 2014, Conaway received significant attention after he uploaded more than 50 videos to . In the videos, which were characterised as \"rambling\" and \"bizarre\", he talked about cryptograms in ian carvings, the , talking horses, ,  and . He also wondered if he was a hologram, referred to himself as \"\", advocated his weight loss book ''The 20 Pennies a Day Diet Plan'' by talking about canned chicken, Arizona Diet Green Tea and sugar free hard candies and promoted his other books, ''Trapezium Giza Pyramid Artificial Black Hole Theory'', ''Baptist Gnostic Christian Eubonic Kundalinion Spiritual Ki Do Hermeneutic Metaphysics: The Word: Hermeneutics'' and ''Christian Kundalini Science- Proof of the Soul- Cryptogram Solution of Egyptian Stela 55001- & Opening the Hood of Ra''.\n\nIn a phone interview with '''', Conaway claimed to have deciphered artwork at the  and said that it was \"part of my duties as a Christian\" to try and \"spread the knowledge that I have\". He also talked about , Egyptian Obelisks, the \"\", the  and  and said that he did not \"believe\" in evolution, arguing that \"Darwin [said] that we descended from monkeys... I haven't seen any evidence to say man came from a monkey.\"\n\nThe videos appeared to have been filmed in the  mail room, where he had also worked since being hired as a clerk at the Municipal Post Office by Comptroller Joan Pratt in 2006. In November 2014, he resigned from his City Hall job and took down the videos. They have been preserved by web developer Chris Cook.\n\nDespite widespread mockery and a general election write-in campaign from State Delegate , who had finished fourth in the Democratic primary for the three-seat district (there were no Republican candidates for the district), Conaway was re-elected in the .\n\n\n\nIn August 2010, Conaway used campaign funds to purchase and give away 500 cameras to Baltimore residents to \"snap pictures of crime in progress\".\n\nIn 2013, Conaway voted for a bill to repeal the .\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Conaway introduced legislation requiring the  to investigate any case involving a police-involved death. The bill received an unfavorable committee report. He also introduced a bill that would double max payouts in police brutality cases, which passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn 2016, Conaway introduced a bill that would allow video cameras in criminal sentencing hearings by filing a written request with the clerk of court. The bill received an unfavorable committee report.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Conaway voted for a bill that would allow  to create its own private police force.\n\nIn 2023, Conaway introduced legislation backed by State's Attorney  to increase penalties for illegally carrying a handgun. The bill was later incorporated into the Gun Safety Bill of 2023, which was passed by the  in April, and signed into law by Governor  in May 2023.\n\n\nDuring the 2007 legislative session, Conaway was one of two Democratic state delegates to vote against a bill cutting $500 million from the state budget.\n\nIn 2014, Conaway voted for a bill to raise the state's minimum wage to $10.10 by 2017.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Conaway voted for the Firearm Safety Act, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Conaway voted for the , which legalized same-sex marriage in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Conaway voted for a bill to index the state's es to inflation to pay for state transportation projects.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''Baptist Gnostic Christian Eubonic Kundalinion Spiritual Ki Do Hermeneutic Metaphysics: The Word'', , 2001. \n* ''The 20 Pennies a Day Diet Plan'', , 2004. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Dereck Eugene Davis''' (born June 6, 1967) is an  serving as the  since 2021. A member of the , he previously served as a member of the  from the  from 1995 to 2021.\n\n\nDavis was born in  on June 6, 1967. After graduating from , he attended the , where he earned a  degree in 1989 and his  in 1999.\n\n\nDavis worked as an aide to the  from 1988 to 1994, first as a constituent services aide and later as a legislative aide. In 1993, he was a member of the Prince George's County Nuisance Abatement Task Force. Davis was an administrator of the  from 2004 to 2011, and deputy director of the Prince George's County Office of Community Relations from 2011 to 2021.\n\n\n\nDavis was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in  and sworn in on January 11, 1995. He was a member of the Environmental Matters Committee from 1995 to 2003, afterwards serving as the chair of the Economic Matters Committee until 2021. Davis was the fourth African American to chair a House standing committee in Maryland and the first from . He was also the chair of the  from 2003 to 2005, 2013 to 2014, and from 2017 to 2021; and a member of the .\n\n'''' has described Davis as a  and an ally of Prince George's County Executive . He voted in favor of  in 1999, but later called this vote a mistake. During his tenure as the chair of the Economic Matters Committee, he was involved in negotiations to avert a 72 percent rate increase in  utility costs, which led into a special legislative session after legislators failed to pass a bill during the regular 2006 legislative session and eventually led to a bill that would temporarily cap rate increases to 15 percent and replace the five-member  with regulators selected by the legislature. The bill passed and became law after the Maryland General Assembly voted to override Governor 's veto of the bill.\n\nDavis supported bills to raise the minimum wage, ban smoking in bars and restaurants, repeal the ban on developer contributions to Prince George's County candidates, and many of Governor 's legislative priorities. He also defended  from criticism from the Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland, saying that Democrats should focus on electing more progressives to the  instead of making elections for incumbents \"as easy as possible\", and opposed bills to legalize  and offer  to terminally-ill patients.\n\nIn September 2008, Davis was questioned by the  in its investigation into whether state senator , who worked as a consultant for , used his position to push for bills that would benefit the grocery store chain. Davis testified before a  in the Currie probe in May 2009, during which he spoke on an amendment introduced by Currie during the 2005 legislative session to transfer a beer-and-wine license from a Shopper's store in  to one in . Currie and two Shopper's executives were charged with extortion and bribery charges, but were acquitted after a six-week trial in 2011, after which Davis ran on a slate with Currie in 2014.\n\nIn April 2019, Following the funeral of House Speaker , Davis announced that he would run for . His candidacy was backed by Prince George's County Executive , the Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland, and . He was also backed by , who also declared her candidacy for Speaker but dropped out of the race after failing to capture enough support. On May 1, 2019, Davis and , who was competing with Davis in the Speaker election, both agreed to withdraw from the race and back Jones after a four-hour, closed-door Democratic caucus meeting on the day of the election. Davis would have been the first African-American Speaker of the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\n\n\nOn April 15, 2015, after U.S. representative  announced that she would , Davis announced that he would run for the  in . During the Democratic primary, he received endorsements from more than a dozen members of the  and county councilmember Derrick Leon Davis, and raised about $464,000 in campaign contributions. Davis dropped out of the race on February 2, 2016, to focus on the legislative session.\n\n\n, 2023]]\nIn October 2021, Davis confirmed he would run for  following the retirement of .  elected Davis as the next state treasurer on December 9, 2021. He was sworn in on December 17, becoming the first state treasurer from , and the second African-American to hold the position, after . During his tenure, Davis has placed additional scrutiny onto contracts with inadequate participation from historically disadvantaged business owners and raised concerns about settlements involving law enforcement agencies or correctional officers.\n\nIn December 2022, administrators of Maryland's  discovered a calculation error affecting all 31,000 prepaid accounts, which led to the Maryland Prepaid College Trust suspending interest payments and preventing families from accessing their prepaid plans. After being re-elected as treasurer in February 2023, Davis asked legislators to move the 529 program into the treasurer's office, which led to legislative leaders introducing a bill to do so. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor  on April 24, 2023. In July 2023, the treasurer's office restored interest earned to the same rates account owners held under their previous contract and that all balances or contributions made after July 2024 would not earn interest.\n\nIn June 2023, '''' reported that Davis was continuing to raise funds for his campaign account as state treasurer, which he said was to stay \"prepared\" for the future and that he had no plans to leave his position. He continued to raise funds during the 2024 legislative session, during which he supported a bill that would add the state treasurer to the list of state officials that were prohibited from raising campaign funds while the legislature was in session. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Moore.\n\nDavis was an at-large delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\nDavis is married to his wife, Monique Whittington Davis, who served as deputy superintendent of  from 2013 to 2018. Together, they have a son and a daughter.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
