    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert L. Flanagan''' (born November 1, 1945) was the Secretary of the  from 2003 until 2007, under the administration of Governor . Prior and subsequent to this position, Flanagan served in the . He was first elected to office in 1987 and served with fellow Republican, , until 2002, when the districts were redrawn and he would move to District 14B.\n\n\nFlanagan was born in , the son of Bernard Lawrence Flanagan (1919-1970) and Margaret (Sawyer) Flanagan. When Flanagan was young, his father was employed on the staff of U.S. Senator  in \n\nFlanagan attended  in  After high school he attended , where he earned his A.B. in economics in 1967. Flanagan attended , where he was a member of the Cornell Law Review, Order of Coif and published The Rights of Handicapped Children to an Education 59 Cornell L.R. 519(1974), earning his J.D. in 1974.\n\nHis younger brother, , also entered politics, but as a , serving as the  from 1993 - 2001 and in the  from 2005 - 2011.\n\n\nAfter college, Flanagan joined the  and earned the rank of lieutenant. He served aboard the , , from 1967 until 1971.\n\nAfter his stint in the navy, Flanagan obtained his  from . He was admitted to the bar in 1974 and began practicing law. He practiced law for 28 years.\n\nIn 1987, Flanagan began his political career by being elected to the , representing District 14B, which covered parts of  and . Districts were later redrawn, and Flanagan was elected into his new district of 9A, which was solely in Howard County. As a Republican member in the heavily Democratic House of Delegates, Flanagan served the role as Minority Whip from 1997 until 2001.\n\nBeing a Republican in the Maryland General Assembly leaves Flanagan little chance to serve as a chair on any committees. However, Flanagan was able to chair the Howard County Delegation from 1991 until 1996. Moreover, Flanagan was a high-ranking Republican on many committees, such as the Judiciary Committee (1987–1990), the Joint Audit Committee (1987–1992, 1995-2003), the Appropriations Committee (1991-2003), the Legislative Policy Committee (1997-2002), and the Rules and Executive Nominations Committee (1997-2002).\n\nIn the 2002 gubernatorial election, Republican  defeated Democrat  to become the first Republican  since  in 1969. Governor Ehrlich appointed Flanagan to . In this position, Flanagan managed the , , the , the various transportation entities, such as the , the , the , and the .\n\nDuring Flanagan's tenure as Secretary from 2003 to 2007, Maryland obtained approval under the  to begin construction of the  as a state of the art, congestion managed highway by developing a new environmentally sensitive design after two prior rejections by the EPA in 1983 and 1997. Maryland also began building its first s on  north of Baltimore; constructed the  terminal at Baltimore Washington International Airport; and planned and constructed a new cruise ship terminal in Baltimore off of I-95. The Baltimore region's bus routes and fixed transit service were reorganized for people with disabilities, resulting in  of a lawsuit by the Maryland Disability Law Center citing long standing deficiencies.\n\nIn 2006, , , defeated Bob Ehrlich in the gubernatorial election, thus ending Flanagan's tenure as the Secretary of Transportation. Flanagan was replaced by  , who was the Secretary during the administration of the previous governor, .\n\nFrom 2007 to 2009, Flanagan was a Senior Vice President with First Southwest Company, advising state and local governments regarding public private partnerships for transportation. He has been a speaker on this topic in various forums including the , Study Group on Transportation Infrastructure. In 2009, Flanagan co-authored \"Emerging Trends in Surface Transport Concessions s in the U.S.\" which was published in Investing in Infrastructure, a comprehensive research source on infrastructure funds, investment techniques, and financing challenges in the world's diverse market by PEI Media Ltd.\n\nFlanagan is a practicing attorney in , focusing on business representation, litigation, government matters, and procurement law.\n\nFlanagan was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in 2014, representing District 9B. Flanagan serves on the Environment and Transportation Committee.\n\nIn November 2018, Flanagan ran for re-election in District 9B and lost to his opponent Courtney Watson (D). Thus ending his long tenure as a public servant in the House of Delegates.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ruth M. Kirk''' (February 2, 1930 – June 17, 2011) was an  who represented the 44th legislative district in the . She was elected 7 times and served a total of 28 years representing west and west central .\n\n\nBorn Ruth Simmons in Baltimore, Delegate Kirk was the fifth of eight children. She attended Baltimore City public schools through the ninth grade and later received a . Prior to being elected to The Maryland General Assembly, Kirk held jobs as a house cleaner and in early childhood education. In 1970, Kirk took a job at , working as a teacher's aide.\n\n\nKirk was first elected in 1982 and sworn in as a member of House of Delegates on January 12, 1983. She was appointed to the Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee and served on it until its elimination in 1990. She was then appointed to the Economic Matters Committee where she served until 2011. There, she served on its deathcare industry work group; workers' compensation subcommittee, 1995–2003; real estate & housing subcommittee, 1999–2003; business regulation subcommittee, 2003–11; property & casualty insurance subcommittee, 2003–06). During her career in the legislature, Kirk also served as a member of the  Tort and Insurance Reform Oversight Committee, 1993;  the House Facilities Committee, 1993–2011; the Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 1999–2004; the Protocol Committee, 2007–11, the Liaison Work Group of the , the  (formerly Maryland Black Caucus), 1983-2011 (member, nominating committee, 2000–11, redistricting committee, 2000–11; past chair, budget committee; past treasurer), the Women Legislators of Maryland, 1983-2011 (president, 1994); the Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2006–11, and the National Black Caucus of State Legislators. Outside of the legislature she was a member of the National Order of Women Legislators; and the  (economic development, transportation & cultural affairs committee, 2005–11; fiscal affairs & government operations committee, 2005–11).\n, Kirk,  and  during a floor session in the Maryland House in February 1984.]]\n\n\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax by 20% - Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* voted in favor of prohibiting ground rents in 2007(SB106)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 44th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:''' (only the top 6 finishers are shown)\n:\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 44th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n at the Ruth Kirk Community Centre in August 2022]]\nShe died in 2011. Her son, Art Kirk, created a recreation center in her honor called the Ruth M. Kirk Recreation and Learning Center and Community Garden.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| children            = 4\n| signature           = Ariana Kelly signature.svg\n}}\n'''Ariana Brannigan Kelly''' (born December 7, 1976) is an American politician who is the executive director of the Maryland Commission for Women. She was a member of the  from , which is located in , from 2023 to 2024. A member of the , she previously represented the same district in the  from 2011 to 2023.\n\n\nKelly was born in . She is the granddaughter of Maryland fire safety pioneer . Kelly graduated from , and later attended the , where in 2002 she earned a  degree in history.\n\nAfter graduating, Kelly worked as a national judicial education program associate for the . She also worked as a producer for ' '''', a weekly news program, from 2002 to 2005, before becoming the executive director of . Kelly worked as the national campaign director for MomsRising.org from 2009 to 2011.\n\n\nKelly was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 12, 2011. She was a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee, including as its vice chair from 2022 to 2023, during her entire tenure and served as deputy majority whip from 2016 to 2023. Kelly also served as the president of the Women Legislators of Maryland caucus from 2017 to 2018, and as the House chair of the Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families from 2016 to 2022.\n\nIn December 2022, Governor-elect  nominated state senator  to serve as the . Kelly filed to fill the vacancy left by Lee in the  in January 2023. During her 2023 Senate appointment, it was alleged that she called one of the other candidates and harassed him for submitting his nomination for the appointment. Kelly denied the allegations. The Montgomery County Central Committee Chair indicated that the allegations were outside their purview for addressing. Kelly won the nomination by a vote of 24–0 with one abstention. She was sworn in on February 27, 2023, and served on the Judicial Proceedings Committee during her entire tenure.\n\nOn March 20, 2024, Governor Moore appointed Kelly to serve as the executive director of the Maryland Commission for Women. She resigned from the legislature following the 2024 legislative session on May 5, 2024, and assumed her new role on May 6, 2024.\n\n\n\n\n'''' has described Kelly as a \"leading abortion rights supporter in the legislature\". In 2019, , which supports abortion, gave Kelly a 100% score. , which opposes abortion, gave Kelly a 6% score during her third term in the Maryland House of Delegates. Kelly supported efforts led by House of Delegates Speakers  and  to codify the right to abortion access in the , and said in September 2021 that the \"time is right for the legislature to pass more progressive policies\" on abortion following the passage of the , which banned abortions in Texas after the .\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Kelly introduced the Contraceptive Equity Act, a bill that would require insurance companies to cover over-the-counter emergency contraceptives at no extra cost. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor  in May 2016.\n\nIn January 2019, Kelly was one of nine Maryland lawmakers to add their names to a manifesto signed by 326 state legislators to reaffirm their commitment to protecting abortion rights.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Kelly introduced a package of bills to ensure abortion access and affordability in Maryland, including the Abortion Care Access to Insurance Act and the Abortion Care Access Act. The Abortion Care Access Act was passed by the Maryland General Assembly and vetoed by Governor , but it became law after the Maryland General Assembly overrode Hogan's veto. In May 2022, following the leak of a draft majority opinion for the  case '''', Kelly joined 82 other legislators in signing a letter pushing Hogan to release $3.5 million in funding to support the implementation of the Abortion Care Access Act.\n\nIn June 2022, following the Supreme Court's ruling in ''Dobbs'', Kelly said that the end of '''' made strong laws on the state level \"even more necessary\".\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Kelly introduced legislation that would require public colleges to have a plan for student access to birth control, including contraception and abortion pills.\n\n\nIn November 2023, Kelly and eight other state senators signed a joint letter that threatened to defund immigrants rights group  because it had called for an immediate ceasefire in the  and condemned the \"utilization of US tax dollars to promote the ongoing violence.\"\n\n\nDuring the 2016 and 2020 legislative sessions, Kelly introduced legislation to provide Maryland workers with up to 12 weeks of , funded by a  shared equally by the worker and employer. In 2022, she introduced a bill that would provide paid family leave to all part- and full-time employees who have worked 680 hours in the past year.\n\n\n rally, 2024]]\nIn February 2018, Kelly, then the president of the Women's Caucus of Maryland, released a set of policy recommendations on preventing sexual harassment in the . These recommendations were accompanied by a report detailing anonymous accounts of sexual harassment in the Maryland General Assembly. Kelly also introduced a bill aimed at implementing these policy recommendations, which was passed and signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Kelly introduced a bill that would include the topic of \"consent\" in sex education classes. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn September 2018, after  was elected to lead the , Kelly accused Glenn of blocking her efforts to assist one of 's alleged sexual misconduct victims and of denigrating other Anderson accusers. Glenn did not comment on these accusations.\n\n\nIn 2013, Kelly voted in favor of a bill that would raise es in Maryland to fund the state's various mass transit projects.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Kelly introduced a bill to expand eligibility requirements for the state's child care tax credits. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nKelly has two children and two step-children. She was married to Barak Sanford from 1999 to November 2012, and later married Stephen Taylor, the owner of Family Back & Neck Care in , in 2022. Together, they live in .\n\nIn July 2015, Kelly was charged with  and trespassing in an incident related to a domestic dispute. According the police report, Kelly was dropping her two children off at her ex-husband's house when she learned that his fianceé was in the residence at the time. She then exposed her breasts in his direction, which he had captured on his cellphone camera. Kelly later called the dispute that led to her arrest a \"domestic quabble\" rather than a criminal manner. Her charges were dropped later that month, with a spokesperson for Montgomery County State's Attorney John McCarthy saying that the incident was \"a matter better suited for family court\" and that the indecent exposure charges were incorrectly applied.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She served 6 terms in the , representing Maryland's District 21 in  &  Counties.\n\n\nFrush was born in  and attended  in .\n\n\nFrush was first elected in 1994, serving 6 four-year terms from 1995 to 2019. From 2007 to 2008, Frush was the Chair of the .\n\nFrush declined to run again in the , instead working on 's campaign for the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Christopher Eric Bouchat''' (born October 2, 1967) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for , which encompasses . He was previously a member of the Carroll County Board of Commissioners from 2018 to 2022, representing District 4 in southwest Carroll County.\n\n\nBouchat graduated from St. Augustine's Catholic School (now St. Augustine Elementary School) and . He attended the Howard Vocational-Technical Center, where he earned a welding certificate, , where he earned a degree in business administration, and the , where he earned a degree in political science. Bouchat worked as a welder with Patrick Aircraft Tank Systems in , before starting his own welding business in 1994.\n\n\nBouchat first became involved in politics in 1992, when he ran for the  in . In 1994, he unsuccessfully ran for the  in , receiving 37 percent of the vote in the Republican primary.\n\nFrom 2003 to 2004, Bouchat served on the Baltimore County Republican Central Committee.\n\nIn 2006, Bouchat ran for the Carroll County Board of Commissioners, challenging the three incumbent Republican commissioners. He once again ran for the Carroll County Board of Commissioners in 2010.\n\nIn October 2013, Bouchat filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in , seeking to succeed outgoing state delegate . Bouchat was the top vote-getter in the Carroll County part of the district, but lost the primary to  Republicans  and , both of whom went on to win the general election.\n\n, 2019]]\nIn 2018, Bouchat ran for the Carroll County Board of Commissioners in District 4, seeking to succeed outgoing county commissioner Richard Rothschild. He won the Republican primary in June, receiving 44.1 percent of the vote. He defeated  Paul Johnson in the general election, receiving 65.5 percent of the vote, and was sworn in on December 4, 2018. On July 26, 2019, Bouchat announced that he would not seek re-election to a second term in 2022.\n\nIn March 2020, Bouchat expressed interest in running for the Maryland General Assembly. In December, Bouchat filed to fill a vacancy in the Maryland House of Delegates that was left vacant by the resignation of state delegate Warren Miller. His candidacy was endorsed by former state delegates  and . On January 6, 2021, fellow candidate  was selected to fill the rest of Miller's term. In 2022, Bouchat filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 9A, but was later redrawn into District 5. Bouchat won the Republican primary on July 20, receiving 12.1 percent of the vote. He ran unopposed in the general election.\n\n\nIn 2012, Bouchat filed a lawsuit challenging the state's legislative redistricting plan, in which he pleaded to the  to establish a new legislative body that would have each county represented by two state senators and for the county's population to determine its number of state delegates, each belonging to a . The Court of Appeals issued an order upholding the state's redistricting plan, denying Bouchat's arguments against it. In January 2013, Bouchat appealed the case by filing a  to the . The Supreme Court denied the petition on April 15.\n\nIn early 2015, Bouchat filed a lawsuit in the Carroll County Circuit Court challenging the state's legislative redistricting plan, which was dismissed after the judge determined that the court did not have jurisdiction over the matter. In August 2015, Bouchat again filed a lawsuit challenging the state's legislative redistricting plan, blaming the composition of District 9A for his loss in the 2014 elections.\n\n\nBouchat was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Judiciary Committee. Bouchat does not intend to run for re-election in , instead expressing interest in a run for statewide office.\n\nIn February 2023, Bouchat, a member of the Frederick County Delegation, said that he would not vote or make any motions during the delegation's weekly meetings. In an email to '''', he said that delegation members who represent districts mostly in  or Carroll counties were in violation of a  ruling if they voted in Frederick County Delegation meetings. Only 2.6 percent of  residents, or about 3,500 people, live in . In 1995, an opinion from the  stated that county delegations are \"not subject to the 'one-person/one-vote' requirement\" of the  of the .\n\nIn March 2023, Bouchat sent a letter to his House Republican colleagues in which he questioned their tactics during floor debates, asserting that they were being too performative during floor debates and urging them to \"look inward for corrective measures that increase our future success rates\". Later that week, six of the most vocal members of the House Republican Caucus released a letter criticizing Bouchat's comments, arguing that the party was able to reach its 50-seat minority in  by speaking out against Democratic taxes and spending. Bouchat agreed that Republicans should contest Democrats in the 2026 legislative elections, but said \"we need to stop annoying them\" until then.\n\n\nBouchat divorced his first wife, Carmelita Seda-Carothers, in 1997, defending himself in court during the divorce proceedings. That same year, Bouchat was convicted of second-degree assault in a domestic abuse with Seda-Carothers. In July 2007, he divorced his second wife, April Elizabeth Shook, who claimed that Bouchat had physically and verbally assaulted her as they sought their divorce. Her abuse claims were thrown out by Judge Thomas Stansfield after no evidence proving the abuse could be produced. In September, Bouchat filed a lawsuit against Shook, charging her claim that he had physically abused her destroyed his campaign.\n\nIn February 2014, the  placed a $42,526 tax lien on Bouchat, which was the result of embezzlement by his daughter, Tawni Bouchat, whom he had employed as a bookkeeper at his own business. The lien led him to initiate criminal charges against Tawni for stealing $21,120 from his company, which she was found guilty of in January 2015. In November 2018, after winning election to the Carroll County Board of Commissioners, Bouchat settled the tax lien by paying $13,000 to the IRS.\n\nTawni Bouchat died of a  in 2017, which he says \"threw me into a depression, it threw me into alcoholism, so I always advise people out there when you've suffered a loss of someone very close you are extremely vulnerable to become an addict yourself.\"\n\n\n\nIn April 2020, Bouchat voted against closing the Northern Landfill in  for 15 days to reduce risk of spreading . Later that month, he voted to reopen the landfill early with reduced hours and restrictions preventing residents outside the county from using it.\n\nIn June 2020, Bouchat attended and spoke at a Reopen Maryland rally in Westminster to protest the state's COVID-19 restrictions. At the rally, he suggested allowing businesses to set their own policies on when people need to wear masks. In July 2020, he wrote an op-ed for the '''' that questioned the value of wearing masks in public. His remarks on the COVID-19 pandemic were criticized by Robert Wack, the deputy health officer for the Carroll County Health Department, who wrote in a letter to the '''' later that month that Bouchat's \"dangerously ignorant opinions are a direct threat to the health and well-being of the county\".\n\nIn August 2021, Bouchat suggested that the Board of Commissioners boycott the annual  Summer Conference over its , saying that he had cancelled his attendance to the event after learning about the policy. He later told '''' that he did not oppose masks or vaccines, but opposed mandates. In December 2021, Bouchat was the only commissioner to vote against instituting a modified mask policy at Carroll County government facilities, which required unvaccinated county government employees to wear a mask while indoors. In February 2022, Bouchat declined to attend the State of the County address at the Carroll Arts Center, which was attended by all other county commissioners, because of its indoor mask-wearing requirement. He instead opted to protest outside the building by handing out copies of a written speech to those walking in.\n\n\nIn July 2019, Bouchat introduced a bill that would place a question on the 2020 ballot that, if approved, would change Carroll County's form of government from a commission to a . After the Board of Commissioners voted to hold off on discussions on converting to a charter government, Bouchat announced that he would not seek re-election to a second term as county commissioner in 2022. In November 2020, Bouchat voted to pass a resolution that would establish a nine-member committee to write a charter; the resolution failed to pass in a 2-3 vote.\n\nIn January 2021, Bouchat recused himself as a non-voting member of the county's Planning and Zoning Commission, and soon after filed motions to eliminate the non-voting positions from the county's Board of Education and Planning and Zoning Commission.  Both motions failed to gain a second and were not voted upon.\n\n\nIn September 2022, Bouchat said he supported a constitutional amendment to the  establishing a 188-member  to draw Maryland's congressional and legislative maps, with each of its members elected proportionally to a county's population and in s.\n\n\nIn June 2020, Bouchat joined a  protest in Westminster. Later that month, he proposed creating a heritage commission to recognize the history and achievements of African Americans in Carroll County.\n\nIn February 2022, Bouchat distributed copies of a printed speech at the annual State of the County address, in which he wrote that he believed that the board of commissioners would benefit from not being made up of \"old Caucasian males,\" calling on women to \"step up and take control of our local government\".\n\n\nIn 2016, Bouchat ran as an unaffiliated candidate to the  in . He said that he would vote for  on the first ballot if the voters sent him to the Convention, and hoped that Trump would pick  as his running mate.\n\nIn January 2021, Bouchat condemned the  and compared the presidential transition to what happens with the Board of Commissioners:\n\n\nIn 2022, Bouchat endorsed former   for .\n\n\nIn March 2023, Bouchat voted against an amendment that would remove a provision that indexed the state's  to the . The amendment failed by a 38-90 vote, with Bouchat being the only House Republican to vote against it.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Tawanna Phyllis Gaines''' (February 1, 1952 – November 12, 2022) was an  who represented  in the  from December 2001 to October 2019. She resigned in the face of federal corruption charges and in 2020 was sentenced to six months in prison.\n\n\nGaines was born in Washington, DC, on February 1, 1952. She attended , 1970-72.\n\n\nGaines had been a member of House of Delegates since December 21, 2001 when she was appointed by  to fill the vacancy of Richard Palumbo who himself had been appointed judge to the District Court of Maryland for Prince George's County. She was appointed by  to be Deputy Majority Whip in 2003. She served on the House Appropriations Committee and was the Chairwoman of the Appropriations Sub Committee on Transportation and the Environment, in addition to the capital budget subcommittees. She was also a member of the .\n\nGaines resigned from the legislature on October 4, 2019 and on October 7 was charged with federal wire fraud for using over $22,000 of campaign money for personal use. Her daughter and campaign treasurer subsequently pled guilty in November 2019 to wire fraud, admitting using campaign funds for personal use. On January 3, 2020, Gaines was sentenced to six months in prison for one count of wire fraud.\n\n\n*voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n*voted against slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n*voted for the Tax Reform Act of 2007 (HB2)\n\n\nGaines died from  on November 12, 2022, at the age of 70.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ronald L. Watson''' (born April 30, 1966) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2021. A member of the , he previously represented  in the  from 2019 to 2021, and served on the  from 2006 to 2010.\n\n\nWatson was born in  on April 30, 1966. His parents were both retired school principals. Watson graduated from  and attended , where he earned a  degree in electrical engineering in 1991; , where he earned a  degree in advanced technology in 1993 and a  degree in systems science in 1999; and , where he earned a  degree in 2002. He is a member of the  fraternity.\n\n\n\nWatson served in the  from 1989 to 2006, during which he worked as a program manager at , , and MCR. He graduated from the  in 2004. Since 2004, Watson has owned his own business, Watson Management Corporation.\n\nIn 2006, Watson was elected to the Prince George's County Board of Education. He served in this position until 2010. Watson unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 23B in , challenging incumbents  and  He ran for the seat again in , during which he defeated Vallario in a .\n\n\n\nWatson was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. During his tenure, he served on the Judiciary Committee, including its family law and juvenile law subcommittees.\n\nIn August 2021, following the resignation of state Senator , Watson applied to serve the remainder of Peters' term in the Maryland Senate. He was unanimously nominated to the seat by the Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee later that month, and was appointed by Governor  on August 27. Watson was sworn into the Maryland Senate on August 31, and was elected to a full four-year term in the . He was a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee from 2021 to 2023, afterwards serving on the Education, Energy, and the Environment Committee.\n\nIn 2024, Watson applied to run as a delegate to the  pledged to , but was denied by the .\n\n\nWatson is married to his wife, Ingrid Watson, who was elected to the  in 2022. Together, they have three children.\n\n\nIn May 2009, after the  passed legislation to cut funding for the Prince George's County Public Schools system, Watson voted to terminate the county board of education's $11 million lease for a new headquarters.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Watson criticized a bill that would allow couples to file for divorce while living in the same house, noting that it would allow people to file for divorce because of their spouse's inability to have sex due to a medical condition.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Watson introduced legislation creating a statewide referendum on renaming the  to the Supreme Court of Maryland, which passed and was approved by voters in the . He also introduced a bill to eliminate the four appointed positions from the Prince George's County Board of Education and make all elected positions at-large, which died without a vote.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Watson introduced the Climate Equity Act, a bill that would require government agencies to assess the impacts of climate and labor before approving permits or projects, and another bill that would make it illegal to send threats to health officers. He also expressed concerns with proposal to raise the state's eviction notice filing fee from $15 to $65, which he said would penalize small landlords.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Watson introduced legislation to create a statewide referendum on legalizing  and another bill allowing municipalities to establish their own police accountability boards. He also supported a bill to raise sentences for illegal gun possession and make knowingly selling someone a weapon used in a crime a felony offense. He also supported efforts to locate the new 's headquarters in Prince George's County.\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Watson says he plans to introduce legislation that would allow parents to waive the requirement that a child must speak to an attorney before speaking to law enforcement and would require parents and children to complete counseling or substance abuse treatment classes administered by the Maryland Department of Social Services. He also plans to support legislation to extend probationary periods for juveniles found guilty of firearm misdemeanors and felonies.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael D. Smigiel Sr.''' (June 18, 1958 – August 28, 2022) was an American politician who was a member of the , where he represented District 36, which covers , , , and  Counties.  He was first elected in 2002 along with fellow Republicans  and  after the legislative boundaries were redrawn.  Prior to 2002, District 36 had a separate representative for , , and  Counties.  After combining the districts, Smigiel won the seat previously occupied by former  Mayor, .  Crouse was appointed to the seat in July 2001 following Governor Parris Glendenning's appointment of longtime Elkton Delegate Ronald A. Guns to the Public Service Commission.\nIn 2006, he defeated Democratic challenger Mark Guns for reelection.  In the 2006 election, the voting method returned to voting for a representative for each county.\n\n\nSmigiel attended  in .  There he received his A.A. degree in psychology and history in 1982.  After community college, he went to undergraduate school at , where he got his B.A. in political science in 1985.  In 1989, he received his J.D. from . Michael served as president of his law school class.\n\n\nAfter high school, Smigiel served in the  from 1975 until 1979.  After college, Smigiel was admitted to Maryland Bar in 1989 and worked thereafter as an attorney. He was also a member of the Cecil County Bar Association, where he served as chair of the ethics committee and as a member of the board of directors.  He also belonged to the Maryland Association of Justice.\n\nSmigiel was also the founder of Mediation, Inc., and alternative dispute resolution center. He served as a member of the Board of Directors for the Bainbridge Naval Training Center Historical Association, Inc.\n\n\nIn the , Smigiel held the position of Minority Parliamentarian and was on the Judiciary Committee where he was a member of the criminal justice subcommittee and was active on several work-groups. He was previously a Deputy Minority Whip from 2003 to 2006 and a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee. Smigiel served as Vice Chair of the Juvenile subcommittee, and was the Vice Chair of the Eastern Shore Delegation representing the nine counties of the Eastern Shore of Maryland. In addition, Smigiel was the founder and chairperson of the Maryland House of Delegates Tea Party Caucus.\n\n\n* in 2014 Co-Sponsored legislation to cut off the 's water and electricity if the agency continued to collect electronic data without specific warrants.\n* in 2013 Co-Sponsored legislation to require a 2/3rds vote in the General Assembly to raise taxes\n* in 2013 Sponsored a bill to repeal the use of \n* in 2013 Co-Sponsored legislation to impose larger penalties on local governments found to have violated Maryland's \n* in 2012 Co-sponsored bill to require health insurance carriers to provide coverage of  services\n* in 2011 Proposed an amendment to the state constitution to make appropriations subject to petition for a referendum, which are currently exempt under Maryland law\n* in 2010 Co Sponsored a 'Taxpayers Bill of Rights' constitutional amendment which would have required certain new taxes be placed to a popular vote, limited increases in the state budget to the amount of inflation plus annual population increase\n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n\n\nIn 2012, Smigiel was appointed by Maryland legislative leaders to a task force to study the impact of a  ruling regarding the liability of owners of s and landlords that rent to them.\n\n\n\nIn 2016, Smigiel sought the Republican nomination for , challenging incumbent  in the party primary.  Smiegel claimed that he felt \"betrayed\" by Harris and other Republicans, and attacked the incumbent from a conservative position on education, state powers, free markets, and taxation. He was overwhelmingly defeated by Harris.\n\n\nSmigiel died at the age of 64 from a heart disease on August 28, 2022.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36 Cecil County'''\n::'''Voters to choose one per county:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*  (archived)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''William Gregory Wims''' (born September 2, 1949) is an American politician, businessman, and community volunteer who is currently a member of the  from District 39.\n\n\nWims was born in  on September 2, 1949, to mother Rachel Stewart Wims and father Earl Alexandir Wims, a laborer. He was raised in Stewarttown, a historically Black community near , in a home purchased by his ancestors after . Wims graduated from  in 1968, and later attended  until 1970, when he transferred to . He later earned a B.S. degree in political science from the .\n\n\n\nAs of July 2021, Wims has served on over 30 non-profit boards, including , the , and . He is also the founder of the Victims' Rights Foundation and the Sniper Victims' Fund, and has raised over $2 million for various causes.\n\nWims was elected to the Maryland Youth Commission soon after graduating from high school. In this position, Wims supported lowering the  from 21 to 18.\n\nIn the early 1970s, Montgomery County Executive  appointed Wims to the Montgomery County Maryland Human Rights Commission, where he was its youngest member. In 1974, he became the first male  teacher in Montgomery County. In 1976, Wims joined the congressional campaign of U.S. Representative , eventually becoming his chief legislative officer and the first African American from Montgomery County to work on  until 1978. Afterwards, he worked as a legislative assistant to U.S. Representative . In 1980, he worked on the presidential campaign of former California governor , later working in the Reagan administration as a legislative assistant to the , and as the Special Assistant to the Director of Minority Affairs and Economic Development until 1989, when he left to start his own government consulting firm, Hammer and Nails Inc.\n\nIn the early 1990s, Wims served as the membership chairman for the  (NAACP). In 1993, he was elected president of the Montgomery County NAACP, eventually becoming the president of the state NAACP branch in 1995. He was later appointed by President  to serve as a deputy administrator of the  and as a board member of the . From 1997 to 1998, Wims worked as a liaison to Montgomery County's minority community for the . In September 2000, he was named executive director of the Montgomery Business Alliance and membership director of the Montgomery County Chamber of Commerce.\n\nIn January 2000, Wims announced that he would form an exploratory committee to consider a run in the special election for the Montgomery County Council seat in District 1, following the resignation of  councilmember Betty Ann Krahnke.\n\nIn 2018, Wims unsuccessfully ran for the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee in District 15, receiving 42.4 percent of the vote. He later served on the transition team of Montgomery County Executive-elect  in November 2018. In July 2021, Elrich appointed Wims to serve as a director for the Montgomery County Regional Service.\n\n\n\nIn April 2023, Wims applied to fill a vacancy left by the resignation of state delegate  to serve as the Assistant Secretary for Inter-Departmental Data Integration for the Maryland Department of Human Services. He won the nomination by a vote of 17–6 on April 18, 2023. He was sworn in on May 2, 2023.\n\n\nIn 1991, Wims identified as a \"\" member of the . He supported the  of . In 2020, Wims unsuccessfully ran for delegate to the , pledged to former Vice President .\n\n\nWims has a daughter named Rachel Wims, who took over as CEO of the Victims' Rights Foundation in January 2019.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Bernice D. Mireku-North''' (born October 29, 1981) is an American politician. She is currently a Democratic member of the , appointed by Governor  to fill the term of , who resigned on January 2, 2023, to serve as the chief legislative officer of governor-elect . She was previously a candidate for Montgomery County State's Attorney in 2022.\n\n\nMireku-North attended Montgomery County public schools and graduated from the  with a B.A. degree in government and politics in 2003, and the  with a J.D. degree in 2006. She also studied abroad at the  in the summer of 2002, studying British and U.S. judicial systems. She also served as a judicial law clerk to  Associate Judge  and Prince George's Circuit Court Judge Dwight D. Jackson.\n\nMireku-North served as the assistant state's attorney in  from 2009 to 2015, then joined the Law Office of Aileen Oliver. Since 2019, she has run her own law firm, the North Law Group, and worked as a criminal defense attorney.\n\nIn 2020, Mireku-North was named co-chair of the Reimagining Public Safety Task Force organized by Montgomery County Executive . The 41-member task force released its final report on February 5, 2021; its 87 recommendations included redirecting some  to non-law enforcement agencies, eliminating police training programs with connections to military training, and increasing recruitment at .\n\n\nIn June 2021, Mireku-North filed to run for Montgomery County State's Attorney, challenging incumbent John McCarthy. She pledged to reform criminal justice, increase diversity in the state's attorney's office, and divert minor offenders from jail. Mireku-North was defeated by McCarthy in the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022.\n\nIn October 2022, Mireku-North applied to fill a vacancy in the Montgomery County Planning Commission.\n\n\nIn December 2022, Mireku-North filed to fill the vacancy left by the resignation of then-Majority Leader of the Maryland House of Delegates , seeking to serve out his four-year term in the Maryland House of Delegates. On January 3, 2023, the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate Mireku-North to fill the vacancy, and on January 6, Governor  appointed her to fill the seat.\n\n\n* Ways and Means Committee, 2023–present (early childhood subcommittee, 2023–present; local revenues subcommittee, 2023–present)\n\n\n\n* Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland, 2023–present\n* Women Legislators of Maryland, 2023–present\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Emmett C. Burns Jr.''' (August 26, 1940 – March 17, 2022) was an American politician from  and a member of the . He served five terms in the , representing Maryland's District 10 in . Burns was a member of the Economic Matters Committee.\n\nOn July 8, 2013, Burns announced his intention not to seek re-election to the Maryland Legislature in 2014. He died on March 17, 2022.\n\n\nBurns was born in , on August 26, 1940. He earned a B.S. degree from , a Master of Divinity degree from , a Master of Religious Education degree from the , and a Ph.D. from the . After a brief stint in the , Burns became a  minister in Baltimore.\n\n\nBurns, a Democrat, was considered a conservative on some social issues.  He opposed a woman's right to choice regarding abortions and efforts to legalize slot machines in the state. He was also an opponent of legalizing same-sex marriage.\nBurns was involved in government task forces on the legacy of  in Maryland, on the impact of s in institutions of higher education, and on entrepreneurship among African Americans. He was a member of the . He sponsored the bill that changed the name of Maryland's major airport to the . After 5 four-year terms in the legislature, Burns opted not to file for re-election in 2014.\n\n\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax while simultaneously reducing income tax rates for some income brackets - Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* Introduced House Bill 90 to invalidate marriages between same-sex couples validly entered into in another state or in a foreign country, declaring that \"marriages between individuals of the same sex are against the public policy of the State.\" On WYPR's ''Maryland Morning with Sheilah Kast'' (January 26, 2010), Burns was quoted as saying \"Same sex marriages are bad economic policy, bad social policy, bad educational policy, it's just bad policy.\"\n: If it had been voted and signed into law, House Bill 90 would have added further restrictions to Maryland's . The bill was defeated on February 3, 2010.\n* voted against Civil Marriage Protection Act, a law allowing same-sex couples to obtain a marriage license.\n\n\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\nIn 1999, Burns accused a tow truck driver of uttering a racial slur, a claim the driver denied. Michael Stansbury, a tow truck driver for Flash Towing, said that he denied service to the politician after Burns started shouting at him and used a profane term to refer to his race.\n\n\nAfter    voiced his support for , Burns wrote a letter on August 29, 2012, to Ravens owner , on official Maryland State letterhead, demanding that Mr. Bisciotti \"take the necessary action ... to inhibit such expressions from your employee,\" further stating, \"I know of no other NFL player who has done what Mr. Ayanbadejo is doing.\" Ayanbadejo's off-field activities did not violate any NFL or Ravens' rules or regulations. Burns was criticized for trying to use the authority of his government position to prevent a citizen from exercising their  rights and for taking a public position on same-sex marriage that was in direct conflict with his Democratic Party platform and the constituency that elected him. In an interview for '''', a spokesperson for the Ravens acknowledged that the team had received the letter but refused to give any further comment. Later however, the Ravens publicly supported Ayanbadejo's right to voice his viewpoints. Ayanbadejo himself affirmed in a subsequent interview with '''' that he had received public support for his actions and that he had no intention of backing away from them.\n\n punter  famously came to Ayanbadejo's defense, penning a scathing retort for the popular sports website ''''. After echoing previous criticisms and wondering why Burns \"hates freedom,\" Kluwe stated that making gay marriage legal \"won't magically turn you into a lustful cockmonster\" and that he himself has been very vocal in supporting same-sex marriage, despite Burns's claim that Ayanbadejo was the only NFL player to do so.\n\nBurns ultimately recanted his demand and acknowledged that Ayanbadejo had the right to speak out on same-sex marriage.\n\n\nBurns died March 17, 2022. His funeral was held on March 26 at his church, Rising Sun First Baptist Church in . He was laid to rest at Garden Memorial Park in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Julie Palakovich Carr''' (born April 22, 1983) is an American politician from . She is a member of the  who currently serves in the , representing  in . She previously served on the  City Council.\n\n\nPalakovich Carr was born in  on April 22, 1983. She attended Boston University, where she earned a  degree in biology in 2005, and the University of Minnesota, where she earned a  in biology in 2007.\n\n\nBefore holding elected office, Palakovich Carr served on several city task forces, including serving two terms on the Environment Commission, chairing the Adequate Public Facilities Ordinance (APFO) Review Committee, serving as vice chair of the City Services and Budget Work Group, and chairing the Watersheds Committee. In addition to her elected career, Palakovich Carr worked for a decade in science policy, including as public policy manager for the . She also co-founded a political technology startup, Victory Guide, that helps candidates run for local office.\n\n\nIn November 2013, at the age of 29, she became the youngest woman ever elected to the Rockville City Council. She was re-elected in 2015 and served until early 2019. She was council liaison to the Animal Matters Board, Environment Commission, Human Rights Commission, and Traffic and Transportation Commission. During her two terms, Palakovich Carr sponsored successful legislation to make Rockville a , ban smoking in outdoor dining areas, strengthen the city's animal cruelty laws, and create a water conservation program for seniors and low-income families.\n\nIn 2016, she was recognized as a Leading Woman by the '''' for her community involvement and professional accomplishments.\n\nPalakovich Carr announced her candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates on July 6, 2017. Had she lost the Democratic primary, she would have been eligible to run for re-election on the Rockville City Council. After incumbent Delegate  announced that he would not seek re-election in the 2018 elections, Delegates  and  formed a slate with Palakovich Carr in advance of the Democratic primary elections. She won the primary election with 24.7 percent of the vote, and later won the general election with 29.5 percent of the vote. After winning the general election, she resigned from the Rockville city council.\n\n\n\nPalakovich Carr was sworn in as a member of the House of Delegates on January 9, 2019.\n\n\n* Member, Ways and Means Committee, 2019- (local revenues subcommittee, 2019–20; revenues subcommittee, 2019-; education subcommittee, 2021-)\n* Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee, 2021-\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019-\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2019-\n* Associate member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019- (vice-chair, legislative review committee, 2019-)\n\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Palakovich Carr introduced legislation that would replace s with .\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Palakovich Carr and  introduced legislation that would allow gubernatorial candidates to pick their running mates after the primary election. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 96-41.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Palakovich Carr introduced legislation that would expand a law that allows voters to receive  to vote in elections to cover early voting. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 91-38.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Palakovich Carr introduced legislation that would ban lobbyists from contributing from their own personal funds to statewide candidates to influence the actions of these elected officials.\n\n\nIn December 2019, Palakovich Carr attended and spoke at a rally in Gaithersburg, Maryland supporting the .\n\n\nIn July 2019, the Maryland State Board of Elections began allowing voters to choose \"X\" or \"unspecified\" as a gender on their voter registration after Palakovich Carr wrote to election officials asking them to consider making the corresponding change.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Palakovich Carr introduced legislation to ban the use of  in criminal court proceedings. The bill passed and went into effect without Governor Larry Hogan's signature.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Palakovich Carr introduced and passed legislation that allows the cities of Rockville and  to levy a hotel tax on rental services. She also voted for legislation that would impose fees on tax-capped  properties in Montgomery County, which failed to pass in an 11-13 vote.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Palakovich Carr introduced a tax reform proposal that would require  for multi-state corporations, eliminate tax credit and subsidy programs, lower the state's  exemption limit to $1 million, and restructure tax brackets for those earning more or less than the state median.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Palakovich Carr introduced legislation to extend the state's  to  filers. The bill passed and became law without Governor Hogan's signature on March 9, 2021.\n\nShe also introduced legislation to allow counties to impose  on a bracket basis, which passed but was vetoed by Governor Hogan on May 28, 2021. The General Assembly voted to override the governor's veto during the 2021 special legislative session.\n\n\nPalakovich Carr and her husband, Eric, have lived in East Rockville for a decade. Together, they have a son.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jason Charles Gallion''' (born February 10, 1977) is an American politician who serves as a  member of the  from the  in  and .\n\n\nGallion was born in  on February 10, 1977, where he graduated from  in 1995. He grew up helping his father, who worked for the State Highway Administration, raise beef cattle at home. He also worked as a teen at the dairy farms owned by his uncle, Nolan Gallion Sr., and the Hopkins family. He attended , where he earned a  degree in political science in 1997. After graduating, he became a farmer, producing dairy from 1999 to 2004 and  and hay from 2004 onward.\n\nGallion got his first glimpse of politics at 13 years old, when he volunteered for 's first council race in . In 2016, he joined Glassman's administration as a part-time agricultural specialist in the Harford County Department of Governmental and Community Relations. Gallion also serves on the county's Economic Development Agricultural Advisory Board and is the liaison from the county's executive office to the Harford County Farm Bureau.\n\nIn 2006, Gallion unsuccessfully ran for the Harford County Council in District D, finishing second to Chad Shrodes in the Republican primary.\n\nIn 2007, Gallion applied to succeed delegate Barry Glassman, who had been appointed by   to the  following the resignation of senator , in the . The Harford County Republican Central Committee voted unanimously to appoint attorney  to the House of Delegates. In 2010, Gallion ran an unsuccessful campaign for District 35A of the Maryland House of Delegates, running on a ticket alongside Dave Tritt and seeking to unseat Norman.\n\nIn 2011, Gallion served on the Harford County Council .\n\nIn 2014, Gallion again ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 35B, seeking to succeed retiring delegate  and delegate Wayne Norman, who sought election to the . During the primary, he received the endorsement of the Maryland Farm Bureau PAC, the , and the Cecil County Republican Club. He finished third in the three-way Republican primary, winning the majority of .\n\nIn March 2018, following the unexpected passing of senator Wayne Norman, the Harford County Republican Central Committee tapped Gallion to succeed Norman on the primary election ballot. while , the late senator's wife, filled the remainder of his term in the Maryland Senate. In the months following his nomination, the central committee considered some political maneuvering that would allow delegate  to run for state senate instead of re-election to the House of Delegates. Days before the Cecil County committee was scheduled to discuss supporting ballot realignment if both candidates declined the nomination, Gallion sent a letter to local GOP leaders that declared his intent to stay in the senate race. Consequentially, the Cecil County committee unanimously voted to table the possibility of ballot realignment. He defeated  Frank Esposito and  Christopher Randers-Pehrson in the general election, receiving 67.6 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nGallion was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019.\n\n\n* Member, Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee, 2019–present (environment subcommittee, 2019–present; health subcommittee, 2019–present)\n* Joint Subcommittee on Program Open Space and Agricultural Land Preservation, 2019\n* Joint COVID-19 Response Legislative Work Group, 2020–present\n\n\n\nThe first bill that Gallion introduced in the Maryland Senate was a bill that would allow  to travel on highways within a 25-mile radius of a farm. He also introduced legislation that would ban the sale of  under the \"milk\" label under the pretext that eleven other  adopt similar legislation by 2029. Both bills passed and were signed by Governor  in April 2019.\n\nGallion introduced legislation during the 2020 legislative session that would ban the sale of foods made of animal tissues cultured from cells outside of the original animal, plants, and insects under the \"meat\" label. The bill received an unfavorable report by the Maryland Senate Finance Committee.\n\n\nGallion, having lost a loved one to the , says that he supports increased  in schools to prevent more people from turning to opioids.\n\n\nIn 2019, Gallion was the only senator to receive a score of 100 percent on the Maryland Free Enterprise Foundation's annual scorecard.\n\n\nDuring a debate on the  education reform plan in March 2020, Gallion introduced an amendment that would have reduced the number of teaching scholarships by $16 million and reduce the expansion of the state's Judy Center network of early education hubs by $12 million. The amendment was rejected in a party-line vote.\n\nGallion introduced legislation during the 2021 legislative session that would move appointing authority for the Harford County school board from the governor to the county executive, with input from the county council.\n\n\nDuring a debate on legislation that would ban people from simultaneously running for elected public offices and political party offices and from holding both offices at the same time, Gallion proposed amending the bill to allow an individual to run for both offices at the same time so long as they can't simultaneously hold both offices.\n\nGallion introduced legislation alongside senators  and  during the 2021 legislative session that would require voters to show  before casting a ballot. He also sponsored legislation that would require people that deliver  to be a family member or part of the immediate household of the voter and ban s or candidates from delivering mail-in ballots for another vote. Additionally, Gallion said that he would sponsor legislation that would increase penalties for voter fraud, including a four-year loss of voting rights.\n\nIn March 2021, Gallion opposed legislation that would expand the number of  centers in Maryland and permanently expand mail-in voting, worrying that the state might be putting an \"extra burden\" on local governments.\n\n\nIn October 2019, the Maryland  gave Gallion a score of 20 percent, the lowest score in the Maryland Senate and tying him with senator .\n\nDuring debate on an omnibus climate action bill (the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2021), Gallion introduced an amendment that would push back the bill's goal of achieving  by 2050 instead of 2045. He also worried that the bill's tree planting program would create habitat for deer in agricultural buffer zones.\n\nGallion said that he would rather have the issue of  versus commercial solar stay in the hands of each county instead of the .\n\n\nGallion, who describes himself as a  advocate, has said that he is \"leery\" about  because he does not want to restrict rights for law-abiding citizens.\n\nGallion introduced legislation during the 2019 legislative sessions that allows Harford County farmers to use rifles and shotguns to rid their properties of animals that damage crops. The bill passed and was signed by Governor Hogan on April 18, 2019.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Gallion defended an amendment introduced by senator  that would exempt s, off-duty officers, or retired officers from legislation that prevents people from carrying guns in or near a , arguing that having an armed law enforcement officer on hand could help quell a disturbance at a polling place if one arose.\n\n\nGallion opposes legalizing , preferring to wait and see what comes from states like  as test cases. However, he has expressed interest in looking into how farmers could get involved in  for .\n\n\nIn 2019, Gallion cosponsored legislation introduced by Governor Hogan that would create an  to draw Maryland's congressional and legislative district maps.\n\nGallion intended on introducing an amendment to the state's legislative redistricting plan to stop the use of hybrid districts, replacing those districts with three single-member delegate subdistricts. However, the amendment was still being drafted on the day of the vote and the Maryland Senate rejected his request to delay the resolution.\n\n\nIn 2014, Gallion signed a petition to overturn Maryland's \"bathroom bill\", which allows a person undergoing  or a person with , to use the restroom of their choice.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Tiffany T. Alston '''(born April 22, 1977) is an  who represented   in the  since January 2023, and from January 2011 to January 2013. She was suspended from office in 2012 after being found guilty of stealing General Assembly funds to pay an employee at her law firm.\n\n\nAlston was born in , and grew up in . She attended Seat Pleasant Elementary School. She graduated from the  with a  in criminology & criminal justice and from  with a  in 2002.\n\nFrom 1999 to 2001, she was a volunteer teacher with the . From 2004 to 2005, she served as a Chief of Staff within the Division of Correction at the . She is a former mentor of the , and a member  of  sorority.\n\nFrom 2004 to 2012, she practiced law with her own law firm, which was located in . Alston's law license was suspended by the  on September 25, 2012, and she was disbarred on May 3, 2013.\n\n\nAlston was a member of the House of Delegates from 2011 to 2013 and served on the Judiciary committee. She was a member of the , the Women's Caucus, and the .\n\nIn 2022, Alston filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 24, seeking to succeed state delegate , who was  in . She won election to the seat and was sworn in on January 11, 2023, and has since served in the Health and Government Operations Committee.\n\nIn January 2024, former Baltimore State's Attorney  hired Alston to represent her in her disbarment case.\n\nIn 2024, Alston applied to run as a delegate to the  pledged to , but was denied by the .\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Alston was a co-sponsor of \"Religious Freedom and Civil Marriage Protection Act\". A similar bill was filed in the Maryland Senate (SB 116 - ) and was assigned to the House Judiciary Committee, the committee on which Alston served. During the committee voting session on SB 116, Alston revoked her co-sponsorship and instead offered an amendment to change the bill from  to s. The amendment failed, and Alston then voted against the bill. Despite Alston's vote, SB 116 was approved by the committee 12-10 and was forwarded to the full House of Delegates for final approval, but the bill was eventually sent back to committee, effectively terminating the bill for the session.\n\nAlston voted against the Civil Marriage Protection Act in committee when it was re-introduced in the 2012 legislative session, but voted for the bill after it was amended to block the bill from going into effect if efforts to bring it to a referendum were being litigated.\n\n\nAlston was  in an  courtroom with  on September 24, 2011 on one count each of felony and misdemeanor theft,  by a fiduciary and two election law offenses for allegedly using  funds and her election campaign funds to cover her wedding expenses and to pay an employee of her law firm.\n\nAlston was found guilty of   of General Assembly funds and misconduct in office on June 12, 2012. The judge postponed sentencing until after a separate trial, scheduled for October 2012, on the charges regarding Alston's use of her 2010 campaign funds to pay her wedding-related expenses. On October 9, 2012, the judge struck the jury verdict and entered probation before judgement after Alston entered a plea deal agreed to pay $800 in restitution to the General Assembly and complete 300 hours of community service. On October 10, 2012, General Assembly Counsel Daniel A. Friedman announced that Alston was suspended from her office without pay or benefits due to a Maryland constitutional provision. Alston sued to try to get her legislative job back, but the Maryland Court of Appeals ruled against her on January 4, 2013.\n\n\nIn February 2014, Alston filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 24, seeking to gain her old seat back from . In order to run for this seat, Alston had to pay the Maryland State Board of Elections back for the $750 in late fees that she owed for failing to file timely campaign finance reports. She came in fourth place in the Democratic primary, receiving 13.0 percent of the vote.\n\nIn 2017, Alston filed to run for , seeking to challenge two-term incumbent . She received 31.5 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary election.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William A. Campos''' (born October 7, 1974) is an  from ,  convicted for corruption in 2018. He served in the  and on the Prince George's County Council.\n\n\nBorn in El Salvador, Campos attended  in ; the , receiving a B.A. in ancient art history & archaeology; and the , receiving a B.S. in computer studies & information systems.\n\n\nPrior to holding office, Campos in 2002 was an aide to then-Delegate , District 47, Prince George's County.\n\nCampos represented District 2 on the Prince George's County Council for ten years, winning a special election in 2004 when his predecessor resigned, and subsequently being elected to two four-year terms.\n\nSubject to term limits, he then ran for, and won, the District 47B seat in the House of Delegates. He served in the House of Delegates for nine months.\n\nCampos resigned his House seat on September 10, 2015, for \"personal reasons\", citing \"his recent marriage, desire to start a family and lack of employment outside the State House.\"\n\n\nOn January 5, 2017, Campos pleaded guilty to accepting about $40,000 to $50,000 in bribes and kickbacks in exchange for official favors. As part of the plea agreement, Campos was required to give up the money he collected in the scheme and pay restitution of at least $340,000. He also faced up 15 years in prison for the bribery and conspiracy charges. Campos was sentenced in May 2018 to 54 months in prison, to be followed by three years of supervised release. It was reported in June 2020 that amid the  Campos was transferred to a halfway house in the Baltimore area to complete his sentence more than a year before his projected release date.\n\n\n\n:\n\n\n:\n\n\n:\n\n:\n\n\n:\n\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Charles Lollar''' (born June 22, 1971) is an American businessman and  politician. A former Marine Corps officer, he was the Republican nominee for 's  in , losing to  incumbent . After coming third in the Republican primary for  in the , he ran for the , losing to Democratic Commissioner Ken Robinson.\n\n\nLollar served in the Marine Corps from 1997 to 2003. He was deployed to the Balkans from March through October 1999 as part of . Leaving active duty in July 2003, he joined the reserves and served as an intelligence officer at . He was then general manager for facility services corporation . As of July 2014, he works as a budgeting and political consultant for government contractor Blackson Arrow.\n\n\nIn his first political campaign, which took place in 2004, Lollar lost a bid for the  school board.\n\nLollar, a  Republican, subsequently moved to Maryland and served as Chair of the  Republican Central Committee. He planned to run for  in the , but was prevented from doing so by the state's requirement that a candidate must have been registered to vote in Maryland for five years. Instead, he sought the Republican nomination to challenge  incumbent  in . Lollar won the Republican primary in September 2010 with 58% of the vote. In the , Hoyer was re-elected with 64.3% of the vote to Lollar's 34.6%.\n\nLollar subsequently became the director of the Maryland chapter of , the head of the  New Day Maryland, spoke at  and  rallies and served as a  to the .\n\nOn September 2, 2013, Lollar announced he was running for the Republican nomination for  in the  at an event in . He raised $65,000 during the whole of 2013 and reported $5,700 cash-on-hand at the end of the year. On February 24, 2014, Lollar announced that his running mate was , an investigative reporter, conservative activist and the Republican nominee for  in .\n\nIn the primary held on June 24, 2014, Lollar finished third out of the four candidates with 15.5% of the vote, behind  and , who received 43% and 29.1%, respectively, but ahead of , who received 12.4%.\n\nAfter his defeat, Lollar announced he would seek the district 1 seat on the , replacing fellow Republican J.T. Crawford on the ballot, who had withdrawn because of work and family commitments. He faced incumbent Democratic Commissioner Ken Robinson in the general election. Lollar, using money left over from his gubernatorial campaign, outspent Robinson and promised to freeze taxes without affecting services, though he offered no specifics as to how he would accomplish this. Lollar was defeated by Robinson by 19,112 votes (42.7%) to 25,467 (57%).\n\n\nLollar and his wife, Rosha, have four daughters. They live in .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jennifer White Holland''' (born April 21, 1988) is an American politician who is a member of the  for  in .\n\n\nJennifer White was born on April 21, 1988, in , Michigan. She attended  in . She graduated from  with a  degree with honors in political theory and constitutional democracy, and social relations and policy in 2010. She later attended the , where she earned a  degree in public health in 2012. In 2022, she ran for the , running on a slate with  , then-state delegate , and management consultant . She won the Democratic primary on July 19, receiving 19.2 percent of the vote.\n\n\nWhite Holland was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. She is a member of the House Health and Government Operations Committee.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brian Jeffrey Feldman''' (born February 4, 1961) is an American politician and a member of the  representing . He previously served in the  representing District 15.\n\n\nFeldman was born in , where he graduated from . He attended , where he earned a  degree in accounting in 1983, and the , where he earned his  degree in 1986. Feldman later attended , where he earned a  degree in government in 2000.\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Feldman worked as an attorney and certified public accountant for  until 1988, when he began working as a trial attorney for the . He has worked as an adjunct professor for Johns Hopkins University since 2006, and for the  since 2019.\n\n\nFeldman was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 8, 2003.\n\nIn June 2013, state senator and then-Senate Majority Leader  announced that he would resign from the Maryland Senate on September 1. Feldman applied to fill the vacancy and faced no formal opposition in the selection process following the withdrawal of his opponents. On September 10, 2013, the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee voted unanimously to nominate Feldman to fill the vacancy left by Garagiola. He was appointed to the  by Governor  on September 12, 2013. Feldman successfully ran for election to a full term in the Maryland Senate in 2014, defeating perennial candidate  in the general election.\n\n\n\n;Maryland Senate\n* Chair, Education, Energy and the Environment Committee, 2023–present\n* Member, Rules Committee, 2023–present\n* Member, Workers Compensation Benefit and Insurance Oversight Committee, 2015–present\n* Executive Nominations Committee, 2019–present\n* Legislative Policy Committee, 2019–present\n* Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, 2019–present\n* Senate Chair, Joint Electric Universal Service Program Work Group, 2020–present\n* Member, Joint Information Technology and Biotechnology Committee, 2014\n* Joint Committee on Cybersecurity, Information Technology, and Biotechnology, 2014–2018\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 2015–2018 (member, 2014–2018)\n* Member, Marijuana Legalization Work Group, 2019\n* Vice-Chair, Finance Committee, 2019–2022 (member, 2013–2022; property & casualty subcommittee, 2015–2017; chair, transportation subcommittee, 2015–2016; chair, health subcommittee, 2017–2018; chair, energy & public utilities subcommittee, 2019–2022; member, health & long-term care subcommittee, 2019–2022)\n\n;Maryland House of Delegates\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, 2003–2013 (business regulation subcommittee, 2003–2010; corporations work group, 2003–2006; property & casualty insurance subcommittee, 2003–2013; consumer protection & commercial law subcommittee, 2007–2010; chair, banking, economic development, science & technology subcommittee, 2007–2013)\n* Medical Malpractice Insurance Work Group, 2004\n* Joint Committee on Access to Mental Health Services, 2005–2011\n* House Chair, Joint Technology Oversight Committee, 2007–2009\n* Member, Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2007–2013\n* House Chair, Joint Information Technology and Biotechnology Committee, 2009–2013\n* Member, Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2011–2013\n* Regional Revitalization Work Group, 2013–present\n\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Feldman introduced the Clean Energy Jobs Act, which would require that half of Maryland's power comes from renewable sources by 2030. The bill was reintroduced in 2019, during which it passed and became law without Governor 's signature.\n\nIn 2021, Feldman criticized a Hogan administration proposal that sought to scale back the state's  program, later amending a bill to limit the 's ability to implement changes to its emissions inspection program.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Feldman introduced the Protect Maryland Health Care Act, a bill that would reinstate the 's (ACA)  following its repeal under the . The bill would combine the money collected under the mandate with s to pay for health care coverage for uninsured individuals. The bill failed to move out of committee, and was reintroduced in 2019, during which it was amended to create a guide on state tax forms to help uninsured individuals sign up for  or subsidized health plans. The amended bill was signed into law by Governor  on May 13, 2019.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Feldman introduced a bill to establish a Prescription Drug Affordability Board, which would have the power to set upper payment limits on select s.\n\nIn December 2019, after the  struck down several provisions of the ACA in its ruling in '''', Feldman promised to enshrine as many of the ACA's provisions into state law as he could. During the 2020 legislative session, he introduced and passed legislation to codify the ACA's consumer protections provisions, including cost sharing limits, pre-existing conditions protections, and keeping dependents on a parents' health insurance plan up to age 26.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Feldman introduced a bill that would allow 16- and 17-year-olds to get vaccinated without parental permission.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Feldman introduced a bill banning medical debt collection agencies from garnishing the wages or placing s on homes of people who owed medical debt, and limiting payments made toward medical debt at five percent of a person's income. The bill unanimously passed the Maryland General Assembly and became law without Governor Larry Hogan's signature. Also in 2021, he introduced a bill to create a pilot program to allow young adults to enroll for health insurance coverage for as little as $1 a month. The bill passed and became law without Hogan's signature. In 2023, Feldman introduced a bill to extend this program.\n\n\nIn November 2023, Feldman and eight other state senators signed a joint letter that threatened to defund immigrants rights group  because it had called for an immediate ceasefire in the  and condemned the \"utilization of US tax dollars to promote the ongoing violence.\"\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Feldman introduced a bill that would allow students with authorized medical cannabis cards to take  on school grounds.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Feldman introduced a bill to legalize recreational marijuana, taxed at 10 percent and gradually increasing to 20 percent by 2027, and decriminalize possession of marijuana up to four ounces for adults 21 years or older. The bill failed to move out of committee. The bill was reintroduced in 2022, during which it passed the Maryland Senate on a .\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Feldman introduced legislation to ban the sale of . He later amended the bill to limit its sale to adults aged 21 and older.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Feldman introduced and passed a bill to legalize adult use cannabis in Maryland and create a regulatory framework for Maryland's cannabis industry.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session and following the , Feldman introduced a bill to provide temporary assistance to \"essential\" government employees during government shutdowns. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor  on March 26, 2019.\n\nIn 2008, Feldman successfully ran for delegate to the  in , pledged to U.S. Senator . In July 2019, he endorsed former Vice President  for president.\n\n\nIn 2017, Feldman introduced a bill that would prohibit  companies from restricting the resale of tickets to concerts or sporting events.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Feldman introduced a bill to deregulate the state's craft brewery industry, increasing the limits on how many barrels a brewery could produce a year and loosening franchise restrictions on small breweries. The bill passed unanimously and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Feldman introduced and passed a bill that would require four-year public universities to develop a plan to provide students with access to emergency contraception and abortion services.\n\n\nIn 2018, Feldman introduced the Maryland Metro/Transit Funding Act, a bill that would pay $167 million to the  (WMATA) as part of a cost sharing agreement between Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia to help the agency pay for new rail cars and maintenance. The bill was signed into law by Governor  on April 25, 2018.\n\nIn July 2019, Feldman criticized  Pete Rahn's decision to withhold $55.6 million in funding from WMATA and questioned whether the state had the legal authority to withhold these funds.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
