    "pages": }\n\n'''Warren E. Miller''' (born October 5, 1964) was a member of the . Miller represented , which includes parts of  and  counties. Miller was appointed by Governor  on March 7, 2003 to replace , who resigned from the  on February 28, 2003, to become the Maryland Secretary of Transportation. On November 30, 2020, Miller announced his intent to resign at the end of 2020.\n\n\nIn 2006, Miller, along with fellow Republican , defeated David Leonard Osmundson to maintain his District 9A seat.\n\n\nMiller attended  in Howard County. He received his bachelor's degree in Business Administration in 1987 from .\n\n\nShortly after college, Miller began to work as a Deputy Directory for the computer center at the  Office of Presidential Personnel. In 1990, he became the confidential assistant to Assistant Administrator, Bureau for Legislative Affairs, . Later, he was appointed as the special assistant to the White House Liaison, Office of Administrator, , a position he held from 1991-1992. In 1992, he became the White House Liaison for the U.S. Office of Personnel Management. In 1994, he was the Congressional campaign manager for .\n\nFrom 1995 until 1996, Miller was a programmer/analyst for Advanced Technology Systems. In 1996, he worked for  until 2005. Since 2006, Miller has been a business development manager for Human Touch LLC.\n\nFinally, Miller was on the Howard County Republican Central Committee from 1998 - 2003.\n\nAs a member of the , Miller has served on the Economic Matters Committee since 2003, and the Joint Advisory Committee on Legislative Data Systems since 2007.\n\nMiller has worked with fellow Republican Gail Bates to amended the Maryland Constitution to define marriage as the union between a man and a woman.\n\n\n* voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted against the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2010 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2018 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Samuel Isadore Rosenberg''' (born May 18, 1950) is an  who has served as a member of the  representing northwest  since 1983. He is currently the longest serving member of the .\n\n\nSamuel Isadore Rosenberg was born in  on May 18, 1950, to father Benedict Lewis Rosenberg and mother Babette Hecht. He grew up in the city's , where he was a member of the .\n\nRosenberg attended  and graduated from  with a  degree in political science in 1972, and , earning his  degree in 1975.\n\n\n\nWhile attending Columbia University, Rosenberg worked as an intern for the Baltimore state's attorney's office. He resigned from this position in July 1974 to run for the Democratic Central Central Committee in the 42nd district, but continued working as an unpaid volunteer in the same position to avoid violating the . Rosenberg was elected to the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee in September 1974. From 1975 to 1976, and again from 1979 to 1981, he worked as a program administrator for the Baltimore Housing Authority, in between working as a producer and assistant for 's ''Square Off'' talk show. Afterwards, Rosenberg worked as a congressional assistant and as a lobbyist for Baltimore Mayor  in the  from 1980 to 1981. He later taught a class in legislation at the .\n\n\n\nIn 1982, Rosenberg ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in . He won the Democratic primary in September, placing third and defeating incumbent state Delegates Steven V. Sklar and David B. Shapiro. Rosenberg was sworn in on January 12, 1983. In 2002, he was redrawn into the , where he successfully ran for re-election.\n\nDuring his first twenty years in the House of Delegates, Rosenberg served as a member of the Appropriations Committee, afterwards serving in the Health and Government Operations Committee until 2004. From 2004 to 2011, and again from 2013 to 2016, he served as a member of the Judiciary Committee, in between serving as the vice-chair of the Ways and Means Committee. Since 2017, Rosenberg has served as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee and as the chair of the government operations and long-term care subcommittee.\n\nIn October 1983, after state Senator  was appointed to serve as the director of the , Rosenberg applied to serve the remainder of her term in the . The Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee voted 4-1 to nominate  executive director Barbara Hoffman to fill the seat later that month.\n\nRosenberg was a delegate to the  in , , and .\n\n\nRosenberg is Jewish and is a member of the . He has lived in the  of Baltimore since December 1977.\n\n\n\nRosenberg has been described by media outlets as being . In November 1981, he signed onto a  letter endorsing the 's decision in '''' and opposing efforts to pass the  to overturn the ''Roe'' decision. In the legislature, Rosenberg supported efforts to expand  funding for abortions and to increase funding for family planning services to prevent .\n\nIn July 1989, following the Supreme Court's ruling in '''', Rosenberg endorsed efforts to repeal the state's 1968 laws on abortion, which required abortions in the state to be performed in a hospital and approved by a hospital review committee. He introduced a bill to do so during the 1990 legislative session, which died in committee. Rosenberg reintroduced the bill in 1991, during which it passed and was signed into law by Governor . After the bill went to referendum in , he supported efforts to uphold the law.\n\nDuring the 2005 legislative session, Rosenberg introduced the Ronald Reagan and Christopher Reeve Stem Cell Research Act, which would provide $25 million a year in state funding toward . The bill was reintroduced in 2006, during which it passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn 2023, Rosenberg introduced legislation to shield the health care and insurance information of people who travel to Maryland to receive an abortion.\n\n\nRosenberg is the author of Maryland's 1988 hate-crimes statute. In October 1998, following the murder of , he introduced legislation to expand the hate crimes statute to include .\n\n (center) and Lieutenant Governor  (left) on legislation to repeal the death penalty, 2013.]]\nDuring the 2007 legislative session, Rosenberg introduced legislation to repeal the death penalty. After a similar measure failed in 2008, he expressed support for a compromise bill that would limit the use of capital punishment. He testified for the repeal bill when it was reintroduced in 2013, during which it passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn 2008, Rosenberg supported legislation to expand the state's collection of s, which was developed under a work group he led.\n\nDuring the 2009 legislative session, Rosenberg supported legislation to prohibit police from spying on political activists and peaceful protest groups.\n\nIn March 2019, Rosenberg supported a bill that would allow  to have its own private police force.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Rosenberg voted for  and the Maryland Police Accountability Act.\n\n\nDuring the 1986 legislative session, Rosenberg voted for a bill that would overturn a  ruling that allowed victims of crimes committed with  handguns to sue the weapon's manufacturers. In 1996, he voted for a gun control bill to limit handgun purchases and prohibit domestic abusers from owning firearms.\n\nIn December 2012, following the  that left 28 dead, Rosenberg said he would support a ban on s in Maryland. During the 2013 legislative session, he voted for the Firearm Safety Act, which banned assault weapons and placed restrictions on firearm purchases.\n\n\nIn January 1980, Rosenberg opposed a bill that would give tenants three days' notice to pay overdue rent. During his 1982 House of Delegates campaign, he expressed support for increasing state assistance for home purchasers and renters. In 1983, Rosenberg introduced legislation requiring colleges buying apartment buildings to extend state protections to residents of the building.\n\nDuring the 1985 legislative session, Rosenberg introduced legislation to provide tax credits to homeowners to remove lead paint. In 1987, he introduced a bill that would allow tenants to put their rent in escrow if lead paint is found in their homes. During the 2000 legislative session, Rosenberg introduced legislation that would allow tenants to recover damages from lead paint manufacturers, which died in committee following aggressive lobbying efforts by paint manufacturers. He criticized efforts to weaken state lead paint laws under the .\n\nIn 1999, Rosenberg introduced a bill that would expand the state's definition of abandoned properties and give the city of Baltimore more power to condemn and demolish such buildings. In 2000, he introduced legislation to increase staffing in the  to combat  in Baltimore.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Rosenberg supported legislation to establish a  in eviction cases. After the bill became law, he signed onto a letter to Governor  calling on him to use federal rent relief funding to support the access to counsel bill. In 2022, Rosenberg introduced a bill to fund the state's right to counsel fund using unclaimed settlement payments from state lawsuits against property management companies. The bill passed and became law without Hogan's signature.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Rosenberg introduced legislation to prohibit the state from contracting with companies that supported the  (BDS) movement. The bill failed to pass out of the legislature, but became law after Governor  signed an executive order implementing it in October 2017.\n\nIn October 2023, amid the , Rosenberg participated in a rally supporting  in Baltimore. During the 2024 legislative session, Rosenberg supported a bill to remove Maryland  director  from the Maryland Commission on Hate Crime Response and Prevention after she made posts on Facebook comparing  to , denied that Israeli children were murdered during the , and condemned the killing of innocent Gazan civilians.\n\n\nDuring the 2003 legislative session, after Governor  proposed locating s at the , Rosenberg expressed concerns that the plan would worsen public safety and traffic in the area, and only said that he would vote for slots if a bill he introduced to reinvest profits earned from the slots toward redevelopment efforts in neighborhoods surrounding the race course was added to it. He voted against the slots bill in 2005.\n\nIn December 2018, Rosenberg endorsed a $442 million plan to redevelop parts of the Pimlico Race Course. He supported an unsuccessful bill to approve the plan during the 2019 legislative session, which was later renegotiated to transfer a portion of the costs onto the , which owns Pimlico, and to include investments in communities surrounding the race course. During the 2023 legislative session, Rosenberg supported legislation to establish a horse racing oversight board.\n\n\nDuring his 1982 House of Delegates campaign, Rosenberg said he supported giving state employees  rights, but opposed giving public safety employees the . In 1984, he voted for a bill to limit s to the state employees' pension system.\n\nDuring the 1986 legislative session, Rosenberg voted against a bill to prohibit selling video tapes containing obscene materials to minors, arguing that children would still be able to listen to the banned records on the radio, which could be recorded easily.\n\nIn 1988, Rosenberg introduced legislation to prohibit the 's  from investigating the library records of foreigners without a subpoena. The bill unanimously passed by the Maryland General Assembly and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn December 1996, Rosenberg said he supported a bill that would test welfare applicants for drug use, saying that it would deter parents of young children from using drugs and incentivize treatment. In July 2019, he said he opposed a  proposal to limit  benefits to 130 percent of the federal poverty level. During the 2020 legislative session, Rosenberg introduced legislation to create a state job training program for people who lost their SNAP benefits as a result of the proposal.\n\nDuring the 2001 legislative session, Rosenberg supported a bill to ban , which passed and became law. In February 2012, he voted for the , which legalized .\n\nIn 2008, Rosenberg supported a statewide referendum to legalize  in Maryland. During the 2013 legislative session, he introduced legislation to extend early voting through Sunday before the election.\n\nIn August 2017, Rosenberg condemned the  in , calling it \"horrendous\".\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Rosenberg voted to repeal \"\" as the official state anthem.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Rosenberg introduced legislation that would require companies that submit bids to take over the  and  Lines to disclose whether, and how, they were involved in . The bill would have only impacted French railway company  (whose subsidiary, , submitted a bid to operate the lines), whom Rosenberg says should \"still be held liable for the damage done to Holocaust victims\". The bill was amended to require companies with Holocaust links to speed up the digitization of their archives and signed into law by Governor . In January 2014, after Keolis submitted a bid to build and operate the , Rosenberg said he would not expand the 2011 law to cover Purple Line bidders, saying that the law had \"served its purpose\" after SNCF digitized its  archives.\n\nIn 2022, Rosenberg introduced a bill to require the  to seek federal approval for an east-west rail line in .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James J. Tarlau''' (born May 23, 1948) is an American politician from , a retired union organizer, and a member of the Democratic Party. He was elected to represent District 47A in the  in 2014 and served one term.\n\n\nTarlau was born and raised in New York City. He attended , where he worked to \"radicalize\" the institution. He was suspended for protesting a visit from Nixon's Interior Secretary  in March 1970. He graduated with an A.B. in history the same year after completing a 158-page long senior thesis titled \"Postwar Reaction and the Foreign Policy of the American Labor Movement\" but the suspension prevented him from participating in graduation ceremonies with his class. After stints driving trucks and a cab, Tarlau earned a master's degree in computer science from  and another master's degree in Labor Relations from . He raised his family in New Jersey and worked to effect political change through union organizing. In 2000 he moved to Maryland, where he served eight years on the  City Council and worked as assistant to the vice president of the . After winning the Democratic primary for a seat in District 47A of the Maryland House of Delegates, Tarlau retired from his union job.\n\n\n'''', Congresswoman , Maryland Lt. Gov. , Maryland State Sen.  and Maryland Del.  endorsed Tarlau's campaign for the House. He ran on a progressive platform, including:\n* Mandating the Geographic Cost of Education Index as a part of the state aid for education formula\n* Promotion of clean energy job projects\n* Passing a $15 minimum wage\n* Changing the tax code so companies headquartered in other states have to pay taxes on their Maryland revenue (combined tax reporting)\n\nWhen a  lobbyist made news by saying publicly that the incoming class of legislators was \"more anti-business\" than their outgoing colleagues, Tarlau was one of 17 newly elected members of the House who signed a letter disputing the characterization.\n\n\nTarlau was appointed to the Ways and Means Committee at the beginning of his first term in the House. His first legislative action was to introduce bill PG 417-15, which would require counties to reveal the criteria they use to calculate each municipality's tax differential.\n\n\n*'''2014 Democratic primary election for the House of Delegates, District 47A.'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 general election for the House of Delegates, District 47A.'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carl W. Jackson''' (born October 27, 1984) is an American politician who serves as a  member of the  representing , which is in .\n\n\nJackson was born in  on October 27, 1984. He graduated from  in Baltimore County, Maryland and attended  in , where he earned a  degree in business administration in 2008 and a  degree in 2017. He worked as an administrative analyst for the  and served as a member of the  Staff Senate from 2014 to 2019.\n\nJackson was called to politics by President  exhortation at the end of his second term that young people interested in making a change should run for office. He entertained his political appetite by volunteering for the campaign of  in the .\n\nJackson was an unsuccessful candidate for the Maryland House of Delegates in , a district that was seen as one of the swingiest of the state's swing districts. He prevailed in the Democratic primary, receiving 24.8 percent of the vote, but was defeated in the general election by a margin of 570 votes. After his election loss, he said that he was \"so depressed he didn't know what to do.\" In December 2018, Baltimore County executive-elect  invited him to co-chair the public safety workgroup for his transition team and he also later joined the Baltimore County Pedestrian and Bicycle Committee at the suggestion of  Cathy Bevins.\n\nIn September 2019, following the resignation of state delegate , who had resigned to take a job with the Baltimore County government, Jackson applied to fill his vacancy. His candidacy was endorsed by Olszewski, state senator , Bromwell, state delegate , and Bevins. In October 2019, Governor  appointed Jackson to the House of Delegates following the recommendations of the Baltimore County Democratic Central Committee.\n\n\nJackson was sworn in on October 21, 2019, to fill a vacancy in District 8 of the . He is the first African-American legislator to represent the district. He was assigned to the House Economics Matters Committee and is a member of the  and the Legislative Transit Caucus.\n\n\n\nJackson introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would make reporting false statements to police officers on the aspects of a person's identity a misdemeanor punishable under the state's hate crime statute by a $5,000 fine or three years of jail time. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 130–6.\n\n\nJackson co-sponsored legislation introduced in the 2021 legislative session that bans registered sex offenders from being students inside public schools. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on May 18, 2021.\n\nJackson introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would require schools to release air quality reports.\n\n\nIn February 2020, Jackson joined six other Democrats in voting against legislation that would mandate s on private sales and transfers of shotguns and rifles.\n\n\nIn February 2021, Jackson joined eight other Democrats in voting against overriding a gubernatorial veto on a bill that would levy a tax on  on large tech companies.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Eric M. Bromwell''' (born December 12, 1976) is an  from  and a member of the . Bromwell represented district 8 in the  from January 2003 to September 2019. In September 2019 he resigned from the  to serve as opioid strategy coordinator for  .\n\n\nEric Bromwell was born in Baltimore, Maryland on December 12, 1976.\n\n\nEric Bromwell received his education from the following institutions:\n*Graduate Studies, , 2000–present\n*BA, English, , 1998\n\n\nEric Bromwell has been a member of the following committees:\n*Member, Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2005–present\n*Member, Maryland Legislative Sportsmens Caucus, 2003–present\n*Chair, Baltimore County Delegation, 2007-2010\n*Member, Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer, 2007\n*Member, Joint Legislative Task Force on Universal Access to Quality and Affordable Health Care, 2005-2007\n*Member, Maryland Medicaid Advisory Committee, 2004-2009\n\n\nEric Bromwell has been a member of the following organizations:\n*Member, The Grunwald Club, 2009–present\n*Member, Charles H. Hickey, Jr., School Advisory Board, 2005–present\n*Member, Maryland Historical Society, 2005–present\n*Member, Linwood Center Advisory Board, 2004–present\n*President, Minte Home Owners Association, 2003–present\n*Co-Chair, Allied Community Services, 2002–present\n*Member, Baltimore County Civic and Social Club\n*Member, Baltimore County Young Democrats\n*Member, Parkville Jaycees\n*Member, Perry Hall Middle School Parent-Teacher Association\n*Board of Governors Member, Sixth District Democratic Club\n\n\nBromwell was born in  and raised Catholic.     "pages": }\n\n'''Mary-Dulany James''' (born February 1, 1960) is an  who has represented  in the  since 2023. She was previously a member of the  in the  for sixteen years, representing  and  Counties along the  corridor. Mary-Dulany James represented district 34A, formerly district 34, for 16 years having first been elected in 1998.\n\nIn 2014 and 2018, James unsuccessfully ran for the  in District 34. In 2022, she launched her third bid for the state senate seat, this time defeating Deputy Secretary of the Maryland Department of Disabilities and former state delegate  in the general election.\n\n\nJames was born in , to father , then a  for , and mother Margaret James, a homemaker. She grew up and still lives on her family's farm in Harford County, and attended  and the  where she earned a  in psychology with honors in 1981. James attended the , earning a  degree with honors in 1986. While studying for the bar exam, she clerked for Judge  in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland. She was admitted to  in 1986. She worked for law firms in Baltimore, then set up her own practice in Harford County where she lived.\n\n\n\nJames ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in 1998, seeking to replace one of two outgoing state delegates in District 34 ( and , both of whom ran for state senate). She won the Democratic primary with 22 percent of the vote, and later won the general election on November 3, 1998, with 18 percent of the vote. James was re-elected to the newly redistricted  ( and  counties) in 2002, and was subsequently re-elected in 2006, and 2010.\n\n\n*Member, Appropriations Committee, 1999-2014\n**oversight committee on personnel, 1999–2003\n**oversight committee on program open space & agricultural land preservation, 1999–2002\n**vice-chair, transportation & the environment subcommittee, 2003–2006, member, 1999–2006\n**chair, oversight committee on pensions, 2003–2006, member, 2003-2014\n**chair, health & human resources subcommittee, 2007-2014\n*Joint Subcommittee on Program Open Space and Agricultural Preservation, 2003–2015\n*Special Joint Committee on Pensions, 2003–Present, house chair, 2003–2006\n*Member, Joint Committee on Base Realignment and Closure, 2007–2011\n*Member, Joint Committee on the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area, 2003–07\n*Chair, Harford County Delegation, 2001–02, vice-chair, 1999–2000\n*Member, Maryland Green Caucus, 1999-2014\n*Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 1999–2015, co-chair, legislative committee, 2005–2015\n*Member Maryland Rural Caucus, 2002-2014\n*Maryland Bicycle and Pedestrian Caucus, 2003-2014\n*Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2005-2014\n*Member, National Conference of State Legislatures \n**Member, economic development, trade & cultural affairs committee, 2005–2007\n**Member, labor & economic development committee, 2007–2015\n\n\n\n\n\n;2014\n\n\nIn June 2013, James said that she was considering a run for the  in District 34, after state senator  said she would not run for re-election in 2014. At the time, James was the only Democratic member of the Harford County delegation. James filed to run for the state senate seat in November 2013, and faced former state senator  in the Democratic primary, who she defeated in the June 2014 primary election by a 2-to-1 margin. She faced  challenger  in the general election, and sought to position herself as an independent Democrat, noting her votes against gas- and sales-tax increases. James was defeated by Cassilly in the general election on November 3, 2014, receiving 42.7 percent of the vote to Cassilly's 57.2 percent.\n\n;2018\n\nIn 2018, James filed to run for the Maryland Senate in District 34, seeking a rematch between her and incumbent state senator Bob Cassilly. She faced former state delegate  in the Democratic primary election, which she won by a 3-to-1 margin. James lost to Cassilly in a tight general election on November 6, 2018, receiving 49.7 percent of the vote to Cassilly's 50.1 percent, or by a 189 vote margin out of 48,788 votes cast.\n\n;2022\n\nIn January 2022, James launched her third bid for the Maryland Senate in District 34, seeking to succeed state senator Bob Cassilly, who  in 2022. She defeated state delegate  in the Democratic primary election on July 19, 2022, by a 2-to-1 margin, and faced Republican challenger  in the general election.\n\nIn the general election, James received financial support from President of the Maryland Senate  and the Senate Democratic Caucus. She also accused her opponent, Republican , of being a carpetbagger, noting that he previously represented Baltimore County in the Maryland House of Delegates before moving to Harford County. James defeated Miele in a tight general election on November 8, receiving 50.55 percent of the vote to Miele's 49.24 percent, or by a margin of 591 votes out of 45,223 votes cast. She is the first Democrat to represent District 34 in the Maryland Senate since 1994. It was the closest race in the .\n\n\n\nJames was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 11, 2023. She is a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee and the Executive Nominations Committee.\n\n\nJames was married to her husband, Brian Feeney, before the two divorced. Together, they had three children and lived in Havre de Grace, Maryland.\n\nOn September 30, 2018, James' daughter, Evelyn Ann James Feeney, suddenly died. This led to James stopping all campaign activities leading up to the general election.\n\n\nWhile in the Maryland House of Delegates, James was considered a  to . In January 2012, she formed a Blue Dog caucus in the state legislature along with other centrist Democratic members of the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\n\nIn February 2013, James voted for a bill that would allow a surcharge of up to $2 a month on residential natural gas bills to pay for new pipelines and distribution system upgrades. The bill passed the Maryland House of Delegates by a vote of 119-18, and later passed the state senate by a vote of 34-13.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, James was one of 18 Democratic state delegates to vote against the Firearm Safety Act of 2013, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nIn April 2014, James expressed concerns regarding the state's overhaul of its health exchange to adopt technology from , saying that there were \"huge budgetary implications\" in switching to the Connecticut model.\n\n\nIn 2005, James was one of 36 Democratic state delegates to vote for a bill that would legalize slot machines at four locations in the state. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a 71-66 vote.\n\nIn 2006, James voted for a bill that would create a ballot referendum to legalize . The bill failed to pass out of the Maryland House of Delegates on a 61-78 vote. In 2012, she voted against the , which legalized same-sex marriage in Maryland.\n\n\nIn April 2004, James was one of two Democratic state delegates to switch their no votes to yes to revive a $1 billion tax plan proposed by  , after House Appropriations Committee Chairman  persuaded her to change her vote. She later defended her vote change, saying that she \"thought it deserved a full hearing on the House floor\".\n\nIn November 2007, James voted for a bill that raised corporate and income taxes, and voted against another bill that increased the state sales tax, car tilting tax, and hotel tax.\n\nIn May 2012, James was one of 18 Democratic state delegates to vote against a bill that raised $300 million in tax hikes.\n\nIn March 2013, James was one of 22 Democratic state delegates to vote against a bill that would raise the state's gas tax and index future increases to inflation to replenish the state's transportation fund.\n\n\nIn March 2010, James said she opposed a bill that would give  to librarians, saying that she thought it was inappropriate \"for the state to be telling the local governments how to conduct themselves\".\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael Anthony Peroutka''' (born 1952) is an American  politician, lawyer, and  activist from . He was the  nominee for  in , and was the  candidate for president in .\n\nPeroutka is a former member of the , a  and  organization designated by the  as a hate group. Peroutka is known for his pro- views, and has said that he is \"still angry\" that . Peroutka has voiced support for  about the , falsely claiming that the attacks were an \"inside job\" accomplished using explosives.\n\nPeroutka attended  and the . He was the chairman of the Constitution Party of Maryland and a member of the executive committee of the Constitution Party National Committee. In 2014, he became a  and won election to the County Council of , representing District 5.\n\nHe is of .\n\n\nIn the , he was the 's candidate. His campaign slogan was \"God, Family, Republic\" and heavily featured  and  themes. His running mate was  minister . Peroutka gained support from many , and was endorsed by the America First Party and . Peroutka was also endorsed by the  and supported by a group called \"Southerners for Peroutka\". Peroutka accepted the endorsement from the League at their 2004 national convention. Far-right radio host and conspiracy theorist  stated that he would be voting for Peroutka.\n\nPeroutka appeared on the far-right radio show '''' to promote his campaign, describing it as a \"Christian/Constitutionalist radio program\" and \"a great blessing to our cause\". Paleoconservative political commentator  stated on the September 7, 2004, edition of '''' that he was considering voting for Peroutka. The November 8, 2004, issue of '''' contained endorsements by  and  (the latter having founded the party Peroutka represented). Peroutka received just over 0.01% of the national popular vote, finishing fifth nationally with almost 150,000 votes. This was a similar showing to previous Constitution Party candidacies of Howard Phillips, and made the party the only third party to increase its share of the vote in 2004.   politician 's support for Peroutka's candidacy was used in a 2013  by opponent .\n\n\nPeroutka is a  who holds views outside the mainstream of U.S. political discourse, even within the modern Republican Party. He said that government officials must \"take a biblical worldview and apply it to civil law and government\" and referred to the principle of  as a \"great lie.\" Peroutka views public schools as a Communist plot; he supports  and opposes government funding for education, stating that it is \"the 10th plank in the Communist Manifesto.\" He rejects laws and constitutional protections protecting abortion and . \n\nIn 2006, he voted in favor of disaffiliating the  from the Constitution Party due to their allowance for abortion in certain circumstances. In 2012, the '''' reported that Peroutka was the single-largest donor to 's 2012 campaign for the Alabama Supreme Court, having contributed $50,000 of the total $78,000 received by Moore until December 31, 2011.\n\nPeroutka is a former board member of the , a  organization that is  as a . He was a member of the group's board of directors from 2012 to 2014. In 2012, the  called Peroutka an \"active white supremacist and secessionist sympathizer\" due to his ties to the League. Peroutka told '''' that he \"continues to be a proud member of the League of the South,\" since it \"has a belief that the central government is too large, too spend-thrift and too out-of-control,\" but he called HRC's characterization of him as a white-supremacist sympathizer \"absurd\" and \"not at all true.\" In 2012, a video showed Peroutka asking a group to stand for the national anthem, and then leading them in the ''de facto''  anthem, \"\". In 2013, he stated that \"all elevation or denigration of individuals or groups based on skin color is immoral and shameful.\" In October 2014, during his campaign for the Anne Arundel County Council, Peroutka announced that he had resigned from the League of the South board of directors and was no longer a member after discovering statements made by members that were \"contrary to [his] beliefs\". He declined to disavow the group during his 2022 campaign for Maryland attorney general.\n\n\nIn 2006, the Maryland Constitution Party disaffiliated from the national party along with other state parties following a schism at the national party's 2006 convention, in which it failed to disaffiliate the Nevada party despite its chairman and gubernatorial candidate's support for legal abortion in some cases. Peroutka stated, \"At this point I could not, in good faith, represent the Constitution Party nor endorse any of its candidates. Unless serious changes occur, I could not run for President in 2008.\"\n\nPeroutka's supporters, however, collected enough signatures to get his name approved as a  in Georgia for the 2008 presidential election.\n\n\n\nIn February 2014, Peroutka switched his voter registration from Constitution Party to  and filed to run for a seat on the Anne Arundel County Council as well as a seat on the county's Republican Central Committee. Peroutka won the seat on the Central Committee, becoming an official representative of the Republican Party in . Peroutka also won the primary election for county council from District 5 on June 24, defeating a number of other Republican candidates, including the incumbent councilman Dick Ladd. He won by 38 votes over Maureen Carr-York to become the Republican nominee in the November 2014 general election. Peroutka won in the general election with 53 percent of the vote and a margin of victory of nearly 1,900 votes over his Democratic opponent. His district covered , , , and . Peroutka, along with the rest of the council, was sworn in on December 1, 2014.\n\n\nRunning for reelection from District 5 in June 2018, Peroutka lost the Republican primary to candidate Amanda Fiedler, 53 percent to 47 percent.\n\n\nIn February 2022, Peroutka filed to run for . He ran on the slogan \"Liberty forever, Mandates never!\" and a platform of opposing , fear of crime and immigration, election integrity, and opposition to abortion. Peroutka ran on a platform in which he prioritize what he called \"God-given, constitutionally-protected rights\" over state and federal laws, specifically those on  and . He also pledged to take legal action against Governor  and local health officers for actions they took to slow the spread of COVID-19. Peroutka won the Republican  on July 19, 2022, with 55.0 percent of the vote over his challenger Jim Shalleck. Peroutka's victory made him one of several extremist candidates nominated by the Republican Party in 2022. \n\nDuring the general election, he said that he would accept the results of the election if they \"appear to be lawful and legal\", but supported legal efforts by state delegate and Republican   to block the counting of mail-in ballots ahead of Election Day. Peroutka was defeated by Democratic   in the general election on November 8, 2022. On November 10, Peroutka said he would not concede the election to Brown, claiming without evidence that \"many odd and suspicious incidents were reported by poll watchers, and more reports are being gathered today.\"\n\n\nIn May 2014, Peroutka, acting on behalf of the Elizabeth Streb Peroutka foundation, a charity he and his brother Stephen established and named after their mother, donated an  skeleton to the , a 70,000-square-foot museum in , that promotes the pseudoscientific  explanation of the origins of the universe put forth in .\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Christopher B. Shank''' (born June 30, 1972) is an American politician who has served in a variety of roles within , including Deputy Chief of Staff and Chief Legislative Officer to Governor . He has previously served in the  representing the 2nd district in , including a stint as Senate minority .\n\n\nShank graduated from  in , and later attended  where he received his B.A. (history) in 1994. He graduated a . He later attained his M.A. (political management) from the Graduate School of Political Management at the  in 1998. He was the valedictorian and received the Howard Paley Academic Excellence Award.\n\n\n\nAfter college, Shank was a legislative assistant to the Washington County Delegation. He served in this role from 1994 to 1998. Along with being a delegate he is also an adjunct professor at the Graduate School of Political Management at George Washington University.\n\nHe is also a member of the Advisory Committee of the Cold Weather Homeless Shelter of Washington County, serving since 1997. He was formerly on the board of directors for the Washington County Chapter of the . Shank is a  the  (ALEC), serving as Maryland state leader.\n\nIn 2008, Shank was given a teaching post in George Washington University's Summer Scholars Program. Shank taught a course on election politics. During the 10-day program he lectured on his experience in campaigning as well as worked with students to simulate a mock campaign.\n\nIn January 2010, Shank announced his intention to challenge long-serving state senator  based on charges that Munson was \"too liberal.\" On September 14, 2010, Shank defeated Munson in the Republican primary election, winning the party's nomination. Shank received 57.05% of the vote compared to Munson's 42.05%.\n\nOn January 13, 2015, Shank was appointed as director of the Governor's Office of Crime Control and Prevention and resigned his state senate seat eight days later.\n\nIn 2016, Shank was promoted to the Deputy Chief of Staff of Maryland.\n\n\n* 2005 - voted for slots (HB1361)\n\n\n*'''2006 race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 2B'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 2B'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 2B'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Diana M. Fennell''' (born August 6, 1967) is an American politician who represents  in the . She previously served as the mayor of  from 2000 to 2010 and as a member of the Colmar Manor town council from 1995 to 2000.\n\n\nFennell was born on August 6, 1967, in , where she graduated from . In 2004, she attended the Academy for Excellence in Local Governance at the  School of Public Policy.\n\nFennell moved from  to  in the early 1990s. In 1994, a neighbor urged her to seek public office. She successfully ran for Colmar Manor town council and was sworn in 1995. In 2000, she was elected as the town's mayor, where she served until 2010.\n\nIn 2002, Fennell ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in . She came in fourth place in the primary election, receiving 13.1 percent of the vote.\n\nIn 2014, Fennell again ran for the Maryland House of Delegates, receiving the backing of state senator  during the primary election. She won the Democratic primary alongside , receiving 23.7 percent of the vote and defeating incumbent state delegate . She received 52.1 percent of the vote in the general election.\n\n\n\nFennell was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015, and was assigned to the House Ways and Means Committee. In her committee, she serves on the election law subcommittee, the finance resources subcommittee, and the revenues subcommittee. She is also a member of the , Women Legislators of Maryland, and the .\n\n\n\nFennell voted for legislation introduced in the 2019 legislative session that would lift a ban on developer contributions in county political races in .\n\n\nFennell supported legislation introduced during the 2018 legislative session that would reform the state's Medical Cannabis Commission and ensure diversity for proprietors in the industry.\n\n\nFennell introduced legislation during the 2019 legislative session that would raise the minimum wage to  in 2023 and phase out the state's  by 2026. During committee hearings, the bill was amended to push back the full-on effective date to 2025 and to remove provisions to automatically increase the wage based on the national . The bill passed as amended and received a gubernatorial veto override on March 28, 2019.\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 47th District (Democratic Primary)'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 47A District (Democratic Primary)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 47A District (General Election)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2018 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 47A District (Democratic Primary)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2018 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 47A District (General Election)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Stephen S. Hershey Jr.''' (born May 2, 1964) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  from  since 2013, and as the minority leader of the Maryland Senate since January 11, 2023. A member of the , he previously represented the district in the  from 2011 to 2013.\n\n\nHershey was born in  to father Steve Hershey, a sportswriter for '''' and '''', and mother Gail Hershey. He was raised in , where he graduated from . Hershey later attended  and graduated from  in 1987, earning a  degree in 1987, and  in 2002 with a  degree. Hershey moved to  in 1996.\n\n\nHershey worked as a vice president for project management for the  from 1993 to 2003, afterwards serving as a member of the Queen Anne's County Economic Development Commission until 2006. Following the election of Governor , he worked as an assistant secretary for the  from 2003 to 2004, and the  from 2004 to 2006. Since 2006, Hershey has served as the vice president of .\n\nHershey first got involved in politics in 2002 as the president of the Queen Anne's County Republican Club. That year, he unsuccessfully ran for the Queen Anne's County Board of Commissioners in District 2, losing to Rodney Niedomanski in the Republican primary.\n\n\n\nIn 2010, Hershey filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 36, challenging incumbent state delegate . He won the Republican primary in September 2010, edging out Sossi by 124 votes, or a margin of 1.2 percent, and ran unopposed in the general election. Hershey was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 12, 2011. He was a member of the Economic Matters Committee during his entire tenure, and served as the Deputy Minority Whip in 2013.\n\nIn August 2013, following the resignation of Senate minority leader , Hershey applied to serve the remainder of Pipkin's term in the . The Republican Central Committees of  and  counties voted to nominate him, while the Queen Anne's and  Republican Central Committees voted to nominate his opponent,  In September, Governor  appointed Hershey to the seat over Smigiel, and he was sworn in on October 1.\n\nHershey served on the Judicial Proceedings Committee from 2013 to 2015, afterwards serving as a member of the Finance Committee. He has also served as a member of the Executive Nominations Committee and the Rules Committee since 2023. In January 2015, Hershey was elected to serve as the Senate minority whip. In this capacity, he worked with the  in its unsuccessful \"Drive for Five\" campaign during the , during which the party only picked up one seat. Hershey did not run for re-election to this position in October 2020, and was succeeded by . In November 2022, following the  in which Republicans lost two seats, Hershey was elected to serve as the Senate minority leader, replacing .\n\nHershey ran for a full four-year term in , during which he faced a  from former state delegate Richard Sossi, whom he defeated with 56 percent of the vote. During his campaign, the  filed a lawsuit against Hershey, alleging that he was infringing on the company's trademarked logo design in campaign materials. The company added that Hershey had used its trademarked logo during his 2002 and 2010 campaigns, during which the Hershey Company issued  orders to stop Hershey from using it. Hershey contested the company's lawsuit, arguing that a ruling for the company would infringe on his constitutional rights. In July 2014, Judge  ruled for the Hershey Company, issuing a preliminary injunction prohibiting Hershey from using the infringing campaign signs.\n\n\n and Lieutenant Governor , 2017]]\n\n\nHershey supports the deregulation of Maryland's farming industry. During the 2015 legislative session, he introduced a bill to reduce penalties for illegal oyster poaching, which passed but did not become law.\n\n\nDuring his 2002 commissioner campaign, Hershey said he supported creating a liaison position for emergency services in the county.\n\nIn 2013, Hershey voted against a bill to abolish the death penalty in Maryland.\n\nIn November 2023, ahead of the 2024 legislative session, Hershey introduced a package of \"tough on crime\" bills, including legislation to increase penalties for gun crimes and to repeal the Juvenile Justice Reform Act, which restricted the state's ability to charge juveniles for most offenses.\n\n\nHershey supports the Broadening Options and Opportunities for Students Today (BOOST) program, which provides state-funded scholarships to low-income students attending s, and spoke out against proposals to cut funding for the program in 2023. He also opposes the  and has proposed cutting back spending on the education reform package so that the state only focuses on its most important components.\n\nDuring his 2002 commissioner campaign, Hershey proposed providing s and improving benefits to retain teachers in the county.\n\nIn 2019, Hershey opposed a bill that would allow county school boards to set their own academic calendars, reversing an executive order by Governor  that mandated a post- start for public schools.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Hershey introduced a bill to extend voting rights to the student member of the .\n\n\n\nIn September 2014, Hershey criticized the bay restoration agreement between Maryland and Pennsylvania, saying that it stunted development on the  and calling the $15 billion cost associated with cleaning up the  an \"unfunded mandate\". He has called the Conowingo Dam one of the largest point sources of  in the state and supports requiring , who operates the dam, to dredge the sediment behind the dam to reduce runoff into the .\n\nIn 2015, amid proposals to build a  off the shore of , Hershey introduced a bill to give the county the authority to veto any large-scale wind project in their jurisdiction.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Hershey opposed the Clean Energy Jobs Act, which would require half of the state's electricity to come from renewable sources by 2030, and questioned whether the bill would create jobs in Maryland. He later expressed disappointment with Governor 's decision to allow the bill to become law without his signature.\n\nIn 2023, Hershey said he opposed the Clean Trucks Act, a bill that would require the  to adopt a rule to phase out the sale of medium and heavy-duty gas-powered vehicles in Maryland. He also scrutinized the POWER Act, which increased the state's  goals to 8.5 gigawatts, and unsuccessfully sought to amend the bill to prevent its costs from being passed down to consumers.\n\n\nHershey opposes , calling it an \"unnecessary burden\" for Maryland businesses. During the 2014 legislative session, he introduced a bill that would exempt counties who use \"best available technology septic systems\" to be exempt from the rain tax.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Hershey supported a measure to provide tax breaks to households that earn more than $150,000 annually, which he claimed represented the state's small business owners.\n\nIn January 2017, Hershey said he would support allowing citizens initiatives on budgetary matters, including newly imposed taxes.\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Hershey voted against a bill to raise the state's minimum wage to $10.10 an hour. In 2019, he voted against a bill to raise it again to , arguing that legislators should instead cut taxes to increase workers' income. In May 2020, amid the , Hershey called on the  to freeze the minimum wage at $11 an hour for two years.\n\nIn 2021, Hershey opposed a bill to impose a tax on .\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Hershey introduced a bill to eliminate all es for retirees. During debate on a bill to decouple state transit fares from inflation, he introduced an amendment to decouple the state's es from inflation, which was rejected in a 27-18 vote.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session and following the , Hershey was one of three Republicans to vote for a bill to ban s in Maryland.\n\nIn 2019, Hershey voted against a bill to abolish the state's Handgun Permit Review Board, which handled  applications.\n\nIn June 2022, Hershey said he supported the 's decision in ''''. During the 2023 legislative session, he opposed the Gun Safety Act, which banned  near schools, government property, construction areas, or entertainment venues, and from entering someone's property while carrying a firearm unless given permission by the owner, calling it \"unconstitutional\". In September, Hershey celebrated a federal court ruling that struck down certain provisions of the Gun Safety Act.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Hershey supported legislation to assist displaced workers following hospital closures. He opposed a bill that would allow the attorney general of Maryland to impose civil penalties onto companies that gouge drug prices, which he claimed would harm competition, and a bill to provide workers with seven days of  a year.\n\nIn 2021, Hershey introduced legislation that would allow pharmacists to switch name brands. The bill passed and became law. He also supported a bill banning medical debt collection agencies from garnishing the wages or placing s on homes of people who owed medical debt, and limiting payments made toward medical debt at five percent of a person's income.\n\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Hershey was one of three senators to vote against a bill to decriminalize . In 2019, he was appointed to a task force on developing policy for legalizing .\n\n\nIn 2012, Hershey served as a delegate to the , pledged to . In 2016, he unsuccessfully ran to serve as an alternate delegate to the , pledged to . Hershey attended the 2017  of , and would later use social media to criticize Trump in now-deleted tweets. He opposed impeaching and removing Trump following the , saying it would \"undermine the efforts to ensure a peaceful transfer of power\".\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Hershey voted against a bill that would give the  the power to pursue cases against the federal government.\n\nIn 2018, Hershey opposed a bill requiring presidential candidates to release their s to appear on the ballot in Maryland.\n\nIn August 2019, following mass shootings in , Hershey released statements on  calling the incident \"an act of terrorism\" and the shooter a , and called on Trump to recognize the \"white supremacy problem in America\". He also expressed support for a primary challenge against Ohio state legislator  after she claimed that the  was caused by \" advocates\".\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Hershey voted against the , which legalized .\n\nIn May 2015, following the , Hershey visited neighborhoods damaged by fires and looting during the protests.\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Hershey sought to kill a bill that would restore voting rights for felons on parole. In June 2020, he wrote a letter to the Maryland State Board of Elections following Maryland's June 2 primary election, which was conducted largely using , to express concern about potential  if mail-in ballots were used in the general election. In 2021, Hershey supported legislation that would require signature verification for mail-in ballots.\n\nIn 2021, Hershey voted for a bill to repeal \"\" as the official state song.\n\nDuring debate on the Abortion Care Access Act in 2022, Hershey introduced an amendment that would restrict the facilities that could provide abortion services; the amendment was rejected. In 2023, he criticized a bill creating a  on codifying '''' into the , calling it \"performative progressivism\".\n\n\nIn October 2010, Hershey criticized the state's public transportation system, arguing that private industry would \"manage and provide this service more cost efficiently than the government\".\n\nIn June 2015, Hershey said he supported Governor 's decision to shift funding for the  toward road widening projects in other jurisdictions around the state, especially .\n\nDuring the 2016 legislative session, Hershey opposed a bill that would require the  to use a scoring system when deciding which transportation projects to prioritize, claiming that the bill would force rural transportation projects to compete with urban transit projects. He introduced an amendment to the bill to create a separate scoring system for transit projects, which was rejected in a 28-17 vote.\n\nIn 2019, Hershey opposed a bill that would give  veto power over a proposed second , which he said would prevent any bridge project from being completed. In April 2022, he proposed replacing the current Bay Bridge spans with a single eight-lane bridge.\n\n\nHershey was married to his wife, Wendy; they are currently divorced. He lives in .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Elizabeth Bobo''' (born December 21, 1943) is an  from  and a member of the . She served as  Executive and in the . Bobo was the first and only female , serving from 1986 to 1990.\n\n\nBobo was born in  on December 21, 1943. She graduated from  in Baltimore before earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in literature from the  and a Juris Doctor degree from the . Bobo was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1992 and practiced as an attorney before her election to the House of Delegates.\n\n\nBobo served one term as Howard County Executive from 1986 to 1990. She was Howard County's first and only female executive. In 1987, Bobo partnered with developer  to form a business outreach program.  defeated Bobo's bid for reelection as county executive in 1990. In 1993, Bobo married former planning board member and councilperson Lloyd G. Knowles.\n\nIn 1994, Bobo was elected to the . She served four terms there, representing District 12B in .\n\nAs a member of the House of Delegates, Bobo voted in favor of increasing the sales tax whilst simultaneously reducing income tax rates for some income brackets in the Tax Reform Act of 2007 (HB2). She voted in favor of in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6). She served on the Environmental Matters Committee, and was noted for distinguishing herself as an advocate for protection of the natural environment.\n\nDuring the , Bobo supported the candidacy of . She served as one of the state's ten electors pledged to Obama in the , and cast her vote for him along with the other nine on December 15.\n\nIn 2012, Bobo announced her decision not to seek reelection in 2014.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Joseph Corey Cluster''' (born July 5, 1979) is a former member of the , representing the 8th district in . He was appointed to fill the vacancy of former Delegate , his father, on September 6, 2016. He married Kourtney Elizabeth Hamel, of Forest Hill, MD, on May 22, 2021.\n\n\nDelegate Cluster graduated from  in Northeast Baltimore County in 1997. He attend  and  where he received is BA in Social Science in 2002.\n\n\nDelegate Cluster first got involved in politics interning for Congressman  during his last two years of college at Towson University. After graduating he was given the opportunity to run the  field operations for the 2002 election. Afterward, he went on to work for Lt. Governor  as Director of External Affairs in his office until 2007.\n\nIn October 2013 he was named Executive Director of the Maryland Republican Party. The Party was $150,000 in debt and only had $10,000 cash on hand when he took over, but alongside Chairman Diana Waterman, Cluster helped raise over $1.8 million dollars the following year. This helped  win one of the biggest upset elections in the country in 2014. In 2016, Joe was appointed to fill the vacancy of former Delegate John Cluster, by Governor Larry Hogan.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Edward R. Reilly''' (born November 28, 1949) is an . He was a  member of the , appointed by Governor  to represent  after State Senator  resigned. He then ran and was elected in November 2010 to his first full term.\n\n\nReilly graduated from  in . Reilly later received his  in banking and finance in 1972 from  in .\n\nReilly has been a member of the U.S.  since 1974 and was president of the Park-Adelphi Jaycees from 1976 to 1977 and is a past-president of College Park Jaycees. He is also a volunteer for the , and a past-president of the Anne Arundel County Life Underwriters Association. Reilly is a  representative and owns his own insurance agency in .\n\nReilly served on the Anne Arundel County Council representing District 7 from December 2002 to June 2009.\n\n\nReilly was selected by the Anne Arundel County Republican Central Committee to replace the retiring  who retired mid-term. He was sworn into the Maryland Senate on June 22, 2009. In 2021, he was elected to serve as the Deputy Minority Leader of the Maryland Senate.\n\nIn 2022, the 's Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics found that Reilly broke with the standards of the body after he told a constituent he planned to pull a bill they both worked on because she donated to his opponent's campaign.\n\nDespite initially filing to run for re-election, Reilly announced he would not seek re-election to the Maryland Senate on April 18, 2022.\n\n\n\nIn 2017, Reilly voted to uphold Governor Larry Hogan's veto of a bill to increase the use of  in Maryland, saying the bill would levy a \"hidden tax\" on consumers.\n\nIn 2021, Reilly was one of two Republican state Senators to vote in favor of the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2021, a bill that aimed to cut Maryland's greenhouse gas emissions by 60 percent by 2030.\n\n\nReilly identifies as an \"advocate of \". During the 2012 legislative session, he introduced legislation to ban . In 2015, Reilly was one of three Republican members of the Maryland General Assembly to vote for a bill to decriminalize marijuana possession.\n\n\nDuring a debate on legislation to raise Maryland's minimum wage to $10.10 an hour by 2018, Reilly introduced three amendments, including one that would have raised the minimum wage just once to $9 an hour in July 2015. All three amendments were rejected.\n\n\nReilly was the only Republican to vote in favor of the Police Reform and Accountability Act of 2021.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Reilly introduced legislation that call for a  that, if approved, would require the  to be drawn with respect to the boundaries, compactness, and commonality of populations. During the 2021 special legislative session, he introduced an amendment to the state's new congressional redistricting plan that would exchange the maps, drawn by the Legislative Redistricting Advisory Commission, with ones drawn by the Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission. The amendment was rejected by a vote of 15-32. In 2022, Reilly introduced an amendment to the state's legislative redistricting plan to again swap out the LRAC-drawn maps with those proposed by the MCRC, which was rejected by a 14-32 vote. He later voted against the legislative maps.\n\n\nDuring a debate on legislation to legalize , Reilly introduced an amendment to change the bill's effective date from October to January 2013, which did not receive a vote. He later motioned to delay the bill to gain more time to prepare amendments. In 2015, Reilly voted against legislation that would allow transgender people to change the gender on their s.\n\nIn 2013, Reilly was one of two Republicans to vote in favor of a bill to repeal the  in Maryland.\n\nIn 2014, Reilly voted against legislation to outlaw  in Maryland, suggesting that the state should work on alcohol education instead of restricting sales of booze.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Reilly introduced a resolution calling for \"female monthly cycle tracking for adolescent girls\" to be added to school health curriculum, which was met with criticism from reproductive health activists who called the proposal invasive and inappropriate. He later withdrew the resolution.\n\n\nThe nine-mile portion of  from Crofton to Annapolis known as Defense Highway was officially renamed after Reilly on October 25, 2023. Reilly worked on solutions to flooding along the road in 2018 and 2019.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jazz M. Lewis''' (born February 26, 1989) is an American politician and  member of the . Lewis represents Maryland's , and is currently serving as House Majority Whip.\n\n\nLewis was born in . He graduated from  and later attended the , where he earned a  degree in political science in 2011 and a  degree in acquisition management and international development in 2014.\n\n\nLewis first entered politics as a campus organizer, organizing students in a protest against a proposed tuition increase. After graduating, he joined the  as a community organizer. In 2012, he worked as a regional field director for 's . After graduating, he became a community organizer for the Good Jobs Better Baltimore campaign. Lewis also worked for U.S. Representative , first as a field director before becoming an executive director in July 2015. During the , he worked as the Maryland political director for former  .\n\nOn January 11, 2017, state delegate  resigned from the Maryland House of Delegates, citing unspecified health issues. Lewis applied to fill the vacancy left by Vaughn's resignation, and was nominated by the Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee on January 24.\n\n\nLewis was appointed to the  by Governor  on February 10, 2017, and was sworn in on the same day. He was subsequently elected for a full term in , and re-elected in . In September 2019, House Speaker  named Lewis as the chair of the House Democratic Caucus. In January 2023, Jones named him as the House Majority Whip, succeeding then-delegate .\n\nFrom 2019 until October 2021, Lewis worked as a senior policy advisor to  .\n\nLewis was an at-large delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\n\n* Member, Appropriations Committee, 2021–present (transportation & the environment subcommittee, 2021–present; oversight committee on pensions, 2021–2022; capital budget subcommittee, 2023–present; chair, oversight committee on personnel, 2023–present)\n* Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2023–present\n* Joint Committee on Legislative Information Technology and Open Government, 2017–present\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2017–2020 (chair, family law subcommittee, 2019–2020, member, 2017–2020; member, public safety subcommittee, 2019–2020)\n\n\n\nIn October 2021, Lewis announced his candidacy for , seeking to succeed outgoing Representative , who was a candidate for . During the primary, he was endorsed by House Majority Leader  and U.S. Representative . He withdrew his candidacy on April 14, 2022, saying that he would seek another term in the House of Delegates in lieu of a congressional bid.\n\n\nLewis has described himself as \"unabashedly a progressive\" who is also a \"consensus-maker\". During his 2022 congressional campaign, Lewis told '''' that he did not express a desire to align with , but hoped to befriend and work with its members.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Lewis introduced a bill that would limit restrictive housing and its use for vulnerable members of the prison population, including pregnant women, older prisoners, and those with disabilities. He reintroduced the bill during the 2019 and 2020 legislative sessions.\n\nIn 2019, Lewis said he opposed a controversial bill that would allow  to employ its own private police force. After realizing the bill had the votes to pass, he introduced a series of amendments to hold the police force accountable. The bill passed with the amendments.\n\nAlso in 2019, Lewis introduced a bill that would require the Department of Legislative Services to prepare racial impact statements on bills creating or modifying misdemeanor and felony offenses. He later worked with legislative leaders  and  to initiate a pilot program requiring racial impact statements on criminal justice bills in 2021.\n\nIn June 2020, Lewis pledged to stop taking campaign contributions from the .\n\nIn July 2020, Lewis was appointed to represent the Maryland House of Delegates on the Law Enforcement Body Camera Task Force, a committee tasked with helping jurisdictions utilize s. During the 2023 legislative session, Lewis introduced a bill that would require the  to negotiate affordable police body camera contracts for police departments with small budgets.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Lewis introduced the , a bill that would end  sentences for juvenile offenders. The bill passed the Maryland House of Delegates and the , but was vetoed by Governor ; the veto was overridden by the Maryland General Assembly during the 2022 legislative session.\n\nDuring his 2022 House campaign, Lewis said he supported the , calling it one of his priorities. Also in 2022, he introduced the New Start Act, a bill that would offer small business loans and training to individuals who were formerly incarcerated and wanted to start a new business.\n\n\nBefore the , Lewis traveled to  with the . He later encouraged progressive members of the U.S. House of Representatives who are critical of Israel to visit the country.\n\nIn November 2021, Lewis called Israel \"one of our core friends\" and said that he supported increasing U.S. foreign aid to Israel. He also said that he would have voted for a bill providing supplemental funding to Israel's  missile-defense system, which passed by a 420-9 vote.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Lewis introduced a bill to establish five Health Equity Resource Communities, each tasked with reducing disparities in the incidence and treatment of diseases, funded by a one percent increase in the state's alcohol tax.\n\nDuring his 2022 congressional campaign, Lewis said he supported a  and expanding access to .\n\n\nLewis supported , a ballot referendum to legalize , voting to pass legislation creating the referendum during the 2022 legislative session and later encouraging his constituents to vote for legalization in October 2022. He had previously sponsored legislation to legalize cannabis during the 2021 legislative session, which failed to move out of committee.\n\n\nIn January 2021, Lewis condemned comments made by state delegate  during the , replying to a post Cox made on  with \"Dan, you are better than this. Please don't cosign this lawlessness.\"\n\n\nIn 2019, Lewis voted to advance a bill that would lift a ban on candidates running in  county-level political races from accepting developer contributions.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Lewis introduced a bill that would remove all  products from the market.\n\n\nLewis is married and lives in . Together, he and his wife have a son and a daughter.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''James F. Ports Jr.''' was a member of the , representing District 8, which covered portions of  &  in Maryland.  He served alongside Democrat  and Republican   In 2002, Ports decided against running for reelection in the House of Delegates and decided instead to run for Baltimore County Council.  He won the Republican primary election, but lost in the general election to Vincent J. Gardina.\n\n\nDelegate Ports graduated from . After serving in the Marine Corps, Ports attended and graduated from , with his Associates of Arts Degree in 1989.\n\n\nAs previously mentioned Ports was in the United States Marine Corps.  He attained the rank of Sergeant, and once received the Expeditionary Medal for Marine of the Month.  He served from 1978 until 1982.\n\nAfter serving in the military, Ports was a supervisor of Industrial and Commercial Gas Field Operations for . He is also licensed as a registered representative by the  as an insurance agent.\n\nIn his community he served as Vice-President of the Northeast Fullerton Community Association, which he was a member from 1986 until 1990. He has been a member of the 8th District Republican Club since 1988. Ports was a member of the Baltimore County Republican Central Committee, serving from 1989 until 1990 and again from 2003 until 2006. He was once elected to be a delegate for the .\n\nDelegate Ports also is a member of the Rossville Democratic Association, the Taxpayers for Government Efficiency, the .  Additionally, he is a member of the Competent Toastmasters, and the  honorary fraternity. Delegate Ports is also an associate member of Lodge no. 76, of the .  He was the Commander of the Perry Hall/White Marsh Post no. 11378,  (VFW) from 1992 until 1994.  He is a life member of the Parkville Memorial Post no. 9083. Finally, he is an honorary co-chair and co-founder of the Perry Hall High School Alumni Association.\n\nDelegate Ports has received awards from People Against Child Abuse, the , the , and the . In 1996, Delegate Ports was selected as Outstanding Young Marylander of the Year by the . Additionally, he received the General  Award from the Maryland Society of the  in 1997. Finally, Ports was awarded Legislator of the Year by the  (ALEC) in 2001.\n\n\nWhile a member of the , Ports was a member of the Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee from  1991 until 1992, the Ways and Means Committee from 1992 until 2003, the Joint Transportation Financing Committee in 1994, and the Special Joint Committee on Competitive Taxation and Economic Development from 1996 until 1997.  Additionally, he served on the Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer in 2002, the Legislative Policy Committee from 2002 until 2003, and the Rules and Executive Nominations Committee from 2002 until 2003. Delegate Ports was also a member of the National Task Force on Energy, Environment, and Natural Resources, and with ALEC from 1991 until 2003, serving as vice-chair of the energy subcommittee. Ports served as Minority Whip from 2001 until 2002.\n\nDelegate Ports originally made a name for himself when he fought against Baltimore County Executive 's property condemnation bill, which was ultimately defeated.  The bill would have allowed the county to use  to seize waterfront property in Essex and redevelop it.\n\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08''' Retrieved on September 07, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Leo E. Green''' (born March 27, 1932) is an American politician in the state of Maryland. He served in the  from 1983 to 2007 as a Democrat. Green attended  and  and is an attorney. He also served as mayor of  from 1968 to 1972.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Casper R. Taylor Jr.''' (December 19, 1934 – April 24, 2023) was an American politician who served as Speaker of the  from 1994 to 2003, amongst the longest Speaker's tenures in Maryland history. He also represented Districts  and  in the House of Delegates from 1975 to 2003.\n\n\nTaylor graduated from the  in 1956, where he was a member of the  .  He started out his career as a restaurant owner, and was first elected to the House of Delegates in 1974.\n\n\nTaylor is credited with helping to bring millions of dollars of state and private investments to the aid of his struggling district in , including the state-backed Rocky Gap Lodge and Golf Resort. In the State House, Taylor authored many pieces of legislation over the course of his tenure, including the \"One Maryland\" bill, aimed at providing tax havens and other incentives for businesses to invest in depressed parts of the state.\n\nTaylor was first elected to the House of Delegates for the 1975 legislative session to represent District 2A. In the 1994 election, he successfully ran as delegate for the newly created .\n\nTaylor served until 2003 after losing his seat in the 2002 election.  His loss is generally attributed to redrawn legislative district lines that added four heavily  precincts in Washington County to his traditionally Democratic district based around Cumberland, and his support for some  laws, which were unpopular in the rural parts of his district.\n\nTaylor received numerous awards, including the Legislator Recognition Award from the Maryland Association of Counties in 1994 and 2001. He was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters from the  in 2001,  in 2000, and  in 1995. He received the First Citizen Award from the  in 2003 and the  from the  in 2004.\n\nIn June 2003, Taylor became a lobbyist and government relations consultant for the Alexander and Cleaver firm in Annapolis. In January 2007, the new House of Delegates office building in Annapolis was named after Taylor. In May 2022, the Baltimore Street Bridge in Cumberland, Maryland, was named after Taylor.\n\n\nTaylor was  and was a former member of the Maryland Catholic Conference's administrative board. He died at his home in Cumberland, Maryland, on April 24, 2023, at the age of 88. On April 29, Governor  ordered state flags to fly at half-staff in Taylor's honor.\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 01C'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 01C'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 01C'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 2A'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1986 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 2A'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
