    "pages": }\n'''Hong Qi''' (born November 4, 1963) is an  who represents the 15th legislative district in the . Qi previously worked as a chief administrator for economic development under .\n\n\nQi was born in ,  on November 4, 1963. She grew up during the height of the , during which her family was persecuted. She migrated to  on February 22, 1989, where she attended  on a sponsorship from Manchester professor Al Deeter, for who she worked as a translator when he visited Shanghai. While at Manchester, she met her future husband, Yu \"Phil\" Peng. She graduated from Manchester University in 1991, earning a  degree in communication studies. Afterwards, the couple worked at universities in , , and , . In 1997, the couple moved to ,  after Qi accepted a position working on multicultural affairs at . She became a citizen of the  in 1999 and earned a  degree in marketing and global information technology management in 2001 while working at American University. After graduating, Qi began working on economic development for a couple of nonprofit organizations.\n\n\nQi began her career in politics with under the administration of Montgomery County executive , who asked her to serve as a liaison to the Asian American community after his election win in 2006. In April 2016, Leggett appointed Qi to serve as his Assistant Chief Administrative Officer on economic and workforce matters in Montgomery County, becoming the first Asian American to serve the position. Following 's loss in the , Qi applied to a training course hosted by Emerge Maryland, an organization created to prepare potential female  candidates for public office, to learn about the process of running for public office. Utilizing her experience at Emerge Maryland, she announced her candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in November 2017, seeking to succeed Delegate . During the Democratic primary, she was endorsed by Leggett and the Maryland . Her 2018 campaign and election were noted for mobilizing the local Chinese-American community through . She won the general election with 23.6 percent of the vote, becoming the first Chinese-born state legislator in Maryland.\n\n\n\nQi was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\n* Deputy Majority Whip, 2022–present\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, 2019–present (workers' compensation subcommittee, 2019–present; vice-chair, business regulation subcommittee, 2022–present, member, 2019–present)\n* Study Group on Economic Stability, 2020–present\n* Joint Committee on Federal Relations, 2021–present\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Asian-American and Pacific-Islander Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2019–present\n\n\n\nQi introduced legislation in 2021 legislative session that would allow for the sale of beer and wine in grocery stores. She introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would create a ballot referendum on allowing grocery stores to sell wine and beer, but it failed to move out of committee.\n\n\nIn June 2020, Qi coordinated the donation of 20,000 masks from , a sister city of , in response to the .\n\nIn August 2020, Qi joined a half dozen Maryland legislators in sending a letter to Governor  to push for widespread  and public disclosure of the results.\n\n\nDuring her 2018 campaign, Qi said that she supports expanding s in Montgomery County and making  a statewide priority.\n\n\nIn January 2021, Qi voted against legislation that would require Montgomery County landlords to provide just cause for evicting a tenant from a residential property, saying that there could be a better solution, such as a third-party \"referee\" and that some landlords might rely on one or two properties as a main income stream.\n\nQi introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would create a pilot program to provide homeless people with a mobile laundry service. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Larry Hogan on May 18, 2021.\n\n\nQi says that she \"does not believe Maryland needs sanctuary community designation\", conveying that Maryland already has safe and welcoming communities. She opposes the use of local resources to enforce federal law when it comes to sanctuary policies.\n\n\nQi supports a . She voted in favor of Senate Bill 280, which would gradually raise the state's minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2025.\n\n\nIn April 2016, Qi endorsed Hillary Clinton in the  and  in the . She also moderated a non-partisan debate between candidates for  in .\n\nIn January 2020, Qi filed to run as a convention delegate for  at the .\n\n\nQi supported , saying that a vote in favor of  would improve the climate for entrepreneurs in Maryland.\n\nIn March 2018, Qi testified in support of naming an  in Montgomery County after , noting that her son came out as gay the summer before he began college.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Todd L. Schuler''' (born January 20, 1977) is an  from  and a member of the .\n\n\nSchuler was born in . His father, Leonard G. Schuler, is a business agent for Plumbers and Steamfitters U.A., Local 486. His mother, K. Michelle Schuler, is an office manager at the Career Development and Placement Center at . He attended ,  and the .\n\nHe was active with both the , the Maryland Association for Justice, and with local Democratic Party organizations before his election.  He is active in the Elmwood Improvement Association.  Todd is a practicing attorney.  He lives in Overlea with his wife, Colleen.\n\n\nDelegate Schuler served one term in the , representing Maryland's District 8 in . Schuler was a member of the Judiciary Committee and a member of its Civil Law and Procedure Subcommittee since his appointment and a member of its Criminal Justice Subcommittee since February, 2009.\n\nIn January 2009, Delegate Schuler became the first member of the Maryland General Assembly to report live the General Assembly Session via Twitter.\n\n\n\n*Co-sponsored legislation which would have brought bottle and can deposits to Maryland. \n*Co-sponsored and helped pass legislation that increased the penalties for possession of child pornography. \n*Voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (Ban on smoking in bars and restaurants) (HB359)\n*Co-sponsored Religious Freedom and Civil Marriage Protection Act.\n*Successfully sponsored a legislative bond bill that (along with its Senate counterpart bill) garnered $250,000 to help fund the Storyville Children's Learning Center at the Rosedale Library, a project of the Foundation for Baltimore County Public Library  (HB360)\n*Introduced legislation to ban plastic grocery bags. \n*Co-sponsored Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reduction Act of 2009. \n*Co-sponsored legislation to require the state to issue permits to carry handguns to all law-abiding citizens of sound mind. \n*One of just eighteen Democrats to cross party lines and vote against the Special Session tax increases of 2007. \n\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08''' Retrieved on Sept, 07 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 08''' Retrieved on Sept, 07 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*http://www.toddschuler.com/ - campaign website\n*http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa14632.html/ - Maryland Manual Online\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Daniel Lewis Cox''' (born August 9, 1974) is an American  politician and lawyer who was a  member of the  representing the  from 2019 to 2023. He was the unsuccessful Republican nominee in the , which he lost in a landslide, and had been endorsed by former president . In 2024, Cox unsuccessfully ran for the U.S. House of Representatives in , losing to former state delegate  in the Republican primary election.\n\nCox is an , who has continuously espoused the disproven conspiracy theory that the 2020 U.S. presidential election was marred by fraud.\n\n\nCox was born in Washington, D.C., on August 9, 1974, as one of ten children. His father, Gary, named him after the biblical prophet . Cox initially lived in , but his family moved north to Frederick County after his father, a minister, took a job there. He grew up on a farm near .\n\n\nCox enrolled at the Wellspring Christian Family Schools, a faith-based home-school organization which was founded by his father, as a child. He attended Mount St. Mary's University from 1992 to 1995 and later attended the , where in 2002 he earned a bachelor's degree in government and politics. He attended  where in 2006 he earned a  degree with distinction. He has been a member of the  since 2006 and was a sole practitioner outside of . Cox is also a member of the , which has been described as an anti- organization and was designated a  in February 2017 by the .\n\nBefore getting involved with Maryland politics, Cox was a high school teacher from 1995 to 2005 at Walkersville Christian Family Schools. He also served as a  in the .\n\n\nCox says he has been active in politics since 1980, when he campaigned with his parents for . He also worked on the  of  and as an aide to former  . He was the Republican nominee for  Circuit Court Clerk in 2006, losing the race to Democratic nominee Michael L. Baker. Cox ran on a platform that included establishing a division to help fathers gain visitation, ensuring mothers received child support, and refusing to issue licenses for , which were not legal in Maryland at the time. From 2007 to 2009, he was the President of the Town Commission of .\n\n\n\n\nOn February 1, 2016, Cox filed to run in  in .\n\nDuring the Republican primary, Cox was described as being the most conservative candidate in the Republican primary race. He campaigned on imposing a 10 percent flat tax for incomes over $36,000 and eliminating payroll taxes, strengthening gun ownership rights, abolishing the , and reducing funding and programs for the departments of , , , and . He supported  in the . Cox pledged to join the , a group of  supporters, if elected.\n\nIn September 2016, Cox claimed that \"far-left sign Nazis\" were stealing campaign signs he posted alongside state highways, and posted on Twitter that he had urinated on the signs as a deterrent to prevent theft.\n\nCox won the Republican primary with 44.4 percent of the vote. In the general election, he was defeated by Democratic nominee and state senator  with 34.2 percent of the vote.\n\n\n, who declined to endorse Cox during the 2022 Maryland gubernatorial election.]]\nIn February 2018, Cox announced that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 4. He ran on a platform that included , increasing immigration enforcement, and supporting gun rights. He campaigned on a platform that included lowering taxes, expanding , and supporting s. In November 2018,  complaints were filed against Cox after he recorded a video of himself within 100 feet of an  center in , which is prohibited by Maryland election law.\n\nCox was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. He was a member of the Judiciary Committee, serving on its family law and public safety subcommittees from 2019 to 2020 and its family and juvenile law and civil law and procedure subcommittees from 2021 to 2023. In his first term, Cox filed 84 bills, only two of which passed (both of which were introduced in 2019), and attached amendments to others.\n\nFrom 2018 to 2021, Cox served as the secretary of the  Republican Central Committee. During the , he served as a Frederick County co-chair for the state's Trump Victory Leadership County team.\n\n\nIn November 2020, Cox said that he was part of a Republican legal team observing the count of mail-in ballots in  during the . After  lost the 2020 presidential election, Cox has repeatedly endorsed Trump's false claims of a \"stolen\" election and called for a \"forensic audit\" of the 2020 election results, later calling for an audit of the 2020 elections in Maryland.\n\nCox helped arrange for buses to take constituents to the \"Save America March\" in Washington, D.C., on January 6, 2021; the rally preceded the , in which a mob of Trump supporters  in a failed attempt to keep Trump in power. During the rally, Cox sent a  attacking Vice President , writing \"Pence is a traitor.\" After receiving backlash, Cox tweeted and retweeted false claims blaming  for the attack on the Capitol, and expressed his support for , the leader of the , an extremist group with nationalist, neofascist and self-proclaimed Western-chauvinist views. Cox later said in June 2022 that his Twitter post was \"his way of expressing his disappointment and not a personal attack on the vice president.\" After his win in the Republican gubernatorial primary, Cox has denied organizing buses for the rally.\n\nThe Frederick County Democratic Central Committee began a letter-writing campaign calling for Cox to be expelled from the House of Delegates for his false claims. Two days later Cox issued a statement denouncing \"all mob violence including those who broke into the U.S. Capitol.\" In the statement Cox said he had attended the rally, but was not involved in the storming of the Capitol. He did not retract his statement about Pence. Governor  and Steven Clark, the chairman of the Frederick County Republican Central Committee, denounced Cox's comments, and delegate , the co-chair of the House Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, said that the committee received some inquiries about Cox's tweets.\n\nIn February 2022, representatives from  and other progressive groups urged the  to consider blocking Cox from the ballot for his participation in the insurrection, citing  to the . In May 2022, a lawsuit was filed against Maryland Elections Administrator Linda Lamone, seeking to remove Cox from the  for his presence during the Capitol attack. Anne Arundel County  judge Mark W. Crooks dismissed the case on May 20, 2022.\n\n\n\n with Lieutenant Governor  in October 2021.]]\nIn late June 2021, Cox filed paperwork to , and formally announced his candidacy on July 4, 2021. He launched his campaign with a campaign rally in  on August 6, 2021. He picked Gordana Schifanelli, an  lawyer, as his running mate. On November 22, 2021, Cox received the endorsement of former president Donald Trump.\n\nAhead of the primary election, Cox threatened lawsuits seeking to invalidate mail-in ballots. Some political observers said before the primary that Cox would have publicly doubted the results if he had lost to .\n\n\n}}\n\nAs polls showed Cox and Schulz running neck-and-neck in polls, the  spent $1 million for a television advertisement promoting Cox, hoping he would win the nomination and be easier for Democrats to defeat in November. Cox denied receiving any support from the DGA, saying that he had \"nothing to do with the ad purchase\". Some observers, including strategist Jim Dornan, say that two factorsTrump's endorsement and the DGA ad blitzallowed Cox to advance to the general election. Other observers, including former  and  chair , say the ads had little impact on voters, highlighting that far-right politician and  activist  had won the  on the same ballot by an almost identical margin to Cox, even though the DGA did not run any ads on his behalf.\n\nCox won the Republican primary on July 19, 2022, defeating Schulz with 52.0 percent of the vote. If elected, he would have been the first governor from Frederick County since . At his victory party, Cox took photos with and accepted a gift from a young man who introduced himself as a member of the . The footage of this encounter, which was uploaded to Cox's  account, was deleted after '''' contacted the Cox campaign, which responded with a statement denying an association with the young man.\n\nFollowing his primary win, Cox sought to distance himself from the January 6 insurrection and former president Donald Trump, removing references to his endorsement from his website and making adjustments to his biography and issues pages. He also deactivated his account on , a website that has been described as a social media haven for white supremacists and neo-Nazis and was used by the perpetrator of the , on which he had more than 1,000 posts. Republican leaders expressed concern that Cox's primary victory would hurt their candidates downballot, with Senate minority leader  refusing to endorse or campaign with Cox and House minority leader  saying that Cox would need to moderate his views for the party to make gains. The Maryland Republican Party would end up losing two seats in the state Senate and three seats in the House of Delegates in the .\n\nCox was defeated by  nominee  in the general election on November 8, 2022. He initially declined to concede after the election was called for Moore by various national news outlets, believing that there was still a path to victory, but called Moore the next day to concede the election.\n\nFollowing Cox's defeat, his running mate Gordana Schifanelli filed to run for Chair of the , seeking to succeed retiring chairman Dirk Haire, but was blocked from running because she filed an hour after the candidacy deadline. Schifanelli later said that Cox blamed her for their loss and that the running mates rarely spoke to each other during the campaign, with their relationship souring well before the general election. Cox disputed this claim, telling ''The Washington Post'', \"I never blamed Ms. Schifanelli for our election loss. Her comments are false and sadly self-serving.\" Cox later endorsed Nicole Beus Harris, a political consultant and the wife of U.S. Representative , as the next chair of the Maryland Republican Party.\n\n\nIn August 2022, Cox said he opposed a lawsuit filed by the Maryland State Board of Elections to allow officials to count mail-in ballots ahead of Election Day, calling it \"unconstitutional\". According to the , Maryland is the only state that restricts the processing of absentee ballots until after Election Day.\n\nIn September 2022 court papers and a hearing, Cox argued that the board lacked the authority to begin tabulating ballots before election day. On September 23, 2022, a Montgomery County Circuit Court judge ruled in favor of the board, allowing it to begin counting mail-in ballots on October 1. Cox appealed to the , which denied his request to halt the counting of mail-in ballots. In October 7, 2022,  unanimously rejected a further appeal from Cox. In an opinion written by Chief Justice  in March 2023, the court held that a section of the state's Election Law Article referenced in his lawsuit did not \"violate the  guaranteed in the \". In February 2023, the  declined to hear Cox's challenge, letting the ruling stand without comment.\n\nCox did not commit to accepting the results of the election with mail-in ballots being counted early. During a debate on October 12, Cox was non-committal when asked if he would accept the results of the election: \"I have always accepted the election results that are fair and that are following the Constitution. At this point, it would be similar to saying that before a surgery takes place to decide whether or not the surgery went well\". Ahead of the election, Cox called on his supporters to \"monitor\" the state's election drop boxes, alleging without evidence that the drop boxes were \"regularly misused and stuffed with nefarious ballots\".\n\n\nAfter being defeated in the 2022 Maryland gubernatorial election, Cox returned to private practice in . In February 2023,   hired Cox as his chief of staff. Cox also started a podcast titled ''It's Your Freedom!'', with the first episode premiering on  on February 7.\n\nAlso in February 2023,  executive Julie Giordano nominated Cox to serve as special counsel for the county. Cox was scheduled to join the county council meeting to discuss any questions and concerns councilmembers had about his nomination, but was not present during the session. The Wicomico County Council voted 6–1 to reject Cox's nomination.\n\nIn April 2023, Cox was hired by Robert Krop, a local firearms business owner who alongside  Chuck Jenkins was charged by federal prosecutors with conspiracy and making false statements to acquire machine guns, to represent him in his federal trial. In June 2023, Judge  denied a motion to dismiss the charges against Krop, in which Cox alleged that the indictment was \"politically motivated\" and questioned the Ukrainian citizenship of the lead  agent in the case. Jenkins' attorneys also criticized Cox's motion, saying that he was employing \"inconsistent, even hostile, defense strategies\" and asking to be tried separately from Krop, which was granted on August 31, 2023. Gallagher dismissed the federal indictment against Krop in May 2024, stating that his  was violated; federal prosecutors filed new indictments against Krop later that month. Krop was acquitted on all counts in October 2024.\n\nIn May 2024, following the jury's guilty verdict in the , Cox called on the  to censure former governor  for calling on elected officials to not \"pour fuel on the fire with more toxic partisanship\" amid the ruling.\n\n\n\nIn May 2023, Cox said he was considering a run for Congress in  in , seeking to succeed outgoing U.S. Representative . On July 3, 2023, someone filed paperwork with the  to enter Cox into the 2024 election, which prompted him to report the filing to the FEC for \"fraud\". According to a '''' investigation, it was Cox's campaign treasurer, Tom Datwyler, who filed the FEC paperwork on his behalf after creating fundraising ads on  for Cox's congressional campaign. Datwyler was told by Cox advisor Rory McShane to terminate the FEC filing the next day, saying that Cox had decided against running in 2024.\n\nDespite these emails, Cox announced that he would run for Congress on October 30, 2023. Cox was seen as a frontrunner, alongside former state delegate , in the Republican primary, during which he sought to associate himself with former president , calling the  against Trump a \"witch hunt\" and continuing to promote disproven conspiracy theories that the 2020 presidential election was marred by fraud, and ran on a platform including immigration, crime, and opposing  health restrictions. Cox was defeated in the Republican primary election on May 14, 2024, placing second behind Parrott with 30.1 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nCox identifies as \"\". In 2019, , which supports abortion, gave Cox a 73% score. , which opposes abortion, gave Cox a 92% score during his first term in the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Cox was one of fourteen state delegates to vote against the state budget, citing the defeat of an amendment blocking state funding for abortions.\n\nIn February 2021, Cox joined delegates  and  at a protest against abortion at the Maryland State House. During his first term in the legislature, Cox introduced fourteen bills that would restrict abortion access and offered budget amendments to remove state funding for the procedure. He also cosponsored several bills that would prohibit abortions if a  is detected, including the Maryland Fetal Heartbeat Protection Act (HB 1195).\n\nIn June 2022, Cox praised the 's ruling in '''', which overturned '''' and ''''. During his gubernatorial campaign, Cox said that he would end taxpayer funding through  for abortions and opposed using taxpayer funding to provide contraception options for college students or to women traveling from other states to obtain abortion services in Maryland. Cox declined to say whether he would support federal restrictions on abortions, including a bill introduced by Senator  that would ban abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy. During a debate on October 12, 2022, Cox said that he supported exceptions for rape, incest, or for the life of the mother.\n\n\nCox  the  and opposes tax subsidies for  programs. He voted against the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2021 (SB 414), a proposed climate bill that would have included a goal to reduce  to a level that is 50 percent lower than it was in 2006 by 2030. He voted against the bill when it was re-introduced in the 2022 legislative session.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Cox said he opposed a bill to ban the pesticide .\n\nIn September 2022, Cox said he would support repealing the state's ban on .\n\nIn October 2022, Cox told '''' that he supported efforts to clean up the . Cox said he considered reducing effluent from bay area sewage systems and ending silt pouring from the  to be a \"top priority\".\n\n\nIn April 2020, Cox posted a portion of the  on his Facebook page after   issued an executive order implementing a stay-at-home directive. He later challenged the legality of Hogan's statewide .   struck down his lawsuit on May 20, 2020, saying that the state and country are \"now in the grip of a public health crisis more severe than any seen for a hundred years.\" He withdrew his request for a temporary restraining order on July 20, 2020. Blake again rejected another lawsuit against COVID-19 restrictions filed by Cox in November 2020. In December 2020, Montgomery County Circuit Court Judge James Bonifant rejected a request made by local restaurants represented by Cox and attorney Ed Hartman to reverse an executive order issued by County Executive  that prohibited indoor dining at restaurants.\n\nIn May 2020, Cox attended a rally in  which protested Hogan's stay-at-home orders alongside delegates  and , former delegate ,  candidate Liz Matory,  candidate Tim Fazenbaker,  founder , and  and  . Later in the month, Cox posted a tweet promoting a  linking the  to the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nIn October 2020, Cox provided legal representation for a  man who was arrested for not wearing a mask at a polling place, arguing that the pair were only ordered to wear masks once they were inside the facility and election staff learned that they were Republicans. The family's request for a temporary restraining order to allow them to vote without wearing masks was rejected by Harford County Circuit Judge Angela M. Eaves.\n\nIn January 2021, Cox cosponsored the Consent of the Governed Act, which would remove the governor's ability to unilaterally declare a state of emergency and would require the governor to form a special session to extend any state of emergency declaration for longer than fourteen days, which would require two-thirds approval from both chambers of the . In February 2021, Cox proposed a resolution that would immediately end Hogan's  emergency declaration. In March 2021, he introduced a bill that would ban any requirement to show proof of \"a medical examination, a vaccination, a medical test, or any other medical information\" for employment or travel, and would allow parents to object to a child's vaccination as a requirement to be admitted to a public school.\n\nIn June 2021, Cox called on Hogan to end the state's coronavirus emergency declaration. In August 2021, Cox used his Facebook page to ask his constituents to e-mail the  to demand that they reject an emergency universal masking mandate regulation for the 2021–2022 academic year.\n\nCox claims to have survived COVID-19 twice, saying that during one of his bouts with the virus, he took  and  he obtained in Florida. Currently, ivermectin is used to treat parasites in livestock and river blindness in humans. It is of no benefit in preventing or treating .\n\nIn January 2022, Cox attended a rally against  in Annapolis, Maryland. In September 2022, Cox said that he was \"pro-vaccine\" but does not believe in mandates.\n\nIn February 2022, Cox introduced articles of impeachment against Governor Larry Hogan for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. It was the first serious effort to impeach a Maryland governor in the state's history. The Maryland House Rules and Executive Nominations Committee voted unanimously to reject the articles of impeachment.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Cox introduced a bill to create a task force to study the history of criminal and civil classifications in Maryland. He also supported a bill that would require people convicted of a violent crime to register information and a photo with the state, and opposed a bill prohibiting people convicted of animal abuse from adopting or buying another pet.\n\nIn June 2022, Cox released a crime plan on  that called for allowing \"modified \" policies and enacting . In July, after a  fatally shot a driver wielding a baseball bat, he posted on the conservative social media platform  that he would \"target an end of squeegee crimes and all crime no matter how small\" and pledged to remove  as Baltimore State's Attorney. Cox has expressed interest in establishing a \"prosecutorial board\" to work with elected leaders in Baltimore and other crime-challenged areas to keep violent criminals in prisons. He also said he was open to using a  to take control of Baltimore to help combat rising crime. In an interview with '''', Cox said he would provide law enforcement officers with  protections along with increased pay.\n\nFollowing the August 8, 2022 , Cox said on social media that he would use the  and  to \"stand against\" the federal government. He also compared the FBI search to the actions of the , 's secret police. At a campaign rally later that month, Cox said he opposed attacks on law enforcement officers, saying, \"It's the politicians that matter. It's not the law enforcement. It's the orders from the politicians. We have to make sure we're not threatening the law enforcement officers. It's the politicians who are giving the orders. It's the politicians who have to go.\"\n\n\nAs a state delegate, Cox was a vocal critic of the , a sweeping education reform package passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021. During the 2022 legislative session, Cox introduced the Maryland Parent Rights Act (HB0618), a bill that would have allowed parents a larger role in their kids' education including notifying them when curriculum changes had been made. The bill failed to pass out of committee. He also voted in favor of an amendment introduced by state Delegate  that would have blocked public schools from discussing gender and sexuality in the classroom.\n\nDuring his gubernatorial campaign, Cox unveiled a \"Defending Parental Rights\" education platform that would ban teaching children in kindergarten through third grade about , calling it \"indoctrination.\" When asked to elaborate his definition of \"indoctrination\", he cited asexual and nonbinary author 's memoirs '''', which he claimed depicts \"things that I cannot show you on television, it's so disgusting.\" Kobabe's book is not being taught in any kindergarten or elementary school classes. He's also called for a ban on , which is not taught in Maryland public schools, and supports the expansion of  by increasing funding for the state's BOOST program, which provides low-income families with scholarships to attend charter schools. In September 2022, Cox said he would appoint more parents to the . In October 2022, Cox promised to create an office for parents' rights on his first day in office and said that he supported mandating agriculture education in schools.\n\n\nIn February 2018, following the , Cox said he opposed laws that ban assault weapons and restrict gun ownership, instead endorsing legislation to  and s.\n\nIn 2019, Cox said he opposed a bill to abolish the state's Handgun Permit Review Board.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Cox opposed a bill that would ban the possession and sale of s, which he compared to the . He also voted against legislation that would increase security measures at firearms stores. In June 2022, Cox celebrated the Supreme Court's ruling in ''''.\n\n\nDuring his 2016 House of Representatives campaign, Cox said that he would move to scrap the  if elected.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Cox voted against the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults.\n\nOn  in April 2021, Cox said he would vote against a bill to allow minors to consent to some health care services, comparing it to the infringement of \"the rights of parents\" by Nazis. Cox's  were criticized by the local . Cox defended his remarks in a letter accusing his colleagues of twisting the words he used during an emotionally-charged floor debate to gain partisan advantage, and offered no apology for his comments.\n\n\nDuring his 2016 House of Representatives campaign, Cox strongly rallied on regulating immigration. He said that he would support the full enforcement of existing laws and passage of , which would establish mandatory minimum five-year prison sentences for any immigrant convicted of reentering the country after being deported.\n\nCox opposed HB892, a bill that would require a  in order for the  to search through the state's driver's license database. He also opposed the Maryland Highway Safety Act of 2013, which allowed undocumented immigrants to apply for driver's licenses.\n\nCox strongly opposed the Dignity Not Detention Act, which would have required people arrested for federal civil crimes to be detained in federal facilities rather than in state or local facilities. During the House debate before the bill's final vote, Cox read off a list of offenses that local law enforcement agencies would not be able to use to pass undocumented people over to ICE after they completed sentences for their crimes. The bill passed the Maryland General Assembly with a veto-proof majority, but was vetoed by Governor Hogan on May 27, 2021.\n\n\nIn 2021, Cox voted against a bill to decriminalize the possession of . In 2022, Cox voted against legislation that would create a ballot referendum to legalize recreational marijuana in Maryland, and another bill that would regulate marijuana possession should the referendum pass in November. During a debate on October 12, 2022, Cox said that he supported the release of those charged with the possession of small amounts of marijuana.\n\n\nIn October 2020, Cox made a post on his Twitter account that contained  related to the .\n\nIn April 2022, Cox attended \"Patriots Arise for God and Country\" conference in . The event was organized by QAnon conspiracy theorists Francine and Allen Fodsick and featured images of conspiracy theories related to the , the , and .\n\nIn June 2022, Cox ambushed a rally for gubernatorial candidate , where Governor  called him a \"QAnon conspiracy theorist\". In response, Cox yelled out, \"Defamation, sir!\" When asked to elaborate on how he had been defamed, Cox said that he was not a member of QAnon. In October 2022, when asked by  if he believed in any of QAnon's beliefs, Cox replied, \"Absolutely not. I'm disavowing all of that. This is just a lie.\"\n\n\nIn April 2001, Cox and his wife Valerie wrote a letter to ''The Dorchester Star'' about the state's Administration Act of 2001 (SB 205), which would ban discrimination against people based on their sexual identity. In the letter, they argued that the bill would violate the rights of \"business owners ... who firmly believe homosexuality is sin and those who practice it are in danger of temporal disease and eternal death.\"\n\nDuring his 2016 House of Representatives campaign, Cox said that he did not support an increase in the . During the 2019 legislative session, he testified against a bill to raise Maryland's minimum wage to .\n\nIn August 2017, Cox served as the attorney in a lawsuit challenging the 's policy on  students. The plaintiffs dropped the lawsuit on November 28, 2017, citing stress and potential humiliation that stemmed from the legal action. In July 2022, Cox said that he would ban transgender students from competing on girls' sports team in schools.\n\nIn September 2018, Cox disputed the  made against Supreme Court nominee , claiming that his accusers \"withheld evidence\" from the confirmation hearing.\n\nIn September 2019, Cox introduced a bill to add \"dignity of the human body\" to the state's  statute to cover spitting on the victim. The bill was named for John Weed, a Frederick County man who died after being assaulted and spit on.\n\nIn March 2021, Cox voted against HB667, a bill that would abandon \"\" as Maryland's state song.\n\nIn 2022, Cox was one of 21 legislators to vote against a bill that would raise the state's minimum marriage age from 15 to 17, saying in an interview that a pregnant 16-year-old should be allowed to marry the father.\n\n\nDuring his 2016 House of Representatives campaign, Cox expressed support for  and called for \"major cuts\" to government spending.\n\nDuring his gubernatorial campaign, Cox said he would immediately suspend the state's gas tax. He also said he would support providing businesses with increased tax credits, including a \"dollar-for-dollar\" tax credit to help employers cover the costs of paying for . Cox also supports eliminating the state income tax and would support cutting the state's corporate tax rate, personal income tax rate, and property tax rates.\n\n\n\nDuring his 2016 House of Representatives campaign, Cox said he supported efforts to reduce congestion on . During his gubernatorial campaign, he said he supported a proposal to expand I-270 and the , but opposed plans to add s or use s to fund the new lanes.\n\n\nCox has been married to his wife, Valerie, since 1996 and has ten children. The Coxes moved out of their home in  in 2004, purchasing a home for between $350,000 and $499,999 in  in 2004 and keeping their Secretary home as a rental property.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes =153,423\n| percentage =52.0\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes =128,302\n| percentage =43.5\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes =8,268\n| percentage =2.8\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes =5,075\n| percentage =1.7\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 1,293,944\n| percentage = 64.53\n| change = +21.02\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes = 644,000\n| percentage = 32.12\n| change = -24.23\n}}\n\n| party = Libertarian Party (United States)\n| votes = 30,101\n| percentage = 1.50\n|change = +0.93\n}}\n\n| party = Working Class Party\n| votes = 17,154\n| percentage = 0.86\n| change = N/A\n}}\n\n| party = Green Party (United States)\n| votes = 14,580\n| percentage = 0.73\n| change = +0.25\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Thomas E. Dewberry''' (born April 29, 1951) is an American politician and judge from Maryland. He served as a member of the , representing  from 1990 to 1994 and  from 1995 to 2002.\n\n\nThomas E. Dewberry was born on April 29, 1951, in , Maryland, to . His father was  and deputy director of the . He attended Loyola High School. Dewberry graduated from the , in 1973 with a  in history. He graduated from the  in 1977 with a . He was admitted to the bar in Maryland.\n\n\nDewberry worked as a lawyer. He was treasurer of the National Conference of Regulatory Attorneys Convention in 1988.\n\nDewberry was a . In 1988, Dewberry was a delegate to the . He was appointed as a member of the Maryland House of Delegates, representing , in 1989. He represented District 12 from 1989 until 1994. He represented  in the Maryland House of Delegates from 1995 until his resignation on May 22, 2002. He was succeeded by . He served as speaker pro tempore from 1997 to 2002.\n\nIn 2002, Dewberry became the chief administrative law judge of the Office of Administrative Hearings. He served in that role until 2019.\n\nDewberry served as president and is a member of the board of directors of Revisions, Inc., a psychosocial rehabilitation center. He serves on the board of directors of Historical Old Salem, Inc. He is a member of the Catonsville Chamber of Commerce.\n\n\nDewberry is married and has two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n|birth_place     = , U.S.\n|death_date      = \n|death_place     = \n|party           = \n|spouse          = \n|children        = 5\n|education       =  () ()\n}}\n'''Ronald Nelson Young''' (born October 19, 1940) is an American consultant, teacher, and . He was a member of the  from 2011 to 2023 and previously served as a mayor of , serving from\n1974 to 1990.\n\n\nRonald Young was born in  and was raised in Frederick. He attended and graduated from . Young attended  and graduated with an Associate in Arts degree. He then attended the  in  and received a Bachelor of Arts degree in history and government.\n\nYoung completed his formal education by earning a  degree in administration and supervision from  (later ) in .\n\n\nYoung became involved in local politics in the late 1960s, primarily in the Frederick County Young Democrats organization along with several friends, among them Galen R. Clagett. Young and Clagett both ran for the Frederick City Board of Aldermen in 1969, and Young was elected and served on the Board of Aldermen from 1970 to 1974 during mayor E. Paul Magaha's administration.\n\n\nIn 1973, Young ran for mayor of Frederick. He defeated former mayor and serving alderman Donald B. Rice in the Democratic primary and then defeated serving alderman Glenmore Rice in the general election. Young assumed the role of mayor in 1974 at the age of 34. Young was re-elected as mayor in 1977, 1981 and 1985. In 1989, he was defeated by  in the general election in a contested election, ending sixteen years of service as Frederick's mayor.\n\nDuring Young's years as mayor, he pursued various projects, including the Carroll Creek flood control project, the Market Street underground wiring project, the , , Clustered Spires Golf Course, and the revitalization of downtown Frederick.\n\n\nYoung worked in commercial real estate, as a part-time college instructor at , and as a consultant in the years immediately following his defeat as mayor.\n\nIn 1991, he worked for the State of Maryland in the . Young later served under Governor  as the Deputy Secretary of the  and served as the Deputy Secretary of the Maryland Department of Planning until leaving in 2000 after a dispute with Glendening.\n\nIn 2001, Young accepted the position of town manager of . He served until 2005, when he decided to make one more run for mayor of Frederick.\n\nAfter his defeat for the mayoralty of Frederick City by William J. Holtzinger, Young maintained a semi-retired lifestyle. He is still involved in commercial real estate, consulting, novel-writing, and painting.\n\n\nIn 2010, Young decided to run for  for District 3. He defeated Don DeArmon in the  in September 2010, and defeated incumbent Senator  in the general election in November 2010. Young was sworn in on January 12, 2011 and appointed to the Senate's Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee. Senator Young also serves on the Alcoholic Beverages, Environment, and Labor, Licensing, and Regulations Subcommittees.\n\nIn the 2012 legislative session his social media bill (SB 434) provided the model language for the federal legislation on the same issue.\n\nSenator Young has voted in favor of , the , congressional redistricting, prohibiting smoking in a car where children are present, and to expand gambling.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session Young introduced a bill that asks drivers who are renewing or obtaining a driver’s license if they want to opt out of the organ donor program, a change from the current system that asks drivers if they’d like to become a donor.\n\nIn 2014, Young was re-elected to the State Senate. Senator Young sits on the Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Committee and is Chair of the Comptrollers Issues Subcommittee which deals with Alcohol, Labor, Licensing, and Regulations. He also serves on the Education Subcommittee as well as the Joint Committee on Program Open Space and Agricultural Preservation. Senator Young is a Senate Representative to the Financial Education and Capability Commission and serves on the National Conference of State Legislation's Natural Resource and Infrastructure Committee.\n\nIn 2021, Young announced that he would not seek another term on the State Senate. He endorsed his wife, , to succeed him in representing .\n\n\nYoung is a member of a number of organizations: 1968–Present he helped create and serves on the board of the Frederick Community Action Agency, 2006–present he is on the board of directors for Goodwill Industries, 2008–present he is on the advisory board for Maryland Shakespeare Theater, the president of East Frederick Rising from 2006-2010, and a member of the following organizations: Rotary Club of Carroll Creek, 1000 Friends of Maryland, American Planning Association, American Legion, Chesapeake Bay Foundation, Fraternal Order of Elks, Fraternal Order of Owls, National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), U.S. Tennis Association, and the Urban Land Institute. Ron Young is also the former President of Delaplaine Visual Arts Center, the Frederick Arts Council, and the Frederick Festival of the Arts. He is a former trustee for the Maryland Art Place and a former member of the Forum for Rural Maryland, Rural Legacy Board, board of directors, and the Way Station. Other organizations that he has belonged to are ; ; ; ; ; and the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
