    "pages": }\n| children            = 5\n| education           =  (, , )\n| signature           = Andy Harris' signature.jpg\n| website             = \n| allegiance          = \n| branch              = \n*\n**\n\n| serviceyears        = \n| rank                = \n| unit                = \n| battles             = \n| module              = \n}}\n'''Andrew Peter Harris''' (born January 25, 1957) is an American politician and physician serving as the  for . The district includes the entire , as well as several eastern exurbs of . He is the only  member of .\n\nPrior to entering politics, Harris worked as an anesthesiologist at  and served as a commanding officer for the Johns Hopkins Naval Reserve Medical Unit from 1989 to 1992. He was elected to the  in 1998, after defeating incumbent  in the Republican primary. He first represented the  from 1993 to 2003, then the  until 2011; both districts included parts of northeastern Baltimore County.\n\nHarris was first elected to Congress in 2010, after defeating incumbent  in the general election. He became the chair of the  in September 2024, after his predecessor, , lost his Republican primary in June 2024.\n\n\nHarris's father was Zoltán Harris, an  who was born in , , in 1911 and emigrated to the U.S. in 1950; his mother, Irene (Koczerzuk), was born in Zarice, . Harris was born in , grew up in , and attended  in .\n\nHarris earned his BS in biology (1977) and his MD (1980) from . The university's Bloomberg School of Hygiene and Public Health conferred his MHS in 1995 in  and health finance and management. . Retrieved September 29, 2017.\n\nHarris served in the  and the  as a commander on active duty during . He previously worked as an , an associate professor of anesthesiology and critical care medicine, and as chief of obstetric anesthesiology at the . Harris also served as commanding officer for the Johns Hopkins Naval Reserve Medical Unit from 1989 to 1992.\n\n\nHarris was first elected to the  in 1998 for District 9, including part of . He defeated his predecessor, Minority Leader , in the 1998 primary election. A major factor in the race was Boozer's role in derailing an attempt to ban  a year earlier; the bill's sponsor, fellow state senator , supported Harris's primary bid. In the general election he defeated  nominee Anthony O. Blades.\n\nHarris's district was later redrawn to be District 7, representing parts of , succeeding . He defeated Democratic nominee Diane DeCarlo in the general election in 2002, and from 2003 to 2006 served as the . He was reelected in 2006, defeating Patricia A. Foerster. He was succeeded by .\n\nIn August 2001, following speculation that U.S. representative  would , Harris formed an exploratory committee to explore a potential run for Congress in . He ultimately decided against running.\n\n\n\n\n\nHarris defeated incumbent Republican  and state senator  in the  for . Harris ran well to the right of Gilchrest, a moderate Republican. He explained that he was upset with Gilchrest's decision to support a -sponsored bill setting a timetable for  and suspected that many of his constituents also felt that way. He was endorsed by the , which raised nearly $250,000 for him, former governor , seven of 10 state senators who represent parts of the district, and House minority leader . His general election opponent,  state's attorney , criticized the Club for Growth's policies, and Harris for having its support. Gilchrest endorsed Kratovil. ''Baltimore Sun''\n\nOn paper, Harris had a strong advantage in the general election due to its Republican lean. Although Democrats and Republicans are nearly tied in registration, the district has a strong tinge of  that favors Republicans. It had been in Republican hands for all but 14 years since 1947, although Kratovil received a significant boost when Gilchrest endorsed him.\n\nOn election night, Kratovil led Harris by 915 votes. After two rounds of counting s, Kratovil's lead grew to 2,000 votes. Forecasting that there was little chance for Harris to close the gap, most media outlets declared Kratovil the winner on the night of November 7. Harris conceded on November 11.\n\nHarris dominated his longtime base in Baltimore's heavily Republican eastern suburbs, which account for most of the district's share of Baltimore County, but failed to carry a single county on the Eastern Shore.\n\n\n\nHarris ran again in the 1st District in 2010. He defeated Rob Fisher, a conservative businessman, in the primary.\n\nHarris's primary win set up a rematch against Kratovil. Libertarian Richard James Davis and Independent Jack Wilson also ran. In the , Harris defeated Kratovil by 14%.\n\n\n\n\nThe '''s''  named Harris one of the top 10 Republicans most vulnerable to redistricting in 2012, noting that  could  Harris's home in Cockeysville out of the 1st. Instead, 's 6th District was redrawn. Some of Bartlett's shares of Harford, Baltimore, and Carroll counties were drawn into the 1st, making this already strongly Republican district even more so.\n\nHarris was reelected, defeating Democratic nominee Wendy Rosen with 67% of the vote. Rosen withdrew from the race after being confronted with evidence that she had voted in both Maryland and Florida in the 2006 and 2008 elections. Rosen had property in Florida, and Maryland law allowed property owners to vote in local elections even if they live elsewhere. But her Florida voting registration reportedly also gave her access to state and federal elections there, which was prohibited by Maryland law. At the time Rosen withdrew, ballots had already been printed. John LaFerla, who had narrowly lost to Rosen in the primary, was endorsed as Rosen's replacement, but could only be a write-in.\n\n\n\nHarris defeated Democratic nominee Bill Tilghman with over 70% of the vote.\n\n\n\nHarris won the Republican primary, defeating three challengers with 78.4% of the vote. Former Maryland state delegate  came in second place with 10.8%.Rachel Kurzius,  , ''DCist'' (April 27, 2016). Smigiel ran because he opposed Harris's strident opposition to marijuana decriminalization in the District of Columbia.\n\nIn the general election, Harris won another term with 229,135 votes (67.8%), , ''New York Times'' (December 13, 2016). defeating Democratic nominee Joe Werner, a \"little-known  attorney and perennial candidate\" who received 94,776 votes (28%). Libertarian candidate Matt Beers received 14,207 votes (4.2%). In February 2016, Harris was the first congressman to endorse  for the . Carson dropped out two weeks later after a poor performance in the  March 1 primaries.\n\n\n\nWhile Harris was running for reelection, the Maryland Democratic Party accused him of ethics violations, alleging that he might have violated ethics rules requiring members to report the source of spousal income and assets. In response, the Harris campaign said the omission was a mistake, and Harris amended his filing once he became aware of the error.\n\nIn the general election, Harris defeated Democratic nominee Jesse Colvin with 60% of the vote.\n\n\n\nHarris defeated Democratic nominee Mia Mason with over 63% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\nHarris had initially promised to serve only six terms (12 years) in the House, but opted to run again in 2022. Maryland state legislators had passed a new congressional map that gave Democrats an advantage over Republicans in all eight of the state's congressional districts, but the map was ruled unconstitutional by Judge  in March 2022. Afterwards, legislators passed a new map that was signed into law by Governor  in April 2022, which returned the district to being solidly Republican. In the general election, Harris faced former state delegate , whom he sought to portray as a tax-approving liberal who would increase federal spending and support  as . Mizeur, in turn, characterized Harris as an ineffective legislator and criticized him for challenging the results of the  and for supporting the Life at Conception Act. Harris defeated Mizeur with 54.4 percent of the vote, his closest race since his 2010 victory.\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n**  (Chair)\n** \n** \n\n\n\n* \n\n\n, 2020]]\nDuring the ,  rated Harris as the 60th most conservative member of the House of Representatives. '''' described Harris as \"an ardent supporter of President \", whose right-wing populism he has called the \"future of the Republican Party\". He initially endorsed neurosurgeon  for president during the , but later backed Trump after Carson suspended his campaign. A member of the House Freedom Caucus, Harris unsuccessfully ran for chairmanship of the  in 2016, during which he campaigned on uniting the caucus and committee.\n\n\n\nHarris identifies as \"\". He has consistently received 0 percent ratings from pro-choice groups, including , and 100 percent ratings from anti-abortion groups, such as the  and the .\n\nDuring the 2000 legislative session, Harris introduced a bill to ban abortions after .\n\nIn 2004, Harris cosigned a letter opposing the Ronald Reagan and Christopher Reeve Stem Cell Research Act, which would require the state to provide $25 million toward  research annually. He also introduced the Human Cloning Prohibition Act, a bill to ban stem cell research in Maryland. In 2006, Harris ed a bill to provide $25 million a year toward stem cell research.\n\nIn 2006, Harris opposed a bill to allow pharmacists to provide patients with . In July 2014, he praised the 's decision in '''', which exempted privately held for-profit corporations from having to cover contraception under the Affordable Care Act. In 2023, Harris cosigned an amicus brief to the  supporting a lower court ruling in '''', which temporarily repealed the 's approval of .\n\nIn 2015, following the release of  by the , an anti-abortion group, that purportedly showed  selling tissues from aborted es, Harris spoke in support of a bill to block  funds from health care providers that performed abortions. He was later appointed to the .\n\nDuring the , Harris praised remarks made by President  on efforts to restrict women's access to abortion.\n\nIn 2021, Harris cosponsored the Life at Conception Act, a bill to ban abortions without exceptions. In June 2022, Harris celebrated the Supreme Court's ruling in '''', which overturned ''''. Following the ruling, Harris said he would support a federal . In July 2022, Harris voted against bills codifying ''Roe'', to protect patients who travel across state lines to get an abortion, and to protect the right to . During a debate in October 2022, he said he would support a bill introduced by Senator  that would ban abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy.\n\n\nHarris supports a federal  and opposes . He opposes increases to the debt ceiling without cuts to federal spending, and opposes increases to taxes and to the . Harris supports eliminating s and implementing a .\n\nIn August 2013, Harris proposed using the  to delay the 's implementation by one year as opposed to voting to defund it. On October 16, 2013, Harris voted against the motion to end the government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling.\n\nIn March 2015, Harris proposed \"shutting down the \" by halving appropriations funding as opposed to a government shutdown.\n\nIn January 2018, Harris voted for a Senate stopgap funding bill to end the . In March 2018, he voted against the , calling it \"fiscally irresponsible\".\n\nIn 2022, following a spike in gas prices as the result of the , Harris supported efforts to extend Maryland's  until the end of the year.\n\nIn April 2023, Harris praised the Republican debt ceiling plan, which limited spending to pre-pandemic levels with one percent annual growth over a decade. He was among the 71 Republicans who voted against final passage of the  in the House.\n\n\nDuring the 2001 legislative session, Harris introduced legislation to create a statewide program to provide state-funded scholarships to students attending s.\n\n\nHarris has questioned whether , but supports using technological developments, such as s and , to tackle climate change. He also supports providing federal funding toward , having played an instrumental role in restoring $60 million in funding for the Chesapeake Bay cleanup program following earlier proposals that saw the program receive no funding.\n\nIn July 2017, Harris amended the  to ban federal funding for any  projects that were closer than 24 nautical miles to the coastline. The amendment was seen as a response to the 's approval of two wind farms off the coast of , both of which were planned to be at least 17 miles from the shore; Harris claimed that the wind farms would be visible from the horizon and discourage tourism to Ocean City. He later called for the Ocean City wind farm project to be revisited, claiming that it would interfere with  shipping channels and  military communications. In 2023, after a dead  washed ashore , Harris called for a moratorium on wind farm construction, which he claimed without evidence was responsible for the whale's death.\n\nIn 2018, Harris said that he supported , but opposed offshore drilling off the coast of Maryland. In 2022, following a spike in gas prices as the result of the , he said he supported restarting the  to reduce gas prices. In 2023, Harris called for an increase in natural gas and coal production as a means to lower the national deficit and counter China's influence on global markets.\n\nIn 2019, Harris voted against rejoining the . He also voted against the Coastal and Marine Economies Act, which would ban any new offshore drilling activity off the Pacific or Atlantic coasts.\n\nFollowing the  in March 2024, Harris called on state and federal officials to \"immediately reduce the environmental and regulatory burdens\" that would hamper reconstruction of the bridge.\n\n\nHarris opposes restrictions on the , but says that citizens who commit or threaten to commit a crime with a firearm should receive harsh sentences. In 2017, he voted for the , a bill that would require all states recognize concealed carry permits issued by other states.\n\nDuring the 2000 legislative session, Harris opposed legislation that would require handguns sold in Maryland to have integrated .\n\nIn January 2016, Harris said he supported a proposal by presidential candidate  to eliminate s at schools, arguing that gun-free zones led to an increase in . After the  on November 5, 2017, Harris compared gun control efforts to  measures, saying \"Jews were not allowed to own guns in Nazi Germany and that didn't end well\". In 2018, Harris said he supported .\n\nIn 2022, Harris voted against a bill to ban .\n\n\nHarris supports Maryland's \"\" healthcare system, voting in 2002 for a bill creating the health insurance pool.\n\nHarris opposes the  (ACA), which he has called a \"government takeover of health care\", and ran in 2010 on a promise to repeal it. During a town hall meeting in August 2013, he criticized the ACA's  and employer mandates, which he said encouraged businesses to increase part-time hiring. Harris also said he supported protecting health insurance access for individuals with s as well as removing caps on insurance benefits. In December 2013, he proposed using  to increase the amount states would need to pay to expand Medicaid by 10 percent.\n\nIn 2013, Harris introduced a bill that would repeal a provision of the ACA that required insurance companies to cover procedures performed by chiropractors, midwives, and similar medical staff. He also cosponsored the , a bill that allowed HIV-infected people to donate their organs to other HIV-infected people, which was signed into law by President  in November 2013.\n\nIn 2014, Harris said he supported an  probe into glitches with , which was among the worst performing in the nation. The probe, which concluded in March 2015, found that the state lacked oversight and internal controls that led to the state improperly spending $28.4 million in federal funding.\n\nHarris was initially supportive of the  (AHCA), which would have partially repealed the ACA. He later said he would vote against the AHCA following last-minute changes made to the bill that he said \"simply won't lower premiums as much as the American people need\". Harris dismissed  estimates that showed that eliminating cost-sharing subsidies would cause insurance premiums to grow 20 percent, calling it \"another excuse by insurance companies to raise premiums\". In May 2017, Harris voted for the AHCA.\n\nIn September 2017, Harris said he supported the , which would have returned control of  back to the states. In October 2017, he said he supported the Trump administration's decision to end federal subsidies to help low-income people pay for out-of-pocket expenses under ACA.\n\nIn 2018, Harris said he supported raising the full retirement age for  from 67 to 70 years old. He also said he supported imposing work requirements on \"able-bodied adults\" for Medicaid and .\n\nIn 2019, Harris voted against the Never Forget the Heroes Act, a bill authorizing permanent health benefits for first responders during the . In 2022, he voted against the Federal Firefighters Fairness Act, which would have eased the compensation claim process for federally employed firefighters diagnosed with .\n\n\nHarris does not support a  for s, saying in August 2013 that \"if you came here illegally, you should be very happy if what we do is just to allow you to remain and contribute to the economy illegally\". He has also criticized amnesty as a \"step back from the rule of law\". Harris supports expanding s for agricultural and seasonal industries as well as . In 2011, Harris co-signed a letter opposing a new  rule to increase the hourly wages of H-2B visa workers.\n\nIn 2014, Harris said he supported instituting a travel ban on  endemic areas.\n\nIn 2017, Harris said he supported , an executive order by President  to temporarily suspend the  and ban travel from six predominantly Muslim countries. He also supported the Trump administration's plan to phase out the  program. In February 2019, he said he supported Trump's national emergency declaration to fund the construction of the , which he claimed would prevent drug trafficking, gang activity, and sexual violence. Later that year, Harris voted against blocking the emergency declaration and the , and voted for a bill to provide $4.6 billion in humanitarian aid for migrants at the Mexico–United States border.\n\nIn 2019, Harris criticized  policies, saying that they \"create an environment of the lack of rule of law\".\n\n\nIn 2001, Harris led a filibuster of a bill prohibiting discrimination against , which lasted more than two hours and ended after two-thirds of state senators voted to limit debate. He also unsuccessfully sought to amend the bill to allow people to discriminate on the basis of religion.\n\nIn 2006, Harris said he supported a  to \"protect marriage between a man and a woman\", which he later cosponsored in 2013 and 2015.\n\nIn 2013, Harris said he was disappointed with the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling in '''', which legalized  throughout the United States. In October 2014, the  placed Harris on its list of the 14 most \"anti-equality\" House members, citing his support for several  bills including one prohibiting on the use of Department of Defense property in gay marriages and another banning federal discrimination against people and organizations on the basis of religious beliefs. In 2015, he cosponsored a resolution disagreeing with the Supreme Court ruling in ''Obergefell''.\n\nIn 2021, Harris voted against the , a bill to add  and sexual orientation to federal anti-discrimination laws. In 2022, he voted against the , which codified same-sex and interracial marriage rights.\n\nIn 2023, Harris voted for the Protection of Women and Girls Sports Act, a bill to ban transgender women from competing in female sports. He also opposed a proposed  rule requiring elementary schools to allow students to participate in school sports programs based on their stated gender identity. In July 2023, Harris voted to strip funding for LGBTQ projects from the , comparing its funding to a hypothetical  project because the \"LGBTQ center organized a protest against conservative mothers\".\n\n\nIn January 2003, Harris said he opposed legalizing medical marijuana in Maryland, saying that he preferred that the issue be handled at the federal level.\n\nIn 2014, Harris was the leading congressional critic of  in the  bill, and led efforts in Congress to block decriminalization from taking effect. Harris's amendment led to a call from D.C. mayor  to boycott tourism to Harris's district and the , as well as an online campaign requesting that D.C.-area businesses refuse him service. Washington D.C. officials and marijuana activists called Harris's actions unwarranted congressional interference.\n\nIn November 2014, D.C. residents voted to legalize recreational cannabis for adults, with 68% in favor. Despite this, Harris said he would use \"all resources available to a member of Congress to stop this action\". On December 9, 2014, congressional leaders announced a deal on a spending bill that included language that would prohibit the D.C. referendum from taking effect. Harris said that \"the Constitution gives Congress the ultimate oversight about what happens in the federal district.\" He said he believes that cannabis is a .\n\nIn 2022, Harris added a provision to the $1.5 trillion spending omnibus package that barred D.C. from legalizing, regulating and taxing the sale recreational cannabis, overriding the will of D.C. voters. Democrats opposed Harris's provision, but Republicans sharply opposed attempts to remove the provision. In February 2024, amid federal efforts to lower the drug designation of marijuana from a schedule 1 substance to a schedule 3, Harris wrote to the  criticizing the agency for not \"sufficiently examining the effect of daily marijuana use\" and the impact of marijuana use on driving, pregnant women, and children.\n\n\nDuring the 2003 legislative session, Harris voted against a bill to impose a two-year moratorium on  sentences.\n\nIn 2006, Harris voted in favor of a bill to legalize  gambling in Maryland, but said he would only support a \"limited plan\" that required statewide and local referendums to legalize slots.\n\nIn April 2009, Harris led opposition to the scheduled screening of the pornographic film '''' at the , threatening to withhold state funding from the university if it showed the film. Following this threat, the university cancelled the screening of the film. After portions of the film were screened by students at the campus lecture hall, Harris unsuccessfully sought to amend the state budget to block funding for the  until it adopted a policy on showing pornographic material on campus, which was later watered down into a compromise requiring the university system to develop policies on what kind of films could be shown on campus, which he supported. In November 2009, the University System of Maryland Board of Regents unanimously voted against adopting a policy to restrict the screening of pornographic films on campus.\n\nIn 2010, Harris said he opposed the  project, a proposal to build a mosque two blocks from the  of the , calling it \"blatantly disrespectful\".\n\nIn 2016, Harris voted against renaming a post office in  after civil rights activist , who he called a \"communist sympathizer\", citing her support for the .\n\nIn 2019, Harris voted against renewing the .\n\nIn 2020, Harris voted against removing an expired congressional deadline for the adoption of the .\n\nIn 2020, Harris said he supported President Trump's decision to  in response to . He voted against removing a marble bust of Justice  from the U.S. Capitol, saying that while he supported proposals to add a bust of Justice , he believed the Taney bust should remain as a \"teaching moment\".\n\n\nThe  which expanded  benefits to veterans exposed to toxic chemicals during their military service, received a \"nay\" from Harris. Regarding cannabis, despite lobbying from  such as the  Harris also voted against .\n\n\n\nDuring the , Harris opposed prohibitions on indoor dining during the  and s, and was skeptical of . In March 2020, he voted for, and later criticized, the . On May 2, 2020, Harris addressed protesters in  attempting to pressure Maryland governor  to lift restrictions, saying, \"I am a physician. Let me tell you something: It is safe to begin to reopen Maryland.\" Harris also called on the state to partially reopen areas with low cases of  and to lift restrictions on \"low-risk businesses\", such as golf courses and small businesses. In February 2021, Harris cosponsored a bill that would block state or local governments from receiving federal COVID-19 relief funds if they enacted restrictions affecting small businesses.\n\nIn August 2020, Harris promoted the use of  to treat COVID-19, despite the lack of evidence for its effectiveness and the subsequent opposition from  and  to its use for the treatment of  in hospitalized patients.\n\nIn December 2020, Harris voted against a measure to raise s sent out under the  to $2,000 per individual. In February 2021, he voted against the .\n\nHarris supported  efforts, but opposed . In March 2021, he led a letter to Acting   urging him to review the two-dose strategy used for 's and 's COVID-19 vaccines, arguing that a single-dose plan would \"save the lives of up to 40,000 American seniors\". In July 2021, amid a surge in COVID-19 cases resulting from the , Harris urged constituents to get the COVID-19 vaccine.\n\n\nIn 2004, Harris criticized a state plan to use s in the 2004 general election and introduced a bill requiring voting machines to print voters' choices onto a paper ballot. He later unsuccessfully sued to block the state from using electronic voting machines during the 2004 elections. In 2006, Harris again criticized the state for using electronic voting machines in its 2006 elections, claiming without evidence that it would lead to voter fraud and suggesting that Iraq and Afghanistan \"had more secure elections than Maryland does\".\n\nIn 2008, Harris supported a bill that would require voters to show  to participate in Maryland elections.\n\nIn 2018, Harris introduced the Protecting Election Systems from Foreign Control Act, which would ban state election boards from contracting with foreign election systems vendors.\n\nIn October 2024, Harris suggested that the  should pre-emptively override the popular vote results in the  and award its electors to Donald Trump because of the impact that  had on Republican-leaning districts.\n\n\nIn August 2020, Harris dismissed accusations that U.S. postmaster general  was attempting to undercut mail-in balloting, which he called a \"conspiracy theory\". He said he opposed using universal  to conduct the , claiming without evidence that it would \"result in people who aren't qualified to have ballots getting them and in some cases people who are qualified not getting them\". Harris later voted against a bill to increase  funding by $25 billion to help the agency prepare for the election.\n\nAfter  won the 2020 presidential election and President Donald Trump refused to concede while making false claims of fraud, Harris defended . Harris falsely claimed there were \"large-scale voting irregularities\" and \"secret, unobserved vote counting in the swing states\", and called on Attorney General  to investigate \"these crimes\".\n\nIn December 2020, Harris was one of 126 Republican members of the  to sign an  in support of '''', a lawsuit filed at the  contesting the results of the . The Supreme Court declined to hear the case on the basis that Texas lacked  under  to challenge the results of an election held by another state.\n\nIn July 2022, the  revealed that Harris was present at a White House meeting with Republican House members on December 21, 2020, to discuss a plan to \"encourage members of the public to fight the outcome on January 6\". He confirmed his attendance to this meeting during a debate in October 2022, during which he said he would \"take the invitation again\" and added that it was \"not planning an insurrection\". Harris also said that he accepted the results of the 2020 presidential election at the debate, and called for .\n\nIn September 2022, Harris voted against the , a bill that made multiple revisions to the voting, certification, counting, and transition process in wake of the .\n\n\nOn October 31, 2019, Harris voted with his fellow Republicans in opposition to a resolution outlining rules for . On December 18, 2019, he voted against both  of the .\n\nHarris was one of four representatives who did not cast a vote regarding the  on January 13, 2021. He tweeted that he opposed it, calling it divisive and a waste of time, and that he needed to be in the operating room caring for patients. During the , Harris cosponsored two different resolutions to  President . He also cosponsored a resolutions to impeach Attorney General  and Secretary of State , who he blamed for the . Very early in the , Harris cosponsored a resolution to impeach Secretary of Homeland Security .\n\n\n\nHarris supports using s to draw redistricting plans for federal offices, calling it the \"biggest thing you could do to increase cooperation between the two parties\". He has described himself as a beneficiary of , pointing to the 1st district's configuration as having been carved out to elect a Republican to Congress and get more Democrats elected elsewhere in Maryland. During his time in the Maryland Senate, Harris sought to pass legislation requiring Maryland to use an independent commission to redraw its districts.\n\nDuring the 2020 redistricting cycle, the Maryland General Assembly redrew Maryland's congressional districts to make Maryland's 1st congressional district more competitive for Democrats by redrawing the 1st district from one that voted for Trump by 20 points to one where Biden slightly won in 2020, an effort that Harris opposed. He instead supported the maps drawn by Governor 's Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission, an independent redistricting commission made up of three Democrats, Republicans, and Independent voters. In March 2022, Judge  struck down the Maryland General Assembly's new congressional districts as an \"extreme partisan \", prompting legislators to pass a new congressional map that undid changes to make the 1st district more competitive.\n\n\nIn an interview with  just after evacuating the Capitol after it was stormed, Harris downplayed the violence of the riot, saying \"Obviously, later we heard there was a gunshot, but other than that, there was no indication that this was a truly violent protest, as violent as one as you would worry about.\" Harris also said he understood the rioters' frustrations and repeated false claims of election fraud. During a debate in October 2022, he denied that the Capitol attack was an \"insurrection\", stating that the only people who had weapons during the attack were .\n\nOn January 6, 2021, after the , Harris had a verbal altercation with Representative  on the House floor after taking offense at Representative 's criticism of House Republicans for pushing unfounded conspiracy theories. During an interview the next day, Harris falsely claimed that leftist provocateurs were behind the storming of the Capitol.\n\nIn May 2021, Harris voted against a measure creating the , calling it \"another partisan stunt from \".\n\nIn June 2021, Harris was among 21 House Republicans to vote against a resolution to give the  to police officers who defended the U.S. Capitol on January 6, which he had called a \"stunt\".\n\n\nHarris supports increasing federal defense funding to combat threats to national security. In 2013, he said he supported cuts to the  and the  to support expanding the military.\n\nIn 2015, Harris voted against the . In 2019, he voted for the , a successor to .\n\n\n\nIn 2018, Harris led a letter opposing a  plan to provide $700,000 for independent media in Hungary, which he charged as having \"distorted the record\" of Hungarian prime minister . In 2022, he praised Orbán's leadership in a speech at the . In 2022, Harris was one of 63 Republicans to vote against a nonbinding resolution to support , which he later defended by saying that the military alliance had \"unfairly criticized the governments of Hungary and Poland\", both of which are members of NATO.\n\n\nIn 2015, Harris said he opposed the , which he said would go toward buying \"weapons that will end up killing Americans at some point in the future\". He later called for increased sanctions on Iran, including a ban on any  in the country.\n\n\nHarris supports Israel's right to defend itself and the . He has criticized the  for funding what he called \"illegal building\" by the  in the , and suggested in December 2022 that the United States should provide funding to Israel for developing infrastructure in these areas. In November 2023, amid the , Harris said he opposed providing humanitarian aid to Palestine and criticized the Biden administration for \"interfering\" with Israel's handling of the war.\n\n\nIn 2011, Harris voted to end the  and to limit the use of funds supporting  operations in Libya.\n\n\nIn 2021, Harris was one of 14 Republican representatives to vote against a measure condemning the .\n\n\nIn 2013, Harris said he opposed the . In 2014, after the Obama administration carried out over 150  on the  in Syria, he called for a new authorization vote on the U.S.-led intervention.\n\nIn April 2017, Harris said he supported the Trump administration's decision to  against the Syrian airfield believed to be responsible for the . He also supported the  following the .\n\nIn 2019, Harris raised concerns over President Trump's , but ultimately voted against condemning the withdrawal. In 2023, he was among 47 Republicans to vote in favor of H.Con.Res. 21, which directed President  to remove U.S. troops from  within 180 days.\n\n\nIn 2019, Harris was one of 16 House members to vote against imposing sanctions against Turkey for its , and one of 11 House members to vote against .\n\n\nHarris is supportive of congressional efforts to provide Ukraine with various forms of aid amid the . In April 2022, he co-signed a letter to President  urging him to extend  to Ukrainian refugees who sought to enter the United States.\n\nDuring a town hall meeting in August 2023, Harris suggested that the U.S. should begin winding down on aid to Ukraine and negotiating for the end of the war, pointing to the national deficit and the , which he deemed to be a failure.\n\n\nDuring the primary race of the  to fill the Senate seat formerly held by , Harris endorsed  in his primary campaign against the incumbent, . Following the news of , Harris said Moore should withdraw from the race if the allegations were true.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHarris was married for 30 years to Sylvia \"Cookie\" Harris, who died of a heart attack on August 28, 2014. They had five children. In July 2017, he married Nicole Beus, a Baltimore County political and marketing consultant who serves as the chair of the .\n\nHarris lives in  on the Eastern Shore, having previously lived in , a suburb of Baltimore. He considered himself a \"citizen-legislator,\" having maintained his medical practice while in the State Senate.\n \nHarris has been an active member in the community as a member of the , an officer in the Thornleigh Neighborhood Improvement Association (vice president, 1984–85; president, 1985–86), a member of the Board of Directors of the Sherwood Community Association (1987–91), and vice president of St. Joseph's School Home-School Association from 1992 to 1994. He also served on the Board of Directors of the Maryland Leadership Council (1995–98), as a member of the North Central Republican Club (treasurer, 1997–98; vice president, 1998), and as a delegate to the 2004 . Harris received the Dr. Henry P. and M. Page Laughlin Distinguished Public Officer Award from the  in 2001.\n\n\nOn January 21, 2021, Harris tried to enter the House floor with a gun, setting off a . This was in violation of new security measures adopted after the . Harris was not allowed to enter and returned 10 minutes later without a gun, at which point he was allowed entry.  began an investigation into the incident.\n\n\nIn October 2021, Harris said on a radio show he prescribed  to constituents for treatment of . Ivermectin is used to treat parasites in livestock and river blindness in humans. It is not approved by the  for treatment of COVID-19. During a discussion of vaccine mandates by the  in November 2021, Harris said that a complaint was filed against him with a physicians board for prescribing ivermectin.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Donald F. Munson''' (born December 21, 1937) is a former  who represented district 2 (). He was defeated in both a  and  in 2010 by Delegate .\n\n\nDonald F. Munson is an American politician from the state of . He started his political career in 1975 when he won the seat in the House of Delegates for district 2, representing Washington County. He won reelection three times before running for the seat in the State Senate in 1990 where he handily defeated  , who finished her late husband's term, with 64% of the vote.\n\nIn 1994, Munson won reelection against Democratic challenger Laura J. Wright, winning with 82% of the vote. In 1998, Munson went unchallenged, receiving 100% of the vote. Mary Newby challenged him in 2002, yet only received 29% of the vote to Munson's 70%. In 2006 Munson won re-election with 98.9% of the vote.\n\nOn September 14, 2010, Munson was defeated in the  primary election by State Delegate Chris Shank. Munson received 42.95% of the vote, compared to 57.05% received by Delegate Shank.\n\n\nMunson attended  while growing up in Washington County. After high school, he graduated from the  with a B.A. in mathematics in 1968.\n\n\nMunson got his first taste of politics in 1953 when he became a  for U.S. Representative . He also served in the . In his community, he is active in many organizations including the Washington County Republican Club , the Washington County Historical Society , Washington County Association for Retarded Citizens, the Antietam Exchange Club, the North American Rod & Gun Club , and the Alsatia Club.\n\nMunson has won numerous awards, including the Legislator of the Year from the Maryland Retailers Association  in 2003, the Outstanding Rural Legislator Award from the Rural Maryland Council  in 2004, and the  Public Service Award from  in 2004.\n\nAs a member of the , Munson serves on numerous committees, including the Budget and Taxation Committee, the Joint Committee on Federal Relations, the Rules Committee, the Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, and the Joint Commission on the , to name a few.\n\n\nDuring the 2010 legislative session, Munson was a sponsor of the Correctional Officers Bill of Rights, SB 887. This bill\n*Provides for specified rights of a State correctional officer relating to employment, investigation, and discipline under specified circumstances.\n*Provides for the procedures for the investigation or interrogation of a State correctional officers\n* Establishes procedures for an application for a show cause order under specified circumstances.\n*Establishes a specified limitation on administrative charges against a State correctional officer.\n\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 election for Maryland State Senate – 2nd District'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 election for Maryland State Senate – 2nd District'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 election for Maryland State Senate – 2nd District'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 election for Maryland State Senate – 2nd District'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1986 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 2C'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/05sen/html/msa12155.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Veronica L. Turner''' (born February 7, 1950) is an  who represents  in the .\n\n\nTurner was born in , on February 7, 1950. She attended , , and the . From 1996 to 2018, Turner served as the president of  (SEIU) Local 63.\n\nAfter the death of  councilmember James C. Fletcher Jr. in 1994, Turner unsuccessfully ran in the special election to serve the rest of his term. She unsuccessfully ran again for the County Council in 2002, losing to  in the Democratic primary by just over 200 votes.\n\n\n\nTurner was a member of the House of Delegates January 8, 2003, to January 14, 2015. Turner declined to run for re-election in 2014, instead running for  and challenging incumbent state Senator . She lost to Muse in the Democratic primary election, coming 2,000 votes shy of defeating him.\n\nTurner was re-elected to the House of Delegates in 2018 and was sworn in on January 9, 2019.\n\n\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, since 2019 (business regulation subcommittee, 2020–present; property & casualty insurance subcommittee, since 2020)\n* Member, Ways and Means Committee, 2019 (education subcommittee, 2019; election law subcommittee, 2019)\n* Member, Health and Government Operations Committee, 2003–2015 (government operations subcommittee, 2003–04; health occupations subcommittee, 2003–2004; public health subcommittee, 2003–2005; health insurance subcommittee, 2004; insurance subcommittee, 2004; health facilities, equipment & products subcommittee, 2005; health facilities & occupations subcommittee, 2005–2010; public health & long-term care subcommittee, 2005–2015; minority health disparities subcommittee, 2011–2015)\n* Member, Joint Committee on Health Care Delivery and Financing, 2005–2014\n* Member, Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 2011–2015\n* House Vice-chair, Protocol Committee, 2014–2015\n\n\n* 2nd vice-chair, , 2012–2014 (law enforcement & state-appointed boards committee, 2003–07; bi-county committee, 2008–2010; vice-chair, Maryland-national capital park & planning commission committee, 2008–2010; vice-chair, county affairs committee, 2011–2012, member, 2013–2015)\n* Member, , 2003–2015, since 2019 (2nd vice-chair, 2004–2006; 1st vice-chair, 2006–2008; chair, 2008–2010)\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2003–2015, since 2019 (endorsement committee, 2006)\n\n\n\nTurner introduced legislation in the 2005 legislative session that would limit the number of patients that nurses could care for. The bill was withdrawn on March 18, 2005.\n\n\nTurner supported the , a bill to legalize  in Maryland, but was unable to vote for it because she had an emergency surgery for a serious illness on the day of the vote. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 72–67 and was signed into law by Governor  on March 2, 2012.\n\nIn January 2019, Turner voted for legislation to lift a ban on developer contributions in county political races. The bill passed out of committee by a vote of 18–5.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ida Gass Ruben''' (born '''Ida Fanny Gass'''; January 7, 1929 – November 1, 2024) was an American politician who served in the  from the 20th district from 1975 to 1987 and in the  from the 20th district from 1987 to 2007.\n\nIda Fanny Gass was born in Washington on January 7, 1929, and married  (died 2007) in 1948. They had four sons.\n\nRuben was first elected to the House of Delegates in 1974, filling a seat that had been vacated by her husband, who was appointed to a judgeship. She became a state senator in 1987 and served in the chamber for 20 years, rising to the position of president pro tem before losing her seat to  in the 2006 election. During her time in office, she helped pass laws to protect victims of domestic violence, and to enforce child support payments.\n\nRuben died in  on November 1, 2024, at the age of 95. Following this, Governor  ordered state flags to fly at half-staff in Ruben's honor.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Marilyn Rubin Goldwater''' (January 29, 1927 – January 7, 2023) was an American politician from  and a member of the . She was a Member of the , 1975–86, and 1995–2007, representing Maryland's Legislative District 16 in .\n\nGoldwater was born in , . She graduated from the  School of Nursing in  in 1948 as a  (RN) before working as an  nurse and hospital administrator.\n\nAfter moving to Maryland in 1960, Goldwater became active in local politics, initially through her children's  and later being elected president of the Women's Suburban Democratic Club. She was first elected to the Maryland legislature in 1974, and as a freshman delegate, she was one of the first two women to be appointed to the Appropriations Committee. She later ran unsuccessfully for  and served in the administration of Governor  as a health policy adviser. In that position, she helped to start the Governor's Wellmobile Program, operated by the Maryland School of Nursing. At the conclusion of Gov. Schaefer's second term, Goldwater ran again for the District 16 Delegate seat, returning to the House of Delegates in 1995. As a legislator, Goldwater was known for her healthcare advocacy; she also supported the  and opposed slot machines.\n\nGoldwater retired from the House of Delegates on August 27, 2007. She died from  on January 7, 2023, at her daughter's home in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert Leroy Ehrlich Jr.''' (born November 25, 1957) is an American lawyer and politician who served as the  from 2003 to 2007. A , Ehrlich represented Maryland's  in the  from 1987 to 1995 and Maryland's  in the  from 1995 to 2003.\n\nEhrlich was the first Republican to serve as governor of Maryland since  left office in 1969. He served one term before being defeated in his  by Democrat . In , Ehrlich sought an unsuccessful rematch against O'Malley. Ehrlich then announced, via his website, that he would \"return to private life.\" In October 2011, he was named chair of 's Maryland campaign for the .\n\n\nEhrlich was born in the Southwest Baltimore suburb of , the son of Nancy (Bottorf), a legal secretary, and Robert Leroy Ehrlich, a commission car salesman. After attending , he studied at , where he attended on a partial scholarship and was captain of the football team and a member of the . Ehrlich graduated from Princeton with an A.B. in politics in 1979 after completing a 140-page long senior thesis titled \": The Man and His Politics.\" He continued on to law school, graduating from  in 1982.\n\nAfter law school, Ehrlich worked for Ober, Kaler, Grimes & Shriver, a Baltimore law firm, and became active in politics. In November 1986, Ehrlich won a seat in the , representing parts of  from 1987 to 1995.\n\n\nHe married  in 1993. They have two sons, Drew Robert Ehrlich and Joshua Taylor Ehrlich.\n\nAs of 2013, he was a frequent guest on the ''.''\n\n\n\nIn 1993,  Representative  announced she would be vacating her seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. Ehrlich announced his candidacy for the open seat and won the election in November 1994. During his term, he introduced legislation aimed at helping  people maintain employment and supported harsher  penalties.\n\nWhile in Congress, Ehrlich served on the U.S. House . He was also a member of the subcommittees on health, telecommunications and the Internet, and environment and hazardous materials; the Congressional Biotechnology Caucus, where he served as co-chairman; and the . In 1999, He voted to remove president  from office during .\n\nEhrlich won all his elections in Congress by margins of at least 25%. He announced he would be forgoing reelection in 2002 to run for governor. He was succeeded by .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2002, Democratic Governor 's second term was ending. While Glendening had been reelected by a substantial margin in 1998, the final years of his term were plagued by a personal marital crisis, and a large state . The rural areas of Marylandlargely Republicanhad long criticized Glendening for what they perceived as zealous environmental regulations; in addition, they believed that he did not give sufficient attention to their needs for infrastructure improvements (bridges, highways, etc.).\n\nOn March 15, 2002, Ehrlich announced his candidacy for the governorship. He attacked Glendening's record, tying his Democratic opponent, Lt. Gov. , to him. Ehrlich promised, if elected, to increase school funding, balance the budget, and protect the . His running mate was , an African-American and the chair of the .\n\nDuring the election, Townsend was criticized for her choice of running mate; she picked retired  , a novice politician who had switched parties only a few weeks before. The Townsend campaign was also hurt by the unpopularity of Glendening, who had implemented a  proposal that was overturned by Maryland's highest court. Townsend's popularity continued to fall when it was reported that much of her campaign money was given by out-of-state donors; Ehrlich remained on the attack while the lieutenant governor's poll numbers declined.\n\nThough  traditionally votes Democratic and had not elected a Republican governor in almost 40 years, Ehrlich won the race (52% of the vote to Townsend's 47%). He was the sixth Republican governor in state history and the first since  left office to take the  in 1969.\n\n\n\nEhrlich said \"fiscal responsibility, education, health, and the environment, public safety, and commerce\" were the \"Five Pillars\" of his administration. He opposed sales and  increases and supported legalization of s to raise revenue.\n\nUnder Ehrlich's tenure, Maryland stayed 0.5% or more below the national unemployment average. The unemployment rate dropped significantly from 4.5% in 2003 to 3.9% in 2006, with an increase of 98,000 private sector jobs, aided by its proximity to the strong labor market associated with the national capital.\n\nEhrlich established a Department of Disabilities within his cabinet for people with disabilities&nbsp;– the first such cabinet-level agency in the nation.\n\nIn 2004, Ehrlich signed the Chesapeake Bay Restoration Act: it funds upgrades of water treatment plants to reduce pollution discharge by a surcharge on business and residential water and septic bills. The resulting reduction in pollution into the bay was expected to meet approximately one-third of Maryland's obligations under the 2000 . The Chesapeake Bay Foundation described the Chesapeake Bay Restoration Act as the most significant piece of legislation for the Bay in a generation.\n\nEhrlich opposed President 's 2006 approval for a  firm to take control of six U.S. port operations, including those at the . (See ).\n\nIn 2006, Ehrlich signed a law banning police traffic ticket quotas.\n\n\nIn January 2006, Ehrlich vetoed the \"Fair Share Health Care Bill,\" also known as the  Bill, which required businesses with more than 10,000 employees in the state (three of the four companies being Walmart, , and ) to either spend eight percent of payroll on employee health care, or pay that amount to a state health program for the uninsured. The bill was commonly nicknamed after Walmart because it was the only company in Maryland of that size that did not already spend the requisite eight percent. Ehrlich, after consulting with counsel regarding the legal validity of the bill, vetoed the proposed legislation as it would run afoul of federal law. Despite this, and over the pleas of state representatives whose constituents benefited from Walmart's employment and feared a diminished presence in the state, the Democratic legislators of the Maryland Legislature passed the bill over Ehrlich's veto, in part leading to cancellation of the building of a Walmart distribution center in one of Maryland's poorest counties.\n\nCritics of the international discount chain claimed that Wal-Mart's low wages force employees and their dependents to rely on state healthcare assistance. (See ). The bill's supporters claimed that the veto showed Ehrlich, whose official biography describes him as \"unapologetically pro-business,\" had sided with \"big corporate interests rather than Maryland's working families.\" For his part, Ehrlich called the bill the \"first step toward government-run health care\" by \"anti-jobs lawmakers.\" He claimed that it would hurt low and middle-income consumers and was unfair to Wal-Mart and other businesses. On July 7, 2006, the Maryland law was overturned in federal court by U.S. District Judge Frederick Motz, who ruled that the law violated the  (ERISA) of 1974, while also noting that it would \"hurt Wal-Mart by imposing the administrative burden of tracking benefits in Maryland differently than in other states.\"\n\n\n\nGovernor Ehrlich opted to seek a second term and did not face opposition in the Republican primary. On November 7, 2006, Ehrlich was defeated for re-election in the  by Baltimore Mayor , who won 53% to Ehrlich's 46%.  Ehrlich's term as governor expired at noon on January 17, 2007.\n\n\nA month after he left public office, Ehrlich and several aides from his administration opened a Baltimore-area office of North Carolina law firm . His wife Kendel took a consulting job as a director of the BankAnnapolis.\n\nIn March 2007, Ehrlich endorsed former New York Mayor  for the US presidency. He was the Chairman of Giuliani's Mid-Atlantic Campaign Committee.\n\nEhrlich and his wife hosted their own radio show on  Radio every Saturday from 2007 to 2010. Governor Ehrlich has guest lectured at Towson University in Professor 's political persuasion class twice a year since 1993.\n\n\n\n\n\nOn March 30, Ehrlich announced that he would challenge incumbent Governor Martin O'Malley.\n\nIn June 2010, Ehrlich was endorsed by Terrapin basketball standout and  NBA draft pick . On June 30, 2010, Ehrlich announced that his running mate would be , who had served under Governor Ehrlich as secretary of state, August 2, 2005, to January 17, 2007, and also as deputy secretary of state and chief legal counsel, March 2003 to August 2, 2005. He easily won the Republican primary.\n\nHis former lieutenant governor, then Chairman of the Republican National Committee , traveled to Maryland on his \"Fire Pelosi\" bus tour to endorse Ehrlich. Former Massachusetts Governor  also appeared at a fundraiser to endorse Ehrlich. Former New York City Mayor  campaigned in Maryland with Ehrlich, calling him \"one of the best governors of all-time.\"\n\nIn the general election, Ehrlich lost again to O'Malley 56% to 42%.\n\nIn December 2011, Ehrlich's 2010 campaign manager, Paul E. Schurick, was convicted of four counts of fraud and conspiracy concerning a scheme to suppress the black vote using 112,000 fraudulent s, which discouraged voters from going to the polls. Political consultant Julius Hensen was also convicted on one count.\n\n\nIn October 2011, Ehrlich was named chairman of 's Maryland campaign for .\n\nAfter initially supporting  as a Republican candidate in the , Ehrlich endorsed nominee  in May 2016.\n\n\n in 2017]]\nAs of December 2020, Ehrlich was working as  in the Washington office of , a major corporate law firm, on the governmental advocacy and public policy (lobbying) team.\n\nIn August 2022, the Maryland Republican Party announced that Ehrlich would lead its \"2022 Victory Campaign\" to support the party's nominees in that year's elections, including  and . He spent most of his tenure fundraising for the Maryland Republican Party as a whole. Cox and Peroutka were defeated in a landslide by Democratic nominees  and  in the general election on November 8, 2022.\n\n\n\n! style=\"background:#ccc;\"|Year\n!     "pages": }\n\n'''Martha S. Klima''' (born December 3, 1938) was first elected in 1982 to represent District 9, which covered a portion of , USA.  She unsuccessfully ran for the State Senate in 2002.  She was defeated by .\n\n\nKlima served in the  for 20 years.  First elected in 1982 and sworn in in 1983, she served on many committees, including: the Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee from 1983 until 1986, the Appropriations Committee from 1987 until 2003, the oversight committee on personnel from 1993 until 2003, the Joint Budget and Audit Committee from 1991 until 1994, the Special Joint Committee on Pensions from 1993 until 2003 and the Special Joint Committee on Group Homes from 1995 until 1997.\n\nShe was the Deputy Minority Whip from 1995 until 2002. She was also a member of the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review from 1995 until 2003, the Joint Committee on Welfare Reform from 1996 until 2003 and the Spending Affordability Committee from 1998 until 2003. She was the Vice-President of the Women Legislators of Maryland in 1988. She is a member of the National Conference of State Legislators. Finally, she was the chair of the Telecommunications and Information Technology Task Force for the  (ALEC).\n\n\nKlima graduated with her associate degree from  in .\n\n\nKlima's primary job early in life was a homemaker. However, she was also involved in politics early in life.  She is a past secretary of the Central Maryland Health Systems Agency. She was elected as a delegate to the , which nominated  and .\n\nAdditionally, Klima was a member of the Baltimore County Chamber of Commerce, once serving as chair of the membership relations committee. She is a past member and governing trustee of the Council on Economic Education in Maryland. She was a board member for the Center for Prevention of Child Abuse of Maryland, and vice-chair of the  from 1986 until 1991.\n\nKlima has won numerous awards and received recognition during her long career, including being appointed an honorary life member of the Maryland Congress of Parents and Teachers.  She was once received the Woman of the Year Award from the Towsontowne Business and Professional Women's Club in 1988. She was awarded Outstanding Legislative Member by ALEC in 1994. She also received the Legislative Award from the Baltimore County Commission on Disabilities in 1994. She also received the Public Service Award from the Baltimore Association for Retarded Citizens in 1994 and finally, the Legislator of the Year award from ALEC in 2001.\n\nFrom 2003 through 2009, she served  on the Maryland Parole Commission.\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland State Senate – District 42''' Retrieved on Nov. 14, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9A''' Retrieved on Nov. 14, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9B''' Retrieved on Nov. 14, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9''' Retrieved on Nov. 14, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1986 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 9''' Retrieved on Nov. 14, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/former/html/msa12256.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kelly M. Schulz''' (born January 2, 1969) is an American politician who served as the Secretary of the Maryland Department of Commerce from January 2019 to January 2022 and earlier as Secretary of the . She served in the  representing , . She ran unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination for Governor of Maryland in , losing to state delegate .\n\n\nSchulz was born on January 2, 1969, in . She attended college, but left at age 19 when she became pregnant. She married, had another child, and worked a series of jobs, including bartending and waiting tables. She later returned to college, attending  in , and earning an  degree in 2003. In the same year, she moved to Frederick County for her husband's job. She completed her undergraduate studies at , earning a  in  in 2006.\n\n\nSchulz is a former aide to the Maryland House Republican Caucus. Her service to the  was recognized with the Grass Roots Activist Award in 2005 and she represented Maryland at the .\n\n\nSchulz won a seat in the two-member District 4A in Frederick County by finishing first in a field of five candidates in the . In the primary election Schulz finished second, edging out incumbent Delegate  by six votes. Schulz was sworn in on January 12, 2011, and was assigned to the House Economic Matters committee. She was a member of the Women Legislators of Maryland.\n\nIn 2012, Schulz filed to run as a Delegate to the , representing . She received 2.1 percent of the vote in the Republican primary election.\n\n\nOn December 17, 2014, Governor-Elect  announced at a press conference that he had chosen Schulz to be his Secretary for the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation. The  unanimously approved her nomination on February 13, 2015. She was sworn in on March 13, 2015.\n\n\nAs Secretary of Labor, Schulz sought to improve Maryland's image among businesses and piloted  programs to prepare youth for  careers.  expressed concern with Schulz's policies, including those concerning .\n\nOn December 17, 2018, Hogan announced that Schulz would succeed Mike Gill as Maryland Secretary of Commerce. Her nomination was unanimously approved by the Maryland Senate on February 8, 2019. She was sworn in on January 9, 2019.\n\nDuring her tenure at the Department of Commerce, the agency played a role in keeping businesses operating during the . Following the pandemic, Schulz sought to promote business through a state marketing effort called \"Innovation Uncovered\".\n\nOn December 30, 2021, the Hogan administration announced that Schulz would leave the administration alongside Maryland Transportation Secretary Greg Slater in order to focus on her gubernatorial campaign. Hogan named Mike Gill, her predecessor, to succeed Schulz as Secretary of Commerce effective January 11, 2022.\n\n\n\n (center), 2022]]\nOn April 14, 2021, Schulz announced that she would vie to become the state's first female  by running to be the Republican nominee in the . Her running mate was Jeff Woolford, an Air Force veteran and assistant Health secretary. She was endorsed by Hogan, who was stepping down as required by Maryland .\n\nDuring the primary, Schulz was noted for withdrawing from many of the candidate forums held around the state, refusing to take a stage with her main opponent . The Schulz campaign said this was to avoid propping up Cox, who was  than the more  Schulz. Cox had been endorsed by former president , who had criticized Governor Hogan and attacked Schulz as a . The primary between Cox and Schulz was seen by election analysts as a proxy war between Hogan and Trump. The  (DGA) spent $1 million on television ads promoting Cox, believing him to be a weaker opponent in a .\n\n\n\nOn July 19, 2022, Schulz lost the primary to Cox, earning 43.5 percent of the vote to Cox's 52.0 percent. Schulz declined to endorse Cox after conceding on July 29, predicting correctly that Democratic nominee  would defeat him in the general election.\n\nJim Dornan, who worked as an on-and-off political strategist for the Schulz campaign, attributed Cox's primary victory to Trump's endorsement and the DGA ad blitz. Other observers, including former  and  chair , said the ads had little impact on voters. Steele noted that  activist  won his primary to be the GOP's candidate for  by an almost identical margin to Cox without DGA ads.\n\n\n, 2023]]\nIn October 2022, the Maryland Tech Council announced that Schulz would serve as the trade association's CEO, beginning on November 1. In February 2023, Schulz was named as a member of the  Board of Associates.\n\n\n\nDuring her 2022 campaign, Schulz said that she supported  and advocated for keeping schools open. She also drafted a \"parental bill of rights\" that included promises to post classroom lessons online, expand the use of s in classrooms, make it easier to open public s, increase funding for private school scholarships, and \"keep partisan politics out of the classroom\".\n\n\nIn August 2013, Schulz called for an investigation into the integrity of Maryland's elections in the state after conservative activist group  claimed to find 173 cases of interstate  in .\n\nSchulz introduced legislation in the 2014 legislative session that would allow  for  elections.\n\n\nSchulz introduced several pieces of  legislation during the 2015 legislative session before she resigned to join the Hogan administration. The first bill would have allowed licensed gun shops to instigate a  and sell firearms to a person upon passing the background check. The second bill would have allowed owners of s to repair broken parts of a firearm that is registered with the . The third would have changed Maryland from a  to a  state. The fourth and final bill would have repealed a law that requires shell casings to be sent to the Department of State Police Crime Laboratory, which maintains a database of discharged casings to track guns that may be used in crimes.\n\n\nIn January 2011, Schulz said she opposed legislation that would provide financial aid to . She also said she thought the state should prevent illegal immigrants from receiving  or .\n\nSchulz opposed legislation introduced in the 2013 legislative session that would allow undocumented workers to obtain limited s.\n\n\nIn 2012, Schulz worked to weaken the Workplace Fraud Act, which gave employers twice as much time to produce records and added exemptions for employers.\n\nIn December 2013, Schulz wrote an op-ed for the '''' criticizing legislation that would raise the state's minimum wage from $7.25 to $10 per hour. She voted against the bill in the House Economic Matters Committee, which passed it, 13–8. Schulz did remove a provision from the bill that would have indexed increases of the minimum wage to .\n\nIn 2017, Governor Hogan appointed Schulz to chair a committee to investigate  policy. In November, the group released a 72-page report containing its conclusions on the implementation of statewide paid-leave legislation.\n\nIn February 2019, Schulz wrote to lawmakers to urge them to consider implementing regional or county wage rates into legislation that would increase the state's minimum wage to .\n\n\nDuring a debate on legislation that would legalize  in Maryland, Schulz introduced an amendment that would report medical marijuana use on the state's . The House of Delegates rejected the amendment.\n\nIn August 2021, Schulz said that she did not have a policy position on the , but mentioned that  was an important economic development opportunity.\n\n\nAs a state delegate, Schulz sponsored and voted for bills that would have restricted abortion rights in Maryland, including a bill to block state funding for abortion services and proposed ballot referendum to amend the state constitution to extend the state's constitutional rights to people \"from the beginning of their biological development\". During her gubernatorial campaign, Schulz said that she personally opposes abortion but would not move to change current Maryland law.\n\nIn January 2012, Schulz said that she opposed  and supported a grassroots movement to start a  to overturn same-sex marriage legislation. She voted against legislation introduced in the 2012 legislative session that would legalize same-sex marriage in Maryland.\n\nSchulz opposes  and , saying that both should be up to the individual.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes =153,423\n| percentage =52.0\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes =128,302\n| percentage =43.5\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes =8,268\n| percentage =2.8\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes =5,075\n| percentage =1.7\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* - \n* at \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Royden Patrick Dyson''' (born November 15, 1948), is a former   politician from . Dyson served in the  from 1980 to 1991 and as a  from 1995 to 2015.\n\n\nDyson was born in . Dyson attended private schools and graduated from Great Mills High School in 1966.  He attended the , and the  in 1968, 1969, and 1970.  He also served as a legislative assistant in the United States House of Representatives from 1973 to 1974 for U.S. Representative  of Michigan.\n\n\nIn 1975, Dyson was elected to the  for district 29. The following year, Dyson ran for Congress in the -based 1st District, losing to two-term  . In 1978 he was a delegate in 1978 to the Democratic National Issues Conference. In 1980, Dyson narrowly defeated Bauman after Bauman suffered a sex scandal in the weeks prior to election day.\n\n\n\nIn the 1988 election, Dyson was dogged by allegations of improper contributions from defense contractors. His Republican opponent was , a high school teacher who had never run for office before.  Dyson won by a smaller than projected margin of 1,431 votes. \n\nDuring his campaign, Dyson's chief of staff  committed suicide by jumping from a building while on a trip to New York with Dyson to meet with executives from . Shortly before the trip, Pappas was the subject of a front-page '''' article, accusing Pappas of misconduct. Dyson refuted the article's claims as untrue. Others critiqued the front page piece piece for obfuscating facts and suggesting innuendo to titillate readers.\n\n\nIn 1990, Gilchrest defeated Dyson 57% to 43% despite again being badly outspent by Dyson, who received substantial PAC contributions in all of his later campaigns.\n\nIn 1995, Dyson was elected to the , representing District 29 ( and southern ). He served in the Maryland Senate until January 14, 2015 after losing the  to Republican Steve Waugh.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n* \n*  in Congress\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Teresa Saavedra Woorman''' (born September 2, 1991) is an American politician who is a member of the  from the .\n\n\nWoorman was born in  on September 2, 1991. Woorman and her family immigrated to  when she was nine years old. After graduating from  in 2009, she attended , where she earned an  in international business in 2012, and the , where she earned a  degree in government and politics in 2015. Woorman became a U.S. citizen while attending college. \n\n\nWoorman worked for the  for seven years after graduating, including as chief of staff and legislative director for several of its members from 2016 to 2021 and as the campaign manager of  incumbents in 2018. She was also the executive vice president of Maryland Young Democrats from 2023 to 2024, and the chair of Pro-Choice Maryland's board of directors from 2022 to 2024. Woorman ran for delegate to the , pledged to  in the primary. She attended the 2020 Democratic National Convention pledged to . She was a delegate to the  pledged to . During the , she served as the campaign manager for 's reelection campaign and as the deputy finance director for 's . Since 2023, Woorman has worked as a public information officer for the Montgomery County government.\n\n\nIn April 2022, Woorman was selected to fill a vacancy on the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee. She was then elected to this position in July 2022, and became the party's secretary in December 2022. In June 2024, following the appointment of state delegate  to the  after 's resignation, Woorman applied to serve the remainder of Love's term in the Maryland House of Delegates. During interviews with the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee (MCDCC), she told party members that she would prioritize housing affordability, ethics reforms, and health equity bills in the legislature. The MCDCC voted 14–10 to nominate Woorman on July 11, 2024. She was sworn in on August 12, 2024 and is a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee. \n\nWoorman has been recognized for her leadership and contributions within the political community. In 2023, she was honored with ''The Dorothy Davidson Award'' from the Montgomery County Young Democrats. In 2024, she received the ''Emerging Leader Award'' from the Latino Democratic Club of Montgomery County, highlighting her influence and dedication to the Latino community.\n\n\nWoorman is married to her husband, Matthew, an opera singer, and they live in .\n\nWoorman received national attention during the , one week after being sworn in to the Maryland House of Delegates. The camera panned to Woorman during 's prime time speech, immediately after Winfrey's reference to 's remarks regarding \".\" Many watching the convention live found this humorous, comparing the broadcast's camerawork to the comedic camera pans used on '''', resulting in the moment . Woorman responded to the moment graciously, confirming on social media that she currently has two cats (Snow White and Oscar), a dog (Gatsby), and no children. A few weeks after the convention in September 2024, Winfrey sent Woorman a bouquet of \"over 300\" roses, a basket of cat toys, a litter vacuum, and a note that said, \"Thank you for rising to this moment with grace and humor\".\n\nWoorman is fluent in Spanish, English, French, and Italian.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
