    "pages": }\n'''John Kevin Delaney''' (born April 16, 1963) is an American politician, businessman, and former attorney who was the  for  from 2013 to 2019. He was a candidate in the .\n\nOn July 28, 2017, Delaney became the first Democrat to announce his . Delaney did not run for re-election to Congress in 2018, choosing to focus on his presidential campaign.  In November 2018, fellow Democrat  was elected to succeed Delaney in Congress, and subsequently endorsed him for . Delaney suspended his campaign on January 31, 2020, citing low poll numbers and wanting to avoid pulling support from other candidates. He later endorsed  for president.\n\n\nDelaney grew up in , the son of Elaine (Rowe), and Jack Delaney, an electrician. He is the nephew of former   . He is of three quarters Irish and one quarter English descent. Delaney spent part of his youth working at his father's construction sites.\n\nDelaney graduated from . Scholarships from his father's labor union () as well as the , , and the  helped Delaney attend college; he earned a  degree from  in 1985, and a  degree from  in 1988.\n\n\nDelaney co-founded two companies that were publicly traded on the . He won the  in 2004.\n\nIn 1993, Delaney co-founded Health Care Financial Partners (HCFP), to make loans available to smaller-sized health care service providers said to be ignored by larger banks. HCFP  in 1996, and its stock began trading on the  in 1998. Health Care Financial Partners was acquired by  in 1999.\n\nIn 2000, Delaney co-founded , a commercial lender headquartered in ; the company provided capital to roughly 5,000 small and mid-size businesses before his departure. In 2010, while Delaney was CEO, CapitalSource was awarded a Bank Enterprise Award from the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund by the U.S. Treasury Department for its investment in low-income and economically distressed communities. In 2005, CapitalSource was named one of '''' magazine's best places to work for its company culture and employee benefits.\n\nCapitalSource continued to be publicly traded on the NYSE after Delaney's election, making him the only former CEO of a publicly traded company to serve in the . In 2014, the lender merged with .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting following the 2010 census, Delaney decided to run for the newly redrawn 6th district against 10-term Republican incumbent . The district had long been a Republican stronghold, but it had been significantly reconfigured. The  shifted much of heavily Republican  and the more rural sections of  into the heavily Democratic . It also shifted Republican-tilting sections of  and  counties, as well as another section of Carroll, into the already heavily Republican . Taking their place was a heavily Democratic spur of western Montgomery County previously in the 8th District. The redrawn district's share of Montgomery County ended just two blocks from Delaney's home in . The redrawn district, the state's second-largest, included nearly the entire western portion of the state, but the bulk of its vote came from the outer suburbs of \n\nOn paper, this dramatically altered the district's demographics, turning it from a heavily Republican district into a Democratic-leaning district.  While  carried the 6th with 57 percent of the vote in 2008,  would have carried the new 6th with 56 percent. The Montgomery County share of the district has three times as many people as the rest of the district combined.\n\nThe shifts were quite controversial, as Republicans accused Democrats of shifting district boundaries in their favor, and former Governor  later admitted the redrawn districts would favor Democrats. \"That was my hope,\" O'Malley told attorneys in a deposition. \"It was also my intent to create ... a district where the people would be more likely to elect a Democrat than a Republican.\"\n\nDuring the primary, Delaney was endorsed by former President , U.S. Congresswoman , Comptroller , '''', and the ''Gazette''.\n\nOn April 3, 2012, Delaney won the five-candidate Democratic primary field with 54% of the vote. The next closest opponent, State Senator , received 29% of the vote, 25 points behind Delaney.\n\nIn the November 6, 2012 general election, Delaney defeated Bartlett by 59%–38%, a 21-point margin. He won the Montgomery County share of the district by almost 56,000 votes, accounting for almost all of the overall margin of 58,900 votes.\n\n\n\nDelaney faced a closer-than-expected contest for reelection against , the Republican candidate in 2012 for U.S. Senate from Maryland. While Delaney won just one of the district's five counties, that one county was Montgomery, which he carried by over 20,500 votes. Delaney ultimately won the race by just over 2,200 votes.\n\n\n\nDelaney won a third term in 2016, taking 56 percent of the vote to Republican Amie Hoeber's 40 percent.\n\n\n\nDelaney introduced legislation to end partisan . The  would appoint independent redistricting commissions nationwide to end partisan gerrymandering, make Election Day a federal holiday, and create an open top-two primary system.\n\nDelaney was ranked as the 53rd most bipartisan member of the U.S. House of Representatives during the  (and the most bipartisan member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Maryland) in the Bipartisan Index created by  and the  that ranks members of the United States Congress by their degree of bipartisanship (by measuring the frequency each member's bills attract co-sponsors from the opposite party and each member's co-sponsorship of bills by members of the opposite party).  In 2015, a similar ranking by the nonpartisan site GovTrack ranked Delaney third highest for bipartisanship among all House Democrats.\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* ''''''\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\nDespite a rumored bid to run against governor  in , Delaney bypassed the  altogether. On July 28, 2017, he announced his run for president in 2020 in a '''' op-ed.\n\nDelaney favored  and proposed a public plan that would cover all Americans under the age of 65 (while leaving  for those over 65 untouched). He opposed Medicare-for-all, arguing that advocacy for the policy would help incumbent President  get re-elected. During a June 2019 debate, Delaney claimed that hospitals will be shuttered under ; , the ''Washington Post'' fact-checker, and  all found this claim to be false and unsubstantiated.\n\nDelaney dropped out of the presidential race on January 31, 2020. He cited his failure to gain traction in polls and wanting to avoid pulling support from other moderate candidates as reasons behind the suspension of his campaign. On March 6, 2020, he endorsed .\n\n\n\nDelaney has been frequently referred to as a \"moderate\". However, he does not entirely identify as such. Delaney has remarked,\n\n}}\n\nHowever, statements made since then suggest he has embraced the moderate label. Appearing on PBS NewsHour on May 8, 2019, Delaney remarked, \"I am probably the most moderate candidate\" in the field of 2020 Democratic presidential candidates.\n\nHe has received the top score of 100 from the  for his support of equality-related legislation, with him stating \"No one should be discriminated against because of who they are or who they love\" in response to this recognition.\n\nDelaney has said he would support increasing the  rate from 21 percent to 23 percent \"to raise about $200 billion for infrastructure\".\n\n\n and her husband, 2024]]\nDelaney and his wife  (née McClain) met at . They married in  in 1989, and moved to the  after graduating. Together, they live in  and have four daughters; Summer, Brooke, Lily, and Grace. April served as deputy administrator of the  from 2022 to 2023 before . Two of Delaney's four daughters attend  while his oldest daughter, Summer, worked as a video journalist and multimedia reporter for  and  (PIX11) News.\n\nDelaney is Catholic, and has said that \"to some extent\" his faith has guided his \"social justice orientation\". He was also a member of the Board of Directors of several organizations: St. Patrick's Episcopal Day School (Chairman), , , and the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John A. Giannetti Jr.''' (born June 9, 1964) is an  and former attorney from Maryland. As a , Giannetti was elected to the  in 1998 for District 13B and served from 1999 to 2003. In 2002 he was elected into the  for District 21, which covers parts of  and .  He was defeated in the 2006 Democratic  and general elections by former member of the Maryland House of Delegates and  .\n\nAs a legislator, Giannetti was the primary sponsor of more than 50 bills that became law, many focusing on changes to business law, juvenile law, and criminal law statutes.\n\nIn February 2006, Giannetti rescued his political rival from choking using the . The incident was reported nationally and received mention on national network morning news programs and by late-night comedians.\n\n\nGiannetti was born at , to Gail (Reilly) and John Giannetti, a . John Jr. attended . He received his B.S. from  (biology) in 1986, and his  from the  in 1994. After a first marriage ended, Giannetti married Erin Appel in June 2004.\n\n\nGiannetti was  to the Maryland Bar in 1995 and the District of Columbia Bar in 2002.  He was an attorney for Vallario & Collins (1995–1998), Fossett and Brugger (1998–2000), and Jackson & Campbell, P.C. in Washington, D.C. (2001–2004). He was a partner in the  law firm Leibowitz, Band & Jezic (2006–2007), and then founded the Law Offices of John Giannetti in , with offices in Anne Arundel, Prince George's, , and  Counties. His law practice represented businesses, families, and individuals and handles cases in , , , and some  matters.\n\nIn October 2016, Maryland's Attorney Grievance Commission filed a petition for disciplinary or remedial action against Giannetti for not filing state or federal taxes from 2008 through 2015. Giannetti says he has since filed and is paying the taxes plus penalties and interest. An April 28, 2017 Circuit Court for Anne Arundel County hearing considered whether Giannetti should be disciplined in the form of a reprimand, suspension or disbarment. Giannetti said the complaint stemmed from a long-running child custody battle. In June 2017, a Circuit Court judge ruled that Giannetti violated professional conduct rules. In December 2017, the  issued a final ruling and suspended Giannetti indefinitely from practicing law. He was able to apply for reinstatement after one year.\n\n\nGiannetti was defeated by James Rosapepe in the 2006 Democratic primary election. After the Republican nominee dropped out of the 2006 race the week after the primary election, Giannetti switched his affiliation to the , and was appointed by the 's central committee to run in the general election, where he was again defeated by Rosapepe. In 2007, he returned his registration to the Democratic Party. Giannetti became the chair of the Annapolis Democratic Central Committee in 2015. He resigned as chair and took a hiatus from the committee in June 2017 when news of his prior tax filing issues became known.\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland State Senate&nbsp;– District 21'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland Senate&nbsp;– District 21'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– District 13B''' Retrieved on Jan, 25th, 2008\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– District 13B'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*https://web.archive.org/web/20070917152914/http://www.johngiannetti.com/ht/d/OfficialDetails/i/554699/aboutus/Y/pid/554703\n*http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/05sen/former/html/msa02772.html\n*http://www.johngiannetti.com/\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Mary Ann Love''' (February 21, 1940 – January 27, 2022) was an  from  and a member of the . She served 4 full terms in the , representing Maryland's District 32. Love was originally appointed to the seat in 1993, but was later elected in her own right. She most recently served on the Economic Matters Committee. Love declined to run for reelection in 2014.\n\n\nMary Ann was born in  on February 21, 1940. She graduated from  in 1958. She attended the .\n\n\n\n\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax by from 5% to 6% - Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* voted to support in-state tuition for all graduates of a Maryland public high school, 2007(HB6)\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000 \n* voted for Jessica's Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007 \n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008 \n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009 \n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet, 2009 \n* voted in 2013 in favor of gun control legislation (SB 281) banning certain firearms and placing significant new restrictions on the ability of law-abiding citizens to own firearms \n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 13, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 13, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 13, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\nLove died on January 27, 2022, aged 81.\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kevin Bailey Hornberger''' (born June 26, 1981) is an American politician from the  who is a member of the , representing . He previously represented  from 2015 to 2023.\n\n\nHornberger was born on June 26, 1981, in . He graduated from  in 1999 and attended , where he earned an  in general studies in 2003. He then attended the  from 2003 to 2004, and later graduated with honors from the  with a  degree in mechanical engineering in 2010.\n\nAfter graduating, Hornberger founded his own company, Blue Collar Engineering Inc., and began working as a facility manager for the . In 2014, he ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 35A, challenging incumbent  Delegate , who was drawn into the district following  in 2012. He won the Republican primary with a 300-vote lead over his opponent. During the general election, he was endorsed by Republican gubernatorial nominee  and U.S. Representative . He defeated Rudolph in the general election with 56.5 percent of the vote.\n\n\n swears Hornberger into the Maryland House of Delegates, 2015]]\nHornberger was sworn in as a member of the House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. Since 2020, he has served as the Deputy Minority Whip.\n\n\n* Member, Ways and Means Committee, 2015–present (education subcommittee, 2015–2018, 2021–present; finance resources subcommittee, 2015–2017, 2019; election law subcommittee, 2017–2018; local revenues subcommittee, 2019; early childhood subcommittee, 2020; racing & gaming subcommittee, 2020–present)\n* Member, Joint Committee on Gaming Oversight, 2015–present\n\n\n* House Chair, Cecil County Delegation, 2015–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2015–present\n* Member, Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2015–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n\n\nHornberger was married to his wife, Danielle, who currently serves as the  of . Together, they have an adult son named Adam. Hornberger lives in .\n\nIn April 2024, Hornberger's son filed second-degree assault charges against him, alleging that his father had shoved him to the ground, cutting his palm and scraping his wrist. Hornberger denied the accusations, saying that his son had become physically violent toward him during a discussion about his future and had fled home after Hornberger called the police. Hornberger's son also sought a  against him, which was denied after Hornberger and his parents contested against it. The assault charges were dismissed in June 2024.\n\n\n\nHornberger introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session to require all vacancies in the  to be filled with . In 2021, he proposed legislation to reform the state's campaign finance reporting system to include a real-time database.\n\n\nHornberger identifies as \"one of the fiercest advocates for the \". During a debate on legislation to ban firearms on college campuses, Hornberger unsuccessfully introduced an amendment to exempt students or staff members who have  permits from the bill. Following the , Hornberger voted in favor of legislation to ban s in Maryland, a vote which he later called \"one of the toughest votes I've ever had to make\". During a debate on legislation that prohibited  sentences for s, Hornberger introduced an amendment that would exempt people \"convicted of a crime involving the possession or discharge of a firearm inside a school building or a conspiracy to commit a crime involving a firearm inside a school building\", which was rejected by a vote of 51–83.\n\n\nHornberger opposed legislation introduced in the 2017 legislation to legalize , saying he supported  but felt it was too early to legalize recreational marijuana. During the 2021 legislative session, Hornberger introduced legislation that would allow medical marijuana patients to possess and carry firearms.\n\n\nDuring a debate on legislation to raise the state minimum wage to  in 2019, Hornberger unsuccessfully introduced an amendment to increase funding for health and human service organizations.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Hornberger co-sponsored legislation that would give farmers the  equipment.\n\n\nIn 2018, Hornberger campaigned on cutting Maryland's taxes. During the 2021 legislative session, he introduced legislation to provide s to business owners who had to close or reduce their operations as a result of the . In April of that year, Hornberger voted in favor of legislation that would let counties set .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James N. Mathias Jr.''' (born September 2, 1951) is an American politician from . Mathias served in the  from 2011 until 2019, was a member of the  from 2006 to 2010, and served as mayor of Ocean City from 1996 until 2006.\n\n\nThe former mayor of , was born on September 2, 1951, in . James N. Mathias Jr. During his childhood, he lived in Baltimore City,  and . He attended high school at  in , graduating in 1969. In 1974, Mathias graduated from the , with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Political Science.\n\nMathias first came to Ocean City as a child, with his parents for summer vacations and it was then that he first fell in love with Ocean City, Maryland. His first Ocean City summer job was at Ponzetti's Pizza on the Boardwalk in 1972. Mathias and his father established a business in downtown Ocean City and built an amusement and arcade operation.\n\nIn 1978 he married Kathleen \"Kathy\" Arlee Petry, who died in August 2011. OC MD Newspapers  Maryland Coast Dispatch » Kathy Mathias Services Announced|website=mdcoastdispatch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-21}} They had two children. Mathias currently works as the Director of Governmental Affairs for the .\n\n\nMathias began his political career in Ocean City in 1987 when he was appointed to the Ocean City Board of Zoning Appeals, where he served until 1990. In October 1990, he was elected as an Ocean City Councilman and was re-elected to that post in 1994. In October 1996, Mathias was elected Mayor of Ocean City. He was re-elected in 1998, 2000, 2002, and 2004. In 2006, Mathias was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates for District 38B, along with fellow Democrat  of Salisbury, where he would serve for one term before running to replace retiring State Senator . Mathias went on to defeat Michael James, general manager of Ocean City's Carousel Hotel and Resort, in the 2010 general election by less than 700 votes. Mathias won re-election in 2014 over Republican state delegate and former mayor of  . In the 2018 general election, Mathias lost his re-election bid to Republican state delegate and former  official , also of Ocean City.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kirill Reznik'''}}}} (born August 9, 1974) is an American politician from  and a member of the . He was previously a member of the  from District 39 from 2007 to 2023, resigning to become the Assistant Secretary for Inter-Departmental Data Integration for the Maryland Department of Human Services.\n\n\nBorn in , , , Reznik's family immigrated to the United States in 1978 when he was 4 years old. His family settled in , . Reznik attended Dade County Public Schools, graduating from  in 1992. Reznik attended , where he served in the  alongside future political journalist , graduating with a B.A. in international relations and a minor in economics in 1995. Later, Reznik went on to attend  and received his M.A. in international peace and conflict resolution from the  in 1998, and received his J.D. in 2003 from 's . After graduation, Reznik was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 2004 and the District of Columbia Bar in 2005.\n\n\nReznik's professional experience includes working in international development and foreign aid programs since 1994. Focusing specifically in the areas of democracy, civil society, and economic development. Reznik has had experience with implementing international development programs throughout the world for well respected implementing organizations and companies such as , , , , and  for donors organizations such as , , and .  Reznik was employed by CAMRIS International where he served as the Director of Operations.\n\nIn addition, Reznik has practiced law in  for the firm of Weinberg & Jacobs focusing on exempt organizations, estate planning, and small business.\n\n\nReznik became actively involved with the local  in Montgomery County, Maryland in 2004 by joining the Montgomery County Young Democrats. Through his involvement, Reznik eventually went on to be Executive Vice President, and subsequently, President of the Montgomery County Young Democrats, as well as the National Committeeman for the Young Democrats of Maryland, and the Deputy Director of the 's mid-Atlantic region.\n\nIn 2005, Reznik volunteered to be the District 39 Coordinator for then-Mayor  in his run for Governor of Maryland. The O'Malley– ticket won the Governorship of Maryland by a vote of 52.7%–46.2% from incumbent Governor . The margin of victory in District 39 was 59.85%–39.10%.\n\nIn 2006, Reznik successfully ran to represent the Democrats of Legislative District 39 on the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee, the local Democratic Party. During his service, Reznik successfully recruited more precinct chairs and vice chairs in recent history for District 39, and successfully helped run the 2006 Maryland Democratic Coordinated Campaign in District 39.\n\nFollowing the , Reznik took action in the state legislature, supporting legislation to divest investments in Russia from the Maryland state government pension plan, and sponsoring a resolution expressing solidarity with the people of Ukraine.\n\nIn the 2022 Democratic primary, Reznik and other members of the house district campaigned for another Democrat to replace , who nonetheless won reelection to the ticket.\n\nOn March 14, 2023, Reznik announced that he would resign from the Maryland House of Delegates on March 21, to serve as the Assistant Secretary for Inter-Departmental Data Integration for the Maryland Department of Human Services.\n\n\n\n\nAfter the retirement of State Senator , and ascension of Maryland State Delegate  to fill Senator Hogan's Senate seat, Reznik was nominated by the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee, and appointed by Governor O'Malley, to fill Nancy King's seat for the remainder of her term on October 2, 2007.\n\nDuring his first term, Reznik has sponsored the following legislation that has successfully been enacted as Maryland law:\n* - Task Force to Study the Procurement of Health and Social Services by State Agencies\n* - Establishment of and regulation by State Athletic Commission of professional and amateur Mixed Martial Arts events\n* - Disclosure of medical records in Children In Need of Assistance (CINA) Proceedings\n* - Establishment of licensure renewal requirements for radiology professionals\n* - Provides employees of Maryland-National Capital Parks & Planning Commission workers' compensation presumption for Lyme Disease.\n* - Extension of Task Force to Study the Procurement of Health and Social Services by State Agencies\n* - Bans the use of corded window blinds in foster homes, family day care facilities, and child care centers.\n* - Exempting the Department of Natural Resources from State Procurement law related to conservation service opportunities entered into with nonprofit entities.\n* - Requiring the State to set hospital reimbursement rates for specific freestanding emergency facilities and altering how the state can issue a license for new facilities.\n* - Prohibiting the performance of specific cosmetic surgical procedures in unaccredited medical offices or facilities.\n* - Requiring health insurance to cover visits for obesity evaluation and management and visits for and costs of developmental screening for child wellness services.\n\n\n\nOn November 2, 2010, Reznik was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates to represent District 39.\n\nDuring his second term, to date Reznik has sponsored the following legislation that has successfully been enacted as Maryland law:\n* - Restricting the ability of employers to use an individual's  against them in hiring or retention.\n* - Debarred entities who do business with Iran from doing business with the State of Maryland.\n* - Requires the State to only contract for electronics recycling with certified recyclers so harmful equipment or chemicals are not dumped domestically or abroad.\n* - Expanded access of the Small Business Reserve Program to a large number of small businesses.\n* - Establishes requirements for the proper handling of the body of a decedent by funeral establishments and crematories in response to recent scandals involving the treatment of remains of Maryland veterans awaiting burial at Arlington National Cemetery.\n* - Enables Licensed Respiratory Care Practitioners to have the right to practice within the scope of their license, including in a sleep laboratory.\n\n\n\n*  - Standing Committee of the Maryland House of Delegates -     "pages": }\n'''Harry Bhandari''' (; born October 1, 1977) is a Nepalese-born American politician and educator. A member of the , he has served as a member of the  from the  since 2019. Bhandari is the first  elected to a state legislature in the United States.\n\nBhandari unsuccessfully ran in the  in , placing a distant second to Baltimore County Executive  in the Democratic primary.\n\n\nBhandari was born in , on October 1, 1977, to father Ammar Bahadur and mother Kanti Kumari. He graduated from , earned his master's in English literature from , and later attended the  where he received his  in 2021.\n\nBhandari moved to the United States in 2005 to present a paper at , and became a U.S. citizen in 2011.\n\n\nBhandari became a teacher for  in 2006 and later taught at , and worked a faculty member for . He briefly returned to Nepal following the  to assist earthquake victims.\n\nBhandari first entered politics in 2008 as a volunteer for . He later served as the secretary of the 's minority caucus and on the board of directors for the District 6 Democratic and Civic Association Club.\n\n\nBhandari unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in . He won election to the Maryland House of Delegates in , during which he ran on a slate with  and incumbent state delegate  and defeated incumbent Republican state delegate  in the general election.\n\n, 2023]]\nBhandari was sworn in on copies of  and  on January 9, 2019, and has served as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee during his entire tenure. He has also chaired the Maryland Legislative Asian-American and Pacific-Islander Caucus since 2023.\n\nDuring the , Bhandari ran to serve as a delegate for  at the . He again applied to run as a delegate to the , pledged to Biden, but was denied by the .\n\n\n\nIn January 2024, ahead of U.S. Representative  announcing that he would not run for re-election in 2024, Bhandari filed to run for  in the . He officially announced his campaign on January 29. During the Democratic primary, Bhandari ran on a platform including healthcare and education. He was defeated in the Democratic primary election, placing second behind Baltimore County Executive  with 8.5 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Bhandari introduced legislation requiring high schools to teach conflict resolution classes. The bill did not pass out of committee.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Bhandari introduced legislation to encourage schools to install s in school construction projects.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Bhandari voted against a bill requiring background checks for shotgun and rifle sales.\n\nIn June 2021, following the fatal shooting of Nepali student Sagar Ghimire in , Bhandari promised to introduce legislation to strengthen the state's gun control laws during the 2022 legislative session. That year, he introduced the Sagar Ghimire Act to reassess Maryland's extreme risk gun law.\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Bhandari supported federal legislation to ban  sales.\n\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Bhandari supported a ceasefire in the , comparing it to the .\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Bhandari supported a bill to establish the Prescription Drug Affordability Board to negotiate the price of  in Maryland.\n\nDuring his 2024 congressional campaign, Bhandari endorsed the . He also introduced bills to create a task force on reducing emergency department wait times during that year's legislative session.\n\n\nIn May 2021, Bhandari called on  to pass the .\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Bhandari introduced legislation that would make the state recognize  as a commemorative day. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor , making Maryland the first U.S. state to recognize the festival.\n\nIn 2024, Bhandari introduced a bill that would require movie theaters to have limited screenings of movies with  and subtitle options.\n\n\nBhandari is married and has two children. He lives in . In September 2018, following the fatal shooting of Brindra Giri in , Bhandari helped Giri's family with funeral arrangements and with translating from Nepali to English.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jared Scott Solomon''' (born April 3, 1985) is an American politician from the  and is a member of the  representing .\n\n\nSolomon was born on April 3, 1985, and raised in suburban . He attended the , where he received a  degree in political science, history, and economics, and , where he received a  in teaching. Solomon also attended one semester at the . After graduating, he taught social studies at  until 2009, after which he worked as a project coordinator for the . From 2011 to 2013, he worked as a senior policy director for First Focus, afterwards working as a policy advisor to U.S. Senator  until 2018, when he resigned to run for the Maryland House of Delegates. In this capacity, Solomon worked on immigration, LGBT, and education policy and was the lead staff negotiator on the reauthorization of the .\n\n\nSolomon was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in , and sworn in on January 9, 2019. He has been a member of the Appropriations Committee during his entire tenure. He is also a member of the Maryland Transit Caucus and an associate member of the Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus and Women Legislators of Maryland.\n\nDuring the , Solomon ran for delegate to the Democratic National Convention pledged to . In the , he canvassed for Democratic nominee  in .\n\nIn January 2024, Solomon, along with state senator  and 20 other Jewish lawmakers, created the Maryland Jewish Legislative Caucus.\n\n\nSolomon is married and has two children. He is .\n\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Solomon introduced a bill providing $30 million to schools for water remediation efforts to reduce lead levels in  to 5 million parts per million, which passed and became law. In 2021, he introduced legislation to encourage school systems to adopt  to reduce , and another requiring schools with lead levels higher than 5 million parts per million to make remedial repairs by summer 2022.\n\n\nIn June 2022, following mass shootings in , and , Solomon attended a  protest in , where he called on Congress to pass gun safety legislation.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session and following an apartment fire that killed one, Solomon supported legislation requiring  to install automatic smoke alarms in public corridors.\n\n\nIn November 2023, Solomon was one of 19 Jewish members of the  to sign onto a letter condemning a statement released by  calling for an immediate ceasefire in the .\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Solomon introduced a bill to consolidate the  process within the , which passed and became law after legislators overrode Governor 's veto on it. In October 2023, he participated a rally organized by  union workers to support collective bargaining efforts between the union and the Washington Service Contractors Association.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Solomon introduced legislation to establish an independent inspector for the  system, which passed and became law.\n\nIn July 2022, Solomon attended a rally at the Kensington Library to prevent disruptions to the library's  event. During the 2023 legislative session, he introduced legislation that would require single-occupancy bathrooms to use .\n\n\nSolomon opposes the state's  and  highway widening plan and has criticized its use of s and s to fund it, calling it a \"\". In December 2019, he was one of 80 lawmakers to cosign a letter calling on Governor  to postpone the project's first phase in December 2019. During the 2020 legislative session, Solomon introduced legislation to increase the state's financial oversight over public–private partnerships and allow the  to remove public–private partnership status from state projects. The bill was reintroduced in 2021. In July 2021, Solomon participated in a rally calling on members of the National Capital Region Transportation Planning Board to not include the highway expansion projects in its environmental studies, which would prevent the projects from getting the \"environmental seal of approval\" needed for the state to start construction.\n\nIn 2020, Solomon introduced a bill that would require the  to launch a memorandum of understanding process to form a  service with  and , which passed but was vetoed by Governor Hogan. During the 2021 legislative session, he introduced legislation to establish a regional rail system integrating commuter rail lines in Maryland, Virginia, and Washington, D.C. The bill was reintroduced in 2022.\n\nIn December 2023, Solomon expressed dissatisfaction with Governor 's proposed $3.3 billion in cuts to the state's transportation fund, saying that the cuts were \"a penny wise and a pound foolish\".\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Joseph J. \"Sonny\" Minnick''' (March 16, 1933 &ndash; October 12, 2015) was an American politician from  and a member of the .\n\n\nMinnick was born in  on March 16, 1933. He served in the  during the . Upon arriving home, he joined his brother Dan Minnick Jr. to take over the management of Minnick's Hollywood Inn, a family business founded by his grandfather in the early 1920s, now known as Minnick's Restaurant and Catering Business, Inc. Minnick's bar was raided on June 29, 2011, which seized five video devices believed to be involved in illegal gambling . Minnick was not charged.\n\nMinnick was active with both the Restaurant Association and with veteran's groups. Minnick was a strong supporter of small businesses in the State of Maryland. He died on October 12, 2015, from a blood disease.\n\n\nHe served five terms in the , representing Maryland's District 6 in . Minnick was a member of the Economic Matters Committee.\n\n\n*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 -Higher Education -Tuition Charges -Maryland High School Students, 2007 (HB6)\n*voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000 \n* voted for Jessica's Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007 \n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008 \n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009 \n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet, 2009 \n* voted against  (HB438) - civil marriage rights for same-sex couples, 2012 \n\nFor the past four years, Delegate Minnick has annually voted to support classroom teachers, public schools, police and hospitals in Baltimore County. Since 2002, funding to schools across the State has increased 82%, resulting in Maryland being ranked top in the nation for K-12 education.\n\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 6'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 7'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 7'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jason Cord Buckel''' (born November 3, 1971) is an American politician, and the minority leader in the . He has represented District  since 2015. He is a member of the .\n\n\nBuckel was born in  on November 3, 1971. He graduated from  in  and attended , where he earned a  degree in political science with honors, and the , where he earned a  degree with honors. He was admitted to the  in 1996. After graduating, he started his own law firm and became a member of the Maryland State Bar Association.\n\nBuckel became involved with politics in 2006, when he became a member of the . In 2012, Buckel led the Allegany County campaign for 's exploratory bid in . In February 2014, he filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates, seeking to unseat incumbent Delegate . He defeated Kelly in the general election, receiving 58.9 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nBuckel was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015.  From 2017 to 2018, he served as the Chief Deputy Minority Whip for the House Republican Caucus, and as the Minority Leader of the Maryland House of Delegates since April 2021.\n\nIn 2016, Buckel filed to run for delegate for the , representing . He received 1.8 percent of the vote in the primary election.\n\nOn April 10, 2023, less than 10 minutes before the legislature adjourned , House Speaker  sought to move onto the next bill after Buckel had explained his vote on House Bill 1071. After a series of other Republican lawmakers began making appeals to also explain their votes, which were rejected by Jones, a shouting match led by  started and continued until the House adjourned, preventing several bills from receiving a final vote before the midnight deadline. During this, Buckel ordered Republican delegates to leave the chamber in protest of Jones rejecting delegates' appeals to speak; about a dozen lawmakers followed him to the doorway. Buckel denied that the disruption was a tactic to keep legislation from passing and later said he blamed Democratic lawmakers for the incident, arguing that they had \"waited until the final minutes of the session to move controversial legislation with limited debate\". After the General Assembly adjourned, the  demanded \"a [public] apology for the disrespect\" shown to Jones.\n\n\n* Member, Ways and Means Committee, 2015–present (election law subcommittee, 2015–2017; finance resources subcommittee, 2015–2019; revenues subcommittee, 2017–present; racing & gaming subcommittee, 2020–present)\n* Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2019–present\n* Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2021–present\n* Legislative Policy Committee, 2021–present\n* Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 2021–present\n* Spending Affordability Committee, 2021–present\n* Legislative Redistricting Advisory Commission, 2021–present\n* Consent Calendars Committee, 2021–present\n* House Cannabis Referendum and Legalization Work Group, 2021–present\n* Member, Tax Credit Evaluation Committee, 2017–2021\n* Work Group to Address Police Reform and Accountability in Maryland, 2020\n\n\n* House Chair, Allegany County Delegation, 2016–present\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2014–present\n\n\nIn October 2021, Buckel was one of five Maryland state legislators from Garrett, Allegany and Washington counties who sent a pair of letters to West Virginia officials asking about annexation of  to West Virginia. These letters caused a local uproar, with Allegany County officials calling the request a political stunt, an embarrassment and unneeded distraction. Following criticism from local officials and some constituents, Buckel and state senator  issued a letter withdrawing support for the secession proposal. In an October 2024 interview with '''', Buckel said that he suggested holding a non-binding secession straw poll among residents of counties in western Maryland to local lawmakers after hearing about West Virginia Governor  suggesting that conservative counties in western  should join West Virginia following the , in which Democrats gained control of both chambers of the . The letters were sent to West Virginia officials while Buckel was on a hunting trip in  and he did not learn of the letters until he returned.\n\n\nIn December 2021, harassment charges were filed against Buckel in relation to his pending divorce. The complaint detailed more than three dozen messages sent by Buckel through  to a  trooper who had a relationship with his estranged wife, including more than a half-dozen messages that had Buckel threatening to take his job and pension and to \"destroy\" and \"bury\" him. These charges were dropped by  prosecutors the next day.\n\nIn August 2023,  reported that Buckel was under investigation for making death threats against a police officer who was dating his ex-wife. According to the police report, Buckel unexpectedly encountered his ex-wife and her boyfriend at a music festival at the , and became alert after noticing his son was not with them. He then began texting his ex-wife to ask where his son was, and approached an off-duty officer and said he would \"put a bullet\" in her boyfriend's head. The investigation was closed after Allegany County detectives interviewed Buckel about the incident, and no criminal charges were filed. In a statement to WBFF, Buckel disputed claims that he threatened her boyfriend.\n\nIn June 2024, Buckel was reportedly arrested for  and with a suspended license. In a statement to ''WBFF'', Buckel was driving home from a sports-themed restaurant after watching a  hockey game when an officer pulled him over and arrested him; he denied having any alcoholic drinks beforehand or driving erratically on his way home.\n\n\n\nBuckel opposed legislation introduced during the 2022 legislative session that banned regulated lobbyists from contributing from their personal funds to a candidate with the intent of influencing action from the candidate, questioning the bill's constitutionality amid the 's '''' decision.\n\n\nBuckel disagreed with Governor 's decision to support a ban on  in Maryland, saying that it would have brought jobs to Allegany and Garrett counties.\n\n\nBuckel does not support  regulations, saying that the government \"does not have a right\" to regulate firearms.\n\nIn March 2022, during a debate on a bill that would ban sales of s, Buckel introduced an amendment that would strengthen convictions for people convicted of firearm theft. The amendment was rejected on a vote of 50–80.\n\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Buckel opposed legislation to give tenants the right of first refusal if the property owner of their residence seeks to sell the property, saying that it would disincentivize developers from building in Maryland.\n\n\nBuckel opposed legislation introduced in the 2021 legislative session that prohibited state and local governments from providing records or data to  for the purpose of civil immigration enforcement.\n\n\nBuckel introduced legislation in the 2015 legislative session that would block law clinics from fighting against Maryland state agencies in court. The bill received an unfavorable report from the House Appropriations Committee.\n\nBuckel opposed legislation introduced during the 2021 legislative session that would remove the  from the parole process for people serving life sentences. The Maryland General Assembly voted to override Governor Hogan's veto on the bill during its special legislative session on December 7, 2021. Buckel also opposed legislation that would prohibit life without parole sentences for juvenile offenders, and introduced an amendment during the debate on the bill that would have banned it from applying to past offenses. The amendment was rejected in a 52–83 vote.\n\n\nBuckel opposes s, calling them \"not necessary and not feasible.\" He also supports providing workers with s on government projects. In September 2024, Buckel wrote a letter to Governor  calling on him to repeal an executive order requiring state agencies to consider a company's use of s when awarding contracts on large-scale public works projects, arguing that it puts local construction workers at a disadvantage to out-of-state employees.\n\n\nBuckel opposes , calling the move a \".\" He has also said that decriminalizing and legalizing the drug would pose many difficult questions for law enforcement, including how to test for  of drivers. Buckel did not rule out voting to allow the use of medical marijuana under tight controls. He voted against legislation creating , a ballot referendum to legalize recreational marijuana in Maryland.\n\n\nBuckel supports using single-member districts in the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nIn August 2015, Buckel was appointed to the Maryland Redistricting Reform Commission by Governor Larry Hogan.\n\nIn July 2021, Buckel was appointed to the Maryland Legislative Redistricting Advisory Commission, which consisted of the leaders of each chamber of the . He objected to the maps adopted by the commission over country splits. He later introduced an amendment that would switch the legislative redistricting panel's maps with those proposed by the Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission. The amendment was rejected in a 43–93 vote. Buckel also opposed the legislative maps passed by the General Assembly in January 2022, saying that the legislative panel's map was drawn for partisan gain. He also opposed congressional maps passed by the General Assembly in March 2022.\n\n\nBuckel opposes introducing any new taxes, but supports the concept of bracketed local income tax as a way for counties to provide relief without losing too much revenue. During his 2014 campaign, he said that he would pursue a tax incentive program to bring cybersecurity and information technology to Allegany County. He also opposes increasing , saying it would hurt local businesses by driving customers to West Virginia and Pennsylvania.\n\nIn April 2021, Buckel voted against legislation that would allow counties to set local income taxes at different rates for lower-income and wealthy residents.\n\nIn March 2022, Buckel voted against legislation that would extend a tax on , expressing concern that it results in higher premiums for people covered by group plans.\n\n\nBuckel supports restoring highway user funds, saying that much of the funding is now being used for mass transit projects in metropolitan areas.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Dan Koenig Morhaim''' (born on December 27, 1948) is an American , , and . He was a member of the  representing northwest  from 1995 to 2019. He sponsored legislation concerning , the environment, and streamlining government operations. As an author, Morhaim has written articles for medical publications and the general media at large.\n\n\nBorn in , , United States, in December 1948, Morhaim graduated from  in Los Angeles and earned a  in history from the  in 1970. Morhaim received his  from  in 1975 and is  in  and .\n\n\nMorhaim was first elected to the  in 1994 and was re-elected in 1998, 2002, 2006, 2010, and 2014. In 2017, the House and Senate ed Morhaim for paid consulting work performed for a company seeking a  license. He chose not to run for re-election in 2018.\n\nIn the , Morhaim served on committees including the Environmental Matters Committee (1995–2003), the Health and Government Operations Committee (2003–17), the , 2017-19; Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review (2003–19), the Joint Committee on Health Care Delivery and Financing (2007–14), the Joint Information Technology and Biotechnology Committee (2009–14), the Joint Committee on Transparency and Open Government (2011–14), the Joint Committee on Cybersecurity, Information Technology, and Biotechnology (2014–19), the Joint Committee on Legislative Information Technology and Open Government (2015–19), and the Joint Committee on Behavioral Health and  (2015–19). Morhaim sponsored numerous bills focusing on health care, the environment, and procurement reform.\n\nHe served as co-chair of the Alliance for Patient Access, a bipartisan national organization of physicians elected to state office, and as co-chair of the Innovations in Health Care Task Force for the  (NCSL).\n\nMorhaim is board-certified in  and , and has over 40 years of front-line clinical experience. From 1981 to 1994, he chaired the Department of Emergency Medicine at  () while building a 90-doctor, 120-employee group at six  hospitals. He is on staff at  and Northwest Hospitals, part of the Lifebridge Health System. Other clinical experiences include the State of Maryland's medical mission to  following the first , the  (Navajo area), Health Care for the Homeless (), medical director for local ambulance companies, and medical director for the 1993  at .\n\nMorhaim was on the faculty at  for 16 years, where he taught graduate students, did  research, and wrote articles for both peer-reviewed and general media publications.\n\nMorhaim has served on the boards of several organizations, including the  (UMBI), Western Indemnity Insurance Company, Maritime Medical Systems, Brick , Unified Community Connections (formerly ), Baltimore , Health Care for the Homeless, the State's Task Force on Recycling, Region III medical director for the State Emergency Medical System, and on the Executive Committees at Franklin Square and .\n \nHe has been recognized for his medical, academic, and legislative work by numerous organizations, including receiving the AMA's  for Public Service in 2011 and s from Maryland nurses, physicians, architects, retailers, minority business groups, and others.\n\nIn 2018, Morhaim announced, after 24 years of service in the , that he would not seek re-election.\n\nIn 2019, he was selected as Chair of the Baltimore County Behavioral Healthcare Council, which helps people with  and/or .\n\nHe was appointed to the Maryland Behavioral Healthcare Council in 2023, and then reappointed by  for a 4-year term starting in 2024.\n\nMorhaim was selected to serve on the Maryland ER Wait Time Commission in 2024 for a 3-year term.\n\n\nA list of key votes\n* Portrays how the delegate stands on an issue\n* Easy to understand\n* Received media attention\n* The vote was passed or defeated by a very close margin\n* Vote Smart received repeated inquiries about a particular vote}} on legislation introduced by Morhaim as the primary or co-sponsor:\n* 2018:HB 115: Prescription medications listed on state's Health Information Exchange.\n* 2017: HB 81: Removes archaic sexist term “confinement” from estate law.\n*2015: HB 216: Clean water: Microbead pollutant phase out and became national model.\n*2011: HB 456: Minority-Women Business Enterprise program extension.\n*2008:HB 906: Organ donation program revised and made operational\n*2004: HB 556: Health Care Decisions, preferences, communication.\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\nMorhaim is married to Shelley Cole Morhaim (writer, film producer, and Chair of the Maryland State Arts Council), and they have three adult children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Galen R. Clagett''' (born February 9, 1942) is an  from  and a member of the . He served three terms in the , representing Maryland's District 3A in . During his tenure he was a member of the Appropriations Committee.\n\n\nGalen Ronald Clagett was born in  on February 9, 1942. He attended  before becoming a real estate agent and President of the property management firm Clagett Enterprises, Inc.\n\n\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax whilst simultaneously reducing income tax rates for some income brackets - Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* voted to support in-state tuition for all graduates of a Maryland public high school, 2007(HB6)\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000 \n* voted for Jessica's Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007 \n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008 \n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009 \n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet, 2009 \n*voted to raise income taxes on single filers earning more than $100,000 and joint filers earning more than $150,000, 2012 \n\n\n* '''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 3A''' Retrieved on Nov. 21, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n* '''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 3A'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brian E. Frosh''' (born October 8, 1946) is an American lawyer and politician who served as the  from 2015 to 2023. He also served five terms in the , representing  in . Prior to serving in the Senate, Frosh represented District 16 in the , serving two four-year terms.\n\nFrosh was elected to his second term as attorney general on November 6, 2018. In his first term, Frosh joined , attorney general of the District of Columbia, in filing a lawsuit against Donald Trump, alleging he had violated the foreign and domestic emoluments clauses of the U.S. Constitution. On October 21, 2021, Frosh announced that he would not seek a third term in .\n\nDuring his tenure as attorney general, Frosh filed numerous lawsuits against the .\n\n\nBorn on October 8, 1946, Brian Frosh grew up in . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from  and a  from .\n\n\n\n\nFrosh joined the Maryland Bar in 1971 and the District of Columbia Bar in 1972. He was a partner at the law offices of Karp, Frosh, Lapidus, Wigodsky, & Norwood, P.A working in business litigation, commercial litigation, and real estate law.\n\n\n]]\nAs both a delegate and senator, Brian Frosh has represented Maryland's District 16, which includes parts of Chevy Chase, Bethesda, and Potomac. Frosh is Jewish.\n\nFrosh represented Montgomery County in the Maryland House of Delegates from 1987 to 1995. In this role, he was a member of the Environmental Matters Committee, Tort and Insurance Reform Oversight Committee, and Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics.\n\nFrosh brought state funding into the district to build the , build sound barriers, and fund programs like those at the National Center for Children and Families, the Ivymount School, Imagination Stage,  and Glen Echo Park.\n\n\nFrosh authored the Maryland Recycling Act, the ban on drilling for oil or gas in the Chesapeake Bay, the Maryland Brownfields Redevelopment Act, numerous energy conservation laws, Clean Cars legislation and other environmental initiatives. https://www.sierraclub.org/maryland/blog/2013/12/news-flash-sierra-club-s-maryland-chapter-endorses-brian-frosh-attorney\n\n\nIn 2009, Frosh proposed changing the laws on protective orders to better protect domestic abuse victims against gun violence, and in 2011, sought to provide temporary lodging for domestic violence victims.\nFrosh also sponsored legislation increasing the guidelines that courts use to set child support payments.\n\nIn 2010 Frosh supported legislation that would give the court the ability to put serious juvenile .\n\n\nAs senator, Frosh worked to draft the law that provides a waiver of tuition and fees to state universities for children in foster care.\n\n\nAs senator, Frosh worked on a number of bills intended to promote energy efficiency, hold down energy costs and reduce the environmental impacts of energy production and use.\n\nFrosh advocated the establishment of service standards and the imposition of penalties if electric utilities failed to provide reliable service. In 2010, Frosh called on the Public Service Commission to investigate Pepco, and in 2011 introduced legislation calling for regulations and stiff penalties. Although Frosh's original legislation passed the Senate, ultimately, the House would only enact penalties that were more lenient than Frosh's proposal.\n\n\nAs chair of the Judicial Proceedings Committee, former Senator Frosh had responsibility for legislation in the Senate dealing with privacy and consumer laws. He sponsored bills protecting the privacy of citizens' personal information in Motor Vehicle Administration files and authorizing Maryland's Attorney General to prosecute violators of Federal anti-telemarketing regulations. The Judicial Proceedings Committee approved legislation establishing a task force to recommend identity theft remedies, beefing up the original bill at former Senator Frosh's recommendation to pay specific attention to protecting social security numbers. Former Senator Frosh has also sponsored bills banning minimum price fixing and creating new tools to crack down on people who defraud the State's Medicaid program.\n\n\nIn response to a 2017 lawsuit by  which sought the release of voter registration data for Montgomery County, Frosh's office filed a court document demanding that Judicial Watch \"identify any Russian nationals or agents of the Russian government with whom you have communicated concerning this lawsuit.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn October 9, 2012, Frosh announced that he had formed an exploratory committee for election to Attorney General. On July 30, 2013, he officially announced his decision to run.\n\nFrosh, who was endorsed by  and '''', won a 3-way primary with 50% of the vote. He then won the general election, defeating Republican Jeffrey Pritzker 56% to 41%.\n\n\n\nOn November 6, 2018, Frosh was elected for another term in office, having defeated Republican challenger Craig Wolf. Frosh campaigned on progressive policies including reduced bail for poor defendants and litigating against the Trump Administration.\n\nFrosh and opponent Craig Wolf debated at the  Law School after Frosh declined an invitation to a televised debate. Wolf attacked Frosh for focusing on national issues instead of Maryland crime, particularly . Frosh said he had convicted hundreds of the most dangerous people in Maryland, including drug traffickers and gang members. Wolf also took aim at Frosh's lawsuits against Trump, saying that Frosh was taking resources which should be used to promote public safety in Maryland, and instead using them to sue the Federal Government. Frosh said that he was defending affordable health care and protecting endangered species from offshore drilling.\n\n\nFrosh expanded the range of the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic Heroin Task Force.\n\nFrosh has argued against bail that defendants can't afford, which he believes could be unconstitutional.\n\nFrosh is leading a coalition of 12 state attorneys general opposing the federal government's plans to expand the scope of offshore drilling for oil and gas, including in waters off the coast of Maryland. Frosh joined other state attorneys general in an effort to block the Trump administration from suspending higher penalties on automobile manufacturers that fail to comply with federal fuel efficiency standards. He also is part of a multistate coalition challenging EPA's decision to roll back  standards for cars and light trucks. Frosh negotiated a $33.5 million settlement agreement with Volkswagen AG and its affiliates, Audi AG and Porsche AG. The agreement settles an enforcement action for the auto manufacturers' use of \"defeat devices\" in certain models of their vehicles in violation of Maryland's air quality control laws.\n\nFrosh reached a settlement with VietNow National Headquarters, Inc., resulting in the organization's dissolution. VietNow, which also used the name VeteransNow, had been raising money using deceptive telemarketing solicitation scripts.\n\nIn August 2017, Frosh issued a cease and desist order against We Can Cer-Vive! The investigation found violations of the Maryland Solicitations Act by the organization and its owner.\n\n\nAs Maryland Attorney General, Frosh has joined lawsuits against the . Frosh joined a Washington State lawsuit against President 's immigration executive order. He joined a coalition of high-tax states suing the Trump Administration over the . He has also joined lawsuits against Trump over a citizenship question on the , the , greenhouse gasses, regulatory rollbacks, vehicle emissions standards, airplane noise, , regulation of , , Obamacare subsidies, what he described as Trump's \"attempts to sabotage\" Obamacare, air pollution, his declaration of a national emergency at the Mexican border, and pesticide labelling.\n\nThe Maryland legislature appropriated $1 million for Frosh to hire five additional attorneys to handle the anti-Trump lawsuits, but Maryland Governor  withheld the funds, saying that it wasn't a good use of the state's money.\n\n\nIn January 2019, a former Maryland Delegate filed a lawsuit against Governor Hogan and Frosh relating to a violation of First Amendment rights. Specifically, through an executive order, Maryland has banned citizens who support the  (BDS) campaign from bidding on state contracts.\n\n\nFrosh has consistently opposed Adnan Syed's petitions in the case of the , which resulted in Syed's imprisonment. In June 2016, the Baltimore City Circuit Court granted Syed's request for a new trial and vacated his conviction, ruling that Syed's attorney \"rendered ineffective assistance\". In May 2018, Frosh filed a petition with the Maryland Court of Appeals to deny Syed a new trial. In October 2019, Frosh authored a legal brief in opposition to Adnan Syed's petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Supreme Court. This case has been covered extensively in the podcast . In late 2018, according to HBO, Frosh offered Syed a plea deal for his conviction that would have required him to admit guilt and serve an additional four years in prison. Syed rejected the deal.\n\n\nIn 2012, Frosh was appointed by Maryland legislative leaders to chair a task force to study the impact of a  ruling regarding the  of owners of s and landlords that rent to them.\n\n\nHe and his wife have two daughters.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Tekesha A. Martinez''' (born 1978) is an American politician who is the mayor of . She was appointed to be Hagerstown's first Black mayor in 2023.\n\nPrior to her mayoral appointment in Hagerstown, Martinez was elected to a seat on the City Council, becoming one of the first Black women Councilmembers elected in the City's history. Martinez has also worked at the   and served as a community mediator for the Washington County Community Mediation Center.\n\n\nMartinez was born and raised in Hagerstown, Maryland, where she attended local schools and grew up in the Washington County Foster Care system. While still at high school, she became pregnant and gave birth to her first of five children at the age of 17. Martinez experienced difficulty with raising her child and sought help from social service agencies, who ignored her, prompting her to move to , where she became interested in poetry. She moved back to Hagerstown and took multiple jobs in hospitality, retail, and construction. She then became involved with the Washington County Boys and Girls Club.\n\n\nMartinez then worked as a program director at the Robert W. Johnson Community Center, getting connected with an opportunity for employment at the Washington County Community Mediation Center (WCCMC). The WCCMC provides assistance in resolving disagreements, including landlord-tenant disputes and conflicts among neighbors. Martinez became a community mediator at WCCMC and went on to co-lead the program in 2019 even after the Hagerstown Community Action Council canceled the program due to funding. Martinez first became interested in politics after working at the WCMC and the Robert W. Johnson Community Center.\n\n\nMartinez ran for Hagerstown City Council in 2020. In the primary election, she placed 9th out of 13 candidates, with the 10 candidates earning the most votes advancing to the general election. She then placed third in the general election in November and was elected to the City Council.\n\nWhile serving out her Council term from 2020 to 2023, Martinez focused on helping the Jonathan Street community and addressing public safety.\n\n\nIn January 2023, following  's appointment of Hagerstown mayor Emily Keller as Special Secretary of Opioid Response, Martinez applied to serve out the remainder of Keller's term as mayor. The Hagerstown City Council unanimously voted to appoint Martinez as mayor on February 7, 2023. She was succeeded on the Hagerstown City Council by Matthew J. Schindler.\n\nAs Mayor of Hagerstown, Martinez has focused on implementing the existing strategic plan from Mayor Keller's administration. One project of focus is a proposed indoor sports complex aiming to draw in visitors for competitive regional athletic tournaments and promote recreation.\n\n\n\nIn July 2023, Martinez filed to run for Congress in . She announced her campaign on July 12, 2023, in Hagerstown. Martinez was seen as a strong fundraiser and leading candidate during the Democratic primary, but behind frontrunners  and , and ran on a platform including public safety, local economic development, homelessness, mental illness recovery programs, and public education. Martinez was defeated by former  deputy administrator April McClain-Delaney in the Democratic primary election on May 14, 2024, placing fourth with 7.0 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
