    "pages": }\n\n'''Tony O'Donnell''' (born March 7, 1961) is an American politician, who represented  in the . In 2016, Governor  appointed him to the . He retired from the commission in June 2024.\n\n\nO'Donnell attended  in . He graduated from  in 1980. He received his B.S. from Regents College of the  (now ) in 1985.\n\nO'Donnell served in , achieving a rank of E-6, from 1979-87. After the Navy, he was a supervisor for the Instrument Modifications Unit at 's . He received the Edward T. Hall Memorial Award for Outstanding Republican Man of the Year – Calvert County, Calvert County Republican Central Committee in 1993. In 2005, he received the Outstanding Employer Partner award from the Maryland Chamber of Commerce.\n\n\n\nO'Donnell was first elected in 1995 into the  for District 29C, which covers parts of  and .  He defeated Thomas Michael Pelagatti by 32 votes. He was re-elected in 1998 (59%), 2002 (52%), 2006 (60%), and 2010 (57%).\n\n\n]]\nO'Donnell was Minority Whip in the  from 2003 to 2006, and served as Minority Leader until 2013. In 2010, he was named one of the \"Most Influential Maryland Legislators\" (Top 20).\n\n;Voting Record\n*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n*voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n*voted against the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n*voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n*voted for  in 1999 (HB703)\n*voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)\n\n\n*Environmental Matters Committee (2007–15)\n**Agriculture, agriculture preservation & open space subcommittee (2007–08)\n**Environment subcommittee (2007–10)\n**Natural resources subcommittee (2007–15)\n**Local government & bi-county agencies subcommittee (2008–09)\n**Land use & ethics subcommittee (2011–15)\n*Rules and Executive Nominations Committee (2007–16)\n*Legislative Policy Committee (2007-2013)\n**Management subcommittee (2007-2013)\n*Judiciary Committee (1995-2004)\n**Family & juvenile law subcommittee (1995-2003)\n**Juvenile law subcommittee (2003–04)\n*Special Committee on Higher Education Affordability and Accessibility (2003–04)\n*Rules and Executive Nominations Committee (2003–04) \n*Appropriations Committee (2004–06)\n**Health & human resources subcommittee (2005–06)\n*Pensions Oversight Committee (2005–06)\n*Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer (2007, 2011)\n\n\n*Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus (2001-)\n*Maryland Rural Caucus (2002-)\n*Taxpayers Protection Caucus (2003-)\n*Maryland Veterans Caucus (2011-)\n\n\n\nIn November 2011, O'Donnell announced his intention to run for the United States Congress representing  currently held by Democratic incumbent .     "pages": }\n'''John C. Wobensmith''' is an American politician who served as the 71st  from 2015 to 2023.\n\n\nWobensmith earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in English from the  and graduated from the .\n\n\nWobensmith served in the  and worked for five decades in national security under U.S. presidents , , , , and . He also served as the senior  representative in .\n\nWobensmith served on the  Board of Education for nine years and after retirement from federal civilian employment, was vice president for International Marketing for Sensys Technologies in London. He also worked for the .\n\nWobensmith served as the treasurer for the 2014 – gubernatorial election campaign and was a member of Hogan's transition team.\n\n\nGovernor-elect  announced the appointment of Wobensmith as secretary of state of Maryland on December 30, 2014. As secretary of state, Wobensmith oversaw the registration of notaries and charitable organizations and served as the governor's liaison for labor relations. He served as the chair of the Governor's Subcabinet for International Affairs and was on the Board of State Canvassers.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James Waters Gilchrist''' (born May 1, 1965) is an American politician who served as delegate for  from 2007 to 2023, representing  and .\n\nDuring his first term, he served on the Ways and Means Committee, where he sat on the Education Subcommittee, the Finance Resources Subcommittee, the Joint Committee on Children, Youth and Families and the Joint Committee on Base Realignment and Closure. For his second term, he moved to the Environmental Matters Committee, where he serves on the Housing and Real Properties Subcommittee and the Environment Subcommittee.\n\nPrior to his election, he worked as a Research Historian for History Associates, Inc., a Community Development Officer for the Department of Housing and Community Development, Policy Analyst for the Department of Legislative Services, and a Legislative Analyst for the Montgomery County Office of Intergovernmental Relations. Gilchrist currently serves as treasurer to the board of directors of the Potomac Area Council of Hosteling International. In his community, he has been the Alliance of Rockville Citizens treasurer, vice president of Americana Centre Condominiums, and chair of the Alliance of Rockville Neighborhood Associations. He has served on the Task Force to Explore the Incorporation of the Principles of Universal Design for Learning into the Education Systems in Maryland, the Commission on Civic Literacy, and the County Affairs Committee on the Montgomery County Delegation.\n\nA resident of Rockville, Jim Gilchrist was raised in Montgomery County, the son of two-term County Executive, Charles W. Gilchrist. He received his BA in English from Grinnell College in Iowa, and an MBA from George Washington University.\n\nIn September 2021, Gilchrist announced he would not seek a fifth term to the House of Delegates in 2022.\n\n\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax by 20% – Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for undocumented immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Bilal Abdul Malik Ali''' is an American politician who served as a delegate to the  representing Maryland's District 41.\n\n\nAli was appointed to the Maryland House of Delegates, filling the vacancy created when  resigned. He was defeated for election in the 2018 Democratic primary.\n\n\n\nAli was sworn in on February 3, 2017, and assigned to the House Ways and Means committee. This proposal followed a report the previous year that  apartment management company was Maryland's most aggressive landlord in obtaining civil arrest warrants.\n\nIn February 2018 Ali proposed disbanding and reconstituting the Baltimore Police Department in the wake of a .     "pages": }\n\n'''Karen Slater Montgomery''' (born August 23, 1935) is an  and artist from the state of . A , she served as the state senator for the  from Maryland's 14th District, which includes parts of Silver Spring, Burtonsville, Olney, Barnesville, Brookeville, Laytonsville, and Damascus in  in the  suburbs. She was elected in 2010 and reelected in 2014. From 2002 to 2010 she served as a member of the .  She resigned from her senate position on January 1, 2016, because of vision problems that limited her ability to drive at night.\n\n\nMontgomery earned her undergraduate degree from  and later a  degree from the . She would serve as a part-time faculty member in the Fine Arts Department at George Washington University until 1987, also working at the Art Barn and the . In 1987, Montgomery switched careers to work in the non-profit sector for a number of organizations including the , Arts for the Aging, and the , from which she retired in 1999. Both prior to and since her election to public office, Montgomery has volunteered with a variety of community organizations related to the arts, women's issues, and people with developmental disabilities.\n\nShe is married and has three grown children. One of her children has , which has driven Montgomery's involvement in community organizations that serve people with developmental disabilities, and her political advocacy related to the issue.\n\n\n\nIn 2000, the reapportionment of Maryland state legislative districts following the  led to the creation of a new district in , called District 14. Montgomery was one of twelve candidates in the Democratic primary election for the district's three house seats. She finished in second place and won the general election for the seat as well.\n\nDuring her first term, Montgomery served on the Environmental Matters Committee, and served on a commission on sustainable forestry appointed by the Governor. Following her re-election in 2006, she moved to the Health and Government Operations Committee. There, she has worked on a number of issues related to health care, including funding for the Developmental Disabilities Administration, support for veterans with behavioral health needs, and shortages in the state's health care workforce. She has also served in leadership positions in the Women Legislators of Maryland, the caucus of female legislators in the General Assembly.\n\nInspired by her son who has autism, Montgomery has been an advocate for better services for people with developmental disabilities. She has argued for better access to early intervention service for young children with autism. In 2009, Montgomery worked to limit state budget cuts to mental health programs and services to people with developmental disabilities. These programs were under threat due to a budget deficit in the state related to the .\n\nIn addition to her work on behalf of people with developmental disabilities, Montgomery has been active on health care, good government, and environmental issues. She has been the lead sponsor of a bill that would create a single payer universal health care system in the state of Maryland. In 2008, she introduced a bill giving certain property owners the right to install solar panels despite historic designations on their properties. Montgomery also worked to ensure that touch screen voting machines had a voter-verifiable paper record for use in recounts.\n\nIn the 2010 elections, Montgomery challenged incumbent Senator  in the Democratic primary and defeated her by less than 200 votes.  also left the House of Delegates that year, leaving two Delegate seats open in District 14.  and  won the two open House of Delegates seats in November 2010.   In early 2016, Zucker was appointed to the District 14 senate office, replacing Montgomery after she resigned on January 1, 2016.\n\n\nIn October 2023, the Brookeville Bypass along  was officially dedicated to Montgomery and former Brookville town commissioner Clyde Unglesbee.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Charlene Mickens Dukes''' (born August 12, 1954) is an American academic administrator serving as the first vice chair of the  since 2023. She was president of  from 2007 to 2020.\n\n\nDukes was born on August 12, 1954 in . She was the second oldest of nine children and was raised in a two-bedroom house for the first fifteen years of her life. Dukes attended  (IUP) for a year before leaving due to racism and wanting to learn more about herself. She moved to  and worked for the  and later  in New York. She re-enrolled at IUP, earning a B.S. in English and secondary education in 1980. She was a . She was active in the . Dukes completed a M.Ed. (1987) and Ed.D. (1992) in administrative and policy studies from the . Her dissertation was titled, ''Factors Contributing to the Process of Transferring by African-American Students from an Urban Community College to a Four-Year College''.\n\n\nDukes was an admission and financial aid officer at the  from 1980 to 1981. She later joined the  in 1981 as an assistant director of admissions. She was promoted to director of admissions in 1985 and director of minority affairs in 1991. In 1995, she served as dean of students. From 1995 to 2007, Dukes was the vice president for student services at the . On July 1, 2007, she became its eighth president and the first female to serve in the role. Duke retired on August 7, 2020.\n\nIn 2013, she was inducted into the . She served on the Prince George's County Board of Education, and was appointed by the governor to the . She served two terms as the vice-chair before being voted as board president. Dukes served as board chair of the Meyer Foundation and secretary of the . On August 7, 2021, she succeeded  as the interim president of . She was succeeded by Jermaine F. William in 2022. Dukes is vice chair on the board of .\n\nIn July 2023, Duke was one of governor 's six appointees to the . She is serving the remainder of James Coleman's five-year term that began on July 1, 2022. Dukes became the first vice chair of the  on November 18, 2023. She had run unopposed and was endorsed by governor Moore.\n\n\nDukes has a son and a stepson.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sheila S. Ruth''' (born October 22, 1963) is an  who represents , based in , in the .\n\n\nFollowing her graduation from  in 1987, Ruth became a publishing systems programmer for Attis Publishing Services from 1987 to 1989 and a computer specialist for the  from 1989 to 1992. Afterwards, she became a computer analyst for  from 1992 to 1994. She would receive a  degree from Villa Julie College in 1995. She later worked as a website developer in the same year, and as a website technologies instructor in 1999. Following her graduation, Ruth became a self-employed website developer.\n\nShe has served as the president of Imaginator Press since 2003 and is the current vice president of s. From 2004 to 2008, she served as the president of Mid-Atlantic Book Publishers Association.\n\nRuth entered into politics in 2016, motivated by the  of  and horrified by the election of , by founding the Baltimore County Progressive Democratic Club.\n\nIn 2017,  chair  invited Ruth to serve on the party's diversity leadership council. In July 2019, Ruth voted in favor of a resolution calling on the state's  members to support a standalone climate debate. Only one of the fourteen Democratic National Committee members, Larry Cohen, voted in favor of a standalone climate debate, with five members voting present and eight members voting against it.\n\nIn 2018, she became a member of the Baltimore County Democratic Central Committee. She is also the co-chair of the Baltimore City/County chapter of  and is a board member of Get Money Out-Maryland. As an activist, she organized support for a package of Baltimore County bills meant to strengthen ethical standards and institute public campaign financing, and was a lead organizer pushing for the passage of Baltimore County's anti-discrimination housing law that prevents landlords from denying applicants based on their source of income.\n\nIn January 2018, Ruth filed paperwork to run for the , seeking to unseat incumbent councilmember Tom Quirk. During the primary, she earned the endorsements of the '''' editorial team, but was defeated with 43.3 percent of the vote.\n\n\nIn January 2020,   appointed Ruth to fill the vacancy created by the appointment of  to the .\n\nRuth filed to run for a full term in 2022. She was endorsed by Progressive Maryland. In July 2022, Ruth finished first in the six candidate Democratic primary race for the two seats in district 44B.\n\n\n* Environment and Transportation Committee, 2020–present (environment subcommittee, 2020–present; natural resources, agriculture and open space subcommittee, 2020–present)\n\n\n* Women Legislators of Maryland, 2020–present\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Anne R. Kaiser''' (born February 10, 1968) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2003.\n\n\nKaiser was born in  on February 10, 1968, to father Jesse and mother Marian. She was raised in a  household, graduating from  and later attending the , where she earned a  degree in political science in 1990, and the , where she earned a  degree and a  degree in educational studies in 1995.\n\n\nAfter graduating from the University of Chicago, Kaiser worked as a staff assistant to U.S. Representative  and Maryland state delegate , and as an intern for the . While attending the University of Michigan, she worked as a teaching assistant for the university and as a policy analyst for the . After graduating from the University of Michigan, Kaiser worked as a policy analyst for the  until 2002. As of 2022, Kaiser works as a teacher at the .\n\nKaiser first became involved in politics during her sophomore year in college, when she encouraged her parents to vote in local elections despite being opposite political parties. From 1997 to 1998, she was the president of the Montgomery County Political Action Committee and the District 19 Democratic Central Club. Afterwards, Kaiser was elected to serve as a member of the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee until 2002.\n\n\n, 2023]]\nKaiser was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 8, 2003. She served as a member of the Ways and Means Committee from 2003 to 2021, and as its chair from 2017 to 2021, afterwards serving as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee. From 2015 to 2017, Kaiser served as the majority leader of the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nKaiser served as a delegate to the  in  and .\n\n\nKaiser came out as  in March 2004, while testifying for a bill that would allow domestic partners to make medical decisions for each other. She is married to her wife, Nancy Lineman, and together they have one child, born in May 2019.\n\nKaiser is  and is a member of the Tikvat Israel Congregation.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2006 legislative session, Kaiser supported a bill that would weigh kids in schools.\n\nIn April 2011, Kaiser spoke in support of , a bill that extended  for .\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Kaiser introduced a bill that would allow the  to \"garnish\" a county's tax revenues to fully fund its school systems. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn December 2014, Kaiser said that she would not support proposals by Governor-elect  to remove school boards' ability to authorize , but expressed openness to removing regulations from private schools. In November 2019, she criticized Hogan's objections to the  education reforms. During the 2020 legislative session, Kaiser opposed legislation that would mandate a post- start day for school districts.\n\n\nIn November 2023, Kaiser was one of 19 Jewish members of the  to sign onto a letter condemning a statement released by  calling for an immediate ceasefire in the .\n\n\nIn February 2006, Kaiser voted against a bill that would amend the  to ban . She supported the , which legalized , and bills to ban discrimination against  people. Kaiser has also criticized Florida's  and opposed attempts to pass similar legislation in Maryland. During the 2023 legislative session, she introduced the Trans Health Equity Act, which would require the state's  program to cover .\n\nDuring the 2006 legislative session, Kaiser voted for a bill to provide $25 million a year toward .\n\nIn 2012, Kaiser supported a bill that would allow the  to ban .\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Kaiser introduced legislation that would create a ballot referendum on holding  when there is a vacancy in a county executive's seat.\n\n\nDuring the 2004 legislative session, Kaiser voted for a bill to raise over $1 billion in taxes by increasing the state  and creating higher income tax brackets for wealthier Marylanders. In 2013, she supported legislation to index the state's  to inflation to pay for transportation projects.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Kaiser voted for a bill that would provide $5.6 billion in tax incentives to  to build their  in Montgomery County.\n\nIn January 2019, Kaiser rejected calls from Governor  during his State of the State Address to pass more than $500 million in tax cuts, including in retirees' income and small business, calling them \"pure fantasy\".\n\nIn November 2019, Kaiser said that she supported the  to fund the  education reforms.\n\n\nDuring the 2004 legislative session, Kaiser supported legislation to block construction of the . In December 2018, she criticized Governor  for not consulting with Montgomery County officials in creating a plan to expand Interstate 270 and the , and said that she favored a proposal by Montgomery County Executive  on improving the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kimberly Nicole Klacik''' ('''' '''Bray'''; born January 19, 1982) is an American businesswoman and political commentator. She was the  nominee for  in the , in which she was defeated by Baltimore County Executive . She was the Republican nominee for  in both the , held following the death of incumbent , and the subsequent . In both 2020 elections, she lost to   by over 40 points.\n\n\nKlacik was born Kimberly Bray on January 19, 1982. Klacik grew up in . She attended , but did not receive a degree. She moved to the  area in 2010.\n\nIn 2013, she founded Potential Me, a nonprofit that assists women with workforce development.  reported that Klacik's non-profit filed only one tax return since 2013, reporting a revenue of under $7,000 and expenditures under $3,000 for providing clothing to 10 women rather than the 200 women claimed by Klacik.\n\nIn April 2022, Klacik became a full-time midday host at Baltimore's , Monday-Friday from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Klacik had worked part-time for WBAL since June 2021, making regular weekly appearances on afternoon host Torrey Snow's show. She left the station in November 2022.\n\nIn May 2023,  announced the addition of Kim Klacik to their morning line up. Klacik began hosting The Kim Klacik Show in the 9am-12 noon time slot.\n\n\nKlacik was elected to the  Republican Central Committee in 2018.  in 2019 called her a \"Republican strategist\" and noted her critiques of Congressman  and the living standards and safety issues in his district.\n\nIn a July 2019 interview on '''', Klacik talked about Cummings's Baltimore district being overrun by trash and dilapidation. An hour later, President  echoed the segment by beginning to disparage both the city of Baltimore and Cummings on  in a series of 19 tweets over two days. Klacik responded to Trump's Twitter comments by tweeting, \"This just made my day.\"\n\n\n\n\nKlacik ran in the special election for Maryland's 7th Congressional District to replace Cummings, who had died in October 2019. After winning the Republican primary, she faced , a former Democratic holder of the seat. In the general election Klacik received 25.1 percent of the votes, losing to Mfume, who received 73.8 percent.\n\n\n\nMaryland's 7th District, which included parts of , the majority of , and more than half of , has been represented by Democrats for decades. No Republican has ever held the seat. Klacik, who did not live in the district, promised to move there if elected. She won the Republican primary on June 2, 2020.\n\nOn August 18, 2020, Klacik's campaign released a , titled \"Black Lives Don't Matter To Democrats\", which was filmed in a dilapidated area of . The video shows her asking three residents whether they wanted to , and they said that they did not. Klacik also criticized the Democratic leaders of , citing Baltimore's alleged notoriety as being among the most dangerous cities in America. The video, posted on Twitter, garnered 4.4 million views its first day, reaching 10 million views by August 22, 2020.  website  called the video \"misleading\". It presented an area of Baltimore, one with a higher poverty rate and more homicides than the 7th District overall, as representative of the district. The video was conceived of and directed and produced by , chief creative officer of . According to Snopes, Klacik's campaign had \"framed the video as one, long walk through a Baltimore neighborhood\" but it was actually filmed from different angles along both sides of a section of Whitelock Street that can be walked in two minutes, and Klacik was shown on a roof of a building at two different points in the video.\n\nPresident  retweeted her ad, stating that \"Kimberly will work with the Trump Administration and we will bring Baltimore back, and fast. Don't blow it Baltimore, the Democrats have destroyed your city!\" Klacik was one of the speakers on the first day of the , where she gave a two-minute speech.\n\nAfter Klacik accused Mfume in a Twitter post of avoiding debating her, Mfume responded with a post saying that Klacik lacked familiarity with Baltimore, does not live in the city, and that a widely viewed campaign advertisement of Klacik's had misspelled the city's name.\n\nKlacik lost the election with 28 percent of the vote to Mfume's 71.6 percent. She conceded the race to Mfume. On November 8, Klacik claimed that she had won in-person voting and that she had raised enough donations to investigate alleged \"irregularities.\" According to the results published by the State Board of Elections, Mfume received more votes in in-person early and election-day voting as well as in mail-in and provisional voting.\n\nBy the end of her 2020 House election campaign, Klacik had raised $8.3 million from small donors, most of them not from Maryland. A 2021 '''' article on Klacik's campaign finance filings showed that the campaign paid $4.2 million to two consulting firms. One of them, Arsenal Media Group, who had contracted with Benny Johnson to script and direct the August 2020 campaign video, received over $500,000. The other one, Olympic Media, was paid almost $3.7 million. Klacik's campaign initially reported part of it to the Federal Election Commission as payments to Republican fundraising platform .\n\n\n\n\nOn February 8, 2024, Klacik announced that she would run for Congress in , seeking to succeed retiring U.S. Representative . During the election, she ran on a platform focused on the issues of crime, immigration, and inflation. Klacik won the Republican primary election on May 14, 2024, and will face Baltimore County Executive  in the general election, during which she sought to bring attention to Olszewski's various . Klacik was defeated by Olszewski in the general election.\n\n\nKlacik was married to Jeffrey Klacik. They have a daughter and lived in . They are currently separated.\n\n\nCommentator  accused Klacik of being a strip club “madame” who spent campaign funds on cocaine. Klacik responded by filing a $20M defamation lawsuit in August 2021. The suit was dismissed with prejudice in December 2022. Further, Klacik was ordered to pay Owens $115,000 for legal fees.\n\n\n\n\n;Republican primary\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n;General election\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n;Republican primary\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n;General election\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Donna Fern Edwards''' (born June 28, 1958) is an American politician who served as the  for  from 2008 to 2017. The district included most of , as well as part of . She is a member of the .\n\nA lawyer and longtime community activist, she defeated eight-term incumbent  in the  and, following his resignation, won a special election on June 17, 2008, to fill the remainder of this term. She was sworn in two days later on June 19, becoming the first  woman to represent Maryland in the United States Congress. Edwards ran for a full term in November 2008, defeating Republican candidate Peter James with 85% of the vote. She ran for U.S. Senate in 2016 in the primary to replace retiring  instead of running for re-election to her Congressional seat but was defeated by   in the Democratic primary. In 2022, Edwards ran for the congressional seat she previously held but lost to  in the Democratic primary.\n\nIn 2013, she sponsored an amendment to the U.S. Constitution that would repeal the 2010 Supreme Court ruling in ''''.\n\n\nEdwards was born in . She earned  degrees in  and  from , where she was one of only six  women in the class of 1980. After working for  at the  with the  program, she attended and earned a  in 1989 from the  (now known as the University of New Hampshire School of Law). Edwards worked for  as a clerk in the 1980s, when he served in the .\n\n\nEdwards co-founded and served as the first executive director of the , an advocacy and legal support group for .  She worked to pass the 1994 .\n\nShe later worked with , and then as the executive director of the Center for a New Democracy.  In 2000, she became the executive director of the , taking a leave of absence during her political campaign.\n\nIn the spring of 2015, Edwards, along with several other members of the House of Representatives, introduced the Restoring Education and Learning Act (REAL Act) to bring back s to prisoners.  Edwards' press release outlines numerous advantages to prisoner education, including net benefits to taxpayers who bear the costs of recidivism.\n\nEdwards is a national co-chair of the progressive group Health Care Voter.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEdwards challenged seven-term incumbent  in the 2006 Democratic primary&nbsp;– the real contest in this heavily Democratic, black-majority district. Edwards focused primarily on Wynn's voting record. Wynn, considered a conservative by African-American Democratic standards, was one of four Congressional Black Caucus members that voted for the 2002 Iraq War resolution. Edwards condemned the war before it started. Wynn eventually began to say he was misled by the Bush Administration and his vote was a mistake. Edwards opposed the , which Wynn voted for. Similarly, Edwards criticized Wynn's vote for the , which eliminated some bankruptcy protections for individuals. Wynn supported the energy bill promoted by Vice President and former  CEO Dick Cheney. Wynn opposed the net neutrality bill of 2006, which Edwards supports.\n\nOn August 16, 2006, before a debate at , an altercation occurred between Wynn's staffers and an Edwards volunteer, leaving the volunteer with a bloody gash to the head. This event brought much media attention to the race.\n\nOn August 30, 2006, '''' endorsed Edwards in the primary race.\n\nThe primary was held on September 12, 2006. Wynn defeated Edwards by 49.7 percent to 46.4 percent, with a margin of 2,725 votes out of more than 82,000 cast. George McDermott, a little-known candidate, took 3.9 percent. The final tally of the primary was unclear for nearly two weeks because of widespread voting problems on new electronic voting machines in Montgomery and Prince George's counties.\n\n\n and , January 2008.]]\n\n\n\nIn 2008, Edwards again challenged Wynn for his seat in the . During the 2008 campaign, Edwards accused Wynn of being out of touch with the community and of accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars of corporate money. Wynn counter-attacked Edwards as hypocritical, citing the fact that she served as executive director of the Arca Foundation, an organization that has invested millions of dollars in oil and gas companies.\n\n\n\nIn the February 12, 2008, primary, Edwards defeated the eight-term incumbent in a rout, taking 60% of the vote to Wynn's 35%. The win virtually assured her of victory in the heavily Democratic district in November.\n\nAfter the primary, Wynn announced he would resign effective June 2008. Edwards won the Democratic nomination for the June 17, 2008,  to serve out the last six months of Wynn's term. \n\nAs expected, Edwards easily won the special election, taking 81 percent of the vote over  Peter James and  Thibeaux Lincecum. She took office two days later, giving her a leg-up on seniority over any new congresspersons who were elected in 2008.\n\n\n\nEdwards ran for a full term in November 2008 and was an overwhelming favorite; a Republican has never tallied more than 25 percent of the vote in the 4th district since it assumed its current configuration after the 1990 Census. Indeed, many of the 4th district's residents already thought of her as the district's congresswoman even before the special election. As expected, Edwards easily won a full term with 85 percent of the vote, one of the highest percentages in the nation for a Democrat facing major-party opposition.\n\n\n\nEdwards won against Delegate  in the September 2010 primary, and then defeated Republican Robert Broadus with 83 percent of the vote in the general election.\n\n\n\nEdwards won against George McDermott and Ian Garner in the Democratic primary, and then defeated Republican Faith M. Loudon and Libertarian Scott Soffen with 77 percent of the vote in the general election.\n\n\n\nEdwards won against Warren Christopher in the Democratic primary, and then defeated Republican Nancy Hoyt and Libertarian Arvin Vohra with 70 percent of the vote in the general election.\n\n\n\nAfter 's announcement that he would not be running for re-election to Congress in order to , Edwards announced on January 20, 2022, that she would be running in the  for her old seat,  congressional district. United Democracy Project, a  associated with the , ran nearly $6 million worth of advertising attacking Edwards during the primary election cycle. Her successful opponent, former   , also received almost half of his campaign contributions from donors associated with AIPAC. Edwards was supported by $720,000 from the  PAC, and $550,000 from the . ''The New York Times'' described the race as a \"proxy fight over Israel\".\n\nWhile there was heavy outside spending in the 2022 Democratic primary, Edwards went from a 13-point lead to trailing Ivey by 5 points as of early June, weeks before United Democracy Project began running TV ads on June 17. Edwards received 35 percent of the vote, while Ivey received 52 percent.\n\n\n\n\nOn April 27, 2009, Rep. Donna Edwards was arrested outside the  embassy during a protest against . The Representative and five other U.S. Congressional Representatives were protesting the blocking of aid to victims. They were arrested after ignoring warnings issued by police maintaining a police line to protect the embassy in Washington, D.C.\n\nThe other U.S. lawmakers arrested during the protest were Reps.  (D-Massachusetts),  (D-Minnesota), Rep.  (D-Georgia), Rep.  (D-Virginia), and  (D-California).\n\n\n*''''''\n** (Ranking Member)\n**Subcommittee on Environment\n*''''''\n**\n**\n**\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEdwards and  (D-MD) faced off in the Democratic primary for the U.S. Senate seat to be vacated by Barbara Mikulski's (D) retirement.  She lost the primary election on April 26, 2016. Edwards received 39 percent of the vote, while Van Hollen received 53 percent. Since she had run for the Senate seat, instead of for reelection to her Congressional seat, Edwards left public office when her term expired in January 2017, and was succeeded by former lieutenant governor .\n\n\nEdwards ran for  Executive but lost to  in the Democratic primary, despite benefitting from an outside group that spent nearly $1 million to support Edwards and ran what ''The Washington Post'' editorial board deemed a \"smear campaign\". Edwards received 24 percent of the vote, while Alsobrooks received 62 percent.\n\n\nEdwards lives in .\n\nOn July 7, 2017, she announced that she had been diagnosed with . Edwards went on MSNBC programs (including AMJoy on July 15, 2017) to explain how the current health care bill that was up for a vote would affect her as a person with , and would affect other people with pre-existing conditions.  She penned an op-ed for ''The Washington Post''.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n**, C-SPAN, December 7, 2008\n*, June 2009\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Aruna Miller''' (née '''Katragadda'''; born November 6, 1964) is an American civil engineer and politician who is serving as the tenth  since 2023. A member of the , Miller formerly served in the , representing  in .\n\nMiller ran for Congress in 2018 to represent , losing to  in the Democratic primary. In December 2021,  chose Miller as his running mate in the Democratic primary of the . They won the Democratic nomination on July 19, 2022, and defeated Republican nominee  and his running mate Gordana Schifanelli on November 8, 2022.\n\nMiller is the first  woman elected lieutenant governor in the , as well as the first  lieutenant governor and first immigrant to hold statewide office in Maryland. Miller is the second woman to be elected lieutenant governor of Maryland after .\n\n\nMiller was born on November 6, 1964, in , , into a   family. Her family came to the United States when she was seven years old. Along with her two siblings and parents, she lived in , where  employed her father, Rao Katragadda, as a mechanical engineer. She attended public schools in Upstate New York and . Miller earned a  degree in civil engineering from the .\n\n\nMiller worked as a transportation engineer for local governments in California, Virginia, and Hawaii. She moved to Maryland in 1990, where she worked for the Montgomery County Department of Transportation. She has overseen programs that advanced access to schools, employment centers, and community facilities that are safe for pedestrians, bicyclists, transit users, and people with differing abilities. In 2015, she retired from Montgomery County to devote her full attention to her service in the Maryland legislature.\n\nMiller became a citizen of the United States in 2000 and voted in the  for  . She became frustrated with the Supreme Court's decision in '''', and subsequently became involved with politics by volunteering to help other candidates get elected. During the , she worked as a precinct-level volunteer for the  and presidential nominee . In 2006, Miller was appointed to serve as an at-large member of the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee and served in that position until 2010.\n\n\n\nAfter state delegate  announced that he would run for the  in 2010, activists in the Montgomery County Democratic Party called Miller to ask her to run. She initially declined to run, but changed her mind after talking with her husband. Miller won the election to represent District 15 in the , but assumed office a month early due to Rice's resignation to take office on the Montgomery County Council. Miller received support from fellow members of the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee, who voted to recommend that Governor  appoint her to finish the last month of Rice's term. Miller was the first Indian American woman to be elected to the Maryland Legislature.\n\nIn 2012, Miller served as an at-large delegate to the , pledged to President .\n\nIn her first term (2010–2015), Miller served on the Ways and Means Committee and its Revenue, Transportation, and Education Subcommittees. In her second term (2015–2019), Miller served on the Appropriations Committee, where served as chair of the Oversight of Personnel Subcommittee, vice chair of the Transportation and Environment Subcommittee, and vice chair of the Capital Budget Subcommittee.\n \n\n* President, Women Legislators of Maryland, Maryland General Assembly, 2016–2017\n* Chair, House Appropriations Oversight of Personnel Subcommittee, 2015–2019\n* Vice-chair, House Appropriations Transportation and Environment Subcommittee, 2015–2019\n* Vice-chair, House Appropriations Capital Budget Subcommittee, 2016–2019\n* Member, Maryland Advisory Council for Virtual Learning, 2012–2015\n* Commissioner, Interstate Commission on the Potomac River Basin, 2013–2019\n* Member, Business Climate Work Group, Maryland General Assembly, 2013–2014\n* Member, Joint Committee on Cybersecurity, Information Technology, and Biotechnology, 2015–2019\n* Member, Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight, 2015–2019\n* Founding Member, Maryland Legislative Asian-American, and Pacific-Islander Caucus 2015–2019\n* Member, Maryland Sexual Assault Evidence Kit Policy and Funding Committee, 2017–2019\n* Commissioner, 21st Century School Facilities Commission, 2016–2017\n* Member, Maryland State Ethics Commission, 2019–2020\n\n\n\nIn May 2017, Miller told '''' that she would run for Congress in  if  decided to pursue a campaign for governor. On July 28, 2017, Miller announced her candidacy in the  to replace Delaney, who said he would not run for re-election to instead . In April 2018, Miller won a  of Democratic activists in Western Maryland. During the election, she was endorsed by the , the , , , and , Rep. , and then County Executive , among others.\n\nDespite having received the most individual donations out of her Democratic opponents, Miller was outspent in the primary 13:1 by , the largest self-funding congressional candidate in U.S. history, and lost the primary to Trone by 9.3%, with 30.7% of the vote compared to Trone's 40.0%, and consequently did not advance to the general election. She won Montgomery County but this was the only voting district she won outright. Had she been elected, Miller would have been the only woman in Maryland's congressional delegation.\n\n\n\nIn February 2019, Miller was named the new executive director of Indian American Impact.\n\nIn January 2021, Miller filed paperwork to run for Congress again had Trone decided against running for a third-term. After Trone launched his re-election bid on May 7, Miller declined to comment on her 2022 plans.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn December 2021,  selected Miller as his running mate in the Democratic primary of the . The Moore-Miller ticket won the Democratic primary election on July 19, 2022.\n\nThe ticket defeated Republican nominees  and Gordana Schifanelli in the general election on November 8, 2022. Miller is the first  woman elected lieutenant governor in the , and the first  lieutenant governor and first immigrant to hold statewide office in Maryland. Miller served as the chair of the transition team for Governor-elect Moore.\n\n\nMiller was sworn in on January 18, 2023. She took the  on the , making her first lieutenant governor to do so.\n\nIn February 2023, Miller became the first woman of color to chair the  meeting after Governor Moore recused himself from a vote related to a contract between the  and , a company he has financial holdings in. In October 2024, Miller and Comptroller  presided over the Board of Public Works, marking the first time in Maryland history in which only women presided over the meeting.\n\nDuring her tenure, Miller has worked on issues involving transportation issues, including mass transit projects like the  and , and in promoting . In April 2023, following a car crash that resulted in the deaths of six highway workers, Governor Moore appointed Miller to chair the Work Zone Safety Work Group. This group was tasked with developing policy recommendations to prevent future work zone accidents. Under Miller's leadership, the Work Zone Safety Work Group proposed several key measures, including modifications to existing state laws to authorize the use of unmanned cameras in work zones and increased penalties for speeding in these areas. These recommendations were incorporated into the Maryland Road Worker Protection Act of 2024, which Miller testified for in both houses of the Maryland General Assembly. The bill was subsequently passed and signed into law by Governor Moore.\n\nMiller was an at-large delegate to the , pledged to  and served as a member of the DNC Rules committee.  Miller traveled out of state to battleground state of Michigan in support of the \n\n\n (left) campaign for Moore and Miller (right)]]\nIn October 2022, '''' reported that Moore and Miller were honored at a fundraiser hosted by individuals associated with , or a  political ideology. The fundraiser occurred after the Moore campaign added a page to its website highlighting Miller's record on supporting Muslim communities and religious freedom, accompanied by the statement, \"There is not one dollar in this campaign that has anything to do with the Hindutva movement or international politics.\" In August 2023, '''' reported that Miller had accepted at least $110,000 in contributions from individuals connected to the Hindutva movement since 2011, but noted the same donors implicated in criticisms of Miller routinely contributed to other Democrats across Maryland, though officials and candidates who are not of Indian descent rarely received criticism for accepting these contributions.    In a November 2022 interview with '''', Miller denied participating in fundraisers with Hindu nationalists, and said that she felt an unfair spotlight had been focused on her because she is Indian-American and grew up in a Hindu-Christian household. \n\nIn June 2023, during Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's state visit to the United States, Miller tweeted a statement in support of efforts urging President  to press Modi on the issue of . At the invitation of President Biden, she attended a  dinner hosted in Modi's honor.\n\nIn July 2023, '''' reported that party officials acting on behalf of Miller had retaliated against people who alleged she had ties to Hindutva, including an instance where a Democratic central committee member claimed that he was threatened by the chair to alter his vote supporting Susan Kerin, an activist who alleged Miller had ties to Hindutva. Another activist claimed that in 2018, he lost his job for criticizing Miller, and another claimed they lost their party position. Miller, in statements to ''The Independent'', denied these allegations and presented evidence disproving one of the claims. The chair of the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee, Saman Qadeer Ahmad, denied she threatened the committee member on his vote.\n\n\n\nIn 2013, Miller co-sponsored legislation that would require schools to start after . In August 2016, Governor  released a statement that included a number of county legislators, including Miller, that supported his decision to move the state's school start date to after Labor Day.\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Miller introduced legislation that would create a state study to review school start times and how sleep affected academic performance and school activities. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor O'Malley on April 4. In 2016, Miller introduced legislation that would recognize school systems as \"Orange Ribbon Schools\" if they had elementary school classes starting after 8am and middle school classes after 8:30am. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan.\n\nIn 2018, Miller introduced legislation that would require high schools to offer at least one high-quality computer science course and encourages local school districts to integrate computer science into their earlier grades.\n\n\nIn 2013, Miller was one of ten Maryland lawmakers named to the Maryland Business Climate Work Group designed to make recommendations and develop long-term plans to streamline business regulations, encourage business innovation, and develop public-private partnerships to finance infrastructure.\n\nMiller encouraged strengthening economic and cultural development between Maryland and India and accompanied Governor  on a trade mission to India in 2011, which resulted in nearly $60 million in business deals for the state of Maryland. Delegate Miller took a lead role in working with the Office of the Secretary of State and the Department of Economic Development to coordinate the Governor's arrangements for his first stop to Hyderabad.\n\nDuring her first term as a state delegate, Miller introduced one of the early Maryland bills for paid family leave.\n\nIn her second term, while serving as chair of the Oversight of Personnel Subcommittee, Miller was the floor leader for multiple bills expanding collective bargaining for employees.\n\nMiller stood in opposition to excluding nail salon workers from being eligible to receive unemployment benefits\n\nIn February 2018, Miller voted for a bill that would provide $5.6 billion in tax incentives to  to build their  in Montgomery County.\n\n\nOne of Miller's first actions after being elected to the Maryland General Assembly was to co-sponsor the Marcellus Shale Act of 2011, which laid the groundwork for the eventual passage of Maryland's fracking ban, which she co-sponsored.\n\nIn 2013, Governor  appointed Miller as a commissioner to the  (ICPRB). The mission is to enhance, protect, and conserve the water and associated land resources of the Potomac River and its tributaries through regional and interstate cooperation. She served on the ICPRB until 2019. \n\n\nIn January 2012, Miller signed onto an amicus brief in the  case of '''' supporting the . During her 2018 House of Representatives campaign, Miller said she supported moving toward a  system.\n\n\nIn March 2018, Miller said that the gun control provisions included in Congress's $1.3 trillion spending bill \"did not go far enough.\" That week, she unveiled a gun control plan that included expanded research, universal background checks, an assault weapons ban, and increasing the minimum age to buy a firearm.\n\n\n rally, 2024]]\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Miller voted for the , a bill to legalize .\n\nIn August 2015, Miller called for the resignation of Maryland Housing Secretary  after he claimed without evidence that parents were deliberately exposing their children to lead paint to get free housing.\n\n\nMiller endorsed former Secretary of State  for  on April 9, 2016. On April 17, 2019, Miller and the Indian American Impact group endorsed U.S. Senator from California  for president.\n\n\nIn March 2018, Miller said she supported studying alternative treatments, including  and , to help patients wean themselves from opioids.\n\n\n game in October 2023]]\nMiller is an adherent of  and swore her oath on the . In 1990, she moved to , where she married her college sweetheart, David Miller. Miller has three adult daughters, and her mother lives with the family in . She and her husband are .\n\nMiller maintains her activism in community organizations and has served on the boards of , Montgomery Parks Foundation, Emerge Maryland, Madison House Autism Foundation,  and the Montgomery County Public Schools Educational Foundation.\n\nMiller is a graduate of Leadership Montgomery.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 217,524\n| percentage = 32.4\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 202,175\n| percentage = 30.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 141,586\n| percentage = 21.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 26,594\n| percentage = 4.0\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 25,481\n| percentage = 3.8\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 24,882\n| percentage = 3.7\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 13,784\n| percentage = 2.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 11,880\n| percentage = 1.8\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 4,276\n| percentage = 0.6\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 2,978\n| percentage = 0.4\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 1,293,944\n| percentage = 64.53\n| change = +21.02\n}}\n\n| party = Republican Party (United States)\n| votes = 644,000\n| percentage = 32.12\n| change = -24.23\n}}\n\n| party = Libertarian Party (United States)\n| votes = 30,101\n| percentage = 1.50\n|change = +0.93\n}}\n\n| party = Working Class Party\n| votes = 17,154\n| percentage = 0.86\n| change = N/A\n}}\n\n| party = Green Party (United States)\n| votes = 14,580\n| percentage = 0.73\n| change = +0.25\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n* at \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Helen Bentley''' (née '''Delich'''; November 28, 1923&nbsp;– August 6, 2016) was an American politician who was a  member of the  from  from 1985 to 1995. Before entering politics, she had been a leading maritime reporter and journalist.\n\n\nBentley was born in the copper-mining town of . Her parents were immigrant , and her father was a miner. When Bentley was eight years old, her father died of , a common miner's disease, and Bentley took a part-time job in a dress shop while her mother took in boarders to support the family.\n\nWhile at high school, she had her first experiences of journalism and politics while working on the weekly newspaper of , which was published by Republican state legislator . She won scholarships to study journalism at the , graduating in 1944 after earning a  degree with honors. While at college, she worked on the Senate campaign for Democrat , and was appointed his Senate secretary.\n\n\n\n\nFollowing her graduation, Bentley worked for small-town newspapers in , and , but she wanted to report hard news for a larger publication; at the time, most women journalists were limited to writing society news. She wrote to all the main East Coast newspapers and eventually, in 1945, '''' offered her a reporting position. She initially reported on labor and union matters, but was subsequently allocated maritime and waterfront news, a significant beat in a city and state  contributed heavily to the economy. She became a widely respected maritime reporter, dealing with people from dock workers to state politicians, and also writing for port agencies and shipping companies.\n\nBeginning in 1950, Bentley hosted a local Baltimore TV program on , ''The Port That Built a City'', presenting maritime and transportation-related news. Later retitled ''The Port That Built a City and State'', the series was produced by Bentley until 1965 and included then-novel  from the decks of ships in Baltimore harbor during the early years of television.\n\nDuring the , Bentley became aware of the congestion in the port of , and traveled there to report on the problems of supplying American troops.  became aware of her report, and subsequently improvements were made to port facilities in  to relieve pressure on Saigon.\n\n\nIn 1969, Bentley was offered a seat on the . However, she declined and asked for the position of chair instead. She was appointed and chaired the commission from 1969 to 1975. The position made her the highest-ranking woman in 's administration. During her tenure, Bentley advocated for federal support for American shipbuilding yards.\n\nBentley challenged  incumbent  in  in 1980 and 1982. She defeated Long on her third attempt in 1984, and was elected to the  and to the four succeeding Congresses, serving from January 3, 1985, to January 3, 1995.\n\nDuring her time in office, Bentley was a strong advocate for protectionist trade policies in support of U.S. manufacturing and the  fleet. She also introduced legislation which enabled the  to be dredged, allowing larger cargo ships to access the port of Baltimore. In the 1990s, she was sympathetic towards Serbians during the civil war in , and opposed U.S. military involvement in that conflict.\n in 1993]]\nBentley was not a candidate for reelection to the  in 1994, but was an unsuccessful candidate for nomination for . Despite an endorsement from the incumbent Democratic governor , she was defeated in the Republican primary by the more conservative .\n\nWhen her successor in Congress, , gave up his seat, Bentley sought to take the seat back in .  However, the district had been made significantly more Democratic in redistricting and included a large slice of Baltimore City, an area Bentley had never represented.  She lost to Baltimore County Executive .\n\nIn 1995, Bentley founded Helen Bentley & Associates, Inc''.'', and provided consultancy services on international trade, business and government. She was also a consultant for the Maryland Port Administration and the , and served on the Board of Trustees for both the  and the Maritime Industries Academy High School.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2004, Bentley was inducted into the . In 2006, as part of the 's 300th anniversary celebrations, the port was renamed the Helen Delich Bentley Port of Baltimore.\n\nBentley was a member of the , and a recipient of the Speaker's Medallion, First Citizen Award, and Governor's International Leadership Award from the state government of Maryland.\n\n\nBentley was married to William Roy Bentley, who died in 2003 from a stroke. The couple had no children. She died at the age of 92, at her home in , from brain cancer.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''Antonino Mangione''' (born April 1, 1987) is an American politician from the  who is a member of the  representing  since 2023, and District 42B from 2019 to 2023. He also served as a  co-chair for the state's Trump Victory Leadership County team.\n\n\nMangione was born in , . He attended , where he received his  in political science in 2009. After graduating, Mangione worked as an intern, and later a show host from 2017 to 2018, with , a talk radio station owned by his family.\n\nIn July 2017, Mangione filed to run for Maryland House of Delegates. He said that he was inspired to run for office by his late grandfather, Nicholas Mangione, a real estate developer who grew up in a poor Italian immigrant family. He won the general election alongside   with 28.6 percent of the vote.\n\n\nMangione has come under criticism for various conflicts of interest that could possibly arise from his relation with WCBM 680. While Mangione was a webmaster and a host, WCBM reposted several videos and posts advertising Mangione's campaign. The promotion from the station was not reported as in-kind contributions. Additionally, Mangione's campaign  page reported that Towson University had offered a new scholarship solely for undocumented students, though according to a university spokesman it had never existed. WCBM then created a web page on its website about the scholarship, linking back to Mangione's campaign Facebook page. Mangione has stated that he does not see WCBM posts or his radio show as in-kind contributions to his campaign.\n\n\nMangione was sworn in as a member of the House of Delegates on January 9, 2019, and appointed to the Appropriations committee. He serves on the health & social services subcommittee and the oversight committee on pensions.\n\nIn June 2023, Mangione announced that he would run for the  in District 42 in , challenging incumbent state senator , who later announced he would not seek re-election.\n\n\n\nDuring his 2018 campaign, Mangione ran on creating \"safe communities\" by getting tough on illegal drug dealers. He introduced an amendment to legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would block people convicted as an adult for more than one murder when they were a minor from seeking reconsideration of prior  sentences; his proposal was rejected in a 54–79 vote.\n\n\nDuring his 2018 campaign, Mangione said that he voiced support for expanding s. During the 2020 legislative session, Mangione was one of two legislators to vote against legislation that would provide an additional $577 million in funding over 10 years to  in Maryland.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Mangione cosponsored legislation that would ban convicted sex offenders from being students at Maryland public schools.\n\nIn July 2021, Mangione called for the firing of  school administrators after an investigation by Project Baltimore found that 41 percent of all Baltimore City high school students earned less than a 1.0 .\n\n\nDuring his 2018 campaign, Mangione was a vocal opponent to  and said that he would not support legislation that would turn Maryland into a . During the 2020 legislative session, Mangione voted to sustain Governor 's veto on legislation that would allow Maryland high school graduates including undocumented immigrants to qualify for the lowest tuition rates at public colleges and universities under certain circumstances, saying that he feared the bill would encourage more illegal immigration.\n\n\nDuring protests against the  in June 2020, protesters in the  of Baltimore tore down and threw a  into the  canal of the . Following this incident, Mangione called to protect the statue and introduced legislation that would prohibit any person from destroying, damaging, vandalizing or desecrating a monument, memorial, or statue of historical significance.\n\nIn 2023, Mangione voted against the Trans Health Equity Act, a bill that would require the state's  program to cover gender-affirming treatment. He later criticized the legislature for passing the bill, saying that he was upset about the direction of the legislative session: \"We've promoted issues like trans equity but we haven't really done anything about crime\".\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James Robert Hooper''' (July 27, 1936 – January 24, 2008) was an American politician who served on the  from 1999 to 2007.\n\n\nHooper attended  in .\n\n\nHooper owned Harford Sanitation Services, which he founded with his father in 1954 and was operated after his death until its sale by his son Bobby Ray Hooper and his daughter, Cindy Hushon. He was a member of the Harford County, Aberdeen and Havre de Grace chambers of commerce, as well as the  Business Association. He also served on the board of directors for the  of Harford County from 1986 until his death.\n\n\nHooper served as a member of the  Council from 1982 until 1990. He was elected to the  in 1998. He was sworn in on January 13, 1999, to represent District 35 in Harford County. The hallmark of his work was constituent service.\n\nHooper announced on November 14, 2007, that he was resigning his Senate seat due to poor health. The resignation took effect on December 31, 2007. He recommended and was replaced by State Delegate .\n\nHooper was lovingly known among the Senate's pages as Senator \"High Five\" Hooper because he would walk into session every day and run down the line of pages and give them high-fives. He was even known to do this among his fellow senators. Hooper's unique way of saying hello at the beginning of a session put a smile on everyone's faces.\n\nHooper succumbed to  on January 24, 2008, at his home in . He was 71 years old.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland State Senate – 35th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland State Senate – 35th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland State Senate – 35th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Karen Patricia Simpson''' (born August 28, 1967) is an American politician who is a member of the  for  in .\n\n\nSimpson graduated from Paint Branch High School in 1985. She later attended , where she earned a  degree in psychology in 1989, and , where she earned a  degree in community counseling in 1996.\n\nSimpson first ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in  in 2018. She was defeated in the general election by Republicans  and state delegate . She moved to  after her husband got a job as a pastor there.\n\n\nSimpson was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. She is a member of the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\nIn May 2022, Simpson signed a  resolution to move Maryland to 100 percent carbon-free electricity by 2035 and to remove  from the state's \"clean energy\" classification.\n\nIn a September 2022 interview with '''', Simpson said she would support strengthening protections for domestic violence victims, including removing the statute of limitations on reporting workplace sexual harassment and creating a state registry for people convicted of domestic violence-related offenses.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Marvin Earl Holmes Jr.''' (born November 27, 1948) is an American politician. He is a member of the , representing  in .\n\n\nHolmes was born in , Ohio, on November 28, 1948. He graduated from  and later attended , concentrating in engineering. Holmes served in the  from 1970 until 1974 where he earned a  and the . He was a member of the presidential honor guard and a search and rescue air crewman. Outside of politics, Holmes is a real estate agent and has been in the field for over 25 years.\n\n\n\nHolmes was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 8, 2003.\n\nIn July 2024, after Prince George's County councilmember Mel Frankin resigned from his at-large seat on the county council, Holmes filed to run in the  to succeed Franklin. He was defeated in the Democratic primary by  on August 6, 2024.\n\n\n*Vice-Chair, Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2020–present\n*Member, Environment and Transportation Committee, 2015–present (natural resources, agriculture & open space subcommittee, 2015–2018; land use & ethics subcommittee, 2015–present; chair, housing & real property subcommittee, 2015–present)\n*Member, Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 2015–present\n*Member, Environmental Matters Committee, 2003–2015\n*Deputy Majority Whip, 2006–2010\n*Member, Joint Legislative Work Group to Study State, County and Municipal Fiscal Relationships, 2009–2010\n*Vice-Chair, House Emergency Medical Services Work Group, 2009–2012\n*Member, Business Climate Work Group, 2013–2014\n*House Chair, Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, 2015–2017\n\n\n*2nd Vice-Chair, , 2003–2010 (vice-chair, 2017; law enforcement & state-appointed boards committee, 2008, 2015–2016; washington suburban sanitary commission committee, 2008–2012; vice-chair, bi-county committee, 2018–present, member, 2003–2007, 2013–2014)\n*Member, , 2003–present (historian, 2011–2012)\n*Member, Maryland Green Caucus, 2003–present\n*Member, Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2005–present\n*Chair, Democratic Party Caucus, 2011–2015\n*Member,  (legislative effectiveness & state government committee, 2005–2007; legislative effectiveness committee, 2007–present)\n\n\n\nIn April 2022, a law which Holmes co-sponsored, , which mandated that condominiums, housing associations, , and  complete a  by October 1, 2023, passed both houses of the . It went into effect in October 2023 and impacted condominium owners in  and across Maryland, with unit owners facing \"five-to-six digit bills over the next few years\" to meet the law's deadlines which require a reserve fund for repairs and maintenance.\n\nIn October 2021, Holmes described reserve studies as necessary because of complaints by association members that they are hit with huge special assessments because there aren't \"enough funds in their reserve accounts\" and argued that the bill would \"help protect against those scenarios\". Holmes has been described as a \"staunch supporter\" of greater oversight of HOAs and condo associations and a \"housing guru\" in the Maryland General Assembly.\n\nPreviously, the Maryland General Assembly failed to adopt statewide legislation mandating reserve studies, but adopted similar legislation for  in 2020 and  in 2021. Holmes also helped write those reserve studies laws.\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Holmes supported a bill to give tenants the right of first refusal if the property owner of their residence seeks to sell the property.\n\n\nFollowing the , Holmes compared  to , stating \"What's going on, unfortunately, is the start of anarchy proposed and accelerated by Trump. We only need to look at how Hitler came into power by chipping away at a society by having others enacting his dominance. It's similar to how slavery became law; one statute at a time by those that have power, in an attempt to increase the powerlessness of those that they wish to dominate.\"\n\n\nIn 2012, Holmes voted against legislation to expand gambling in Maryland; the bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 71-58 and was signed into law on August 15, 2012.\n\nHolmes introduced legislation during the 2019 legislative session to lower the state's lead exposure threshold from 10 to 5 micrograms per deciliter, the 's reference level that demonstrates elevated lead levels in children. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor  on April 30, 2019.\n\n\nIn 2012, Holmes voted for legislation to raise the state's  to replenish the state's transportation fund.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Aaron M. Kaufman''' (born February 15, 1987) is an American politician and disability rights advocate. A member of the  , he is a member of the  for  in . Kaufman has , and is the first member of the  with a physical disability.\n\n\nKaufman graduated from . He attended , where he received an  in general studies in 2009, and the University of Maryland, College Park, where he received a  degree in American studies in 2011.\n\n\nKaufman previously served as an administrative assistant for the Maryland House Ways and Means Committee. He is a long-time member of the Maryland Developmental Disabilities Council and , and has worked on campaigns at several levels of government. He also served as a senior manager of legislative affairs at the .\n\nIn 2014, Kaufman was elected to the Montgomery County Central Committee and served through December 2022.\n\nOn April 19, 2022, Kaufman applied to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 18, seeking to replace state Delegate  on the ballot after Carr withdrew his candidacy hours before the candidate filing deadline on April 15 to run for the county council, and no candidates were able to file to run in his place before the deadline. On April 20, the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate him to run in the district. Kaufman, along with state Delegates  and , faced Republican George Cecala in the general election.\n\n\nKaufman was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\n\nIn May 2022, Kaufman signed a  pledge to support legislation to get Maryland to use 100 percent carbon-free electricity by 2035 and to remove trash incineration from the state's \"clean energy\" classification.\n\n\nWhile working at the Jewish Federations of North America, Kaufman pushed for legislation that would offer more financial security to people with disabilities, including the ABLE Age Adjustment Act (S.331) and the Savings Penalty Elimination Act (S.4102). In July 2011, Kaufman attended a  rally at the  to urge the president to protect disability funding in budgetary negotiations with Congress.\n\n\nIn February 2011, Kaufman joined more than 100 disabilities advocates in a rally at the  calling on the legislature to raise the state's alcohol tax. The alcohol tax bill was signed into law by Governor  on May 19, 2011.\n\nIn April 2022, Kaufman said he supported creating  for corporate taxes.\n\n\nIn April 2022, Kaufman said he supported establishing other mechanisms of filling vacancies in the Maryland General Assembly, such as . Currently, under Maryland law, the only way to fill such a vacancy is through nomination by local central committees.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carol L. Krimm''' (born January 5, 1951) is an American politician who served in the  from district 3A from 2015 to 2023.\n\n\nKrimm was born in  on January 5, 1951, where she attended . She later graduated from the University of Maryland, where she earned a paralegal certificate, and from Frostburg State University, where she earned a  degree, and later an  degree, in political science. She entered politics in 2007 by becoming a member of the . From 2009 to 2013, she served as a legislative aide to delegates  and , who both represented District 3A in the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\nIn 2009, Krimm was elected to the . During her term, she served on the city's Airport Commission and Taxicab Commission.\n\nIn January 2014, Krimm announced her candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates. She received 36.3 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary and 28.0 percent of the vote in the general election.\n\n\nKrimm was sworn into the Maryland House of the Delegates on January 14, 2015.\n\n\n* Appropriations Committee, 2015–2023 (oversight committee on pensions, 2015–2023; vice-chair, transportation & the environment subcommittee, 2019–2023, member, 2015–2023; member, capital budget subcommittee, 2020–2023)\n* Joint Committee on Ending Homelessness, 2015–2023\n* Special Joint Committee on Pensions, 2015–2023\n* House Chair, Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee, 2020–2023\n* Work Group to Study Shelter and Supportive Services for Unaccompanied Homeless Minors, 2019–2020\n\n\n* Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2015–2023\n* Maryland Military Installation Legislative Caucus, 2017–2023\n* Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–2023\n* President, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2020–2021 (member, 2015–2023; 2nd vice-president, 2016–2018; 1st vice-president, 2018–2019; vice-president, 2019–2020)\n* Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2022–2023 (house executive board, 2022–2023)\n\n\n\n\nIn 2020, Krimm co-sponsored House Bill 206, which provided government aid to unaccompanied minors. The bill unanimously passed both chambers of the  and became law. She also introduced legislation that would require real estate agents or homeowners to disclose that a property is prone to s. The bill unanimously passed the Maryland House of Delegates, but did not receive a vote in the Maryland Senate. Krimm reintroduced the bill during the 2021 session, where it passed both chambers and became law.\n\n\nKrimm introduced legislation during the 2019 legislative session that would have loosened franchise restrictions on small brewers. The bill passed both chambers of the Maryland General Assembly with unanimous support and was signed into law by  .\n\nKrimm is an advocate of . In July 2020, Krimm urged Maryland Transportation Secretary Gregory Slater to investigate ways to increase remote work and other alternative work techniques to reduce traffic congestion. In August 2020, she suggested the immediate creation of a  to take advantage of the increase in remote work during the . During the 2021 session, Krimm introduced legislation that would require state and local governments to develop plans for remote working and to encourage private businesses to adopt remote working practices. The bill passed and became law.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 session, Krimm sponsored legislation that would increase funding for the Maryland Healthy Soils Program.\n\n\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 3A District (Democratic Primary)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2014 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 3A District (General Election)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2018 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 3A District (Democratic Primary)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2018 Race for Maryland House of Delegates&nbsp;– 3A District (General Election)'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
