    "pages": }\n'''Constance Morella''' (; née '''Albanese'''; born February 12, 1931) is an American politician and diplomat. She represented  in the  from 1987 to 2003. She served as Permanent Representative from the U.S. to the  (OECD) from 2003 to 2007. She is on 's faculty as an Ambassador in Residence for the Women & Politics Institute. She was appointed to the  (ABMC) by President  in 2010.\n\n\nShe was born Constance Albanese in . After graduating from Somerville High School in 1948, she attended , where she earned an Associate of Arts in 1950 and a Bachelor of Arts in 1954. Although she was raised in a family of  , she became a  after meeting Anthony C. Morella, who had worked for  Republicans , , , and others. After they wed, the couple moved to .  After Connie Morella's sister died of cancer, Tony and Connie Morella adopted her six children to join their own three children.\n\nMorella became a secondary school teacher in  in Maryland from 1957 to 1961. She graduated from  with an M.A. in 1967 and was an instructor there from 1968 to 1970, when she became a professor at  in . She continued to teach until 1985, when she left teaching to fully focus on her political career.\n\n\nIn 1971 Morella was appointed as a founding member to the Montgomery County Commission for Women, an advisory women's advocacy body, and she was elected its president in 1973. She became active in the . In 1974, she ran for the  from the 16th District (Bethesda), but did not win. She ran again in 1978, winning the seat and receiving more votes than the three previous incumbents. She was reelected for an additional term, before running for .\n\n\nIn 1986, Morella ran for the open Congressional seat in . The district was being vacated by Democrat , who was running for the Democratic nomination for the U.S. Senate. Morella's opponent in the general election was State Senator Stewart Bainum, a multimillionaire business executive who consistently outpolled her throughout most of the campaign.\n\nA major turning point came when Morella unexpectedly won endorsements from '''' and ''''. She was the first woman to hold this seat. Although she was a Republican in an area that had become heavily Democratic, she proved highly popular among her constituents and won re-election seven times, serving until 2002.\n\nMorella opposes her party's positions on , , , and the , voted for government funding of s and  programs for , and favored the legalization of . She received some support from  and opposed many tax cuts. Morella, however, voted against President Clinton's , as all other Congressional Republicans did. She voted against declaring  the official language of the  and, in 1996, against a bill overwhelmingly approved by Congress and signed by President  to combat .\n\nIn 1996, Morella was one of only five Republicans to vote against the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act. In 1998, she was one of only three Republicans to vote against renaming the Washington National Airport the . Morella was the only Republican in the entire Congress to have voted against approving the  in 1991 and again in 2002. She was active in human rights, women's health, and  issues in Congress, and served on the  and .\n\nMorella was U.S. representative to the 1994   in  and co-chair of the Congressional delegation to the 1995 U.N.  in . Among the legislation she sponsored were the 1992 Battered Women's Testimony Act, which provided funds for indigent women to hire expert testimony in domestic abuse cases, and the Judicial Training Act, which funded programs to educate judges about domestic violence, especially in child custody cases.\n\nMorella came under greater pressure after her party took control of the House in 1994 Congressional elections. Although she signed the  developed by Newt Gingrich, she had a mixed record supporting the subsequent Republican majority in Congress. She did not openly challenge the new House leadership until 1997 when she voted \"present\" for  instead of for the incumbent, . In 1998, she was one of four Republicans, along with  and  of New York and  of Connecticut, to oppose all four  of  against Clinton during the .\n\nAs a Republican representing an affluent Democratic district in an increasingly Democratic state, Morella faced a succession of increasingly strong Democratic challengers.  While she managed to fend them all off, even in the big Democratic years of 1992, 1996, and 1998, the low popularity of the Republican-controlled Congress gradually undermined her. She tried to portray herself as giving her district a place at the table, but over time, Morella's Democratic opponents claimed that a vote for Morella was a vote to keep  and other Republicans unpopular to district voters in power.\n\n\n President  stated that he intended to draw Morella's district out from under her after her relatively narrow reelection in 2000. The Democrats controlled both the State Legislature and the Governor's Office in 2000, thus controlling the  for the . Staffers from Senate President Miller, House Speaker Cas Taylor, and Governor  drew new maps to  out Morella and fellow moderate Republican . One proposal went so far as to divide her district in two, effectively giving one to State Senator  and forcing Morella to run against popular Delegate and  member .\n\nThe final redistricting plan was less ambitious but still made the already heavily Democratic 8th district even more Democratic. It restored a heavily Democratic spur of eastern Montgomery County removed in the 1990 redistricting and added nine precincts in  from 's heavily Democratic . Although it forced Van Hollen and Shriver to run against each other in an expensive , Van Hollen defeated Morella in 2002 with 52 percent of the vote to Morella's 47 percent (Morella would have narrowly won re-election in her previous district, according to election returns). Proving just how Democratic this new district is, the Republicans have only put up nominal challengers in the 8th since Morella's defeat; none of them have ever won more than 40 percent of the vote.\n\nIn 2013, Morella signed an amicus curiae brief submitted to the Supreme Court in support of  during the  case.\n\nMorella publicly endorsed former Vice President Joe Biden, a Democrat, in the 2020 US Presidential election, over Republican incumbent Donald Trump.\n\n\nPresident  appointed her United States Permanent Representative to the  (OECD) on July 11, 2003.\n\nShe was unanimously confirmed by the  on July 31 and sworn in on October 8 of that year, becoming the first former member of Congress to serve as  to the OECD. She is an honorary board member of the  who declared Morella a ''Feminina Excelente''.\n\nShe officially served as Ambassador from August 1, 2003 to August 6, 2007.  In November 2007, she was succeeded by Christopher Egan, son of .\n\n\nOn August 24, 2020, Morella was one of 24 former Republican lawmakers to endorse Democratic nominee  on the opening day of the Democratic National Convention.\n\n\nMorella has received honorary doctorates from , 1988; , 1989; , 1989; Mt. Vernon College, 1995; , 1996; , 1997; , 1997; , 1999; , 2000; and , 2004.\n\nHer numerous awards and recognitions include induction into the Maryland Women's Hall of Fame, the Ron Brown Standards Leadership Award, and public service awards from the , the , and the Hubert H. Humphrey Civil Rights Award from the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights \"for selfless and devoted service in the cause of equality.\"  awarded her the Medal of the Legion of Merit. She received the Foremother Award by The  in 2008.\n\nIn 2013, she was awarded the Knight Commander's Cross of the  for putting \"energy and enthusiasm into growing the Congressional Study Group on Germany, which is the oldest and most active parliamentary exchange involving Congress and the legislative branch of another country\" during her tenure as President of the .\n\nIn 2016, she was conferred with Imperial Decorations by the Japanese government. For her contributions to deepen the  in the U.S. Congress, she was awarded with the .\n\nOn April 14, 2018, the Bethesda Library branch of the  system was renamed the Connie Morella Library.\n\n\n\n\n\n*Write-in and minor candidate notes:  In 1996, write-ins received 379 votes.  In 2000, Lih Young received 77 votes; write-ins received 275 votes; and Scott Walker received 19 votes.\n\n\n\n*  – a Rockville, Maryland bookstore which Morella sought to save from bankruptcy\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  at the \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Richard Sossi''' is a former member of the . He represented District 36, which covers , , , and  Counties.\n\n\nSossi graduated from the  in 1965 with a B.A. in Asian Studies.\n\n\nAfter college, Sossi joined the , where he served from 1965 until 1970.  He did a tour in Vietnam, from 1966 until 1967, and served as Deputy Branch Chief for the National Security Agency from 1968 to 1970. While in the military, he graduated from the Defense Language Institute studying Chinese.  He also completed Officers' Cryptologic Course for the  in 1969.\n\nAfter the military, Sossi was a self-employed businessman, owning The Ship and Soldier Shop since 1977.  He was a member of the Queen Anne's County Republican Central Committee from 1990 until 1998. He has had the honor of serving as an alternate delegate to the Republican Party National Convention several times (1992, 1996, 2000).\n\nIn his community, Sossi is a member of the  Post 278, the , the , the , and the Coastal Conservation of America.  He also serves on the Cecil County Chamber of Commerce, the Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce, and .\n\n\nRichard Sossi married Flora Schoolfield (Sossi) in 1970 and has one daughter, Yvette Sossi Kalkay, and one grandson, Armando Kalkay.\n\n\nHe was first elected in 2003 and served along with fellow Republicans  and . In 2002, he defeated Democratic incumbent Wheeler R. Baker for the seat in Queen Anne's County.  In 2002, the election for that district called for the voters to choose 3 from the slate, whereas in the 1998 election, the voters chose one delegate from each county.\n\nIn 2006, Sossi defeated Wheeler R. Baker again, this time with 53% of the vote.\n\nAs a member in the Maryland House of Delegates, Sossi was appointed to be the Deputy Minority Whip in 2007.  He serves on the Environmental Matters Committee (2003–2011) and numerous subcommittees including local government & bi-county agencies subcommittee, 2003–05; housing & real property subcommittee, 2003–05, 2007-; natural resources subcommittee, 2003-; affordable housing work group, 2004; housing for individuals with disabilities work group, 2004; natural resources & ethics subcommittee, 2005; land use & ethics subcommittee, 2006; agriculture, agriculture preservation & open space subcommittee, (2006–2011);  ground rent work group, (2006–2011); co-chair, abatement of drug-related nuisances work group, 2004); Chair, Queen Anne's County Delegation, (2003–2011). DeWeese Carter Center Advisory Board, (2005–2011); Task Force to Study the Boating Industry in Maryland, (2007–2011).\n\n\n*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n*voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n*sponsored and voted for Veterans Advocacy and Education Act of 2006 (law)(HB3) (SB305)\n*sponsored and voted for Prohibition against Inflicting Unnecessary Suffering or Pain on Animals (regardless of ownership) 2006 (law)\n*voted against the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n*voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36 Queen Anne's County'''\n::'''Voters to choose one per county:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36 Queen Anne's County'''\n::'''Voters to choose one per county:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa14003.html\n*http://www.mdp.state.md.us/redistrict/2002ld_courtappeals_62102_MD_map_web.pdf\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Lisa Marie Belcastro''' (born September 24, 1988) is an  who represented the  in the  from 2020 to 2023. She was appointed to office in March 2020 by Governor  on the recommendation of the  Democratic Central Committee. Belcastro took the seat vacated by  when Hettleman was appointed to the Senate seat vacated by , who resigned in January.\n\n\nBelcastro was born in , , on September 24, 1988. She attended  in , , earning a B.S. degree in science health and physical education in 2012. Since graduating, she has worked as an adapted physical education teacher for  and as an assistant  coach for  from 2012 to 2017.\n\nBelcastro became involved with politics in 2017 by working as a volunteer coordinator for the  campaign of Izzy Patoka. From 2019 to 2020, she worked as a legislative aide to Patoka.\n\nIn 2020, after Delegate  was elevated to the  following the resignation of former Senator Robert Zirkin, Belcastro applied to fill the vacancy left by Hettleman in the Maryland House of Delegates. The Baltimore County Democratic Central Committee voted 4-1 to nominate her to fill the vacancy over four other applicants, including former Delegate . Governor Hogan appointed Belcastro to the Maryland House of Delegates on March 10, 2020; she was sworn in the same day.\n\n\nBelcastro was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on March 10, 2020.\n\nBelcastro was defeated for election to her seat in the 2022 Democratic primary. Redistricting had placed the three 11th district incumbents in a 2-seat district; Belcastro placed third in the vote.\n\n\n* Member, Health and Government Operations Committee, 2020–2023 (government operations & health facilities subcommittee, 2020–2021; public health & minority health disparities subcommittee, 2020–2023; health occupations & long-term care subcommittee, 2022–2023)\n* Study Group on Economic Stability, 2020–2023\n\n\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2020–2023\n* Women Legislators of Maryland, 2020–2023\n\n\n at the Maryland Association of Counties conference, 2023]]\nIn April 2023, Belcastro was appointed as the Deputy Secretary of the Maryland Department of Disabilities. She took office on May 31, 2023.\n\n\nBelcastro is openly  and is married to a woman. She lives in the  neighborhood of .\n\n\n\nBelcastro introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would require updates to Maryland's assisted living facility regulations, with specific protections for memory care units at these facilities. The bill unanimously passed both chambers of the  and became law on May 30, 2021.\n\nBelcastro introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that requires the Maryland Health Commission to assess standards of care at Maryland's assisted living facilities with 10 or fewer beds.\n\n\nIn July 2020, Belcastro signed onto a letter calling on the  system to alter the Student Code of Conduct to explicitly ban wearing or displaying symbols, such as the s and the , unless it is necessary for educational programming.\n\nBelcastro introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would ban the practice of seclusion in public schools. The bill unanimously passed the House of Delegates on March 15, 2022, and is currently on second reading in the Maryland Senate.\n\n\nIn April 2020, Belcastro signed onto a letter calling on Governor Larry Hogan to close the state's gun stores during the .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ryan Nawrocki''' (born 1983/1984) is an American politician and communications professional. He is a member of the  for  in north . He was previously a candidate for the  in District 6 in 2010 and 2018.\n\n\nNawrocki attended , where he earned a  degree in political science, public policy, economics, and sociology, and , where he earned a master's degree in public administration. After graduating, he started his own companies, including a medical aesthetics practice and a  company.\n\nNawrocki first got involved in politics by working in the , at which time he was the youngest appointee in the administration of  .\n\nIn 2010, Nawrocki unsuccessfully ran for the . He was defeated by  nominee Cathy Bevins by 503 votes.\n\nAfter his 2010 loss, Nawrocki began working as a spokesman to  , eventually becoming Harris' communication director. In January 2016, Nawrocki was appointed as senior director for the Maryland Transit Administration. Nawrocki also operated his own public relations firm, Red White and Blue LLC, which was hired by Maryland Environmental Service director  at a cost of $10,000 per month for work that included \"challenge coins\", writing remarks for senior staff including McGrath, note cards, and installation of new artwork in conference room.\n\nNawrocki once again challenged Bevins in the 2018 councilmanic elections, receiving endorsements from Ehrlich, Harris, and former county executive . Bevins again defeated Nawrocki by 3,594 votes, or 8.5 percent.\n\nIn February 2022, Nawrocki announced his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 7A. In May 2022, incumbent state Delegate  announced that she would run on a ticket with Nawrocki over state Delegate . The two were also endorsed by state Senator  and county councilmember David Marks. Nawrocki won the Republican primary, coming in second place behind Szeliga with 27.6 percent of the vote. He defeated autistic rights advocate  in the general election.\n\n\nNawrocki was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Environment and Transportation Committee and the Maryland Freedom Caucus.\n\nIn April 2023, Nawrocki sent a letter to State Superintendent Mohammed Choudhury accusing the  of hiding scores from failing scores by altering data files available on the department's website. An investigation conducted by the state inspector general found no evidence of these claims.\n\nIn May 2024, Nawrocki signed onto a letter condemning the jury's guilty verdict in the , calling the ruling a \"political prosecution from a kangaroo court and left-leaning prosecutor\" that is turning the U.S. justice system into a \"third world parody of law and order\".\n\n\nNawrocki is married to his wife Lauren. Together, the couple has five children, and lives in .\n\nIn November 2007, Nawrocki's then-girlfriend, now wife, twice called police to report a physical altercation between her and Nawrocki. In the first report, filed November 11, 2007, Nawrocki allegedly pushed her during an argument; Nawrocki denied it and she was not injured. In the second report, filed five days later, she told police that Nawrocki \"hit her in the mouth, splitting her lip and then pushed her to the floor\" during an argument at their  home. The report also alleges that Nawrocki \"began to choke her and she had to dig her fingernails into his arms and back to make him let her go.\" Nawrocki was never charged with a crime in the incident and says the claims in the report were an exaggeration to police. His wife also said in an interview with '''' that the police reports don't represent what really happened. The police reports became relevant when he ran for county council in 2018, when protesters involved in women's organizations picketed outside Nawrocki campaign events holding signs that accused him of domestic violence. Nawrocki accused his opponent, incumbent county councilmember Cathy Bevins, of sending the protesters to his event, an accusation which Bevins called \"absolutely ridiculous\".\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n\n \n}}\n\n'''Edward Leo Cochran Jr.''' (born 1929) is an American chemist known for his work with . In 1956 he moved from , to his hometown in Clarksville, Maryland, and began his career at .  He also served as the second  of .\n\n\nCochran graduated with a B.S. from  in 1949. He achieved a master's degree in chemistry from  in 1951 with a thesis on Basicities of Various Hydrazones. He earned his PhD from the  with a thesis on the photolysis of the alkyl iodides in the liquid phase.\n\nCochran worked for the  as a chemist for most of his career except for the period which he was County Executive of Howard County, Maryland. As chemist, Cochran was part of a team that carried out pioneering studies on the nature of free radicals, along with , Frank. J. Adrian, Vernon A. Bowers, Samuel Foner, and others, including the description of the  spectra of simple free radicals trapped in solid matrices at cryogenic temperatures. Dozens of free radicals were described for the first time, including hydrogen, deuterium, nitrogen, methane, alkyl, formyl, ethynyl and vinyl, NH2 and ND2 and cyanogen and Methylene Imino. Their paper on electron spin resonance proved to be one of the most frequently cited APL publications into the 21st century.\n\nFollowing his term as County Executive, Cochran returned as spokesman for the Applied Physics Laboratory, and learned how to fly at . Cochran's family has remained active in Howard County. His son William is an active artist with works proposed for , his daughter  became a school board member, County Councilperson, and Maryland State Delegate. His daughter Mary Catherine is a founding member of Preservation Howard County, winning the preservationist of the year award for defending and preserving the remaining county historical resources after significant losses to land development approved by the county.\n\n\nCochran served part-time as a member of the  (1964–1968) becoming chairman and as a Howard County Councilperson (1971–1974). Cochran served as Howard County Executive (1974–1978), running on a slate of Columbia Democratic Club sponsored representatives from Columbia including Ginny Thomas, Lloyd Knowles, Richard Anderson and . He was a member of the Regional Planning Council (1974–1978) and of the Criminal Justice Information Advisory Board, (1977–1980). Other activities include: Board of Appeals candidate (1980), Howard County Task Force on growth and development (1988), and Howard County Charter Review Commission (2012).\n\n\n\n\nThe Howard County School Board had pursued a policy of voluntary integration prior to 1964, which resulted in only a fraction of black students attending white schools. As late as 1964, ten years after , the board stated that it would not consider forcing integration until 1967, to \"allow for a reasonable period of adjustment\" to the change. However, in May 1964, as the county experienced increasing growth, the board was expanded to five members, and Cochran was appointed as one of the board's new members. He is credited by Maryland State Senator , then the education chairman of Howard County's  chapter, for providing the swing vote on February 9, 1965, to close all-black schools.\n\n\nIn 1975, as County Executive, Dr. Cochran introduced an act establishing an Office of Human Rights and making discrimination on the basis of race, creed, religion, physical or mental handicap, color, sex, national origin, age, occupation, marital status, political opinion, sexual orientation, or personal appearance in the areas of housing, employment, law enforcement, public accommodations, and financing unlawful in Howard County Maryland..\n\n\nIn 2009, the Howard County Human Rights Commission awarded Cochran the 2009 Human Rights Award. In 2010 he was awarded the James Clark Jr. Medal from  for his role in growing Howard Community College as a member of the board of trustees.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

He previously served in the  in the upper house of the , representing  in southern  from 1983 to 2011.\n\n\nDella was born in , the son of  (Sr., 1908-1990), the then also President of the .  He grew up in southwest Baltimore and attended the  and also subsequently the . He still occasionally works as an attorney, following his political career.\n\n\nDella was first elected during the  year of 1976 to the , as one of the three councilmen then elected from the old 6th councilmanic district for south and southwestern Baltimore City serving six years (before the City Charter was amended in the early 2000s to create ten single-member districts currently). \n\nIn 1982, he won his seat in the , representing the same area, which his father ( (Sr., 1908-1990) had also represented and serving as President of the Senate, several decades earlier. \n\nHe sat on the Finance Committee and the Executive Nominations Committee.\n\nIn January 2009, he introduced a bill (SB 233) intended to ban \"\", and would have \"outlawed any games that award drinks as prizes in city taverns\". Della withdrew the bill eve of its first committee hearing, stating \"\"We're getting inundated with so many e-mails that I don't have the time to fool with it... ...I just hope that if people continue doing it, they do it in a way that there's not excessive drinking and disrespect for the surrounding neighborhoods.\"\n\nAfter 28 years in the body at the  in the state capital of , Della was defeated for reelection in the 2010 Democratic Party's primary by .\n\n\n*  \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* :  George W.     "pages": }\n\n'''Jean B. Cryor''' (December 13, 1938 &ndash; November 3, 2009) was a member of the  for District 15, which covers a portion of , and later sat on the Montgomery County Planning Board.\n\n\nCryor was born (December 13, 1938) in  and raised in the suburbs of . She lived in  for over 35 years, and died on November 3, 2009, of cancer.\n\n\nCryor attended  in Overbrook, Pennsylvania, now located in .  She attended the . In 1979, she graduated from  with her M.B.A.\n\n\nShe married Daniel J. Cryor (1933–1978) November 21, 1959. The Cryors moved to the  area in 1972 for Mr. Cryor's job as a television reporter, and he later became a legislative aide for Rep. . After her husband's sudden death at the age of 45, Cryor raised her three daughters, Allison, Jennifer and Deirdre, as a widow in .\n\n\nCryor spent much of her career in journalism. She was a reporter for the '''', and for 10 years, she was the mid-Atlantic head for the election reporting pool of the networks and wire services. She was an editor and publisher at , launching the Potomac, Bethesda, Chevy Chase and Poolesville Gazettes.\n\nCryor was first elected to the  in 1994, winning re-election twice, serving on the Ways and Means Committee during her 12-year tenure in Annapolis. In 2005, she was the only Republican to support the creation of a Pay Equity Commission, voting to override the veto of Governor .\nIn 2006, she lost her bid for a fourth term by just 152 votes to Democrat  &ndash; Cryor was the only incumbent Republican Delegate from Montgomery County. The Montgomery County Council appointed her to the County Planning Board in June 2007.\n\nCryor was selected as a delegate for the . She was the only Republican to have been elected president of the Women Legislators of Maryland. She served on numerous boards, including the Maryland Commission for Women, the , , the Potomac Theater Company and Montgomery Women.\n\n\nCryor won several awards over her career, including first prize for Investigative Reporting by the Maryland Society of Professional Journalists in 1993. She was honored as Citizen of the Year (1993) by the Almanac Newspapers; Legislator of the Year (2000) by the Maryland Retailers Association; Businessperson of the Year (2002) by the Maryland Businesses for Responsive Government; Building the Bridge to Excellence in Maryland Public Schools (2002) by the State Board of Education; Legislator of the Year (2002) by the Childhood Brain Tumor Foundation and Registry of Maryland; Maryland's Top 100 Women by the Daily Record (2003 and 2006); the Woman of Achievement Award (2005) by the Suburban Maryland Business and Professional Women Association; and the Lifetime Service Award (2006) from the Potomac Chamber of Commerce.\n\nIn July 2010, Glen Hills Park near her Potomac home was dedicated in her honor. In 2013, she was inducted into the  and was awarded the House of Delegates' .\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15''' Retrieved on Nov. 20, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15''' Retrieved on Nov. 20, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15''' Retrieved on Nov. 20, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Dawn Danielle Gile''' (born January 1, 1980) is an American politician and attorney. She is a member of the  for  in .\n\n\nGile graduated from  with a  degree in psychology and a minor in French before getting her  degree from  in 2006. She worked in the  area before moving to  in 2007. Before becoming a state senator, she served as the president of the Military Spouse JD Network.\n\nIn July 2021, Gile filed to run for the Maryland Senate in District 33, seeking to defeat state senator , who later announced his retirement. She won the Democratic primary unopposed, and faced Republican state delegate  in the general election. During her campaign, she received endorsements from  , former U.S. Senate candidate , and former Deputy Secretary of the  Ardath Cade.\n\nIn October 2022, Saab filed a $2 million defamation lawsuit against Gile, alleging that some of her campaign literature contained false information about him and his business, including the suggestion that he is under federal indictment. Gile, in a statement to '''', called Saab's lawsuit a \"distraction and a misuse of the legal system\" and implied that his allegations were an act of desperation. Saab dropped the lawsuits once the election was over.\n\nGile defeated Saab in the general election on November 8, 2022, receiving 55.41 percent of the vote to Saab's 44.48 percent. She is the first Democrat to win the state Senate seat in 50 years and the first Democrat to hold the office since .\n\n\nGile was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 11, 2023. She is a member of the Finance Committee.\n\n\n\nGile is a military spouse, with her husband, SGM (ret.) D.J. Gile, serving in the military for 24 years. Together, they have three daughters and live in .\n\n\nGile has been described as a .\n\n\nGile supports the , a sweeping education reform bill passed by the legislature during the 2020 legislative session that would provide schools with $3.8 billion a year for 10 years. In January 2022, she called the Blueprint bill a \"wonderful piece of legislation\" but said that it did not address all the issues facing students and staff in public schools.\n\n\nGile supports efforts to clean up pollution and runoff in the  and the . In January 2022, she said she supports smart development and sustainable agricultural practices to protect local ecosystems, specifically adding that she supports providing farmers with support to reduce  from chicken farms.\n\n\nDuring her state senate campaign, Gile sought to capitalize on the issue of abortion rights following the 's decision in ''''. During the 2023 legislative session, Gile defended a bill in the Maryland Senate that would create a  on codifying the right to abortion access into the .\n\n\nGile supports closing  in Maryland's tax code. She also supports making military retiree pay exempt from state taxes.\n\nIn March 2023, Gile was one of five Democrats to vote for an amendment that would have decoupled the state's es from .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Juanita Sandra Bartlett''' (born January 6, 1966) is an American politician and lawyer who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2019.\n\n\nBartlett was born in  on January 6, 1966. She graduated from , where she earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in English in 1987, and attended classes at the  and  before receiving her Juris Doctor degree from  in 2007. Bartlett is a member of the  sorority and the .\n\nBartlett worked as an intellectual property attorney with various D.C.-area law firms from 2000 to 2015, afterwards starting her own law office and working as an adjunct professor for  since 2016. She was admitted to the  in 2014, and the  in 2016.\n\nBartlett first became involved in politics in 2006 as an alternate member of the  Democratic Central Committee until 2010, when she became an elected member of the committee. In that same year, she also became a member of the West County Democratic Central Club and the District 32 Democratic Club. In August 2017, Bartlett announced that she would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 32. During the Democratic primary election, she ran on a slate with state delegates , , and  (who was later replaced with  following his death). The district was targeted by the  and the , who had hoped to defeat the 's supermajority in the legislature. Bartlett won primary election in June 2018, and later defeated her Republican challengers in the general election with 20.7 percent of the vote.\n\n\nBartlett was sworn in on January 9, 2019, and has been a member of the Judiciary Committee during her entire tenure, becoming its vice chair in 2023. She has also served as a deputy majority whip since 2020.\n\nIn 2020, Bartlett became the first Black woman to serve as the chair of the , and became the first Black person elected to the position in December.\n\n\nBartlett lives in . She is married and has two children. She is .\n\nIn March 2019, Bartlett revealed that she had potentially terminal  and had a double  to remove it.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Bartlett introduced bills to automatically enroll inmates who complete their sentences into voter rolls.\n\nIn June 2020, Bartlett attended a  against  in , where she promised to introduce regulations on . During the 2021 legislative session, she introduced a bill that would prohibit s from arresting and searching a student except in situations involving \"serious bodily injury\". The bill passed the House, but died in the Senate.\n\nIn June 2021, she attended an NAACP protest in  after a video showing  violently arrest five Black teenagers for vaping on the boardwalk surfaced on social media.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Bartlett introduced the Child Interrogation Act, which prevented police from interrogating underage defendants without first allowing them to consult with an attorney. The bill passed and became law. She also supported the Juvenile Justice Reform Act, which restricted the state's ability to charge children younger than thirteen for most offenses.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Bartlett supported a bill to create a pilot program in elementary and middle schools to hire social workers to monitor students with behavioral, social, or legal difficulties.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Bartlett introduced Jaelynn's Law, which would require guns to be safely stored and inaccessible for children below the age of 18. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor . In May 2023, she condemned a Severn man who gained national attention for protesting against gun control bills the legislature passed that year by carrying a  through his neighborhood, adding that she would look at introducing a bill in 2024 to prevent people from doing this.\n\n\nBartlett condemned the  as an \"attempt at sedition\" and expressed solidarity with congressional lawmakers and workers.\n\n\nIn 2019, Bartlett voted for a bill to allow  for terminally ill patients.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Bartlett supported the CROWN Act, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of hair style and texture. The bill passed and became law. She also introduced a bill to ban \"Request to Suspend Investigation\" waiver forms in sexual assault cases.\n\nIn July 2020, Bartlett signed onto a letter calling on regional news organizations to increase employee diversity.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Bartlett introduced a bill to prohibit police from arresting and charging child victims of trafficking. The bill passed and became law.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Bartlett introduced a bill that would allow the Anne Arundel County Council to impose real estate transfer taxes on properties worth over $1 million. The bill passed the legislature, but was vetoed by Governor . The legislature overrode Hogan's veto on the bill during the 2021 special legislative session.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William G. Folden''' (born April 5, 1972) is an American politician who is currently a Republican member of the , representing  since 2023. He was previously a member of the , representing  from 2015 to 2019.\n\n\nFolden was born in Hagerstown, Maryland, and graduated from nearby . He later attended Frederick Community College, where he earned an  degree in criminal justice. Folden also served in the United States Army in the  and as a infantry sniper. From 1994 to 2011, Folden served as the deputy sheriff of Frederick County, and has served as a police officer for the city of  since 2011, even working as an officer while in the Maryland legislature.\n\n\nIn 2006, Folden announced his candidacy for , challenging incumbent Republican sheriff Chuck Jenkins. He was defeated by Jenkins in the Republican primary, coming in third with 21.16 percent of the vote.\n\nIn June 2021, Folden filed for the House of Delegates race in . In September 2021, he withdrew his bid for delegate and entered the Senate race in District 4 for the seat being vacated by . He won the  on November 8, 2022, by a margin of 57.54% to 42.36%.\n\n\n , 2015]]\nFolden was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. He served in this position until January 9, 2019, after being defeated by Democratic challenger  in the . He was the only active police officer in the state legislature.\n\n\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2015 (family law subcommittee, 2015)\n* Environment and Transportation Committee, 2015–2019 (housing & real property subcommittee, 2015–19; land use & ethics subcommittee, 2015–19; motor vehicle & transportation subcommittee, 2017–2019)\n* Member, Public Safety and Policing Work Group, 2015–2016\n* Chair, Frederick County Delegation, 2018–2019 (vice-chair, 2017)\n* Member, Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2015–2019\n* Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2015–2019\n\n\nFolden was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee.\n\n\nFolden is married and has three children.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Folden introduced a bill that would provide state funding to and relax restrictions on the state's s.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Folden introduced a bill that would allow military members to end their housing leases early if deployed or called to a new duty station. The bill passed the House of Delegates unanimously.\n\n\nIn January 2018, Folden said he supported a bill that would prohibit people convicted of  from having access to firearms.\n\n\nDuring the , Folden endorsed  and served on the Cruz for Maryland Leadership Team.\n\n\nIn July 2015, following the  earlier that year, Folden sent a letter to the co-chairs of the Public Safety and Policing Work Group requesting that  mayor  testify about the city's tactical response.\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Folden introduced a bill that would create the Maryland Police Training Commission to develop a lethality screening protocol and training to use when investigating complains of domestic violence and assault by strangulation, which was signed by Governor  in May 2016.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Folden introduced a bill that would train emergency responders on how to properly handle interactions with veterans affected by trauma.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Folden voted against a  that would allow the  to file lawsuits against the federal government, saying that he opposed the expanded powers because the Attorney General did not have these powers when they were elected.\n\nIn October 2018, Folden called for an independent review of complaints against Frederick Community College president Elizabeth Burmaster, which claimed that she had been verbally and physically abusive toward faculty and administrators at the college. Later that month, the community college board of trustees voted to request an investigation into the complaints.\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Folden introduced a bill that would make it illegal to drive in the far left lane of a highway unless the driver was passing another vehicle. The bill passed the House of Delegates by a 73-66 vote, but failed to move in the state senate. Folden reintroduced the bill during the 2018 legislative session, where it failed to move out of committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Thomas E. Hutchins''', born in , was a member of the  for District 28, which covers a portion of , prior to being selected to be the secretary of Maryland State Police.\n\n\nDelegate Hutchins graduated from  in . He holds a master's degree in state and local government from the , with undergraduate degrees in law enforcement and sociology from UMUC and an associate degree from  in criminal justice. Hutchins has graduated from several significant professional schools associated with law enforcement and military professions. He is a 1990 graduate of the  in , and a graduate of the 29th  in , and the Command Programme,  in .\n\nIn February 2005 then Colonel Hutchins was presented with an honorary degree from the  for his dedication to the college in which he began his academic quest and for bringing focus to the importance of public service based on his two lifetime careers in the fields of military and law enforcement. Hutchins founded a scholarship endowment for military veterans who enroll in the law enforcement/public safety academic track at the College of Southern Maryland.\n\n\nAfter serving in the military, Delegate Hutchins was a Maryland State Police trooper. Elected to office three times, he served on the judiciary committee, in addition to the gaming law & regulation, and criminal justice subcommittees, to name a few.\n\nColonel Thomas E. Hutchins was appointed by Governor  January 21, 2015 as Director of the Governor's Office for Homeland Security. Hutchins served as personal advisor to the governor on all homeland security issues from counter terrorism to disasters. In addition he supervised a portfolio of Cabinet agencies including the departments of: State Police, Military, Public Safety and Correctional Services, Veterans Affairs, Information Technology, Institute for Emergency Medical Service System, Emergency Management Agency, and the Office of Crime Control and Prevention. During his tenure Hutchins provided key advice to these cabinet agencies guiding them through the transition and several critical incidents to include the riots in Baltimore City during April 2015.\n\nIn 2003, Delegate Hutchins resigned from the Maryland House of Delegates to accept an appointment as Secretary of Veterans Affairs by Governor .  He served in this position for less than a year when he was appointed as the secretary of the Maryland State Police, also by Governor Erhlich.  He replaced , who resigned after a criminal indictment.  Ed Norris is also the former Baltimore City Chief of Police appointed by then Baltimore Mayor . Hutchins was appointed by Governor Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. as secretary of the Department of Maryland State Police and the superintendent of the Maryland State Police on December 10, 2003.  Hutchins was confirmed as secretary of the Department of Maryland State Police by the Maryland Senate in an unprecedented event when he received confirmation in a unanimous vote of approval on the Senate floor without ever being referred to a committee for review.  He is no stranger to the Maryland State Police, having served in the department more than two decades before his retirement in 1994.  During his career with the State Police, Hutchins served in every bureau of the department and broadened his experience through key assignments outside the department. In the history of the Maryland State Police, he is the fourth trooper to come from the ranks of the department and be appointed superintendent.\n\nSeveral significant highlights of his state police career are his command of the State Police Academy / Training Division, which included outreach and training to several foreign countries. He was also instrumental in the formation and leadership of the Maryland State Police Special Tactical Assault Team Element, training them in urban and rural tactics to counter high threat situations, Air Assault Insertion and Rescue Operations, also participating in numerous operations. \nOne accomplishment in Hutchins' career that is little known arose from his observations and subsequent traffic stop of a suspicious person which turned out to be the second secretary of the Soviet Embassy. According to the FBI this encounter uncovered one of the highest-ranking Soviet KGB agents ever identified in the United States at that time. That agent was ultimately found to be involved with John Walker, the U.S. Navy spy who inflicted significant damage to the U.S. intelligence network and the defense of this nation during the later part of Cold War era.\n\nIn 2007, newly elected Governor Martin O'Malley fired Hutchins and replaced him with Baltimore County Police Chief Terrence B. Sheridan.  O'Malley was criticized by   for removing Hutchins, who was the last appointed cabinet member remaining from the Ehrlich administration and the last member of the cabinet from Southern Maryland.\n\nDuring the period 2007 through 2013, Hutchins provided strategic planning assistance to JTF International a non-governmental organization enhancing law enforcement services in the Provincial Police Department of Cordoba, Argentina. Additionally, he worked as a contractor providing strategic planning and liaison support to the Department of Defense NGB J32 Counterdrug Division.\n\n\nIn 2008 it was revealed that the  had included 53 names of non-violent protesters in several databases that track suspected terrorists, despite the lack of any evidence of crimes being committed. This action was taken under authorization from Hutchins, who at the time was serving as the state police superintendent. \nDuring testimony before the Maryland Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee, in which he voluntarily testified on the record, he stated \"if it happened during my tenure then I am ultimately responsible\";  he apologized for the actions that had been taken by certain members of the department stating that those names should not have been entered into that data base. He further stated on the record, that one of those named did in fact raise concerns for violence due to past actions and statements and went on to say that \"sometimes advocacy groups can have one or more fringe people who have their own agenda\" meaning they attach themselves to the group. Hutchins closed by saying the last thing you want is the Superintendent standing before you after a catastrophe to explain why preventive actions were not taken.\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 28''' Retrieved on Dec. 7, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 28''' Retrieved on Dec. 7, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 28''' Retrieved on Dec. 7, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''Clarence W. Blount''' (April 20, 1921 – April 12, 2003) was an  who was the first  to be the majority leader of the . He represented the  in  from January 11, 1971, to January 8, 2003.\n\n\nClarence Blount was born to Lottie and Charles Johnson Blount Sr., in South Creek, North Carolina, and one of four children. As a child, Blount helped his father work on a tobacco plantation. The Blount family was so poor that they could not afford to buy their children shoes. When Blount was five years old, his mother died, and his family moved to  during the , growing up in the 400 block of North Carey Street. It was only after the family moved to Baltimore that Clarence Blount was able to begin school at the age of 10. He attended Baltimore City public schools and graduated from  and then decided to go to college. One month after Blount entered , he was drafted into the then segregated  to fight in . He served with distinction in Italy as a member of the all-Black . The courage and dedication to duty that he demonstrated while removing mines from a river passage earned him a battlefield commission. After fighting for his country against both the enemy and the barriers of , Blount returned to Morgan State in 1946 and graduated in 1950 with a  in political science. Blount would later attend The , earning an M.L.A. degree in 1965. Clarence Blount was a former principal and educator at  and a former executive assistant to president at the .\n\nBlount entered politics in the early 1970s, becoming a member of the Democratic National Committee. He was Delegate to the Democratic Party National Convention in 1988, 1992, 1996 and 2000.\n\n\nBlount was elected to the Maryland State Senate in 1970 to represent Maryland 41st district which was and still is entirely in the boundaries of . In 1983, Senate President  chose Blount to be the Majority Leader of the Maryland Senate, making him its first African-American majority leader. He held this position until he left office in 2003. In 1987, he became the first Black chairman of a Senate committee – the Economic and Environmental Affairs Committee. His demeanor and stature as an educator and veteran earned him the nickname of \"The Conscience of the Senate\". He also served on the following committees:\n* Judicial Proceedings Committee, 1971–1974\n* Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, 1972–1974\n* Vice-Chair, Budget and Taxation Committee, 1975–1986 (past chair, health, education & human resources subcommittee)\n* Member, Executive Nominations Committee, 1975–2003\n* Legislative Policy Committee, 1979–2003 (management subcommittee)\n* Spending Affordability Committee, 1982–2003\n* Joint Budget and Audit Committee, 1983–1997\n* Rules Committee, 1983–2003\n* Co-Chair, Joint Committee on State Economic Development Initiatives, 1995–1996\n* Member, Special Joint Committee on Group Homes, 1995–1996\n* Joint Audit Committee, 1997\n* Special Study Commission on the Maryland Public Ethics Law, 1998\n* Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, 1999–2003\n* Senate Chair, Joint Committee on the Port of Baltimore, 2000–2003\n* Co-Chair, Senate Committee on Redistricting, 2001–2002\n* Member, Special Committee on Gaming, 2001–2003\n* Co-Chair, Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer, 2002\n\nIn 1984, Blount was elected chairman of the  and served in that capacity until 1986.\n\nBlount played an instrumental role in the state takeover of the Baltimore school system in 1997, delivering a crucial speech before a vote on legislation that put millions of dollars into the school system in return for management reforms and a state role in running the system.\n\nOn July 6, 2002, Blount announced that he would not seek re-election in 2002.\n\n\nIn 1998, state delegate  filed a lawsuit against Blount, alleging that Blount lived outside of the district he represented and should be removed from the ballot. Boston was running against Blount in the Democratic primary. At the time of the lawsuit, Blount kept an apartment with no telephone and only a  to sleep on within the district, but lived in , which is located outside of the district in . Blount's attorneys argued in court that Blount qualified to represent the district because of this apartment, relying in part on  's 1984 opinion that listed 20 elements that determined a politician's residence. In August 1998,  Circuit Court Judge Michael E. Loney ruled that Blount lived outside of the district and was ineligible to run in it, removing his name from the ballot; Blount appealed the ruling the day after. In September 1998, the  ruled in favor of Blount, putting him back on the Democratic primary ballot and overturning the lower court ruling. Court of Appeals Judge  wrote in the court's 29-page opinion that while the Court acknowledged that Blount's apartment was not his home, but argued that a \"domicile\" doesn't mean a lawmaker's primary residence. \"The requirement is that one must be domiciled in the district, and domicile is not synonymous with party place of abode.\" The decision would come to be known as the \"Clarence Blount rule\".\n\nIn 2022, Maryland state senator  introduced and passed a bill that would place a  on the ballot to amend the  to overturn the Boston v. Blount decision, requiring candidates to \"maintain a primary place of abode\" in their district for at least six months before the general election.\n\n\n]]\nClarence W. Blount died April 12, 2003, of complications from a stroke; he was 81. Memorial services were held at the Carl J. Murphy Fine Arts Center at , and were moderated by state senator . U.S. Senator , U.S. Representatives  and Elijah Cummings, and current and former city, state, and judicial leaders spoke at the memorial service. After his funeral service, Blount was laid to rest in . U.S. Representative Elijah Cummings honored Blount in a speech on the House floor on May 1, 2003:\n\n\nThe Clarence W. Blount Towers on the campus of  were named in his honor.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n'''Craig Jason Zucker''' (born March 23, 1975) is an American politician who has represented  in the  since 2016. A member of the Democratic Party, he previously represented the district in the  from 2011 to 2016.\n\n\nZucker was born in , and raised in nearby . He earned his  from  in 1997, and his masters degree in government from  in 2004.\n\n\nZucker first got involved in politics as a college intern for U.S. Senators  and , and later worked as a scheduler for Senator . He worked as a legislative director to Maryland state delegate  from 1999 to 2000, afterwards working as a deputy district director for U.S. Representative  until 2004. Zucker served as the vice-chair of the Mid-County Recreation Advisory Board in  from 2004 to 2006, and as the deputy chief of staff to Comptroller Peter Franchot until 2010.\n\nIn 2002, Zucker unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 14, placing fourth with 12.3 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary election.\n\nIn August 2024, Zucker became a senior vice president of strategic development and government relations at Service Coordination Inc.\n\n\nZucker was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 12, 2011, and was a member of the Appropriations Committee during his entire tenure. From 2015 to 2016, he served as the House chair of the Joint Audit Committee.\n\nIn December 2015, following the resignation of state senator , Zucker applied to serve the remainder of her term in the Maryland Senate. His candidacy was backed by Senate president  In January 2016, the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate Zucker to fill the seat, and Governor  appointed him to the seat at the end of the week. Zucker was sworn in on February 4, 2016.\n\nZucker was a member of the Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Committee until 2018, afterwards serving in the Budget and Taxation Committee. In December 2019, following the election of  as , Zucker was named as the chair of the Senate Democratic Caucus. In August 2021, Ferguson appointed Zucker as the chair of the Capital Budget Subcommittee following the resignation of .\n\nSince 2016, Zucker serves as the Senate member on the Maryland Commission on Disabilities.\n\n\nZucker is married to his wife, Jenny. Together, they have two children and live in . He is .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2022, Zucker sponsored the End the Wait Act, which reduces the wait for waiver services.\n\n\nIn 2018, Zucker introduced a bill that would require the state to teach . The bill passed and became law.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Zucker introduced legislation that would add seats for a parent and teachers to the , and the Ready to Read Act, which requires school systems to provide additional support to kindergarten and first grade students with reading challenges. Both bills passed and became law.\n\nIn 2022, Zucker introduced a bill that would prohibit public schools from secluding other students except under certain conditions.\n\n\nIn 2016, Zucker voted to overrode Governor 's veto on a bill that would restore voting rights to released felons.\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Zucker introduced a bill that would require Maryland to use an  to draw its congressional and legislative districts if , , , , and  all passed legislation to do the same. The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor Hogan.\n\nIn 2018, Zucker introduced a bill that would require s to record data on political advertisements and users targeted by them, which passed and became law without Governor Hogan's signature.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Zucker introduced a bill to authorize the state to issue  licenses to fund the state's sports wagering industry and public schools. The bill passed and became law. After voters approved a statewide referendum to legalize sports betting in the , Zucker led a workgroup to develop a bill regulating the state's sports wagering industry, which passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Zucker introduced a bill that would require the  to redirect $14 million from abandoned property funds to a fund providing the  in eviction cases. The bill passed and became law.\n\n\nIn November 2023, Zucker and eight other state senators signed a joint letter that threatened to defund immigrants rights group  because it had called for an immediate ceasefire in the  and condemned the \"utilization of US tax dollars to promote the ongoing violence.\"\n\n\nIn December 2019, Zucker participated in and spoke at a rally in , to support of the .\n\n\nIn March 2011, Zucker said he supported the , which legalized .\n\nIn 2013, Zucker voted for a bill to repeal the death penalty in Maryland.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session and amid the , Zucker introduced legislation that would ban employers from imposing s on workers reporting sexual harassment and require employers with more than 50 workers to disclose information about their records in maintaining harassment-free workplaces. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session and following the suicide of 's son, Tommy, Cullison introduced a bill named for Tommy that would allow people to opt into periodic calls from  crisis counselors. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan.\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Zucker introduced legislation that would provide income tax breaks on up to $2 million of forgiven mortgage debt. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn 2013, Zucker voted for a bill to index the state's es to inflation to pay for transportation projects.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Zucker introduced a bill that would require the state to provide at least $500 million toward  projects annually for five years. The bill died in committee.\n\nIn 2021, Zucker introduced legislation that would prohibit the Maryland Transit Administration from purchasing buses that are not .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
