    "pages": }\n'''Rushern Leslie Baker III''' (born October 24, 1958) is an American lawyer and politician who served as the 7th  of  from 2010 to 2018. He previously served as a member of the  from 1994 to 2003, representing  in northern Prince George's County. A member of the , Baker unsuccessfully ran for  in  and .\n\n\n\nBaker was born in , on October 24, 1958. His father, Rushern Jr., was an officer in the  and served in the  and his mother, Carolyn, worked as a nurse's aide. Baker moved frequently during his childhood, including stints in , before eventually settling in .\n\nBaker recalled having learning struggles in school. He attended five elementary schools, two middle schools, and two high schools before graduating from Classical High School, where he played for the high school football team as a running back and defensive back. Afterwards, Baker attended , where he earned his  degree in history in 1982 and his  degree in 1986, and was a member of the student government association. Afterwards, Baker enlisted in the , serving from 1987 to 2001 and attaining the rank of .\n\n\nAfter law school, Baker worked as a senior  fellow in the office of U.S. Senator  for one year, afterwards working as a contract complaints officer in the District of Columbia Department of Housing and Community Development from 1987 to 1989. After serving as a legal counsel and special assistant for the Peoples Involvement Corporation from 1989 to 1999, Baker ran his own law firm, Baker & Perry LLP, until 2002.\n\nBaker served as a delegate to the  in , , , , , and .\n\n\nBaker was appointed to the Maryland House of Delegates by Governor  to succeed , who was appointed to the Maryland Senate. He was sworn in on August 11, 1994. Baker served as a member of the Judiciary Committee from 1995 to 1998, afterwards serving on the Appropriations Committee from 1999 to 2003. He was also a member of the  and was the chair of the  from 1999 to 2003. During his tenure, Baker opposed legislation to provide $270 million in state funding for  stadiums in  and , a bill designating  as the official state language, and the nomination of whose policies Baker compared to U.S. Supreme Court Justice as . He supported bills to ban , require the state to translate all public documents and forms into , and limit the powers of the .\n\n\n\n\n\nIn early 2000, Baker announced that he would run for Prince George's County Executive in 2002, seeking to succeed term-limited county executive . He targeted women voters and enjoyed a boost in momentum after '''' endorsed his campaign during the Democratic primary, but continued to trail county state's attorney  in polling up to election day. Baker was defeated in the Democratic primary by Johnson on September 10, 2002, placing second-to-last with 12.5 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn June 2005, Baker announced that he was forming an  to run for Prince George's County Executive in 2006, challenging incumbent county executive . He declared his candidacy in January 2006, and ran a campaign criticizing Johnson's handling of crime and education in Prince George's County. Baker was narrowly defeated in the Democratic primary in September 2006, receiving 47.5 percent of the vote to Johnson's 52.5 percent.\n\n\n\nBaker thrice ran for Prince George's County Executive in 2010, seeking to succeed term-limited county executive . He won the Democratic primary in September 2010, defeating Prince George's County Sheriff , who was backed by Johnson, and state delegate  with 43.9 percent of the vote. Baker ran unopposed in the general election.\n\n\n\nBaker filed to run for re-election as county executive in February 2014. He ran unopposed in both the primary and general elections.\n\n\n, 2015]]\nBaker was sworn in as Prince George's County Executive on December 6, 2010.\n\nDuring his tenure, Baker advocated for efforts to lure and retain businesses to the county and simplified the county's permitting process, which caused Prince George's County to undergo an economic revival that saw it lead the state's other jurisdictions in job growth and allowed it to achieve a budget surplus. Revitalization projects in the county's underserved communities and major development projectsincluding the  casino, the University of Maryland Capital Region Medical Center, and the  transit linebroke ground under his administration. Baker also pushed for reforms to the county's ethics law amid the arrest of his predecessor, , on federal corruption charges; and sought to rehabilitate the county's  by proposing legislation to restructure the county Board of Education. He unsuccessfully sought to raise property taxes in Prince George's County to pay for education reforms and supported a failed referendum that would have increased the number of terms that county-elected officials could serve from two to three.\n\nBaker received criticism for his handling of education issues in Prince George's County. After the  passed Baker-backed legislation in 2013 that allowed him to appoint the superintendent of the Prince George's County Board of Education as well as many of its members, Baker appointed Kevin Maxwell to serve as the board's superintendent. Under Maxwell's tenure, the school system lost $6.4 million in federal  grants after a review found that county officials failed to address complaints that teachers in the program were humiliating and using  against students; and was the subject of a state probe that found that the grades of nearly 5,500 students were altered between 2015 and 2017, which prompted the Maryland State Board of Education to assign a monitor to prevent future grade manipulation. Maxwell also approved large pay raises to a number of central-office employees without board approval. After Maxwell's tenure became an issue during the 2018 Democratic gubernatorial primary, Baker defended Maxwell by highlighting that the school system added nearly 9,000 students under his tenure and expanded specialty programs, including , full-day prekindergarten, and .\n\nBaker initially declined to say how he would vote on , a ballot referendum to legalize , but finally endorsed the referendum in October 2012.\n\n\n\n\nOn June 21, 2017, Baker announced that he would run for  in 2018, challenging incumbent Republican Governor . In February 2018, Baker chose former  candidate  as his running mate.\n\nDuring the Democratic primary, Baker touted his accomplishments toward the economy and crime as county executive, and supported proposals to raise the minimum wage to , increase funding for state community colleges, accelerate the state's clean energy transition, and revive the . He received endorsements from U.S. Senator , U.S. Representative , Attorney General , Montgomery County Executive , and former governors  and . He also received financial support from businessman , who was  in .\n\n\nBaker was defeated by former  president  in the Democratic primary election on June 26, 2018, placing second with 29.3 percent of the vote. '''' blamed his loss on Baker's failure to aggressively tout his accomplishments as county executive, lackluster fundraising skills, and his past conflicts with county unions and activists. Following his defeat, Baker campaigned for Jealous in the general election, in which Jealous was defeated by Hogan.\n\n\n\nOn April 8, 2021, Baker that he would again run for governor of Maryland in , seeking to succeed term-limited Governor . His running mate was , a member of the  Council from 2009 to 2022. During the Democratic primary, Baker unveiled a crime and policing plan that included proposals to increase police hiring, address vacant housing in Baltimore, and provide jobs and education to . He also criticized the leaked draft majority opinion for the  case ''''.\n\nInitially viewed as one of the frontrunners in the race alongside Comptroller , Baker fell behind in polls and fundraising; by June 2022, his campaign reported having less than $100,000 cash on hand and placing a distant fourth in polls of the Democratic primary. Furthermore, many of the high-profile elected officials who backed Baker's 2018 campaign had endorsed other candidates. He suspended his campaign on June 10, 2022.\n\n\nSince leaving office, Baker has run his own consulting firm, Baker Strategy Group. In July 2019, Senate President  appointed Baker to the  board. During his tenure, Baker worked with the  to establish the Elected Executive Leadership Program. He left the board 2021.\n\nIn November 2024, after county executive  won the , Baker said that he would run to succeed Alsobrooks as county executive.\n\n\nBaker met his wife, Christa Beverly, as an undergraduate at  in 1978. Baker is a member of Gamma Pi chapter of  fraternity.  The Bakers lived in Washington, D.C., briefly, before settling in , where they raised three children, including son . Rushern IV briefly served as Baker's campaign manager during the final weeks of his 2022 gubernatorial campaign.\n\nIn 2010, Baker's wife, Christa, was diagnosed with . The family decided to speak publicly about her diagnosis in 2012 in order to increase awareness for the disease and advocate for greater funding for medical research. Baker is an active member of the . In 2016, Baker got a tattoo of her initials and the logo for the  on his arm. Christa died due to Alzheimer's disease on September 18, 2021.\n\nIn March 2024, Baker received the Thomas Kennedy Award from the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 231,895\n| percentage = 39.6\n}}\n\n| votes = 171,696\n| percentage = 29.3\n}}\n\n| votes = 48,647\n| percentage = 8.3\n}}\n\n| votes = 48,041\n| percentage = 8.2\n}}\n\n| votes = 34,184\n| percentage = 5.8\n}}\n\n| votes = 18,851\n| percentage = 3.2\n}}\n\n| votes = 13,780\n| percentage = 2.4\n}}\n\n| votes = 9,405\n| percentage = 1.6\n}}\n\n| votes = 9,188\n| percentage = 1.6\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 217,524\n| percentage = 32.4\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 202,175\n| percentage = 30.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 141,586\n| percentage = 21.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 26,594\n| percentage = 4.0\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 25,481\n| percentage = 3.8\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 24,882\n| percentage = 3.7\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 13,784\n| percentage = 2.1\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 11,880\n| percentage = 1.8\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 4,276\n| percentage = 0.6\n}}\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 2,978\n| percentage = 0.4\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''James Carlton Hinebaugh Jr.''' (born December 12, 1946) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for  in  and  counties. He previously served as a member of the Garrett County Board of Commissioners, representing District 3 from 2014 to 2022.\n\n\nJames Carlton Hinebaugh Jr. graduated from . He graduated from the  in 1974 with a Bachelor of Science in computer science and mathematics. In 1988, Hinebaugh graduated from  with a Master of Business Administration degree in public administration.\n\nIn 1966, Hinebaugh was activated in the  and was deployed overseas for eight years, including service in . He retired as a  in 1995.\n\nIn August 1995, Hinebaugh was appointed Director of the Garrett County Department of Economic Development. During his tenure, the department experienced numerous business expansions, a decrease in the unemployment rate from 13.7 percent in 1997 to 7.5 percent in 2011, and the creation of six industrial parks. He also helped establish the Garrett County Scholarships Program in 2006, which provides two years of free tuition at  to county high school graduates. He retired from this position on October 1, 2012.\n\nIn 2014, Hinebaugh ran for the Garrett County Board of Commissioners in District 3, challenging incumbent commissioner Bob Gatto. He defeated Gatto in the Republican primary, receiving 36.8 percent of the vote to Gatto's 33.3 percent. He won the general election with 47.7 percent of the vote.\n\n\nHinebaugh was sworn in as a member of the Garrett County Board of Commissioners on December 9, 2014. He won re-election to a second term in 2018.\n\nIn January 2019, Hinebaugh was elected on one-year term the  board of directors. In December 2021, Hinebaugh was named to serve on the association's executive board.\n\nIn 2022, Hinebaugh filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 1A, seeking to succeed retiring state delegate . He won the Republican primary on July 19, 2022, receiving 58.5 percent of the vote, and later won the general election on November 8.\n\n\nHinebaugh was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Appropriations Committee.\n\n\nHinebaugh is married to his wife Barbara. Together, they have four children, and live in .\n\n\nHinebaugh's decorations and medals include:\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Cheryl Diane Glenn''' (born May 27, 1951) is an American politician. She was a member of the  , representing Maryland's  which is situated in northeast . She resigned in December 2019 in advance of a federal indictment for  and  to which she pleaded guilty in January 2020. In July 2020, she was sentenced to two years in prison.\n\n\nGlenn was born in Baltimore, Maryland and attended the public primary and secondary schools there. She graduated from  in 1969, the Community College of  (paralegal studies) and the George Meany Institute (labor relations). She became the Political Director of and lobbyist for the Mid-Atlantic Regional Council of Carpenters, (2004- ) after serving as President of the City Union of Baltimore, 1988–96. She was married to Benjamin Glenn, who has since passed away, and has five children and eight grandchildren. Glenn is also raising her granddaughter, Taylor Bishop.\n\n\nAfter a long career in the labor movement, Glenn was elected to the . Glenn was among three people elected to represent the 45th district located in east Baltimore.  Although it was her first run for a state office, she finished ahead of both the incumbents in that district in the general election.\n\nGlenn has been a member of House of Delegates since January 10, 2007. She initially served on the Environmental Matters Committee and several of its subcommittees and work groups: ground rent work group (2007); housing & real property subcommittee, 2007–2104; local government & bi-county subcommittee, 2007–2014; motor vehicle & transportation subcommittee, 2007–2104. At the beginning of the 2014 session of the Maryland General Assembly Glenn was reassigned to the Economic Matters Committee.  She is chair of the  and a member of its Fiscal Subcommittee, a member of the Women Legislators of Maryland and former chair of the .\n\n\n*Co-sponsored HB 860 (Baltimore City Public Schools Construction and Revitalization Act of 2013). Signed by the Governor on May 16, 2013, the new law approved 1.1 billion dollars to construct new schools in Baltimore City.\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted in favor of the Tax Reform Act of 2007 (HB2)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted in favor of slots (HB4) in the 2007 Special session\n* Primary Sponsor Employee Misclassification Act of 2008 (HB 70)\n*co-sponsored the Work Place Fraud Act of 2009 (HB819)\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – 45th District'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\nIn December 2019, U.S. Attorney  said Glenn accepted $33,750 in bribes. According to the '''', \"In charging documents, federal prosecutors allege that from at least March 2, 2018 through Feb. 11, 2019, Glenn 'defrauded the citizens of Maryland' by soliciting and accepting monetary bribes to affect, advocate for and vote on certain bills relating to opioid treatment clinics, liquor licenses and the expansion of the state's medical marijuana industry.\" Glenn pleaded guilty on January 22, 2020 and faced possible sentencing of up to 25 years in prison. Prosecutors asked for a three-year sentence while Glenn requested home detention. In July 2020, Glenn was sentenced to two years in prison. Glenn reported to  at the end of September 2020. In January 2021, she was released from prison to serve the rest of her sentence, scheduled to expire in June 2022, in home confinement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kriselda Valderrama-Lobo''' (born November 17, 1970) is an American  who represents  in the .\n\n\nKriselda Valderrama was born in  to , a judge in  and  representing . She is of  ancestry. She graduated from , and earned a  degree in respiratory therapy from .\n\n\nValderrama was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 10, 2007. Since 2022, she has served as the Deputy Majority Leader of the Maryland House of Delegates.\n\n\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, 2015–present (banking, economic development, science & technology subcommittee, 2015–2018; unemployment insurance subcommittee, 2015–2018; chair, workers' compensation subcommittee, 2021, member, 2015–present; member, business regulation subcommittee, 2019; chair, alcoholic beverages subcommittee, 2022–present, member, 2020–present)\n* House Chair, Joint Committee on Workers' Compensation Benefit and Insurance Oversight, 2015–present\n* Member, Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2021–present\n* Member, Judiciary Committee, 2007-15 (juvenile law subcommittee, 2007–2015)\n* Deputy Majority Whip, 2011–2018\n* Member, Legislative Policy Committee, 2019\n\n\n* Chair, Bi-County Committee, , 2017–present (law enforcement & state-appointed boards committee, 2014, vice-chair, 2008–2010, chair, 2011–2014; member, bi-county committee, 2015–present)\n* Member, Women Legislators of Maryland, 2007\n* Maryland Legislative Asian-American and Pacific-Islander Caucus, 2015–present (1st vice-chair, 2016–2019; chair, 2019–2021)\n* Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n\n\n\nValderrama introduced legislation during the 2020 legislative session to provide all Maryland workers with up to 12 weeks of . The bill was reintroduced in 2022, during which it passed and became law after the General Assembly voted to override Governor 's veto.\n\n\nValderrama endorsed  for president on April 9, 2016.\n\n\nValderrama was a co-sponsor of the , a bill to legalize . The bill passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 72-67 and was signed into law by Governor  on March 2, 2012.\n\nValderrama introduced legislation in the 2016 legislative session to prohibit employers from excluding women from desirable positions and for employers to retaliate against employees for sharing salary information with co-workers.\n\nValderrama introduced legislation in the 2018 legislative session to block employers from imposing s on workers reporting sexual harassment and require employers with more than 50 workers to disclose information about their records in maintaining harassment-free workplaces. The bill passed and was signed into law on May 16, 2018.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brian Alan Chisholm''' (born November 7, 1970) is an American politician who represents northern  in the . A member of the , he represented  from 2019 to 2023, afterwards representing the .\n\n\nChisholm was born in , and graduated from  in . He holds a  degree in Marketing from .\n\n\nChisholm was a member of the Pension Oversight Commission of  from 2015 to 2018. He was vice-chair of the commission from 2017 to 2018.\n\nIn 2014, Chisholm ran for election to one of two  seats in the Maryland House of Delegates, but came in fourth in a field of eight candidates in the Republican primary. On October 19, 2017, he announced that he would again run for the House of Delegates, and, together with incumbent and fellow Republican , won. Chisholm was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates om January 9, 2019, and has served as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee during his entire tenure. He is also a member of the Maryland Freedom Caucus.\n\n\nChisholm currently lives in  and works as a mortgage banker. He is married and has one child.\n\nChisholm co-owns, with former state delegate , a fitness gym in Severna Park. In February 2021, a former employee filed a lawsuit against the two lawmakers, alleging that she was retaliated against for reporting sexual harassment by another co-worker. A federal jury ruled for the employee in September 2023.\n\n\n\nIn April 2020, Chisholm sent a letter to the  asking the agency to publicly release more information about s in elder care facilities.\n\nIn May 2020, Chisholm attended a Reopen Maryland rally to protest COVID-19 restrictions put into place through s by Governor .\n\nChisholm introduced legislation during the 2021 legislative session that would provide a property  to businesses in  that were affected by the state's COVID-19 emergency declarations. The bill received a favorable report from the Anne Arundel County Delegation, but stalled in committee.\n\n\nIn July 2020, Chisholm organized a \"\" rally in , which he said was separate from the  movement.\n\nIn 2021, Chisholm opposed legislation that would remove the  from the Maryland Parole Commission, and introduced an amendment that would require inmates serving a  to get \"unanimous agreement\" from the state's parole board to be released. His amendment was rejected in a 91–41 vote.\n\n\nIn April 2023, Chisholm sent a letter to State Superintendent Mohammed Choudhury accusing the  of hiding scores from failing scores by altering data files available on the department's website. An investigation conducted by the state inspector general found no evidence of these claims.\n\n\nIn 2021, Chisholm opposed legislation that would allow register voters to opt-in to an  list instead of reapplying for mail-in ballots before statewide elections, introducing an amendment that would require voters to have a . His amendment was rejected.\n\n\nIn May 2024, Chisholm signed onto a letter condemning the jury's guilty verdict in the , calling the ruling a \"political prosecution from a kangaroo court and left-leaning prosecutor\" that is turning the U.S. justice system into a \"third world parody of law and order\".\n\n\nIn 2021, Chisholm opposed legislation that would allow Maryland counties to set up a , introducing an amendment that would have required counties to lower the tax on lower income brackets if officials opt to increase the tax for higher income brackets. His amendment was rejected.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n}}\n\n'''Wendell Roy Beitzel''' (born January 17, 1943) is an American   from . He served in the , representing  which covers  and  counties, from January 2007 to January 2023.\n\n\nBeitzel graduated from  in 1964 with a  in biology. He has also received a  in management and a  from .\n\n\nBeitzel served in the  from 1965 to 1968. He was a microbiologist for the  from 1968 to 1971. He was part owner of the Point View Inn & Motel from 1973 to 1978, the Starlite Motel & Restaurant from 1978 to 1983, and the Point View Inn & Motel from 1981 to 2003. When Beitzel Enterprise existed as a company that controlled public accommodation services, he served as President of Beitzel Enterprises, Inc. He served as the Assistant Director of Environmental Health at the Garrett County Health Department from 1971 to 1981.\n\nIn 1981, he assumed the position as administrator for the Garrett County Sanitary District until 1998, he started focusing more on his owned businesses. He has been a farmer since 1983, and was also a Director of Infrastructure Development, D.C. Development LLC, 2003 to 2006. Beitzel served a term as a Garrett County commissioner from 1998 to 2002.\n\nBeitzel became a Maryland State Delegate in 2007 after the 2006 election. He was first appointed to the Health and Government Operations Committee in 2007, but was relocated to the Appropriations Committee in 2009 - where he currently sits as a member. He is part of the Capital Budget Subcommittee, Transportation and the Environment Subcommittee, and the Personnel Oversight Committee - all part of the Appropriations Committee.\n\nIn August 2021, he announced he would not seek a fifth term to the House of Delegates in 2022.\n\nIn October 2021, he was one of five Maryland state legislators from Garrett, Allegany and Washington counties who sent a pair of letters to West Virginia officials asking about annexation of  to West Virginia. These letters caused a local uproar, with Allegany County officials calling the request a political stunt, an embarrassment and unneeded distraction.\n\nFollowing criticism from local officials and some constituents, Delegate  and State Senator  issued a letter withdrawing support for the secession proposal.\n\n\nBeitzel was the subject of criticism in 2011 when he received $427,000 in state funds for agreeing not to develop farm land he owned. The deal actually cost the state of Maryland $455,000, since they also contributed fees for appraisal and other professional services, totaling $28,000.00. The property in question was a farm owned by Wendell and Ruth Beitzel near Accident, Maryland, which they acquired around 2007.\n\nBeitzel submitted an application to the Board of County Commissioners to establish an Agricultural District for a farm they own on Accident-Bittner Road For the purpose of seeking conservation easements utilizes the Maryland Rural Legacy Program. The Beitzel application was approved on February 6, 2008, by the Garrett County Planning Commission and by the Agricultural Preservation Advisory Board on February 28, 2008.  The Board of Garrett County Commissioners approved the application April 29, 2008.\n\nThe Beitzel application was then submitted with 5 others to the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation by the Garrett County Department of Planning and Land Development on April 30, 2008. After approved by the creation of an Agricultural Preservation district by the Garrett County Commissioners, Beitzel submitted an application to participate in the Garrett County Bear Creek Rural Legacy Program to convey development rights to the property in exchange for payment to be determined by appraisal.\n\nThe administration of the program, started by the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, ordered three appraisals.  After assessment of the easement, Beitzel was offered $427,000 for the conservation easement on January 12, 2009.  Beitzel accepted the offer on January 28, 2009.  It took several years before the transaction was finally approved by DNR while two other applications were being processed.  After being informed that the application was approved by the DNR for settlement in 2011, Beitzel informed Mr. Williams A Somerville, Ethics Advisor for the Maryland General Assembly Joint Committee and Legislative Ethics of the pending transaction and asked for a review of the easement to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest before and to ensure appropriate disclosure before requesting final approval by the Board of Public Works for Maryland.  In addition, the Delegate submitted Form B&D Disclosure of Interest to the Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics.\n\nThe Beitzel application was approved by unanimous vote of the Board of Public Works and the sale of the conservation easement was finalized in 2011.\n\n\nIn March 2014, Beitzel voted against raising the state minimum wage from $7.25/hour to $10.10/hour. The House of Delegates voted 89 to 46 in favor of the legislation. Beitzel spoke out against the wage increase, stating the bill would harm small business owners and cause them to go out of business.\n\n\nIn 2016, Beitzel opposed legislation that would prohibit carrying firearms and deadly weapons on Maryland college campuses. Betizel had concerns that the legislation would impact hunters who might inadvertently travel on university property with a firearm in their vehicle.\n\nBeitzel has sponsored several pieces of legislation related to , a major reservoir in his district, including bills that would allow landowners to purchase contiguous property  and a plan to provide funding for state-owned lakes such as Deep Creek.\n\n\n\nBeitzel said he has been supporting the practice for drilling and as a landowner served to gain from drilling. \"I've been criticized from potentially benefiting financially from  (drilling)\", said Beitzel, who added he would not benefit any more than those who had Marcellus Shale under their property.\n\nIn March 2015 the Maryland Legislature debated a bill, HB449, that would provide for a three-year period to study the health effects of . A panel of experts would study the environmental and public health risks of hydraulic fracturing. Supporting the gas industry's concerns about the bill, Beitzel expressed opposition to the bill and has argued repeatedly that additional studies and regulations would deter gas development in Western Maryland and was not business friendly. Beitzel offered several amendments to the bill which failed on the House floor before a final veto-proof vote in favor of the health study and moratorium. In the end, Beitzel was part of the 103 House members who voted for and helped pass the legislation.\n\nIn a WCBC radio interview posted online on April 9, 2015, Beitzel further explained his opposition to creating the panel of health experts by stating \"The makeup of the panel was created in such a fashion that I felt it was just so slanted to the one side that they would get the results they wanted\". He finally voted for a version of the bill that did not include public health considerations, stating in an interview on WCBC radio about the final bill \"it was not really a bill that was going to cause a whole lot of harm\".\n\nThe fracking issue intensified in the legislature in 2017 when two bills to ban fracking in Maryland were introduced in both the House and Senate.\n\nBeitzel was quoted in '''' as saying \"If you don't have property with natural gas, then you have nothing to gain from it, and it's easier to be opposed to it\". He further suggested that he would not benefit from fracking because \"he does not own the gas rights for his own property, much of which is off-limits to drilling because it is either designated for agricultural preservation or located within one of the watersheds that would be protected under the state's proposed regulations.\"\n\n''The Washington Post'' did a follow-up story on the issue when opposition accused Beitzel of a conflict of interest, which he presented to the Maryland Ethics Council in 2011 to assure the public there was no act of wrongdoing. The question of his conservation easements was raised again, along with his former comments which had led many to conclude that he was not disclosing that he stood to benefit financially if he chose to lease his land for drilling. \"I can only lease that land for agricultural purposes and other uses that are not restricted by the conservation easement,\" he explained the preceding month. Beitzel later provided clarifying remarks and the ''Post'' included a copy of a legislative ethics committee report on the matter.\n\nRegardless of Beitzel's stance on the development of natural gas in Western Maryland, his support has become obsolete since both bodies of the General Assembly passed legislation to ban the process of hydraulic fracturing (House Bill 1325/Senate Bill 740).  support for a ban on hydraulic fracturing and approval to sign the bill into law prevented a proposed moratorium, which would have allowed each county to vote whether or not the residents of that county wanted to ban the practice.\n\n\n\nIn February 2017, Beitzel was recognized by the  for his \"commitment to upholding conservative principles through their voting records during the 2016 legislative session.\"\n\n\n*'''2006 race for Maryland House of Delegates – '''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\nIn January 2023 Garrett College renamed its career technology training center to honor Beitzel in recognition of his efforts towards its creation.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''H. Wayne Norman Jr.''' (November 3, 1955 – March 4, 2018) was an American  and  who was a member of the , representing District 35 in  and  counties. Norman was appointed to the Maryland House of Delegates in 2008 to fill the vacancy created when Delegate  was appointed to the  to replace , who resigned because of illness. Glassman subsequently was elected as Harford County Executive, leaving a vacancy in the Senate seat. Norman was elected to that vacant Senate seat in the 2014 General Election.\n\n\nNorman graduated from the  in 1976 with a bachelor's degree in history. He returned to the  and received his J.D. in 1980. He was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1981.\n\n\nPrior to being appointed to the , Norman was a member of the Harford County Liquor Board. He was also a member of the Harford County Republican Central Committee from 1998 until 2007. He was a life member of the Harford County Republican Club. Also, he was a member of the Bel Air/Forest Hill Community Council. He was a member of the Harford Chamber of Commerce, the Western Maryland Railway Historical Society, and the Sons of the American Legion. In addition he was an honorary Life Member of the Kingsville Volunteer Fire Company. Norman maintained his law office in Bel Air, Maryland. He was a past President of the Harford County Bar Association (2008–2009).\n\n\nNorman died suddenly on March 4, 2018, at the age of 62.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Nancy Jacobs''' (born October 27, 1951, in ) is a former  representing District 34.\n\n\nJacobs attended  in . After high school, she attended , where she graduated in 1973 with her  in journalism and speech.\n\nAfter college, she began her career at  in . She became the owner and operator of West Shore Indoor Tennis Club, , where she worked until 1984. Then in 1985, Jacobs became the communications coordinator for the Maryland  . She was also a realtor from 1987 until 1991.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1994, incumbent  State Delegate  decided to retire in order to run for a seat in the . Jacobs ran and ranked first place with 23% of the vote. The other two candidates who won the district were incumbent   (23%) and  (22%). In 1998, she decided to retire after one term to run for a seat in the State Senate.\n\n\nShe was Minority Deputy Whip from 1997 until 1999.\n\n\n*House Judiciary Committee\n\n\n\n\nJacobs was first elected to the Maryland State Senate in 1999 to represent District 34, which covers portions of  and , . In 1998, she won the seat vacated by fellow Republican , who was the state senator for District 34 for only four years. Jacobs won a close election against Democratic challenger and former fellow Delegate , whom she only defeated by 139 votes out of over 37,000 votes cast.\n\nIn 2002, the election was a different story. This time she won with over 60% of the vote, defeating Democrat Arthur Henry Helton, Jr. The election in 2006 was a little closer. That year she defeated Democrat William B. Kilby with 57% of the vote. In 2013 Jacobs declared to her supporters that she would not run for re-election in 2014.\n\n\nDuring the 2007 session of the Maryland General Assembly, Senator Jacobs sponsored Maryland's version of . Her bill was passed by a 139–0 vote in the House and 43–3 in the Senate and has been signed into law by the governor.\n\nShe was elected Senate Minority Whip in 2009 and was the first woman in Maryland history to become the Senate Minority Leader in 2011. She retired from the Senate in 2015\n\n\n*Judicial Proceedings Committee\n*Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families\n*Joint Oversight Committee on the Department of Juvenile Services\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, Jacobs decided to run in the newly redrawn  and challenge incumbent Democratic U.S. Congressman . She won the Republican primary in April with 62% of the vote. Ruppersberger defeated her 66%-31%.\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland State Senate – District 34''' Retrieved on Oct. 13, 2007\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland State Senate – District 34''' Retrieved on Oct. 13, 2007\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland State Senate – District 34''' Retrieved on Oct. 13, 2007\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 34''' Retrieved on Oct. 13, 2007\nVoters choose three:\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/05sen/html/msa12249.html\n* http://www.nancyjacobs.com/site/\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Van T. Mitchell''' (born November 28, 1955) is an American politician who served as the Secretary of the  from 2015 to 2016. A member of the , Mitchell previously served as the principal deputy secretary of the Maryland Department of Health from 2004 to 2007 and as a member of the  from 1995 to 2004.\n\n\nMitchell was born in , on November 28, 1955. He graduated from  before attending .\n\n\nMitchell was the chief executive officer of MSI Inc., a construction supply business, from 1985 to 2006. His company's warehouse and lumber yard were destroyed during the . After Governor  left office in 2007, Mitchell worked as an associate for Manis, Canning and Associates from 2008 to 2015, and as a lobbyist for Cornerstone Government Affairs since 2017.\n\nMitchell first became involved in politics in 1982, when he became a member of the Charles County Democratic Central Committee. He served on the Town of La Plata's Business District Commission and the  Board of Trustees from 1993 to 1995.\n\n\nMitchell was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in  and sworn in on January 11, 1995. He was a member of the Economic Matters Committee from 1995 to 2003, including as the chair of its workers compensation subcommittee from 1999 to 2003, the Appropriations Committee in 2003, and the Environmental Matters Committee in 2004. He was also the chair of the  from 1996 to 2002 and the Charles County Delegation from 2003 to 2004. During his tenure, Mitchell supported efforts to increase funding for school construction and local highways, including the construction of bypasses around  and .\n\nIn April 2004, Mitchell announced that he would not seek re-election in 2006, saying that he wanted to spend more time working at his business and with local charities. He resigned from office early after Governor  appointed him as principal deputy secretary of the  in September 2004.\n\n\nOn December 23, 2014, Maryland Governor-elect  appointed Mitchell to be his Secretary for the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Mitchell's appointment was confirmed by the  on February 13, 2015, and he was sworn in later that day. During his tenure, Mitchell focused on efforts to tackle the  and oversaw the state's response to a capacity crisis at state hospitals from mid-to-late 2016.\n\nOn December 15, 2016, amid pressure from state legislators to more promptly care for criminal defendants awaiting psychological evaluations, Mitchell resigned as Secretary of Health effective immediately to \"pursue opportunities in the private sector\". He was succeeded by Dennis Schrader, who previously served as Governor Hogan's appointments secretary.\n\nIn August 2019, Maryland Senate President  and House Speaker  named Mitchell to serve as the chair of the Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board.\n\n\nMitchell is married and has two children.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

(economics), graduating in 1954. In 1992 he began his political career when he worked for the Republican State Central Committee.\n\n\nRzepkowski graduated from  in , which is in . He attended the  and received his B.A. in government & politics in 1993 receiving . Additionally, Rzepkowski was the charter president of the Eta Epsilon chapter of  fraternity at the University of Maryland.\n\n\nRzepkowski was first elected in 1994 when, along with fellow Republican  and Democrat , he defeated Democratic incumbent .  In 1998, Rzepkowski won reelection along with Love and      The general election in 2002 was identical to 1998 with all three incumbents winning reelection.\n\nRzepkowski resigned his seat on April 30, 2003, to accept a position with the Department of Business and Economic Development.  was appointed by Governor  to replace Rzepkowski as the delegate for District 32.\n\nWhile in the , Rzepkowski was the Chief Deputy Minority Whip in 2003.\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 13, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 13, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 32''' Retrieved on Nov. 13, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n* http://archive1.mdarchives.state.md.us/msa/mdmanual/06hse/former/html/msa12303.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael H. Weir Jr.''' (born September 2, 1948) is an  from  and a member of the .\n\n\n\nWeir was born in  on September 2, 1948. He attended the  and . He has been a firefighter with the  Fire Department since 1981. Weir has received a number of awards from  organizations.\n\n\n\nDelegate Weir is currently serving in his 3rd term in the , representing Maryland's District 6 in . Weir is a member of the Environmental Matters Committee.\n\n\n*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000 \n* voted for Jessica's Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007 \n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008 \n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009 \n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet, 2009 \n* voted against Civil Marriage Protection Act (HB438) - civil marriage rights for same-sex couples, 2012 \n\nFor the past four years, Delegate Weir has annually voted to support classroom teachers, public schools, police and hospitals in Baltimore County. Since 2002, funding to schools across the State has increased 82%, resulting in Maryland being ranked top in the nation for K-12 education.\n\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 6'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kenneth D. Schisler''' (born July 31, 1969) is a former member of the  and former chair of the .\n\n\nSchisler was first elected to office in 1990 when he was only 21 years old. He was elected to represent District 37, which covered , , , and  counties. He was elected along with three  - Don William Bradley, Samuel Q. Johnson III, and Robert A. Thornton, Jr.  He replaced  , who eventually returned to the General Assembly in 1995 as a State Senator.\n\nIn 1994, District 37 was divided into 37A (Dorchester and Wicomico Counties) and District 37B (Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, and Wicomico Counties). In this reconfigured district, Schisler won reelection along with fellow Republican , one of the candidates he defeated in 1990.  Schisler and Eckardt defeated Democratic incumbent Robert Thornton, Jr. and challenger Philip Carey Foster.\n\nIn 1998, Schisler and Eckardt again won reelection, this time defeating Democratic challenger William Steven Brohawn.   The next general election in 2002 had similar results, except there was no formal Democratic challenger.\n\n\nSchisler attended St. Michaels High School in  in . He went to  where he earned his B.S. in biology in 1992. He later returned to college and to get his J.D. from the  in 1998. During his undergraduate years at Salisbury State, Schisler was initiated into the  fraternity.\n\n\n\nSchisler was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1999 and began practicing as an attorney. He is also a member of the Talbot County Bar Association.\n\nIn 1992, he was selected as a delegate for the . In 1993 he got to serve as a delegate to  and  as part of the American Council of Young Political Leaders. In addition, Schisler is a charter member of the Talbot County Young Republicans club.\n\nOutside of his political activities, Schisler is a member of , an \"international non-profit organization dedicated to the conservation of wetlands and associated upland habitats for waterfowl\". He is active member in several environmental groups including the Maryland Ornithological Society, a group that focuses on the protection of birds, and Nature Conservancy.\n\nSchisler is also a member of the , and the  fraternity. He was once a participant in , a leadership action program, which was sponsored by the  of Maryland.\n\nSchisler has earned numerous awards including the  Honor Society, (1987), the Outstanding Academics Award and The Humanitarian Award from  in the 1989-90 school year, and the Outstanding Greek Scholar from , also during the 1989-90 school year.\n\n\nAs a member of the , he was a Minority Whip from 2002 until 2003, Deputy Minority Whip from 1994 until 1997, a member of the Environmental Matters Committee, several subcommittees, and the Joint Committee on Chesapeake Bay Critical Areas from 1992 until 2003. He resigned as Whip in 2003 after his appointment to the Maryland Public Service Commission.https://www.newspapers.com/image/282771518/ He served as a member of the Department of Natural Resources Special Funds Work Group from 2002 and 2003 and the Joint Committee on the Selection of the State Treasurer in 2003.\n\nSchisler was the chair of the Talbot County Delegation and the Eastern Shore Delegation in 2003.  He also served on the , a task force on energy, environment, & natural resources. Furthermore, he served on a Solid Waste Management Task Force in 1998, the Governor's Task Force on Eastern Shore Economic Development from 1999 until 2001, and the Mid-Shore Regional Council from 2001 until 2003. Finally, he was on the Tri-County Council for the Lower Eastern Shore of Maryland from 2001 until 2003.\n\n\n*voted for electric deregulation in 1999 (HB703)\n\n\nFrom 1997 until 1998 he served on the Task Force to Study Retail Electric Competition and the Restructuring of the Electric Utility Industry. This is relevant to the work in his next position, the chair of the  (PSC). Schisler was appointed to the five year position by Governor  in 2003 to succeed .  This appointment was approved by the .\n\nDuring the 2006 gubernatorial election, Schisler came under fire by the Maryland General Assembly and Democratic candidate  for approving a 72% rate hike by utility provider  (BGE).  Schisler's defended his position by stating that the rate hike was the long-term result to the deregulation plan enacted by the Maryland legislature in 1999 during the term of the previous governor, , and approved by the former members of the PSC. One of the members of the PSC that approved the rate cap was Joseph Curran III, the brother-in-law of Baltimore mayor and gubernatorial candidate Martin O'Malley, and son of the , .\n\nThe 1999 plan would allow for competition for electricity in Maryland, but called for a rate cap to last until 2006, which turned out to be a rate so low that it discouraged competition. The original plan also would allow for rates to be reset at the end of the capped period, at which time the market forces would determine the going rate for electricity.\n\nIn the criticism of Schisler, O'Malley stated that the PSC was a \"lapdog for special interests\" and demanded that Schisler be removed from his position.    In a similar vein, , the Speaker of the House for the Maryland House of Delegates, criticized the casual relationship between Schisler and Carville Collins, an industry representative who represented BGE and  Electric. The Democrat's argument was that the Schisler and the rest of the appointees on the commission were too friendly with the industry and not looking out for the interest of the consumers, thus having lost their independence.\n\nIn June 2006, the Democratic-controlled Maryland General Assembly passed a law that included the removal of the current members of the PSC. Ken Schisler sued (''Kenneth D. Schisler, et al. v. State of Maryland'')http://www.courts.state.md.us/opinions/coa/2006/140a05.pdf  and won the right to keep his job arguing that only the governor could fire the members of the PSC.  The law, had it taken effect, would have allowed the General Assembly to appoint 2 members each by the  and  to the PSC, while only allowing the Governor to appoint one member. Currently, the appointment of members of the PSC belongs to the executive branch.\n\nMartin O'Malley won the gubernatorial election in 2006, thus Schisler lost his advocate, Governor Bob Ehrlich. State Senate President  tried to negotiate an amicable deal which would have had Schisler removed, but Schisler turned down the offer. O'Malley's chief council, Ralph S. Tyler, said that if Schisler would not resign his position, he could be fired.  Under pressure, Schisler eventually resigned on February 2, 2007.  Governor Martin O'Malley appointed  to replace Schisler. Larsen is a former Insurance Commissioner for the Maryland Insurance Agency.  Larsen was given a salary of $185,000, 58% more than Schisler's salary of $117,000.\n\nThe PSC approved a 15% increase that would take effect in July 2006 and be in place for 11 months. This was during the final months of Governor Ehrlich's term. A future increase was to be determined after the election. However, Ehrlich was defeated by Martin O'Malley. With the 11-month period nearly over, a 48% rate hike has been proposed, which when calculated along with the original 15%, is nearly identical to the originally proposed 72% rate hike from 2006. Ironically, the new commissioners under Governor O'Malley accepted this proposal stating that there was no legal way to change these new rates.\n\n\n*'''2002 electionfor Maryland House of Delegates – District 37B''' Retrieved on Sept. 30, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 37B''' Retrieved on Sept. 30, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 37B''' Retrieved on Sept. 30, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 37''' Retrieved on Sept. 30, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''Jheanelle K. Wilkins''' (born May 29, 1988) is an American politician who has represented  in the  since 2017. A member of the , she has served as the Chair of the  since 2022.\n\n\nWilkins was born in Kingston, , and moved to the United States with her family when she was five. She grew up in , where she graduated from  and later attended the , where she earned a  degree in sociology in 2009; and , where she earned a Master of Public Administration in social policy in 2011.\n\n\n\nWilkins started as an intern at the  in 2008 and has served in various roles, including field assistant, field associate, and field manager. She now serves as the group's Director of State and Local Government Affairs. During her tenure at The Leadership Conference, she has worked to advance immigration reform, education equity, and civil rights legislation, including the Justice Reinvestment Act, which eliminated mandatory minimum sentences for nonviolent offenders in Maryland.\n\nShe served on the board of the Montgomery County Association of Black Democrats and was active with the Montgomery County Young Democrats. In 2014, she was elected to the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee.\n\n\n\nIn December 2016, after state delegate  was appointed to the  following 's election to the  in , Wilkins applied to fill the vacancy left by Smith in the Maryland House of Delegates. The Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee voted 19–9 to nominate Wilkins to the Maryland House of Delegates on January 10, 2017. She was appointed to the seat by Governor  on January 24, and was sworn in the following day. She is the first African-American woman to represent this district, and became the first Black woman elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in county history alongside  and  after winning election to a full term in , during which she ran on a slate with Smith, state delegate , and .\n\nIn 2020, Wilkins ran for convention delegate to the  in Maryland's 8th congressional district, pledged to U.S. Senator . She was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\nIn December 2022, Wilkins was elected as the chair of the , succeeding .\n\n\n* Vice-Chair, Ways and Means Committee, 2023–present (member, 2017–present; education subcommittee, 2017–2020; finance resources subcommittee, 2017–2019; revenues subcommittee, 2019–2020; early childhood subcommittee, 2021–present; chair, election law subcommittee, 2021–present)\n* Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 2023–present\n* Opioid Work Group, 2018\n* Parliamentarian, 2020–2023\n\n\n\nIn August 2018, Wilkins participated in a protest in  following the killing of Robert White, who was shot multiple times during an encounter with the Montgomery County police, where she called for reforms to the criminal justice system. In May 2019, she participated in another demonstration after the  released body camera recordings showing a white officer using the  during a loitering investigation.\n\nIn August 2020, Wilkins called on Governor Larry Hogan to fire Arthur \"Mac\" Love IV, the deputy director of the Governor's Office of Community Initiatives, after he posted memes on Facebook showing support for , who  two protesters during the . Love was fired on August 29. In April 2021, after Derek Chauvin was sentenced in the , Wilkins released a statement calling for an end to police violence. In February 2023, following the , she released a statement expressing outrage with Nichols' \"heartless\" killing.\n\n\nIn October 2012, Wilkins attended a rally at the  in support of the  in '''', which held that colleges have some discretion to consider race when making admissions decisions.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Wilkins introduced legislation to expand discrimination prohibitions that apply to private schools.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Wilkins introduced the \"Counselors not Cops Act\", which would redirect state funding for s toward mental health services in schools, and the Police Qualified Immunity and Accountability Act, which would abolish  for police officers.\n\nIn December 2022, administrators of Maryland's  discovered a calculation error affecting all 31,000 prepaid accounts, which led to the Maryland Prepaid College Trust suspending interest payments and preventing families from accessing their prepaid plans. During the 2023 legislative session, Wilkins said she would support legislation to increase transparency in the agency.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Wilkins introduced legislation that would prohibit landlords from evicting tenants without providing a \"\". The bill was rejected by the House Environment and Transportation Committee, and was reintroduced in 2021 and 2022.\n\nDuring the , Wilkins led a letter to Governor  calling on him to cancel rent and mortgage payments for residents and businesses affected by the pandemic. During the 2021 legislative session, she introduced legislation to prevent landlords from raising rent or issuing charges during public health crises.\n\nIn 2023, Wilkins introduced legislation to allocate $15 million toward rental assistance vouchers.\n\n\nIn January 2016, Wilkins said she would support the legalization of , but said she wanted the state's marijuana industry to reflect the state's diverse population. During the 2023 legislative session, Wilkins said she supported equity provisions in House Bill 556, which established the framework for the state's marijuana industry following the passage of , calling them an \"important starting point\".\n\n\nIn January 2019, Wilkins was one of nine Maryland lawmakers to add their names to a manifesto signed by 326 state legislators to reaffirm their commitment to protecting abortion rights. In 2022, Wilkins said she opposed the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling in '''', which overturned '''', saying that the ruling would disproportionately affect marginalized people.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Wilkins introduced legislation that would require the state to disclose how much it pays prisoners who work while serving prison sentences. The legislation passed and became law.\n\nIn March 2020, Wilkins said she supported the CROWN Act, which would ban discrimination based on hairstyle in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Wilkins opposed bills providing  to corporations and the wealthy, including one that would benefit the . She voted for a bill to provide $8.5 billion in incentives to  to build its  in Maryland, which she initially declined to back until she could see the bill in its final form.\n\nIn 2020, Wilkins introduced legislation to provide tax breaks to small businesses affected by the construction of the .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Wilkins supported legislation to extend the state's  to  taxpayers.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Wilkins introduced legislation that would allow voters to opt into a permanent vote-by-mail list.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Wilkins argued against legislation that would create special elections to fill vacancies in the , saying that she felt that candidates of color would struggle to fundraise in special elections and that the central committee nomination process led to more minority candidates serving in the legislature.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Donald B. Elliott''' (October 18, 1931 – October 7, 2024) was an American politician of the  in the state of . He served from 1986 to 2015 as a member of the Maryland House of Delegates.  He served as the representative of Maryland legislative district 4B, which encompasses Carroll and Frederick Counties in Western Maryland.  Delegate Elliott was known for his dedication to health care issues, particularly the crisis in Maryland regarding uncompensated care, and worked in later years to address the issue of removing citizens from the uninsured rolls through various measures.\n\n\nElliott was first elected to the  in 1986 to represent District 4B, which covers  and .  He originally defeated Republican incumbent Delegate Lanny V. Harchenhorn, and defeated Democrat Robert George Fehle Sr. in the general election. He sat on the House Health & Government Operations Committee as the ranking minority member, and also on two subcommittees; the House Insurance Subcommittee and the House Health Facilities & Occupations Subcommittee.\n\n\nElliott attended  in .  He graduated from the  School of Pharmacy in 1957. He later attended , to continue his study of pharmaceutical chemistry.\n\n\nElliott served in the  and remained in the  until 1971, retiring at the rank of Lt. Commander.\n\nDelegate Elliott has worked as a pharmacist in several capacities, including owning & operating two pharmacies in Carroll County, and remained a registered pharmacist.\n\nDuring his time in the legislature, Elliott had concentrated his efforts on the Health & Government Operations Committee towards reforming Maryland's health insurance market.\n\nDelegate Elliott introduced legislation in the 2008 session centering on personal responsibility with regards to health insurance. This legislation encompassed one piece of the noted .  The personal responsibility concept has been endorsed by former  Governor , and also former U.S. Speaker of the House .\n\nDuring the 2010 session of the , he attempted to eliminate the requirement to have all vehicles in Maryland have front license plates.  The Maryland Department of Legislative Services estimated this would have saved the state over $500,000 the first year alone, with savings of over $750,000 in subsequent years.\n\nElliott officially retired from politics and the Maryland Legislature in January 2015.\n\n\n*voted against the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359) \n*voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750) \n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n\n\n\nElliott died in , on October 7, 2024, at the age of 92.\n\n\n*'''2006 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 4B''' Retrieved on Sept, 8 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 4B''' Retrieved on Sept 8, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 4B''' Retrieved on Sept 8, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 4B''' Retrieved on Sept 8, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 4B''' Retrieved on Sept 8, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''1986 election for Maryland House of Delegates – District 4B'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa12218.html\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Marlon D. Amprey''' (born January 24, 1987) is an American politician who has served as member of the  representing  since 2021.\n\n\nAmprey was born on January 24, 1987, in . His grandparents came to Baltimore during the . His uncle, Walter Amprey, served as the superintendent of  from 1991 to 1997.\n\nAmprey graduated from  in 2009 with a  in American government and politics; , where he earned a  in elementary education and curriculum; and  with a  degree in 2016. In the same year, Amprey earned a certificate in business management from the .\n\n\nAmprey was a teacher for Howard Road Academy Public Charter School, a school in , and was a member of  from 2009 to 2011. From 2011 to 2013, he was a sixth grade teacher at . While attending law school, Amprey interned for U.S. Representative . He has served as the director of Patterson Park Public Charter School and Code in the Schools since 2016.\n\nAmprey then worked as a corporate associate at  from 2016 to 2019, afterwards working as an associate of  until 2020. He worked as an associate at Cole Scholtz P.C. from 2020 to 2021, at McKennon Shelton & Henn from 2021 to 2022, and at Rosenberg Martin Greenberg LLP since 2022.\n\nAmprey served on the transition team of Baltimore mayor-elect .\n\n\n\nIn December 2020, after state Delegate  resigned following his election as president of the , Amprey applied to serve the remainder of Mosby's term in the Maryland House of Delegates. His candidacy was backed by state Senator  and Baltimore mayor-elect Brandon Scott. The Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee voted 4-3 to nominate Amprey to the seat on December 30, and Governor  appointed him to the seat on January 6, 2021. He was sworn in on January 13, 2021. Amprey was elected to a full four-year term in .\n\nAmprey served as a member of the Environment and Transportation Committee from 2021 to 2022, and has served in the Economic Matters Committee and as a deputy majority whip since 2023.\n\n\nAmprey is married to his wife, Normandi, whom he met while teaching. Together, they have a daughter.\n\n\n\nAmprey supports the .\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Amprey introduced a bill to review expanding the staffing and operations of the .\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Amprey introduced legislation to establish the West North Avenue Development Authority to oversee and support community revitalization efforts. The bill passed and became law. He also supported a bill to provide relief to assist homeowners with making mortgage payments amid the .\n\nIn 2022, Amprey introduced a bill to impose a 90-day pause on home purchases made by large investors in Maryland. The bill died in committee.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Amprey introduced legislation to prohibit exclusive listing agreements from lasting more than a year, which passed and became law.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Amprey introduced legislation that would require private security guards to be licensed by the state, and establish minimum training standards for security agencies. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Aisha Nazapa Braveboy''' (born July 29, 1974) is an American politician and attorney who has served as the  of  since 2018. She was previously a member of the , representing the  from 2007 to 2015.\n\n\nBraveboy was born in , to father Cuthbert and mother Norma Braveboy, who migrated to the United States from . She graduated from  and later attended the , where she earned a bachelor of art degree in government and politics in 1997. Afterwards, Braveboy earned her  degree from the  in 2000.\n\nAfter graduating, Braveboy became an associate with  law firm Gabriel J. Christian & Associates. From 2000 to 2002, she worked as an attorney for the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau of the .\n\n\nBraveboy first got involved in politics in 2002, when she worked on the county executive campaign of . From 2003 to 2005, she worked as an advisor to Prince George's County officials. Afterwards, Braveboy worked in the Office of Central Services, where she managed properties owned or leased by the county.\n\nIn 2003, Braveboy started the Community Public Awareness Council nonprofit, which sought to provide mental health services and workshops to first-time juvenile offenders and their families to reduce .\n\nIn 2006, Braveboy ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 25, seeking to succeed state delegate , who ran for .\n\n\nBraveboy was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 10, 2007. During her tenure, she supported legislation to reduce  and , and to protect homeowners from deceptive lenders.\n\n\nFrom 2012 to 2014, Braveboy served as the chair of the . In this position, she advocated for increased funding for  and opposed legislation setting .\n\n\n\n* Member, Economic Matters Committee, 2007–2015 (alcoholic beverages subcommittee, 2007–2010; business regulation subcommittee, 2007–2015; banking, economic development, science & technology subcommittee, 2011–2015; chair, consumer protection & commercial law subcommittee, 2011–2015, member, 2007–2015)\n* Member, Law Enforcement and State-Appointed Boards Committee, Prince George's County Delegation, 2013–2015 (bi-county committee, 2007–2008; chair, Washington suburban sanitary commission committee, 2008–2010; chair, Maryland-national capital park & planning commission committee, 2011, member, 2012)\n\n\n\n\nOn September 19, 2013, Braveboy filed to run for . Her platform included supporting the state's , opposing the , and fighting against large polluters.\n\nDuring the Democratic primary, her campaign received endorsements from various labor unions, including the Washington D.C. Building and Construction Trades Council and  Local 1619.\n\nBraveboy was defeated by state senator  in the Democratic primary on June 24, 2014, placing last with 20.1 percent of the vote. If elected, she would have been Maryland's first African American attorney general. Following her defeat, Braveboy worked as a lobbyist for the  and the Innovations Group LLC until 2018.\n\n\n\n\nOn November 9, 2017, Braveboy announced her candidacy for state's attorney of Prince George's County. She ran on a progressive platform that included prosecuting domestic violence, expanding county diversion programs, and prosecuting repeat violent offenders. Braveboy led the Democratic primary in endorsements, which included the Prince George's County , correctional officers union, and various labor unions. She won the Democratic primary on June 26, 2018, receiving 62.8 percent of the vote, and ran unopposed in the general election.\n\nBraveboy ran for reelection unopposed in 2022.\n\n\n, 2024]]\nBraveboy was sworn in as state's attorney on January 7, 2019. Upon being sworn in, she named juvenile justice reform and crackdowns on illegal guns as her top priorities while in office.\n\nIn 2019, Braveboy created the state's first conviction and sentencing integrity unit to weigh new consideration for county convictions and sentencings, which led to the release of seven people sentenced to life as juveniles. Later that year, she announced that the county would no longer recommend  as a condition of release, instead requesting alternatives including counseling, drug testing, and mental health evaluations.\n\nIn March 2020, after Prince George's County recorded its first case of , Braveboy sought the release of 150 pretrial defendants to reduce the spread of the virus.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Braveboy supported legislation to make strangulation a first-degree felony assault and another bill to allow prosecutors to pursue hate crime charges for acts \"motivated in part\" by hate. In October 2020, she launched an initiative to support victims of domestic violence and strangulation.\n\nIn May 2021, following a national spike in s, Braveboy launched a task force to increase awareness and prevention of carjackings in Prince George's County, which collaborated with community organizers to host community-focused events and broadcast commercials targeting young people. She also worked with U.S. Attorney  to prosecute carjackings.\n\nIn August 2021, Braveboy endorsed efforts encouraging the  to create a task form to reform the justice system to be less punitive and more equitable.\n\nIn November 2024, after county executive  won the , Braveboy said that she would run to succeed Alsobrooks as county executive.\n\n\n\nIn 2013, Braveboy introduced a bill to remove the check box that asks if applicants have a criminal record from  for state jobs. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor . She also voted in favor of legislation to repeal the death penalty, which passed the House of Delegates by a 82–56 vote.\n\nIn June 2020, after the  released a 92-page partially redacted report detailing discriminatory actions taken by the  that prompted the resignation of Chief Hank Stawinski, Braveboy called for increased police transparency and sought greater access to police officer records.\n\nIn September 2020, Braveboy said she opposed ceding the ability to prosecute police officers to an independent body, and lobbied against efforts to pass a bill doing so during the 2021 legislative session. In 2021, she testified in support of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, a police transparency and accountability reform package. In October 2021, she released the county's \"do-not-call\" list of 57 officers with credibility issues.\n\nIn 2021, Braveboy said she supported legislation to end  for juveniles.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Braveboy said she supported legislation to establish a \"safe harbor\" to protect minors who are victims of trafficking.\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Braveboy supported legislation to extend probationary periods for gun crimes committed by juveniles, limit the Child Interrogation Protection Act, and allow state's attorneys to file a motion to modify an incarcerated individual's sentence \"at any time\".\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Braveboy introduced legislation to require students to stay in school until they turn 18 years old, which passed and was signed into law by Governor Martin O'Malley. She also opposed shifting the state's $239 million teacher pension system to counties.\n\n\nIn 2012 and 2013, Braveboy opposed bills to levy a five cent tax on disposable bags.\n\n\nIn April 2013, Braveboy voted for the Firearm Safety Act of 2013, a gun control reform package.\n\nIn May 2021, Braveboy launched the \"Our Streets, Our Future\" campaign to promote gun violence prevention efforts in Prince George's County through community engagement, employment services, and social media advertisements targeted toward young people.\n\nIn 2022, Braveboy said she supported a bill to ban s in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2014 legislative session, Braveboy testified in support of a bill that would ban s and place a six-month moratorium on s.\n\n\nIn 2013, Braveboy introduced legislation to raise the state minimum wage to $10.10 per hour by 2015. In 2014, she voted for a bill to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour by 2017.\n\n\nDuring the , Braveboy supported efforts to create a third minority-majority congressional district. She later voted against the state's redistricting plan, which she said \"dilutes minority votes by breaking them up into several districts\".\n\nIn 2014, Braveboy said she supported the , which would require states to use s to draw federal and state districts.\n\n\n rally, 2024]]\nIn 2008, Braveboy voted against bills that would give domestic partners hospital visitation and medical decision-making rights in emergency situations. In 2011, during debate on the , which she voted against, Braveboy introduced an amendment that would block the bill from going into effect unless it was approved in a statewide referendum. Her amendment was criticized by supporters of same-sex marriage rights as a delay tactic, but she later defended her amendment as a way to gauge public opinion. In 2014, Braveboy voted for legislation to ban discrimination against  individuals.\n\nIn 2011, Braveboy abstained from voting on a bill to prohibit Prince George's County officials from taking contributions from developers with development proposals in the county, saying that she would prefer a statewide ban on such contributions.\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Braveboy introduced a bill to repeal a law that gave presiding religious denominations the legal authority to seize properties of local congregations.\n\nIn November 2012, Braveboy spoke against , a ballot referendum that sought to repeal , a bill that would extend  for .\n\nIn 2014, Braveboy said she supported a bill to decriminalize simple marijuana possession in Maryland.\n\nIn July 2022, following the 's ruling in '''', which repealed '''', Braveboy said she would not cooperate with extradition requests for individuals who travel across state lines to get an abortion.\n\n\nIn 2013, Braveboy voted against a bill to index the state's gas tax to  to fund the state's transportation budget.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
