    "pages": }\n'''William Claiborne Ferguson IV''' (born April 15, 1983) is an American politician, attorney, and former schoolteacher. He is a  member of the , representing the  since 2011, and serving as the  since January 8, 2020. The district is composed of parts of .\n\n\nFerguson was born in  and graduated from  and  with a double major in political science and economics in 2005. He then joined , teaching history and government to ninth and tenth graders at  in Baltimore for two years. In 2007, he earned a  degree from the . Since 2012, Ferguson has served as the director of reform initiatives at the Johns Hopkins School of Education.\n\nFerguson served as a community liaison on educational issues for , the president of the , from 2005 to 2006. From 2009 to 2010, he was a special assistant to , the chief executive officer of . He graduated '''' from the  with a  in 2010.\n\n\nIn 2010, Ferguson challenged six-term incumbent  for the Democratic nomination for the 46th district in the Maryland Senate. He won the primary election by a margin of 59-41%. Running in a heavily Democratic district, he won the general election with no formal opposition, receiving 98% of the vote. He is the youngest state senator ever elected in Maryland. His youth earned him the nickname of \"Baby Senator\".\n\nOn October 24, 2019, Senate Democrats unanimously voted to nominate Ferguson to succeed Senate President . Ferguson was perceived as more progressive than Miller. He was sworn in as Senate President on January 8, 2020.\n\nIn June 2024, Ferguson joined CI Renewables, a Baltimore-based solar energy firm, as the company's general counsel.\n\nFerguson was an at-large delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\n\nFerguson is married to Lea (née Smith), who he proposed to during the  in 2009. Together, they live in  and have two children. He attends religious services at the St. Casimir Catholic Church in southeast Baltimore. Ferguson is a member of the .\n\n\n\nFerguson supports the  recommendations, also known as the , and served on the Commission on Innovation and Excellence in Education before becoming President of the Maryland Senate.\n\nFerguson opposed legislation introduced during the 2015 legislative session that would have armed s while they patrolled schools, calling it a \"counterproductive strategy\" and saying that counseling and other services would be more useful in enhancing school safety.\n\nIn 2018, Ferguson blamed Governor  after Baltimore schools closed early amid facilities problems, saying that the governor did not provide adequate funding for public schools.\n\n\nIn 2019, Ferguson voted in favor of an amendment to make the  ineligible to receive renewable energy subsidies, which passed in a 34-12 vote.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Ferguson voted for the Firearm Safety Act, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s. In November 2023, he criticized a  ruling that struck down a provision of the state's Firearm Safety Act that required handgun owners to obtain a \"handgun qualification license\" to buy a handgun.\n\n\nFerguson supports the legalization of , saying he'd support legalizing it by passing a law during the General Assembly session. In 2021, he co-sponsored legislation to legalize marijuana. In 2022, Ferguson said that a voter referendum to legalize marijuana \"wouldn't be his first choice\", but stressed that it would be unfair to put the question before the voters without letting them know the details of the state's marijuana program.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Ferguson introduced legislation that would establish a Commission to Restore Trust in Policing to investigate the 's Gun Trace Task Force, whose members' abuse of power over several years resulted in  of eight of the unit's nine officers on  charges related to a robbery and extortion scheme. The bill passed both chambers unanimously and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on May 15, 2018. The Commission published its final report on December 2, 2020. In February 2021, Ferguson said that he would support repealing and replacing the state's .\n\nIn March 2021, Ferguson said that he would support giving  full local control of its police department, supporting a bill to include a city charter amendment to do so on the ballots of Baltimore voters as soon as 2022. The bill passed both chambers and became law on May 8, 2021.\n\nIn October 2021, Ferguson spoke out against Governor Hogan's proposal to increase funding for local law enforcement, saying in a statement that \"divisive rhetoric does not make us safer\" and that \"improving public safety isn't about just writing a bigger check\", but said that lawmakers \"support investments that enhance trust and safety\".\n\n\n rally, 2024]]\nFerguson was a co-sponsor of the , which legalized .\n\nIn June 2021, Ferguson spoke out against Governor Hogan's decision to opt out of federal unemployment insurance programs provided under the , writing a letter to the governor urging him to rethink the decision.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Ferguson introduced legislation that would require companies on  to close at 10 p.m. nightly. Following a compromise made between city politicians and venues on The Block, the bill was amended to require clubs to hire off-duty Baltimore police officers to patrol the nightlife district three nights a week and implement new security rules. The bill unanimously passed both chambers and became law on April 9, 2022.\n\nIn October 2023, Ferguson said he supported reforms to the process for filling vacancies in the . He also endorsed , but conceded that it was unlikely to pass the legislature anytime soon.\n\n\nIn 2020, Ferguson stated that he would be opposed to an across-the-board increase in taxes to pay for the , a sweeping education reform bill. During that year's legislative session, he introduced legislation that would levy a tax on  to pay for the Commission's reforms, which passed but was vetoed by Governor Hogan on May 7, 2020. The General Assembly voted to override the governor's veto on February 12, 2021.\n\nIn May 2022, Ferguson rejected calls for an extension to Maryland's fuel , claiming it would have \"long-term consequences\" for critical infrastructure in the state.\n\n\nIn 2013, Ferguson called for a \"rethink\" of the , backing a proposal by the Right Rail Coalition to replace the eastern leg of the Red Line with a .\n\nIn 2015, Ferguson sponsored legislation that would regulate and tax  in Maryland, but also allow such companies to operate under less regulations than traditional taxi companies. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 14, 2015.\n\nFollowing the  in March 2024, Ferguson introduced an emergency bill to provide income replacement for workers impacted by the disaster.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jamila Jaye Woods''' (born July 9, 1963) is an American pastor and politician who is a member of the  for  in .\n\n\nWoods was born in . She graduated from , earning a  degree in political science in 1990 and a  degree in 1999.     "pages": }\n'''Cory V. McCray''' (born October 31, 1982) is an  who serves as a member of the  for , located in . Previously, McCray served as a member of the  and acting Chair of the .\n\n\nMcCray was born in  and attended .\n, 2012]]\nShortly after McCray's 18th birthday, he signed up for an apprenticeship program with the , where he later served as an organizer. The program gave him enough money to start investing in real estate, purchasing his first house at 20. By age 25, he owned seven houses.\n\nIn 2011, McCray received an  in business management from the  and a Bachelor of Arts degree from the  in 2013. From 2011 to 2013, he served on the Baltimore City Board of Elections.\n\nIn 2012, McCray and other community leaders formed the B.E.S.T. Democratic Club, which encouraged young people in east Baltimore to get involved in politics. By 2014, the group had more than 500 members.\n\nIn May 2013, McCray announced his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates, seeking to succeed delegate , who was appointed to the House following the death of . He prevailed in the Democratic primary, receiving 19.5 percent of the vote and coming third in a field of eight candidates. He received 27.6 percent of the vote in the general election.\n\nMcCray is considered a political ally of . During his 2014 House run, he worked closely with Scott when he was a city councilmember to provide constituent services to residents he encountered while . McCray was also a member of his mayoral transition team in 2020.\n\n\nAfter being sworn in on January 14, 2015, McCray was appointed to the House Environment and Transportation Committee. He is also a member of the  and the .\n\nIn March 2017, Nicole Hanson, executive director of Out for Justice, filed an ethics complaint was filed against McCray, saying that she felt \"physically and psychologically\" threatened by McCray after he lost his temper during a conversation about the roots of poverty, causing him to throw a chair against a wall and begin using expletives. McCray denied throwing a chair, but acknowledged that his language and volume were unacceptable. He did not apologize to Hanson until he ran into her at a community event several weeks later. In April, the General Assembly's ethics committee found that McCray \"breached the standards of conduct expected of a member.\"\n\nIn July 2017, McCray publicly expressed interest in challenging Senate President Pro Tempore  in the 2018 primary election, saying that he was \"about 90 percent sure he will challenge his senator.\" He announced his candidacy for the  in September. McCray defeated McFadden in the Democratic primary election, receiving 58.5 percent of the vote to McFadden's 41.5 percent. He faced no Republican challengers in the general election.\n\n\nMcCray was sworn into the Maryland Senate on January 9, 2019. He was appointed to the Budget and Taxation Committee, the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee, the Special Committee on Pensions, the Joint Audit Committee, and the Spending Affordability Committee, and is a member of the Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, the Legislative Black Caucus of Maryland. He was also an associate member of the Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus from 2019 to 2020. In November 2020, He was elected chair of the Baltimore City Senate Delegation.\n\nIn October 2019, following the death of Representative , McCray said that he would give \"serious consideration\" to running in the  in  to fill the rest of his term. He later said that he would not run for the seat.\n\n\n\nMcCray was sworn in as the acting chair of the  on November 11, 2019, following the resignation of , who announced her candidacy for the special election in Maryland's 7th congressional district. He opted out of running in the election for the party's new chair. During his short tenure, he alleged that the organization was overspending without strong financial controls under Cummings' leadership. To right the organization's fiscal health, he cancelled contracts with consults and recommended other fiscal controls to the Maryland State Central Committee. On December 7, 2019, the Maryland Democratic Party elected  to serve as party chairwoman again through December 2022.\n\n\n\nIn March 2021, McCray joined five other senators in delivering a letter to Governor  that expressed \"grave concerns\" over equity of the state's vaccination program rollout.\n\n\nMcCray was one of four senators to vote against legislation introduced in the 2020 legislative session that would provide tougher penalties for gun offenders.\n\nMcCray introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would require the  to notify city police whenever someone is released on bail.\n\n\nMcCray introduced legislation during the 2019 legislative session that would expand food stamp benefits through the summer months to students who rely on free meals from their schools. The bill passed and became law without Governor Hogan's signature.\n\n\nMcCray introduced legislation in the 2015 legislative session that would restore . The bill passed, but was vetoed by Governor Hogan; the Maryland General Assembly voted to override the veto on February 9, 2016.\n\nMcCray introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would require the Baltimore police to redraw district boundaries after each census. The bill passed and went into effect on October 1, 2019.\n\nIn September 2020, McCray sent a letter to Baltimore City elections director Armstead Jones to ask for more dropoff ballot boxes to be placed in his district, saying that his district had fewer boxes compared to others and calling the placement of boxes within Baltimore \"unconscionable\".\n\n\nIn September 2019, McCray voted against a climate debate resolution at the , arguing that his constituents needed him to advocate for greater movement on issues like justice reform, police brutality, and economic opportunity.\n\nMcCray introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would reform the Maryland Environmental Service to restrict future payouts, restructure the board and add new requirements, such as ethics training.\n\n\nMcCray introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would raise the minimum wage to  by 2023. The bill passed with a full-on effective date of 2025, but was vetoed by Governor  on March 27, 2019. The Maryland General Assembly voted to override Hogan's veto on the bill the next day.\n\n\nMcCray voted in favor of legislation introduced in the 2019 legislative session that would create an armed police force at the private . He also introduced legislation that would require Baltimore police leaders to live in the city.\n\nMcCray introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would make the  a city agency instead of a state agency. The bill did not receive a vote over reservations from other city senators. He introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would create a commission to study local control of the city police and allow voters to determine if the city government should regain control of the police department via a charter amendment during the  or  general election. The bill passed and became law.\n\n\nMcCray introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would increase the tax on cigarettes and other tobacco products.\n\n\nIn 2021, McCray joined local officials in advocating for more funding to meet the 's maintenance and other needs. He introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would increase funding to the Maryland Transit Administration to make the state's bus system, ,  and  more safe and reliable. The bill passed the  but was vetoed by Governor Hogan on May 28, 2021. The legislature voted to override Hogan's veto during the 2021 special legislative session.\n\nMcCray introduced legislation during the 2022 legislative session that would waive late fees and give Maryland residents the ability to set up payment plans for delayed  charges.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\nActing|years=2019}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Emily Khoury Shetty''' (born January 11, 1984) is an American politician and attorney who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2019.\n\n\nShetty was born in , on January 11, 1984. Her mother immigrated to the United States from  and raised Shetty and her sister as a . She was raised in , where she worked at her local library when she was nine years old and later volunteered with . Shetty earned her  degree from  in 2005, attended the , and earned her J.D. degree from the  in 2008. She was admitted to the  in 2009.\n\n\nAfter graduating from Catholic University, Shetty worked for U.S. Representative  until 2012, first as a legislative assistant and then as his legislative director. From 2012 to 2014, she worked as the senior director of legislative affairs with the , afterwards working as a consultant for lobbyist groups Stanton Park Group and Horizon Government Affairs. In 2020, she started her own lobbying firm, Step Up Advocacy.\n\nFrom 2013 to 2014, and again from 2015 to 2018, Shetty was a member of the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee. In 2014, she unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 18, receiving 11 percent of the vote behind incumbents , , and . Shetty ran again in 2018 after Waldstreicher announced he would run for the , winning the Democratic primary with 19.7 percent of the vote and defeating Republican challenger Linda Willard in the general election with 30 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nShetty was sworn into the House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She was a member of the Judiciary Committee from 2019 to 2022, afterwards serving in the Appropriations Committee. Since 2023, Shetty has served as the chair of the House Democratic Caucus.\n\nDuring the , Shetty ran as a delegate to the , not pledged to any candidate.\n\n\nShetty is married to her husband, Ash Shetty. Together, they live in , and have one child. She has a chronic autoimmune disorder.\n\n\n\nDuring her 2014 House of Delegates campaign, Shetty said she supported increasing state investments in .\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Shetty introduced legislation that would allow pharmacists to switch name brands. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn 2022, Shetty introduced a bill that would allow organ donors to decide whether their organs would be donated to research or a surgical transplant. The bill unanimously passed the Maryland General Assembly and became law.\n\n\nShetty supports indexing the state minimum wage to inflation.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Shetty introduced the Law Enforcement Trust and Transparency Act, which would establish statewide standards for officer-involved death investigations.\n\nIn 2021, Shetty introduced a bill to limit how police could use  and their databases. The bill passed and became law without Governor 's signature.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Shetty introduced legislation that would allow  people to change their names without having to advertise it in a newspaper. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn 2022, Shetty supported legislation to raise the state's minimum marriage age to 17 years old. She also supported the Abortion Care Access Act, which provided $3.5 million toward clinical reproductive services training for health care professionals.\n\n\nShetty supports the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Adrian A. Boafo''' (born May 10, 1994) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for District 23 in . He previously served as the  and District 3 council member for the  from 2019 to 2022.\n\n\nBoafo was born in  on May 10, 1994. His parents were immigrants from  who migrated to the United States after the country's democratic political systems collapsed.\n\nBoafo graduated from  in 2012. He later attended the , where he received a  degree in government and public policy in 2016, and , where he received a  degree in 2019. After graduating, Boafo worked as a national press assistant for U.S. Representative . He later served as the campaign manager for   from 2018 to 2021.\n\n\n\n\nBoafo filed to run for District 3 of the Bowie city council on May 8, 2019, challenging incumbent council member Darian Senn-Carter. Boafo won election to the Bowie city council on November 6, 2019, with 34.8 percent of the vote. Soon after, the council selected him to serve as the city's youngest mayor pro tempore, succeeding at-large council member Henri Gardner. While working for the Bowie city council, Boafo also worked as a federal lobbyist for the .\n\n\n\n\nIn May 2020, Boafo voted to stop construction and cancel the city's contract to build a new ice rink, instead opting to build an indoor courts facility. In July 2020, Boafo voted against cancel public-private partnership proposals to repair and operate Bowie's city-operated ice rink. After the city council voted to reject the proposals, it created a task force for the amenity. The task force unveiled its recommendations on January 19, 2021.\n\nIn January 2021, Boafo voted against a bill to support a preliminary plan for the Bowie's Mill Branch Crossing development.\n\nIn June 2021, Boafo introduced a bill to provide city residents with a rebate of up to $50 to install a new water filtration system. The City Council unanimously voted to pass the initiative. Later that month, the ' Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Subcommittee approved a $2 million request from the city to replace one mile of a tuberculated cast iron water main.\n\n\nIn 2019, Boafo included a budget line item in the city's budget to reimburse Bowie residents for installing outdoor cameras. In November 2020, Boafo and the Bowie Police Department launched a program to provide rebates up to $50 for residents who purchase and install a home security camera.\n\nIn June 2020, Boafo attended a vigil to honor , , and  at Allen Pond Park in Bowie.\n\n\nIn 2022, Boafo issued a statement asking for a correction from Bowie mayor Tim Adams after he included Boafo on his list of endorsements in the , saying that despite having a \"great working relationship with Mayor Adams, there was no communication or confirmation in advance of the endorsement.\" Boafo later endorsed state delegate  for . He also endorsed author and former nonprofit CEO  for .\n\n\n\nBoafo announced he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 23 on February 25, 2022. His campaign was endorsed by House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer. He won the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, placing second with 14.4 percent of the vote. Boafo was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\nIn September 2024, Boafo established his own federal , GenBlue PAC, to endorse progressive candidates running for Congress.\n\n\n* Economic Matters Committee, 2023–present\n* Business Regulation Subcommittee of the Economic Matters Committee, 2023–present\n* Workers' Compensation Subcommittee of the Economic Matters Committee, 2023–present\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Mark Soo Chang''' (born July 9, 1976) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2015. A member of the , he unsuccessfully ran in the  in , losing to state senator  in the Democratic primary.\n\n\nChang was born on July 9, 1976, in . He was one of three children born to Hak Jin Chang, who was a small business owner during the 1980s and 1990s, and his wife, who worked at Annapolis General Hospital and who died when Chang was eleven years old. He is a first-generation , with his parents having moved to the United States from  in 1975.\n\nChang graduated from  and later attended the , where he earned a  degree in psychology and graduated cum laude in 1999. In 2010, Chang attended , where he earned a  degree.\n\n\nChang entered politics in 2003 by becoming a member of the  Republican Central Committee. In 2006, he ran for the Maryland House of Delegates as a  and was defeated in the general election with 17.1 percent of the vote. After his defeat, Chang went to work as a community liaison for Anne Arundel County Executive . In 2012, he switched his party affiliation from Republican to . Chang was replaced by County Executive Laura Neuman after she took office following Leopold's corruption conviction and subsequent resignation, and he subsequently worked as a legislative aide to state senator \n\nIn 2014, Chang again ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 32, this time as a Democrat. He won the general election in November 2014, becoming the first Korean-American elected to the  from Anne Arundel County, and the first in the state alongside state delegate-elect .\n\n\n\nChang was sworn into the House of Delegates on January 14, 2015. He has been a member of the Appropriations Committee during his entire tenure, and became the committee's vice chair in 2021.\n\nOn December 5, 2023, Chang announced that he would  in , seeking to succeed retiring U.S. Representative . The bill was reintroduced in 2020, during which it passed and became law.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James Matthew Morgan''' (born February 5, 1973) is an American politician who has served as a  member of the  representing , which includes the Northwestern portion of , since 2015.\n\n\nMorgan was born on February 5, 1973, in . He graduated from  in nearby .\n\n\nMorgan was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 14, 2015, and has served as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee during his entire tenure. From 2019 to 2021, he served as the Assistant Minority Leader of the House of Delegates. Morgan is also a member of the Maryland Freedom Caucus.\n\nIn 2021, Morgan ran for Minority Leader of the House of Delegates on a ticket with Delegate . The Adams-Morgan ticket was defeated by  and  by a \"more than a 2–1 margin\".\n\n\n\nIn April 2023, Morgan sent a letter to State Superintendent Mohammed Choudhury accusing the  of hiding scores from failing scores by altering data files available on the department's website. An investigation conducted by the state inspector general found no evidence of these claims.\n\n\nIn 2015, Morgan joined  in filing a lawsuit challenging the .\n\nMorgan opposed a 2021 bill that would require elections for county commissioners to only be decided by voters within the districts in which the candidate is running. During debate on the legislation, he introduced an amendment that would impose the same rules on school board districts, which was rejected by a 45–93 vote. The bill later passed the House of Delegates by a vote of 95-39.\n\nMorgan opposed legislation introduced during the 2021 legislative session that would send a  to every registered voter in both the state's primary and general elections.\n\nIn April 2021, Morgan proposed an amendment that would make top law enforcement officers in each jurisdiction elected by local members of the public.\n\n\nFollowing a , located within Morgan's district, Morgan responded with pessimism that proposed  legislation would be effective in preventing future shootings, saying \"I don't know if there is a policy fix.\" During the 2019 legislative session, Morgan introduced legislation to give local school systems the ability to station s at every school within its jurisdiction.\n\n\nMorgan opposed a 2019 bill to create a Prescription Drug Affordability Board to negotiate the prices of s, expressing concern that the board would lead to shortages of life-saving medications.\n\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Morgan opposed bills to give tenants the right of first refusal if the property owner of their residence seeks to sell the property and another that would put rent payments in escrow if a landlord neglects life-threatening defects in a tenant's residence, saying that legislators should instead focus on passing bills to crack down on \"slum tenants\" instead of s.\n\n\nMorgan supported  in the . He criticized 's decision to join , saying \"It definitely conflicts with where the party is as a whole.\"\n\nIn May 2024, Morgan signed onto a letter condemning the jury's guilty verdict in the , calling the ruling a \"political prosecution from a kangaroo court and left-leaning prosecutor\" that is turning the U.S. justice system into a \"third world parody of law and order\".\n\n\nIn March 2018, Morgan opposed legislation that would have renamed the  after senator .\n\nIn April of the same year, Morgan proposed an amendment to expand  legislation to regulate privacy policies on social media companies; the amendment was rejected over concerns that it did not fit the scope of the bill.\n\nFollowing the  on May 25, 2020, Morgan called Floyd's death \"tragic\" and indefensible\" while accusing Democrats of using the incident as an \"excuse to drive political narrative\" and \"dismantle the police departments\".\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Larry Young''' (born November 25, 1949) is a former member of the  from 1988 to 1998, representing Baltimore's 44th district. He was expelled from the Senate in 1998 over ethics charges, but later acquitted at his own trial.\n\n\nBorn in Baltimore, Maryland, on November 25, 1949, Young attended Baltimore City public schools.\n\n\n\nYoung was a member of the  from 1975 to 1988, representing District 38 (Baltimore City). He was Chair of the Environmental Matters Committee, 1983–87 (member, 1975–83) and Chair of the , 1987–88.\n\nIn June 1988 Young sought to become chairman of The , a position that is determined by a vote of African-Americans serving in the . The caucus elected  over Young when Young was under investigation by a Baltimore grand jury for assault and filing a false kidnapping report.\n\nYoung was a member of the Maryland Senate from 1988 to 1998, representing Baltimore City District 44 (1992–98) and Baltimore City District 39 (1988–92). He served on the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee from 1988 to 1990. From 1990 to 1998 he served on the Senate Finance Committee.\n\n\nThe  Maryland Senate expelled Young on January 16, 1998, for using his position to profit his private business. Young, who sat as chairman of the Health subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee, was also president of a private, for-profit health consulting firm called the LY Group. The ethics committee found that Young used his position and influence to leverage $10,000–99,000 into the LY Group. In addition, the committee found that Young solicited and accepted a number of gifts in violation of the ethics law, including a $24,800 1995 blue . He was later acquitted of criminal bribery charges.\n\n\nYoung has since presented a talk radio show, and played a talk radio show host in the  drama ''''. In an essay in the official series guide, ''The Wire: Truth Be Told'',  implies that the character of the corrupt and venal Maryland State Senator  is patterned on Young.\n\nThe details of Larry Young's false abduction report and the resulting political aftermath is described in David Simon's ''''. In the book, it is implied that Young's false report was an attempted cover up for his own assault against a political aide, in an argument over Young's sexual advances against the aide's fiancé.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "revisions":

    "pages": }\n'''Caylin A. Young''' (born October 18, 1987) is an American politician. He is a member of the  for  in . He previously served as the public policy director of the  of Maryland.\n\n\nYoung graduated from Hampton University with a  in mathematics. He later attended the , where he earned his  degree.\n\nYoung interned for the , served as a legal fellow to U.S. Senator , and was a legislative assistant for former state senator  and former state delegate . He also served as the legislative director for then- president .\n\nIn 2018, Young unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 45, coming in fourth place with 12.1 percent of the vote.\n\nIn December 2019, Young applied to fill a vacancy in the Maryland House of Delegates to serve the rest of the term of state delegate Cheryl Glenn, who resigned and pleaded guilty to federal corruption charges. In January 2020, the Baltimore City Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate  to the seat, with Young placing second behind Branch. After the controversial vote, Young sought legal advice to challenge the results, arguing that succession votes have traditionally required four votes, whereas Branch got three.\n\nIn January 2021, the American Civil Liberties Union of Maryland hired Young to serve as its public policy director. He left the ACLU in December to serve as the deputy director for the Baltimore City Office of Equity and Civil Rights.\n\nIn 2022, Young ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 45, running on a ticket with state senator  and , a community activist. He won the Democratic primary on July 19, narrowly defeating incumbent state delegate Chanel Branch by 116 votes.\n\n\n\nYoung was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 11, 2023. He is a member of the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\nIn January 2024, Young attended and spoke at a rally at the  to support a resolution calling on  to support a ceasefire in the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joel Martin Rubin''' (born April 8, 1971) is an American politician and media commentator on domestic political and Middle East affairs. He served as a member of the  Town Council from 2017 to 2023, and previously worked as a senior  official in the . In 2020, Rubin also directed Jewish outreach for .\n\n\nRubin was born on April 8, 1971, and raised in a  family in . He attended  for his undergraduate education, where he received a  in politics. He went on to study 's , where he received an  in public policy and management with a minor in business administration.\n\n\n\n\nRubin served in the  in . Rubin was the founding Political Director of , a liberal organization dedicated to promoting the two state solution  and secular left wing values; Rubin worked on Capitol Hill as a legislative assistant to s  of Iowa and  of New Jersey, both Democrats.\n\n\nRubin appears as a political commentator on American networks such as  and ; and on international networks such as i24, , and . He also writes political and national security commentary for , , , and .\n\nRubin has also appeared in Jewish magazines for his political work.\n\n\nRubin worked for three U.S. government agencies in the administrations of Presidents  and  – the , , and . In January 2015, when he served in the State Department as the  for House Affairs in the , he was an official government witness and testified to the . Rubin left the U.S. State Department in July 2015.\n\n\nRubin was a founding board member of the , established in 2017 in the wake of the  in . In 2020, he joined  as head of Jewish outreach, and worked as a policy volunteer for the  following the . From 2020 to 2022, Rubin worked as an executive director for the  advocacy group.\n\nRubin was a surrogate for the ; an advocate for the Iran nuclear deal as the Policy Director for ; and as a commentator on the . Following the 2018  at his hometown synagogue, , Joel appeared on Fox News and MSNBC to discuss the attack, later commenting as well on the rise of  in America after the 2019 . Rubin frequently comments on foreign policy and congressional politics for networks such as , , , .\n\n\n\nRubin ran for Congress in  in , in what was the most expensive Congressional primary in American history at the time. He was defeated in the Democratic primary, placing second to last with 1.1 percent of the vote. Rubin was elected to the Chevy Chase Town Council in 2017, and was subsequently re-elected in 2019 and 2021.\n\nIn 2018, Rubin unsuccessfully ran for the  in , seeking to succeed outgoing state delegates  and . He received endorsements from the  and  during his campaign, but was defeated in the Democratic primary, placing fifth with 11.2 percent of the vote. In 2022, Rubin applied to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 18, seeking to replace state delegate  on the ballot after Carr withdrew his candidacy hours before the candidate filing deadline on April 15 to run for the county council, and no candidates were able to file to run in his place before the deadline. The Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee nominated one of its members, , to fill vacancy on April 20, 2022.\n\nOn July 24, 2023, Rubin announced that he would run for Congress in  in , seeking to succeed outgoing U.S. Representative . During the Democratic primary, he ran on a platform that included national and foreign policy issues. Rubin dropped out of the race on March 6, 2024, and endorsed former  deputy administrator .\n\n\nDuring his tenure at the U.S. State Department, Rubin worked to prevent Congress from passing a resolution of disapproval of the  with a veto-proof majority.\n\nDuring his 2016 congressional campaign, Rubin said he supported raising the federal minimum wage to , increasing infrastructure spending, and strengthening  and  by removing the cap on es. He also spoke against the , citing concerns over protections for workers at home and abroad, and said he supported moving funding away from the  and toward education.\n\nIn October 2017, Rubin voted to approve a $50,000 grant to the Friends of the Capital Crescent Trail, a trail group that was suing to prevent the construction of the , saying that the companies contracted to build the transit line were not following commitments to ease the impact to the town. The grant was rejected by the Chevy Chase Town Council by a 4–1 vote.\n\nRubin has criticized the use of the term \"\" towards  as antisemitic. During his 2024 congressional campaign, he described himself as a \"defender of Israel\", but said he opposed the expansion of  as well as Israeli Prime Minister 's . In October 2023, amid the , Rubin said he supported providing additional air missile defense systems for the , supporting humanitarian efforts in , and preventing escalation from  and .\n\n\n\nRubin is married to his wife, Nilmini (née Gunaratne), whom he met at a going-away party for his college roommate in the spring of 2000. She is a  who works as a senior policy advisor for the  and is a registered . Together, they have three daughters and have lived in  since 2006. He is Jewish and a member of the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|birth_place     = \n|death_date      = \n|death_place     = \n|party           = \n|children        = 2\n|education       =  () ()\n}}\n'''Sheree L. Sample-Hughes''' (born September 13, 1977) is an American politician who since 2015 has served as a member of the  representing  in  and  Counties on the , centered around . A member of the , she was the  of the Maryland House of Delegates from 2019 to 2024.\n\n\nSample-Hughes was born on September 13, 1977. She grew up in , and attended . She went on to earn a bachelor's degree in public relations from  in 1999, and a master's degree in public administration from  in 2014. Sample-Hughes is a member of the  sorority.\n\nSample-Hughes is married to her husband, Desmond, and has two sons. She teaches at . In 2017, her son was involved in a serious incident that required him to be airlifted to the .\n\n\n\nSample-Hughes first got involved in public service as an affordable housing coordinator for , where she worked until 2000 when she became a special events coordinator for the Governor's Office on Service and Volunteerism. From 2002 to 2004, she served as the president of her local American Legion Post.\n\nIn 2006, Sample-Hughes was elected to the  in District 1, which encompasses northern parts of Wicomico County and the city of Salisbury. She was the first African-American woman to serve on the county council. Sample-Hughes was also appointed as a member of the Maryland Commission on Correctional Standards, which she served as the vice chair of from 2010 to 2014.\n\n\nIn 2014, Sample-Hughes was encouraged by incumbent state delegate  to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 37A, succeeding him as his health declined. She ran unopposed in the  after Cane withdrew his candidacy. Sample-Hughes was sworn into the  on January 14, 2015. She served as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee until 2022, when she was moved to the Economic Matters Committee. Since 2019, Sample-Hughes has been the only Democrat and the only person of color to represent the Eastern Shore of Maryland in the .\n\nFrom 2018 to 2019, Sample-Hughes served as the president of the Maryland Women's Legislative Caucus, becoming the first African-American to chair the caucus. In this position, she supported legislation to support female veterans and the elderly, and victims of workplace harassment and rape.\n\n\nIn September 2019, House Speaker  named Sample-Hughes as speaker pro tempore, succeeding her following her election as speaker. She was elected to this position by the Maryland House of Delegates in January 2020. In May 2023, following votes against several bills backed by Democratic leaders of the legislature, Jones said she would not renominate Sample-Hughes as speaker pro tempore during the 2024 legislative session, instead nominating delegate . Jones said that the decision to select a different speaker pro tempore was not a personal decision, but instead part of a general post-election restructuring of leadership. She had also offered Sample-Hughes a senior leadership position, which she declined.\n\nIn the , Sample-Hughes voted as an elector in . She was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\nSample-Hughes has described herself as a \"traditional Democrat\", and has pointed to a divide between herself and  members of the legislature. She has cited  as her political role model.\n\n\nSample-Hughes supports increased funding for school construction projects and increasing personnel pay. She has expressed concerns about Eastern Shore counties' ability to implement the  reforms, which she supports.\n\nIn 2015, Sample-Hughes expressed apprehension with proposal to adopt an elected school board in Wicomico County, saying that she worried that the school board would not accurately represent the county's diversity.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, she voted against a bill that would require teachers to go through  training. Sample-Hughes supported an unsuccessful amendment to the bill that would have allowed Eastern Shore school systems to continue using a private company for contracting its virtual education services. She also introduced legislation to increase financial literacy classes in schools.\n\n\nIn 2019, Sample-Hughes voted against a bill banning oyster harvesting in five  sanctuaries.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Sample-Hughes voted in favor of the Promoting Offshore Wind Energy Resources Act, which would quadruple the state's offshore wind capacity by 2031.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Sample-Hughes voted for s, which she described as a \"tool that can be used to intervene in and prevent a crisis situation\". During the 2023 legislative session, she voted against the Gun Safety Act of 2023, an omnibus gun control bill that increased requirements and fees to obtain a handgun permit, strengthened safe storage requirements, and prohibited carrying guns near certain locations. Sample-Hughes later questioned the legislation, claiming it would create \"unnecessary challenges\" when it comes to allowing people to legally carry guns.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Sample-Hughes introduced legislation that would require landlords to give a 60-day notice before rent increases. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Larry Hogan.\n\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Sample-Hughes voted in favor of legislation to increase participation in the state's medical marijuana industry.\n\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Sample-Hughes said she supported the Fair Wage Act of 2023, which would raise the minimum wage to  by 2024, but opposed a provision that would index increases to the state's minimum wage to inflation, and later supported a committee amendment to remove this provision.\n\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Sample-Hughes supported a bill to require private employers to provide employees with accrued sick leave. In 2022, she supported legislation requiring businesses and workers to contribute to a state-run medical leave program.\n\n\nIn 2020, Speaker  appointed Sample-Hughes to the Work Group to Address Police Reform and Accountability in Maryland. The work group released its recommendations in October, which included repealing the state's  and regulating the  that police could use during arrests. These recommendations were incorporated into the Police Reform and Accountability Act, which Sample-Hughes voted in favor of during the 2021 legislative session.\n\nIn October 2020, Sample-Hughes expressed concern with proposed budget cuts by Governor  that would've required the  to close one of its helicopter bases, which she feared would affect public health and safety on the Eastern Shore. Hogan later announced that state officials would no longer consider closing one of the state police's helicopter bases.\n\n\nIn 2019, Sample-Hughes said she supported legislation to establish the Maryland Truth and Reconciliation Commission to document racially motivated lynchings in the state's history. During the 2021 legislative session, she introduced legislation to remove \"\" as the state's official anthem. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan. Sample-Hughes later attended a rally in June 2021 to call for the removal of the Talbot Boys statue in Easton, which was the last  on public land in Maryland.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Sample-Hughes voted against the Trans Health Equity Act, which requires the state's  program to cover . She voted against the bill again when it was reintroduced in 2023, and later said she opposed the bill because of her religious and personal beliefs.\n\n\nIn April 2024, Sample-Hughes was the only Democratic member of the Maryland House of Delegates to vote against a bill that raised Maryland's tobacco tax and vehicle registration fees to pay for state transportation projects.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michele Jenkins Guyton''' (born October 19, 1966) is an American politician from the  and is a member of the  representing .\n\n\nGuyton was born on October 19, 1966, in , . She attended  in ,  and received her  in psychology and anthropology from  in 1989. She later jointly earned an MA in women studies from  of  as part of the Boston-area Graduate Consortium for Women’s Studies, alongside an MA in psychology from . Guyton also possesses a  in developmental and social psychology from Brandeis, which she received in 1996.\n\nIn 2015,   appointed Guyton to serve on the . The  approved her nomination in a 42-0 vote. She served on the board until January 1, 2019, when she resigned to become a state delegate.\n\nIn January 2018, at the , Guyton announced her intent to run for state delegate, citing the  as what motivated her to run for office. During the primary, she enjoyed endorsements from various organizations, including the Maryland , Metro Baltimore Council ,  Maryland, and the , and state senator . She received 48.4 percent of the vote in the 2022 Democratic primary and narrowly defeated  Tim Robinson in the general election with 26.5 percent of the vote. Mileah Kromer, a political scientist and pollster at , suggested that Guyton's primary win indicated a polarized electorate in Maryland's 42nd district.\n\nGuyton is a developmental psychologist and disabilities advocate who has worked at various institutions relating to psychology, including the , the North Carolina Department of Mental Health, and the . Her three sons all have disabilities, which moved her to co-found a support group for families with disabilities that has since evolved into the Mid-Atlantic chapter of the . She has also used her position as state delegate to introduce several pieces of legislation that would support disabled Marylanders.\n\n\n\nGuyton was sworn in as a member of the House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She was floated as a potential candidate for Maryland Senate in 2022. Unopposed in the Democratic primary, Guyton was reelected in the 2022 general election by a more than 20% margin.\n\n\n* Ways and Means Committee, 2019–present (education subcommittee, 2019–present; finance resources subcommittee, 2019; racing & gaming subcommittee, 2020; early childhood subcommittee, 2021–present)\n\n\n* Women's Legislators of Maryland, 2019–present\n* Maryland Legislative Transit Caucus, 2019–present\n* Maryland Legislative Latino Caucus, 2019–2020\n\n\nGuyton is a self-described progressive Democrat, but has expressed that she will work across the aisle to support good ideas \"regardless of who is sponsoring them.\"\n\n\nGuyton supports , boosting mental health supports in schools and improving teacher-student ratios in classrooms.\n\n\nIn February 2020, Guyton joined seven Democratic delegates in voting against a bill that would mandate  on private sales and transfers of shotguns and rifles.\n\n\nGuyton supports expanding access to healthcare, saying that she \"believes it really is a human right\" and that  is worth discussing but would have to be paid for.\n\n\nOn the campaign trail, Guyton advocated for the legislature to pass a \"$15 an hour living wage with future indexed increases.\" In March 2019, she was one of two Democrats in the Maryland House of Delegates to vote against a bill that would raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour.\n\n\nGuyton opposes raising new taxes, instead advocating for redirecting priorities and using funding sources like lottery money and the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Douglas Friend Gansler''' (born October 30, 1962) is an American attorney and politician who served as the 45th  from 2007 to 2015. Gansler previously served as the  for  from 1999 to 2007. \n\nHe won the state  primary election for attorney general and defeated   in the , taking 61% of the vote. He was re-elected unopposed in the . \n\nGansler unsuccessfully ran for  in the , losing the Democratic primary to . Gansler was also a gubernatorial candidate in the , losing the Democratic primary to .\n\n\nBorn in , Gansler grew up in  in . There he attended Chevy Chase Elementary School, and , a private Quaker school in the Washington, D.C., area, for grades 6–12. \n\nGansler became involved with politics at 13, knocking on doors for , who was then running for the  in . From Sidwell, Gansler went to . He was an All-Ivy, All–New England College  player, and nurtured an interest in public service, graduating . Gansler earned a  degree from the . He was a  to Hon. John F. McAuliffe, Judge on the .\n\nAfter working for a brief period as a  at a  and at the s of Coburn & Schertler and , Gansler was hired as an , serving from 1992 to 1998. There he prosecuted, among others, a  diplomat who killed a young woman while driving drunk near .\n\n\n\n\nIn 1998, Gansler was elected State's Attorney for Montgomery County, Maryland, serving from January 1999 to January 2007. While serving, he prosecuted several high-profile cases, including the ,  and . Gansler also launched programs to fight gangs, punish criminals, and protect the public, including domestic violence dockets and , gang prosecution unit,  Task Force to target criminals preying on seniors, and an  unit.\n\nOn one occasion, the Maryland Court of Appeals  him for public statements he made about a possible confession and possible  in a high-profile case involving the beating and murder of a Maryland jogger. He was the first elected State's Attorney to be sanctioned by the court. \n\n Gansler was elected as Maryland Attorney General in 2006, taking the  as Attorney General of Maryland on January 2, 2007. While in office, he focused on , , , and . \n\nGansler was elected to a second term on November 2, 2010. \n\n\nGansler protected the , its tributaries, and Maryland's other natural resources. He secured  settlements, water pollution, oil pollution and  penalties. \n\nGansler also led the successful charge to have  banned from dishwasher detergent and arsenic banned from chicken feed, and helped secure standing for environmental groups to sue polluters in State court.\n\nHe also laid the groundwork for the construction of a  to convert 500 million pounds of chicken manure into energy, potentially keeping the single largest source of  and  out of the , while providing Maryland  with an additional source of revenue.\n\n\nGansler fought various forms of fraud that threatened , contributed to the cost of healthcare, and undermined citizens' financial security and well-being. This work included an agreement with all the major  companies to end usurious refueling rates, and a settlement with all four major  carriers requiring disclosure of the terms of cell phone insurance.   \n\n\nIn a fight against , Gansler recovered nearly $1 billion in relief and assistance for Maryland homeowners. He was aggressive in going after  lenders, foreclosure scammers, unscrupulous contractors, and others who made home ownership difficult. His efforts recovered hundreds of millions of dollars for consumer victims.\n\n\nGansler worked to keep consumers safe from healthcare scams. This work included the largest recovery in a healthcare fraud investigation in U.S. history against a major  that illegally marketed drugs at the expense of consumer safety. It also included multimillion-dollar victories against healthcare providers who abused  at taxpayers’ expense, and others that preyed on the infirm. Gansler also advocated for better healthcare options for Marylanders, both through his Health Education and Advocacy Unit, and through his leadership in supporting broader healthcare solutions like the .\n\nTo promote the health and safety of Maryland teens, Gansler led the effort to limit youth access to  and tobacco by combating the marketing practices of alcohol and tobacco companies that target younger consumers. This work led to an agreement with two of the largest alcohol manufacturers to stop the production and distribution of alcoholic \"energy\" drinks, as well as an agreement with one of the largest gas station franchises in the world to curb tobacco sales to minors at its 13,000 outlets across the United States.\n\n\nRecognizing that rapid developments in  and enterprise have created new and significant  risks for both consumers and corporations, Gansler led state and national efforts to protect . For example, he led a charge by 36 state attorneys general to demand accountability from the nation's largest provider of Internet services when it unilaterally changed its . He also brought an action against a major retailer for an online breach that led to the theft of consumer credit card data from 100 million transactions.\n\n\nGansler established the first-ever Attorney General   Unit in Maryland. Gansler co-chaired the statewide   and spearheaded tougher  laws through his role as Co-Chair of Maryland's Family Violence Council.\n\nGansler also established a statewide  initiative focused on school-aged children, shut down an online anonymous gossip site being used to torment young students, helped eliminate the online  adult services section of , and worked on a nationally coordinated effort targeting  who use  websites to lure victims. Tens of thousands of  were removed from  sites as a result of this effort. For this work, he received the Champion of Online Safety Award.\n\n\nGansler demonstrated a long-standing commitment to  in his creation of the first-ever Director of Civil Rights position in the Office of the . He set up a Voting Irregularities  to address  issues in Maryland, and a  Finance Advisory Committee to explore ways to ensure fair participation in the  process. He also published a report providing guidance on  training protocols that is being used nationally by , and a report that assists Maryland's institutions of higher education in legally developing and maintaining diversity. He worked for judicial election reform that would ensure diversity of the bench. For this work, as well as his successful efforts to increase diversity both in the  State's Attorney's Office and the Office of the Attorney General, Gansler was awarded the Dr.  Dream Keeper's Award.\n\n\nGansler was the first statewide elected official in Maryland to support . In 2010, Gansler issued a  that clarified Maryland's ability to provide  to valid out-of-state s. That opinion provided the underpinning for a subsequent Maryland Court of Appeals  recognizing same-sex marriages from other states. For his early and strong support of marriage equality, Gansler received the ’s Ally for Equality Award.\n\n\nGansler was a proponent of the Maryland State Police requirement for concealed carry permits, which states that a citizen must have a good and substantial reason in order to acquire the permit.\n\n\nDuring the 2008 presidential election, Gansler was the first statewide official in Maryland to support , and went on to be the Maryland Co-Chair, with Representative , of Obama’s Presidential Campaign.\n\n\nGansler was elected to serve as President of the  (NAAG) in 2012. He served as Chair of the Democratic Attorneys General Association (DAGA) until becoming President-Elect at the NAAG. He also chaired NAAG committees on Youth Access to Alcohol, the Environment and Energy.\n\nAs President of NAAG, Gansler focused the organization’s attention on privacy in the Digital Age. He formed a Committee on Internet Privacy at NAAG to keep close watch on developments in the Internet space that affect consumers’ control over their information, and headed several efforts to hold accountable those who fail to properly respect  online. He called attention to companies that collect information from children in ways that appear out of compliance with the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act.\n\n\n\nGansler formally announced his candidacy in the  to succeed , who was term limited, on September 24, 2013. Gansler had a warchest of $5.2m and said that he was \"flattered by the depth and breadth of support I have received from all corners of Maryland\". Gansler was criticized by a Maryland veterans organization for suggesting that his leading opponent in the Democratic primary, Maryland Lt Gov. , a former US Army Reserve , was \"somebody who has never managed anybody, never run anything\", as a result of his service. Gansler later explained that his comments were specifically in reference to managing the state's health exchange. Brown won the Democratic primary, but was defeated by Republican Party candidate  in an upset in the general election.\n\n\n\n, 2022]]\nOn May 25, 2021, Gansler announced that he would run for Governor of Maryland in the . His running mate was former  mayor Candace Hollingsworth. A central part of his platform was fighting crime in .\n\nOn July 19, 2022, Gansler lost the primary, placing fourth behind , , and . He conceded defeat on July 21, 2022, and endorsed Democratic nominee Wes Moore the next day.\n\n\n* In November 2002, Gansler irritated colleagues when he filed charges in Maryland against the ,  and , who were also being prosecuted in Virginia. More than a year after the snipers had been convicted in Virginia, Gansler held a trial in Maryland. Gansler stated that the trial only cost taxpayers $2,000, however Sheriff Raymond M. Kight said that the costs had exceeded $743,570, when taking into account costs such as overtime pay to provide security throughout the trial process.\n* In November 2003, Gansler became the first sitting prosecutor in Maryland history to be censured by the state's highest court, for improperly discussing evidence, such as a defendant's confession, at news conferences \"on more than one occasion\", related to three criminal cases. '''' described him as a \"near-perfect specimen of a classic political archetypethe prosecutor on the make,\" noting that \"[h]e's smart, he's well-connected, he's telegenic, and he raises gobs of cash.\"\n* In August 2013, Gansler was tape-recorded speaking disparagingly of his Democratic primary opponent in the 2014 Maryland gubernatorial race, Lieutenant Gov. , who he accused of relying on race in the contest. \"I mean, right now his campaign slogan is, 'Vote for me, I want to be the first African American governor of Maryland,'\" Gansler said. His comments provoked outrage.\n* On October 12, 2013, '''' published memos written by state troopers alleging that Gansler repeatedly requested officers assigned to him to drive in an irresponsible manner. A spokesperson for Gansler denied the reports.\n* On October 24, 2013, the '''' published a photo showing Gansler at a house party attended by his son in , where underage drinking was taking place. In response, Gansler said he was there briefly, did not notice any underage drinking, and that even if he had, he did not have \"moral authority over other people's children\" outside Maryland. Gansler later said that in hindsight, he should have assumed there was underage drinking and should have discussed it with the chaperones.\n\n\n\nGansler is married to Laura Leedy Gansler, a  lawyer and author about legal cases. He coaches both his sons, Sam and Will, in a variety of sports. Gansler is Jewish.\n\nGansler's father, the late , was Professor of Public Policy at the , and former .\n\nGansler founded a lacrosse league for Baltimore inner-city youth, called  Youth Lacrosse. He mentored at-risk area youth, served on the Montgomery County Commission on Aging, and co-chaired the  Criminal Justice Committee. For his work in establishing the Charm City Youth Lacrosse League, he received the “Innovator of the Year” award from Maryland's largest legal publication.\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sid A. Saab''' (born February 20, 1971) is an American politician who was a Republican member of the , representing  ().\n\n\nSaid Amal Saab was born in  on February 20, 1971, and migrated to the  in 1990.\n\n\nSaab was elected to the House of Delegates in the 2014 General Assembly elections, succeeding delegate  and becoming the first member of the  to have been born in Lebanon.\n\nIn January 2020, Saab worked with delegate  to introduce a bill that would require hospitals or nursing facilities in the state to begin ensuring personnel wear an identification tag when providing patient care. The bill would pass the House of Delegates and  by votes of 136-0 and 45-0, respectively, and would be signed by  . In April 2020, Saab joined delegates , , , , , and  in pressing the Hogan administration to release data on the 2,000 inmates released at the beginning of the  and COVID-19 case outbreaks in nursing homes and other elder care facilities.\n\nIn February 2021, Saab joined delegates Kathy Szeliga and  at a protest against abortion at the Maryland State House.\n\nIn April 2021, Saab told  that he was actively considering a run for  executive. In December 2021, he announced that he would seek a third term in the House of Delegates instead of running for executive, but later announced in April 2022 that he would run for  in 2022, seeking to succeed outgoing state Senator . Saab was defeated by Democrat  in the general election.\n\n\nSaab is married to Sarah. They have three children.\n\nSaab co-owns, with state delegate , a fitness gym in . In February 2021, a former employee filed a lawsuit against the two lawmakers, alleging that she was retaliated against for reporting sexual harassment by another co-worker. A federal jury ruled for the employee in September 2023.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Lisa Adrienne Gladden''' (born October 6, 1964) is an  from  and a member of the . She formerly served in the , representing Maryland's District 41 in .  She resigned as Senator due  on January 10, 2017\n\n\nBorn in , , Gladden attended  and the  before entering practice as an attorney in the Office of the Public Defender. She was active with the , the Alliance of Black Women Attorneys, and with the Democratic Party.  Gladden, a Democrat, told The Baltimore Sun in 2010 that she had multiple sclerosis. She told the newspaper she was first diagnosed in 1995 but did not disclose it because she didn't want sympathy or to become a \"poster child\" for .\n\n\nGladden was first elected to and served as a member of House of Delegates from January 13, 1999 to January 8, 2003. During that time she was a member of the  Judiciary Committee and chaired its criminal justice subcommittee from 1999 to 2003. She was also a member of the Liaison Work Group in the  from 1999 to 2003.\nGladden was elected to the Maryland State Senate in 2002, and was re-elected in 2006. She had been heavily mentored and rose quickly through the ranks, achieving the position of Majority Whip. Gladden was also vice-chair of the Judicial Proceedings Committee, a member of the  and a member of the .\n*'''Legislative notes'''\n**voted against  in 1999 (HB703)\n**voted for slots in 2004 (SB197)\n*2006\n**voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n*2007\n**voted in favor of prohibiting ground rents in 2007(SB106)\n**voted in favor of the Tax Reform Act of 2007 (HB2)\n**voted in favor of slots (SB3)\n*2009\n**sponsored a bill establishing that a material, compound, mixture, or preparation that contains Salvinorin A or Salvia divinorum, with a specified exception, is a Schedule I controlled dangerous substance.\n\n\n2012-  Gladden was appointed by Maryland legislative leaders to a task force to study the impact of a  ruling regarding the liability of owners of s and landlords that rent to them.\n\n\n\nIn December 2007, Gladden was chosen by the  to appear on the ballot, in the Maryland democratic presidential primary, as a female delegate for Obama from . Gladden campaigned in Ohio, South Carolina, Pennsylvania and Maryland for Obama during the primary campaign. She finished first among the female delegates in the Maryland Democratic election and went to the , in Denver Colorado, as a delegate committed to . Along with Maryland Delegate , Gladden served as co-chair of the Baltimore for Obama campaign in both the 2008 primary and general elections.\n\n\n\n\n\n* '''official MD Senate website'''\n**Bills sponsored  \n* profile\n*''Follow the Money'' - Lisa A.     "pages": }\n  \n'''David V. Fraser-Hidalgo''' (born November 25, 1969) is an Ecuadorian-born American politician and a member of the  representing  in . He was appointed to complete the term of Delegate  following Feldman's appointment to a Senate seat and has since been elected to his own full term.\n\n\nFraser-Hidalgo was born on November 25, 1969, in . He grew up in , attending  in . In 1992, he earned a  in History from .\n\nFor three years, Fraser-Hidalgo served as a police officer in Montgomery County before leaving the police department and entering the business world. He has worked for a number of firms, including being a partner in a Montgomery County based tech firm for 10 years and as an Area Director for Regus. He has also been involved in a variety of volunteer activities in the county, including as a leader in the Boyds Civic Association and sits on the boards of the Montgomery County Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Community Farm Share and the National Caucus of Environmental Legislators.\n\nIn 2010, Fraser-Hidalgo unsuccessfully ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 15, coming in fourth place with 8.8 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn 2013, the retirement of Senator  from the Maryland Senate prompted the appointment of Delegate  to fill the remainder of Garagiola's term. This left an open Delegate seat, which was contested by a number of applicants. Fraser-Hidalgo won the final vote of the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee by a close margin, and on October 16, 2013, was appointed by Governor  to fill the seat. He was sworn in on October 21, 2013.\n\nIn February 2015, Fraser-Hidalgo joined state Senator  and Delegates , , , and  in organizing the Maryland Latino Legislative Caucus, becoming one of the caucus' first six members. Fraser-Hidalgo served as the Latino Caucus' chair from 2019 to 2024.\n\n\n\nFraser-Hidalgo has repeatedly introduced legislation that would ban the practice of  in Maryland. During the 2017 legislative session, his bill passed and was signed into law by Governor  on April 4, 2017.\n\nFraser-Hidalgo introduced legislation in the 2019 legislative session that would increase the state's electric vehicle tax credit to $3,000. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on April 30, 2019. A bill extending the tax credit was introduced and passed during the 2022 legislative session and was signed into law on April 21, 2022.\n\nFraser-Hidalgo introduced legislation in the 2021 legislative session that would charge polluters a  for their , investing the revenue earned from the fee into education and green infrastructure. The bill received an unfavorable committee report.\n\nFraser-Hidalgo introduced legislation in the 2022 legislative session that would set goals for electrifying the state's vehicle fleet, with 100 percent of passenger cars purchased to be electric by 2028 and all passenger cars in the fleet to be electric by 2031.\n\n\nFraser-Hidalgo introduced legislation in the 2018 legislative session that would create a pilot program authorizing both growing and processing operations for . The bill passed with nearly unanimous support (136-1 in the House and 46-0 in the Senate) and was signed into law by Governor Hogan on May 8, 2018. He introduced legislation during the 2019 legislation to fully legalize commercial hemp farming, which was signed into law by Hogan on April 30, 2019.\n\n\nFraser-Hidalgo introduced legislation in the 2016 legislative session that would have strengthened laws on . The bill was watered down during committee hearings, but passed and became law on May 19, 2016.\n\nFraser-Hidalgo introduced legislation in the 2020 legislative session that would require  to fill vacancies in the .\n\n\nFraser-Hidalgo lives in , in a home that is almost completely . He was married to Lisa Bethel, and has two children, Samantha and Scott. In the early spring of 2018, his wife Lisa died from cancer.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
