    "pages": }\n'''Guy Joseph Guzzone''' (born March 27, 1964) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2015, and as its majority leader from 2019 to 2020. A member of the , he previously represented the district in the  from 2007 to 2015, and as a member of the  from 1998 to 2006.\n\n\nGuzzone was born in  on March 27, 1964. He graduated from  and attended the , where he earned his  degree in economics and government & politics in 1986, and later his  degree in public management as a MacArthur Graduate Fellow in 1988. Guzzone also attended , where he earned an executive certificate in juvenile justice and multi-system integration in 2008.\n\n\nGuzzone first got involved in politics as a college intern for U.S. Representative . He later served as a special assistant to county councilmember  from 1991 to 1995. In 1994, Guzzone was appointed to the  village board of directors, serving as its chair from 1995 to 1998. From 1996 to 1998, he served as the state director of the .\n\n\nOn October 26, 1997, Guzzone announced that he would run for the Howard County Council in District 3, seeking to succeed Republican Dennis R. Schrader, who unsuccessfully ran for county executive. He ran unopposed the Democratic primary in September 1998, and faced Republican Wanda Hurt in the general election. The election was seen as the most competitive in the county, as the winning candidate would decide who held the majority on the county council. Guzzone defeated Hurt in the general election on November 5, 1998, with 58.1 percent of the vote. He was sworn into the county council in December 1998, and served as the council's chair in 2001 and from 2003 to 2005.\n\nIn 2006, Guzzone chaired the transition team of Howard County Executive-elect .\n\n\nIn November 2005, after initially considering a run for county executive, Guzzone announced that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 13, challenging , who briefly ran for Congress in 2006. During the Democratic primary, he ran on a slate with incumbent state delegates Shane Pendergrass and . Guzzone won the Democratic primary in September 2006, placing third and edging out Quinter, and defeated Republican challengers in the general election. Guzzone was sworn in on January 10, 2007, and was a member of the Appropriations Committee during his entire tenure.\n\nIn October 2013, Guzzone was named to the Howard County organizing team for Lieutenant Governor 's .\n\n\nOn June 14, 2013, Guzzone announced that he would run for the Maryland Senate in District 13, seeking to succeed retiring state senator . During his campaign, he ran on a slate with  and state delegates Shane Pendergrass and Frank S. Turner. Guzzone ran in the Democratic primary unopposed and won the general election on November 4, 2014, defeating Republican challenger Jody Venkatesan with 62.3 percent of the vote.\n\nGuzzone was sworn in on January 14, 2015, and has been a member of the Budget and Taxation Committee during his entire tenure.\n\n\nIn November 2018, Senate President  announced that he would appoint Guzzone as majority leader of the Maryland Senate. After Miller announced that he had been diagnosed with , he was seen as a likely candidate to succeed him if Miller was to step down, but he declined, instead endorsing eventual Senate President , who returned the favor by appointing Guzzone to chair the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee following his election. During his tenure as chair, he implemented a three-minute limit on testimonies and frequently utilized work groups to develop policy.\n\nIn 2018, Guzzone chaired the transition team of Howard County Executive-elect .\n\nGuzzone was a delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\nGuzzone was married to , whom he moved from  to  with in 1992 and later divorced. Pam was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in . Together, they have three children.\n\nGuzzone has .\n\n\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Guzzone introduced legislation to increase funding for the Maryland Legal Services Corporation, the state's largest funder of civil legal aid, which passed and became law.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Guzzone said he supported Governor Hogan's , which provided $750 s to low-income families in Maryland, calling it a \"good place for us to start\". He supported the \"Maryland Senate Recovery Now\" amendment to the bill, which added $520 million in grants to businesses and workers on unemployment insurance to the bill.\n\nIn February 2023, Guzzone said that the Budget and Taxation Committee would begin interpreting bills with funding mandates through the lens of a constitutional amendment passed by voters in 2020 that gave the legislature increased power over fiscal policy.\n\n\nIn January 2012, Guzzone criticized Governor 's plan to shift responsibility for teachers' pensions to local jurisdictions, saying that he would need to be \"really convinced\" to vote for it.\n\nIn January 2020, after Prince George's County Executive  and Baltimore mayor  expressed concern about the cost of the , Guzzone promised to get \"every county and city\" on board with the funding formulas in the bill. Legislators would later amend the bill's funding formulas to lessen its impacts on poorer areas of the state, which decreased the bill's cost to Prince George's County to $183 million and to Baltimore to $170 million by 2030. Guzzone also supported legislation to creating a tax on  and expanding the state sales tax to include , and an amendment that would limit the Blueprint's implementation if state revenues dropped by more than 7.5 percent.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Guzzone supported legislation that would designate Maryland's votes in the  to the winner of the national popular vote provided a red state agrees to do the same.\n\nIn 2020, Guzzone supported a resolution calling on Congress to hold a convention to overturn ''''.\n\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Guzzone introduced legislation to establish a Forest Conservation Task Force to develop recommendations on how to address deforestation without disrupting development. The bill passed and became law. In 2021, he introduced legislation to establish the Clean Water Commerce Fund to reduce pollution in state waterways, which passed and became law.\n\nIn February 2019, Guzzone voted for a bill that would allow the Howard County Council to impose a tax on plastic bags, but said he would have preferred if the bill banned plastic bags instead of charging a fee.\n\n\nIn August 2012, Guzzone said he was undecided on legislation to expand gambling in Maryland.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Guzzone introduced the Racing and Community Development Act, a bill that would provide $375.5 million in state funding to refurbish  and , financed by revenues from slot machines and gambling. He also supported legislation to legalize  in Maryland, which was overwhelming approved by voters in the .\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Guzzone supported the Firearm Safety Act, a bill that placed restrictions on firearm purchases and magazine capacity in s.\n\n\nIn February 2011, Guzzone supported legislation to establish a  system in Maryland.\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Guzzone introduced, but later withdrew, legislation that would provide terminally ill patients with . He also introduced the \"Keep the Door Open Act\", which would increase state payments to community behavioral health clinics and organizations.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Guzzone introduced legislation to give library workers in Howard County .\n\nIn June 2020, Guzzone expressed concerns with provisions of Governor 's 2021 budget that reduced worker salaries by $95 million and eliminated 92 positions. He supported a proposal in Hogan's 2022 budget to give state employees a $1,000 bonus.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Guzzone introduced legislation that would give community college employees collective bargaining rights. The bill passed and became law after legislators voted to override Hogan's veto on the bill during the special legislative session later that year.\n\n\nIn June 2019, Guzzone was appointed to a task force to study the . During the 2021 legislative session, he supported legislation to legalize recreational cannabis in Maryland.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Guzzone voted for legislation that would ban discrimination against  and  people.\n\nIn 2012, Guzzone campaigned against , which sought to repeal .\n\nIn September 2016, following a report that accused Howard County Sheriff James Fitzgerald of discrimination and harassment toward his employees, Guzzone said that he hoped Fitzgerald would resign. After the Howard County Council began considering impeaching him from office, Fitzgerald announced that he would resign in October.\n\n\nIn 2005, Guzzone supported legislation to cut property taxes for seniors. In 2006, he introduced legislation to provide tax credits to homeowners who install  or  equipment, which was unanimously approved by the county council and became law. Guzzone also opposed a bill that would further cut property taxes for seniors, supporting a motion to table the bill.\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Guzzone voted for legislation to index the state's es to inflation to pay for state transportation projects. In 2023, he opposed an amendment to the state budget that would have decoupled the fuel tax, saying that the state needed the tax for another two years while expressing support for a new funding mechanism to pay for state transportation projects.\n\n\nIn April 2021, Guzzone blocked legislation that would codify promises made by the  toward highway expansion projects on  and the , saying that there were \"too many issues\" with the bill.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Edward Joseph Pipkin Jr.''' (born November 1, 1956) is an American activist, politician, and  former member of the , had represented Maryland's , and was first elected in 2002 and served until 2013.  Prior to his election to the state senate, he worked in the field of business finance, trading bonds in .  He also founded an environmental group known as \"Citizens Against Bay Dumping,\" during which he was successful in lobbying for legislation that banned irresponsible disposal of dredge spoils in the .  Pipkin currently lives in . In 2004, he unsuccessfully ran for the  against .  Then, in 2008, he unsuccessfully ran for Congress in , against incumbent  and State Senator , losing the primary to Andy Harris. On August 5, 2013, Pipkin announced he would retire from the State Senate to attend graduate school.\n\n\nPipkin grew up in , and went to . He initially attended , but ultimately received his B.A. from . He received an  from the .\n\n\nPipkin has three children: Carter, Meredith and Tyler.\n\n\nPipkin was elected to the State Senate in 2002 after defeating Democrat Walter M. Baker, who held that seat since 1979 and the chairman of the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee. Baker was the only state senator to vote against Pipkin's efforts to ban open bay dumping. Pipkin defeated Baker by 24 percentage points.\n\nSince his arrival to the Senate, Pipkin has authored legislation that include creating a task force to bring broadband internet to his eastern shore constituents; creating a committee that will ensure responsible handling of taxpayer dollars by the state government; and advocating for an elected school board in Cecil County to increase public involvement in public schools.\n\nPipkin was re-elected in 2006 with 63.7% of the vote, and re-elected again in 2010.\n\nOn August 5, 2013, Pipkin announced that he would retire from the State Senate, effective the following week, to pursue a graduate degree in sports management at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, Texas.\n\n\nIn the , Pipkin ran unsuccessfully against incumbent Democratic senator .\n\nHe ran a series of ads during the campaign with his self-coined slogan \"who knew\" that attacked Mikulski's policies. This led Mikulski, who was already considered a favorite, to hold a debate with Pipkin.\n\n\nIn 2003, Pipkin sponsored a bill to return a tax credit to employers who provide daycare for their employees. In 2004, he sponsored a permanent repeal of the estate tax in Maryland. In 2006, Pipkin sponsored a reduction in state property taxes and a reduction in income taxes.\n\n\nAs a resident of , Pipkin himself has been affected by  on the , and has fought to reduce the problem.  In 2005, he proposed a set of bills, which ultimately failed to pass, in that year's  session, known as the \"Bay Bridge Users' Bill of Rights\".  The bills would have, among other things, made various modifications to the governing board of the  (MdTA), banned trucks from the bridge when one of its dual spans is carrying two-way traffic, and waived tolls whenever backups extended beyond a certain point.\nLater that year, Pipkin was one of the 22 citizens appointed by Governor Robert Ehrlich to serve on  the , to explore the possibility of building a new crossing of the .\n\nIn the 2006 Maryland General Assembly session, Pipkin once again tried to pass parts of the Bay Bridge Users' Bill of Rights, this time more successfully.  Among the bills that passed that year included one that made various modifications to the governing board of the MdTA (e.g. addition of two appointed members; imposition of three term limit of service; lengthening of terms to four years, rather than three years; etc.).\nAlong with Delegate Mary Roe Walkup (R-Dist. 36), Pipkin also proposed a bill to remove the - crossing from the list of crossing locations that could potentially be studied in the future).\nHowever, that bill did not pass (nor did it pass when re-introduced in 2007).\nAlso during 2006, Pipkin worked collaboratively with MdTA to promote successful legislation (Senate Bill 168, signed into law as Chapter 24 of 2007 of the Laws of Maryland) that doubled the amount of violations fines that could be issued for overweight tractor-trailers crossing the bridge.\n\n\n*'''2006 race for Maryland State Senate – District 36'''\n:\n\n*'''2004 race for U.S. Senator'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 race for Maryland State Senate – District 36'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jon Steven Cardin''' (born January 12, 1970) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2019, and previously from 2003 to 2015. A member of the , he unsuccessfully ran for  in . Cardin is the nephew of U.S. Senator .\n\n\nCardin was born in  on January 12, 1970. He graduated from the  and attended Tufts University, where he received a  degree in international relations in 1992; the , where he earned a Master of Public Service degree in policy sciences in 1996; , where he earned a  degree in judaic studies with honors in 1996; and the , where he earned his  degree with honors in 2001.\n\n\nAfter Cardin was admitted to the  in 2001, he clerked for Baltimore City Circuit Court Judge  until 2002. Afterwards, he started his own law firm, Jon S. Cardin, P.A.\n\n\nIn 2002, Cardin filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 11, seeking to succeed delegate Michael Finifter, who resigned to serve as a state circuit court judge.\n\nCardin was first sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 8, 2003, and was a member of the Ways and Means Committee during his entire first stint in office. During the 2014 legislative session, Cardin missed 75 percent of committee votes, which he attributed to him leaving early to recognize  and to spend time with his daughter and pregnant wife.\n\nIn February 2018, Cardin filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 11, seeking to succeed retiring state delegate . He won the Democratic primary election on June 26, 2018, placing third with 23.6 percent of the vote. During the general election, Cardin was targeted by the , who sent out flyers attacking him for voting for tax increases under the  administration. He won the general election on November 6, defeating Republican challenger Jonathan Porter with 29.3 percent of the vote.\n\nCardin was sworn in for his second stint in the legislature on January 9, 2019, during which he has served on the Judiciary Committee.\n\nIn December 2019, following the resignation of state senator Robert Zirkin, Cardin said that he would apply to serve the remainder of Zirkin's term in the Maryland Senate. In January 2020, the Baltimore County Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate  to fill the vacancy over Cardin.\n\nIn August 2024, after  won the Democratic nomination in the  in , Cardin expressed interest in serving the remainder of Olszewski's term as .\n\n\nIn August 2009, Cardin was criticized for using  resources to perform a marriage proposal prank. Cardin was using a friend's boat when police boarded the boat as a Foxtrot helicopter hovered above the boat. According to the '''', Cardin's girlfriend thought she was going to be arrested when Cardin proposed to her. After the issue became public, Delegate Cardin promised to reimburse the City of Baltimore for the costs incurred. Cardin paid $300 to the Baltimore Police Department to cover the costs and donated $1,000 to the city's mounted unit. The Baltimore Police Department launched an internal affairs investigation into the marriage proposal incident. In November 2009, a police sergeant was charged with misconduct in connection with the prank.\n\n\n\n\nIn November 2012, Cardin formed an  into a potential run for  in . He officially announced his candidacy on July 22, 2013, becoming the first candidate to enter the race. Cardin ran on a platform that involved focusing on , , and public safety.\n\nDuring the Democratic primary, Cardin was criticized for benefiting from political  after campaigning with his uncle , for misusing  resources in a stunt wedding proposal, missing 75 percent of committee votes during the 2014 legislative session, and touting an endorsement from Ski Money, a Baltimore-based rapper who had been indicted on human trafficking charges in Baltimore County. Following the Democratic primary election, he called these criticisms \"the most negative smear campaign in a Democratic Party primary in Maryland's modern history\".\n\nIn June 2014, Cardin filed a report with the Maryland State Board of Elections against state senator  and state delegate , both supporters of , accusing the lawmakers of \"verbally harassing\" one of his campaign volunteers. Both legislators denied Cardin's accusations, with McIntosh saying that she had not confronted any Cardin supports while canvassing and Gladden saying that she was never at the polling place described in the report.\n\nPolling ahead of the primary election showed Cardin leading other Democratic challengers Frosh and , but with a majority of voters saying that they were undecided. He was defeated in the Democratic primary by state senator  on June 24, 2014, and conceded to Frosh the day after the election. Following his defeat, Cardin worked as a lobbyist.\n\n\nCardin is married to his wife, Megan (née Homer). Together, they have two children and live in .\n\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Cardin voted to repeal the death penalty in Maryland. He also introduced a bill that would fine speed camera vendors who issue erroneous tickets.\n\nIn 2014, Cardin introduced a bill that would make revenge porn punishable by a five-year jail term and a $25,000 fine.\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Cardin introduced legislation to expand the state's  to protect people suffering from an overdose from arrest or prosecution.\n\n\nDuring the 2007 legislative session, Cardin introduced a bill requiring elementary schools to have 150 minutes of es a week. The bill received an unfavorable report in the House Ways and Means Committee.\n\n\nDuring the 2011 legislative session, Cardin introduced a bill that would allow  to Maryland political candidates by text message. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn 2021, Cardin introduced a bill that would require the state to send s to all registered voters. He also introduced a bill that would amend the  to appointed state judges serve 12-year terms before running in a retention election.\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Cardin introduced legislation that would levy taxes on bullet sales and impose a $25 gun registration fee, with revenues earned from the excises going toward mental health services in the state. He also introduced bills to ban s, and another requiring s for weapon sales.\n\n\nDuring the 2005 legislative session, Cardin voted to override Governor 's veto on a bill limiting increases on  premiums and to levy a premium tax on s.\n\n\nDuring a committee hearing on legislation creating a  on legalizing  in 2022, Cardin expressed concerns about the  and with drivers using cannabis while driving, but nevertheless voted to pass the referendum bill.\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Cardin voted for the , a bill to legalize . In 2014, he introduced a bill to ban  for LGBT teens.\n\nIn 2013, Cardin introduced Grace's Law, which would make harassing a child with the intent of encouraging them to commit suicide punishable by a fine and jail time. The bill was named for Grace McComas, a 15-year-old who took their own life in 2012 following online taunts and hate speech. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor . In 2019, he introduced legislation to increase the penalties under Grace's Law to up to 10 years in prison. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor .\n\n\nDuring the 2013 legislative session, Cardin voted for a bill to index the state's es to inflation to pay for state transportation projects.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kathryn L. Afzali''' (born May 27, 1957) is an American politician who represented  in the  from 2011 to 2019.\n\n\nAfzali was born and raised in the . She is a graduate of . She was a columnist for the '''' from 2003 to 2006.\n\n\nAfzali was sworn in as a member of the Maryland House of Delegates on January 12, 2011. She was assigned to the House Ways and Means Committee and to its Election Law and Education subcommittees. She served as the  Republican on Ways and Means. She is also a member of the Women Legislators of Maryland.\n\nBy the end of Afzali's first legislative session in Annapolis, she sponsored or co-sponsored forty-nine bills.\n\n\n\n  proposed, and  adopted, a redistricting plan that reconfigured Republican incumbent U.S. Congressman 's 6th congressional district to one that  won in the . The previous version of the district had President Obama at 40%, while the newly redrawn district had President Obama at 56%.\n\nOn January 11, 2012, believing that Bartlett would be retiring, Afzali announced her intention to run for the GOP nomination to represent . Bartlett eventually decided to run for reelection. He won the primary election with 44% of the vote in a crowded field but went on to lose the general election.\n\n\n\nAfzali won the Republican primary on June 26, 2018 with 42.7 percent of the vote. She was defeated by incumbent  County Executive Jan Gardner in the general election, receiving 43.1 percent of the vote to Gardner's 52.1 percent. After her loss, Afzali stepped down from the Frederick County Republican Central Committee.\n\n\nAfzali is a member of the Grace Community Church of Frederick. She is a Life Member of the .\n\n\n\nHer first successful piece of legislation was a honey standard which passed unanimously through both chambers and has been used as a model in other states.\n\nShe introduced a Farm Estate Tax bill that eliminated .\n\n\nAfzali has sponsored legislation to increase sanctions on drunk drivers with multiple offenses, and was responsible for \"Anayah's Law\", which allows Child Protective Services to be relieved of its obligation to reunite children with their parent if the parent has committed \"severe physical abuse\" against the child.\n\nIn her second year, she pushed for legislation to require a photo  in the state of Maryland.\n\nIn 2013, she co-sponsored legislation that would make cyber-bullying a child a misdemeanor.\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Afzali introduced legislation to ban telemarketers and others from falsifying the origin of their calls and establish a penalty for providing false location information.\n\n\nAfzali endorsed  for president on September 8, 2011. Afzali endorsed  for president on April 21, 2016.\n\n\nIn 2018, Afzali voted to sustain Governor Larry Hogan's veto on a bill to required employers with 15 or more employees to provide .\n\n\nIn 2018, Afzali testified in support of legislation to extend tax credits to police officers in high-crime neighborhoods to .\n\nDuring her county executive campaign, Afzali said that she would freeze es in her first 100 days. She also said that she supported \"slower growth\" with less high-density development to keep the county from having to raise taxes.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sarah Siddiqui Wolek''' (born November 6, 1979) is an American politician who is a member of the  from .\n\n\nWolek was born in  and spent part of her childhood in . She grew up in  after her family moved so that her younger sibling could attend  programs, and graduated from . Wolek earned her  degree in economics and Bachelor of Science in information technology from the  (UMD), and later graduated from  with a  degree and from the  with a  degree in public policy.\n\n\nWolek worked for the federal government after graduating until shortly after the , working in positions including the , the , the , and the . In 2017, Wolek returned to UMD to teach classes and workshops focusing on purpose and character, community, relationships, nature, prosperity, and wellness.\n\nFrom 2018 to 2022, Wolek served as a member of the  Democratic Central Committee from District 16. In November 2018, she was named as a member of Montgomery County Executive-elect 's transition team. In December 2018, Wolek graduated from Emerge Maryland, a group dedicated to training and electing Democratic women to office.\n\nIn March 2023, Wolek was one of eighteen candidates to apply to fill a vacancy in the Maryland House of Delegates left by the appointment of then-delegate  to the . On March 21, the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee voted 16–8 to nominate her to serve the rest of Kelly's term.\n\n\nWolek was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on April 3, 2023. She is a member of the House Appropriations Committee. Wolek is the first  woman to serve in the .\n\n\nWolek is married to her husband, a  Polish immigrant. Together, they live in  and have three children.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Steven J. DeBoy Sr.''' (born January 2, 1956) is a  member of the , serving since 2003.\n\n\nDeboy graduated from the Baltimore County Police Academy in 1977. He holds a bachelor's degree in  from the University of Baltimore, and an associate degree in Criminal Justice from  Community College. \nHe served as a Baltimore County police officer and detective for 20 years, as the senior legislative assistant, to Baltimore County Councilman S.G. Samuel Moxley, and as a special investigator for the  Police Department.\n\n\nDelegate DeBoy has served on the Appropriations Committee, the Health and Human resources subcommittee, the oversight committee on personnel, the education subcommittee for the Baltimore County Delegation, and was the Vice-Chair for the Baltimore County Delegation in 2005. He is a member of the , the Task Force on the Exemption of Law Enforcement Officers' Pensions from Taxation.\n\n\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006(SB154)\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted in favor of increasing the sales tax whilst simultaneously reducing income tax rates for some income brackets – Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n* voted for the Maryland Gang Prosecution Act of 2007 (HB713), subjecting gang members to up to 20 years in prison and/or a fine of up to $100,000 \n* voted for Jessica's Law (HB 930), eliminating parole for the most violent child sexual predators and creating a mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in state prison, 2007 \n* voted for Public Safety – Statewide DNA Database System – Crimes of Violence and Burglary – Post conviction (HB 370), helping to give police officers and prosecutors greater resources to solve crimes and eliminating a backlog of 24,000 unanalyzed DNA samples, leading to 192 arrests, 2008 \n* voted for Vehicle Laws – Repeated Drunk and Drugged Driving Offenses – Suspension of License (HB 293), strengthening Maryland's drunk driving laws by imposing a mandatory one year license suspension for a person convicted of drunk driving more than once in five years, 2009 \n* voted for HB 102, creating the House Emergency Medical Services System Workgroup, leading to Maryland's budgeting of $52 million to fund three new Medevac helicopters to replace the State's aging fleet, 2009 \n\nFor the past four years, Delegate DeBoy has annually voted to support classroom teachers, public schools, police and hospitals in Baltimore and Howard Counties. Since 2002, funding to schools across the State has increased 82%, resulting in Maryland being ranked top in the nation for K-12 education.\n\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 12A''' Retrieved on Jan, 27th, 2008\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n\n\nHe is the son of Donald DeBoy and grandson of the late Ferdinand DeBoy (1904–1973) and Hazel Winslow DeBoy (1907–1996). He is a second cousin of actors  and , both of whom (like Delegate DeBoy) hail from the Farrell-DeBoy family of Baltimore, Maryland (PJ Is the grandson of the late James J. DeBoy Sr., a brother of Ferdinand DeBoy.).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Tom Hucker''' (born April 9, 1967) is an American elected official and a  from the  of . He served from 2007 until 2014 as a member of the  from District 20, which included neighborhoods in  and . He also previously served as a member of the Montgomery County Council, representing District 5 from 2014 to 2022.\n\n\nBorn in , Hucker graduated from .  He won a Gasson Scholarship to  and graduated with honors in 1988, majoring in biology, English, and philosophy.  There, he was prominent in efforts to end  and protect the environment.  He was twice elected to the Senate of the Undergraduate Government of Boston College, and was elected President of the Boston College  chapter and Treasurer of the statewide MASSPIRG Board of Directors.  For his senior thesis, he directed a statewide student lobbying effort to pass legislation strengthening Massachusetts' testing standards for drinking water.\n\nAfter graduation, Hucker continued his career as a public interest advocate by moving to  to work for the Fund for Public Interest Research.  There, he ran field campaigns for the United States Public Interest Research Group and the  to reauthorize the federal , the , the , and other federal legislation.  As a Regional Campaign Director, he supervised offices in the southern United States and later others along the east coast.\n\n\nHucker came to prominence in Maryland politics when he founded Progressive Maryland, an advocacy group, in 2001. The group brought together thousands of individual members in partnership with dozens of the state's largest community, labor, civil rights, and faith-based organizations into a single organization to improve the lives of working families in Maryland.  The group combined door-to-door organizing, grassroots leadership development, policy research, and face-to-face advocacy with lawmakers.\n\nIn that role, he authored and led successful campaigns to pass the Montgomery County  law in 2001, and the Prince George's County living wage law in 2002.  Both laws require most county contractors to pay their workers enough to feed their families without food stampsover 130% of the federal poverty level.\n\nAs an advocate in , he then authored and led efforts to pass the nation's first statewide living wage bill in 2004, which was vetoed after the legislative session by Gov. .  The bill was sponsored by Del. .\n\nRather than overriding Ehrlich's veto, House and Senate leaders instead decided to pursue a bill with a much larger impact on low-income workers by raising the state , the first time Maryland had passed a minimum wage higher than the federal standard.  The increase was estimated to produce a pay raise for 129,000 Maryland workers.\n\nAs director of Progressive Maryland, Hucker was recognized with the Friends of Latinos award by the Hispanic Democratic Club of Montgomery County, the Defenders of Justice award from the Maryland Alliance for Justice, and their Public Service award by the League of Korean Americans of Maryland.\n\nHucker was elected to his first term in the House of Delegates in 2006, after a four-month grassroots campaign.  He was endorsed by '','' which wrote that Hucker \"has proven most effective at getting good bills enacted\" (September 10, 2006).  Hucker was also endorsed by '''', the Montgomery County Education Association and the Montgomery Federation of Teachers, the Maryland , the , the Maryland Nurses Association, the Fraternal Order of Police, , the Montgomery County Career Fire Fighters Association/IAFF L. 1664, the Hispanic Democratic Club, the Coalition of Asian Pacific American Democrats (CAPAD-MD), the Alliance of Retired Americans, the Hispanic Democratic Club of Montgomery County, the Progressive Democrats of America, the Metropolitan Washington Council, AFL-CIO, and over 25 other organizations.\n\nIn January 2009, Hucker was charged with driving under the influence.\n\nHucker was elected to represent District 5 on the Montgomery County Council in November 2014 and re-elected in 2018. He is the Chair of the Council’s Transportation and Environment Committee and serves as a member of the Public Safety Committee.\n\n\nHucker served on the House Economic Matters Committee, and on its Consumer, Workers Compensation, and Insurance Subcommittees.  He previously served on the Environmental Matters Committee, and on its Environment, Natural Resources, and Land Use and Ethics Subcommittees.\n\nIn 2010, House Speaker  appointed Hucker the House Chair of the Joint Committee on Federal Relations, and Montgomery County Delegation Chair  appointed him to be the Chair of the Bi-County Affairs Committee, which regulates the  and the .\n\nIn April 2009, he was appointed to serve on the Climate, Energy, and Environment Policy Committee of the .\n\nIn June 2009, the  appointed Hucker to a new organization, State Legislators for Health Care Reform to provide policy advice and organize support for the President's national health care reform efforts.\n\nIn his first General Assembly session, Hucker authored and was co-lead sponsor of the first statewide living wage law in the nation.  The legislation received national media attention including this article in ''The New York Times''. The law required most state contractors to pay their workers wages high enough to feed their families without needing food stampsabout 130% of the federal poverty level (HB 430).\n\nIn 2009, Hucker passed HB 184 to require the state to finalize a plan to offer universal pre-Kindergarten for all Maryland four-year-olds, and HB 1263 to reduce mercury pollution by requiring auto manufacturers to pay to recycle mercury capsules in older American cars.  \nIn 2010, Hucker built on HB 184 by passing HB 350 to require the Maryland State Department of Education to apply for federal Early Education Challenge Grant support to expand pre-kindergarten in Maryland.  Also in 2010, he passed HB 1250  to significantly strengthen the state law against SLAPP (Strategic Lawsuits Against Public Participation) suits to protect environmentalists and civic activists from frivolous lawsuits intended to harass and intimidate.  He also successfully sponsored HB 1322  to fight human trafficking by requiring all hotels and motels that have been the site of prostitution or human trafficking to post a sign in every hotel room with information on human trafficking and the phone number of the National Human Trafficking Hotline.  The bill was a priority of the Maryland State Police, the Montgomery County Police, and the Women Legislators of Maryland.\n\nHucker has also sponsored legislation to expand health care access, ban arsenic from chicken feed, provide mental health services for veterans, facilitate offshore wind turbines, and ban discrimination in housing.\n\nHucker was recognized as a 100% Environmental Voter by the Maryland  and Environment Maryland.\n\nHe also received a 100% rating from , and has been a vocal advocate for marriage equality.\n\nHucker was also described as a \"Champion of Working Families\" by Progressive Maryland and received the highest score in the Maryland General Assembly.\n\nHucker served as the representative of the Maryland General Assembly on the Board of Directors of Purple Line Now!, an advocacy group organized to protect the environment and expand transit options by building a light rail line from Bethesda through Silver Spring, past the University of Maryland-College Park, and on to New Carrollton, Maryland.  The group led a successful organizing campaign that resulted in a decision by Gov. Martin O'Malley that the Purple Line would be a light rail line, following similar decisions by the state legislative delegations, County Executives, and County Councils in both Montgomery and Prince George's Counties.\n\nBecause of his years of successful advocacy inside and outside the General Assembly, Hucker also served on the board of directors of the , a national nonprofit that provides research and strategic advocacy tools to help state legislators to pass progressive policy reforms, including legislation to reward work, strengthen communities, and expand health care access.\n\nHucker endorsed Sen.  for President in 2007, months in advance of the Maryland Presidential Primary, and served on the Maryland for Obama Steering Committee.\n\n\nHucker was elected to serve on the Montgomery County Council in November 2014 to represent District 5 and was overwhelmingly re-elected in 2018. In 2019, he was elected by his colleagues to serve as Council Vice President alongside then-Council President Sidney Katz, and in December 2020, he was elected to serve a one-year term as Council President. Hucker serves as the Chair of the Council’s Transportation and Environment Committee and serves as a member of the Public Safety Committee. He also represents the County Council on the Board of Directors for the Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments, and as a Commissioner on the Washington Suburban Transit Commission.\n\nIn his first Council term, Hucker fought to reduce the achievement gap, invest in high-quality Pre-K and reduce class sizes. He voted to establish new after-school and full-day Head Start programs in Montgomery County Public Schools. Hucker helped lead the fight to guarantee paid sick leave for all workers in Montgomery County and voted to raise the minimum wage to $15/hour in 2017, which went into effect in 2021. Hucker has introduced and passed legislation aimed at increasing protections for tenants and families. In 2020, he introduced Ezechiel’s Law, a bill that requires landlords to install window guards for free for tenants with children under the age of 10. The bill was unanimously passed and went into effect in 2021. Hucker introduced and the Council unanimously passed Bill 50-20, a bill that requires landlords to monitor and maintain, and eventually replace, mercury service regulators in all residential buildings.\n\nAs the Council’s lead for the environment, Hucker passed bills to expand parks, protect drinking water, increase recycling, and expand solar energy. He has advocated for the expansion of public transit in Montgomery County, leading efforts to expand Ride-On Express on US-29 beginning May 2018, proposing and receiving funding for BRT on New Hampshire Avenue and the Burtonsville Access Road. As a member of the Public Safety Committee, he has led efforts to expand the use of body-worn cameras by Montgomery County police officers, including mandating that body cameras be activated when police are dealing with minors in all situations. In 2021, he introduced and passed a bill to expand review and oversight of body-worn camera footage and improve transparency in the reporting of serious police incidents. As Council President, he played a vital role in the county’s Covid-19 recovery, including organizing rallies to call for more emergency relief from the state and leading efforts to stand up a mass vaccination center in Montgomery County.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* in the \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Lauren Arikan''' (born December 14, 1984) is an American politician who has served as a  member of the  since 2019. She previously represented the  from 2019 to 2023, afterwards being redrawn into district 7B.\n\n\nArikan was born in  on December 14, 1984. She is a member of the  community. She attended  in  and the  in . Since 2009, she has worked at her family's businesses, Arikan Accounting and Tax, Arikan Acres, and Arikan Investments. She is married and lives on an eight-acre  and  farm in  with her husband, Yusuf, and their four children.\n\nArikan first got involved in politics in 2012 by becoming a member of the Board of Directors for the Maryland Friends of Midwives organization. From 2015 to 2018, she served as the chair of the Love Maryland PAC. In February 2018, Arikan filed to run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 7. She won the Republican primary with 13.6 percent of the vote, coming in third place in a field of thirteen candidates. She defeated Democrats Allison Berkowitz and Gordon Koerner and Green Party candidate Ryan Sullivan in the general election, receiving 23.3 percent of the vote.\n\n\nArikan was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. She was assigned to the Judiciary Committee by House Speaker . In 2021, she was elected to serve as vice president of the Women Legislators of Maryland caucus. She left the caucus in 2022 after its members voted to elect Delegate  as its new president over Arikan, who was in line to become its next president. Arikan is also a member of the Maryland Freedom Caucus.\n\nIn August 2021, Arikan filed a complaint with the  against , who had formed a  to raise money for his exploratory effort in the . Steele's campaign dismissed these allegations, calling them \"completely meritless\" and accusing Arikan of supporting  in the Republican primary. Arikan denied these claims, saying that she intended to stay \"completely out of the gubernatorial Republican primary\".\n\n\n\nIn March 2022, Arikan proposed an amendment to abortion rights legislation that would ban abortion services based on the gender of the fetus. The amendment failed by a vote of 40-86.\n\n\nIn March 2020, Arikan voted against a measure to kill legislation that would allow for liquor sales in Baltimore County on Sundays. The measure was approved by a vote of 14-4.\n\n\nArikan opposes  in schools. In August 2021, she attended an  rally outside a meeting for the .\n\nArikan introduced legislation during the 2021 legislative session that would allow parents living in districts that do not offer full in-person instruction by Fall 2021 to apply to receive the amount the state spends per child in public school to spend on  tuition.\n\nArikan opposed legislation introduced in the 2022 legislative session that would create an Institute for Public Leadership at the .\n\nIn April 2023, Arikan sent a letter to State Superintendent Mohammed Choudhury accusing the  of hiding scores from failing scores by altering data files available on the department's website. An investigation conducted by the state inspector general found no evidence of these claims.\n\n\nArikan supports the use of  in elections and placing restrictions on .\n\n\nArikan opposed legislation that would temporarily place restrictions on when landlords could evict their tenants until April 2022, and another that would guarantee low-income tenants a  in eviction cases, saying that she would sell her rental properties if the bills were enacted, instead investing in rental property in .\n\n\nIn May 2024, Arikan signed onto a letter condemning the jury's guilty verdict in the , calling the ruling a \"political prosecution from a kangaroo court and left-leaning prosecutor\" that is turning the U.S. justice system into a \"third world parody of law and order\".\n\n\nArikan supports  and is the founder of the Birth Circle of Baltimore.\n\nArikan opposed legislation that would ban threats made against health officials and hospital workers, saying that she received death threats during her first session in the General Assembly but \"nothing ever came of it\" after reporting it to law enforcement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Haines graduated from  and attended .\n\n\nHaines was a real estate broker and an appraiser and was a former dairy farmer. He was a member of the Maryland Association of Realtors (legislative committee, 1986–1990), chair of the Legislative Committee, Carroll County Association of Realtors, from 1986 to 1990, a member of the American Association of Certified Appraisers, and a director of the Bank of Maryland Carroll County.\n\nIn 1975, he received the Realtor of the Year award by the Carroll County Association of Realtors.\n\nHaines was a member of the Housing Study Committee for the city of  from 1974 to 1980, and a member of the Board of Zoning Appeals for the city of Westminster from 1983 to 1989.\n\n\nHaines died on January 13, 2024, at the age of 85.\n\n\n* '''2006 race for Maryland State Senate – District 5'''\n:\n\n* '''2002 race for Maryland State Senate – District 5'''\n:\n\n* '''1998 race for Maryland State Senate – District 5'''\n:\n\n* '''1994 race for Maryland State Senate – District 5'''\n:\n\n* '''1990 race for Maryland State Senate – District 5'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Mary Roe Walkup''' (born May 4, 1924) is an American former politician who was a delegate in the . She represented District 36, which covers , ,  and  Counties.\n\n\nFirst elected in 1994, she won one of two seats left open by R. Clayton Mitchell and C. Ronald Franks, serving alongside Wheeler R. Baker and Ronald A. Guns.  In 1998, delegates were elected by county, in which case Walkup defeated Democratic challenger Clarence Hawkins for the seat in .  In 2002, the election returned to the District selecting three delegates from the list.  She was one of three Republicans, the others being  and , that helped unseat incumbent Wheeler R. Baker.  Finally, in 2006, the election returned to voting for one candidate per county, and she won reelection by defeating Joan O. Horsey.\n\n\nWalkup attended Kent County public schools. She graduated from the  with her R.N. in 1945.\n\n\nAfter college, Walkup was a nurse at the  Hospital.  In 1978, she was elected to the Board of County Commissioners for Kent County, serving two terms, the second term as President.\n\nWalkup has also been a lifelong advocate of environmental matters.  She served for four years starting in 1982 as a delegate for the Legislative Committee on the Maryland Association of Counties. She is a charter member of Kent Conservation, Inc., as citizens' watchdog group founded in 1969 that focuses on environmental issues in Kent County.\n\nWalkup is also a member of the Kent Chapter of the , Kent County Farm Bureau, the  Association, the  Land Conservancy, and the Maryland Conservation Council. In 1977, she received the Conservationist of the Year from the Maryland Wildlife Federation.\n\n\nAs a member of the , Walkup served on the Economic Matters Committee beginning in 1995, and several other subcommittees.\n\n\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted for  in 1999 (HB703)\n* voted for income tax reduction in 1998 (SB750)\n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36 - Kent County''' Retrieved on Sept. 30, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36 - Kent County''' Retrieved on Sept. 30, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose one for each county:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 36''' Retrieved on Sept. 30, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Yvette Lewis''' (born 1952/1953) is an American political executive and activist who served as the chair of the  from 2011 to 2015 and 2019 to 2023.\n\n\nLewis is a professional opera singer and lives in . She served as chair of the  from 2011 to 2015. She was a  at the . She reassumed her role as party chair in December 2019, succeeding acting chair , and served until October 6, 2023. Lewis was succeeded by acting chair Everett Browning.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Justin D. Ready''' ( ; born April 15, 1982) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  since 2015, representing  in . He previously represented the district in the  from 2011 to 2015.\n\n\nReady was born in , but moved to , at the age of 11 after living in . He graduated from  in 2002, and afterwards attended , where he earned a  degree in political science in 2004.\n\n\nReady became interested in politics at a young age. After graduating from Salisbury, working as a field director on the  of . He later worked as a legislative aide to state delegate  from 2004 to 2006, afterwards working as the chief of staff for state senator .\n\nIn April 2008, the  named Ready as its executive director, replacing John Flynn. He served in this position until July 2009, when he was fired by party chairman James Pelura for \"personnel reasons\". Ready's firing eventually led to the removal of Pelura as chairman of the Maryland Republican Party. Ready later served as an interim executive director from July to December 2011.\n\nAlso in 2008, Ready unsuccessfully ran for delegate to the , pledged to .\n\n\nOn January 5, 2010, Ready announced that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 5A, challenging incumbent state delegates  and . He won the Republican primary, placing first with 39.3 percent of the vote, and later defeated Democrats Francis X. Walsh and Sharon L. Baker in the general election alongside Stocksdale. Ready was sworn in on January 12, 2011, and served as a member of the Health and Government Operations Committee. He ran for re-election to a second term in . Ready was a member of 's Change Maryland organization, and later served Hogan's transition team following his upset victory in the .\n\nIn 2011, Ready served as a co-chair for 's  in Maryland. He later ran for delegate to the  pledged to Perry, receiving 1.2 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn January 2015, following the resignation of state senator  to serve as the chief legislative officer to Governor , Ready applied to fill the vacancy left by Getty in the Maryland Senate. The Carroll County Republican Central Committee nominated Ready alongside Dave Wallace and County Commissioner Robin Bartlett Frazier to fill the seat. Hogan appointed Ready to the seat on February 2, and he was sworn in on the same day. Ready was elected to a full four-year term in .\n\nReady served as a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee from 2015 to 2021, afterwards serving on the Finance Committee. In October 2021, Ready was elected to serve as the Senate minority whip.\n\nDuring the , Ready participated in organizing activities for . He celebrated 's win in the , calling it a \"pretty stunning repudiation of , and the establishment, the media establishment, and sort of the coasts\".\n\nReady endorsed Maryland Secretary of Commerce  in the . After Schulz was defeated by far-right state delegate  in the Republican primary, Ready endorsed Cox, claiming that he would act as a counter on progressive legislation passed by the legislature.\n\n\nDuring his tenure in the Maryland House of Delegates, Ready was a member of the legislature's  caucus. In January 2020, the  gave Ready a score of 76 percent on its annual legislative scorecard, the highest score among members of the Maryland Senate.\n\n\nIn the Maryland Senate, Ready repeatedly introduced and supported bills to increase penalties on violent crimes, including those involving guns. He has called  \"out of control and destabilizing our entire region\", and has expressed skepticism on claims that gun control would decrease violent crime.\n\nDuring the 2015 legislative session, Ready introduced a bill to increase penalties for human trafficking. The bill was withdrawn after activists expressed concerns that the bill's definition of \"trafficker\" was too broad.\n\nIn 2019, Ready introduced \"Laura and Reid's Law\", a bill to increase penalties for murdering a pregnant woman. The bill was named after Laura Wallen, a pregnant woman who was allegedly murdered by her boyfriend in September 2017. The bill passed and was signed into law by Governor Larry Hogan. He also introduced a bill that would prohibit courts from authorizing  for an individual accused of assaulting a police officer.\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Ready expressed concerns with and voted against Governor 's appointment of  as , pointing to the Schiraldi's controversial approach to reducing juvenile crime amid the state's \"crisis in juvenile crime\".\n\n\nIn May 2015, Ready defended Governor Larry Hogan's decision to withhold $68 million in funding for Maryland's costliest public school systems, saying that the state needed to restrain its growth spending to settle its fiscal issues.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Ready defended Governor Larry Hogan's  requiring public schools to start after , claiming that the order resulted in \"incredibly good\" economic effects.\n\nIn October 2019, Ready expressed skepticism with the 's recommendations, also known as the , comparing them to the recommendations made by the Thornton Commission and arguing that it would be better to address  deficits in education locally rather than raising education funding statewide. He later voted against the Blueprint bill, arguing that it would have a significant negative impacts on the state's economy.\n\nIn February 2022, Ready signed onto a letter to the  imploring the agency to rescind its  in schools, falsely claiming that masks were ineffective at limiting the spread of .\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Ready introduced a bill to establish the \"fundamental right to parents' rights\" in education.\n\n\nIn 2016, Ready opposed a bill to automatically register people to vote when getting their driver's license at the .\n\nIn March 2019, Ready said he supported Governor Larry Hogan's proposed redraw of Maryland's congressional mapswhich saw  redrawn to include  and  counties, thereby making it more favorable to Republicansfollowing the 's decision in ''''. In June 2021, Ready participated in hearings for Hogan's Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission, during which he advocated for districts that broke up communities as little as possible. He criticized the redrawn congressional districts passed by the legislature during the 2021 special legislative session, calling it \"incredibly ed\".\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ready introduced a bill to require voters to show a government-issued  before casting a ballot, citing what he called \"major deficiencies\" in the . The bill was reintroduced in 2022. In August 2024, Ready endorsed the , a federal bill that would require voters to show  when registering to vote.\n\n\nDuring the 2018 legislative session, Ready said he supported a bill to repeal several sections of the Firearms Safety Act, including a ban on s.\n\nIn 2019, Ready said he opposed a bill to abolish the state's Handgun Permit Review Board, which handled conceal carry applications. In June 2022, he celebrated the 's ruling in '''', which overturned Maryland's concealed carry laws. In 2023, Ready said he opposed the Gun Safety Act, a gun control bill that increased requirements to obtain a handgun permit and limited where guns could be publicly carried following the ''Bruen'' decision, saying that he anticipated the bill's \"fiery end by the court\" if passed.\n\n\nReady supports efforts to repeal .\n\nDuring the 2017 legislative session, Ready said he opposed a bill requiring companies to provide employees with five days of  per year, which he claimed would exacerbate income inequality.\n\nIn 2019, Ready criticized the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults.\n\n\nReady supported  in 2012, which sought to repeal , a bill that extended  for , saying that the bill made Maryland appear as a .\n\nIn 2014, Ready condemned a proposal to house immigrant children at a former  Center in , and blamed the increase in immigrant children on President 's immigration policies.\n\nIn 2017, Ready supported the Trust Act, a bill that would prohibit police from asking about a detainee's immigration or citizenship status. During the 2020 legislative session, he introduced legislation that would require state correctional facilities to cooperate with  (ICE), accusing detention centers in  and  counties of defying ICE requests. In 2021, Ready opposed the Dignity Not Detention Act, a bill that would end all contracts between state correctional facilities and ICE, arguing that it would make communities less safe.\n\nIn 2021, Ready said he opposed a bill to extend the state's  to non-citizens. In 2023, during debate on a bill to make the tax credit permanent, Ready introduced an amendment to phase out the credit for non-citizens, which was rejected in a 14-33 vote.\n\n\nReady describes himself as being pro-police, but supports citizen oversight over the police and military. He has criticized police reform bills passed by the  during the 2021 legislative session, including a bill regulating  policies, which he called the \"most dangerous provision in the police bill package\".\n\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Ready introduced a bill that would allow police departments to negotiate contracts to purchase s, citing the state's 2025 deadline to have on-duty officers wearing body cameras. He also criticized a bill to give the  sole prosecutorial power over police-involved incidents, imploring legislators to instead pass bills to deal with violent crime.\n\n\nDuring the 2012 legislative session, Ready voted against the , which legalized . He later supported a  aimed at repealing the law, saying that he believed that the \"institution of marriage\" was between a man and a woman. In 2022, he defended a Carroll County Board of Education policy banning s in schools. During the 2024 legislative session, Ready opposed a bill to provide legal protections to health care providers that provide  to out-of-state patients, arguing that it would expand access to gender-affirming care to minors.\n\nIn December 2018, Ready signed onto an amicus brief in the  case '''' defending the cross-shaped  monument in .\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Ready voted against a bill to raise the age to buy tobacco and nicotine products from 18 to 21, calling it \"government overreach\".\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ready introduced legislation that would give college athletes the right to profit off their names and likenesses. The bill passed and became law.\n\nIn March 2022, Ready said he opposed a bill to provide $3.5 million toward training medical professionals to provide abortions, calling it \"reckless and wrong\". During the 2023 legislative session, Ready sought to amend a bill creating a  on codifying abortion access into the  to include a provision protecting the right to make reproductive decisions without being coerced by health care providers. The amendment was rejected.\n\n\nReady is married and has two children.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| children        = 2\n| profession      = Paralegal and journalist\n| signature       =\n| footnotes       =\n}}\n\n'''Carmen Michael Amedori''' (November 25, 1955 – June 9, 2024) was an American journalist and politician. She was elected in 1998 to the  for District 5A, from .  After being re-elected in 2002 she served in the  until 2004, when she was appointed by Governor  to the state Parole Commission where she served until 2009. Amedori was a background actor and had a featured extra role on  and also played the lead in productions with Siren's Media. She was a writer and a licensed realtor.\n\n\nCarmen M. Amedori was born on November 25, 1955, in Maryland to an Italian family. She attended parochial and public schools. She graduated in 1977 from  (then Villa Julie College). She also attended the .\n\n\nAmedori worked as a paralegal for many years before becoming a . She wrote for '','' the '' and ''  Among other awards, she received the Distinguished Journalism Award from the Society of Professional Journalists.\n\nShe was appointed as a district court commissioner for Carroll County District 10, serving from 1991 to 1993. Amedori was a member of the Maryland Taxpayers' Association, the National Association of Legal Assistance, Citizens Against Government Waste, Citizens Against Big Charter Government, and Americans for Tax Reform. In 1998 she was serving as chairperson of the Carroll County Charter Board which she later led the charge to defeat.\n\nAmedori was elected twice to the Maryland House of Delegates (1998 and 2002).  While in the State House she served on the House Judiciary Committee, where she was ranking member in 2004.  She also had the distinction of serving as assistant minority leader, as well as a minority whip.\n\nIn June 2004, the governor appointed her to a six-year term on the Maryland Parole Commission. In February 2010, Amedori announced her candidacy for US Senator, running against incumbent senator , who had been serving for many years.  Amedori dropped her bid for the Senate on April 16, 2010, announcing she would run for the office of Lieutenant Governor of Maryland, on the  ticket with Maryland gubernatorial candidate .\n\nTwo weeks later Amedori left the Murphy ticket, endorsing former Maryland Governor , Murphy's opponent in the Republican primary. She argued that Ehrlich had the best chance to beat current Maryland Governor  in the general election. She said, \"If there was going to be a loss to O'Malley, let it be Bob's loss.\"\n\nThat year Amedori moved from Carroll County to Maryland's Lower Eastern Shore to be with her 89-year-old father. On September 14, 2010, Amedori was elected to the  Republican Central Committee.  She also served as Campaign Manager to a conservative candidate for the House of Delegates in State District 38B.  Carmen returned to Carroll County in October 2013 where she had been a resident for 32 years and to the City of Westminster where she was a homeowner for 14 years.\n\n\n*Sponsored Parental Notification and Judicial-bypass legislation\n*Pro-Second Amendment, lead sponsor on CCW bills, as well as right to protect property legislation\n*Fiscal Conservative\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 5A''' Retrieved on Sept. 11, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 5A''' Retrieved on Sept. 11, 2007\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\nIn 1977, Amedori married Robert DePaola; they had two daughters together, After some years, they divorced. Amedori later married attorney Jerry F. Barnes, who then became State's Attorney in Carroll County Maryland. Carmen was later married to Timothy Headley of .\n\nAmedori died at her home in  on June 9, 2024, at the age of 68.\n\n\n*''School Bell Award, Maryland State Teachers' Association, 1988 (sustained coverage)''\n*''1989 (spot news).     "pages": }\n'''Susan Wolf Turnbull''' (born November 2, 1952) is an American politician. She was the  nominee for  in the , alongside candidate for governor . Previously, she served as chair of the  and vice chair of the .\n\n\nTurnbull earned a  degree in  from , a  in community services and urban affairs from the , and a  in  from the .\n\n\nTurnbull was a member of the  board of directors from 2008 to 2012. Turnbull serves on the board of the University of Maryland Institute for Citizenship and Politics and the board of the  of Greater , D.C. She also served as chair of  from 2009 to 2013 and has been a member of the Council of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations since 2009.\n\nFrom 1992 to 2011, Turnbull was a member of the  (DNC), serving as vice chair from 2005 to 2009 and deputy chair from 2003 to 2005. Previously, she was the chair of both the DNC Women's  and DNC Women's Leadership Forum. From 2009 to 2011, Turnbull chaired the  and led the Maryland Democrats to a reelection victories for  governor  and Senator . She was a principal speaker at events in more than 35 states and several foreign countries on behalf of the DNC and three . She previously served as the chair of the  .\n\nOn November 29, 2017, , candidate for the Democratic nomination for , announced the selection of Turnbull as his .\n\n\nTurnbull lives in , with her husband Bruce, an attorney.     "pages": }\n'''Craig Lamont Rice''' (born September 27, 1972) is an American politician and former member of the , serving from 2010 to 2022. Elected in 2006 to the , he served one four-year term and represented District 15 in western and northern .\n\n\nRice was born in a  hospital but raised in the suburbs of . He graduated from . He attended the , majoring in . Following a family tragedy, Rice returned home and transferred to , where he majored in .\n\nPrior to entering politics, Rice was a senior sales manager for .\n\n\nHe is married to Tineshia \"Tia\" Rice, the owner of AnaLyn Studio Salon located in downtown Bethesda. He is father of three children, Alex, Anaiya, and Caelyn.\n\n\nRice was elected in 2006 to serve in the state house with incumbents  and , defeating incumbent , Montgomery County's lone Republican representative. He served on the House Ways and Means Committee and the Montgomery County delegation's Land Use and Transportation Committee. While in the legislature, Rice worked as a business development consultant for the government of Puerto Rico.\n\nIn 2010, Rice won a five-way Democratic primary for Montgomery County Council, District 2. He defeated Republican  in the General Election. This, at the time, made him the youngest African American to serve on the Council and only the second African American man to serve in that role. Rice served on the Council's Education Committee and the Health and Human Services Committee, becoming Chair of the Education Committee in 2013. In 2013, Rice was elected the Council President, succeeding .\n\nRice was re-elected to the County Council in 2014. In 2015, Rice began organizing Education Budget Forums throughout the County. Rice was appointed to the Kirwan Commission on public education in Maryland, where he chairs the commission’s work group on early childhood education.\n\nRice was re-elected to a third term on the County Council in 2018. Rice has received many awards over the course of his career. In 2018 he received the 2018 Metropolitan Kappa Youth Foundation Cornerstone Award for Education and Leadership.\n\nIn 2019, Rice received The Montgomery County Board of Education’s Award for Distinguished Service to Public Education Community Individual.\n\n\n*'''2018 Race for Montgomery County Council – District 2'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 Race for Montgomery County Council – District 2'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2010 Race for Montgomery County Council – District 2'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 15'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Denise Roberts''' (born September 4, 1973) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  representing  since 2024.\n\n\nRoberts was born in  on September 4, 1973. She graduated from  before attending , where she earned a  degree in radio, television, and film in 1995, and , where she earned a  degree in public relations, advertising, and communications in 2002.\n\nRoberts has run her own photography business, D. Geneva Photography, since 2002, and has worked as a television host for Prince George's Community Television's ''Level Up'' since 2014. She was also involved with advocating for local small businesses, served as vice president of her local , and in leadership of a local coffee club within the .\n\nRoberts previously worked as a spokesperson for Prince George's County Executive  from 2005 to 2009. In 2018, she unsuccessfully ran for Clerk of the Circuit Court in , placing second with 30.7 percent of the vote behind Mahasin El Amin. Following her defeat, Roberts worked as the communications director for Prince George's County State's Attorney . In 2022, she ran for the Prince George's County Council in District 6, placing second with 27.6 percent of the vote behind Wala Blegay.\n\n\nIn December 2023, following the appointment of state delegate  to the , Roberts applied to serve the remainder of Charles' term in the Maryland House of Delegates. Her nomination was backed by Charles and state delegate . The Prince George's County Democratic Central Committee voted to nominate her to the seat later that month. She was sworn in on January 8, 2024.\n\n\nRoberts has two children.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Susan L. M. Aumann''' (born July 1, 1960), is a member of the , District 42.\n\n\nSusan Aumann is a former member of the , represent District 42, which is a portion of  in . She served this district along with fellow Republican  and Democrat .\n\nPrior to 2002, District 42 was represented by Democrats , , and . However, after the district lines were redrawn, McIntosh moved to District 43 and Rosenberg moved to District 41, where they both won reelection.  On the other hand, Campbell remained in District 42, but was defeated by a host of new Republicans, including Aumann, , and . In 2006, Aumann won reelection, along with . Incumbent Trueschler did not run for reelection.  In his stead, Democrat  won his seat.\n\n\nAumann attended , an all-girls preparatory school in Towson. After high school, she attended the , receiving her B.A. in business administration & management in 1983. Continuing her education, she attended the .\n\n\nMuch of Aumann's career has been focused on accounting.  She was a sales associate at Valley Motors, a car dealership in  from 1983 until 1985, when she became a loan counselor with First Financial Federal Credit Union, in nearby , where she worked for a year. Soon thereafter, she worked as a private banking account executive for the Bank of Baltimore, working there from 1987 until 1988. In 1988, she took a position as a staff accountant for Ira J. Sugar & Associates, where she worked until 1989. In 1989, Aumann began working for MNC Financial, which was bought by , where she stayed for several years. She later worked for Congressman , first as a Financial Operations Officer and Treasurer, then as Finance Operations Officer and Treasurer for his \"Bob Ehrlich for Maryland Committee\" where she stayed until 2002.\n\nAumann was a member of the Baltimore County Republican Central Committee from 1994 until 1998 and the North Central Republican Club from 1990 until 1999. Other groups where she is a member include the Loch Raven Watershed Coalition, Shepherd's Knoll Condominium Association, the Historic Hampton, Inc. in  and the Women's Committee of Hampton.\n\nAs a member of the , she was a member of the Appropriations Committee, the Joint Audit Committee, the Joint Committee on the Management of Public Funds, the Special Joint Committee on Pensions, and the Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics. From 2007, she was a Deputy Minority Whip.\n\n\nShe is married to R. Karl Aumann, former Secretary of State for Maryland under Gov. Ehrlich. The couple has two children.\n\n\n* voted for slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted for Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted for the Clean Indoor Air Act of 2007 (HB359)\n* voted against in-state tuition for illegal immigrants (HB6)\n\n\n*'''2006 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42'''; retrieved October 1, 2007.\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 42'''; retrieved October 1, 2007.\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Obie Patterson''' (born March 7, 1938) is an American politician. He was previously a  member of the  from the  in . He served on the Prince George's County Council representing District 8, and in the  representing the 26th district.\n\n\nPatterson was born in  on March 7, 1938. He attended  in , where he earned a  degree in biology in 1965, and the , where he earned a  degree in public administration in 1971. After graduating, he served in a variety of roles at the .\n\n\nPatterson was a member of House of Delegates from January 11, 1995, and to January 10, 2007. He served as the Chair of the  from 2002 to 2004. In 2006, Patterson unsuccessfully ran for Maryland Senate in District 26, losing to former state Delegate  in the Democratic primary by a 55%-45% margin.\n\nIn 2010, Patterson was elected to serve on the Prince George's County Council in District 8. Termed out of running for re-election, he ran for the Maryland Senate in 2018, seeking to succeed C. Anthony Muse, who decided against running for another term to run for  of Prince George's County.\n\nIn September 2018, the Prince George's County Republican Party filed an ethics complaint against Patterson, claiming that his county government staff used a government email address to distribute an invitation to a reception featuring Democratic  . He won the general election in November 2018 with 92.5 percent of the vote and was sworn in on January 9, 2019. Later that month,   appointed Patterson to serve as the deputy majority whip of the Senate Democratic Caucus.\n\nOn April 6, 2022, he announced that he would not seek re-election to the Maryland Senate.\n\n\n\nPatterson opposed Governor Larry Hogan's proposal to construct a pro football stadium on a large parcel of federal land in , saying \"I don't know how anyone can think about bringing the  there without some drastic increase in better transportation\".\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Patterson voted for the Climate Solutions Now Act, saying that he \"reluctantly\" supported the legislation. In the same year, he introduced various environmental bills, including:\n* Senate Bill 70, which would require the state to establish uniform standards for mold assessment and remediation\n* Senate Bill 121, which would require the Commission on Environmental Justice and Sustainable Communities to develop policy recommendations on clan energy projects and investments to benefit low-income communities\n* Senate Bill 151, which would amend the Maryland State Constitution to establish a right to a healthy environment\n\n\nDuring the 2006 legislative session, Patterson voted to override Governor 's veto of the Fair Share Health Care Fund Act, which would require  to pay more for employee health care.\n\nDuring the 2019 legislative session, Patterson refused to cast a vote on the End-of-Life Option Act, which would have provided  to terminally ill adults, causing the bill to die in a tied 23–23 vote. On his decision not to vote, Patterson said he had no regrets about decision, adding, \"I did not cast a vote simply because I could not bring myself to move right or left on the bill and therefore I didn't vote on all. I don't know if it is [a violation of Senate rules] but I had to vote my conscience and that's what I did\". In 2020, when the bill was reintroduced, Patterson said that he would cast a vote if the bill came up for a vote again, but did not say how he planned to vote.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Patterson introduced legislation that would allow police officers to arrest a person based on witness testimony and video evidence. Patterson voted in favor of the General Assembly's police reform package.\n\n\nDuring the 2001 legislative session, Patterson voted in favor of legislation to implement a two-year moratorium on Maryland's use of . The bill passed the Maryland House of Delegates by a vote of 82–54. He also voted in favor of legislation to add gays and lesbians to the state's anti-discrimination law, which passed in a 88–50 vote.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Patterson introduced legislation that would rename  after former  . The bill died in the Maryland Senate after its first reading a month later. He also introduced a bill that would replace  with .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
