    "pages": }\n\n'''George William Owings III''' (April 11, 1945 – October 31, 2023) was an American politician. He served as the Secretary of the  from 2004 to 2007 and from 2015 to 2023. He served as a member of the  in  and  from 1988 to 2004.\n\n\nGeorge William Owings III was born on April 11, 1945, in , to Mary (née Maxwell) and  His father was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates in 1938 and later served as chief clerk in 1956. Owings attended  in . He attended the , from 1963 to 1964, afterwards serving in the  as a  in the . He graduated from  in 1978 with an  in liberal arts.\n\n\nOwings worked as a mortgage banker with Residential Financial Corporation. He was a member of the . He ran twice for commissioner of , but lost. He was appointed by Governor  as a member of the , succeeding  in January 1988. He represented  from 1988 to 1994 and  from 1995 to 2004. He also served as the House Majority Whip from 1994 to 2004, lobbying for issues including legalizing s.\n\nOwings was appointed the Secretary of the  on March 18, 2004, by Governor . He remained in that role until January 17, 2007. He then served as acting secretary until May 9, 2007, when Governor  appointed  to succeed him.\n\nIn July 2009, Owings said he was exploring a run against O'Malley in the Democratic primary of the . He announced his candidacy in January 2010, and ran on a platform criticizing O'Malley for raising taxes, cutting the state's budget, and repealing the death penalty. Owings dropped out of the race on July 1, 2010, after undergoing a major surgery.\n\nIn March 2014, Owings filed to run for county commissioner in Calvert County. He placed first in the Democratic primary, but was defeated by Republicans Steve Weems and Tom Hejl in the general election.\n\n\nIn December 2014, Governor-elect  announced that he would appoint Owings as Secretary of the Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs. He took office on January 22, 2015, and was sworn in on February 13. He served in that role until the end of Hogan's tenure as governor. Following the end of his tenure, state inspectors released a series of reports documenting allegations of abuse and neglect at the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home, the state's only veterans home, which Owings said he was first made aware of in \"late 2021, early 2022\" and had never discussed the conditions at the veterans home with Hogan. He faulted the  for straining resources at Charlotte Hall, but said that he would \"take the blame\" for the issues. The Maryland General Assembly passed legislation to increase oversight over the Charlotte Hill Veterans Home in response to these reports in 2023, and the  voted to award a $159 million contract with PruittHealth to oversee the veterans home.\n\nOwings was director of Operation Raise the Roof, a veteran outreach program.\n\n\nOwing was married to his wife, Louise Carroll, whom he later divorced. Together, they had one son. His partner was Katherine Marie Boyd.\n\nOwings died at his home in Calvert County on October 31, 2023, at age 78. Following the news of his death, Governor Larry Hogan and  expressed their condolences. His funeral was attended by Hogan, Bob Ehlrich, U.S. Representative , and Maryland Veterans Affairs Secretary .\n\nOwings' decorations and medals include the ,  with Bronze Star Device,  and the  with Silver Star Device.\n\n\n\nDuring the 1991 legislative session, Owings introduced legislation to create financial penalties for hunting or killing a . In 1999, he proposed a bill to make animal cruelty a felony offense, which was watered down in committee.\n\n\nDuring the 2000 legislative session, Owings opposed legislation requiring built-in locks for all new handguns.\n\n\nDuring the 1991 legislative session, Owings voted against a bill creating a referendum on codifying the right to abortion into the . In 1997, he introduced legislation banning \"\". In 2003, Owings sought to amend the state budget to remove $2.5 million for -funded abortions.\n\nDuring the 1998 legislative session, Owings introduced legislation that would make it optional for adults to wear a helmet while riding a motorcycle. The bill was rejected in committee.\n\nIn 2000, Owings introduced a bill that would allow students to volunteer a prayer during graduation ceremonies.\n\nDuring the 2001 legislative session, Owings voted against legislation banning .\n\nIn September 2019, Owings ordered the removal of a plaque put up the by  to honor , a Confederate Navy officer who had attended the .\n\n\nDuring the 2004 legislative session, Owings voted against a bill to raise $1 billion in sales and income taxes to pay for education reforms.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Paul D. Corderman''' (born September 1, 1977) is an American politician from  and a member of the . He is a member of the  from District 2, which covers parts of , assuming office on September 1, 2020. He was a member of the  from District 2B from December 2017 to August 2020.\n\n\nCorderman was born on September 1, 1977, in  to , a member of the  and circuit court judge. He graduated from  in 1995, and later attended the , where he earned a  degree in criminal justice in 2000.\n\n\nCorderman first got involved in politics following the death of his father in July 2012.\n\nIn 2016, Corderman ran for the Hagerstown City Council on a platform of increasing grants and tax incentives and cutting regulations. He was sworn in on November 29, 2016. Corderman resigned from the city council to serve in the Maryland House of Delegates on December 19, 2017. He was succeeded by Charles Austin Heffernan Jr.\n\n\nIn November 2017, following Governor 's appointment of state delegate  to the Washington County Circuit Court, Corderman applied to serve the remainder of Wilson's term in the Maryland House of Delegates. In December 2017, the Washington County Republican Central Committee voted to nominate Corderman to fill the seat, and Hogan appointed Corderman to the Maryland House of Delegates later that month. He was sworn in on December 20, 2017. Corderman was elected to a full four-year term in .\n\n\nIn August 2020, following the resignation of state senator , Corderman said he would apply to serve the remainder of Serafini's term in the Maryland Senate. The Washington County Republican Central Committee nominated Corderman to fill the vacancy on August 26, and Hogan appointed him to the Maryland Senate the following day. He was sworn in on September 1, 2020. Since 2023, Corderman has served as the ranking chair of the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee.\n\nCorderman ran for a full full-year term in the Maryland Senate in . During the primaries, he filed a lawsuit against Democratic challenger Shawn Demetrious Perry, alleging that Perry was ineligible to run because he did not live within the district. In June 2022, Circuit Court Judge Dana Moylan Wright denied Corderman's challenge to Perry's candidacy. Corderman defeated Perry in the general election on November 8, 2022, receiving 63.8 percent of the vote to Perry's 36.1 percent.\n\n\nCorderman is married to his wife, Kerri. Together, they have a daughter.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Corderman introduced the \"Suzanne Jones Act\", named for a woman stabbed to death in Hagerstown in October 2017, that would require state  to release prisoners back into the communities where they lived before incarceration. The bill failed to pass out of committee. In April 2020, he signed onto a letter questioning the early release of prisoners amid the .\n\nIn September 2020, Corderman signed onto a letter calling for the cancellation of hearings on police reform, expressing concerns that the hearings would demoralize police officers.\n\n\nCorderman supports the Broadening Options and Opportunities for Students Today (BOOST) program, which provides scholarships to students attending s, and criticized funding cuts to the program in the state's 2019 budget.\n\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Corderman introduced legislation to increase  reimbursements for .\n\nIn August 2022, Corderman criticized a proposal by Mayor Emily Keller to locate a 24-hour crisis center in downtown Hagerstown, saying that it was contributing to the \"disintegration and degradation of our downtown community\". He also said he opposed bills decriminalizing certain drug-related violations in Maryland.\n\n\nIn January 2017, Corderman said he opposed plans to redevelop Noland Village in Hagerstown, saying it would worsen the city's various socioeconomic issues, including the . He later voted against a  with Bethel Gardens, a low-income housing complex in downtown Hagerstown.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Corderman introduced legislation that would provide  to health care workers following the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nIn 2023, Corderman introduced a bill that would prohibit Washington County from charging an .\n\n\nCorderman supports the expansion of  and has called for increased state funding toward the project.\n\nDuring the 2020 legislative session, Corderman introduced a bill requiring a study on expanding  commuter rail lines to  and , which passed and became law. He was also the only Republican state delegate to vote in favor of a bill increasing state transit maintenance spending by $500 million.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert Julian Ivey''' (born August 3, 1995) is an American politician serving as a member of the  from  in .\n\n\nIvey was born in , to  and  in 1995. His father is currently a member of Congress and his mother currently serves on the  Council. As a sixth grader, Ivey starred in the Broadway production of '''', singing and dancing in the role of young . He graduated from  in 2013. In 2018, he received a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science from the , where he was a member of the campus'  chapter and led protests over campus police tactics and campus racism.\n\n\nDuring the , Ivey was elected to and attended the  as a delegate for , and supported  after she was nominated as candidate by the Democratic Party.\n\nIn May 2017, Ivey was elected to the  town council. During his first year on the town council, he introduced and passed legislation to designate the town a .\n\nIn 2018, Ivey ran for the Maryland House of Delegates in District 47A, challenging incumbent state delegate . During the primary, he received endorsements from state senator , the local , and state comptroller .\n\nDuring the , Ivey campaigned for former NAACP president . In May 2018, Ivey accused Jealous of trying to keep him off the Democratic primary ballot to improve his own chances and those of Tarlau, who endorsed Jealous' gubernatorial campaign. Valerie Ervin, then-candidate for lieutenant governor, similarly claimed Jealous tried to keep her off that ticket by contacting her employer, the national . Jealous denied Ivey's claims, sharing text messages between him and Ivey where he told Ivey “hang in there. . . We are political family.”\n\nIvey defeated Tarlau in the Democratic primary in June, placing second behind incumbent state delegate  with 32.5 percent of the vote to Tarlau's 29.6 percent. He was unopposed in the general election.\n\nIn January 2020, Ivey was elected vice chair of the . In January 2023,   appointed Ivey Deputy Majority Whip, as well as Vice-Chair of the Public Safety & Administration Subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee.\n\nIvey was campaign manager for his father Glenn Ivey's successful 2022 bid for the Democratic nomination to represent  in the .\n\n\n\nIvey was sworn into the Maryland House of Delegates on January 9, 2019. He was assigned to the House Ways and Means Committee and serves on its Financial Resources and Local Revenues subcommittees. Ivey is a member of the . Media outlets have described Ivey as a progressive.\n\n\n\nIn June 2020, Ivey started a petition calling on leaders of the Maryland General Assembly and governor  to reconvene for a special legislative session on the , evictions, and police brutality. For each day following the petition, Ivey posted  highlighting victims of police brutality. The legislative leaders rejected calls to form a special session, but convened workgroups on creating legislation on issues including police reform. In September, Ivey wrote an op-ed for '''' that again called for a special legislative session. House Majority Leader  rebuked the op-ed in an internal memo, calling it \"tremendously disrespectful to the Speaker of the House\" to push for a special session in the press without first checking in with Jones and other colleagues.\n\nAlso in June 2020, Ivey co-signed a letter penned by Speaker Jones that called on Hogan to enact reforms surrounding police use of force policies in the state.\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ivey introduced legislation that would require all Maryland law enforcement agencies to issue  to all on-duty officers by 2022.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ivey introduced legislation to abolish the appointed members of the Prince George's County Board of Education. The bill died without a vote.\n\n\nDuring the 2021 legislative session, Ivey introduced legislation that would automatically send out mail-in ballots to all registered voters.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 legislative session, Ivey introduced legislation that would exempt diabetic care products from the sales and use tax. The bill passed and became law on April 1, 2022.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Mary Ann Lisanti''' (born October 27, 1967) is an  and a member of the , who represented  in the . Previously she represented district F on the  Council, representing , ,  and .  In January 2014 Lisanti filed to run for the  and to not seek a 3rd term on the County Council. In early March 2019, the House of Delegates unanimously censured Lisanti for a racial slur directed at the African-American majority , with her own county's Democratic Party calling for her resignation.\n\n\n\nLisanti entered the race for Delegate in district 34A after much speculation that she might run for the seat left open when Delegate  decided to run for .  On June 24, 2014 Lisanti led the Democratic primary by nearly 10 percentage points, with Marla Posey-Moss coming in second, after a heavily contested race with five candidates vying for two seats.  Lisanti and Posey-Moss faced Republicans  and Mike Blizzard in the General election in November. Glass and Lisanti finished 1 and 2, thus gaining election.\n\n\nOn February 26, 2019, '''' reported that Lisanti referred to a legislative district in  as a \" district\" [thus in the original] in conversation with another Democratic legislator.  She was removed as the chair of a subcommittee. Two days later she was unanimously  by the House of Delegates in a 136-0 vote, but refused to resign her seat. On March 2, 2019, the Harford County Democratic Central Committee called for Lisanti to resign for using the racial slur.\n\n\nOn January 28, 2022, Lisanti entered the race for State Senate in District 34, seeking to succeed Senator , who announced his candidacy for  in April 2021. Lisanti lost the Democratic primary to .\n\n\n*'''2006 Primary Election Results Harford County Council – District F'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2006 General Election Results Harford County Council – District F'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2010 General Election Results Harford County Council – District F'''\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 Primary Election Results Maryland House of Delegates - District 34A - Harford County'''\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2014 General Election Results Maryland House of Delegates – District 34A - Harford County'''\n\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n\n*'''2018 Primary Election Results Maryland House of Delegates - District 34A - Harford County'''\n\n::'''Voters to choose two:'''\n:\n*'''2022 Primary Election Results Maryland Senate - District 34'''\n\n::'''Voters to choose one:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Glenn Frederick Ivey''' (born February 27, 1961) is an American politician and attorney serving as the  for  since 2023. The district covers most of the Black-majority areas on the Maryland side of the .\n\nA partner at the law firm of Ivey & Levetown, he served as the state's attorney for , from 2002 to 2011. Ivey won the 2022 Democratic primary for the 4th congressional district over , who previously represented the district for four terms, and then defeated the Republican nominee. According to the , his district is tied with  for the most Democratic in the country, with an index rating of D+40.\n\nIvey served on  as chief counsel to Senate majority leader , as counsel to U.S. senator  during the , as chief majority counsel to the , and on the staff of U.S. representative . He also worked for U.S. attorney  as an assistant U.S. attorney and as chair of the . He was twice elected  for Prince George's County, Maryland.\n\n\nIvey was born in , but grew up in , where much of his extended family lived and his mother worked as the first Black teacher at an all-white school. His immediate family later moved to , after his father got a job with the . Ivey graduated with honors from , where he earned an  degree in politics in 1983. In 1986, he received a J.D. degree from .\n\n\nAfter graduating from Harvard Law School in 1986, Ivey worked for the Baltimore law firm of Gordon-Feinblatt. From 1987 to 1988, he worked on Capitol Hill as an aide to U.S. representative , after which he returned to law, working for Preston, Gates, Ellis & Rouvelas.\n\nIn 1989, the  hired Ivey as an  in Washington, D.C. He worked for  . Afterward, Ivey returned to Capitol Hill to serve as majority counsel to  chairman . From 1995 to 1997, he served as the counsel for senator  during the Senate  and coordinated the Senate investigation into the suicide of . Eventually, Ivey served as chief counsel to Senate Democratic leader  until 1998.\n\nIn March 1998, Governor  named Ivey to serve as chairman of the . As chairman, Ivey oversaw the  and helped the PSC determine how to monitor telephone services and foster competition in the telecommunications industry. On October 18, 2000, Ivey announced that he would resign from the PSC by the end of the month to become a partner at the  law firm, and said he was contemplating a 2002 run for Prince George's county state's attorney.\n\nIvey ran for Prince George's county state's attorney in 2002, seeking to succeed outgoing state's attorney . In the primary, he was endorsed by U.S. representative , U.S. senator , and ''''. He defeated deputy state's attorney Mark Spencer in the primary with 60.0% of the vote. He ran unopposed in the general election.\n\nFollowing the end of his second term as state's attorney, Ivey became a partner at  before moving to a position as a partner at Leftwich & Ludaway, in Washington, D.C., from 2012 to 2017. Afterward, he was a partner at the District-based law firm Price Benowitz. In 2020, Ivey opened his own law firm, Ivey & Levetown, in .\n\nIvey taught trial advocacy at Harvard Law School during winter sessions from 2013 to 2021 and was an  at the  from 1995 to 2014. He is a past president of the D.C. chapter of the Harvard Law School Association, a former chair of the Maryland Legal Services Corporation, and a former member of the D.C. Bar Association's board of governors.\n\nIn July 2020, Prince George's county executive  appointed Ivey to serve as the chair of the county's police reform task force. During committee meetings, Ivey scrutinized policies surrounding , which experts say can enable racial profiling and precipitate a police shooting. The committee released its final report on December 3, which included recommendations relating to community engagement, employee hiring and retention, police department finances, internal oversight, and standards and regulations.\n\nIvey is a member of 's Board of Directors.\n\n\nIvey ran and was elected twice as state's attorney for Prince George's county and served from January 2003 to January 2011. In November 2009, he declined to run for Prince George's county executive or for a third term as state's attorney, instead forming an exploratory committee to look at challenging U.S. representative  in the 2010 elections. In January 2010, he decided against running for a third term or against Edwards, saying he wanted to return to the private sector after the end of his term.\n\nWhen Ivey took office in December 2002, Prince George's county had the second-highest crime rate in Maryland. During his two terms as state's attorney, he oversaw reductions in crime and led reform measures that put cameras in police interrogation rooms and prosecuted officers accused of excessive force. He sought to involve community groups in crafting policies and strategies for tackling crime in the county and partnered with faith leaders to assist domestic violence survivors and to gain tougher sentences for convicted offenders.\n\nIn October 2002, following the arrest of   and , Ivey declined to prosecute them in his county because of their murder convictions in both Maryland and Virginia.\n\nIn 2005,   said he considered Ivey as his running mate in the . Ivey declined, running for re-election instead.\n\nIn July 2008, Ivey's office faced intense public scrutiny to hold someone accountable following the strangulation death of 19-year-old Ronnie White, who was accused of killing a police officer. In December, the grand jury involved in the death investigation had concluded its deliberations, determining that it had insufficient evidence to bring down indictments in the case. After a yearlong investigation, Ivey announced that there was no evidence to support murder charges against jail employees. The  also reviewed the case and concluded that there was insufficient evidence to charge anyone with murder or manslaughter.\n\nIn August 2010, Ivey endorsed , the executive director of the Prince George's county revenue authority, to succeed him as Prince George's county state's attorney.\n\n\nIvey was sworn into the United States House of Representatives on January 3, 2023, succeeding .\n\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n** Subcommittee on Responsiveness and Accountability to Oversight\n* \n* \n\n\n\n* \n*  \n* Equality Caucus\n* Bipartisan HBCU Caucus\n* Bipartisan Artificial Intelligence Caucus\n* Caucus on Homelessness\n* Black Maternal Health Caucus\n* High Tech Caucus\n* Pro-Choice Caucus\n* \n* Second Chance Task Force\n* Democratic Faith Working Group\n* Substance Abuse / Mental Health Task Force\n* Gun Violence Prevention Task Force\n* Sustainable Energy and Environment Coalition\n\n\nIvey voted with President 's stated position 96.2% of the time in the .\n\nOn July 29, 2024, Ivey was announced as one of six Democratic members of a bipartisan task force investigating the .\n\n\n;2012\n\nIn October 2011, Ivey said through a spokesperson that he was considering a run for the  in , challenging the incumbent, . He declared his candidacy on November 3, but dropped out in January 2012, saying he could not raise enough money for his campaign.\n\n;2016\n\nIn September 2015, Ivey announced that he would again run for the House of Representatives in Maryland's 4th congressional district, seeking to succeed Edwards, who unsuccessfully ran for  in .\n\nDuring the primary, Ivey was endorsed by former  , Prince George's county executive , state senator , and many municipal leaders. He also led his competitors, including former Maryland lieutenant governor  and state delegate , in fundraising until the very end of the campaign.\n\nThe primary was held on April 26, 2016. Brown defeated Ivey, 41.6% to 34.0%, a margin of 8,712 votes out of 114,623 cast. Peña-Melnyk took 19.0%. Ivey worked as an attorney in private practice following his loss.\n\n;2022\n\nOn October 26, 2021, Ivey again declared his candidacy for the House of Representatives in Maryland's 4th congressional district, seeking to succeed outgoing Representative , who ran for  in .\n\nDuring the primary, he was endorsed by '''', former Maryland governor , former Prince George's county executive , former Montgomery county executive , and various municipal leaders. '''' called the race a proxy fight over . The United Democracy Project, a  established by the , spent $5.9 million on Ivey's campaign, while  spent $720,000 on former U.S. representative 's campaign. Ivey downplayed the help he received from AIPAC and its allies, telling ''The Post'' that while their support was \"extremely helpful\", voters in the district weren't especially concerned about Israel.\n\nIvey turned a 13-point deficit into a five-point lead over Edwards by early June, weeks before United Democracy Project began running TV ads on June 17.\n\nThe primary was held on July 19, 2022. Ivey defeated Edwards, 51.8% to 35.2%, a margin of 13,677 votes out of 82,662 cast. Former state delegate  took 5.7% of the vote.\n\nIvey won the general election on November 8, 2022, defeating Republican nominee Jeff Warner.\n\n\n\n\nWhen Ivey first took office as state's attorney in 2002, he said he believed in using the . He sought the death penalty several times during his tenure as state's attorney, and said in November 2007 that he filed notice of his intent to seek death in case about once a year.\n\nIn February 2009, Ivey testified before the ' Judicial Proceedings Committee that he had had a change of heart during his time as state's attorney, particularly because of the effect the process had on victims' families. In January 2012, he called the death penalty a \"political tool\". Ahead of the 2013 legislative session, Ivey pushed for a bill that would repeal the death penalty in Maryland, which became law.\n\n\nIn July 2022, an Ivey campaign aide told  that Ivey supported the  and a quick transition away from fossil fuels.\n\n\n\nIvey opposes the  negotiated by the  in 2015. In December 2021, he said he wanted a commitment to \"full and neutral inspections [of Iranian nuclear sites]\" and an end to Iran's funding of  and  before the U.S. reenters the deal.\n\n\nIn 2006, Ivey traveled to Israel with other local elected officials on a  trip. He took two trips between September 2023 and October 2024 organized by .\n\nIvey supports a  to the  and \"Israel's right to exist and defend itself\". In December 2021, he said he would vote to fund Israel's  missile-defense system and opposed placing conditions on U.S. foreign aid to Israel to leverage components of negotiations about a two-state solution.\n\nIvey opposes the  (BDS) movement against Israel.\n\nHe voted to provide Israel with support following .\n\nIvey received $807,215 in campaign contributions from pro-Israel sources.\n\n\nAs state's attorney, Ivey sought increased sentences for gun offenders, targeting those who carry or store guns illegally, regardless of whether the weapon is used in crimes or if the person charged is a first-time offender. He also said he supported the \"Boston Strategy\" for youth violence, which involves targeting gangs and prosecuting all offenders tied to a crime to get long sentences. In March 2008, Ivey joined an  brief in the  case '''' in support of the District of Columbia's  ban. In March 2010, he signed onto an amicus curae written by the  for the U.S. Supreme Court in ''''.\n\nIn December 2015, Ivey released a gun safety plan. Ivey's plan called for s and expanded gun dealership inspections, a ban on s and , and increased funding for the .\n\nIn April 2023, Ivey introduced his first bill, the Raise The Age Act, which would raise the legal age to buy a  or  from 18 to 21.\n\n\nIvey supports  and the legalization of . In June 2024, Ivey signed onto a Maryland Healthcare for All pledge to support legislation to extend -provided healthcare benefits beyond 2025.\n\n\nDuring his 2022 campaign, Ivey said he would seek to tie federal police funding to departments serious about rethinking policing tactics. He also said he would be willing to work with police to fight crime while \"holding accountable\" officers engaged in misconduct. He does not support the \"\" movement, arguing that it damaged Democrats electorally and served as a \"distraction\" from real issues.\n\n\nIn October 2012, Ivey appeared in an ad to support , a referendum to support the legalization of .\n\n\nIn November 2022, Ivey said he supported bringing the new  headquarters to Prince George's County, later citing it as one of his top priorities. In March 2023, Ivey joined other Democratic members of Maryland's congressional delegation, Governor , and Prince George's County Executive  in co-signing a letter to President  asking him to get involved in the FBI's headquarters selection process. In November 2023, the  announced that it would locate the FBI's new headquarters in .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n with two of his sons, including ]]\nIvey met his future wife, , through a mutual friend who attended Stephenson's high school and Ivey's law school. They have been married since 1988, have five childrenincluding Maryland delegate and live in . Ivey also has another daughter from a previous relationship. He is a .\n\nIn February 2004, Ivey took a leave of absence of several weeks to undergo surgery to remove a bean-sized   on his . His doctors told him that the cancer was detected early and his chances of a full recovery were good. He has been cancer-free since.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*   official U.S. House website\n*  campaign website\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John S. Arnick''' (November 27, 1933 – June 13, 2006) was an  from  and a member of the . He served in three separate spans of time as a member of the , representing Maryland's District 6 and District 7 in . He died in 2006 due to lung cancer.\n\n\nArnick graduated from  in .  He then attended and graduated from the  with his bachelor's degree.  He later returned to the University of Baltimore's School of Law and graduated with his LL.B. in 1961.\n\n\nAfter college Arnick served in the United States Marine Corps from 1956 until 1959.  After getting his law degree he was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 1962 and was a practicing attorney.\n\n\nJohn Arnick was first involved in politics in 1967 when he became a Magistrate at Large for .  The following year he was elected to office for the first time.  During his time in office he served as Majority Leader from 1971 until 1979 and again from 1978 until 1990.  Arnick also received the , Jr., Founder's Award from the House of Delegates in 2003.  Arnick resigned from the House of Delegates on April 30, 2006, in order to serve on the State Board of Contract Appeals.  He was appointed to that position by former Maryland Governor , but died soon afterward.\n\nHis political career stumbled a couple of times.  In 1978 he ran for a state senate position, but lost.  However, he ran for his House seat again in the next election cycle and won.\n\nIn 1993 he was nominated by former Maryland governor  to a 10-year District Court judge position.  However, he was forced to step down after he was charged with making sexist and racist jokes at a dinner in 1992.  According to ''The Washington Post'', he was well known for his \"salty language and flamboyant behaviour\".  At the time he had already resigned his seat in the House of Delegates as he had already taken his seat on the judicial bench and was waiting for senate approval.  Fortunately for him the Baltimore County Democratic Central Committee reappointed him back to his House Delegate seat.\n\nIn addition to being Majority Leader, Delegate Arnick served on many committees and caucuses including:\n\n*Environmental Matters Committee, 2003–06\n*Rules and Executive Nominations Committee, 1983–92, 1995-06\n*House Chair, Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, 2003–06\n*Joint Commission on the Maryland Port Administration, 2005–06\n*Legislative Policy Committee, 1969–79, 1987–92, 1994–2005\n*Chair, Environmental Matters Committee, 1972–79, 1987–90\n*House Chair, Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive and Legislative Review, 1983–86, 1995–2003\n*Economic Matters Committee, 1983–87\n*House Chair, Tort and Insurance Reform Oversight Committee, 1987–92\n*Special Joint Committee on Energy Pricing, 1990–91\n*Chair, Judiciary Committee, 1991–92\n*Commerce and Government Matters Committee, 1994–2003\n*Chair, House Facilities Committee, 1995–2005\n*Special Committee on Gaming, 2001\n*Chair, Baltimore County Delegation, 1969–70\n*Maryland Legislative Sportsmen's Caucus, 2001–06\n*Taxpayers Protection Caucus, 2003–06\n*Maryland Veterans Caucus, 2005–06\n*National Conference of State Legislatures\n\n\n\n*'''2002 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 6'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1998 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 7'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1994 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 7'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1990 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 7'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n*'''1986 Race for Maryland House of Delegates – District 7'''\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph M. Getty''' (born April 14, 1952) is the former chief judge of the . He was appointed as a judge of that court on June 27, 2016, by Governor . Effective September 11, 2021, Hogan appointed him as chief judge to replace  as she reached the mandatory retirement age of 70, an age Getty himself reached after seven months. He was succeeded by .\n\nGetty is a former Republican  and  representing 's . In February 2015, then-Senator Getty was appointed by Governor  to his cabinet, as legislative and policy director during his second term as senator. When Getty vacated his seat, he was replaced by former delegate, now Senator . Getty also served in former Governor 's cabinet in a similar capacity.\n\nJoe Getty is also a regular contributor to the ''Northern News'', which is a weekly newspaper that distributes to Hampstead, Manchester and Upperco, Maryland. He also previously served as the director of the Historical Society of Carroll County.\n\nHe is a graduate of the .\n\n\nIn 2012, Getty was appointed by Maryland legislative leaders to a task force to study the impact of a  ruling regarding the liability of owners of s and landlords that rent to them.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|years=2016–2021}}\n\n|-\n\n|years=2021–2022}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Victor R. Ramirez''' (born July 20, 1974) is a former state delegate and state senator for District 47 in . He was born in , , in 1974. His family soon after moved to the United States and he lived in .\n\n\nRamirez attended Mt. Rainier and Thomas S. Stone Elementary, Hyattsville Middle School, and graduated from Northwestern High School. He received his B.A. from  in 1996 and his J.D from St. Thomas School of Law in  in 2001.\n\n\nRamirez was admitted to the Maryland Bar in 2001 and began a practice in his own name. He was elected to the  in November 2002, becoming with , who was elected at the same time, the first  elected to the .\n\n\nRamirez was a member of House of Delegates from 2003 to 2011 and a member of the Joint Committee on Federal Relations and the Special Committee on Higher Education Affordability and Accessibility (2003–2004). Ramirez served as a member of the Ways and Means Committee (2003–2006) and the Ways and Mean's subcommittee on education (2003–2004).\n \n* Ramirez has a Chair on the Law Enforcement and State-Appointed Boards Committees.\n* Ramirez has served in the Prince George's County Delegation (from 2007 vice-chair, 2003–2006).\n* Ramirez is a Member of the Maryland Educators Caucus (from 2005) and the Maryland Veterans Caucus (from 2005).\n\nIn January 2007 he proposed a bill that would allow undocumented immigrants to attend public colleges and universities at the in-state tuition rate.\n\nIn 2010 Ramirez defeated the incumbent senator from district 47.\n\n\nDuring the 2008 democratic presidential primary, Ramirez endorsed the campaign of Illinois Senator  and was co-founder of Latinos for Obama in Maryland.\n\n\n* voted in favor of Maryland gas tax increase\n* voted for the Healthy Air Act in 2006 (SB154)\n* voted against slots in 2005 (HB1361)\n* voted in favor of in-state tuition for undocumented immigrants in 2007 (HB6)\n* voted in favor of the Tax Reform Act of 2007(HB2)\n\n\nRather than seek reelection to the Senate in 2018, Ramirez ran for Prince George's County state's attorney, losing in the Democratic primary with 27 percent of the vote total.\n\n\nRamirez announced in March 2021 that he would run for an open seat on the Prince George's County Council from district 2. He lost in the Democratic primary to , 50.9% to 44.8%.\n\n\n*2006 race for Maryland House of Delegates – 47th district\n::'''Voters to choose three:'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ivan Jules Bates''' (born September 1968) is an American politician and lawyer who has served as the  since 2023.\n\n\n\n\nBates was adopted by his parents, Henry and Cleora, in . Due to his father's service in the , his family moved several times, including to Germany, , and , before finally settling in , where Bates attended the segregated , where he graduated with a 1.9 GPA.\n\nAfter graduating from high school, his father enlisted him in the , where he was assigned to the  and worked as a light wheel vehicle mechanic before reaching the rank of private first class. He was honorably discharged from the Army in 1988.\n\nAfter leaving the military, he enrolled at , where he served as the second president of the Howard University Student Association before graduating with a  in journalism in 1992. Afterwards, he attended the , where he received his  degree in 1995. While at William & Mary, he clerked for the . After graduating, Bates wanted to move back to Los Angeles, California, but his mother asked him to move to Baltimore to take care of his aunt Edna.\n\n\nBates started his legal career in Baltimore, working as a law clerk for Baltimore Circuit Court Judge David B. Mitchell. He later worked in the homicide division of the Baltimore State's Attorney's Office under state's attorney  from July 1996 to June 2002. He left to become a defense attorney for the law firm of Schulman, Treem, Kaminkow, and Ravenell, and worked on the  case ''''.\n\nIn 2006, Bates started his own law firm of Bates & Garcia, P.C., in downtown Baltimore. He represented Baltimore Police sergeant , one of six police officers charged in the arrest and  in April 2015, and several clients victimized by the corrupt , whose members in 2017 were federally indicted and convicted of . In June 2019, Bates testified before the commission to Restore Trust in Policing, recommending a number of state laws to prevent corruption in Baltimore's criminal justice system.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn August 26, 2017, Bates announced his candidacy for state's attorney of Baltimore, challenging incumbent state's attorney . He ran on a platform of supporting  and curbing .\n\nDuring the campaign, Kristien Miller, a supporter of , filed a lawsuit against Bates alleging that he was not qualified to run for state's attorney. In March 2018, Baltimore Circuit Court Judge Lawrence Fletcher-Hill ruled that Bates had lived in the city since 2016 and was qualified to run for state's attorney.\n\nIn May 2018, Bates released a campaign ad in which he claimed that he had \"never lost a murder case\". He came under fire for this claim, as online court records show that Bates prosecuted eight murders and dropped five of them. Bates defended his claims by providing additional court records that list him as a prosecutor in homicide cases against Lynelle Whiting and Gregory Everett in 2001 and 2002 respectively. In June, he released a list of 11 more cases he claimed as \"wins\", four of which had ended in convictions. He later threatened to sue the two other candidates in the race, Vignarajah and Mosby, and the '''' newspaper for , calling the claims made by the candidates related to his murder cases were \"absolute lies\".\n\nAlso in May 2018, Bates told the '''' that he would drop charges against , the '''' podcast host who was serving life in prison for his initial conviction in the  in 1999.\n\nBates was defeated in the Democratic primary on June 26, 2018, placing second behind Mosby with 28.1 percent of the vote.\n\n\nOn November 18, 2021, Bates announced that he would again run for state's attorney, challenging incumbent state's attorney Marilyn Mosby.\n\nBates supports improving the technology used in the state's attorney's office, including s that would add subtitles to  videos. He unveiled a prosecution plan in March 2022, which includes cracking down on gun violence and restarting prosecutions for nonviolent crimes such as , prostitution, and , promising mandatory prison sentences for people convicted on gun charges. He also sought to increase collaboration with the  to reduce violent crime. He stressed during the campaign that these policies did not mean the city would be returning to a tough-on-crime mindset that leads to mass incarceration, with many cases being funneled to diversion courts to connect people with alternative treatment services.\n\nDuring the primary, Bates received endorsements from ''The Baltimore Sun'', former  , former mayoral candidate , Maryland Senate President , state delegate , and former state's attorney Greg Bernstein.\n\nBates defeated incumbent state's attorney Marilyn Mosby and Democratic challenger  in the Democratic primary on July 19, 2022, receiving 40.9 percent of the vote. Bates was to face  candidate Roya Hanna in the general election, but she dropped out and endorsed Bates shortly after his primary win, clearing his path to victory.\n\n\nBates was sworn in as state's attorney on January 3, 2023. On his first day in office, he reversed Mosby's non-prosecution policy for low-level offenses like drug possession, prostitution, and trespassing.\n\nIn July 2022, Bates told '''' that he planned to drop the controversial case against , who was scheduled for a fifth murder trial in the fatal shooting of  security guard Kevin Jones in 2015. He declined to comment on the case after winning the Democratic primary, saying that \"[a]s State's Attorney-elect, I am no longer a private citizen. I must be mindful of the gag order imposed to the current State's Attorney and how it would ethically apply to me\". On January 13, 2023, Bates ended the State's Attorney's office's prosecution of Davis, dropping all charges against him.\n\n signs Bates' gun sentencing bill, 2023]]\nDuring the 2023 legislative session, Bates endorsed a bill to increase maximum sentences from three years to five years for people who illegally carry handguns, arguing that it would \"ensure fairness under the law and serve as a deterrent\". The bill was supported by all elected state's attorneys in Maryland, and opposed by the  of Maryland, faculty of Baltimore law schools, and the , who cited research from  which showed that longer sentences did not deter crime. The bill was later incorporated into the Gun Safety Bill of 2023, which was passed by the  in April, and signed into law by Governor  in May 2023. In March 2023, Bates endorsed an anti-crime package introduced by the , which included bills strengthening penalties for gun theft and repeat violent offenses.\n\nIn July 2023, amid a  that killed two and injured 28, Bates released a statement expressing his condolences and calling for gun control and policies targeting repeat violent offenders.\n\nDuring the 2024 legislative session, Bates supported legislation to extend probationary periods for gun crimes committed by juveniles, limit the Child Interrogation Protection Act, and allow state's attorneys to file a motion to modify an incarcerated individual's sentence \"at any time\".\n\n\nBates has two daughters named Brielle and London. He lives in the  community of Baltimore.\n\nIn 2021, Bates' third wife, Lana, filed for a divorce.\n\nHours before Bates was sworn in as State's Attorney of Baltimore, he was hospitalized and treated for dehydration. Despite this, his swearing-in went as planned.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
